column2: Last week the Treasury received a small fraction of the total payment due from eleven European nations on their war debts. It could have expected nothing more. It has long been evident that France, which "deferred" one payment due a year ago and another due last June, would follow the same procedure at the present date.

WAYNESVILLE, N.C., Dec. 16 (AP). -- Three mountaineers, charged with killing Thomas Price, philanthropist and retired railroad executive, were convicted tonight of second degree murder by a jury in Haywood Superior Court.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15. -- The chief producing regions have now com- pleted their State grain deliveries, with the result that "free trade" in foodstuffs by collectivized and individual farmers is allowed. Such regions include the North Caucasus, five out of seven Ukrainian Prov- inces, the Tartar Republic, the Crimea, Bashkir, Moldavian and Armenian Republics, and the Prov- inces of Moscow, Leningrad, Nizhni-Novgorod, Ivanovo and the Middle Volga.

COLUMBIA, Tenn., Dec. 16 (AP). -- Investigators learned today that Cord Cheek, an 18-year-old Negro, lynched near here last night, had been abducted from the home of relatives in Nashville soon after his release from jail upon the grand jury's failure to indict him in connection with an alleged attempted attack on a young white girl.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16. -- The Bureau of Student Employment of Princeton University provided 2,014 jobs for 753 Princeton undergraduates last year, according to statistics released today by William B. Van Alystyne Jr. and Richard W. Warfield of the Department of Personnel.

Business activity in the metropolitan area continued to forge ahead during the week, nearly 50 per cent of the companies replying to the questionnaire of the New York Credit Men's Association indicating an increase in sales. About 30 per cent reported no change and the remainder mentioned decreases.

A resolution addressed to President Roosevelt and the two Senators from New York State, asking them to sponsor the Costigan AntiLynching Bill, was adopted at a luncheon meeting of the League for Industrial Democracy at the Town Hall Club yesterday.

Several important deals by operators and others during the past three months indicate a steady and genuine improvement in real estate conditions, points out Samuel Field, vice president of the firm of Adams Co.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Marked Increases in the construction field are the only exception to continued minor changes in productive activity throughout the United States, according to the weekly survey of business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

PELE, the volcanic goddess who sleeps beneath the Hawaiian chain of islands, who pushed them up in the beginning from a mile-deep ocean bed, who built Mauna Loa and Manna Kea as twin peaks higher then any other in the Pacific, who still keeps her kettles stewing in the most unstable spot on earth down at the end of the islands, is stirring from her slumber.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 16. -- Eugene Goossens, director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, will give the world premiere of Emerson Whithorne's First Symphony on Jan. 12 in this city. Mr. Whithorne's orchestral work "Moon Trail" was performed this week for the first time by the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Boston under the direction of Serge Koussevitzky.

THERE are some things that can never be satisfactorily explained. One of them is why, at a time when quite ordinary novels are being sold for $2 a copy, an extraordinary autobiography like this can be bought for fourteen bits ($1.75 to you).

Mrs. Payne Whitney's First Minstrel, winner of the Junior Champion Stakes, is placed at the top of the 2-year-olds of 1933 by the Jockey Club handicapper, Walter S. Vosburgh. The announcement was made yesterday in the Racing Calendar, official organ of the Jockey Club, and is the first step of this kind since the Jockey Club was organized in 1894.

The celebration of Christmas will be begun today in virtually all the churches. In the church calendar it is the third Sunday in Advent. There will be Christmas oratorios, Christmas pageants, Christmas cantatas, manger services with processions, "candle-light" and carol services, and in some places the carols will also be sung in the streets.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 14. -- A combination of circumstances has changed the lot of North Carolina tobacco farmers from that of least favored citizens at the beginning or the marketing season in August to that of the most favored class as the marketing season nears its end.
LONDON, Dec. 16. -- Postmaster General Farley said today that he was not in the least afraid that the controversy over the monetary policy would divide the Democratic party.

The largest order for equipment which has been authorized in many years and the only major order of its kind to have been made since the onset of the depression in 1929 was disclosed yesterday through inquiries by the Van Sweringen railroads in the East for rolling stock worth $25,000,000.

To the Drama Editor: In a recent issue of a newspaper there appeared an article entitled "National Theatre Plan to Be Told F.D." This article goes on to state that a dream for a national theatre has been given to the first lady of the land by an English actress who is active in the theatrical field in New York.
THE Federal Government should help support our public school system for the following reasons:

DESPITE predictions to the contrary, as the year draws to an end, the comedian is still on the air and there seems little likelihood of the radio funny fellow's early demise. Beginning Jan. 3, Jack Pearl will be the aerial envoy of another sponsor, succeeding Bert Lahr on Wednesday nights at 8 o'clock.

Every phase of offensive and defensive football was rehearsed yesterday by Columbia as it went through its longest and most strenuous workout at the 105th Field Artillery Armory in preparation for the Rose Bowl battle with Stanford in Pasadena, Calif., Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A 5 percent wage increase was granted to the American Federation of FullFashioned Hosiery Workers today by the National Labor Board in an arbitration award filed by Senator Robert F. Wagner, chairman of the board.

BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- Three were known dead today, four were missing and nineteen were saved after the 104-foot Boston fishing schooner Ellen T. Marshall caught fire last night, burned to the water's edge and sank in a northeast blizzard off Cape Sable, N.S.

THOMAS JESSE JONES, the educational director of the Phelps-Stokes Fund, is to be thanked not only for his own reply to the question, "What is education?", but also for recalling the classic answer of THOMAS HUXLEY, made sixty-five years ago in an address at the South London Working Men's College:

With foreign exchanges confined to a narrow radius, the domestic markets had to depend yesterday for their inspiration upon developments of a more or less negative character. Nowhere was there any demonstration that indicated any marked recovery of speculative confidence.

An application for summary judgment for $88,587 in the suit by James E. Finegan as a taxpayer to recover increases of salary voted to city officials in the "salary grab" law passed by the Board of Estimate a few weeks after the municipal election of 1929, will be made to Supreme Court Justice Levy on Friday.

THE "thinking machine" exhibited last week by Norman B. Krim of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology before a section of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at Cambridge, Mass., deserved all the publicity that it received.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City is thinking of becoming a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator at the primary election next Spring, it was reported yesterday in New Jersey political circles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Well, they're calling a clinic in Washington early next month to go over the case of my sick Uncle. Specialists from every State in the Union will be there. The family doctor will have charge, which is about the only hopeful thing I can say for the whole business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Higher income taxes on private banking partnerships such as those of J.P. Morgan Co. and lower rates on small businesses were proposed today before the House Ways and Means Committee as a means of preventing huge tax savings by financiers.

NOT unlike the ancient alchemists who sought some occult formula for transmuting base metals into gold, playwrights of this later day have long sought the infallible method of turning novels into successful plays.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16. -- Under a strong ride by Lester Balaski, Nyack, owned and trained by Frank Seremba, won by a head at 3 to 5 in the featured race at Jefferson Park today. The 5-year-old gelding by Noah from Paradox had been second in his three starts here before today.

The executive committee for the annual Beaux-Arts Ball, which is customarily the climaxing entertainment of each Winter season in New York, is now at work planning a fete that is expected to be one of the most elaborate even produced by this committee of artists and architects.

HANS LANGE, assistant conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony, will direct his first concert of the season with the orchestra Thursday night. C.P.E. Bach's sinfonia No. 3 for string orchestra and cembalo will be played for the first time by the Philharmonic on this occasion.

BELGRADE, Dec. 15. -- In the Balkans more than anywhere else in Europe, skepticism is the pre- vailing attitude toward the ex- change of ceremonial royal visits as harbingers of a new era of peace. Even allowing for all doubts, it is nonetheless predicted that this week's visit of King Boris of Bulgaria to King Alexander of Yugoslavia marks the beginning of a change in the relations of these traditionally unfriendly nations.

ISTANBUL, Dec. 2. -- About eigh- teen months ago the Swiss Govern- ment, in response to an invitation received from the Turkish Govern- ment, sent Professor Malche to Is- tanbul to advise the Minister of Public Instruction on the reform of the university.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Sweeping pay cuts for clergy and church employees in Vatican City and Rome were ordered today by Pope Pius. Those who receive salaries of from $85 to $170 monthly are to receive 10 per cent less after Jan. 1, and those who receive more than $170 monthly are to get a 15 per cent reduction.

LONDON. DICTIONARIES are not commonly thought of as a stimulus to festivity, but the completion of the great Oxford English dictionary has been celebrated by a luncheon. The repast was spread in the hall of the ancient Goldsmiths' Company, which contributed u5.000 to the cost of the work, and the list of guests included many distinguished names.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to make a comment or two on one point in the article by Norman R. Gibson, "The Power Debate," which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 10.

BREMERTON, Wash., Dec. 16. -- Christened by a descendant of one of the founders of the Oregon town whose name it bears, the United States Navy's 10,000-ton cruiser Astoria was launched in the Puget Sound Navy Yard here today.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 16. -- Captain Norman Murray Smith, public works officer at the Boston Navy Yard, was appointed today chief of the Bureau of Yards and Docks at the Navy Department with the rank of Rear Admiral. He will succeed Read Admiral Archibald L. Parsons who will retire as chief of the bureau on Dec. 23.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16. -- For the first time in its history the Soviet Union has completed its State grain "collections" before the end of the year -- specifically, by Dec. 14, which is two and a half months earlier than ever before.

BOSTON, Dec. 14. -- Five agencies are now at work in Massachusetts on the related problems of curbing crime, expediting court processes and promoting justice. Never before has there been so formidable an attack upon a condition that is fast becoming intolerable and yet has persisted so long as to seem almost incurable and with which, for various reasons, the profession immediately interested appears unable to deal.

Unique among forthcoming events for philanthropy and one that appeals to mankind in general but to women in particular, is the series of lectures entitled "What Is Charm?" arranged in behalf of Mulberry Community House. The lectures will be held during the noon hour in the ballroom of Sherry's, Jan. 2, 4, 9 and 11.

Hint From Titipu. Ko-Ko -- Uncle Sam, what do you think? My dear old aunt in Trenton has sent me a nice new hundred-dollar bill for Christmas, and I want to consult you as to how can I most advantageously spend it so as to promote national recovery.

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- Paris has seized upon a new idea (believed to have originated in New York) for the presentation of corsets and lingerie. These foundation garments are shown under evening gowns of a cellulose material which feature all the latest lines and style points.

Miss Rosamond F. Murray of Brooklyn confirmed her position as the peerless junior equestrienne of the Eastern United States last night when she won the championship in horsemanship at the Second Annual Brooklyn Junior Horse Show.

IN his latest book Professor Fisher continues to attack the major symptoms of the depression malady: debt and the "dishonest" dollar. Of the two the latter is the more dangerous, for under a falling price level the attempt to liquidate debts by paying with swollen dollars really increases the unpaid balances.

LONDON, Dec. 1. NEWS of Bernard Shaw's work has a habit of travelingfast. The substance of his new play, "On the Rocks," is already known in America, and I need not now add an elaborate discussion of it to the cable sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES within an hour of the curtain's fall.

TOKYO, Dec. 16 (AP). -- All Japan is anxiously awaiting the gokeiji, "the honorably auspicious event," the birth of a baby to the Emperor and Empress, which physicians of the Imperial Court have announced may be expected before the New Year.

WASHINGTON. THE retirement of George N. Peek as Administrator of the Agricultural Adjustment Act has thrown a spotlight on the Federal Government's seven-months' campaign to pull the farmer out of the hole in which he has been struggling since 1928.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The special correspondence from Teheran published in THE TIMES of Dec. 10 was a great surprise to me.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Those who during the past fifteen years have watched the efforts of successive British Governments to try to get France and Germany to come to an agreement, firstly, about reparations and, secondly, about disarmament and all the other minor questions involved in it, have begun to wonder if the British method is the right one.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 13. -- Although Oregon's special session of the Legislature has retired into the pages of history after having accomplished the two-fold purpose for which Governor Meier called it -- enactment of a liquor control bill and legislation for relief funds -- the question now bothering the citizens is "how much of it will take."
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 16. -- Trinity easily defeated the New York Aggies tonight in its opening basketball game, 39 to 16. Martens led in scoring with 14 points, while Daut had 10.

MYSTERY story addicts are numbered among the most vehement of American fans, and Rufus King is a name with which most of them are very well acquainted. Murder is the very special subject of this writer, a mild-mannered young man, of whom the purveyorship of mayhem and homicide would never be suspected.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Reconsideration by the Mixed Claims Commission of the Black Tom and Kingsland sabotage cases on charges of fraud, collusion and suppression of evidence by witnesses presented on behalf of Germany has been directed by the umpire, Owen J. Roberts, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.

When Manufacturers Disagree. AUTOMOBILES won't look so much alike next year. The two pictures above indicate something of the difference that is likely to appear. The top photograph shows a really streamlined car.

THIS book of poems, beautifully printed and illustrated with some fine wood engravings, is, in good part, a reprint of Mr. Doro's poems first published by the poet himself about two years ago in Paris. But to this first American edition several poems have been added and they make all the difference.

PARIS. AT about this point in the season hard-working elegantes take some time off from social duties to look to the reinforceing of weakening wardrobes, so as not to be caught unawares by Christmas or pre-holiday festivities.
The metropolitan indoor polo season opened last night at the Squadron C Armory with the first division of Fort Hamilton outriding the Squadron C trio to win, 12 to 4 1/2 in a Class B contest.
Although prices improved in Liverpool, quotations on the Cotton Exchange here moved lower yesterday and closed at the bottom with losses of 7 to 12 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Senate, when advised today of a coalition of his opponents at home against his mission to seek better independence legislation, authorized the following statement:

Young women headed by Miss Mary Schuyler Schieffelin will sell flowers and cigarettes and will act as ushers at the performance of "As Thousands Cheer," Friday night at the Music Box Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for the Manhattanville Nursery Association and the Third Street Music School Settlement.

BIOGRAPHICAL studies of D. H. Lawrence, with perhaps some critical glance at his literary work, have been numerous; books purely critical, with a minimum of biographical reference, less so. This rather small volume by Horace Gregory, is, from first page to last, entirely critical, a study not of the man but of his works; and although the two cannot be absolutely sundered, there is here nearly as complete a separation as is possible.

OUT in the wide open spaces which have long been America's boast some 2,000 schools recently echoing childish voices stand silent and disused. Thousands of children in Kansas, Arkansas and Louisiana, for instance, have no choice whether to learn or play truant.
PARIS, Dec. 8. -- French difficul- ties with the English language are proverbial, but the Academy dic- tionary in its latest edition is en- deavoring to set an example of exactitude.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 16. -- With its regulars playing only during the greater part of the first half of the game, the Dartmouth basket ball team overwhelmed Harvard tonight, 54 -- 20. This was the Crimson's initial appearance in the Eastern Intercollegiate League since 1908.

BERLIN, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Bishop Joachim Hossenfelder of Brandenburg and other extreme leaders of the Nazi German Christian movement resigned from it tonight after a hot all-day session attended by German Christian leaders from all parts of Germany.

IT is natural in great national controversies for both the opposing parties to appeal to history. Each reads into it, as Lincoln in his second inaugural said both North and South read into the Bible, its own passionate convictions and aspirations.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Dec. 17. -- Following the receipt of detailed reports that fighting has broken out on the southern borders of Chekiang Province between the Fukien rebels and government forces, General Lu Ti-ping, Chekiang's Governor, has left Hangchow to speed to the front.

The inordinately high income surtax rates imposed by the Revenue Act of 1932, at present effective, and the unreasonable potential responsibilities placed by the Securities Act upon persons venturing to raise capital for new business undertakings, appear to be two of the predominant factors having the effect of hindering industrial recovery.

The New York Rangers will tackle the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The rivalry that has always existed between these teams, coupled with the exciting brand of hockey they invariably display, should attract a large crowd to witness the struggle, the first between them this season on local ice.

Discussing recently some phases of the difficult problem of fixing genuine real estate values, Arthur J. Mertzke, economist to the Federal Loan Bank Board, pointed out that the cost of replacement minus depreciation was the real basic test of home values.

The new supply of crude oil in October averaged 2,514,000 barrels daily, the largest for that month since 1930, and 14.5 per cent above the 2,195,000 barrels in October last year, according to William J. Kemnitzer, from data of the United States Bureau of Mines.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 16. -- Martin Finn's Gloritone scored her first West Virginia victory in the featured Monumental City Purse at Charles Town today. The 3-year-old daughter of The Porter and Slow and Easy led home a field of five over the mile and a sixteenth route.

THE Patent Office in Washington is not the only place where schemes are registered and hopes marked with a serial number. Hollywood, too, has become a Mecca for the crackbrain and the intellectual hasheesh eater. A regiment of massive minds daily besieges the various studio gates with the "idea of the century" and the smashing plan for producing a cinema epic.

Fencing, from the women's angle, will begin in earnest next month. During the past week the Manrique novice tournament was staged, but the season for the metropolitan district actually gets under way with the Voorhees competition at the Fencers Club on Jan. 10.
William Sloane Coffin, president of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died suddenly yesterday at his home, 333 East Sixty-eighth Street. He was in his fifty-fifth year.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 16 (AP). -- For the first time since the Epsom Downs meeting opened on Nov. 30, Jack Westrope, the country's leading jockey, was shut out today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 16. -- In compliment to their house guest, Bruno Graf of Berlin, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Henry Kroger gave a dinner tonight at Villa Sueno.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- Governor Lehman dismissed today the charges brought by Fritz Brieger for the removal of George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, and also denied the request of the Society for the Prevention of Crime for an extraordinary grand jury to prosecute John Theofel and Judge John Hetherington for alleged violations pf civil service and penal laws.

TRIESTE is a city that waits. A seaport town, handsomely built around the shores of a placid bay, she lies in the extreme northeast corner of the Adriatic, has 250,000 inhabitants and is known by name the world over as the headquarters and point of departure of more than one wellknown line of steamships to the Americas and the Far East.

A plan for the creation of a board to work out a long-time program for a new and more comprehensive air defense program was revealed here yesterday. An organization known as the Air Defense League, of which Colonel Samuel Price Wetherill Jr. of Philadelphia is president and Jay Cooke vice president, has been formed with branches in New York and other cities.

The annual Christmas Festival of the People's Chorus will take place this afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Several young women of society headed by the Misses Margaret Prentiss, Ella Milbank and Helen and Marion Hope have been aiding in the plans for the festival, which will present a varied program of early and modern Christmas music.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 16. -- Displaying a return to the form which took him to the National P. G.A. title two seasons ago, Olin Dutra of Santa Monica stepped into the lead in the California open golf championship today.

For many years the Mount Holyoke College Glee Club has distinguished itself for the dignity and beauty of its programs and the musicianship with which they are delivered. Last night's concert of the club, given at the Town Hall and devoted to Christmas carols, was no exception.

THREE years after the completion of his first memorable volume Dr. Waxman presents the second of his projected three-volume history of Jewish literature from the close of the Bible to our own day. Not since the labors of Zung, Graetz and Steinschneider have we had so ambitious an undertaking.
PARIS, Dec. 15. -- Shakespeare is being accused of mixing into pres- ent-day French politics and several Deputies have announced they will question the government about it.

The final engagements for the senior high dual meet swimming championship of the Public Schools Athletic League yesterday left De Witt Clinton and Evander Childs locked for the lead in the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond group and Erasmus Hall and Par Rockaway in possession of the Brooklyn and Queens titles.

While the curtailment program undertaken by the cotton-textile industry for this month has resulted in increasing costs to varying degrees, mills are absorbing these extra expenses, according to statements made yesterday by leaders in the industry.

PARIS, Dec. 16. -- Premier Mussolini's suggestion that the League of Nations should be re-formed met with the answer from France, Poland and the Little Entente today that the fundamentals of the League must not be tampered with. The Italian leader had asked changes to permit the entrance of Germany into international disarmament discussions.

Twenty million pounds or foodstuffs, including butter, cheese, beans, flour and pork, will be distributed monthly in New York State this Winter as part of the Federal relief program, it was announced yesterday. Eggs probably will be included also.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have sat patiently suffering through many a radio program, and at last I am moved to utter a protest, which I hope may be timely.

Evangeline Booth, commander-inchief of the Salvation Army, will soon set out on a globe encircling tour of 30,000 mlies, which will take her to the principal cities of Near Zealand and Australia, where she will attend the territorial congresses of the Army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Senator Copeland described virtually to President Roosevelt today plans for a complete revision of the criminal statutes, involving about thirty pieces of legislation, of which, twenty-one have been written, as a result of the crime survey made by a special Senate committee.

The Federal Surplus Relief Corporation, empowered to superintend the purchase of the millions of dollars worth of clothing and food for the needy this Winter, will ask for samples and prices on all types of products within the next two weeks, it was learend here yesterday.

More than 200 social, civic and political leaders attended a "Prohibition Repeal Dinner," held last night at the Manhattan Club, Madison Avenue at Twenty-sixth Street. The dinner was arranged by a committee of forty headed by Morgan J. O'Brien, former Chief Justice of the Appellate Division, who presided.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- Christmas shopping reached its flood tide this week, with estimates placing the dollar turnover by the various large stores at from 15 to 30 per cent above last year. Sales of toys are the best in several years. Medium-priced items continue to lead, but several of the stores report a noticeable gain in sales of better-grade jewelry.

RUSSIAN recognition having cleared the way for rebroadcasts to the United States from Moscow and other centres of the Soviet, the broadcasters are confronted with a queer technical puzzle. It seems that the radio waves from Russia in following the Great Circle route to America flash too close to the magnetic pole in this side of the sea, and that means an abundance of static bombards the program.

Although the RFC has offered for fourteen successive days to buy newly mined gold at $34.01 an ounce, the price of scrap gold, as fixed by the leading dealers in John Street, has fallen to $22.80 an ounce, scarcely more than $2 an ounce above the old statutory value of gold still paid by the United States Assay Office, which is $20.67 an ounce.

LANCASTER, N.H., Dec. 16. -- A Girl Scout swung an axe on a sixfoot fir tree here this morning, and a few minutes later she and three other members of White Mountain Troop of Girl Scouts were carrying from the woods the personal Christmas tree of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.
ROLAND YOUNG, who collects penguins When he is not engaged in his usual business of being amiable, is to be glimpsed in company with Lillian Gish at the Paramount this week in "His Double Life."

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York asked President Roosevelt yesterday to order the continued operation of the Coast Guard as an independent service and to maintain it at its present standard of efficiency. The President is considering a proposal for its amalgamation with the Navy Department in his program of coordination of Federal departments.

PARIS, Dec. 16. -- While London and Berlin are discussing, apparently with mutual satisfaction, a possible basis on which armament limitation discussions can be renewed. Paris seems to be exploring many other possibilities than those of reaching agreement with Germany.

Price movements on local commodities exchanges were restricted yesterday to a narrow range, with the trend irregularly lower. Trading was quiet, with only a few dealings reported in each commodity. Cash prices were lower. Silver futures opened 5 points higher to 25 points lower and closed 7 to 30 points higher in sales of 1,550,000 ounces.

THE relief ship for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police post on Ellesmere Land nosed its way around the eastern cape of Craig Harbor and came to anchor under a bluff streaked with snow, over which the wind poured from the ice cap above, driving before it a white, frozen spume.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Treasury Department's investigation of the alleged dumping of Canadian newsprint in the United States at unfair prices, will be broad and may take several months, officials of the Customs Bureau said today.

ANOTHER instance of the good sense of employing an author to write the cinematic adaptation of his own train child is the film of Elmer Rice's clever play, "Counsellor-at-Law," which last week delighted audiences at that Radio City Music Hall.

The social and economic projects undertaken by the national administration are "blazing new trails" toward a permanent solution of the nation's problems, Dr. Leon C. Marshall, Director of the Institute of Public Law of Johns Hopkins University, declares in a survey on "Unemployment Relief and Public Works," issued yesterday by Teachers College, Columbia University.

In the death of Richard J. Glendon, Columbia, rowing and sport in general lost one of their most distinctive characters. The younger Glendon made a very definite contribution to the ancient sport of rowing distinct and apart from carrying on in the shoes of his father.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Those who set consistency above all other virtues, and think it the most valuable attribute of statesmanship, are having the time of their lives in Washington these days. They can point to this thing said and the other thing done in innumerable instances, and to policy directions reversed without a moment's notice.

OTTAWA, Dec. 14. -- An optimistic review of the Canadian mining industry has been given by W.A. Gordon, Minister of Mines in the Dominion Government, who follows his general conclusions with a detailed analysis of production and prospects.

PAINTINGS by Walter Griffin, the first New York exhibition of this artist in several years, are being shown at the Buffa Galleries, 58 West Fifty-seventh Street. These warm-hued French and Italian landscapes are romantic, somewhat impressionistic, and are imbued with a dreamy quality reminiscent of cathedral towns, cloistered peace, tapestries and stained glass.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- Willard Spenser, composer of "The Little Tycoon" and other comic operas, died of heart disease today at his home in St. David's, after an illness of four months. He was in his eighty-second year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The thirtieth, anniversary of the first flight in a heavier-than-air machine was celebrated today in a spectacular demonstration by army, navy and marine fliers, and for the most part under the same threatening conditions that faced the Wright brothers, Wilbur and Orville, during their experiments on the Kill Devil sand dunes.

The foot of a mouse, an insect's eye, particles of atmospheric dirt, a newly hatched squid and crystallized asparagus juice were some of the exhibits that 1,200 New Yorkers inspected through microscopes last night at the exhibition of the New York Microscopical Society.

A variety of furnishings and objects of art will be offered for sale at auctions here this week. On Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons, the Rains Auction Rooms will sell the collection of David A. Bernstein of New York and Old Greenwich, Conn., including eighteenth century English and American furniture,. Lowestoft China, glass, blue Staffordshire and other English china, and other Jots.

NEW YORK. Miss Eleanor Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Gould, and Ludrow Whitaker Stevens, who are to be married on Jan. 19 in the chantry of St. Thomas Church, were honored by Carroll L. Wainwright at a small reception last night in his home, 7 Mitchell Place.

The final recital in the series of Sunday evening recitals for the benefit of Christodora House Music School will take place tonight in the concert hall of Christodora House in Tompkins Square, Ninth Street and Avenue B. The artists will be members of the Morgan Trio, and Mark H. Haight, who will present his romance travelogue, "The Romance of the English Inn," with colored stereoptican and motion pictures.

ON the 24th of December Enrique Fernandez Arbos celebrates his seventieth birthday. As violin virtuoso, teacher and conductor he has been signally honored in many lands, and it is significant that, in spite of revolution, every succeeding government or Cabinet in Spain has been well disposed toward the activities of Arbos and of the Symphonic Orchestra of Madrid, which, with intervening tours and appearances as "'guest" leader in many lands, he has conducted Since 1904.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Federal Government today started a $199,000 income-tax suit against Samuel Insull, fugitive utilities man.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 16. -- The Nassau County Philharmonic Society will give a series of holiday teas and musicales to raise funds for the resumption of the Spring concerts, President James N. Gehrig announced today. The concerts will be held at the Rivoli Theatre, Hempstead.

THAT plan at Twentieth Century to present Fredric March as the Jean Valjean of a contemplated produce tion of Hugo's "Les Miserables" has been abandoned in favor of "The Affairs of Cellini," in which Mr. March will be the star.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation moved again today to bring relief to New York financial institutions when it agreed to provide $3,500,000 of Federal funds to rehabilitate the Globe Rutgers Fire Insurance Company, under conditions which would furnish other capital to the company.

OF the nine writers whom Mr. Rascoe calls "Prometheans." only two -- Friedrich Nietzsche and D.H. Lawrence can fairly be said to have something of the attributes of the prophet and rebel; and Mr. Rascoe, as it happens, does not emphasize their heroic strain.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra began one of its seasonal activities yesterday morning in Carnegie Hall and ended another there in the evening. Ernest Schelling conducted the first of the orchestra's eleventh year of Children's Concerts in the morning, and Bruno Walter directed his final concert at the students' series in the evening.

THE advent of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe, whose first American appearance is to be made this week, brings once more into circulation hereabout the phrase "Russian ballet," a phrase which some twenty-four years ago began to be part of the vernacular.

The Liquor Situation. The State Alcoholic Liquor Control Board modified its ruling that restaurants to be eligible for a license must have been in business on the same premises for a year prior to filing an application.

Louis I. Harris, former Health Commissioner, retorted sharply yesterday to the criticism of the department made in Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne's statement on Friday announcing his retirement. Dr. Wynne said he found the department demoralized five years ago when he assumed office.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16. -- Harvard's varsity wrestling team opened its season with a 21-to-11 victory over M.I.T. today. Harvard also prevailed in the freshman meet, 26 -- 10.

THE protection of New York Harbor against the dumping of garbage again came into the news recently when the Supreme Court granted the city until July 1 to complete its incinerator system and to cease dumping waste at sea off the New Jersey coast.

BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- If a German does not read some newspaper, and if, as a result, he suffers damage or neglects to do some act to his own advantage, it is his own fault and no responsibility rests on any third person, for it is the duty of every one to read a paper.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 13. -- Puerto Rico is about equally divided on the question "Is Governor Robert H. Gore returning?"

Moscow. IF you ring the bell four times, Sergei Eisenstein, whose name is synonymous with Soviet cinema, will himself come to the door to let you in. He will invite you into a typical Moscow flat in which live several families, where he occupies one fair-sized room.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- One more starting pitcher and probably an outfielder will be the only additions of the 1934 edition of the New York Yankees, Manager Joe McCarthy said today on his return from the major league baseball meeting in Chicago.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 16. -- Lovers of George Santayana gathered informally at Amherst College today to celebrate the poet-philosopher's 70th birthday. Referring to Santayana as "the most significant and effective restater of the standpoint of Greek moral philosophy since the death of Matthew Arnold," Professor Sterling P. Lampreeht, head of the Amherst Philosophy Department, presented the philosopher's conception of a happy union between those two inevitable forces of human existence, the intellect and the passions.

Without any special reason that Wall Street could assign, speculative operations for the advance of prices of stocks seemed yesterday to have been suddenly abandoned. That was the explanation which many brokers offered for the extension of the decline on the Stock Exchange.

WHEN President Roosevelt appointed Joseph H. Choate Jr. to be chairman of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration he once more emphasized the unconventional methods which have marked his actions since he first took office.

BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- Eddie Shore, Boston hockey Star, today told Managing Director Frank Patrick of the National Hockey League, that he was partly dazed from a hard fall when he collided with Irvin (Ace) Bailey, Toronto player, now hovering between life and death at the City Hospital after a delicate brain operation.

The wild-water fowl crisis in the United States and Canada will be discussed thoroughly at the annual session of the American Game Conference, which will be held in this city late next month. The tentative program, issued by the American Game Association, sponsors of the conference, shows that one full day will be devoted to the problem.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is very little in Harold Cal- lender's "Fascism's Tide Sweeps Onward," appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, which can ba criticized from a factual stand- point. The interpretation that he places upon his facts, however, calls for a few words of comment.

Replying to the German Day address in Madison Square Garden of Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador, Samuel Untermyer charged the Ambassador last night with "insincerity and hypocrisy" and reiterated his earlier accusations that Dr. Luther was a "propagandist in disguise and violating our neutrality and hospitality."

Smoke curling from a thirteenth-floor window of the Town House at 108 East Thirty-eighth Street yesterday morning led to the discovery of a tragedy. Hurrying to the apartment of Louis Joseph Vance, William McCoy, assistant manager of the apartment hotel, found the body of the popular author encircled in flames from a blazing upholstered armchair.

ATLANTA, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Federal Judge E. Marvin Underwood granted Al Capone today the right to appeal to the Fifth District Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans from Judge Underwood's recent decision denying Capone his freedom on a writ of habeas corpus based on the statute of limitations.
A MID the mass of propaganda that pours from the Soviet presses, there have recently been published three books which have an interest independent of the gospel according to Marx and Lenin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- A new discovery about the night air, showing that people who breathe it take into their systems one-third more radio-active matter than in the daytime, was explained today by Carnegie Institution scientists.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP). -- For the first time since January, 1932, Chicago will have civic opera on Dec. 26, when the newly organized Chicago Grand Opera Company begins its five-week season at the Civic Opera House.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- A bridge party for the benefit of the Dobbs Ferry Free Library wad given tonight at the home of Walter Herbert Cluett of Ardsley Park. There were thirty-five tables. Mrs. Franklin Q. Brown of Springhurst, Dobba Ferry, was honorary chairman, and Mrs. Albert F. Lopez was general chairman.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Dec. 16. -- Mrs. May Hanson, 39 years old, was found guilty by a jury today of the torch murder of her divorced husband, Earl C. Hanson, 42 years old. She was sentenced to fourteen years in prison.

ALARGE number of Federal employes have found out since last March that Uncle Sam is no longer quite such an easy boss as he used to be. Pay cuts, enforced vacations and some involuntary retirements have shaken the old tradition of once on the payroll, always on the payroll.

To the Drama Editor: Being an Englishwoman a great deal of my leisure time is taken Up with our favorite indoor sport of "writing letters to THE TIMES" -- letters, of course, of indignation and protest which, fortunately, are rarely posted. But this one is going.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 14. -- Judge M.D. Dickerson of the Waycross Circuit of the Superior Court has established somewhat of a precedent here by smoking in court.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 16. -- An apparent attempt to kidnap the younger son of H. Ennis Jones, former vice president of the closed Franklin Trust Company of Philadelphia, failed today when screams of the child's mother frightened an intruder from the Jones home in Pennsauken township.

Last Summer Dr. William Beebe, explorer of jungles and deep seas, whose books on his scientific adventures have become classics of their kind, and Mrs. Beebe, novelist and historian, who writes under the pen name of Elswyth Thane, set out for different parts of the world in search for further material in their respective fields of endeavor.

PANAMA, R.P., Dec. 13. -- There is apparent in El Salvador general opinion that non-recognition of the government of President Martinez by the United States has made more acute the economic crisis in that country. There is also optimistic or political opinion that recognition by the United States will bring back prosperity.

THE amenities of Mr. Newton's book collecting are well known. His enthusiasms are wide, his prejudices deep. He has always been particularly interested in Dr. Johnson and his eighteenth century circle, but he often goes further afield in following his literary in terests.

OTTAWA, Dec. 14. -- Canada gave prohibition a fair trial during and after the war, and one by one, between 1921 and 1930, all the provinces except little Prince Edward Island abandoned the experiment and went into one form or another of legal sale of intoxicants.

HAMBURG, Dec. 16. -- Gottfried Feder, creator of the National Socialist economic program and now Under-Secretary of the Ministry of Economics, delivered before Hamburg business men today a speech apparently intended to supplement a recent address by his chief, Dr. Kurt Schmitt.

Municipal government "conceived in corruption and flourishing on graft" has been permitted to "bankrupt our cities and surrender our citizens to the rule of the underworld," Thomas E, Dewey, Acting United States Attorney, said yesterday, speaking over a National Broadcasting network of forty-six stations.

Opinion in favor of low taxes on alcoholic beverages is gaining ground in Washington. Badly as the Government needs revenue, it is of more immediate importance to drive out the illegal liquor traffic which prospered under prohibition. This cannot be done if taxes are unreasonably high.

CASUAL observers have applied the term "Fascist" to the nationalist movements in Germany and Japan, as though these were made after the Italian pattern. But this is misleading. The two countries, in social structure, historical development and present policies, should be compared with each other rather than with Italy.

Jamaica High School's rifle team captured the city P.S.A.L. championship yesterday, defeating five other qualifying sextets in the final round at the Richmond Hill High range. The winning total was 1.023 points.

ALTHOUGH the playwright has dominated the theatre for a great many years the actor, it seems to me, is becoming a person of increasing importance. After the series of remarkable performances we have had this Autumn it is silly to go on pretending that the actor is the playwright's tumble servant.

ATER less than three years of its hopeful experiment, the Spanish Republic is tottering. Its strongest supporter, labor, has deserted the republican standard, and its enemies either look back to Alfonso or across to Italy and Germany. All the citizenry expects, and most of it is prepared, to plunge forth violently in search of something other than political democracy to cure Spain's many economic and social ills.

State and municipal bonds, in small amounts, most of them for payment at the end of the month, together with parts of several loans for payment at the beginning of next year, and two entire issues for June, made up the bulk of announcements last week of securities to be retired before their dates of maturity.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Frederick H. Prince of Boston, who is expected here to be the next financial chief of Armour Co., came to Chicago today, held a peace conference with a committee of Armour's directors in the Blackstone Hotel and left the city again tonight for the East after eluding interviewers.

AMERICA seems suddenly to have gone regional, and a good thing it is. We are not the eldest of the world's brotherhood of nations, but we are one of the largest; and only in an ultimate classification can the artists of this broad land be lumped.

THE first edition of this classic treatise appeared in 1920, the beginning of the great American experiment noble in motive. The first American, and the fourth English, edition conies opportunely, almost coincident with the end of that experiment.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 16. -- With two former world's champions among the many notables in attendance, the famous Greentree court of the late Payne Whitney once again rang to the marker's cry in court tennis tournament competition today for the first time in years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Technical experts who aided the late Professor Albert A. Michelson in his experiments with light agreed today that if the discoveries reported from Pasadena, Calif., can be proved, they upset the Einstein theory that the velocity of light is absolute, the one thing in the universe which does not change.

PRLNCETON, N.J., Dec. 16. -- A brilliant solo effort by Gilbert Lea, former St. Paul's star, nearly three minutes after the second overtime session had begun gave the Prince ton hockey team a 5-4 decision over Boston University tonight. The losers had twice come from behind to threaten the Tigers' undefeated record.

The intercoastal steamship lines will seek an immediate settlement of the difficulties that have delayed the drafting of a code of ethical competition, it was indicated yesterday. A tentative agreement has been reached by the Calmar Line and the intercoastal conference, it was said, and objections of the Nelson and Shepard Lines to conference regulations will be studied with a view to effecting a settlement.
The scheme of gold buying now being operated by the RFC has no parallel in other countries and no precedent in financial history. Among the features of the plan which make it unique are:

The forthcoming engagement of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe, which opens here Friday night at the St. James Theatre, has aroused such interest among members of society that two performances in the first week of its run have been taken over in the interests of philanthropic organizations.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York has expressed agreement with the National Industrial Traffic League in its recommendation that the Federal government seek equality of opportunity for water, motor and rail transportation in so far as legislation can make it possible, by relaxing existing Federal legislation which is applied to the railroads.

An effort to create a greater spread of employment among musicians has been undertaken by local NRA officials, who have called a meeting of unemployed musicians for 3 P.M. Tuesday at the St. Nicholas Auditorium, Sixty-sixth Street and Columbus Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- At the end of today's session of the House Ways and Means subcommittee considering Tax Law revision. Chairman Hill expressed the opinion that the full committee would follow more closely the suggestions of the subcommittee than the proposals of the Treasury Department.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ford and Mary Pickford visited the Ford Ex-position of Progress yesterday at the Port Authority Commerce Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street. So difficult was manoeuvring through the great throng that packed every aisle of the six-acre exhibition hall that the three visitors frequently were separated during their tour.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- The appointment of Sandor Harmati as director of the Westchester County Music Festival was announced today by Mrs. Eugene Meyer, chairman of the board of governors of the Westchester Choral Society and chairman of the Westchester County Recreation Commission.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16. -- While Weirton Steel Company officials were asserting that employes voted of their own free will for collective bargaining representatives yesterday, officials of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers said today that they had many affidavits from workers charging coercion and intimidation.

Professor O.M.W. Sprague sheds some much desired light on "sound money" which it is popular just now to say is something mystical if not mythical. President Roosevelt undoubtedly understands what sound money means and knows the horrors of unsound money.

THE Present migration of gray squirrels from New England States to new areas is likened to the famous treks of the Norway lemming. Like the restless Scandinavian rodent, the squirrels, which are also Irregular migrants, are crossing bridges and swimming rivers just as they did in the "grand squirrel trek" of 1866.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 16. -- Playing in convincing fashion, Robert Grant 3d, Harvard senior, gained a place among the semifinalists in the Gold Racquet tourney at the Rockaway Hunting Club today, one of the leading squ racquets events of the year.

Payroll and pension deficiencies amounting to $2,815,000 have been reported to the Board of Aldermen with the request that the board issue that amount in special revenue bonds to avoid payroll defaults on Dec. 31, it was learned at City Hall yesterday.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Maybe Rugby had something to do with it after all.

With the idea of increasing the safety of the players and adding to the interest of football for the spectators, the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Football Officials offered four recommendations yesterday for consideration by the rules committee.

Don M. Parker of the Garden City Golf Club, organizer of the New York State Golf Association ten years ago, was re-elected president of that body yesterday at the annual meeting at the Manhattan Club.

For the first time since 1911, a native of the metropolitan area heads the men's national tennis ankings. Also, for the first time since 1922, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody is placed lower than first in the women's ratings. She was not ranked last year.
DUBLIN, Dec. 15. -- The grass is green in Ireland this Christmastide, and the Irish Free State is at peace in every sense except politically, despite the new eruption of the Blue Shirt Fascisti.

THE title of this anthology is doubly appropriate, for "All the Year Round" was the title that Charles Dickens gave to his own magazine, and there is in this volume a selection from Dickens for each day in the year. It is a book that the Dickens lover will like to dip into at random, for on each page he will encounter some old friend.
PARIS, Nov. 25. WE are to have the new Bernstein play in a few days and the new Marcel Achard play will follow. Meanwhile, the only novelty is J.J. Bernard's "Jeanne de Pantin" at the Odeon.

Evidence of steady recovery that promises to gain marked headway in 1934, and which is directly traceable to the NRA program, was seen by leading merchants in a nationwide survey made during the week by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14. -- Curiosity over the reputed billions of the "Mellon Industrial and Financial Empire' has been tempered somewhat lately by the revulsion against the eager talk in political circles of the "plums" expected in the way of fees for collection of the State inheritance tax on the bequests of Richard Beatty Mellon, who die recently.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 16. -- Operating with the precision of a welloiled machine, the seventh Pan-American Conference met in plenary session this afternoon and rubber-stamped in rapid succession eleven matters which had previously been studied, debated and approved by committees.

Sentiment in the principal farming areas is better today than at any time in the last three years, Horace Bowker, president of the American Agricultural Chemical Company, said yesterday in a review of the agricultural situation in 1933.

TWO prehistoric ruins of the American Southwest are to be preserved from further disintegration with the aid of funds provided under the public works program, according to an announcement from Secretary of the Interior Ickes.

LEIPZIG, Dec. 16 (AP). -- The burning of the Reichstag building last February remained an enigma after a final, sensational hearing tonight as four of the men charged with setting the blaze protested their innocence and the fifth stolidly refused again to talk.

ICELAND! Wild horses! The title has all the atmosphere of a poem. And a spirited saga this story of wild horses proves to be. What distinguishes it from its companion pieces on animals is the exquisite descriptions of a country little known to the majority and its extraordinary style.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14. -- Disturbances that at times required police intervention marked the return to work this week of 22,919 unemployed men in St. Louis, the quota assigned to the city under the Civil Works program. But these disturbances were merely the pathetic efforts of men long out of work to get back on a payroll.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 28. -- Now that H.H. Kung has succeeded his brother-in-law, T.V. Soong, as Minister of Finance in the Chinese Government he is faced with the urgent problem of somehow inducing Chinese capital to assist in the development of industry instead of hiding in foreign banks or in Chinese banks in foreign concession areas.

Defending team titleholders had a perfect day in the two city P.S. A.L. indoor track and field championship meets held yesterday at the 245th Coast Defense Armory (formerly the Thirteenth Regiment Armory) in Brooklyn.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 16 (AP). -- The United States Rubber Company won a skirmish today in a long legal battle to collect damages from the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for alleged infringements of balloon tire patents when Federal Judge Paul Jones ruled that seven patents of the United States Rubber Company had been infringed upon by the Firestone company in the last six or eight years.

Pilots and other shipping men spoke in praise yesterday of the seamanship displayed by Captain Antonio Lena of the Italian liner Conte di Savoia in getting his ship out of the harbor Friday afternoon while other vessels were tied up by the fog.

TORONTO, Dec. 16 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs turned on the Montreal Canadiens tonight after receiving two shut-outs and scored a 3-to-l triumph. The victory lengthened Toronto's lead in the National Hockey League International section.

KALGAN, China, Nov. 9. -- Ravaged and impoverished by civil war and banditry, the province of Chahar is struggling to "come back,'' under the leadership of General Sung che-yuan. The present Governor took office after the rebel "Christian General," Feng Yuhsiang, had been induced to give up his self-assumed dictatorship and retire to Shantung.

THERE are many avenues to a writing of history. The subject might be considered from the economic, political or social point of view, or from their various subdivisions. It might be a record of wars and their aftermath, or perhaps a study of the individual heroes or villains who dominated the scene for a while.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Protesting against the use of Federal funds for the construction of public projects which compete with existing privately-owned plants, the Illinois Manufacturers Association calls upon the Public Works Administration to change its policy.

LYND WARD'S new story in woodcuts is a distinguished and forceful book. The form of narration without words has become widely enough accepted so that no extended explanation of it is necessary. It has a special advantage in vividness, brevity and the dramatic impact that the method allows.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 16 (AP). -- A jury which sat for nearly twenty-nine hours reported late today, acquitting Anthony Reino and Charles Shore of the murder of James Stevens, a detective, during a bank hold-up in Rensselaer May 29 and disagreed in the case of Leonard Scarnici, New York gang leader.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 14. -- There may be a big row on in Alabama because no Negroes are to be found on juries, but here in South Carolina when a Negro is drawn as a juror he does everything possible to get out of it. Negroes do not like to be mixed up in the "co't doin's" of white, folks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Following a conference with President Roosevelt this afternoon, Representative Doughton of North Carolina, chairman of the House Committee on Ways and Means, stated that the Liquor Tax Bill, which will be reported to the House early in the coming session of Congress, would probably provide a levy between $2.10 to $2.40 a gallon.
TORONTO, Dec. 16. -- For the first time since 1914 the Yale University hockey team invaded Toronto tonight and defeated the University of Toronto, 5 to 3, in the Varsity Arena.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- Interclub team racing in sailing dinghies was inaugurated today with the Larchmont Yacht Club defeating the Essex Yacht Club from Connecticut, 63 points to 47.

To insure the employment of the maximum number of men, Travis H. Whitney, civil works administrator, asked the five Borough Presidents and the central purchasing bureau of the city yesterday to submit their projects to him before making commitments for materials or equipment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP). -- A committee of experts of the International Chamber of Commerce today proposed that the rail-highway transportation competition problem could be worked out by leaving the question to solve itself or by the establishment of monopolistic control.
PARIS, Dec. 16 (AP). -- French concessions to facilitate the American importation of apples and pears have been sent to Washington, it was learned tonight in government quarters.

ATLANTA, Dec. 14. -- Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, won this week in the deep South the added respect and increased admiration of all who heard her clear-cut talks. But it must be confessed that it was Frances Perkins, the woman, that this section received with a warmth of welcome that must have pleased her.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- Back in 1859, at the moment John Brown was being hanged at Harpers Ferry as an Abolitionist, hundreds of Rochesterians knelt in prayer at a mass meeting as bells tolled throughout the city, already an important terminal on the "underground railway" and the refuge of Frederick Douglass.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 16. -- Far Rockaway High, which successfully had completed its defense of the Queens P.S.A.L. swimming championship earlier in the day by defeating Jamaica High, tonight vanquished the Lehigh University freshmen, 45 to 21.

The city P.S.A.L. junior high school basketball championship remained in the Bronx as the Creston quintet defeated Frederick Douglas of Manhattan, 26-21, in the sectional final yesterday at Public School 99, Manhattan.

BOTH author and illustrator of this book are dead. E.A. Parker has scrupulously edited the text from corrections made by the former during nearly forty years, and with the pen-and-ink drawings of Mr. Batten are published for the first time.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 16. -- The State Board of Health suggested to Governor Moore today that instead of a three-State compact that would include Connecticut, New Jersey enter into an agreement with New York State and New York City to stop pollution of the Hudson River, New York Harbor, Newark Bay and adjacent waters.

PART of the difficulty in formulating a statement of one's position on the question of granting Federal money for the public schools lies in the lack of a definite program which one can evaluate and in the difference in the definitions of the terms used.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- President Roosevelt has spoken over the radio twenty times since his inauguration ten months ago and Mrs. Roosevelt seventeen times, it was shown today in a recapitulation by the National Broadcasting Company.

Herbert Bayard Swope, treasurer of the Recovery Party which put forward Joseph V. McKee as its candidate for Mayor, announced yesterday that its campaign deficit of approximately $81,000 had been cleared completely and that all its bills had been paid.

OILS and water-colors by Alexander Sideris comprise the one-man show at the Hellenic Centre, 307 West Fifty-fourth Street. Besides the oils, which include still-life, portraits and flowers, there are water-colors of Greek villages and coast vistas; also Metropolitan Museum interiors.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- Sir Eric Phipps, who was summoned to an audience with King George at Buckingham Palace today before leaving to spend the week-end in the country with Foreign Secretary Simon, is reported to have brought from Chancellor Hitler a new set of proposals to reconcile the German demand for equality in armaments with the French desire for security.

REPORTS from Detroit and other centres of automobile manufacture indicate that more and more companies are getting into production with the models they will introduce at the National Automobile Show, opening here on Jan. 6.

THOUSANDS of high school students throughout the country are debating the merits of the American broadcasting system vs. the Britsh plan. It is a lively topic because both systems are vastly diferent.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Plans for one of the most extensive man hunts ever organized in Cook County, with Federal agents, sheriffs, police and constables cooperating in every community of the United States, were announced today by State's Attorney Courtney.

The swimming team of Prospect School secured second place in the city junior high, school champion ship of the Public Schools Athletic League by downing Seth Low, 37 to 25, in the third and final engagement for interborough laurels in the George Washington High pool yesterday.

Retail holiday trade has reached satisfactory proportions, although it has not developed the broad sweep forecast for it early in the Fall, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. Final results, according to the buying office, will show an increase over last year's figures.

THIS is Mr. Morley's first collection of essays in five years, though within the past seven months he has also published an omnibus of his works, a volume of verse, and a travel book, which is sufficient evidence of his copiousness.

BOMBAY, Dec. 16 (Canadian Press). -- The English cricket team held a dominating lead over India at the close of play today in the official test match, topping the Indian eleven's first ininngs' score with six wickets in hand.

BROOMSTICKS, Amen!" will open at the Biltmore Theatre on Jan. 12, with rehearsals therefor beginning in a day or so. The play is by Elmer Greensfelder and has been tried out a couple of times here and there.

The Society of Medical Jurisprudence celebrated its fiftieth anniversary with a dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria. About 200 members and guests attended.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Any American seeking proof of Britain's nationalistic mood today need only study the past week's discussions of shipping problems in the Parliament and the press.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 13. -- Just as the corn loans poultice was beginning to have a soothing effect on the inflamed body of agriculture, the rash has broken out in a new spot. It is caused by trying to feed 45-cent corn to $3 hog's and $4 to $5 beef cattle.

THE West of the old days, the frontier, the Santa Fe Trail, the Oregon Trail, the Pony Express, the Days of '49 -- magic phrases all of them, of such power that to speak of any one of them is like touching an electric button and illuminating stirring scenes of the mighty epic that was the winning of the western half of our country.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- The Comtesse de Buyer-Mimeure recently brought together a number of well-known French and American women who are members of the Catholic Sewing Circle. They assembled at a historic chateau in Passy.
MANILA, P.I., Dec. 16 (AP). -- With foes of the politically powerful Manual Quezon in control, the once defunct Democrata party was revived at a convention here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Resignation of the Consumers Advisory Board of the NRA was demanded today at the closing session of a two-day meeting of the Emergency Conference of Consumers' Organizations. Severe attacks were made upon the board, linked with a statement that the board comprises "six college professors, five club women, three government representatives, one social leader, one house -wife, one cooperator and one lawyer."

The country has emerged from the depression and business is improving, General W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Rail-road, told members of the Pennsylvania Society last night at the organization's thirty-fifth annual dinner in the Waldorf.

DATTON, Ohio. ORVILLE WRIGHT, the first man to fly a powered airplane, on the eve of the thirtieth anniversary of that famous flight proceeded to explode one of the most persistent myths in the annals of aviation.

Under the direction of the Bursar and Fellows of Merton College, Oxford, the School of Pythagoras and Merton Hall at Cambridge has been rebuilt.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- A plan for regulation of the tobacco industry, including manufacturers of cigars and cigarettes as well as retailers, was agreed upon after a hearing on the code today.

IN spite of all improvements in planes and engines, in spite of a greatly enlarged and increasingly accurate weather reporting service, the weather still remains the one big obstacle to air transport.

THOMAS JEFFERSON and a Welsh quarry village named Liansaintffraidglynceilog do not seem to have much in common. They did not until recently, when a tablet in honor of the author of the Declaration of Independence was unveiled at the Ceiriog Memorial Institute there.
A bomb was exploded in the ranks of British dogdom when the Kennel Club passed a resolution barring advertising solicitors for the canine papers from judging.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Two gangs of bandits, one suave and the other rough, robbed a hotel and a large store, respectively, in the heart of the city today.

Labor's views on the regulation and control of liquor were presented yesterday in a statement by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, read by Benjamin Miller, chairman of the committee, at a hearing before the committee on alcoholic beverage laws of the Federal Bar Association, held in the Bar Association, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Mrs. Busch Greenough will give a reception Tuesday afternoon at the St. Regis for the various committees working in behalf of the benefit matinee performance of "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Dec. 28. Miss Lily Pons and Nino Martini, who will sing the leading roles in the opera, will be guests of honor at the reception.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the recital by Jose Iturbi, pianist, in behalf of the charitable projects of the Protestant Big Sisters. It will take place the night of Dec. 28 in the ballroon of the Waldorf-Astoria.
HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 16 -- The resignation of Jackson L. Cannell as head coach of Dartmouth football was accepted today by the full meeting of the Athletic Council.

MADRID, Dec. 16. -- Alejandro Lerroux, veteran statesman of the republic, formed tonight a government composed almost entirely of Republican Radicals. This government replaces the Barrios Cabinet, which was named only to hold elections and which would have resigned earlier if the anarchist rising had not delayed its resignation until this morning.

As the final week of Christmas business is reached, earlier tendencies have been confirmed. Trade is best in the agricultural regions, is running ahead in the industrial districts and holding even in the urban centres. In this set-up, the mail order companies are reporting the largest increases, with the chain systems and department stores following in order as a general thing.

WERE this the romantic rather than the machine age, there could be little doubt that the magnificent flight of the Lindberghs, ringing the northern great sea, would be the subject of a saga. Colonel Lindbergh, descendant of those bold explorers who made the name of Viking resound down the centuries, has inherited with their blood all of its qualities of resource, of daring tempered with good judgment, of skill in the management of vessels.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 16 (AP). -- Looking forward to the special election Dec. 28, Democrats in the 34th Congressional district claim they have "better than an even chance" of sending John J. Burns to Congress to fill out the unexpired term of Representative John W. Clarke, Republican, who was killed in an automobile accident last month.

RECENT developments have increased the anxiety with which the nations are awaiting the naval conference of 1935. Some of these happenings have caused many to fear that a naval building race not unlike that which ended in the debacle of 1914 has already started.

MY Luft-Hansa plane with the swastika painted on its tall made a series of spectacular curves in the descent upon Berlin -- its only dramatic gesture, but an effective one. We had met with rainclouds most of the way from London, sometimes cruising serenely above them in that sunny region which flight opens like a polar landscape to the wayfarer, but oftener driving through mist and sleet over a sullen countryside.

THE rolling hillside vineyards of California are paying homage to wine's return, and the vignerons are jubilant over a generous crop and a giant crush. Once more, after years of almost total idleness, vineyards and wineries extending in a 500-mile chain from the redwood empire to the one-time desert wastes of the southland are throbbing with restored circulation.

La Stampa Libera, an Italian-language labor newspaper, pub- lished here, has made public a translation of a document described as instructions issued to newspapers in Italy by the Fascist Press Bureau. This document, La Stampa Libera said, was smuggled out of Italy a few months ago.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 16. -- At the termination of the plenary session of the Pan-American conference today Secretary of State Hull expressed gratification with its adoption of the economic and peace sections of its program. He said he was especially happy because they went through with unanimity of expression and votes.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 16. -- A plenary session of the seventh PanAmerican Conference is an exceedingly interesting spectacle. To it come ninety-four delegates representing all but one of the American republics. Only Costa Rica is absent.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- The action of the wheat market today was similar to that of yesterday, an early break of about 1 1/2 cents being followed by purchases of about 1,000,000 bushels of the May, regarded by the trade as a resumption of Federal relief operations.

Lamar L. Fleming, a member of the Board of Managers of the New York Cotton Exchange and a leading cotton merchant of this city for thirty-five years, died last night at his home, 26 East Tenth Street, after a long illness.

YESTERDAY was the seventieth anniversary of the birth of George Santayana. The occasion is noteworthy to a large circle of readers throughout the English-speaking world, for it marks a milestone not only in the life of a man but in the history of both literature and philosophy.

Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C. won the Princeton Club's annual invitation squash tennis tourney yesterday by defeating Edward G. McLaughlin of the Columbia University Club in a five-game final on the Princeton Club court. Wolf triumphed in last year's tournament also.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 16. -- Puerto Rico, where he has conducted medical research for more than thirty years, today honored Dr. Bailey K. Ashford, discoverer of the hookworm disease and cure, by placing a bronze bust of him in the School of Tropical Medicine of Columbia University and the University of Puerto Rico.

MADRID, Dec. 16 -- The fourth anarchist uprising in the republic's two years and eight months of existence brings Spain again face to face with the problem of whether democratic liberty can mean anything but chaotic conditions in the Iberian Peninsula.
LEESBURG, Va., Dec. 16 (AP). -- A sentence of life imprisonment was imposed today on George Crawford, Negro, for murdering Mrs. Agnes Boeing Ilsley, prominent Middleburg (Va.) sportswoman.

AS fresh and genuine and captivating a booh about the sea as has appeared in many a day. It has a value beyond its interest as a thrilling tale of adventure, for it is autobiographical and a fine picture of a boy starting at 14 on his chosen career.

IT has become almost a commonplace to pick up the morning newspaper and read of what seems to be a new project to put hundreds of thousands of met to work, or of some new fund of millions of dollars for relief, or of the free distribution of millions of pounds of some surplus foodstuff.
The speed fluctuations disclosed in the A.A. Michelson speed-of-light measurements, the completion of which was announced Friday in Pasadena, Calif., were commented on by scientists yesterday.

THIS study of the Roosevelt program for a New Deal has two aspects of usefulness and interest. It affords, in the first place, a collection of facts gathered from authoritative sources and exactly stated. It outlines the important policies of the administration and is accompanied by analysis and description of the aims sought and the methods by which they are to be attained.
AKRON, Dec. 16 (AP). -- One branch at least of the rubber industry will be operating under an NRA code soon.

MUSEUMS are sending out to neighborhood social settlements and library buildings displays of decorative art. These are generally made up of objects selected from the museum's own collections, but they often include craft work lent by neighborhood groups of the alien-born. Children from schools and study clubs, and thousands of persons who have never been inside a museum go to the exhibitions and listen to the explanatory talks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Labor will demand that general Johnson and the National Labor Board draw up a clear-cut statement outlawing company-sponsored unions and proceed against them in the courts on the ground that employer support for employe organizations is prohibited by the Recovery Act, William Green announced today.

Despite unfavorable weather conditions, Christmas sales continued to-gain during the last week and in most sections of the country were well ahead of a year ago. In several cities snow and sleet hampered shoppers, while the nature of the buying varied in the different sections of the country.

DETROIT. OFFICIAL disclosures of spring mechanisms that have been devised to yield greater riding comfort in 1934 cars by giving front wheels independent suspension continue to stir the automobile centre.

DURING the past few days many of us have been reading long and ardent descriptions of the new Museum of Art at Kansas City. It is, indeed, an imposing monument to erect in obedience to our steadily increasing ambition to reach the ideal of those elder days of art when, our old friend Mr. Longfellow assures us, "builders wrought with greatest care."

BETWEEN those two striking and positive figures in Tudor history, Henry VIII and Queen Elizabeth -- both of them perennially tempting to the biographer and fascinating to the general reader -- there stands the unlovely and relatively obscure person of "Bloody Mary."

Robert Ridgway, consulting engineer of the Board of Transportation, retired yesterday after fifty years of service in the engineering activities of the city, the State and the nation. The retirement was not marked by any official ceremonies, Mr. Ridgway merely bidding farewell to his associates, several of whom had worked with him for more than forty-five years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Filing for registration under the Securities Act of a statement by the Conversion Office for Foreign German Debts of Berlin, covering certificates of indebtedness or "scrip" of the corporation amounting to 45.000,000 reichsmark, was announced today by the Federal Trade Commission.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 14. -- Vermoniers will go to the polls to vote in a special primary election, on Dec. 19, for party candidates for the United States Senate and the House, of Representatives. The election will be held Jan. 16.

FOR many months the British public has been much perturbed over a sensational case of alleged espionage. Last Spring Lieutenant Norman Bafflie-Stewart, an officer with the highest standing in popularity and reputation, was tried by courtmartial and found guilty of disclosing information respecting tanks, armored cars and automatic rifles to a foreign power, namely, Germany.
