ROME, Dec. 15 -- Italy faces the prospect of a general cut in wages and salaries to bring them into adjustment with the situation created by four years of depression.

MILAN, Dec. 7, 1933. IN the general picture of Italy's new opera and ballet production, the Municipal Casino Theatre of San Remo occupies a position of the first rank. As an index of its comparative importance, it will suffice to recall that it put on last season no less than five world premieres (Alfano, Pick, Veretti, Sonzogno, Toni), two premiere choreographic adaptations of modern works (Pizzetti, Respighi) and three Italian premieres (Malipiero, de Falla, Rabaud).

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 16. -- Women's rights registered probably their most notable single triumph in history today when the Pan-American Conference voted to submit to its members a treaty guaranteeing equal nationality rights and to recommend that all countries grant equal civil and political rights as soon as possible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Preliminary reports of Justice agents on the employes' election held yesterday at the Weirton Steel Company's three plants have been received at the Attorney General's office, and a comprehensive report is expected Monday.

Forty-three gunners competed yesterday at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club, where the annual Christmas turkey shoot was staged. Twenty-three turkeys were up for competition, the conditions stating that no gunner could win mere than one bird.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 12. -- The two recent proclamations of Governor William Lanser of North Dakota, staying execution of evictions by foreclosure and dispossessions of property, stand against a background of legislative and executive acts and a history of debtor revolt that make them appear less revolutionary than when standing by themselves.
Today the Fund for New York's Neediest Cases enters its last full week before Christmas.

At the request of Coordinator EASTMAN, the Science Advisory Board has appointed a committee "to study the "matter of scientific research for the "railroads in conjunction with the railroad management." Seemingly, the railroads are to become conscripts of the laboratory.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Erwin Rudolph, Cleveland star who won the title in 1930, trounced the defending champion, Ralph Greenleaf of New York, 125 to 44, today, to take undisputed possession of second place in the world's pocket billiard championship tournament.
A well-coached Fordham quintet displayed a dazzling offensive in the first half and then had enough left to coast to a 40-to-30 victory over Columbia on the Lions' court last night.

PARIS, Dec. 7, 1933. THE Dutch show more curiosity than the French for old French music. Remembering that three hundred years ago the operas of Lully took their theatres by storm, they have made the experiment of reviving the last of his works, "Acis et Galatee," composed in 1686.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- Pennsylvania gained its third straight victory of the season by turning back the University of Michigan's basketball team at the Palestra tonight, 32 to 25.

MONTREAL, Dec. 16 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons gained a third-place tie with the Ottawa Senators in the International division of the National Hockey League tonight with a 3-to-2 victory over Ottawa.

Piercing the Titans' powerful zone defense with a fast passing attack, City College's undefeated varsity basketball team scored its fifth straight victory last night when it conquered the Westminster College five, 25 to 13, in the Lavender gymnasium.

IT is a little bit late in the year to be kicking a football around, but the "Rose Bawl game at Pasadena, Calif., is in the offing, with Columbia selected to represent the East and Stanford picked to uphold the prestige of the West. If the old order of business at such football functions is still in force.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan will be Police Commissioner after Jan. 1, and Fire Chief John J. McElligott will head the Fire Department as commissioner. The two appointments were announced yesterday morning by Mayor-elect F.H. La-Guardia at his office, 1,450 Broad-way.

SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 16 (AP). -- Members of a jury which sang hymns before bringing in a verdict of second-degree murder against Alex Zielinski, 45, last night, were assailed today by Judge Will Leach before he sentenced the defendant to ten to twenty years in Eastern penitentiary.

Stabilization of the dollar would inject new life into this country's foreign trade by doubling the current volume of exports and putting importers back into world markets as active buyers, foreign traders said here yesterday. Exporters and importers alike agreed that early stabilization at any reasonable figure is imperative if either group is to be able to make plans for the coming year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The NRA today modified the Blue Eagle voluntary re-employment agreement or blanket code to permit all employers under it to work their help overtime at the year-end for inventory purposes.

The fine work done by the National Economy League during its first year has not been forgotten. It helped to prepare public support for President ROOSEVELT in his courageous demand that nearly half a million veterans of the World War be stricken off the pension list because they were not really entitled to be on it, with the consequent saving of about $400,000,000 a year.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 17 (AP) -- H.L. Mencken, the author, and Alfred Knopf, the New York publisher, appeared in police court today to tell how last night they captured a pair of pacifists who started a fight.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 17 -- Swinging into the third and probably the last week of the seventh Pan-American Conference, the delegates felt today that the most important objects of the conference had been disposed of at yesterday's plenary session.

Particularly in the mood of the Christmas season are several newly opened exhibitions, among them the "Paintings of the Madonna" at Ehrich's and the group of Flemish and Italian primitives at Knoedler's.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Whisky prices will be reduced when the distillers file their price list this week with the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, Dr. J.M. Doran, supervisor of the Alcohol Code Authority, declared today.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 17 -- The miniature gold racquet emblematic of squash racquets supremacy went to Beekman Pool, the national titleholder, today, as the winner of the gold racquet tourney staged at the Rockaway Hunting Club courts.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- How the skies appeared to the people of Palestine at the time of the birth of Christ was shown today to audiences at the Fels Planetarium of the Benjamin Franklin Memorial and Franklin Institute Museum.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- On the thirtieth anniversary of the first successful flight in a power-driven plane, Orville Wright heard himself and his late brother, Wilbur, characterized here today not only as pioneers in the airplane field but as men who "accurately laid the foundation for the science of aeronautics."

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- An attempt to extort $10,000 from Robert A. Gardner of Lake Forest, broker and former national amateur golf champion, on the threat of killing his son, Henry Keep Gardner, 11 years old, was revealed tonight with confirmation of reports that his home has been guarded by Federal agents and police since Friday.

The remainder of the schedule in the newly formed Eastern Amateur Hockey League was released yesterday by Thomas F. Lockhart of the Metropolitan Association A. A.U. A total of sixty-five games still must be played. Seven have been contested already.

A 7-year-old Negro girl was burned fatally and three firemen and a Negro tenant were injured about 5 o'clock yesterday morning when fire of undetermined origin swept the three upper floors of a five-story tenement at 547 Lenox Avenue.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 -- The Soviet Union's, budget for the coming year will be 45,000,000,000 rubles, as cormpared with 35.000,000,000 for the year just ending. (This is a 28.8 per cent increase.) It is true these are paper -- or what you might call in America "rubber" rubles, the purchasing power of which is considerably lower than the gold or "Torgsin" rubles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Holding that the administration's gold purchase plan cannot be relied upon to restore higher price levels, the Brooklngs Institution suggests in a study that the present uncertainty and economic instability call for a "reconsideration of monetary policies in relation to economic recovery, both nationally and internationally."

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 17 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 72, which compares with 71.7 a week ago, 71.4 two weeks ago, 71.7 three weeks ago and 72.1 four weeks ago. The average of Oct. 15, at 72.2, was the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

DETROIT, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The extension until Sept. 1, 1934, of the NRA automotive code, announced at Washington tonight, comes on the eve of one of the industry's most vigorous sales drives and at a time when optimism is apparent in all quarters.

Rows of yellow candles, symbolizing the traditional menorah, glowed at every table last night as the Jewish Education Association celebrated the completion of twelve years of service with a Chanukah dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Maurice P. Davidson, city chairman of the City Fusion party, announced yesterday the appointment of a New York County Executive Committee, named in accordance with the constitution and by-laws adopted recently by the City Executive Committee.

ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 17 (by wireless) -- We have been beset by heavy ice for three days, and for the last twenty-four hours have been almost at a standstill. The Wyatt Earp, living up to her illustrious namesake, is a fighter -- she bucks ahead.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Led by Bill Kendall, recruit right winger, the Chicago Black Hawks trounced the Canadiens of Montreal tonight in a National Hockey League fixture.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 17 -- Making a sweep of the three final round matches, the New York City court tennis team retained the Payne Whitney Memorial Cup to day in the intercity doubles on the Whitney court at Greentree.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- The James K. Hand Walking Association, composed of prominent business and professional men Of New York City, Westchester and Connecticut, held its fortieth annual hike today. Despite reports that the association would disband, the forty-first annual hike will be held on schedule next year, it was announced.

TORONTO, Ont., Dec. 17 -- The Consolidated Mining and Smelting Company, which has resumed cash dividends with a payment of $1.50 a share to be made on Jan. 15, against a 10 per cent stock dividend a year ago, has issued a statement which reads in part:

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Had it not been for the disordered state of mind caused by the present confusion in the exchanges, the feeling of financial Paris is that no one would have taken seriously the rumor which hag persistently circulated abroad, that France would shortly abandon gold.

BERLIN, Dec. 17 -- The flat statement that Ernst Torgler, former Communist floor leader in the Reichstag, would be acquitted in the Reichstag fire trial was made today by the ultra-nationalist Boersen-Zeitung in a dispatch from Leipzig.

The Principality of Monaco will apply to the Supreme Court of the United States today for permission to sue the State of Mississippi on bonds of the State that have been unpaid for more than ninety years. The bonds are $2,000,000 Mississippi Planters Bank 6s issued in 1831 and 1833 and $5,000,000 Mississippi Union Bank 5s issued in 1838 and in default since 1841.

DUBLIN, Dec. 17 -- President Eamon de Valera of the Free State Executive Council believes peace, prosperity and contentment will be attained most readily by an independent Ireland free from ties with any government or association of governments save such as she may voluntarily enter into after her complete independence has been assured.

An 11-year-old invalid girl wag killed and four other persons were injured, two seriously, when the two autos in which they were passengers were in collision about 12:30 P.M. yesterday near the east end of the Queensboro Bridge. Both cars were badly damaged and one of them turned over.

BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- Reichsbank President Hjalmar Schacht's speech in Switzerland implying the impossibility of maintaining the present reduced bond service had no effect on dollar bonds here, and quotations on these were somewhat firmer.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 17 -- Initiating the series of similar events they will give the first and third Sundays of each month throughout the season, Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne entertained this morning with a swimming party and musicale at the pool and patio of their oceanfront villa, Casa Beata.

An increase in deaths and new cases of tuberculosis in the city's congested areas was revealed in a report issued yesterday by the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor. The report covers the work of the association's committee for the prevention and relief of tuberculosis for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1933.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- A group of Republican Assemblymen conferring in Albany today called for proof of charges made by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, against Fred W. Hammond, Assembly Clerk, that as an agent of H. Edmund Machold, former State Chairman, representing "special interests," he exercises control over the Assembly.

The Book - of - the - Month Club choice for January is "Brazilian Adventure," which Scribner will publish on Jan. 5. Peter Fleming wrote it and it is an account of his adventures during a 3,000-mile trip through the Matto Grosso in search of Colonel P.H. Fawcett, the English explorer, who disappeared there nearly ten years ago.

Henri Morin de Lenclay, the new director of the French Line in the United States, is about to announce that H. Ainsley Highman, who has been the general passenger manager here since March 1, 1932, will be retired from that post on Dec. 31.
Appointment of Langdon W. Post as Tenement House Commissioner was announced yesterday by Mayorelect LaGuardia as the first step in working out a program of municipal housing and slum clearance.

With the approval of the State Civil Works Administration, of which Alfred H. Schoellkopf is chairman, the local Civil Works Administration, headed by Travis H. Whitney, will today launch a project designed to facilitate the comprehensive slum clearance program now being developed by the Slum Clearance Committee.

The New York A.C. hockey team opened its Eastern Amateur League season and defeated the Hershey sextet, 2 to 1, in an overtime game at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of more than 1,000 saw the game.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- The Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company refused today to abide by a ruling of the National Labor Board that it permit all striking employes to return to work and allow a new election of employe representatives.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Cattle, corn and hog prices are decidedly out of line, the government paying farmers 45 cents a bushel to hold their corn on farms until Aug. 1. The farmers are sealing up millions of bushels, as the price offered to farmers is higher than can be obtained through other methods.

Rapidly expanding interest in Spring merchandise, together with last-minute reorders on gift items and a continued heavy demand for formal dresses, featured activity in the wholesale markets here last week. Spring lines of ready-to-wear are not complete, but indications are already strong that a marked suit vogue will develop during the early Spring.

In an address at Boston on Saturday Mr. NEWTON D. BAKER renewed the warning against depending solely upon public appropriations for the poor and distressed. The city, the State and the Federal Government can and ought to do much. They have an obligation, if private charity is not equal to the task, to meet the absolute wants of people out of work and out of funds without in the least being blameworthy.

The performance of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe on the afternoon of Dec. 27 at the St. James Theatre has been taken over by members of the Schola Cantorum in behalf of that organization. Many seats already have been purchased for the benefit.

The governmental powers of the United States have been usurped by a "group of irresponsible, anonymous, almost impersonal domestic financiers" who will deliver the country into the hands of communism unless they quickly moderate their attitude, the Rev. John D. McCarthy declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17 (AP) -- An outsider in the betting, Zekiel, today won the Jefferson Parish Welfare Association Handicap, feature of the card at Jefferson Park. A crowd of 5,000 attended.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- An unsettled feeling prevails in the grain trade, not only in the United States and Canada but also throughout the world, largely because of uncertainty as to what the Roosevelt administration intends to do in both grains and stocks.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 17 -- The Dartmouth Athletic Council concluded its two-day session this morning without having come to any conclusion regarding the football coaching situation. It asks for more alumni and undergraduate opinion on the subject.

Latest reports from Trenton indicate that a record number of hunters will take to the woods in New Jersey today for the opening of the four-day deer-shooting season. Wardens throughout the State submitted reports yesterday indicating the presence of a considerable number of deer in the more thickly wooded areas.

If the concerts of the League of Composers may be taken as a partial reflection of the attributes of contemporary composers, last night's performances under the league's aegis at the French Institute aroused considerable hope that the Age of Confusion may be passing.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 17 -- The Dartmouth Athletic Council concluded its two-day session this morning without having come to any conclusion regarding the football coaching situation. It asks for more alumni and undergraduate opinion on the subject.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 17 -- Development of a new "atom-gun" which fires nine times as many proton bullets per given time as any other "smasher" hitherto available to science for bombardment of the hearts of atoms was announced, here today by President Karl T. Compton of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

An appeal for a more generous response than usual to the campaign of the United Hospital Fund for money to support the free work of its fifty-six affiliated institutions was issued yesterday by George Blumenthal, president of Mount Sinai Hospital, who was for many years vice president of the fund.
RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Stanley Winborne, State Securities Commissioner, revealed today that be had issued orders to cancel and revoke the registration of twenty-two investment trust issues.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Heads were broken, a police car was overturned and four policemen were seriously hurt today in a fierce clash between the police and about 600 Communist demonstrators near the German Embassy.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The monthly index number of average wholesale prices for French commodities at the end of November, compiled by the Statistique Generale, is 383, comparing with 384 in October and 391 in November, 1932. Index numbers for the separate groups of commodities compare as follows:

Major LA GUARDIA is keeping the pledge which he made in the municipal campaign. He promised not to know such a thing as politics in his administration, and to secure as heads of department men whose character and competence would be so well known that nobody would inquire or care what their party record had been.

IN "Washington Merry Go Round," that irreverent book published by Liveright, Inc., before the advent of the Roosevelt Democracy in Washington, there is a story of "Charlie" Curtis's stock campaign speech about the menace to the American farmer of imported Chinese coldstorage eggs. As Robert Allen and Drew Pearson and the other authors of the "Merry Go Round" tell it, the story is hilarious -- the reductio ad absurdum of the Protectionist position.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Definite signs of business revival appeared throughout the world in the fiscal year ended June 30, according to Secretary Roper's annual report, made public today.

Representatives of the shippers and trade organizations in the New York port district will confer tomorrow with spokesmen of the steamship lines on plans for an investigation of the so-called freight loaders' racket which is said to exist on the waterfront piers.
Complete results of the analysis of the bar and store whiskies tested by Board of Health chemists will be made known this afternoon by Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne.

Several properties on the upper West Side and in Harlem were involved in realty transactions reported by brokers over the weekend. Flats in West 143d and 112th Streets changed hands and a row of ten tenements in 135th Street was listed under new control.

Fewer changes in the "Golden Horseshoe" and other boxes of the Metropolitan Opera House, revealed by the new season's list of boxholders made public yesterday, were cited by friends of the opera as evidence of the loyal support given by patrons and the public generally in their determination to save the opera in New York City.

HAVANA, Dec. 17 -- Four men were killed and ten wounded this afternoon during a demonstration by the Cuban Federation of Labor against the recently-enacted law, calling for the employment of 50 per cent of native labor in all establishments.

John. McCormack sang for the golden jubilee fund of the Church of St. Benedict the Moor last evening at Carnegie Hall, to the tune of $10,000 profit to the Negro congregation in West Fifty-third Street and its day nursery in Harlem. Mary Lewis, soprano, also was a volunteer at Mr. McCormack's invitation, both appearing as guests of the pastor, the Rev. T.J. Shanley, an old classmate of the tenor's in Ireland.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 17 (AP). -- Attorney General Greek Rice said tonight he had received notice of the filing of Monaco's petition asking leave of the United States Supreme Court to sue the State of Mississippi for collection of two nineteenth century bond issues.

Some indications of resistance to the downward movement in production and trade were apparent in the first half of this month according to the current monthly report of the conference of statisticians in industry of the National Industrial Conference Board.

BOMBAY, Dec. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Fifty thousand persons jammed the grounds today to see the resumption of the official test cricket match between England and India, and thousands more were unable to enter, although they offered as much as five times the price of a seat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Direct loans to industry through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for meeting payrolls and increasing employment were understood today to be under serious consideration by the administration.
The crucial week in the effort to take care of New York's Needles Cases is beginning now with the Fund $21,286 below its mark at the same period last year.

MIAMI, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh groomed their seaplane today for the last leg tomorrow of their flight homeward for Christmas. They planned to leave about 6:30 A.M. It was not disclosed whether they planned to make stops en route.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 17 -- A meeting of the foreign ministers and chairman of delegations at the Pan-American Conference has been called for tomorrow to hear Secretary of State Hull's exposition of why the United States is unwilling to back up any acts of force that may be authorized by the League of Nations toward the solution of the Chaco War.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 17 -- Leo Diegel, professional from the Philmont Country Club, Philmont, Pa., won the California open golf championship today, shooting 282 for seventy-two holes, six strokes under par.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 17 -- One byproduct of the Pan-American Conference may be an improvement in relations between El Salvador and the United States. Arrangements were being made today for a meeting between Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Jose Cipriano Castro to discuss the situation.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- John McGrath, 82 years old, former constable of Yonkers, was rescued from his fifth-floor apartment this afternoon when fire threatened the building at South Broadway and Lawrence Street and drove more than twenty-five tenants to the street.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Convinced for twenty years that she suffered from a permanent, incurable blindness, Mrs. Mabel Naylor, mother of two small children, has regained her sight through a successful surgical operation.
To the Editor of The New York Times : The several bank and other robberies reported in this morning's newspaper mark, in my opinion, the beginning of a national crime wave.

The Niagara Falls Cataracts, a fighting hockey sextet from Ontario, which was unable to send the puck into the net for a single tally in the opening period, came back in the second and third with a furious attack to score a 10-to-2 victory over the St. Nicholas Hockey Club yesterday afternoon.

Although the public phase of its campaign for an unemployment relief fund of $4,000,000 closed on Saturday, with the fund oversubscribed, the Citizens Family Welfare Committee continued yesterday to receive contributions. Announcement was made that the drive would be continued by various groups of the committee until their allotted quotas were completed.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 17 -- W. Murdock was both the high scratch and the high handicap gunner in the shoot for the President's Cup over the traps of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today. He returned a card of 40, 6 -- 46.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Dec. 18 -- Strong Communist forces, flying red flags bearing the hammer and sickle, are now interposed between the Fukien rebels and government troops near Kienou, forty miles northward of Yenping. A distance of only twelve miles separates the opposing armies, and a clash is expected hourly.

Long Island University chess players made their debut in the newly organized New York City Intercollegiate Chess Association yesterday at the Isaac L. Rice Progressive Chess Club. Matched against Yeshiva College, they were defeated, 4-0.

The Brooklyn Civic Orchestra, recently formed with sixty players, is to be increased to 100, a call for the forty additional musicians having been issued by Dr. Paul Kosok of Long Island University, which is sponsoring the organization.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Thirty-one sailing dinghies competed today in a north easterly drizzle at the Larchmont Yacht Club's Winter regatta. Each of the two classes, A and B, was split into two divisions, one designated as red and the other as green.

DUBLIN, Dec. 17 -- Amid scenes of wildest excitement General Owen O'Duffy, leader of the united opposition to the de Valera government, was arrested this afternoon for wearing a blue shirt while attempting to address an outdoor meeting of his adherents at Westport, a seashore town on the Atlantic edge of County Mayo.

The systems governing many of the denominational schools in the United States were criticized yesterday by the Rev. Dr. W.T. Elmore of the Eastern Theological Seminary, Philadelphia, who delivered the sermon at the First Baptist Church. Broadway and Seventyninth Street.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Horace S. de Camp will give a tea dance on Dec. 26 at their home, 960 Fifth Avenue, to introduce their daughter. Miss Julia Janet de Camp.

The national council of the Fellowship of Reconciliation, one of the largest pacifist organizations in the world, has decided to drop one of its executive secretaries, J.B. Matthews, it became known yesterday.

False Christians who "magnify the pains of childbirth and discount the joys of motherhood through the practice of birth control" were denounced as anti-Christian yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, in the third of a series of Advent sermons at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy, Fordham Road and Marion Avenue, the Bronx.

Arrangements have been made by the advisory committee of the Women's Auxiliary of the Polyclinic Hospital for a tea dance Dec. 29 at Mayfair House to raise money for the support of the children's wards of the hospital.
MIAMI. Fla., Dec. 17 (AP). -- With the stables filling at the rate of nearly 200 horses a week, trackmen at Florida's two ovals are confident Winter racing will come into its own this season.
RIPLEY, Ohio, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Indefinite suspension of tobacco sales here, the largest burley market in

Very Confused Fighting. Perhaps a joint conference of Platonists, medieval scholastics and Talmudists could decide who really did win the recent Battle of the Agricultural Department, the problem is altogether too complex for the general public.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Pasquale Natalie of Chicago won from Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland by a score of 125 to 102 in forty-one innings in the world's pocket billiard tournament tonight. Natalie had a high run of 28 to Rudolph's 26.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- General Johnson today outlined a plan by which the Consumers' Advisory Board, to which he stated he had up to this time paid little attention, will go into full action to protect the American buyer and force the readjustment of all codes in which labor conditions and general code regulations raise the prices too high, either on specific or general items of merchandise.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 17 -- Daniel Earle McGugin, who had not seen a football until he entered Drake University at the age of 16, looked back over thirty-four years of association with the gridiron today and said he believed the playing rules in general were satisfactory.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- A new high point was reached in the dollar's recovery this week when on Wednesday the New York-London rate dipped to $5.02 to the pound sterling. This compares with an extreme rate of $5.53 touched in the November slump.

To the Editor of The New York Times : A little investigation should convince interested persons that fiat money cannot lawfully be issued wihout a constitutional amendment, requiring the affirmative action of thirty-six States. The United States Constitution reads as follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Reports of improvement of business in this district Jast week were more numerous and satisfactory than had been known in several years. General buying has created the best feeling and furnished an impetus for further grains.

Traditionally, the two or three closing weeks of a year used to make up an uneventful period in the markets. The rule was broken by all previous December stock markets since 1929. Approach of the New Year seemed on those occasions to cast a shadow over financial sentiment; prices both for stocks and bonds declined all but continuously.

The National Economy League, leader of the fight that ended in the curtailment of veterans' expenditures last Spring, made public yesterday a petition to President Roosevelt and Congress asking for a reduction of future "emergency" expenditures under the recovery program.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- In a sensational forward passing battle the Chicago Bears won the national professional football championship today by beating the New York Giants, 23 to 21. The game was witnessed by 30,000.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 17 -- Dullness bordering on stagnation featured the cotton contract market here last week. Apparently much the same state of things prevailed in all the cotton markets at home as well as abroad. There was an almost entire absence of speculative interest and the amount of trade buying and price fixing, as well as hedge selling, was small.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A $34,000,000 issue of Group Securities, Inc., of Jersey City, an investment company, was included in $36,000,000 of securities proposed to be issued in registration statements filed under the Securities Act and made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

It was clearly demonstrated at Madison Square Garden last night that fights are not necessary to make a hockey game exciting. The New York Rangers and the Boston Bruins, long-standing rivals in the National Hockey League, clashed before a crowd of 13,000 persons and staged as exciting a battle as has been played here this season, without the slightest show of belligerence.

Despite rain and poor light conditions excellent cards were returned at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Z.G. Simmons took the high scratch cup by breaking 97 out of 100 targets. The high handicap prize went to W.B. Miller.

Mrs. Ward W. Fenner will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 530 East Eighty-sixth Street, for committee members working toward the success of the benefit hockey game between Princeton and McGill Universities, Dec. 30, at Madison Square Garden.

Proportional representation and elimination primaries without party designation for candidates on the primary tickets will be features of measures now in preparation for introduction in the 1934 session of the Legislature. They are designed to bring about reforms in town and county governments throughout the State.

PALMA, Majorca, Dec. 17 -- Majorca business interests are up in arms over a drastic order just adopted by the Spanish Government regulating foreign visitors and residents in the Balearic Islands. The Fomento de Turismo at a stormy meeting adopted a resolution demanding that the government immediately rescind the regulations, which, it declares, would kill tourist trade in the tranquil islands and make them altogether too tranquil.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17 -- The steel trade did not expect the large increase in production of steel ingots that was reported last week, the official figure setting the rate at 31.5 per cent of capacity, against 28.3 per cent in the preceding week and 25.2 per cent in the week ended on Nov. 11, the lowest since late in April.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 17 (AP). -- William Neely Mallory, captain of Yale's football team in 1923, today criticized the statements of two Yale players who last week told alumni at a banquet in Montclair, N.J., that they played for other reasons than to "win."

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- After killing his mother, Mrs. Anna Dolack, 64 years old, with a .22 calibre rifle last night, George Dolack, 23, of 47 Park Row, Wallington, N.J., shot himself in the left temple. He was taken to St. Mary's Hospital in Passaic, where before he died, he is said to have explained to detectives:

The Catholic action medal -- a new medal which is to be awarded annually by St. Bonaventure's College, Allegany, N.Y. -- was presented for the first time last night to Alfred E. Smith, who was hailed as the outstanding Catholic in the United States.

Dr. WYNNE, who is soon to retire as Commissioner of Health, is one of the few high officials of the dying regime who will be missed. His enduring monument will be the successful offensive against diphtheria, which nearly decimated the old mortality figures from that dread disease, reducing child deaths from an average of 750 a few years ago to not more than eightyfive in the year about to close.

Spattered with mud and drenched by a steady rain, Louis Gregory of the Millrose A.A., one of the 1932 Olympians, won the Metropolitan. A.A.U. senior cross-country championship yesterday over the six-mile Forest Park course in Queens. This was strictly a race for mudders and Gregory proved himself the best of a well-matched lot.

The annual report of the Secretary of Commerce, published today, covers the fiscal year which ended June 30. This is a more cheerful period to write about than that which fell last year to the lot of Mr. ROPER'S predecessor. If it includes the financial panic of last February-March, it also includes the recovery of confidence and the impressive forward movement of prices and business between early Spring and midsummer.

All the world knows that thirty years ago yesterday ORVILLE WEIGHT flew a motor-driven plane 120 feet at Kitty Hawk, N.C. The story has been told many times, and anniversaries of the achievement will long be celebrated. To the glider which the Wright brothers had been experimenting with a 16-horsepower engine and twin-screw propellers were attached.

The committee for holders of City of Miami (Fla.) bonds announced yesterday that the plan for refunding all the city's $29,350,000 of bonds outstanding had been declared operative and that it would mail checks today for back interest to the holders of the $24,500,000 of bonds deposited with it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Government buying of hogs in the eight principal Western markets last week absorbed a large percentage of receipts, being 10,000 to 15,000 a day, or about 90,000 for the week. The run of receipts at eleven leading markets aggregated 536,000 for the week, an increase of 91,000 over the previous week and 101,000 greater than a year ago.

Commodity futures in local markets tended irregularly lower last week, with a trend also toward a further reduction in trading activity in most instances. Movements were listless, as few outside developments stimulated interest.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $3,192,962,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The 125th anniversary of the consecration of the original Grace Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Rector Street was commemorated yesterday at special services in the present church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

BERLIN, Dec. 17 -- The unusually well-informed Frankfurter Zeitung predicts today that at the meeting of the central committee of the Reichsbank tomorrow Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, the bank's president, will reduce the cash payments on Germany's foreign debt service under the partial transfer moratorium from the present 50 per cent to between 30 and 35 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Now, as always at this season, there is springing up all over Manhattan and almost overnight a sparsely planted wood of evergreen blossoming with many colored lights designed to keep the legend of Kriss Kringle alive and people's hopes high.

Miss Elsa Maxwell gave a large dinner last night in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice. Colors appropriate to the Christmas season were used in the decorations. During the evening elaborate divertissements were given by well-known stars of the theatrical and musical worlds.

BERLIN, Dec. 17 -- The annulment of a mixed marriage on the ground that it violates the Nazi dogma of "blood kinship as the foundation of the new State" has been decreed by a Berlin court. The case is the first decided in Berlin under the so-called Aryan paragraph and is therefore of fundamental significance.

Trading in cotton was somewhat more active last week than in the previous rather slow week. Prices fluctuated over a narrow range, exhibiting little tendency either upward or downward. At the end of the week, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 3 to 9 points lower than at the close of the week before.

BERLIN, Dec. 17 -- Germany's proposed new athletic plant for the Olympic Games of 1936 is being hailed as the first representative monument of the Third Reich. On Chancellor Hitler's personal initiative, it is proposed to build one of the biggest and most elaborate sports centres in, the world for the games.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- More than a hundred persons were injured this afternoon in the worst riot in years as a massed attack was launched by several hundred Communists against the vanguard of 5,000 marchers in a Ukrainian parade.

SALEM, Mass., Dec. 17 (AP). -- The Salem High School football team, whose acceptances and refusals of an invitation to play Urban Military Academy of Los Angeles on Des. 24, caused their supporters to lose count, today decided to go West.

BERLIN, Dec. 17 -- Germany's proposed new athletic plant for the Olympic Games of 1936 is being hailed as the first representative monument of the Third Reich. On Chancellor Hitler's personal initiative, it is proposed to build one of the biggest and most elaborate sports centres in, the world for the games.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- More than a hundred persons were injured this afternoon in the worst riot in years as a massed attack was launched by several hundred Communists against the vanguard of 5,000 marchers in a Ukrainian parade.

SALEM, Mass., Dec. 17 (AP). -- The Salem High School football team, whose acceptances and refusals of an invitation to play Urban Military Academy of Los Angeles on Des. 24, caused their supporters to lose count, today decided to go West.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, EN ROUTE TO ANTARCTICA, Dec. 17 -- Twelve hundred miles southeast of Wellington, N.Z., the flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition tonight was pushing through thick fog along a southeasterly course.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 17 -- Those who believe Secretary of State Cordell Hull is the member of the Roosevelt Cabinet most likely to get what he wants can find support for their belief in the evolution of his activities at the Pan-American Conference.
Women interested in the work of the Italian Welfare League will give a supper dance Jan. 5 aboard the Roma to raise money for the charitable enterprises of the organization.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 17 -- The South and Central American delegations to the Pan-American Conference were completely bewildered today by the declaration that the United States desired to disassociate herself from the work of the Inter-American Commission of Women.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The Board of Trade's index number of average British prices in November, based on the average for 1913 as 100, is 102.8. It compares with 102.6 for October and 101.1 for November, 1932.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- A second emergency operation was performed on Irvin (Ace) Bailey, Toronto Maple Leafs hockey player, shortly after noon today. Later doctors at the City Hospital said his condition was poor.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- An article in yesterday's Temps under the title "France and Germany" has, by its favorable presentation of Chancellor Hitler's proposals and its conclusions, added fuel to the controversy in which the Paris press is daily indulging on the question:
A chime of twelve bells, which has just been installed in the two towers of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, was dedicated yesterday morning.

BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- The stock market opened the week with a moderate reaction, after which quotations mostly rose, with substantial gains by coals, lignites, steels and papers. Later, in consequence of the new import prohibitions, A.K.U. and Bemberg advanced.

Eight gold stars were added yesterday to the silken banner of the Police Department's Honor Legion at the legion's annual memorial service held in the Shubert Theatre on West Forty-fourth Street. The flag now bears 207 stars, each representing a member of the department who has been killed in the performance of duty.

The Cudahy Packing Company reports for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 28 a consolidated net profit of $1,813,766 after charges, interest, depreciation and taxes. This was equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.85 a share on the 467,489 common shares of $50 par value.

The dollar showed a fractional recovery last week, based on the quotation for the French franc. After an opening low of 63.19 cents, established on Monday, there was a sharp rally to 65.38, on Wednesday, the highest since November 1. A reaction followed from this point to 63.76, on Saturday, but on balance there was a net gain of .31 cent on the week. Range a year ago, 100.43@100.29 cents.

The final 1933 drill in this city of Columbia's football squad will be held this afternoon at the 105th Field Artillery Armory. There will be plenty of work Coach Lou Little announced yesterday, but the intensiveness that marked the sessions last week will be missing.

DAYTON, Tenn., Dec. 17 -- Over 1,000 unemployed citizens of Rhea County broke loose from a mass meeting held in the court house here last night to protest the administering of Civil Works funds and drove a county official, his wife and a son out of the town.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Government buying of hogs was liberal last week and offerings of cured products for future delivery were plentiful. There was liquidation by holders of old-style December and January contracts. The former were said to be well cleaned up to a delivery of more than 17,000,000 pounds of cash lard by packers.

Anticipating the promised Federal loan and grant of $23,160,000 for completion of the new city subway system, the Board of Transportation is preparing to get work started within a few days after the initial funds are made available, it was indicated yesterday.

Man's treatment of man "is our chief obstacle to the belief in the reality of God," the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin said in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.
MARSEILLES, France, Dec. 17 -- Four men tossed helplessly in a seaplane caught in a blinding snow-storm on the Mediterranean Sea tonight while rescue ships searched frantically for them.
DETROIT, Dec. 17 -- In a game in which only three penalties were called, the Detroit Red Wings and New York Americans of the National Hockey League played to a 4-4 overtime tie tonight.
Louis Joseph Vance, who was burned to death in his apartment at the Town House, 108 East Thirty-eighth Street, left a mystery behind him as baffling as any he concocted in fiction.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Harry M. Pollok, sports promoter and manager of Freddie Welsh when Welsh was lightweight champion of the world, shot himself to death late last night or early today, according to police.

The fifty-acre farm at Red Bank, N.J., formerly owned by Bertram Cutler, Standard Oil executive, has been purchased by Louis Kaiser, of the New York Stock Exchange, and will be used by him for the breeding and training of race horses.

The average daily register in the public schools of New York City during the school year 1932-33 was 1,105,542, an increase of 22,777 over the previous year, Dr. William J. O'Shea, retiring Superintendent of Schools, says in his forthcoming annual report.
The theft of jewels valued at $2,000 from the apartment of Rosa Ponselle, Metropolitan Opera soprano, was disclosed yesterday as detectives investigated the robbery.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 18 -- William J. Bingham, director of athletics at Harvard, in his annual report, submitted today to the president of the university, suggested either an athletic tax or assistance from the general university funds to offset the shrinkage in gate receipts.
Jim Browning still rules as the world's heavyweight wrestling champion in New York State, and Ed (Don) George of Buffalo retains championship recognition in the New England States and Canada.

Bronx Democrats and Republicans began yesterday to organize for the special election in the Twenty-first Senatorial District on Dec. 28 to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Henry G. Schackno, City Court justice-elect.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Accusing her husband of "laziness and profligacy," Miriam Jordan, film player, has filed a suit for divorce against Joseph Davis of New York and London.
An exhibition of recent portraits in bronze and polychromed terra-cotta by the well-known American sculptor, Jo Davidson, has opened at the Knoedler Galleries, to remain until Dec. 24.

Tammany, according to reliable information revealed yesterday, will not press for passage of the McGillick Bill, now in the local laws committee of the Board of Aldermen. The bill, in effect, would keep in office all Tammany exempt-employes, including commissioners, except those who could be removed on charges, under the new administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The price at which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will buy newly mined gold was raised today by 5 cents to $34.06, the first advance since Dec. 1, but if this marked the beginning of a new phase of the administration's monetary policy, no explanation was available in official circles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Philippine Islands are not within the scope of the NRA.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 18 (AP) -- In case he has made no plans for celebrating New Year's Day, James Lafayette Marks probably will find the Rose Bowl game at Pasadena between Stanford and Columbia to his liking.

Nobody on the spot or here seems able to explain why the United States refrained at the Pan-American Conference from joining with moat of the other nations represented at Montevideo in approving the treaty establishing equality of political rights for women. There are arguments both against and for the plan, but the surprise is that the present attitude of our Government is a reversal of its former position.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Financial London's "worst fears" are confirmed by new German interest cuts, which are held here to be without any real explanation. Strong protests, it is understood, are being prepared, and the British Government may be asked to take diplomatic action.

With speculators ignoring the higher gold price which was posted yesterday after a pause of more than two weeks, the markets were easily depressed. Wall Street was disappointed that there was not a more enthusiastic response, but the philosophic attitude of the commission houses was that the advance in gold had been "discounted."

The funeral of William Sloane Coffin, art patron and president of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, took place yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. The church was filled with leaders in art, religion, social welfare, education and business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The influence which the devaluation of the dollar would exert in bringing about a trade recovery and a rise in prices is a problem which bristles with difficulties. Commonly in the past devaluation has come as the final stage in the return of a disordered currency to the gold standard.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 18 -- Organization of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council was completed today. Raymond B. Stevens of New Hampshire was elected permanent president, it was announced following a conference held in the Federal Reserve Board's chambers at the Treasury Department.

Resumption of the upward manipulation of the Government's gold price apparently did little more yesterday than to confuse the speculative markets. Judging by their action, the advance of 5 cents an ounce in the posted price of gold -- the first change since Dec. 1 -- was not considered a particularly noteworthy incident.

Chief Justice Frederic Kernochan of Special Sessions gained ninety-nine votes yesterday in the recount he demanded on the last election, in which Owen Bohan, Tammany district leader, defeated him for General Sessions by 2,767 votes.

Deficiencies in city payrolls and pension funds amounting to more than $2,800,000 will be met from the proceeds of a $3,500,000 revenue bond sale to be authorized shortly by the Municipal Assembly, George McAneny, Controller, said yesterday.
The Fund for the Neediest Cases, after several encouraging days, suffered a reverse yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Secrets of alleged collusion in the Insull receivership cases, which have been fought over in court proceedings for almost a year, finally were disclosed at a hearing before Federal Judge Evan A. Evans today.

PEIPING, Dec. 18 -- The stage is set for an outbreak on a large scale of internecine warfare on the north- western frontiers, acoording to C. Oberg, a Swede, who arrived in Peiping today after a six months' journey into Chinghai Province.

MONTREAL, Dec. 18 -- Official announcement was made here today by representatives of Pries Brothers Co., Ltd., of a new plan for reorganization of that company which would permit the concern to carry on the business. The announcement revealed that interests controlled by Lord Beaverbrook, Lord Rothermere and the Duke-Price Power Company, acting as underwriters only, have joined in the proposal.

A rise of $21,421,153 in the volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding took place in November, according to the monthly survey of the American Acceptance Council. This was the third successive monthly advance and lifted total volume as of Nov. 29 to $758,212,098, a new high level for the year to date and $64,000,000 higher than the total for three months ago.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 18 -- The depression hit the Pacific Coast last, and apparently recovery is pursuing the same leisurely course westward. For a long time they thought they were depression-proof there.

The opening session of the week in money witnessed no change in either the volume of business or rate variations to distinguish it from any day last week. Demand was light and quotations for all classifications remained unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 1 per cent, while counter trades were arranged at 3/4 @ 7/8.

Guggenheim Brothers will discontinue the sale of copper on Jan. 1, at which time the Kennecott Copper Corporation will take over their sales organization. Guggenheim Brothers have been the sales agents for Kennecott for several years.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will grant an appearance in a major role at the Metropolitan to a young American, the winner of the nation-wide contest to be held by the Schubert Memorial, Inc., it was announced yesterday. The award will be known as the Schubert Memorial Opera Prize and the contest will be held in conjunction with the National Federation of Music Clubs in Philadelphia in May 1935.

Police Commissioner Bolan gave out yesterday a statement by Joseph P. Moran, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, replying to reported criticism of the administration of the organization's funds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Overtures of conciliation have been made by the Smithsonian Institution to Orville Wright, with a view to healing the old breach and bringing back from England the original Wright airplane.

Pennsylvania Station was darkened and all Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroad trains in the New York area were halted -- two under the East River -- when a short circuit burned out wires in a sub-station at 242 West Thirty-first Street at 11:50 A.M. yesterday.

An additional appropriation of $1,000,000 by the Board of Estimate to facilitate the program of the local Civil Works Administration will be asked on Friday, when Travis H. Whitney, Civil Works Administrator for this city, will lay before the board plans for expanding the work program for January.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- Disregarding protests of Germany's foreign creditors, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, announced today that during the next six months Germany would further reduce interest payments on her foreign indebtedness as follows:

Peconic Bay anglers have renewed agitation for laws to protect fishing in that famous body of water, according to members of the East End Surf Fishing Club. A resolution was adopted by the club at its meeting in Riverhead last week by which nets, set lines and trawls would be barred from certain regions of the bay.

Local member banks of the Federal Reserve and other banks that will become members of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation were awaiting yesterday a ruling from the corporation upon what constitutes insured deposits under the terms of the act creating the corporation.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler denied last night the application by Joseph Nemerov, a lawyer, through Max D. Steuer, for permission to sue George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, to oust him from control of properties of the guarantee mortgage companies now in rehabilitation.

A request for $1,000,000 additional to complete City Water Tunnel 2, the $57,000,000 delivery main that is to augment the city's facilities for conveying water from Hill View Reservoir in the Bronx to points in the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn has been made to the Board of Estimate by the Board of Water Supply.

Irving Beitler, 39 years old, a patient in United States Veterans Hos- pital 81, 130 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, shot his wife, Edna, 32, yesterday afternoon in a reception room of the institution. Then he shot himself three times.

A hearing involving a woman defendant accused of having practiced psycho-analysis without a license will be held in magistrate's court Jan. 16. Sol Ullman, Deputy Attorney General, who will prosecute the case in behalf of the State Board of Medical Examiners, said last night that it would be his first prosecution of a case directly involving an allegedly unlicensed practitioner of psycho-analysis in seven years experience in handling cases concerning the legality of medical practices.

An application for a temporary injunction forbidding the Board of Estimate to grant a twenty-five-year franchise to the Fifth Avenue Coach Company on its existing route from Manhattan to Jackson Heights, Queens, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Edna Masse, a taxpayer living at 7,903 Thirty-second Avenue, Queens.

Transit unification negotiations between the incoming city administration and representatives of the transit companies were begun yesterday with a conference at the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

General Hugh S. Johnson was requested yesterday to direct a poll of longshoremen of the Pacific Coast to determine whether they would accept the leadership of the International Longshoremen's Association in their negotiations for wage contracts and working conditions with the steamship lines operating on the Coast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Broad expansion of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the extension of its statutory life were indicated as essential today by Jesse Jones, chairman, if the RFC is to carry out the current program for extending assistance to banks.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- The aces of his once-championship baseball combination scattered over the American League, Connie Mack sat in his tower office at Shibe Park today and told of the rebuilding of the Athletics.

The selection of Cart Owen Hubbell as the "man of the year" in all sports marks the second time the honor has gone to a major league baseball star in the three-year history of this annual Associated Press poll. Pepper Martin ran away with the contest in 1931.

The Governors of Kentucky and Tennessee have proclaimed a "holiday" on tobacco sales, and many of the markets in those States are closed. This action affects principally sales of burley -- one among some twenty-five types of tobacco grown in the United States. A larger surplus of it has been piled up than of any other kind, and there has been much dissatisfaction with prices.
LENINGRAD, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Harpo Marx received an ovation here tonight.

The Harvard Club defeated the Princeton Club, 3 to 2, in their Class B, New York Division squash racquets match on the losers' courts last night. In the same group the Heights Casino vanquished Union League, 3 to 2, and the University Club turned back the Racquet and Tennis Club by the same score.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- France took measures today to insure keeping her army at full strength during the three "lean years," when the low birth rates in 1915, 1916 and 1917 would ordinarily reduce the number of youths called to the colors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Authority to borrow $15,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for three years was sought today by the Illinois Central Railroad in an application to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The money would be used to meet the maturity of half an issue of $20,000,000 of short-term gold notes, and of equipment trust certificates and interest.

TRENTON, Dec. 18 -- New Jersey must take steps to relieve the "overburdened property owner at once if the public school system is to avoid a general breakdown," according to the report of the School Survey Commission. The report was submitted to Governor Moore today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- All banks not affiliated with the Federal Reserve System which had applied for membership in the temporary fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to the close of business Dec. 15 have been examined as to their qualifications, the corporation announced today.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 18 -- His swing is as smooth and flawless as ever. The foot and hip movements are as rhythmic as in the days, not so long ago, when he was marching toward the greatest heights ever scaled by a golfer.

Walls for Murals. If 2,500 unemployed mural artists are to find work with the CWA, it follows that there must be walls for the mural artists to decorate. The walls are there. Some of the public buildings to be beautified probably date back before the war.

The second concert of the Beethoven Association's sixteenth season, which took place last night at the Town Hall, brought forth Harold Bauer, pianist; Efrem Zimbalist, Bruno Jaenicke, solo French horn of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, and the Aguilars, Spanish Lute Quartet, consisting of Ezequiel, Pepe, Elisa and Paco.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Dec. 18 -- The personal estate of Z. Smith Reynolds, wealthy sportsman and aviation enthusiast and heir to the millions left by his father, the late R.J. Reynolds, tobacco manufacturer, totals $200,184.36, it was revealed today when Moses Shapiro, appointed July 3 by the clerk of Superior Court, filed an inventory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The first attacks of organized business on pending proposals to plug up "loopholes" in the income tax system left a majority of the Ways and Means Committee today with the apparent determination to go through with the plan for complete revision of the law.

A memorial service for the late Dr. Henry Suzzallo, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching and former Professor of Sociology at Teachers College, Columbia University, was held yesterday afternoon in Milbank Chapel of Teachers College.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- A statement issued tonight by a committee of bondholders acting in behalf of holders of the 5 1/2 per cent sterling bonds of the Societe Intercommunale Belge d'Electricite suggests that the Belgian company has accepted as final Friday's unanimous judgment of the House of Lords upholding the gold clause and the bondholders' contention that this company's bonds and the coupons attached are payable on a gold basis.

Yesterday the Principality of Monaco, owner of Mississippi bonds in default for something over ninety years, applied to the Supreme Court of the United States for leave to bring suit in that court against the State of Mississippi for judgment for principal and interest.
Several financial institutions were included as sellers in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

The amendment to the legitimate theatre code affecting dramatists and the sale of motion-picture rights of play, was accepted at a special meeting of theatrical managers and producers, signatories to the basic agreement of the Dramatists Guild, held yesterday afternoon in the offices of the League of New York Theatres.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18 -- Calling him- self a. "100-per-cent Hornsby man," Louis B. Von Weise, executor of the estate of the late Philip De Catesby Ball, today was elected president of the St. Louis club of the American Baseball League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Tentative plans to raise a minimum of $30,000,000 through the application of a processing tax on milk in a production control program have been formulated by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

An investigation into the trading activities in the Atlas Tack Company's common stock, which broke sharply Saturday and yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, has been begun by the State Attorney General's office, it was announced yesterday.

A strike of 30,000 restaurant and hotel workers in this city was voted yesterday by a group of unions, as a protest against the Restaurant Code now before President Roosevelt for signature. The unions voted to call the strike should the President sign the code.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will divide this pre-Christmas week between New York and the capital.
The Cohens and the Kellys, the Smiths and the Joneses are slowly winning their way back to prosperity, if the new Winter issue of the Manhattan telephone directory is an index.

Instead of stimulating buying yesterday, as it did last month, an advance in the Washington gold quotations appeared to unsettle sentiment, and prices on the Cotton Exchange finished with losses Of 4 to 5 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks an 90 leading cities on Dec. 13 shows increases for the week of $122,000,000 in net demand deposits and $83,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and decreases of $81,000,000 in loans and investments, $11,000,000 in time deposits and $50,000,000 in government deposits.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Tuesday, Dec. 19 -- An armistice has been arranged in the Chaco war between Bolivia and Paraguay, which has cost the two countries more than 100,000 casualties in the past year and a half.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 18 -- The New York Shipbuilding Company began work today on its share of the administration's $238,000,000 naval building program by laying the keels for four destroyers, to be named the Porter, Winslow, McDougal and Selfridge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Faced by a division in the party on the monetary question, recovery agencies and other major problems, Republican Congressional leaders conferred today on strategy in the coming session, and decided to "wait the next play of the administration."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Renewing his opposition to the pending equalization and pooling agreement of the oil industry, Senator Borah, of Idaho, in a letter to Secretary Ickes, the oil administrator, today gave his reasons for opposing the plan under which, he contends, the major companies would control the industry and bring ruin to the independent concerns.

While neighbors were searching Hicks Street on Brooklyn Heights for two missing children yesterday, Lawrence Condon, 6 years old, and his sister, Josephine, 4, were gazing in the windows of a toy shop on Flatbush Avenue more than two miles away.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- George W. Alger of New York City was named today by Governor Lehman as a Moreland Act commissioner to investigate the "management and affairs of the insurance department with reference to the operations, conduct and management of the title and mortgage guarantee corporations under its supervision."

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club Class C squash tennis team yesterday administered the first defeat of the season to the City A.C. team. The Brooklyn players won by 4 to 1 in what was considered an upset by many. The City A.C. team still heads the list of twelve clubs in the Metropolitan League, with six victories and one defeat.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck today asked the Public Service Commission for an extension until Friday in its order requiring a 6 per cent reduction in gas and electric light rates charged thousands of New York City consumers by the Consolidated group of utility companies.

BOMBAY, Dec. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Finally overcoming determined Indian resistance, the touring English cricket team today wound up the first official test match ever played in India with a victory by nine wickets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The National Labor Board was reported today to be considering an injunction test in the case of the Budd Manufacturing Company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- James Caras, 22-year-old star from Wilmington, Del., tonight shot his way into a tie with Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia for first place in the world's pocket billiard title tournament.

Because of what he characterized as "unfavorable publicity" given him by some evening newspapers, Stanley Wyman, who in the past attracted attention by posing as somebody else, resigned yesterday as "receptionist" with the City Civil Works Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Disclosures even more sensational than those before Judge Keidan's grand jury in Michigan last Summer are promised in the investigation of the Detroit "closed" bank situation which the Senate Banking subcommittee will begin tomorrow.
GENEVA, Dec. 18 -- The League of Nations bulletin of statistics for December, issued today, shows a further increase in the value of world trade.
NEW YORK. Robert W. Bingham, Ambassador to the Court of St. James's, and Mrs. Bingham, who are expected on the Empress of Britain Thursday, will be at the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Home-Owners Loan Corporation's acceptance of the resignation of William G. Donne, State manager for Illinois, following extended conferences with Mr. Donne concerning operations in that State was announced today by the corporation's board.

Reports that newstand owners in Manhattan and the Bronx were being made the victim of a last-minute "shakedown" by the Tammany machine were denied last night by Commissioner of Licenses Sidney S. Levine.
Federal and State investigations on various phases of the so-called whisky trust were urged last night in a resolution adopted by the Wholesale Liquor Dealers Committee of New York.
The failure of the United States delegation at the Pan-American Conference in Montevideo to vote for the treaty according nationality rights to women was sharply criticized by women here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- For the second time since its organization, the NRA received an order from the President today to participate in a tariff investigation -- this time with regard to the imports of rugs.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 18 -- The Mexican economic program to be studied for the coming Santiago conference does not advocate cancellation of governmental debts, Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Puig Casauranc told the Pan-American Conference Steering Committee tins afternoon.

The Coast Guard may board at will any foreign or American vessel within the territorial waters of the United States, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday, reversing two contrary decisions of lower courts.

Play for the metropolitan indoor tennis championship, last held in January, 1932, was started yesterday by the New York Indoor Tennis Club at the Hamilton courts in the Twenty-second Regiment Armory. All the first-round matches were completed, and George R. Preston was the only player to gain the third round.

Carlos J. Avila, who came here from South America to deal in securities, was placed on trial yesterday before Federal Judge Grover C. Moscowitz and a jury on an indictment charging him with the possession of bonds stolen from the liner Leviathan.

"The Man of the Renaissance," by Ralph Roeder, sold 2,200 copies last week in addition to Book-of-the-Month Club sales. Since its publication at the beginning of this month this book has had several 1,000-sale days, according to the Viking Press, which is just sending a new edition to press.

The Harriman National Bank Building on the southeast corner of Forty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, was sold at foreclosure in the Vesey Street Salesroom yesterday to the Dry Dock Savings Institution, plaintiff in the action, on a nominal bid of $100,000.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The accusation that the Pan-American Conference agenda was changed to forestall discussion of a Cuban proposal to outlaw intervention in American nations was made today by the Cuban delegation.

BOSTON, Tuesday, Dec. 19 -- Irvin (Ace) Bailey, Toronto hockey player injured in a recent game here, took a turn for the worse at 1 A.M. today and Dr. Joseph Hahn, attending physician, was summoned to his bedside.

A plan to rid the city of street beggars and professional "panhandlers" was presented yesterday by the Welfare Council and brought immediate approval from Chief City Magistrate James E. McDonald, Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein and William Hodson, who is to be Welfare Commissioner in the LaGuardia administration.
BOSTON, Dec. 18 -- The Boston Olympic Hockey Club administered a 5-to-3 defeat to the Harvard sextet in the Boston Arena tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today set for hearing Jan. 15 a test case brought by the government to determine whether pending charges of violations of the National Prohibition Law can be prosecuted or must be dismissed.

Legislation fixing definite and scientific methods for determining valuations of property owned by public-utility corporations and enabling the Public Service Commission to prevent excessive payments to affiliates was recommended yesterday in a presentment handed up by a Queens County grand jury to Supreme Court Justice Edward Riegelman.

Commodity prices moved irregularly lower yesterday in trading on local exchanges, in spite of the advance in the RFC's gold purchase price. In most cases opening quotations were steady, but the markets sagged off in later dealings. Trading was slightly more active.
BERLIN, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Reichsbank statement, as of Dec. 15, shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Ten members of the Fellowship of Reconciliation, one of the largest pacifist organizations in the world, resigned yesterday to protest an attitude of "pure pacifism" which some of its members espouse.

Stimulated by the agreement of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to provide $8,500,000 with which "interested parties" with necessary security may buy first preferred stock of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company, officials of the company were busy yesterday drawing up the final details of a plan of reorganization to be submitted to creditors.

Peter Rogers of 430 East Fifty-seventh Street was found dead last Wednesday in his stateroom on the steamship American Farmer, which is scheduled to dock here today. A radio message to the American Merchant line, owners of the steamer, reported Mr. Roger's death yesterday.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 18 (AP) -- New photographs of the strange behavior of 3,000,000,000-bolt invisible bullets of light -- cosmic ray photons -- have been taken by Dr. Cart D. Anderson.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company reports for the year ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $4,674,302 after all charges, taxes and depreciation. This was equal, after dividends on $7 and $6 prior preference stocks, to $1.97 a share earned on 757,442 shares of $4 cumulative preferred stock, upon which no dividends have been paid since Feb. 28 last.

Only rarely does the acquisition of a powerful economic position depend on real productive ability, on creative achievement, Dr. Albert Einstein told a distinguished gathering at the Hotel Roosevelt last night at a dinner commemorating the 100th anniversary of the birth of Alfred Nobel, inventor of dynamite and founder of the Nobel Awards.

The receivers for the Interborough, at a recent hearing granted by Controller George McAneny, it was disclosed yesterday, protested against payment of a tax of 1 1/2 per cent on company profits. They held that the city had no right to charge a license or excise tax on a business which the company was obliged to carry on under its contract with the city.

The Secretary of Agriculture should be made a "czar" of the imports and exports of agricultural products for this country, according to James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany. He presided at a luncheon of the Committee for America Self-Contained yesterday, at which Dr. Lionel D. Edie was the principal speaker.

A PLAY now running on Broadway -- and just published by Anderson House of Washington, D.C., for $6 in book form -- is further testimony to the fact that when a charming face and a historical enigma coincide, the literature growing up around the coincidence will constitute both a library in its own right and a labyrinth more devious than the one built in Crete.

DUBLIN, Dec. 18 -- Counsel representing the United Ireland party, that is the combined opposition to the de Valera government, obtained tonight a writ of habeas corpus calling for the production of General Owen O'Duffy, the party's leader, before the High Court on Wednesday.

Operating deficits of the group of fifty-six voluntary hospitals comprising the United Hospital Fund of New York will total $4,500,000 this year, according to a statement issued by the officials of the fund yesterday.

In a Civilian Conservation Corps camp in the South an army sergeant protested to his captain that, while he could drill men, he knew nothing about teaching them. "It's your job," said the captain, "to teach that youngster "over there to write his name. I don't "want any more payrolls going in "from this camp with an 'X' marked "on them."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Secretary Ickes, who has administered $3,300,000,000 worth of public works loans and grants with what he believes is a minimum of graft, today struck out firmly in the first complaint which has come to his attention.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- A majority of football coaches of New York, New Jersey, West Virginia and Pennsylvania want the present gridiron rules to remain unchanged so that spectators, players, coaches and officials may have an opportunity to "catch up" with them.

United States Government bonds and domestic corporation issues closed irregularly lower yesterday on the Stock Exchange in response to the decline in the dollar in the foreign exchange market as the RFC's domestic gold-buying price was moved up.

The Musical Mornings conducted by Albert Morris Bagby at the Waldorf-Astoria were continued yesterday morning with the three hundred and sixty-eighth of the series. The artists were Miss Lucrezia Borl and Giovanni Martinelli of the Metropolitan Opera and Mischa Elman, violinist.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 18 (AP) -- A drive to sign up burley tobacco growers for acreage reduction began today as Virginia joined Kentucky and Tennessee in closing its burley markets in protest against prices paid since the season opened a week ago.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 -- Former Premier Ismail Sidky Pasha has changed his mind concering his complete retirement from Egyptian politics. He sent a letter today to the President of the Chamber of Deputies announcing he had decided to retract his resignation as a member of that body.
Pre-Christmas services will be held this week in many of the larger churches in Manhattan.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 18 -- A second-half rally by Princeton gave the Tigers a 37-26 victory over a hard-fighting Rutgers basketball team before 1,500 spectators tonight.

The sale of $43,700,000 of capital notes to the RFC by eleven New York banks and trust companies, postponed last Friday because of an error, was completed yesterday in the local offices of the RFC in the Federal Reserve Bank Building.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 18 -- "Concrete points" for solution of the Chaco conflict have been agreed upon by the Bolivian Government and the League of Nations Peace Commission here, it was reliably stated here today.
