PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18 -- Patio Margery was the setting tonight for a stag dinner with which John Charles Thomas entertained, taking his guests later to the wrestling bouts at Lake Worth.

The smoke and soot evil in the city has been reduced 80 per cent since the Health Department started its drive against the nuisance more than three years ago, Dr. Thomas Darlington said yesterday as he presided for the last time as chairman of the Smoke Trial Board.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Trade in wheat today on the Board of Trade was mainly local and the Federal Relief Agency saw no necessity of supporting the market, as it did on Friday and Saturday. Prices fluctuated erratically in a range of 1 3/8 to 1 7/8 cents and closed 1/4 to 3/8 cent a bushel lower.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, just four and a half hours out of Miami, set their big seaplane down at the Charleston Navy Yard this afternoon, and it was announced they had come for "a quiet overnight visit" with Rear Admiral James J. Raby, Commandant.

A row of first magnitude in the Republican State organization is imminent. A showdown is certain on the charges advanced by W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, that the Republican Assembly under its present leadership has been dominated by the power and public utility interests.

Northampton County, Pa. Northampton County, Pa., awarded yesterday a new issue of $450,000 of bonds to a syndicate comprising the Philadelphia National Company, Brown Brothers Harriman Co. and Yarnall Co. The bankers named a price of 100.73 for the bonds as 4 1/4s. Graham, Parsons Co. and associates bid 100.66 for the bonds as 4 1/4s.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Relief needs and expenditures rose between October and November, but less, proportionately, than in previous depression years, Relief Administrator Hopkins said today.

The mystery surrounding the death of Louis Joseph Vance, novelist, who was found dead in a charred chair in his apartment in the Town House, 108 East Thirty-eighth Street on Saturday, was dispelled yesterday with the finding of an autopsy that he had had "three plus ethyl alcohol" in his brain at the time of death.

Gains ranging from 1 to 38 per cent in Christmas trade during the first fifteen days of this month over the corresponding period a year ago were reported by leading department stores throughout the country in a telegraphic survey made by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A drift away from the city in a "back-to-the-farm" movement as a result of "widespread unemployment" in industrial centres was noted today by Secretary Ickes in his annual report to President Roosevelt.

What strikes one about the news from Mount Wilson that the velocity of light is not so constant as EINSTEIN has been telling us is the objective attitude of the measurers. There is a refreshing lack of personal opinion, or of lame explanations, on the part of Drs. PEASE and PEARSON about readings that seem to upset the work done by the late Professor MICHELSON.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Thirty-three contests have been arranged for live Princeton minor sports teams during the Winter season, according to schedules announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday the result of analyses of twenty-five samples of whisky from retail stores and public drinking places in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Major letters to thirty-six varsity football players were included in the announcement of 168 athletic awards made today by the Princeton Athletic Association.

Claims for fees of nearly $300,000 by receivers, attorneys and accountants for services in the twelve-week equity receivership early this year of the now bankrupt Paramount Publix Corporation were opposed as "excessive" and "vague" yesterday by counsel for bondholders and other creditors of the corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Sometimes people who would not otherwise have done a certain thing -- good or bad -- have done it partly because of steady predictions that they would. "The gallows would never have occurred to me," said the highwayman as he took his last walk to Tyburn Tree, "if my great-aunt hadn't always insisted I would finish here."
FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Several hours after his ship, the American Export Exarch, went aground Saturday at midnight on the north coast of Cyprus, Captain A.T. Hickey killed himself.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Announcement was made today of the tentative program for the midwinter banking and trust conference of the New Jersey Bankers Association to be held in Trenton on Jan. 18 and 19. Carl K. Withers, president of the association, is trust officer of the First Mechanics National Bank of Trenton.
BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- Voting was abolished in Prussia today by six sweeping laws which centralized the government and introduced the leadership principle into the smallest local unit.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- America has caught the Christmas shopping spirit in the biggest way since 1928, a survey of Chicago business indicated today.

One of the largest commercial leases of the year on the West Side of Manhattan has been closed with the F.W. Woolworth Company, chain-store operators, in the Port Authority Commerce Building at 111 Eighth Avenue.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday. Friday. For the best names...... 1 1/4 % 1 1/4 % The quotations are for three-four months' paper.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The text of the statement issued today by the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council after its organization meeting follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Ways and Means Committee members were hopeful today that basic provisions of a liquor-tax bill would be approved by the committee on Friday.

A 2-year-old Negro boy was fatally injured yesterday morning when his mother leaped with him in her arms from a fourth-floor flat at 20 East 130th Street as smoke billowed up the stairway from a fire three floors below.

For generations the slums of the East Side have been a disgrace to New York -- and to America. The Tenement House Law, the Housing Law and the Multiple Dwelling Law, supplemented by the efforts of a few farsighted men and women, have brought about some improvement.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 -- The largest shopping crowd in four years was written into the chronicle of Cleveland business Saturday.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- The inevitability of inflation if rigorous economy is not begun at once to balance the budget was foreseen by several speakers when the government's finance measures came up for debate before the Senate today. Finance Minister Georges Bonnet and Premier Camille Chautemps replied they would remain "unyielding adversaries of inflation."
HAVANA, Dec. 18 -- Jefferson Caffery, special representative of President Roosevelt in Cuba, arrived in Havana this morning by plane.

The next concert of the Musicians Emergency Fund at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 17 will take the form of a Mendelssohn celebration, Dr. Walter Damrosch announced last night. The grand finale of the concert will be a performance of the wedding march from the "Midsummer Night's Dream" music, for which Mr. Damrosch has written the words.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors made available today $65,000 for current expenses from the county road fund, instead of the $375,000 requested last week by County Treasurer T. Darrington Semple.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh hopped off from Miami at 9:46 A.M. today. Arising early, the couple, who arrived here Saturday after a 900-mile trip from San Pedro de Macoris, Dominican Republic, ate a hearty breakfast and then motored to the international seaplane base.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- The Boerse was dull and generally weaker today. The approach of the Christmas holidays and the impending Reichsbank ruling on the German moratorium kept business at a minimum, while increased pressure on I.G. Farben, attributed to foreign sales, caused professionals to liquidate.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- Ratification of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence deep waterway treaty, pending before the Senate, was opposed as "economic suicide" in a resolution adopted here by 500 delegates from twenty States attending a special conference of the Atlantic Deeper Waterways Association.

Dr. S.C. McLeod of the Ardsley Club was elected president of the Metropolitan Golf Association last night at the annual meeting at the Hotel Commodore. He succeeds Stacey Bender of Shackamaxon, who has presided over the local association for a period of three years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Protest and surprise at the action of the United States delegation at Montevideo in abstaining from support of the equal nationality treaty, approved by other nations at the Pan-American Conference, were expressed today in cable messages to Secretary of State Hull sent by Senators Fess, Hastings and Walcott and by representatives of women's organizations who called this morning on Acting Secretary Phillips at the State Department.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18 -- Eisenberg, now owned and trained by A. G. Tarn, defeated his former stablemate, Flying Don, in the featured race at Jefferson Park today.

Ivar Kreuger's private collection of paintings, silverware and books were viewed by more than 500 persons yesterday at a warehouse at 830 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, where they were placed on exhibition prior to the sale Thursday. The articles were brought from his Manhattan apartment soon after his death in Paris in 1932.

Sinclair Lewis, winner of the Nobel Prize for literature in 1930, last night halted the Nobel centennial dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt for twenty minutes while he retired to his room because he considered he had been insulted by photographers.

THE visitor was without much formality, substituting for it a deeply enthusiastic gleam in the eye and a small gold football dangling on a watch chain. He advanced with simple, straightaway football, dispensing with any attempt at deception.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Describing the lynching of Cord Cheek Friday night as a "disgrace," Governor Hill McAlister today posted $1,000 reward for apprehension of the Negro's slayers, while the county grand jury laid aside all other matters to push "a thorough and complete investigation."

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 18 -- W.G. Merion's Dornoch led home a field of five in the featured West Virginia Purse at the Charles Town track, today. W.I. Newmarch's Vacillate, beaten by four lengths, was second. Another four lengths back, P.S.P. Randolph's Jesting saved the show.

Autograph material of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh is more valuable than that of any other living person. Among celebrities whose autographs compare in value with those of the famous flier are President Roosevelt, ex-President Hoover, Mussolini, Rudyard Kipling and the Prince of Wales, according to Thomas F. Madigan, collector and dealer in autographs.

DUBLIN, Dec. 19. -- General Owen O'Duffy and John O'Sullivan, one of the Blue Shirt adherents arrested with him on Sunday, were brought this evening to Dublin, where they must be produced in the High Court tomorrow morning in compliance with the writ of habeas, corpus obtained by the United Ireland party.

COLOGNE, Dec. 19 -- "Der Heidenkoenig," that one of Siegfried Wagner's three posthumous operas that he is said to have considered his ripest effort, was performed for the first time anywhere at the Cologne opera on Saturday evening in the presence of the composer's widow, Frau Winifred Wagner; her children and numerous government officials.

While Berkeley Bell was among the seeded players to score in easy fashion yesterday, the second round of the metropolitan indoor tennis championship was marked by a hard-fought match in which Dr. Eugene McCauliff. defending titleholder, finally subdued Frank Rericha, the junior star.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- General Johnson declared today that national opinion had veered around behind the NRA in the past two weeks.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Federal Judge George P. Hahn rebuked Willys-Overland Company bondholders today for their attitude toward continued operations at the Toledo plant during the resumption of hearings on the application of the company's receivers to build from 5,000 to 7,000 "Model 77" automobiles.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19. -- The Odessa Farm's Dignified closed with a rush in the featured fifth race at Jefferson Park today to nip Shipp and MacMaster's The Break a few strides from the wire and triumph by a head.

Daily average gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,352,950 barrels, compared with 2,317,750 in the previous week, an increase of 35,200 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 48,450 barrels in Oklahoma and a drop of 7,000 in California were the most important changes.

A meeting of executives of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce was held here yesterday afternoon at the offices of the chamber, 22 East Fortieth Street, as a preliminary to the departure of its representatives for Washington last night, to attend this morning the scheduled hearing on the airplane manufacturers' code before the NRA.

Herman H. Smith, chief engineer of the Board of Estimate, and Deputy Controller Arthur Philbin applied for retirement yesterday. Mr. Philbin has been in the Finance Department since 1918. Mr. Smith began his city service in 1903. Each receives a salary of $10,840 a year.

License Commissioner Sidney Levine moved last night to obtain a contempt citation from the Supreme Court against Stanley Walker, city editor of The New York Herald Tribune, and Jack Beall, reporter, because they refused to disclose the source of a news story dealing with the reported "shaking-down" of newsdealers.

The amendment to the legitimate theatre code affecting dramatists and the sale of motion-picture rights of plays, which was accepted on Monday by the managers, was repudiated yesterday by the board of the Dramatists Guild because the managers had attached thereto a rider providing that the manager would have the option of contracting for a play under the new clause or of dealing with the dramatist under the present basic agreement.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 (AP). -- The Public Service Commission today notified Justice Gilbert C. Schenck of the Supreme Court that it would extend until Jan. 5 its order for a 6 per cent reduction in gas and electric rates in New York City. The reduction was to have become effective Dec. 20.

The New York Stock Exchange was asked yesterday to furnish the State Bureau of Securities with complete data on the trading of the Atlas Tack Corporation stock as Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant State Attorney General, continued his investigation of the market activities of the stock.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 19 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull made a categorical promise today that "no government need fear intervention on the part of the United States under the Roosevelt administration." His statement climaxed an enthusiastic series of pacific demonstrations at the Pan-American Conference.

There are pleasing signs that Washington officials are giving heed more meekly than they did to criticisms of the Government's monetary policy. The truth is that a body of intelligent and disinterested objectors has been built up in such strength that not even General JOHNSON can undertake to whistle it down the wind.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Seven indictments were returned in the Lake County (Ind.) Circuit Court at Crown Point today in connection with the alleged mismanagement of the affairs of the Northern Indiana Public Service Company, which was formed by and for many years under the control of Samuel Insull.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Prosecution of violators of the Home Owners Loan Law who are suspected of soliciting commissions or other irregularities was promised today by the Home Owners Loan Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Crops harvested in 1933 brought $4,076,537,000 on the farm, an Increase of 42 per cent over the $2,879,517,000 of the previous year, according to a final check today by the Department of Agriculture.

After more postponements than the return of prosperity, Owen Davis's "Jezebel" finally turned the corner at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre last evening. This, you will remember, is the Irama in which Tallulah Bankhead had hoped against nope to appear until the state of her health made that definitely impossible.

Albert E. Barrett, 46 years old, of Oak Lane, Morristown, N.J., a traffic manager for the New York Telephone Company, was passing the ten-story office building at 227 Fulton Street at 11 o'clock yesterday morning when a dog fell on his head and knocked him unconscious.

To the Editor of The New York Times: four report of my speech on Soviet recognition, at the Women's National Republican Club on Dec. 15, while in the main admirable, gave an erroneous impression of some of my remarks. I did not make the statement that Soviet Ambassadors were "pieces of window dressing," but merely quoted a Russian authority to that effect.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- A week before the New York opening the Metropolitan Opera gave it first performance of the season here tonight at the Academy of Music. Not since 1908 and 1909 has the company opened out of town The reason for the early date is the fact that the New York season begins next Tuesday because Monday is Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Turning today to the financial collapse in Detroit, the Senate Banking Investigation Committee heard testimony that subsidiary banks of the Guardian Detroit Union Group, Inc., were told by the holding company to continue .

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 19 -- Through the efforts of Julius Kahn, president, now en route home from the Orient, the Truscon Steel Company has amalgamated its steel business in Japan with the Mitsui Company. The two companies will begin a program of expansion soon and expect eventually to produce everything in the steel line required in Japan.

ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- Governor Lehman took steps today to ascertain the reasons for delay in Washington on several Federal aid projects. He directed Dean Carl E. Ladd of the College of Agriculture at Cornell, who also is chairman of his Agricultural Advisory Commission, to enlist the aid of other members of the commission and go to Washington to learn, if possible, why these projects have been held up.

Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia announced last night that his immediate program after his inauguration includes asking the Legislature for legislation to help New York City balance its budget, re-establish its credit, revise the city charter, and reform the magistrates' courts to drive out gangsters and racketeers.

Dr. Laura Virginia Douglas, assistant principal of Public School 159, will read at the Christmas assembly at Hunter College today the world-famous editorial of Francis P. Church, "Is There a Santa Claus?" which appeared in The Sun Sept. 21, 1897.

State of New Jersey. The State of New Jersey announced yesterday that it will enter the market on Dec. 28 at noon with a new issue of $7,000,000 of educational aid bonds. The issue will be dated Jan. 1, 1934, and will mature serially from 1936 to 1942.

On the trip that ended yesterday, Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh bounded an area equivalent to more than a quarter of the world, flew about 29,081 miles over land and water and visited twenty-one countries. They spent about 198 hours in the air, and part of this will be credited officially to Mrs. Lindbergh to make her eligible for a transport pilot's license.

A Fordham quintet that grew increasingly impressive as the game progressed rallied in the final six minutes to wrest a seesaw struggle from Yale, 35 to 29, before a crowd of 4,000 in the Maroon gymnasium last night.
PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Imports into France declined by 3 1/2 per cent for the first eleven months of this year as compared with the same period in 1932, while exports dropped by 6 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 19. -- The National Emergency Council, supreme authority in the emergency and relief activities of the Federal government, held its first meeting at the White House today. Following that meeting Frank C. Walker, executive director, announced that the council would be functioning soon and that State directors, now being chosen, would be called to a meeting here in mid-January.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Jameson and Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Perry Morgan will give a dinner dance at the Central Park Casino on Dec. 28 for their debutante niece, Miss Sarah Morgan Gardner, daughter of Mrs. Henry B. Gardner of Princeton, N.J.

BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- The Boerse responded today to the new reduction in interest payments on Germany's foreign debt with an upward movement which recovered seme of the recent losses. Gains bet-ween 1 and 2 points were frequent and in some cases went beyond 3 points.

A drive by merchants and manufacturers against continuation or increase of the present State sales tax took form here yesterday as the State commission on tax revision, headed by Senator Seabury C. Mastick, met at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The plan advocated by Professor Rogers of Yale whereby the devaluing of the dollar to 50 cents would double the national gold holdings and give the administration an additional $4,000,000,000 sounds to one who is trying to keep both feet on the ground during the present upheaval suspiciously like getting something for nothing.

For the first time since 1929 world trade has shown an Autumn gain by comparison with the previous Spring. On this point a dispatch to THE TIMES from Geneva yesterday quoted figures put out by the League of Nations. They show that the total value of the world's exports and imports in October was 12 per cent above the figure for last April.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The death of the Dalai Lama is expected to cause uneasiness in Russia, China and Great Britain. He was pro-British and there is much anxiety regarding the political leanings of the new monarch.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 19. -- It was announced at the Naval Academy today that Edgar E. (Rip) Miller would be football coach for next year, with the same authority and duties as for the last three seasons.
Several commercial parcels, in addition to the usual housing turnover, were included in the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

More than 2,000 persons assembled yesterday at the Pennsylvania Station to cheer Columbia's football squad on its way to the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., where the Lions will oppose Stanford on New Year's Day. Mayor O'Brien and many persons prominent in sports were on hand to wish the team success.

HAVANA, Dec. 19. -- Jefferson Caffery, representative of President Roosevelt, continued his study of the Cuban situation today. He received American newspaper men at noon, but asked them for information and gave out little for publication.

All the markets seemed to Wall Street yesterday to have lost their capacity, for enthusiasm. There was no one incident in the news which impressed these markets and, as a result no doubt, prices simply wandered up and down, but without ever getting out of the narrow limits to which they were confined early in the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Federal Government began still another experiment today when President Roosevelt ordered the establishment of a corporation to lend money to householders in the Tennessee Valley for the purpose of electrical equipment with which to use electric current generated at Muscle Shoals.

Stocks, bonds and commodities showed little actual progress yesterday after an obviously labored effort to shake off their apathy. The foreign exchange market remained dull, fluctuating within a narrow arc. No one of the markets distinguished itself.
The Detroit Red Wings scored a goal in the first period against the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night, and the tally was enough to bring the visiting skaters victory.

About everything in the way of architectural design from an Egyptian tomb to a modernistic office building was to be found among the hundred drawings presented in the prize competition to demonstrate the possibilities of developing the block front on the east side of Times Square, between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Are our Winters growing warmer, as some of the old folks insist?

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 19. -- The armistice between Bolivia and Paraguay, which goes into effect tonight until Dec. 30 is largely a result of Secretary of State Hull's peace initiative and the patient, persistent manner in which he has worked behind the scenes with the fixed determination that the Pan-American Conference should not adjourn without terminating the Chaco war.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Lord Salisbury celebrated the twenty-first birthday of the controversial question of reform of the House of Lords by obtaining permission of his fellow-peers to introduce a bill on that subject.

Powder Into Peace. Nobel Prize winners at the Alfred Nobel centenary dinner responded to the occasion each after his own fashion. SINCLAIR LEWIS paid tribute to the memory of the inventor of dynamite by exploding in his honor.

Supporters of Jacob A. Livingston are seeking to put him back as Brooklyn Republican leader, it was learned yesterday. They believe that acceptance by F.J.H. Kracke of the post of Commissioner of Plant and Structures from Mayor-elect LaGuardia eventually will lead to his retirement.

In their concert in the Town Hall last night the Dessoff Choirs under Margarets Dessoff sang a first performance anywhere of the contemporary Hugo Herrmann's Choral Variations on St. Francis's "Canticle of the Sum" and a first American performance of "Es kummt ein Schiff geladen," by Conrad Beck.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP). -- In action on their home rink for the first time since Irvin (Ace) Bailey suffered his serious accident, the Boston Bruins tonight defeated the Montreal Maroons, 1 -- 0. It was a tame overtime game that was featured by the sensational play of the rival goalies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Now that the Federal Government has withdrawn from its latest and possibly its greatest failure to stabilize a commodity market, losses of millions of dollars to the dairy industry are revealed.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Japan's new 8,500-ton cruisers will be "by far the most powerfully-armed cruisers in the world for their tonnage," according to the new edition of Jane's Fighting Ships, the authoritative guide to the world's navies, which was published today.

MONTREAL, Dec. 19 -- Creation of a starchless potato has been accomplished through the efforts of Dr. Harold Hibbert, Professor of Industrial and Cellulose Chemistry at McGill University, and Dr. R.F. Suit, Professor of Plant Pathology at MacDonald College.
BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- The wartime logbook of a German submarine was offered today in support of the contention that sea monsters such as that recently reported seen in Loch Ness, Scotland, exist.
"Design for Living" ended its engagement at the Criterion last night. It Is scheduled to reach the Paramount following the engagement of "Alice in Wonderland" at that theatre.
Eight indictments against two officials of two guarantee mortgage companies will be sought before the Queens County Grand Jury today by District Attorney Charles S. Colden.

George McAneny, Controller of the City of New York, was elected president of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company yesterday. He will take office on Jan. 1. He will succeed Joseph V. McKee, who resigned as president of the title company to become a candidate for Mayor of the city in the recent election.

While duck shooting still can be enjoyed on Long Island and in New Jersey, the general season along the North Atlantic coast has ended, and from all indications the predicted shortage of well-known species which customarily come to the region failed to materialize.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 19 -- A wholesale department of the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation was opened here today to partly supersede the present retail branch, which has not been functioning speedily enough to satisfy the authorities.

Several additional conferences on rapid transit unification will be held between himself and representatives of the Interborough and B.M.T. before the Fusion administration takes office on Jan. 1, Mayor-elect LaGuardia declared during a press conference yesterday.

Directors of the Empire Trust Company approved yesterday the plans for recapitalization involving the sale to the RFC of $3,000,000 of capital notes and a write-down of capital and surplus by $3,350,000. The regular dividend of 25 cents a share was declared, payable on Jan. 2 to stock of record Dec. 22.
Contributions of more than $200,000 by Wall Street, to the relief fund of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee were announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the committee.

Representatives of the shipping and trade groups of the New York port district submitted yesterday afternoon charges of intimidation and improper practices among freight loaders on the waterfront piers, to a committee of the New York Shipping Association meeting at 80 Broad Street.

For her twin tennis achievements in saving the Wightman Cup for the United States with a deciding singles victory and then dethroning her famous rival, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, for the American championship, Miss Helen Hull Jacobs wins the acclaim of the nation's sports observers as the outstanding woman performer of 1933.

Professional dealers, a multitude of the curious and a sprinkling of celebrities attended the auction of Texas Guinan's personal property which began yesterday at 24 West Fifty-eighth Street. Housewives chortled when they got such bargains as garish floor lamps for a dollar, or cigarette boxes for 50 and 75 cents.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 19. -- The international law committee's approval today of the Cuban recogntion and non-intervention project was the first major parliamentary defeat for the United States delegation since the Pan-American Conference opened.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP). -- The football program of Villanova College for 1934 was announced today by Alexander G. Severance, graduate manager of athletics. It names eight opponents, and a ninth may be added later.
Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence Johnston of this city and Cape Vincent, N.Y., gave a supper dance last night in the ballroom of the Pierre for their debutante daughter, Miss Jane Brooks Johnston.
Purchase of a Manhattan business building by an operator and an apartment house deal in the Bronx featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

HAVANA, Dec. 19. -- One man was killed and four were gravely wounded today in riots following a strike of commercial employes in protest against the recent decree calling for the employment of 50 per cent of native Cuban labor in all concerns.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The Daily Mail's Bengal correspondent said tonight he was informed from a usually reliable source that the Dalai Lama was poisoned.

The police sent out a confidential message over the teletype system at 2:32 o'clock this morning saying that Jesse L. Livermore, the stock market operator, of 1,100 Park Avenue, was missing and had not been seen since 3 P.M. yesterday.

A cross-section of the city's employment agencies reported yesterday a general increase in available jobs. In some fields, notably among domestic servants, there were more jobs than applicants. Among office employes, stenographers seemed most in demand.

Acting on the series of chemical analyses by which it established during the last few days that distilleries were taking liberties with the name of whisky, the Board of Health yesterday amended the Sanitary Code and made it the law of this city that labels on all whisky sold here after Jan. 5 shall show definitely what is in the bottle.

The St. John's University varsity basketball team upset Providence College, 43 to 31, and snapped the Rhode Island five's winning streak of fourteen consecutive games before a capacity crowd in the De-Gray Gymnasium in Brooklyn last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Roosevelt, in an executive order, today bestowed on the National Labor Board the authority he proposed for it when he created it in a statement at his Hyde Park home in August.
PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Chancellor Hitler sent a definite rearmament program to the French Government today, but the revised demands failed to change the Franco-German deadlock.

Eleven properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were sold at auction yesterday. In each case the plaintiff was the successful bidder. Church and Prince Street parcels were among those involved in the auctions. Two scheduled sales were put off to later dates.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 19. -- Jubilation and thanksgiving pervaded the Pan-American Conference today over the eleven-day armistice halting seventeen months of conflict between the armies of Bolivia and Paraguay in the Gran Chaco. It is felt there is little likelihood of renewal of the struggle that already has cost 100,000 lives.

After having declined on Monday, when Washington raised the gold quotation, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday as the gold figure remained unchanged and distant months more than recovered recent losses. Although prices eased at one time, trade calling developed as March approached the 10-cent level and closing buying for mill account brought the best figures of the day in the final trading.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 19 (AP). -- Eddie Dowling, Broadway actor, was mentioned today in circles close to the administration, as a likely successor to William D.L. Star-buck of New York, as Federal Radio Commissioner for the Eastern zone.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with great interest that part of your editorial in THE TIMES of Dec. 15 advocating a change in the present park system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Employment decreased 28,000 and weekly payrolls $9,000,000 between Oct. 15 and Nov. 15, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, reported today. She pointed out that declines were usual at this season of the year.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Production of lumber in 1934 for the continental United States was set at. 5,076,000,000 feet, approximately 1,000,000 feet more than the estimated consumption for the year, by the National Control Committee of the Lumber Code Authority of the NRA, meeting here today.

Babe Ruth of the Yankees appeared in only 137 games this past season, but, on the official records released yesterday, still remained the most-respected batsman in the American League. He received 114 bases on balls from opposing pitchers.

A proposal for clearing congested court calendars by appointing for an emergency period official referees to try all cases pending on the calendar for three months or more was adopted last night at a meeting of the Federal Bar Association at the Hotel Commodore.

Mrs. Lyman Candee gave a dinner last night in the Tapestry Room of the Park Lane to celebrate her husband's birthday. The other guests were Mrs. H. Martin Smith, Mrs. Sheppard Plimpton, Mrs. Cave-Cole, Mrs. Martie J. Post, Miss Bessie Ballin, Dr. Ira L. Hill, Henry E. Simmons, John J. Thompson, Dr. Hubert Noel of London and Henry T. Leggett.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The self-appointed legal commission of inquiry into the burning of the Reichstag reassembled here today after two months to hear a report on the Leipzig trial by Gaston Bergery, French Socialist Deputy.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Republican members of the Assembly are arriving here tonight in an angry mood to attend the unofficial caucus, called for tomorrow, when preparations will be made for an airing of charges that the lower house under its present Republican leadership has been subservient to the power interests.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 19. -- Albert A. Baronl's Cash Surrender was barely able to gain a head decision over Mrs. Kathleen Jesberger's Croon in the featured event at Epsom Downs today. Gene D. was third.

TRENTON, Dec. 19. -- The public schools of New Jersey offer both the best and the worst to be found in educational programs throughout the United States, according to a section of the New Jersey School Survey Commission report made public here today.

The spicy, holiday tang of balsamfir trees piled up before thousands of stores serves to remind juvenile New Yorkers that, weather notwithstanding, Christmas is only a few days away. In the past week carload upon carload of Christmas trees, piled high on flat cars, have arrived in the New York market and have been distributed to the retail dealers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- John Dickinson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, led a seven-hour attack before the Ways and Means Committee today on some of the proposals of that body's subcommittee for tightening the revenue law against income tax evasion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Trade in grains today was at a minimum on the Board of Trade, the pre-holiday dullness being accentuated by the desire to even up for the government's final estimate of this year's crops, which was announced later in the day.

Heartly (Hunk) Anderson, who resigned recently as coach of the Not Dame football team, would be willing to accept the post of head coach at City College if it were offered him, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 19. -- Messages of congratulations of the favorable action taken at Montevideo on the equal nationality treaty and protest against the attitude toward it of the American delegation continued to arrive today at the headquarters here of the National Woman's party.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Dec. 20. -- The condition of Irvin (Ace) Bailey, Toronto hockey player, was reported "about the same: if anything a little better," in a bulletin issued at the Boston City Hospital at 1 A.M. today.

LA PAZ, Dec. 19. -- The truce with Paraguay, which, becomes effective at midnight tonight, has brought little change in the atmosphere here. Fear is expressed that the Paraguayan claims on the disputed Chaco territory may prove obstacles to a pacific settlement.
The Manhattan basketball team scored a 44-17 victory over Cathedral College in the Manhattan gymnasium last night. The triumph brought to an end the threegame losing streak of the Jaspers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Dec. 19 -- Emilia Da Prato, a 26-year-old singer who won a high place in the Atwater Kent national radio audition contest in 1927, was shot and killed in her South San Francisco home today by a jealous press agent suitor.

Communists staged another protest yesterday against German fascism and the "farcical Reichstag fire trial" outside of the offices of the German Consulate at 17 Battery Place. The police estimated the number of the demonstrators at more than 3,000.

BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- German official interest in the exchange of diplomatic conversations between London and Paris may be said to have lapsed into a state of listless curiosity. Chancellor Hitler, who has personally assumed direction of the Reich's major foreign policies, has left for his Bavarian estate, where he will remain over the holidays.
City officeholders who have been counting on their special privileges as war veterans to keep their jobs after the change of administrations next month received a partial setback yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The State Department was trying today to settle the difficulties surrounding the increase in the French liquor import quota so that negotiations might proceed with other nations seeking to help meet the demand for alcoholic beverages in the United States.

The New York Stock Exchange firm of Boettcher, Newton Co. will segregate its investment business from its commission business on Dec. 28, it was announced yesterday. The present firm will be reorganized with headquarters at 52 Wall Street, under the same name, and a firm, to be known as Boettcher Co., with headquarters in Denver, will be formed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- In a final effort to determine whether the President would be able to report to Congress a budget which would not call for an increase in the public debt, officials sought today to estimate emergency expenditures for the next fiscal year.

Approval of 3,853 civil works projects providing jobs for 362,329 unemployed was announced yesterday by the State Civil Works Administration through Frederick I. Daniels, executive director. In addition to these civil works projects the administration approved Civil Works Service projects for 31,194 persons.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 19 (AP). -- A lien against Arthur Hopkins, husband of Doris Kenyon, the actress, for $47,398.10 back income taxes was filed here today by Frank J. Shaughnessy, Federal collector of internal revenue.

SAINTSBURY found some exceedingly good claret in Edinburgh, when he lived there. The eighteenth-century tradition had survived. A correspondent of The London Times has dug up a record of the "festive Meetings" of the Edinburgh Assurance Company. In 1836 twenty diners were contented with thirty-four bottles of wine, in 1837 twenty-two finished thirty-six.

James C. Penney, chain-store operator, was named here yesterday as defendant in a suit for an accounting filed in United States District Court by a committtee of depositors of the City National Bank in Miami, which was closed on Dec. 22, 1930.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 19 (AP). -- Charles A. Plumley, retiring president of Norwich Unniversity, was nominated by the Republicans of Vermont today as their candidate for the seat in the United States House of Representatives left vacant by the appointment of Representative Ernest W. Gibson, Republican, to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation price for newly mined domestic gold remained at $34.06 an ounce today, and although the White House carefully guarded its plans, the more general belief in official circles was that no new move of major importance was in prospect, at least before the assembling of Congress on Jan. 3. At that time it is expected that the President will report on his accomplishments.

Sweeping reforms in the city's prison system, notably the placing of a trained penologist at the head of the Correction Department and purging the department of political control, were advocated yesterday by Joseph Fulling Fishman, Deputy Commissioner of Correction.
Pennant winners in their league, the Washington Senators also came through as the season's fielding champions and annexed a few individual titles as well, the official records just released reveal.
The long arm of the law collared "Mutt and Jeff' last night.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 19 (AP). -- Southern manufacturers approved resolutions today urging adoption of wage differentials existing in Southern industries prior to July, 1929, and asking that the South obtain representation in the preparation of codes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Forbes Watson, technical director of the Public Works art project recently formulated for inclusion in the Civil Works program, announced today the creation of sixteen territorial areas, with committee headquarters established at a central point in each region.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 19 -- A 2 per cent retail sales tax, designed to yield about $35,000,000 a year and to supplant the present State school, road and soldier bonus taxes, will be recommended to the 1934 Legislature.

Charley Massera, Pittsburgh heavyweight, furnished an upset by out-pointing Maxie Rosenbloom of New York, who holds the world's light heavyweight championship, in the feature bout of ten rounds last night at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn.

The Westchester women's squash racquets team yesterday defeated New York and New Jersey in the third and final meeting in the metropolitan intergroup competition. The matches were played at the Cosmopolitan Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Mrs. Roosevelt was the honor guest at luncheon today of Mrs. Swanson, wife of the Secretary of the Navy, who entertained at her home in R Street at the fourth in the series of Cabinet luncheons given annually for the President's wife.

Representatives of all the more than 160 banks in Greater New York will meet on Friday in the auditorium of the Federal Reserve Bank to discuss the adoption of a code of fair practices under the NRA. A draft of the code, drawn up by the Greater New York Bankers NRA Committee under the chairmanship of Merrel P. Callaway, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, was submitted to the banks on Monday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 19 (AP). -- A 50 per cent increase in the number of drinking places in New York State was predicted today by Captain John B. Judson, executive director of the State Alcoholic Beveral Control Board, as a result of modification of the regulation which prohibited licensing of restaurants in business less than a year.
Declines in prices continued yesterday on local commodity exchanges, although a firmer undertone was apparent late in the day. For the most part a pre-holiday dullness characterized trading.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler reserved decision yesterday on an application to dismiss the suit by the Bush Terminal Corporation, the New York Dock Company and other warehouse and terminal corporations to declare invalid the statute permitting the Fort of New York Authority to pay $60,064 to the City of New York in lieu of taxes on the inland freight terminal at Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- The dollar fell from yesterday's closing of 16.21 francs to 16.14 but closed stronger at 16.17 when it had become known that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had not increased the gold rate today.

Senator BORAH is at least consistent in filing with Secretary ICKES strong objections to the pooling agreement within the oil industry. He holds that it will lead straight to monopolistic control by the larger companies. They would be able, under the proposed rules, not only to fix prices and allotments, but to punish those who do not submit to this kind of regulation, as well as absolutely to wipe out independent companies.

Because of the recently disclosed connection of Waxey Gordon, convicted racketeer, and the Hotel Piccadilly, 227 West Forty-fifth Street, the hotel's application for a liquor license was disapproved yesterday by the City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

A radical change in the present probation system of the magistrates' courts was announced yesterday by Chief Magistrate James E. McDonald. The reform involves a shift of all probation bureaus to a central building in Manhattan and a redivision of the work of probation officers.

The Marie Harriman Gallery's fourth annual exhibition of work by American artists is now on. It is an attractive group display, perhaps the best of the American series as presented thus far at this gallery. The immediate impact is exhilarating, and while some of the paintings seem of little account, others reward the special study they invite.

Buyers' Registrations Off. The number of buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a decrease in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. The total, however, remained ahead of the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- George J. Schaller, a banker in Storm Lake, Iowa, has been elected acting governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, effective on Jan. 1, it was announced today. The leave of absence of James B. McDougal, governor of the bank since its founding in 1914, has been extended until next March. Mr. McDougal was forced to give up active duty last March because of ill health.

Efforts to have the P.S.A.L. conduct competition in football in 1935 were defeated at the December meeting of the high schools games committee of the P.S.A.L. yesterday at the Hotel Astor. A proposal to that effect was presented at the November meeting', but was beaten, 19 to 10, when it came up for a vote yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Patronagre worth $28,050 was distributed at meetings of the steering committees of both houses which followed the conference. Essex County was successful in not only obtaining the appointment of an assistant secretary of the Senate at $1,200, but also in the House received the appointment of William S. Cantaloupo of Newark as assistant secretary at $1,200, bill supervisor at $I,300, sergeant-at-arms at $700, and assistant supervisor at $600.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Alderman Mathias Hauler of the Forty-third Ward was charged tonight with assault with intent to murder Policeman John J. Ahearn, whom he shot and wounded in front of Bauler's Tavern early today.

FLINT, Mich., Dec. 19. -- General Motors was placed behind President Roosevelt's recovery program "to the fullest extent" by William S. Knudson, executive vice president in charge of all car and body building operations, in a speech here tonight.

The names of the members of the eleven contract bridge teams of four Which have won regional championships of the United States Bridge Association and thereby qualified for the grand national championship of the association, which will be held at the Hotel Pierre the week beginning Jan. 8, were announced yesterday.
Depleted this year in numbers, but not in generosity, friends of the Neediest responded yesterday to the appeal with the greatest outpouring of contributions so far this year.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies held the largest rally in its history last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. Twenty-five hundred persons, including leaders in many professions, attended the opening of the "minute appeal" which will close the organization's drive for $4,200,000.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19. -- News of the Japanese-Manchu advance on Kalgan, which is the key to the Chinese-Mongolian frontier, was on the front page of today's Pravda. This accords with a forecast in a NEW YORK TIMES dispatch a week ago that the Soviet expected some such move by the Japanese.

MANY odd and curious events come to pass in baseball -- in and out of season. Varied are the reasons ascribed to them. Charitably, some of the critics regard them as a force of circumstances. Less charitably, others rather acrimoniously consider the matter an outgrowth of crass stupidity and a rock-ribbed conservatism which seems to imbue the very soul of a man once he becomes attached to professional baseball in an executive capacity.

The State of New York was informed officially of the dire straits in which repressive legislation has left horse racing here by the report of the New York State Racing Commission, which was made public yesterday by Secretary Joseph A. Reilly.

It is significant that Major LAGUARDIA, without even waiting for the obsequies, should plunge immediately into the transit problem inherited from the O'Brien administration. If city finances are his chief responsibility, unification of existing subway and elevated lines, public and private, offers one of the likeliest means of bringing about an easier, financial situation.

BERLIN, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Admiral Friedrich von Ingenohl, who was chief of Germany's High Seas Fleet for a period during the World War and who commanded a squadron in the battle of Heligoland Bight, died today at the age of 76.

BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- The first session of the newly created Foreign Trade Council opened today with speeches by Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, and Dr. Kurt Schmitt, the Minister of Economics, which besides emphasizing the importance of the occasion stressed the vital necessity for further measures to bolster up Germany's sinking export trade.

To the Editor of The New York Times . It is a little insulting to our community intelligence to have a body called Enonomic Council tell us so often and so much about the virtuous educational economies of Fall River. We have in New York City 7,000,000 people as against the 120,000 of Fall River.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Two proposals seriously advanced by Presidential advisers but not yet cards in the new deal are giving great concern to many people in this country. One is the plan to regulate profits and fix prices in an effort to eliminate the deep valleys of boom years and the great peaks of prosperity.

United States Government bonds and domestic corporation issues finished irregularly lower and foreign loans irregularly higher yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading totaled $13,013,500, compared with $10,592,000 on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The texts of the statement issued by the White Bottle today and of Executive orders bearing on the National Emergency Council read as follows:
Miss Joyce Bell, New York University freshman, went to her classes yesterday unescorted by the guard who was assigned to her several days ago after threatening notes had been left in her locker.

Kay Francis, motion picture actress, and her husband, Kenneth MacKenna, actor and director, are "amicably separating" they announced yesterday through the office here of Warner Brothers, to which company they are both under contract.

Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia announced yesterday the appointment of Frederick J.H. Kracke, chairman of the Kings County Republican Committee, as Commissioner of Plant and Structures and the selection of his personal staff.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- A full written report on the German Government's proposals regarding Germany's part in any armaments convention, for the future of the Saar and for a ten-year non-aggression pact with France is now in the possession of the Quai d'Orsay.

David Owens, 33 years old, who donned huge overalls to secrete more than $7,000 in furs and other garments he had stolen from stores, was sentenced to prison yesterday by General Sessions Judge Donellan for not more than three years. He had pleaded guilty specifically to the theft of a $795 mink coat last January from Lord Taylor.

The groundwork has been laid through the NRA for a sweeping business advance, which can be accelerated by the cohesive efforts of the leaders in industry, finance and trade, A.D. Whiteside, Deputy NRA Administrator, said yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor at the Hotel Astor by the American Arbitration Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The National Labor Board intends to set a hearing date early in January on a group of cases reported to it by the New York Regional Labor Board, which will appear as complainant against the firms cited because of their alleged refusal to carry out decisions of the National Labor Board.

Swimming seventy-five feet from shore in the cold waters of the Harlem River at 126th Street. Joseph Capo of 170 East 111th Street, a truck driver, yesterday rescued from drowning Alfredo Ferrari, 43 years old, of 330 West Nineteenth Street.
Cathedral Boys High and De La Salle Institute yesterday triumphed in their opening New York division games in the C.H.S.A.A. basketball competition.

Armed with an opinion by Samuel Untermyer supporting their complaint, representatives of bookstores in this city appeared before the Retail Code Authority at NRA headquarters. 45 Broadway, yesterday and demanded relief from what they termed the ruinous competition of department stores that are selling books at or below cost.
Tammany offered the olive branch yesterday to the hostile Bronx Aldermen who have threatened to ally themselves with the incoming Fusion Aldermen to obtain control of the board.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh came home yesterday after an absence of five months and ten days and 30,000 miles of flying. They alighted in the East River off College Point at 2:38 P.M., taxied ashore at the ramp of an aircraft company and less than an hour later left by automobile for their home.

Major LAGUARDIA'S speech at the Citizens Budget Commission dinner was delivered without notes, but not without premeditation. The Mayorelect has done much thinking on the difficult municipal problems that will at once confront his administration, and his address showed it.

Aboard the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg when she sailed for Germany shortly before last midnight was Ignatz Westenkirchner, unemployed carpenter and wood carver; his wife and their three children. Westenkirchner was bound back to the Fatherland at Chancellor Hitler's expense, with the promise of a job in the Nazi Brown House in Munich.
HAVANA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Widespread shooting broke out in Havana tonight. Snipers perched on roofs and gunmen in speeding automobiles began shooting at soldiers.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, En Route to the Antarctic, Dec. 20 -- At noon today the flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition was barely a day's steaming from the edge of the unknown waters encircling the Pacific quadrant of Antarctica.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 20 -- The government's electoral success today exceeded expectations. In Bucharest 52 per cent of the votes went to the Liberals. The National Peasant party is the strongest opposition group, but it falls far behind the government.

The Queens grand jury in Long Island City yesterday indicted Oscar Jacobs, president of the Long Island Title Guarantee Company of Jamaica and former vice president of the Sunrise National Bank of Baldwin, L.I., on six counts charging forgery in the third degree and illegal borrowing from his own company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A decentralization of the process of interpreting Federal Reserve law was ordered by the Reserve Board today, Federal Reserve agents being instructed to act as interpreters for the member banks on the meaning of intricate features of the act.

The holiday exodus began yesterday with an appreciable, if slight, increase in the number of trains, buses and passengers moving through the city's terminals. The migration will gather momentum today and reach its peak on Saturday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20 -- Princeton's towering basketball team defeated Harvard, 49 to 19, in the opening Eastern Intercollegiate League game for the Nassau quintet and the first home league game for the Crimson tonight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20 -- Taking first and second places in each event, the Harvard varsity swimming team easily defeated M. I.T., 64 to 7, in a dual meet tonight. Two record-breaking performances by the victors featured the competition.

The proposed 2 per cent retail sales tax and the State liquor authority plan as means of broadening the tax base to relieve real estate owners were recommended yesterday to the State Commission on Tax Revision by Joseph W. Catharine, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Labor will ask Congress to create a Federal Railroad Credit Corporation and thereby "remove the banker" from the field of railroad financing, so that $2,000,000,000 of refinancing may be completed "without profit" in the next two years.

"Is there not in New York City or environs a family (or individual) who would enjoy giving a 'Merry Christmas' to two splendid Christian boys, aged 16 and 13, on scholarship in boarding school? The mother, a widow, is at present without a home and is financially unable to provide for them during the Christmas recess, Z 2659 Times Annex."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- News from Montevideo that the United States would sign the nationality treaty was received with rejoicing here today by a deputation from the National Woman's Party which went to the State Department to protest against the attitude of the American delegation, only to find on arrival that the occasion was one for an exchange of congratulations.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 20 -- In a decision filed today, Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink granted an injunction retraining the City Council of the city of Long Beach from receiving bids for the collection and disposal of garbage and ashes of the city and from accepting any contract with respect to such services.

Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo, who is endeavoring to clear eighty-nine matrimonial cases from the Bronx Supreme Court calendar before Christmas, freed four alimony prisoners from the county jail yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 20 -- The United States will sign the treaty guaranteeing equal nationality rights to women, Secretary of State Cordull Hull announced today at the Pan-American conference. The signature will be accompanied by a reservation providing "that agreement of the United States is, of course and of necessity, subject to Congressional action.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- For the first time in fifteen years all the Rockefellers will be together at Pocantico Hills this Christmas, because of the illness of John D. Rockefeller Sr.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The House of Representatives, according to a tentative program agreed upon by the Democratic leaders, is likely to pass the liquor tax bill in the first few days of the session.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, following the course of stocks, and relatively little rallying power was disclosed after stop-loss orders started to be uncovered.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Traditional German Protestantism today delivered a broadside attack on the authority of Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller by demanding the immediate reconstruction of his ecclesiastical ministry or cabinet and guarantees that he would defend the purity of the faith and eliminate politics from the Reich Evangelical Church.

Joseph Fulling Fishman, Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Correption, announced yesterday his resignation, effective Dec. 31. In a statement explaining his action, Mr. Fishman declared that Commissioner Wilbur Wright, recently appointed by Mayor O'Brien, had "resented so much my recommendations for reform in economies of personnel and operation."

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The Prince of Wales was installed today as Master of the Amalgamated Company of Stationers and Newspaper Makers and later at Stationers Hall applauded the members upon the successful union of the two companies, of which the Newspaper Makers was only recently formed.

The Britannica Bookshop, which opens a new Fifth Avenue branch today in the British Empire Building, Radio City, has had privately printed a limited edition of Clement C. Moore's "The Night Before Christmas." The book consists of a facsimile of a sixteen-page illustrated pamphlet containing the poem, published here in 1848, and a brief biography of Clement Clarke Moore written by Arthur N. Hosking.

While Henry Ford has refused to associate himself with the NRA, Ford dealers throughout the county, apparently acting under instructions from Detroit, are leadingill others in NRA activity and the speed and spontaneity of their compliance with the motor vehicle retail code, according to an announcement yesterday by John B. Hulett, code administrator for the metropolitan district.

Berkeley Bell, ranking player in the tourney, gained the quarterfinal round of the metropolitan indoor tennis championship yesterday by virtue of a straight-set triumph over Joe Abrams, De Witt Clinton High School captain, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The police revealed tonight that the arrest of R. G. Switz and nine other alleged spies was brought about by the discovery of Soviet espionage in Finland, in connection with which Arvid Jacobson and his wife, formerly of Detroit, Mich., were arrested with eighteen others last October.
STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Dec. 20 (AP) -- For the first time in seven years the Herbert Hoovers will spend Christmas in their own home here.
The last of Texas Guinan's personal possessions were auctioned off yesterday in the final sessions of the two-day sale at the auction rooms at 24 West Fifty-eighth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Prime Minister MacDonald announced in the House of Commons today that the famous fourth-century Bible, the Codex Sinaiticus, formerly owned by the Czars, would be purchased from the Soviet Government for more than $500,000 for the British Museum.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 20 -- The seventh Pan-American Conference narrowly escaped going on the rocks with a bang this afternoon on Paraguay's announcement of the capture of Fort Munoz and three other forts yesterday. Casto Rojas and Arturo Escalier of Bolivia were indignant, contending it was a tacit even if not a legal violation of the armistice that has been arranged.

Prices for commodity futures traded on the local Exchanges again moved in a relatively narrow range yesterday, with the trend irregularly lower. Trading volumes remained at the recent low levels. Cash prices were also lower in most instances.

Officers and committees of the American Power Boat Association were named last night at a meeting of the executive council held in the Hotel Lexington. It was decided also to give more power to the association's racing commission, or put more teeth in the racing rules.

SAK FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- Victory at the California polls for the Central Valley water project, involving a bond issue of $170,000,000, was indicated, today with returns from 7,451 precincts out of the 8,095 in yesterday's referendum showing 431,482 favorable and 403,921 unfavorable votes.

Rulings by the Federal Reserve Board, with respect to the right of individuals in the securities business to serve as directors of banks which are members of the Federal Reserve System, under the terms of the Banking Act of 1933, indicate that membership in a stock exchange does not make it necessary to apply for special permission to be a director.

A plan to establish graduate chapters of Phi Beta Kappa throughout the country, in addition to its collegiate chapters, was adopted at the annual meeting of the Phi Beta Kappa senate yesterday at the society's headquarters, 145 West Fifty-fifth Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief dismissed today the action brought by Mrs. Dorothy Furry of New Rochelle as a taxpayer to stop the pay of City Manager John F. Donovan, George I. Roberts Sr. and John F. Manning, departmental directors.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 -- The seventh victory in nine starts fell to the North Star III filly Betty Farrell in the featured race at Jefferson Park today. She came on near the end of the live and onehalf furlong route to win easily by a length and a half in 1:06 4-5.

Robert Gustav Blumenthal, former president of the Commercial Factors Corporation, who died suddenly last Jan. 14 after participating in a polo game, left an estate appraised yesterday at $741,735 gross and $647,546 net, of which $509,025 was in securities.

Charter memberships in the new, all-year-round club, the In-Town Country Club, which will open soon at 4 East Seventieth Street, are nearly fully subscribed, Pierre L. Willis, managing director of the organization, announced yesterday.
CROWN POINT, Ind., Dec. 20 -- Mr. Dell Plain and two others of the seven defendants indicted here surrendered tonight to Sheriff Lillian Holley of Lake County. They were released on bond.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 -- Casa Pequena, their Golf View Road villa, was the scene tonight for a dinner followed by contract bridge at which Dr. and Mrs. Edmund Le Roy Dow were hosts. The guests were Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr., Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Henry Kroger, Mr. and Mrs. William R. Sweatt, Mrs. James H. Kennedy and Mrs. Elden C. DeWitt.

Two cases in which newsdealers were said to have been victims of extortion in connection with their permits were laid before License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine yesterday by his Chief Inspector, Samuel H. Martin. Mr. Levine is conducting an inquiry into charges of "shake-downs" allegedly done while James F. Geraghty, Bronx district leader, was the commissioner.

The City Athletic Club and Columbia University Club squash tennis teams remained deadlocked for second place in the Metropolitan Class A league by triumphing yesterday. Each has won four games and lost one.

WOODBRIDGE, Dec. 20 -- Jack Humes, 48 years old, of Sewaren, was instantly killed and Mrs. H. J. Lewis of Woodbridge was fatally injured tonight when a car in which they were riding was struck by a Pennsylvania train at Woodbridge.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- When Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Secretary, arrives here tomorrow he may expect to be met with every possible objection on every point in the German proposals, which the London Cabinet is reported to have found by no means unacceptable.
The self-sacrificing generosity with which friends of the Neediest are striving to meet this year's unusual demands had telling effect yesterday.
The United States Bureau of Home Economics makes its Christmas contribution by telling those who fill baskets of food for the needy what to put into them. The general advice as to types of food is:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Roosevelt, commenting on news from Montevideo that the Western Hemisphere is again at peace after seventeen months' warfare, told newspaper men today he felt very happy that the Chaco dispute had at last been settled.

VIENNA, Dec. 20 -- Protests have been made at the United States Legation here concerning an alleged effort of the Austrian Government to prevent an American film company from showing outside Austria a film telling the love story of a Hapsburg.

Setting a blistering pace in the final period, New York University's basketball team, in its opening game of the season, came from behind to defeat St. Francis College of Brooklyn, 28 to 18, in the University Heights gym last night. The visitors led throughout the opening period and held a 16-to-15 margin at half time.

The directors of the Chase National Bank discussed yesterday at their weekly meeting the question of selling preferred stock of the bank to the RFC, but deferred action pending the results of further conferences between the bank's officers and the RFC.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Not until yesterday, when it was just six months old, did the Tennessee Valley Authority get much attention from those who have been trying to follow the dizzy pace of the administration. People in the South have been definitely conscious of the Authority.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- The "foreclosure rebellion" of Sonoma County farmers culminated in the killing of a money lender and the suicide of his slayer here today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I saw in your issue of Dec. 14 the statement of Commissioner Bolan to the effect that he is ready to put a policeman on any brewery or distillery truck upon request.

A pamphlet issued by the Vocational Guidance Bureau of the Heckscher Foundation has been disavowed by August Heckscher, following protests by the New York Academy of Medicine and the Medical Society of the County of New York on an article on chiropractic in the pamphlet, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- E.V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, famous American war ace, warned against aerial unpreparedness at a public hearing today on the proposed code of fair competition for the aircraft manufacturing industry.

The New York Retail Code Authority, of which Grover A. Whalen is chairman, made yesterday a ruling prohibiting the 50,000 merchants under its jurisdiction from deducting from their employes' salaries for time off because of holiday closings.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- Mrs. Emily Tapscott Balch, author and painter and widow of Edwin S. Balch, explorer, talked two armed robbers out of walking from her home today with her collection of antique silverware.

The church pension fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church made pension payments to 2,200 beneficiaries this year that totaled almost $1,100,000, William Fellowes Morgan, president of the fund, says in his annual report to the trustees, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Government financing of the national recovery program has been an important influence on bank reserves, credit and deposits in recent months, according to the Federal Reserve Board's monthly bulletin issued today.

The reorganization plan of the Altoona Logan Valley Electric Railway Company has been modified to eliminate a proposed holding company, the protective committee headed by J.C. Neff announced yesterday, and depositing bondholders have until Jan. 2 to file dissents in writing from the amended plan and to withdraw deposited bonds upon payment of their pro rata share of committee expenses.

Abolition of the tipping system in restaurants and its replacement by a minimum wage rate of $30 for a forty-five-hour week to be fixed by the NRA code for the restaurant industry was proposed yesterday by the local joint executive board of the New York unions of waiters and other restaurant workers.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- By watching the activities of a 29-year-old American, Robert Gordon Switz of East Orange, N.J., French political police succeeded in identifying and apprehending today members of what is said to be a Europe-wide spy organization.

A powerful right-hand punch carried Al Demedowitz to the heavyweight championship of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. last night at Madison Square Garden. Opposing James Alba, sturdy young Bronx warrior, in the final round of the unlimited weight class, Demedowitz landed only one heavy blow, but that was enough to bring him victory and the title.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad is considering borrowing 55,000,000 from the Public Works Administration to finance repairs and improvements to equipment and the purchase of rails, Daniel Willard, president, said yesterday. Part of the loan might be used for airconditioning additional passenger cars, he said.

Ambitious programs of the Civil Works Administration and of the incoming city administration to aid in improving living conditions in the slum districts of New York were outlined to the members of the New York Building Congress at a luncheon meeting yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A Presidential executive order again departed from all established form today to express a personal note when President Roosevelt directed extension of the holiday season for the benefit of Federal employes who have been working, often overtime, in the departments and bureaus here.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- All Jews, with the possible exception of front-line war veterans, and all "Marxists" without exception will be barred from editorial or illustrative work for any German newspaper or magazine, beginning Jan. 1, according to the rules of procedure announced today for the press law recently decreed.
Continuance of purchases by an operator and several leasehold deals were included in the Manhattan realty activity reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Governor Lehman commuted the sentences of ten convicts today, whose pleas he had considered while on a sick bed, including Paul Chapman, convicted in February, 1918, of first-degree murder in Brooklyn, whose sentence of death was commuted to life imprisonment by Governor Whitman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The text of the certificate of incorporation of the federal Surplus Relief Corporation, as filed in Delaware, is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Secretary Wallace came to grips with the dairy industry today when the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation accused him of being responsible for the collapse of butter prices in the last two weeks.

Limit of Blue-Prints. Architects from all parts of the country submitted plans in a prize competition for the improvement of an entire Times Square blockfront. The purpose was to increase the income yield of the property.

The names of Mr. and Mrs. Ludlow Ogden Smith were omitted from the Philadelphia Social Register of 1934, it was disclosed yesterday. Mrs. Smith is known professionally as Katharine Hepburn, and recently has attracted wide attention through her performances on the stage and screen.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 20 -- Operating at a loss of $53,029 for the fiscal year ended last June 30, the Princeton University Athletic Association reports in its annual financial statement that It now has a total deficit of $185,471. The report appears in the current issue of The Princeton Alumni Weekly.

The National League of Women Voters' opposition to the equal nationality rights treaty now under consideration at the Pan-American Conference in Montevideo is based on its belief that the treaty is a "very nice expression of principle but means absolutely nothing."

Jesse L. Livermore returned to his triplex apartment at 1,100 Park Avenue at 6:15 yesterday evening, after an absence of twenty-six hours in which Federal, State and city authorities had been investigating theories of amnesia, suicide and kidnapping.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Secretary Ickes ordered today an immediate inquiry into the price of crude oil.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Roosevelt was described today as favoring a legislative plan incorporating a proposal to assess a "stamp tax" against duck hunters to provide $1,000,000 a year to be used for the creation of reserves to preserve wild fowl.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- An unexpected psychological effect of the government's wheat acreage reduction program was seen today in the Bureau of Agricultural Economics report of Winter wheat sown for harvest next Summer.

A dinner with dancing was given last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis by Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor for their nieces, the Misses Barbara and Marie Louise Southwick, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Southwick of Shelter Island Heights, N.Y.

Creation of a nation-wide banking system under the control of uniformly operating banking authorities, the increase of banks' minimum capital requirements from $50,000 to $500,000, and the modification of the banking guaranty plan and the Securities Act were urged last night by James P. War burg in an address at the Hotel Astor.

Julius Lehrenkrauss, head of a number of corporations bearing his name and located at 359 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, testified yesterday at a hearing under the bankruptcy laws into the activities of the concerns directed by him that he had withdrawn $1,900 from the firm because he "was looking for the future."

CROWN POINT, Ind., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Warrants charging Samuel Insull Jr. and six others with conspiracy to commit a felony and embezzlement and larceny from the $100,000,000 Northern Indiana Public Service Company were in the possession of deputy sheriffs for service tonight.

John McKenzie, the present Commissioner of Docks, will retain his post under the LaGuardia administration. Announcement of his intention to reappoint Mr. McKenzie was made yesterday afternoon by the Mayor-elect.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Professor Friedrich Dessauer, noted X-ray specialist and former Reichstag member of the Catholic Centrist party, who has been on trial in Munich-Gladbach in the Rhineland on charges of mismanaging the People's Union for Catholic Germany, was acquitted today, together with a co-defendant, Dr. Knecht.

AS a child of Prohibition, whose vinous experience has been largely limited to "dago red" or homemade saki, we are appalled by a reading of Julian Street's "Wines: Their Selection, Care and Service" (Knopf, $2). For Mr. Street, the old gourmet, unveils depth upon depth of knowledge to correspond with circle upon circle of our ignorance.

Robert Gordon Switz, who is held in Paris on accusations of espionage, was a New Yorker until a year ago. He lived with his wife, Mrs. Marjorie Tilley Switz, at 12 Grove Street, in Greenwich Village, neighbors there recalled last night that he was "a very pleasant young man who didn't look as though he'd harm a soul."
