RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Hunk Anderson, former Notre Dame coach, expressed the opinion today that Columbia University would give Stanford "a good game" in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day.

The Down Town Glee Club, which gave a concert last night in Carnegie Hall, again demonstrated that a group of good amateur singers may, under the discipline of a leader who insists upon quality in performance and program, attain to impressive professional standards.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Forty-two varsity letter awards, including twenty in football, were announced today by Cornell's Athletic Council. Nine cross-country and thirteen soccer letters were also given.

Two temperamental horses, attached to wagons requisitioned by the Postoffice Department for delivering Christmas packages, wandered away from their drivers yesterday morning in Brooklyn. A general police alarm was broadcast throughout the borough in the belief that mail thieves were operating.

Both Harvard and Yale made a propitious start yesterday in the forty-second annual tournament for the championship of the H.Y.P. D. College Chess League, the first round of which was contested at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club.

Scoring its third victory in a row in Class C. Group 2, of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association tournament yesterday, the Squash Club remained undefeated in the current tourney by halting the Columbia University Club, 4 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Cotton of this year's crop ginned prior to Dec. 13 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 12,356,769 running bales, exclusive of linters and including 568,090 round bales counted as half bales and 5,151 bales of American-Egyptian.

James J. Hoey was sworn in yesterday morning in the Internal Revenue offices at the Custom House by Federal Judge John C. Knox as Collector for the Second District and commenced his new duties immediately. He succeeded William Dugan.

A novel departure in auction sales was inaugurated yesterday by the Beekman Galleries at 146 East Fifty-sixth Street. Instead of the works of art that customarily come under the hammer in New York's galleries, there were offered pedigreed dogs, eighty-three of which were knocked down for a total of $3,234.50, the average per head being $39.

As part of Tammany's program of placing as many of its henchmen as possible in "bomb proof shelters" during the LaGuardia administration, Mayor O'Brien, according to reports current yesterday, is planning the transfer of John J. Donlon, secretary to the Department of Sanitation, and Jay T. Fox, a member of his own secretarial staff, to the payroll of the Board of Transportation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Secretary Wallace announced tonight a parley of farm leaders to be held here Friday would centre its attention on a plan for rehabilitation, of the dairy industry.

Heavy selling, centring first in a handful of so-called specialty stocks and then extending to almost all departments of the market, produced yesterday a sharp downward reaction on the Stock Exchange. The weakness was communicated quickly to other markets and the result was a general lowering of price levels.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Political uprising against the dictatorship of Senator Long had swept Louisiana tonight, with a most telling blow against his five-year dynasty delivered by Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley of New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Chairman John H. Fahey of the Federal Home-Owners Loan Corporation board said today that the situation in New York was being cleared up and that prospects were for more rapid approval of loans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The cleaners and dyers who challenged minimum prices set by the NRA blanket code as "too high" won their battle today when General Johnson announced the fixing of new prices ranging from 50 cents to 75 cents for cleaning and pressing, instead of the 65 cents to 95 cents previously set.

Sales Buying Still Restricted. Buying for post-holiday sales did not grain appreciably during the week and all indications are that the bulk of such buying will swing over into the first weeks of the new year. In most lines of department store goods retailers already have sufficient stocks either on hand or on previous order to carry them through much of January.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Evidence that banks in the Guardian Detroit Union Group made condition reports showing "no bills payable," although the facts were otherwise, was developed today before the Senate Bank Investigation Committee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A.L. Fenton points out in his letter to THE TIMES that the Home Owners Loan Corporation bonds are unattractive to mortgagees unless guaranteed as to principal by the government. He overlooks the fact that the holder of a mortgage now eligible to be exchanged for the bonds hag no guarantee of principal now.

After advancing for seven consecutive months, the Government's indices of both employment and payrolls in manufacturing industries turned sharply down in November. Secretary PERKINS suggests that the loss may be in part a not unnatural reaction following rapid earlier gains and in part the result of normal seasonal influences.

The Vienna Choir Boys, directed by Hans Urbanek, gave the third concert of the Town Hall Endowment series last night in the intimate auditorium, well suited to such manifestations of the choral art. The program had two major elements.

Less attention than it deserves has been paid to the decision last Friday by Great Britain's highest court, declaring that interest and principal on bonds which had contracted for payment in gold must be paid as stipulated. This decision by the Law Lords is equivalent, unless appeal is permitted to the Privy Council, to a decision by our own Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland defeated James Caras of Wilmington, Del., 125 to 39, in ten innings in the world's pocket billiard championship tournament tonight and ended the loser's hopes for the title. Rudolph had a high run of 39 and Caras one of 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Amendment of the Economy Act in line with a four-point resolution adopted by the American Legion at its convention in Chicago in October was included in a legislative program presented to President Roosevelt today by a delegation headed by Edward A. Hayes, national commander.

Eighteen debutantes served as manikins yesterday afternoon at a fabric fashion show given at Louis Sherry's, Park Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, in connection with a luncheon for the benefit of the Crusade for Children.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The facilities of the Massachusetts State sale of securities division today were placed at the disposal of the Attorney General of New York in an investigation of the sale of Atlas Tack Corporation stock.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 20 -- After deliberating five hours a jury returned tonight at 9:10 verdicts of guilty against five defendants in the first trial of the Passaio jury "fixing" investigation. All were convicted of conspiracy to commit embracery.

ROME, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The ninety-two "champion" mothers in Italy's provinces, who have brought 1,288 children into the world, came to Rome today to receive the enthusiastic acclaim of Premier Mussolini and the populace.

The feat of William Harold Terry and his team of destiny, the New York Giants, in winning the National League pennant and the world series was voted the outstanding team achievement of the year by sports editors and writers balloting in The Associated Press third annual sports poll, announced yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 20 -- Michigan's fast passing basketball team defeated Rutgers, 32 to 22, tonight before a crowd of 1,500. Al Plummer, forward, led the visitors in a speedy attack which kept them in the lead from the outset of the contest.
CHARLES TOWN, West Va., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Jockey Paul Sage, veteran rider, today won four consecutive races at Charles Town to dominate a program of claiming events.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The new Federal Surplus Relief Corporation is an agency enjoying broader powers than those vested in any other emergency arm of the government, it was disclosed today as its articles of incorporation became available.

For several minutes at a time the share market was more or less demoralized yesterday because of the unexpectedly heavy pressure against a few stocks. Sponsors of the stocks that have been, receiving so much attention on the part of the Stock Exchange management were evidently unprepared for the rush of liquidation and short selling which developed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Speculation over the future of President Roosevelt's gold-purchase policy increased today following last night's conference at the White House, when Mr. Roosevelt conferred with Eugene R. Black, governor of the Federal Reserve Board; Acting Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury, the Secretary's fiscal adviser, Earle Bailie; and Professor George F. Warren of Cornell, advocate of the "commodity dollar."

BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- The slight but progressive improvement that Irvin (Ace) Bailey has made since his relapse of Monday night continued tonight and, for the first time since the Toronto hockey player suffered his skull fracture on Dec. 12, his physicians expressed hopes of his recovery.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Wholesale commodity prices receded slightly in November, Isador Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor, announced today.
Licensed liquor stores may remain open from 9 A.M. to 8 P.M. on Christmas and New Year's Days, the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board ruled yesterday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The indefinite suspension of Reginald (Red) Horner, defense star of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League, who was set down for his part in the Bailey incident at Boston, today was set to end Dec. 31 by Frank Patrick, managing director of the league.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 20 -- Leonard G. Brown of Orange was appointed today by the Controller of the Currency as receiver for the Orange National Bank, which ceased unrestricted operations in March. Fiftyfive per cent of the bank's deposits were made available for withdrawals in the recently formed First Orange National Bank, which now occupies the quarters of the old institution.

Eleventh-hour liquidation of January contracts before notices are issued tomorrow and setbacks in other markets weakened prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and a 15-point decline left the list 3 to 12 points lower. For the first time in more than two weeks the March broke below 10 cents a pound.

As a result of a "further sharp expansion in specifications against expiring fourth-quarter contracts," steel operations have risen to 36 per cent of ingot capacity, according to the review of The Iron Age. The official estimate of operations at the beginning of this week was 34.2 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 20 -- The Columbia Lions, bound for the Tournament of Roses, stopped off for five hours here today, went through a brisk workout under the watchful eyes of Coach Lou Little and his aides and tonight resumed their journey westward.

The deer-hunting season in New Jersey comes to an end today. It has been a short season but a fruitful one for the sportsmen, according to all reports which have been received. Deer have not been so abundant in years.

Dr. and Mrs. Albert Vander Veer gave a tea dance for their debutante daughter, Miss Margaret Luisa Vander Veer, yesterday in the Egyptian room of the St. Regis. The debutante wore a gown of blue crepe trimmed with silver fox fur, and a corsage of gardenias.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Former President Hoover has counseled Republican party leaders to refrain from attacking administration policies in the early days of the next session of Congress and to wait until the "errors of the economic program" have accumulated.

NEW YORK. M. Jean Boissonnas, Minister Plenipotentiary of France, and Mme. Boissonnas, who had been at Mayfair House, have gone to Washington. Their son, M. Remi Boissonnas, last Saturday married Miss Mary Louise Lobenstine of Montreal, formerly of this city.

One of the largest debutante parties of the season was a dinner dance given last night at the Colony Club by Mrs. William L. Harkness for her niece, Miss Eleanor Hale Mullally, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mandeville Mullally of Hewlett, L.I. Christmas greens, mistletoe, holly, poinsettias and red balloons decorated the ballroom, where the dinner was served at small tables, on which were vases of red roses.

Justice Albert Cohn of the Supreme Court denied yesterday the application of Sadye Greenberg, taxpayer, for a temporary injunction barring the Board of Estimate from awarding twenty-five-year bus franchises in Manhattan to the New York City Omnibus Corporation and its parent company, the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.

Brooklyn Republican district leaders expressed resentment yesterday at the acceptance by Frederick J. H. Kracke, county leader, of the post of Commissioner of Plant and Structures in the LaGuardia administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Industries and businesses not already covered by codes of fair competition were invited by President Roosevelt today to extend their operations under the President's reemployment agreement four months beyond Jan. 1, the original expiration date of the agreement.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Liquidation by professional traders, caused by the failure of the public to follow up yesterday's price-raising efforts, turned the Boerse weak today. Leading stocks lost from 1 to 2 points at the opening. Siemens Halske lost 2 1/2 per cent and Reichsbank dropped 4 points.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A determined effort by affected enterprises to have the special manufacturers' excises of the 1932 tax bill repealed began today before the Ways and Means Committee.

Statements by officials of the Stock Exchange that they were scrutinizing the trading in shares of the Union Bag and Paper Company and several other concerns were followed yesterday by a wide break in these issues and general unsettlement in the market.

The Public Service Commission announced last night the fixing of temporary emergency rates for electricity applicable to the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company. The new rates, to become effective as of Sept. 15, 1933, will mean a reduction of more than $360,000 a year, or 15 per cent, on all bills for eleetric-metered service to general consumers, according to the commission.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Despite passage of the Budget Bill by the Senate and advance information that the Bank of France's statement tomorrow will show the withdrawal of no more than 50,000,000 francs from its gold reserves during the week, the dollar as well as the pound strengthened against Paris exchange today, while the Dutch florin and the Swiss franc, especially the former, were weak.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The famous New Zealand runner, Jack Lovelock of Oxford University, holder of the world's record at the mile, may not run again as the result of a recent operation on a cartilage in his leg.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Governor Lehman laid aside affairs of state this afternoon and, with Mrs. Lehman, entertained 143 children from St. Vincent's Orphan Asylum, which is next door to the Executive Mansion.

AT a recent dinner given by Babe Ruth to a group of baseball writers from around the two major league circuits, comprising his All-America selective board which annually assists him in picking his All-America baseball team, the scribes drew up a ballot consisting of what they considered the ten outstanding achievements in the great man's career.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Gay World, winner of $17,430 with a string of important victories including triumphs in the Chicago Derby and the Waggoner Handicap, today carried the silks of J. A. Nix to a one-length victory in the San Jacinto Handicap at Epsom Downs.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The accounting of the estate of the late Judge Cornelius Doremus of Ridgewood by his daughter, Miss Nellie B. Doremus, was allowed today by Judge J. Wallace Leyden in the Bergen County Orphans Court. The gross estate was valued at $298,285.25.

GENEVA, Dec. 20 -- The League of Nations Year Book giving the balances of payments in 1931 and 1932, issued today, brings out some remarkable changes. It contains the complete accounts for these years of eighteen countries, half of which were on gold and half on paper currencies.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Over the protest of Chairman Macy's own Assemblyman, Republican members of the Assembly in caucus here this afternoon ordered an investigation by a committee of their own selection of the charges recently made by the chairman to the effect that under its present leadership the lower house of the Legislature has been dominated by the power interests of the State.

Cardinal Hayes, two archbishops, eighteen bishops, two abbots-ordinary and nine abbots, together with more than 250 priests, will participate in the consecration to the episcopate of the Right Rev. Bernard John Kevenhoerster, the Prefect-Apostolic of the Bahama Islands, which will take place this morning at 10 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- The Phillies, who were expected to do some trading at the major league meeting -- but didn't -- made a post- conference deal today that they hope will bring to their infield the offensive power and defensive tightness it needs.

President ROOSEVELT gives good reasons for keeping the re-employment agreements in force for an additional four months. They were to have expired on Jan. 1. But as there are still many industrial codes not yet framed or approved, it is desirable to continue the President's Agreement for a longer time than was at first thought necessary.
Ireland stands at the top of a list of Police Department statistics issued yesterday by Commissioner Bolan.

DUBLIN, Dec. 20 -- The Free State Government succeeded today in keeping General Owen O'Duffy, its leading opponent, in jail another twenty-four hours and postponing for that length of time the formulation of an accusation on which it will attempt to detain him for trial before a military tribunal.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- A warning to the German Supreme Court against condemning Ernst Torgler, former Communist Reichstag leader, to death was issued tonight by the self-appointed Legal Commission of Inquiry into the Burning of the Reichstag.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, Police-commissioner-to-be, visited Police Headquarters yesterday as the guest of Commissioner Bolan. He made an inspection tour of the building, sat through the daily lineup of prisoners and then had an hour's chat with Mr. Bolan.

President ROOSEVELT gives good reasons for keeping the re-employment agreements in force for an additional four months. They were to have expired on Jan. 1. But as there are still many industrial codes not yet framed or approved, it is desirable to continue the President's Agreement for a longer time than was at first thought necessary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Abuses requiring further investigation in the Pennsylvania anthracite district, where unemployment runs to 25,000 in the Wilkes-Barre-Scranton region alone, induced the fact-finding committee for the National Labor Board to ask the board today for the appointment of another committee with absolute powers.

Business in money continued upon a small scale. Routine requirements about made up the bulk of the turnover, little new funds being taken In any section. Quotations for all classes remained unchanged.

All classifications of bonds were irregularly lower yesterday on the Stock Exchange in comparatively quiet trading. Tax-selling and switching were prominent in the day's dealings. United States Government bonds were off 1-32 to 8-32 point, with the exception of the Liberty 3 1/2 s, which moved up 1-32, and three other issues which held unchanged.
BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- No less than 400,000 Germans, divided almost equally between men and women, will be sterilized shortly under a low that goes into effect on Jan. 1.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 21. -- Columbia University's Lions, en route to Pasadena, Calif., for a Rose Bowl engagement with Stanford's football team Jan. 1, practiced their passing game today at the home stadium of the nation's outstanding advocate of the aerial attack, Southern Methodist University.
ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 21 (by wireless). -- This is our ninth day in the pack ice. At noon today our position was 66.54 S., 176.05 E.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 21. -- A tour of the Eastern and Southern United States as a guest of the Rockefeller Foundation has convinced Sir Arthur Steel-Maitland, a member of the British Parliament and former Minister of Labor, that the Roosevelt administration is "putting a bottom to things," or establishing a standard of living below which the American people will not drop again.

Two gangsters were convicted in thirty minutes yesterday in Judge Corrigan's part of General Sessions of kidnapping Miss Betty Chum, a Chinese, for a $5,000 ransom. The convicted men, Michael Galotto, 25, of 560 Henry Street, and Leo Messina, 24, of 251 Carroll Street, both of Brooklyn, were remanded to the Tombs for sentence next Friday.

A slight decline in bank clearings, in New York City during the week ended on Wednesday was sufficient to pull the total for the entire country, as measured by twenty-one leading centres, below that of a year ago. This is shown in the weekly report by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- An aggressive campaign in the coming Congress for a six-hour day for railroad employes will be conducted by the Railway Labor Executives Association, representing the twenty-one standard rail unions, it was announced today by Alexander F. Whitney, chairman of the association.
THE HAGUE, Dec. 21. -- Orders placed in this country by Soviet Russia in November amounted to 1,500,000 guilders ($936,000 at the current rate).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Evidence that the Guardian National Bank of Commerce of Detroit, now in receivership, had outstanding in May, 1932, loans of $7,755,362.44 to its directors, of which more than $4,000,000 was in direct loans, was presented to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.
SAULTE STE. MARIE, Mich., Dec. 21. -- Freight tonnage through the American and Canadian locks this year was virtually double that in 1932, it was shown today.

John E. Joyce, referee in bankruptcy for the Louis K. Liggett Company, adjourned until next Wednesday a hearing of creditors held yesterday in the Federal Building to listen to details of an offer of $9,915,863 made by the United Drug Company for all the assets of the bankrupt.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- On the eve of a crucial meeting here between Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, and Joseph Paul-Boncour, French Foreign Minister, it became known today that France was definitely opposed to Germany's armament proposals.

Plans for immediate action to expose whatever links exist between organized crime and crooked politics were laid yesterday at the organization meeting of the special crime-fighting committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
NEW YORK. Chauncey Stillman will give a dinner dance tomorrow for Miss Rosalie Watson and Louis Bancel Warren, whose engagement has been announced.

The so-called "kick back" racket by which building trades workers are forced to turn back a large part of their pay has become almost universal in the United States, the Senate subcommittee on racketeering of which Senator Royal S. Copeland is chairman, was told yesterday at a hearing at the Bar Building in West Forty-fourth Street.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- The FrancoGerman trade negotiations that have been going on here for the last six weeks definitely broke down today without any agreement and the Reich's delegation took this evening's train for Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Pan American Airways is negotiating with the Portuguese Government for permission to land in the Azores Islands and on Portuguese territory on a regular transatlantic air service. This is regarded as confirming, reports that Pan American is contemplating the establishment of a regular transatlantic service at the earliest possible moment.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bayne of Ramelton, New Vernon, N.J., gave a supper dance last night in the roof garden of the Pierre to introduce their younger daughter, Miss Daphne van Beuren Bayne. The debutante is a granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. van Beuren, whose home was in this city, and of the late Samuel G. Bayne, founder and for more than thirty-five years president of the Seaboard National Bank.

Appointment of four Deputy Controllers in the Finance Department was announced yesterday by Controller-elect W. Arthur Cunningham. There are five deputies at present, and the Controller-elect said that the other place would not be filled.

Properties on the west side of Manhattan figured prominently in the real estate business reported by brokers yesterday. A Sixth Avenue building changed ownership and an apartment house on Eightieth Street was leased for a long term and will be remodeled.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Samuel Insull Jr., who was formerly vice chairman of the board of the Northern Indiana Public Service Company, and two other former directors of the concern surrendered at Crown Point, Ind., today on indictments voted Tuesday by the grand jury.

The ancient rivalry between Harvard and Yale again is in evidence in the annual tournament of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club. Yesterday each team won its second straight match. Play will terminate with games of the third round today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Forced into the unfamiliar role of sidelines spectator on the eve of a hot political campaign. Senator Huey P. Long late today called his "war council" into supar-private session while all Louisiana was kept guessing what his next move would be.

Subscriptions were received yesterday from 11,474 persons by the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which is raising a fund for relief of the needy and unemployed to be disbursed in special services by accredited welfare agencies of the city.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 21 (AP). -- While his football players have been tackling final examinations, Coach Tiny Thornhill of Stanford has outlined a practice campaign he believes will round the boys into top shape to meet Columbia in the Rose Bowl.

Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller signed yesterday a judgment instructing the Marine Midland Trust Company, as trustee for the 5 per cent secured sinking fund gold debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company, as to its duties in a suit by the trust company asking such instruction.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 21 (AP). -- The Canadian National liner Prince George crashed on a rock in a snowstorm last night on the British Columbia coast and was refloated today after passengers and crew were rowed ashore.

At the Academy of Inscriptions and Belles-Lettres the other day M. CARCOPINO defended JULIUS CAESAR against the ancient charge or myth -- "campaign material" invented by his enemies -- of entanglement with and subservience to CLEOPATRA. The story of the conveyance of that baggage into the court of the mighty JULIUS reads like a scene from comic opera.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Representative Smith of Washington said that as "a member of the delegation which urged the President to do something about silver, I am particularly elated and am confident his action will be approved by the nation."

A marked gain in the re-employment of women under the National Recovery Act is shown in returns received by the NRA women's division in reply to several thousand questionnaires addressed to leaders of women's clubs for distribution among their members, Miss Emma Dot Partridge, chairman of the women's division, announced yesterday.

The living habits of 83 per cent of the families who vacated the "lung block" on the East Side to permit model housing construction will remain unchanged, according to a study by the Fred L. Lavanburg Foundation and Hamilton House.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Wholesale commodity prices declined .1% per cent last week, Isador Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department, announced today.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 21. -- Acquisition by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of property near the Public Service Terminal Building here, including deals involving property formerly owned by Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Public Service Corporation and its operating subsidiaries, were explained today at the continued hearing before the Public Utility Commission.

A 20 per cent increase over last year in the sale of tickets for single performances for the first week of the Metropolitan Opera season was recorded yesterday, the opening day for the individual seat sale, it was announced last night by Earle Lewis, box office treasurer.

Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems made her debut last night at a dinner with dancing in the Georgian Room of the Pierre given by her mother and stepfather, Prince and Princess Irbain-Kahn Kaplanoff. The debutante wore a gown of white brocaded satin with pearl trimming and carried a bouquet of white orchids, and the Princess Kaplanoff a gown of green brocaded in gold thread.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press). -- The British Government will offer tomorrow to holders of Newfoundland Government stocks and bonds the privilege of exchanging their securities for new 3 per cent bonds, due in ten and thirty years and guaranteed by the British Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The text of President Roosevelt's silver proclamation is as follows:

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Walter Runciman, president of the Board of Trade, told the House og Commons today that a "satisfactory" solution of the surtax controversy with France would be announced in a few days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- In the last article of this series I shall consider the permanent, monetary arrangements which seem to hold out the greatest promise of yielding a dollar of stable purchasing power. This is an entirely different problem from that of monetary policies designed to meet our immediate needs.

The Right Rev. Bernard John Kevenhoerster, Prefect-Apostolic of the Bahama Islands since 1929 and previously for twenty-one years pastor of St. Anselm's Church, the Bronx, was consecrated a Bishop yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- M.A. Wetherell, Central African big game hunter, has found, according to The Daily Mail, a definite spoor of a huge amphibian on the shores of Loch Ness, the region from which stories of a remarkable "prehistoric sea monster" have emanated lately.

Dry Goods Jobbers More Active. With an improvement in the banking situation in certain parts of the Midwest, dry goods wholesalers are finding demand for their goods expanding steadily and during this week sold a large volume, reports yesterday indicated.

Miss Ann Lowsley was presented to society yesterday by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Oswald S. Lowsley, at a tea dance in the Tapestry Room of the Park Lane. Miss Lowsley wore a gown of aqua brindille and carried a muff of gardenias. Her mother's gown was of blue and gold net.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Three gun- men, two of them fugitive bank robber suspects, were shot and killed by police tonight in a sensational raid on an apartment at 1,428 Farwell Avenue, which was believed to be the hideout of John Dillinger and members of his band of escaped Indiana convicts.

Holding that the proposal to establish a three-platoon system in the Fire Department would add $7,500,000 a year to the city budget, the Citizens Budget Commission is prepared to oppose passage of the bill by the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly today.

Mrs. Archibald Douglas Russell gave a large dinner dance for Miss Agnes Landon Pyne, debutante daughter of Mrs. M. Taylor Pyne Jr., last night in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton, which had been most effectively decorated for the occasion.

The removal of home relief centres from school buildings, where such services have created hazards to young children and have handicapped public education, was urged yesterday in a report of the United Parents Associations.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Just before leaving for Paris today, Sir John Simon confirmed officially for the first time that Chancellor Hitler had proposed a pact of non-aggression with France and with every other one of Germany's neighbors.

The St. Paul's School hockey team of Concord, N.H., will meet the Yale freshmen in Madison Square Garden this afternoon, starting at 3:30 o'clock, in what will be the first game on the Garden ice between teams representing St. Paul's and the Yale yearlings.

The New York State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board was asked yesterday by the Federal Alcohol Control Administration to close a loophole which racketeers had discerned in the United States import quota regulations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Consolidation of purchasing operations in the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation and discontinuance of such activities by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration will be effected in a few days in the interest of efficiency and economy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- President Roosevelt's decision to buy and coin silver will greatly increase our exports to the Orient and other countries with a silver coinage, and prove a powerful stimulus to recovery, Senator Pittman, author of the silver resolution adopted at the World Economic Conference, declared today.

Twenty-six patrolmen and detectives who rescued persons from drowning in metropolitan waters were cited and received cash awards at police headquarters yesterday from the Life Saving Benevolent Association. Most of the rescuers received medals.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- The prices of the best hogs advanced 5 to 10 cents here today, with weights ranging from 190 to 240 pounds selling readily, while packing sows were steady and underweights 10 to 25 cents lower. The latter were plentiful, suggesting that the government's plan to lend 45 cents a bushel on corn in cribs was resulting in farmers selling hogs and holding back corn.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, which was formally organized on Dec. 18 with the encouragement of President Roosevelt but without actual government backing, will begin its work in January with the return of its president, Raymond B. Stevens, from a vacation.
The collapse of Notre Dame's football team followed by its unexpected one-point victory over the Army combined to furnish the sports world with its biggest surprise of 1933.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Liquidation was on again today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and the decline did not stop until prices had dropped as much as 2 1/4 cents a bushel from the previous close, with the July in the lead.

The Civil Works Administration announced yesterday through Travis H. Whitney, the administrator, that at the request of Mayor-elect LaGuardia it would conduct a survey of all property owned by the city with a view to developing means for its best utilization.

Signs that the present season is bringing less than the normal requirement for additional currency and that the banks consequently are meeting the Christmas demands upon them with unusual ease appeared in this week's Federal Reserve report, published yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Frederic M. Campbell, assistant to the vice president of the Coca-Cola Company, committed suicide early this morning in the garage of his home at 90 Beechtree Drive, according to County Medical Examiner Amos O. Squire.
The Fund for the Relief of the Neediest Cases is still far behind, but it is slowly gaining.

DUBLIN, Dec. 21. -- After an allday hearing in which counsel for the de Valera government attempted to justify and continue the detention of General Owen O'Duffy, militant leader of the Opposition, and his companion, Captain John Sullivan, the High Court in Dublin peremptorily ended the proceedings this evening by ordering the immediate release of both men.

LAKELAND, Fla., Dec. 21. -- Undefeated high school teams from Ithaca, N.Y., and Lakeland fought on even terms in a colorful intersectional football game tonight to gain a 7-7 tie. A crowd of 4,000 saw the evenly matched elevens battle for the benefit of the Salvation Army's Christmas basket fund.

POONA, India, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press). -- A one-day cricket match between the touring Marylebone team and Poona ended today in a draw, although the English eleven, thanks to masterly bowling by Hedley Verity, held a long lead when stumps were drawn.
Presentation of grand opera at low prices will be resumed at the Hippodrome in mid-January, it was announced yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 21. -- The forthcoming negotiations to end the Chaco war were under a cloud tonight as Bolivia accused Paraguay of a breach of the truce which began at midnight on Tuesday, Dec. 19.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- Robert Gordon Switz of East Orange, N.J., and his wife were declared by the police today to be linked to espionage activities for several countries. Some Paris newspapers asserted the police found they had been financed entirely by Moscow, but one newspaper said they had been employed by Germany.

A sale of the property of the late Ivar Kreuger from his penthouse at 791 Park Avenue brought about $8,000 yesterday at public auction in the Goodman Warehouse, Jersey City, to satisfy the Federal Government and other creditors in this country of the Swedish "match king," who shot and killed himself in his Paris apartment on March 12, 1932.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 21. -- The newspaper Popayan was fined 500 pesos yesterday for unauthorized publication of reports of movements of troops and acquisition of war materials. It is the first penalty inflicted under the new censorship decree.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The Bronx Hockey Club of New York and the Baltimore Orioles battled through a ten-minute overtime period tonight to a 2-to-2 tie in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game.

A proposal to regulate security trading in this country by the issuance of Federal licenses to brokers, which has been under discussion in Congressional committees in Washington, has received favorable attention recently from members of some of the largest Stock Exchange firms, it was disclosed yesterday in a survey of Wall Street houses.

John Foster Dulles, lawyer who represented American creditors at the Berlin conferences with Hjalmar Schacht, head of the Reichsbank, is arriving today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others aboard are Mrs. Dulles, the Right Hon. Frederick Guest, M. P.; Mr. and Mrs. Barren Collier, Noel Coward, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Norris, Robert van Royen, Mr. and Mrs. James F. Dawson, George Gordon, Harley L. Clarke, C.M. Dunning and W.J. Westaway.

Although younger pitchers came to the fore in earned-run effectiveness in the American League in 1933, it is Robert (Lefty) Grove of the Athletics who appears as the champion hurler of the season, according to the official averages released yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 21. -- The nations of the world should adjust internal commodity price levels as the first step toward prosperity, Spruille Braden of the United States delegation to the Seventh Pan-American Conference told the commission on economic and financial matters this morning.

The guaranteed-mortgage situation required a curb on the power of a refractory minority to block the will of a substantial majority, it was asserted by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, in defending the Schackno Law last night before the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

German Sterilization Courts. Inability to say who discovered America is likely in this country to exclude a man from naturalization. In Germany's new eugenic court a lack of acquaintance with CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS may bring a verdict of sterilization.
Miss Margaret Polk Yates made her debut last night in a "snowstorm" that raged in the ballroom of the Pierre, where a supper dance was given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Adams Yates.

With final liquidation of the January long interest preparatory to notices this morning and a three-day holiday ahead, trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was mainly in evening up. Fluctuations in the March delivery held within a five-point range and contracts appeared to be wanted slightly below 10 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The new Fusion administration which will take office in New York City Jan. 1 presented to the Public Works Administration today its plan for clearing New York's slum districts and erecting modern dwellings to be rented at low cost.

Mesopotamia is in danger of losing its monopoly as "a blessed word." Others are threatening to displace it. Among its keen competitors in the United States just now is the word "collective." This has an almost infinite range and applicability. As a portfolio word it has few rivals.

Prices of bonds ruled firmer yesterday on the Stock Exchange after having shown considerable irregularity earlier in the week. United States Government issues finished generally higher, with gains of 6-32 to losses of 3-32 point. Leading foreign loans pointed up.

The union of the Stationers Company and the Newspaper Makers is a recognition of "the conserver of all arts" from its earliest use to its most popular modern application. The installation of the Prince of WALES as the Master of the Amalgamated Company adds royal distinction to this essential instrument of modern democracy.

Unusually close competition marked last night's play in the Class A division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League. All four of the matches played resulted in victories by the margin of a single game and numerous drawnout deuce engagements were recorded.

The marriage of Mrs. June Hamilton Rhodes of New York, daughter of Mrs. Francis Robert Hamilton of Los Angeles, Calif., to Ferdinand Doan Sanford, also of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand V. Sanford, whose home was in Warwick, N.Y., took place yesterday afternoon in the Reformed Church in East Eightyninth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Friday, Dec. 22. -- Representatives of 27,000 truckmen and drivers, defying a last-minute plea of the National Labor Board, voted a city-wide walkout at 11:30 o'clock last night, threatening a tie-up of general delivery and transportation facilities.

Fifteen recommendations for strengthening the criminal law and for expediting trials of criminal cases were made public yesterday as a program for which the Association of Grand Jurors of New York County will work at the next session of the New York State Legislature.

The reaction of the New York public to a celebrated name as contrasted with its reaction to mere music is rather dismaying. Last night the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Erected by Hans Lange, assistant conductor, gave the most interesting program it has given this season, and some of the best performances.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 21. -- Paraguay has upset the negotiations for ending the war in the Chaco by violating the armistice negotiated Tuesday, according to the Bolivian Foreign Office.

BELGRADE, Dec. 21. -- The process of appeasement in the Balkans continues. The Croat leader, Dr. Vladko Matchek, who recently was sentenced to seven years' imprisonment by the special court instituted under the Yugoslav dictatorship for alleged political offenses, probably will be released from prison for twelve days to visit his family.

The name of KNUD RASMUSSEN, who died in Copenhagen yesterday, was identified with exploration in Greenland, and particularly with studies of the Eskimos, as that of no other had been. He had the advantage over other explorers of being able to speak the Eskimo language.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 21. -- A reward of $500 was posted today for information leading to the whereabouts of Clarence L. Marks Jr., Dartmouth student who disappeared from Hanover on Dec. 10. It will remain in effect for ninety days from today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Nine more persons, including a former bank president and a lawyer, were indicted today in connection with the $250,000 daylight mail robbery staged here on Dec. 6, 1932.

Billy Beveridge's goal-tending was too much for the New York Rangers last night, and the blue-jersey outfit had to be content with a scoreless tie against the Ottawa Senators. Cheered on by a crowd of 7,000 spectators at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers sought to advance themselves in the National Hockey League standing, and sent a steady bombardment at their rivals' net, but Beveridge turned back everything shot at him.

The plane and all the equipment used by Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh on their recent 30,000-mile survey flight, in which they spanned both the North and South Atlantic and visited twenty-one countries, has been presented by them to the American Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The protracted deadlock over a reciprocal agreement by which France would buy more American fruit in exchange for an increased wine quota was broken tonight, with France agreeing to quadruple her import quota on American apples and pears in exchange for double the present wine quota.

President Roosevelt's action, extending the provision of the International Silver Agreement to provide for the monetization by the government of virtually all newly mined silver in this country came as a distinct surprise to the financial community.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21. -- One of the closest finishes ever seen at Jefferson Park was witnessed in the fourth race today as three horses crossed the finish line noses apart. The judges decided that Mrs. R.T. Flippen's Barashkova had won, with the Old Gold Stable's Belle Delight second and M.A. McNamer's Cloirado third.

MUCH seems to be said and written these days on what might be considered the proper competitive spirit. In other words, the question is profoundly asked whether the boys should play the game to win or just play it with no idea what the score is or will be.
PARIS, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
Sales of real estate in Westcheser County during the past year have totaled over $15,000,000, according to a survey just completed by A.W. Lockyer, vice president of Prince Ripley, Inc.

The spirit of the Constitution has been stifled; State powers have been absorbed by Federal powers, and a dictatorship is being erected in the United States, which, if it becomes permanent and effective, will endanger the perpetuity of the Union, Representative James M. Beck of Pennsylvania said last night.

The draw for the national junior and boys' indoor tennis championships, which will get under way Tuesday morning on the Seventh Regiment Armory courts, was announced yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt entertained forty tinder-privileged children at her annual children's Christinas party yesterday afternoon at the Women's Trade Union League, 247 Lexington Avenue. Earlier in the day she attended the wedding of Mrs. June Hamilton Rhodes and Ferdinand D. Sanford at the Reformed Church of Harlem.

BERLIN, Dec. 21 (AP). -- A sentence of death for Marinus Van der Lubbe and acquittal for Ernst Torgler on the arson charge, but his detention for a new trial on the charge of high treason, will be contained in the verdict of the Supreme Court judges who have been trying the Reichstag fire case, The Associated Press learned today from a usually reliable source.

Former Judge Samuel Seabury returned yesterday on the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain from a brief trip abroad and was outspoken in his comment on the recent meeting between Postmaster General James A. Farley and former Mayor James J. Walker in Paris.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 21. -- J.Y. Christmas's Grayback came from behind in the fifth event at Charles Town today to win by two lengths from Mrs. F.M. Watts's Forceful in a six and a half furlong dash for juveniles.

ALBANY, Dec. 21. -- Investigation by a committee of Republican Assemblymen into charges by Chairman Macy will be no "whitewash," according to a statement issued today by the committee as it sent a formal request to the chairman to appear Wednesday to substantiate his accusation that power interests, through H. Edmund Machold and Fred W. Hammond, clerk, had exerted improper pressure on the Assembly in connection with utility legislation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- With one Executive order, President Roosevelt tonight ratified the silver agreement negotiated at the London Economic Conference, and provided for the purchase of virtually all newly mined domestic silver, half to be coined and half to be deposited in the Treasury.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A thorough investigation of income tax payments was added today to the troubles besetting Senator Huey Long and his Louisiana political associates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard, has written to General Hugh S. Johnson declining appointment as a Presidential member of the motion picture industry code authority under NRA.

Among the newest of many new agencies in Washington is the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation, soon to be known, no doubt, as the FSRC. Its articles of incorporation, published yesterday in THE TIMES, mark out an exceedingly broad field within which it may function.

Tammany is in the unusual position of a criminal who pleads "Not Guilty" and then proceeds, in open court as it were, to offer one piece of evidence after another of guilt. It has pretended all these years, and right up to Nov. 7, that it is an organization dedicated to the public service.

TRENTON, Dec. 21. -- At a hearing today in the Assembly Chamber in the Capitol William B. Duryee of the State Milk Control Board warned that price-cutting or other evasions of the code prescribed for the dairy industry in New Jersey would be met with vigorous action.

As analyzed last night by a leading monetary expert who has made a study of the silver question, the President's proclamation goes far beyond the scope of the London agreement. The President's announcement, this expert said, falls into two parts, first, the ratification of the London agreement itself; second, provision for the free coinage of domestically mined silver produced from now on.

Robert Gordon Switz, who is accused of espionage in Paris, started his career of adventure when he was 18 years old, according to Harvey Klemmer of 18 Barrow Street. Mr. Klemmer, an author and former Detroit newspaper man, traveled through Germany with Switz in 1922 on a capital of $15.

With the Christmas exodus from the city expected to begin this evening, welfare groups, churches and other organizations, some of which had already begun their observance of the holiday season, made announcement yesterday of their plans for celebrations and for bringing Yule cheer to the needy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Relief sought by interested industries from manufacturers' excise taxes appeared improbable today as the Ways and Means Committee chieftains went ahead apparently determined to push through their program to plug up leaks in the Revenue Law and increase the Treasury's income by $200,00,000.
The following additional contributions were announced yesterday by the Citizens Family Welfare Committee. Contributions may be sent to Thomas Cochran, treasurer of the committee, 120 Broadway.
RENO, Nev., Dec. 21. -- Fixing of the price of silver at 64 1/2 cents an ounce by the government was greeted with widespread enthusiasm by mining men of the West today.
LONDON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Patrolman Harry Kroll, 29 years old, of the East Twenty-second Street police station was wounded critically early this morning in a battle with a hold-up man in a grill room at 337 Third Avenue. During an exchange of about eight shots, the robber was wounded twice and was taken with the patrolman to Bellevue Hospital, where he also is in a critical condition.

The consumer will "pay heavily" if proposals for price-fixing in manufacturers' codes now pending are allowed, the National Retail Dry Goods Association has advised the National Recovery Administration, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the association.

Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributers, Inc., said yesterday that employment in the motion picture industry was now up to the 1929 level and that "art has progressed through all the trying days of the depression."

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- A spy trail that police suspected would lead directly to "Germany's master organization" was followed by authorities today in their investigations of a band in which they allege two Americans were the "liaison" agents.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 21. -- The South Orange team won its fifth straight match in the class B division of the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League as it defeated the Plainfield Country Club today, 4 -- 1. The Montclair Athletic Club defeated the Short Hills Club by the same score at Montclair.

Junius Spencer Morgan was reelected commodore of the New York Yacht Club at the organization's annual meeting, held last night in the clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. Vice Commodore W.A.W. Stewart and Rear Commodore E. Townsend Irvin also were re-elected.

With the approach of the holidays, business on the Stock Exchange and in most of the other markets was curtailed sharply yesterday. There was, at the same time, a slow return of confidence after the speculative disturbances of the day before.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, En Route to Antarctica, Dec. 21. -- The flagship of the Second Byrd Antarctic Expedition this afternoon was successfully extending the first penetration along the 150th meridian toward the undiscovered coastline of the Pacific quadrant of Antarctica since Captain Cook's record southing of 1773.

Berkeley Bell contributed the outstanding performance of the week in the metropolitan, indoor tennis championship as he vanquished John Nogrady, former St. John's College star, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, yesterday.

Much satisfaction was felt among conservationists yesterday over the report from Washington that President Roosevelt had expressed hearty sympathy with the duck stamp bill which is to come before the next Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Under a plan now being considered by the Department of Justice, Federal investigators in the various branches of the government would receive authority to enforce all laws of the United States, Attorney General Cummings disclosed today.

The Railroad Credit Corporation declared yesterday its largest dividend, 3 per cent, totaling $2,200,000, payable on Dec. 30 and making disbursements 10 per cent, or $7,500,000, authorized since the corporation began to repay loans six months ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- President Roosevelt today received from Roger W. Babson, statistician, a plan to employ 3,000,000 men in specific work-creating projects to be encouraged through exemption of surtaxes on incomes.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 21. -- Miss Sophronisba Breckinridge is daily evoking increasing respect and admiration here for her forthright qualities. She is asking no quarter in the give and take of conference debates.

Mrs. Elizabeth Billings, 29 years old, socially prominent and the wife of Jason E. Billings, a member of the New York Stock Exchange concern Billings, Olcott Co., was killed instantly yesterday morning when she fell or jumped from the window of her apartment on the third floor of 4 East Ninety-fifth Street.

Officials of three branches of the City Government warned yesterday that the holiday season had brought boom times to an old racket. Business and professional men tnroughout the metropolitan district, it was revealed, are being asked by telephone for contributions to a charity in which, according to the solicitor, a judge, welfare official or other public figure is interested.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- A wave of revolt swept through the masses of German Protestants today when Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller officially announced the fusion of the Evangelical Youth movement with the Hitler Youth.
HARRISBURG, Dec. 21. -- The special session of the Legislature, convened six weeks ago by Governor Pinchot, adjourned sine die today after final ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A program for rehabilitating farmsteads throughout the country with the creation of a purchasing agency like the Home Owners Loan Corporation has been started by the Department of Agriculture in cooperation with the Civil Works Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The administration revoked the gold clause in government obligations that had been contracted on that basis, and it is still doing business at the old stand. The retroactive force of repudiation was denounced all over the country as official turpitude, but every evidence points to the fact that the President lost no general popularity.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 21. -- The veteran Carnoustie Scot, Macdonald Smith, blazed his way into the lead in the $4,000 Pasadena golf tournament today with a scintillating 67, four strokes under par for the Brookside municipal course.

So much emphasis has been placed on the mural side of the nation-wide government plan to put 2,500 idle artists to work that the more comprehensive aspect of this "Public Works of Art Project" seems rather to have been snowed under.

"Alice in Wonderland," the film version of Lewis Carroll's classic, will be presented at the Paramount today. A large cast of well-known players has been assembled for the picture and the title role is played by Charlotte Henry. Mary Pickford will appear on the stage in several scenes from Fodor's "A Church Mouse."

Mere "guesses" and "opinions" as to land values, even though offered by experts, are not to be considered authoritative, Public Service Commissioner George Lunn ruled yesterday at a hearing on the application of Westchester communities for a reduction in New Haven Railroad commutation rates.

Eighty unemployed artists, some of them well known, have been put to work here during the first week of operation of the New York Regional Committee of the Public Works of Art Project, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Juliana Force, chairman of the New York committee.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- General Johnson has telegraphed ail State Governors asking them to set up "little" NRA'a in their Commonwealths.

Many of her younger friends in society gave a supper dance last night at the Gotham for Miss Martha Rosalie Humphrey, daughter of Mrs. Theodore F. Humphrey, who has just returned from a tour of Europe. Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Stout of 270 Park Avenue acted as host and hostess, receiving with the guest of honor.

Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, returned yesterday with Mrs. Bingham on the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain to spend the holidays in Louisville. He hopes to have a six weeks' vacation before returning to his post in London.
Wilbur T. Wright, Commissioner of Correction, criticized yesterday his retiring deputy, Joseph F. Fishman, as "a disloyal subordinate who wanted to supersede his chief."

BOSTON, Dec. 21. -- Irvin (Ace) Bailey, injured Toronto hockey player, today enjoyed the best day he has had since his skull was fractured in a collision with Eddie Shore of the Boston Bruins at the Boston Garden on Dec. 12.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 21. -- A new bank, the Park National, with capital and undivided profits of $1,100,000, will open its doors tomorrow for business here. The announcement was made tonight after the directors had received official authorization from Washington.

The estates of Richard Sutro and his brother, Lionel, who organized the banking firm of Sutro Brothers Co., were appraised yesterday. Richard Sutro, who was active in the firm at the time of his death on Aug. 3, 1930, had $17,163,083 gross, but it was reduced by a debt of $7,166,526 to his firm on a trading account, and other deductions, to $9,246,364 net.

After their excitement of Wednesday the domestic markets were comparatively tranquil yesterday, which was a welcome condition so far as Wall Street was concerned. The markets apparently had no inkling that such a major development in the government's monetary policy as that disclosed in its silver proclamation was in prospect.

A downward price trend continued yesterday in most of the local commodity futures markets, although in several instances the volume of trading showed a slight improvement over the low levels which had prevailed recently. Cash prices were irregularly lower.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Cornell's basketball team opened its season by defeating Toronto, 30 -- 13, in the Drill Hall tonight.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 21. -- Hugh Dillman entertained tonight with a buffet dinner at Sandy Loam Farm, in compliment to Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Thomas, who are guests of Mrs. Thomas's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne, at Casa Beata.
MONTREAL, Que., Dec. 21. -- Deficit of $56,618 from operations for 1932 was reported at the annual meeting of shareholders of the Canadian Marconi Company here today.

MADRID, Dec. 21. -- The Spanish Cabinet will discuss tomorrow the grave situation that has arisen in Cuba with the killing of four Spanish citizens in disturbances. Spain may ask intervention by the United States. It was suggested in government quarters tonight that the United States would be justified in fulfilling her treaty obligations in Cuba.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- The Boerse was somewhat irregular today, but showed a firm undertone and gains outnumbered losses. Changes either way, however, stayed within fractional bounds as a rule. Only a few specialties scored gains of two to three points.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The cut-rate Public Service theatrical ticket agency of New York City asked the aid of Congress today in its contest with the Treasury over the admissions tax.

HAVANA, Dec. 21. -- A mass demonstration was held this afternoon by about 30,000 Cubans, organized by the government authorities, to show adherence to the Grau San Martin government and to protest against the Platt Amendment.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Four stories of extortion or irregularity in the issuance of newsstand licenses were told to License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine yesterday as he continued an inquiry into his department as run by former Commissioner James F. Geraghty, Bronx district leader.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 21. -- About 125 juniors attended a dinner dance at the Field Club, Greenwich, last night. It was arranged by a committee consisting of Mrs. Harold L. Lloyd, Mrs. Graham Brush, Mrs. Max B. Berking, Mrs. Alanson T. Enos Jr., Mrs. George Griswold Jr., Mrs. Austin S. Ingleheart, Mrs. Challen R. Parker, Mrs. Stanley B. Resor and Mrs. Charles G. Rafferty.

The leaders of the shipping industry in foreign countries favor international agreements, framed by their governments, to reduce the excess of tonnage now operating in the world markets and end the uneconomic situation which has cost the ship lines millions of dollars, according to Robert C. Lee, vice president of Moore McCormack, owners of the American Export Line.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Public Works Administration in a year-end summary of allotments made from the $3,300,000,000 authorized by Congress showed it now had less than $300,000,000 on hand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Securities issues of about $5,000,000, of which $2,000,000 represents new capital enterprises, are contemplated in registration statements filed under the Securities Act with the Federal Trade Commission and made public today.
The Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field championships, which have been held in armories since their inception, will move into Madison Square Garden this season.

BERLIN, Dec. 22 -- Despite the impending holiday interruption, the Boerse was firm and livelier today, gains ranging beyond two points. Continued optimistic business reports and strength in German securities abroad acted as stimulants. Heavy industrials were irregular, but electricals, public utilities, rayons, machineries and automobiles were in good demand.

There was an unmistakable prescience of success in the air last night at the St. James Theater when the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe made its American debut as the direct successor of that miraculous ballet Russe of Diaghileff which last visited this country sixteen years ago.

Wall Street's celebration of Christmas took place yesterday, an old custom having established Saturday as the equivalent of a holiday in the minds of many of its denizens. Trading in stocks, bonds, cotton, leather, rubber and silk was conducted amid holly and wreaths.

When he sent his "emergency" message to the Board of Aldermen advocating a bill to establish the three-platoon system in the Fire Department, Mayor O'BRIEN assumed that he could easily force it through the Board of Estimate. Apparently, he did not stop to think that three of its members would have good and sufficient reasons to see the matter in a different light.

Expenses of the protective committee for Republic of El Salvador bonds on which payment of back interest will be made on Jan. 1 were announced yesterday as $6 for each $1,000 bond. The figure was announced by the committee on Securities of the New York Stock Exchange in ruling on the republic's 8 per cent bonds, Series A, due in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Ninety applications for loans amounting to $463,638 were approved in New York State last week after detailed appraisal, it was announced today by the Home Owners' Loan Corporation. Of these, eight, totaling $40,742, were approved with reduction, and eighty-two, totaling $422,896, were approved without reduction.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 22 -- After more than a week of quarterly examinations, Stanford's football players today renewed practice for their Rose Bowl game with Columbia at Pasadena New Year's Day.

Fish and game legislation to be presented this Winter at Albany is certain to embrace the question of split fees as between hunting and angling. Many sportsmen's organizations throughout the State have drawn tentative revisions and the chances are that a great many ideas will be forthcoming.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The RFC has been asked to provide about $66,000,000 to enable some 600 State banks to qualify under the deposit insurance provision of the Glass-Steagall Banking Act of 1933.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 23 -- Prolonged double blasts by Tokyo sirens informed the people early this morning that an imperial Prince and heir to the throne had been born.

Announcement overnight of the ratification by the Washington Government of the London, silver agreement had a stimulating effect yesterday upon all the domestic speculative markets. Prices on the various exchanges were higher. All the foreign currencies advanced against the dollar.

The Molaska Products Corporation of Cleveland, Ohio, in an expansion move, has leased from the Bethlehem Steel Corporation about five acres of the former Bethlehem shipbuilding plant on Staten Island Sound at Elizabeth, N.J. The lease, which runs for eighteen months, includes an option to purchase during that time.

Dickens's Youngest Son. In tomorrow's NEW YORK TIMES Magazine there is an article on CHARLES DICKENS and Christmas. It is from the hand of Sir HENRY FIELDING DICKENS, the youngest son and last surviving child of the great novelist, who died in London on Thursday, almost on Christmas Eve.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Roosevelt has the combined newspaper and graphic arts code of fair competition on his desk and may sign it tomorrow, the National Recovery Administration announced tonight.

Miss Kate Peck Shepard and Miss Barbara Stevenson made their debut together last night at a dinner dance in the Japanese Room of the St. Regis, given jointly by Mr. and Mrs. Otis Norton Shepard, parents of Miss Shepard, and Dr. and Mrs. James Morley Hitzrot, uncle and aunt of Miss Stevenson, who is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Stevenson of New Canaan, Conn.
BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- Irving (Ace) Bailey, injured Toronto hockey player, tonight was declared "out of danger" by Dr. Donald Munro, Boston specialist who twice operated on his fractured skull.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- In his role as a seeker after information regarding the attitudes of various countries toward disarmament and more concretely toward the German proposals for rearmament and Italian hints as to the desirability of altering the League of Nations, the British Foreign Secretary, Sir John Simon, began his travels today in Paris.

The flight that Admiral Byrd has made along the 150th meridian of west longitude toward the Antarctic continent is the logical continuation of his flights eastward from Little America on his last expedition. It was on the last flight he made then that he discovered the Edsel Ford Mountains stretching far up into the unknown region to the east of the Ross Sea.

With a well-earned 2 1/2-1 1/2 victory over Yale in the third and final round at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. Harvard retained the championship in the forty-second annual tourmanet of the H.Y. P.D. College Chess League. For the sixth time the Crimson took the Belden-Stephens Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, filed a report on the strike at the Edgewater (N.J.) Ford plant with the NRA today charging that Ford interests had violated the NRA mandate for collective bargaining.

The plan of corporate organization for guaranteed mortgage certificate holders provided under the Schackno Law found widespread favor among attorneys for various groups of certificate holders appearing before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday afternoon.

It is expected that the famous plane Tingmissartoq, which Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Mrs. Lindbergh presented to the American Museum of Natural History on Thursday, will be placed on public view by the end of next week, F. Trubee Davison, president of the museum, said last night.
NEW YORK. George A. Gordon, counselor of the American Embassy in Berlin, and Mrs. Gordon arrived on the Bremen and are at the Ambassador.

Mr. and Mrs. John Augustine Hartford gave a dinner dance at the Plaza last evening, to introduce to society in New York their niece, Miss Louise Makepeace McKelvy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frances Graham McKelvy of Easton, Pa.

While the Neediest Cases Fund will be open for contributions after Christmas, it would add greatly to the cheer not only of those in need but also of those who purpose to give if they were to do so quickly, so that Christmas morn may see as many as possible of the Three Hundred Cases provided for.

Charges of cruelty to child inmates, of the Arthur Sunshine Home and Kindergarten for Blind Babies at Summit, N.J., have caused New York State to withdraw children sent to that institution and New Jersey to begin an investigation.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 22 -- Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard University, declined appointment as a member of the moving-picture code authority because of block booking, he revealed today when he made public correspondence with NRA officials.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- Supreme Court Justice Schenck heard arguments today on an application to restrain the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board from enforcing its rule that retail liquor stores must be 1,500 feet apart and that such stores cannot be operated within 200 feet of a church.

DUMAS'S Guardsmen live not only in his books. The line is perpetually continued. A writer in Figaro celebrates HENRY DE CORTA, who died recently in Tonkin, a lieutenant colonel in the Foreign Legion, "magnificent, unmanageable, violent." He sounds as though he came from the Midi.

MONTEVIEDO, Dec. 22 -- Three days' dangerous crisis, threatening to break up the Chaco peace negotiations, was successfully overcome late this afternoon when Bolivia and Paraguay agreed to leave to a League of Nations subcommittee determination of whether their armistice was violated by Paraguay in occupying four forts.
TOKYO, Dec. 22 -- The Diet reassembles tomorrow to prepare for formal opening by the Emperor on Tuesday, after which it will adjourn until the end of January.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 -- Jockey Jimmy Hunter just managed to get A.G. Tarn's Pulis to the front in the closing strides to win by a nose in the featured fifth race at Jefferson Park today. A.L. Wynston Jr.'s Burnside finished second after leading almost all of the way. Pacheco was third.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The increased production of silver will augment the surplus of other metals, control of which has been attempted by codes and other methods, published figures of the Bureau of Mines indicate.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Hogs weighing 210 pounds or less were in demand today and 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday, while other weights were slow sale and mostly steady, although the close was weak to 10 cents lower.

FOOCHOW, Dec. 22 -- Although the leaders of the Fukien Government continue refusing to admit having formed a definite alliance with the Kiangsi Province Communists, they frankly say they are counting upon the "cooperation" of the Reds and estimate the combined Fukien.
BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- The Olympic Club of Boston brought to a close Dartmouth's four-game winning streak with a 5-to-3 decision tonight in an exciting hockey game at the Boston Arena.

CHRISTMAS-PRINT tales of sleet and freezing, of storm over the Atlantic and longed-for fire, fit this season. Tough, not exactly print-like, but packed full of hard weather, is the chronicle of American whaling, "Lowered Boats," by Foster Rhea Dulles (Harcourt, Brace, $3). Warmed by thick blankets of blubber, thousands of whales, who seemed marked by destiny then to light the world at night, stayed close to polar ice. Charles Lamb rhymed:

General retail sales for the final week of Christmas shopping ran from 10 to 40 per cent in excess of the total for the corresponding week of last year, with the best reports emanating from the agricultural districts and industrial centres, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The President's silver proclamation is not of the high importance which some may impute to it. The "supplementary agreement" of July 22 at the London Economic Conference, between delegates of the largest silver-producing and silver-consuming countries, plainly foreshadowed it.

Shipping men hailed yesterday the announcement of the reappointment of John McKenzie as Dock Commissioner. Continuing him in office was called the wisest move the LaGuardia administration could have made in bolstering the port in its contest with rivals for world trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Retail food prices moved sharply downward during the two weeks' period ended Dec. 5, the general level of prices for Dec. 5 showing a decrease of 12-10 per cent over the two weeks' period, according to figures announced today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department.

A brief outlining the powers and limitations of the Federal Government in regulating stock exchanges has been prepared by Raoul E. Desvernine, counsel for the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, and administrators of the Stock Exchange code.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Out of the welter of weasel words and untested theories there emerges the suggestion from Professor James Harvey Rogers, monetary adviser of the President, that our government, if it continues its present policy, stasnds to make a "profit" of $4,000,000,000 by devaluing our $4,000,000,000 of monetary gold.

In the longest battle of the week's play, Mark Hecht, University of Pennsylvania star, lost to William Thompson of Brooklyn, an unseeded player, in their quarterfinal match of the metropolitan indoor tennis championship yesterday.

Thomas H. Cullen Jr., 33-year-old son of Representative Thomas H. Cullen of Brooklyn, was appointed a city magistrate at 9 o'clock last night, after waiting in City Hall all day with his father for the ceremony.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- With the remark that the Insull investment trusts operated in 1929 as "nothing but a glorified gambling institution," Federal Judge Evan A. Evans decided today that the $238,000,000 Insull Utility Investments, Inc., was placed in receivership by collusion.

For the twenty-second successive year a "Tree of Light" has been installed in Madison Square. This "mother" of outdoor community Christmas trees is the gift of a small group who remain anonymous. Their generosity has made the tree possible since 1912.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- An additional Congressional appropriation of a sum to be determined, but in any event not less than $200,000,000, was asked today to assist in farm aid, particularly for the dairy and beef cattle farmers. The resolution was adopted at a conference of farm leaders with officials of the AAA and the Department of Agriculture.

Although W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, said yesterday he had not decided whether he would accept the invitation of a committee of Republican Assemblymen to go to Albany next Wednesday to substantiate his charge that power interests controlled the Assembly, the impression prevailed among his friends that he would do so.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- The circumstances under which two young American university graduates, Robert Gordon Switz and his wife, the former Miss Marjorie Tilley, became implicated in a European underground espionage network are expected to be cleared up when they are questioned tomorrow by an examining magistrate.

The coal producers of the United States are planning a legislative proposal to be introduced in Congress as soon as it convenes in January providing for a Federal tax on natural gas sales to industrial consumers. It is reported that they will ask that this tax be set at 10 cents a 1,000 cubic feet of gas, comparing with a present average charge of 16.8 cents a 1,000 cubic feet made by natural gas utilities.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Shipping companies engaged in the North Atlantic trade commenced tonight to issue a new schedule of fares that will become operative on Jan. 1, in accordance with an agreement reached by the North Atlantic conference of Dec. 7.

Members of the congregation of the Manhattan Congregational Church, which is housed in the Manhattan Towers, 2,166-8 Broadway, disclosed last night that they have virtually been locked out of their church. They said they faced the possibility of not holding Christmas services tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A questionnaire seeking to learn the amounts of their holding, how acquired and whether any stock was given as bonuses or for consideration of services in aviation concerns has been sent to all officers and directors of aviation companies holding air mail contracts between 1924 and the present time.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- Philadelphia's general transportation strike, of which President Roosevelt took cognizance today, showed first signs of disintegration tonight when the bakery drivers' local voted to withdraw its support.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Dec. 22 -- Mr. and Mrs. R. Thomas Watts Jr. of Lynchburg are announcing today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Langhorne Watts, to George Austen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Austen of University, Ga. The wedding will take place in June.
