With newsreel cameras grinding and flashlamps flaring, Governor Gifford Pinchot of Pennsylvania signed the bill that makes that State the twentieth to ratify the Child Labor Amendment yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital here.

Frank Lusk Babbett, philanthropist, connoisseur of art and a leading resident of Brooklyn, left the bulk of his estate to public institutions, it was disclosed yesterday by Phillips Avery, attorneys for the executors of Mr. Babbott's estate.
LEIPZIG, Saturday, Dec. 23 -- Marinus van der Lubbe was sentenced today to die for high treason in the burning of the Reichstag last February.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Praise for the enterprise of Admiral Byrd in flying from open water to explore unknown territory before his steamship reached her destination, was expressed tonight by Dr. Isaiah Bowman, director of the American Geographical Society of New York.
Former Mayor James J. Walker's sporty $16,500 town car (which the city purchased for him for $7,000) was sold, yesterday for $3,400.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 22 -- There are only three rooms to every house, big and small, a kitchen, a "settin' room" and a bedroom, and no citizen in this land should be so poor as to have less, Owen D. Young told a gathering here at a banquet held in connection with the dedication of the General Electric Institute at Nela Park.
By defeating the Harvard Club last night the Princeton Cub Class B squash tennis team moved into a tie for second place with the City A.C. in the Metropolitan League tourney.

An impenetrable defense which repulsed numerous onslaughts aided the New York A.C. sextet in scoring a 1-to-0 victory over a fighting Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club team last night at Madison Square Garden.
BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Twenty thousand dollars is the stumbling block in the deal that would send Charles (Chick) Hafey, Cincinnati's bespectacled outfielder, to the Braves.

Action on the proposal to establish the three-platoon system in the Fire Department will rest with Mayor-elect LaGuardia, because Mayor O'Brien yesterday deferred the Board of Estimate's action until today.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 23 -- A brief announcement of the birth of Japan's Crown Prince was broadcast throughout the empire today, followed by the playing of the national anthem.
Despite the generosity of 511 men, women and children, many of whom gave money they could ill spare, the Fund for the Neediest Cases suffered a reverse yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 22 -- The persistent head cold, a common ailment which long has baffled physicians, may at last have met its match.

VIENNA, Dec. 22 -- The Catholic Bishops of Austria issued tonight a sharply worded pastoral letter summoning the Austrian people to "stand firmly behind the Dollfuss government and the Catholic Church in order to prevent a situation similar to that now obtaining in Germany as regards the church and its clergy."

Father Knickerbocker surrendered yesterday to the genial old gentleman with the white whiskers and the red fur-trimmed suit who plans to pay his annual midnight visit to millions of homes here on Sunday.

DELHI, India, Dec. 22 -- The Legislative Assembly today passed the Reserve Bank Bill establishing a reserve bank free from political influence which has been regarded as an essential prerequisite to the proposed new federal constitution in India.
The building of a memorial in Times Square to the late Rev. Francis P. Duffy, wartime chaplain of the old Sixty-ninth Infantry, was expedited yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

The St. John's University quintet of Brooklyn last night outscored the John Marshall College of Law basketball team of Jersey City, 24 to 19, at Edison Gymnasium, Union City. A crowd of 1,000 attended.

Frank Gibney, 70 years old, and his brother Thomas, 72, died yesterday as they had lived -- mysteriously. They were both found dead in their dingy four-room flat at 226 East Twenty-second Street, where they had lived as recluses for thirty-six years.

Alice and those pleasantly mad companions of her trips in Wonderland and through the Looking Glass are now busy entertaining youngsters, and those who would like to be, in 225 theatres in this country and Canada, including the Paramount of this city.

Mrs. J. Stewart Brown and Mrs. Edwin Hume Benjamin jointly gave a dinner with dancing last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for Miss Virginia Saxton, debutante niece of Mrs. Benjamin. The guests were received by Mrs. Benjamin, who wore gold-colored satin, and Miss Saxton, who wore a gown of dull-gold lame and a corsage of orchids.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The biblical manuscript Codex Sinaiticus, the sale of which to Britain by the Soviet Government has aroused widespread protest in this country, will reach London Christmas Eve and be handed over to the British Museum next Wednesday.

For the final week of the year there has been scheduled a total of $12,721,971 of new State and municipal bonds for award through competitive sealed bidding. This compares with this week's revised total of $9,196,222. The weekly average of new municipal financing for the year to date stands at $15,187,614.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Announcement that President Roosevelt had not only ratified the silver agreement reached in the economic conference at London in July but had also ordered government purchase of silver at 64 1/2 cents an ounce has pleased the British "industrial north."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- While stock market tickers tapped out a bullish response today to President Roosevelt's silver purchase program, the President expressed the hope that the world-wide agreement brought to bear on silver could be extended to other monetary bases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Evidence that the Guardian Detroit Union Group, Inc., had deficits totaling $1,042,649.13 in 1930, 1931 and 1932, which were not reported to its stockholders, although reported to the Michigan State Securities Commission, was developed today before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., Dec. 22 -- John W. Van Buskirk, 50 years old, of Gordon Road, Essex Fells, president and director of C.J. Holt Co., customs agents, Manhattan, was killed here tonight when a car in which he was riding alone, was in collision with a truck.

The Misses Katherine and Joan Blake, daughters of Dr. Joseph A. Blake and the late Mrs. Duer Blake, were introduced to society last night at a large supper dance in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton, given jointly by Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Berlin and Mr. and Mrs. John W. Mackay.

The stimulation of interest in opera and the possible starting of opera companies in many urban centres will result from the broadcasting of the Metropolitan Opera presentations, Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association, said in a radio interview yesterday.

The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of $3.50 a share on the common stock in addition to the regular quarterly disbursement of 25 cents on the common and 87 1/2 cents on the preferred stock.

DUBLIN, Dec. 22 -- With General Owen O'Duffy out of jail and the great issue of the legality of wearing a blue shirt settled for this generation, the Irish Free State has settled down to decorating its Christmas trees and spending a pleasant festive season.

The Christmas demand for wine and liquor, coming on top of repeal, has drained the stocks available in this city. Yesterday retailers lacked entirely some kinds of liquors and the stocks of other kinds were rapidly thinning. Customers with lists of the bottles they wanted for the holiday celebration were compelled to make a tour of shops to piece their stocks together.

The two four-story and two five-story dwellings at 116 to 122 East Seventy-ninth Street, on a plot 71 by 102.2 feet, were bid in at auction yesterday for $100,000 by the plaintiff, the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, in an action against the 122 East Seventy-ninth Street Corporation and others, to satisfy a claim of $250,238.71.
Dr. John A. Harriss came to the aid of the city's pedestrians yesterday with a bright and gleaming red hand that proved a decided asset in their daily skirmish with traffic on Fifth Avenue.

Mrs. Lena Feldman, a widow with four small children, testified yesterday before License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine that she had given former Commissioner James F. Geraghty three $7.75 boxes of cigars while her children went hungry in a vain attempt to save her newsstand license.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 22 -- Henry Latrobe Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a tea dance this afternoon at the Sulgrave Club to present to society their daughter, Eleanor.
MONTREAL, Dec. 22 -- McGill University's unbeaten hockey team outclassed Harvard tonight at the Forum, 8 to 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to THE NEW YORK TIMES the public affairs committee of the Socialist party has announced its opposition to a policy of inflation. Norman Thomas at the same time presented for the committee a five-point recovery program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A subsistence homestead community, to consist of 200 families including about 1,000 people, is to be established in Monmouth County, N.J., Secretary Ickes announced today.

The application in behalf of professional musicians to restrain the Police Department Band from playing at any but official functions on the ground that it is a waste of city funds and helps to keep thousands of unemployed musicians out of work was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn.

In response to inquiries from THE NEW YORK TIMES, leading newspapers throughout the country last night sent the following editorial comment on President Roosevelt's decree for government purchase and coinage of silver.

Cathedral Boys High vanquished Manhattan Prep, 32 to 16, yesterday in the Manhattan College gymnasium for its second victory in as many New York division C.H.S. A.A. basketball games. John Pelkington, Cathedral centre, tallied 26 points. At half time, the winners led, 17 to 5.

HAVANA, Dec. 22 -- A student, Jose Hernandez, was shot in the leg and two others received minor injuries today when marines fired on a group of high school students demonstrating in front of the Department of the Interior.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In these swift days of crisis I often wish that more or us could rouse to life that inner force of which I heard long ago in the Alps at the top of the great St. Bernard -- from a gigantic old monk who through nearly forty Winters had gone out into storms with the huge dogs to rescue travelers lost in the snow.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Two Philadelphia stars, Andrew Ponzi and George Kelly, today qualified to meet for second place in the world's pocket billiard title tournament.
PARIS, Dec. 22 -- Despite the United States action to revalorize silver, the dollar remained firm in Paris today and the exchange market generally was calm.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 22 -- The sizzling 67 that Macdonald Smith posted in the first qualifying round of the Pasadena open championship yesterday was still the best of the lot tonight as the top-heavy field of 205 contestants was pared to scores of 78 or better.

Brooklyn Tech, the defending champion, went back into a tie with Jamaica for the lead in the P.S.A.L. hockey championship race by defeating New Utrecht, 2 to 0, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The game was one of three on the schedule, other winners being Erasmus Hall and Textile.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Internal Revenue Bureau reported stamp, manufactures' and miscellaneous taxes for the first five months of the 1934 fiscal year as follows:

Payment of the city's 130,000 civil works employes, delayed in many instances by technical difficulties arising from the necessity of setting up disbursement machinery in accordance with Federal regulations, was speeded up considerably yesterday as groups of workers in various parts of the city protested against delays in their checks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Roosevelt began a Christmas celebration today in which every one in the White House or officially connected with it was to participate, but members of his secretarial staff wrinkled their brows in perplexity over the flood of greetings and gifts coming from all parts of the country.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- The trustees of the University of Pennsylvania today reaffirmed their confidence in the Gates plan of intercollegiate athletic activity at Penn.

Stimulated by the President's proclamation regarding purchases of newly mined domestic silver and in sympathy with an advance in other markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange gained yesterday 20 points, or $1 a bale, or more. With the January position liquidated and notices issued for 20,000 bales, operators seemed more disposed to furnish support than for some time and all cotton offered was readily absorbed at advancing prices.
Manhattan real estate trading showed a substantial rise yesterday on the eve of the Christmas holidays. Two apartment building and a tall midtown store and loft structure changed ownership.

Blended properly with the holiday humors, "Going Hollywood" has enough basic liveliness to produce a sprightly and jocular mood at the Capitol. The overwhelming magnitude of the latter-day musical pictures is gratefully absent from this one.

Plans for purchase by the city of the Rockaway division of the Long Island Railroad, to be converted into a part of the city's rapid transit system and for a connection between this line and the Independent Subway under Queens Boulevard, were filed yesterday with the Board of Estimate by the Board of Transportation.

Mr. and Mrs. Morris Woodruff Kellogg of 14 East Seventy-second Street and Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Winthrop Kellogg, to Maitland Armstrong Edey, son of Mrs. Alfred Edey of this city and the late Mr. Edey.
The indoor polo season will get into full swing tonight with the opening game at Squadron A Armory, supplementing those at the Squadron C drill shed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES at Nov. 21 there appeared an item headed "State Income Tax Facing Reforms," in which the chairman of the State Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws announced that certain recommendations to modify and ease this burdensome tax had been adopted at a session of the commission at the Bar Association.

Christmas Trade Ending Strong. The week provided a brilliant close to the period of Christmas shopping, retail executives here reported yesterday. Heavy sales gains over a year ago were noted on every day of the week thus far, despite unfavorable weather conditions.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 22 -- The first steps by the Pan-American Conference to give concrete form to Secretary Hull's tariff proposal was taken today. The committee on new economic matters approved the Brazilian delegation's motion calling on the Pan-American countries to relax sanitary regulations having the effect of restricting exports.

With an enthusiastic introduction by Colonel Edward M. House, a new biography, "Paderewski: The Story of a Modern Immortal," will be published late next month by Macmillan. Charles Phillips, Professor of English Literature at the University of Notre Dame, wrote it.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22 -- A terrific blast against the housing, food supply and labor conditions generally in the new "giant Socialist city" of Magnitogorsk, steel centre in the Ural region, appears today in the newspaper Industrial Life, which is the organ of the Commissariat for Heavy Industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Rumors that further developments of importance in the administration's monetary policy impended were widely circulated tonight after a special meeting of Federal Reserve Bank governors with the Federal Reserve Board, about which a cloak of deep mystery was thrown. Those at the conference refused all comment about what had taken place, but there was an intimation that the deliberations were of great importance.
EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 22 -- Lou Little was optimistic today about the chances of his Columbia football team against Stanford at the Pasadena Rose Bowl on New Year's Day.

Two inquiries into racketeering are now going on in this city. Before one of them, conducted by a committee of the United States Senate, of which Senator COPELAND is chairman, evidence was produced to show that many workingmen have been compelled to give up a part of their wages -- sometimes a large part -- in order to keep their jobs.

A tea dance was given yesterday at the Park Lane by Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey S. Earnshaw of this city and Garden City, L.I., to present their daughter, Miss Rosalind Earnshaw. The debutante wore a gown of green and silver lame and carried a muff of gardenias.

The individual brilliancy of several of its basketball stars gained a decisive 44-to-29 victory for New York University over its ancient foe, Columbia, at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night before a gathering of 2,000. With its court forces still badly disorganized by the loan of some of its players to the Rose Bowl football squad, the Blue and White was never a match for the more polished Violet contingent.

HONGKONG, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Heavy casualties and extensive damage were reported today as a result of bombing raids by Nationalist Government aviators over Changchow, in Fukien Province. As troops of the revolutionary "people's government" in Fukien were said in Chinese dispatches to have been routed after sharp engagements with Nationalist forces along the near-by frontier of Chekiang Province, thirteen airplanes dropped thirty-two bombs on Changchow.

A sharp rally in all commodities and securities, with silver setting the pace, was the first reaction to the President's proclamation for the minting of all newly mined silver. In the financial community the action was considered to be inflationary in nature, and the dollar corroborated this impression by declining against all foreign currencies.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 22 -- The United States delegates to the Pan-American Conference plan to leave for home on the assumption that the Chaco peace negotiations will be too protracted to permit witnessing the final signature of the treaty.

The trend toward glorifying the amateur in American sports, reaching its peak in the boom times, has reacted to such an extent that sports observers, in summing up the trends and developments of 1933, now find a marked comeback by all the leading professional branches of athletics, with the single exception of boxing.
"Roman Scandals," with Eddie Cantor, Ruth Etting, David Manners and Gloria Stuart, will open at the Rivoli today.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- Finis to the baseball saga of Connie Mack -- its first chapter inscribed half a century ago, its latest just drying on the pages -- will be written only when the diamond dean no longer can carry on.
The Newhouse Galleries have opened their second annual exhibition of American genre paintings, which depict the robust pioneer period. This show will remain through January.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- With the remark that "the money the government is distributing through the Civil Works Administration is practically a dole," General Johnson today criticized Harry L. Hopkins, Emergency Relief Administrator, for setting wages higher than the minimums in NRA codes.
LONDON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A Reuters dispatch from Turin today said the Princess Yolanda, eldest daughter of the King and Queen of Italy, had given birth to a son.

Following a firm opening, there was a moderate setback yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The main body of stocks closed with average prices 1 to 6 points higher. Mining shares led the slow advance, reflecting the announcement of the government's plans for the purchase of newly mined silver.

Races out in Long Island Sound rather than in the harbors will predominate for the Star class sloops, as a result of a decision last night at the meeting of the Western Long Island Sound fleet of the International Star Class Association. The gathering was held at the Western Universities Club.

Franchise grants for twenty-five years, with no right of recapture by the city, were awarded by the Board of Estimate yesterday to the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, the New York City Omnibus Corporation, the Madison Avenue Coach Company and the Comprehensive Omnibus Corporation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Opposition to the Prince plan of railroad consolidation, coupled with a demand that employes and public be consulted in consideration of any consolidation plan, formed part of the program adopted today by the Railway Labor Executives Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Dec. 16 amounted to 554,832 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 17,329 cars, or 3.2 per cent, more than in the preceding week and 39,063 cars, or 7.6 per cent, more than in the corresponding week last year, but 26,338 cars, or 4.5 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Ways and Means Committee today adopted a levy of $2 a gallon on distilled spirits as the basic rate for new liquor taxes to be recommended to the House.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 22 -- A broadcast program from Station XMAS, including carols, recitations, dialogues and a Christmas play, was presented this morning by pupils of the Palm Beach Private School, Inc., before a large attendance of parents and guests.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Winnipeg will be the only grain market open tomorrow, as all American and Argentine exchanges, as well as that in Liverpool, are to close for the Christmas holiday.

A trio consisting of William Kroll, violinist; Milton Prinz, 'cellist, and Frank Sheridan, pianist, gave its first concert at the Town Hall last night. The ensemble, which presented a series of recitals at Cummington, Mass., last Summer, played the Brahms Trio in B, Op. 8; Mozart's Trio in C, Kochel 548, and Ravel's Trio in A.

Commodities traded on local exchanges were influenced yesterday more by the silver news than by anything else. In all the markets except that for copper, prices reversed their recent downward trend and closed with gains. Trading was substantially more active.

MADRID, Dec. 22 -- The situation in Cuba continues to arouse anxiety for the fate of Spanish citizens there. Although the matter was not mentioned in the official report of today's Cabinet meeting, it is understood the government was informed by Foreign Minister Leandro Pito Romero of grave disturbances in Cuba, and it was decided to get further reports from the Spanish Ambassador in Havana.

Leopold Godowsky, pianist and composer, announced yesterday through his daughter, Mrs. David Saperton of 171 West Seventy-first Street, the loss of two suitcases containing mementos of his wife, who died Dec. 4 at the Ansonia Hotel.

A brilliant dash by John Bissell, which ended in a pass to Pieter Fosburgh, opened the way for the St. Paul's School hockey team to gain a tie with the Yale Freshmen at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

A resident of New York State who owns stock in a liquidated bank in another State may not claim immunity from assessment on his stock under the laws of the other State, Surrogate George A. Wingate in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

Miss Beatrice Cutting Wagstaff made her debut last night at a dinner dance in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton given jointly by Mr. and Mrs. George B. Wagstaff and Mr. and Mrs. David Wagstaff. The debutante is the daughter of George B. Wagstaff and the Hon. Mrs. Lionel Forbes-Sempill of London and niece of David Wagstaff.

Emanuel Vidal Lazaga, former officer in the Cuban Air Service and reported to be a refugee, was killed instantly yesterday when a plane he was flying crashed in Flushing Bay. According to eyewitnesses, he sacrificed his life to protect persons on the ground at College Point.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Secretary Ickes replied by letter today to Senator Borah who criticized the pending agreements bearing upon price and marketing practices in the oil industry. Senator Borah, maintained that the agreements threatened the welfare of the small, independent oil companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec 22 -- Despite a number of seasonal declines in November, internal revenue collections for the first five months of the 1934 fiscal year amounted to $913,114,037, an increase of $379,671,599 over last year. The Internal Revenue Bureau announced today that miscellaneous internal revenue had brought in $630,636,299 for the five months, an increase of $299,327,994; income taxes $188,548,881, a drop of $13,585,251, and processing taxes $93,928,857, a net gain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The opinion of a Chief National Bank Examiner last year that the Guardian Group of banks in Detroit was "somewhat of a promotion scheme" and that dividends were declared "far beyond the point of conservatism" was presented today to the Senate committee.

The Board of Estimate authorized Controller George McAneny yesterday to sell city securities to make up deficits in the police pension fund and in the payrolls of the Hospitals and Education Departments.

Bonds of domestic corporations and leading foreign loans moved higher on the Stock Exchange yesterday as United States Government issues sagged in response to the government's announcement regarding its silver-purchase policy. Long-term Federal obligations closed at net losses of 1-32 to 18-32 point, except the called fourth Liberty 4 1/4 s, which held unchanged, and the Treasury 3 3/8 s, due in 1947, callable in 1943, which moved up 1-32 point.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Whether Pope Pius's Christmas address tomorrow before the College of Cardinals would be broadcast from the Vatican City radio station had not been definitely decided tonight, but it was believed his voice would go on the air at noon [6 A.M., Eastern standard time] and would be heard throughout the world.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 23. -- Thirty travel-weary Columbia football players shook the transcontinental dust off their feet today and immediately set about conjuring some gridiron tricks for the edification of Stanford in the Rose Bowl, Pasadena, New Year's Day.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23. -- Carrying top weight of 118 pounds over the six-furlong course with ease, Frank D. Seremba's Zekiel proved the best by far of the six racers which started in the New Orleans Athletic Club Purse that headed today's program at Jefferson Park.

Drinking and Driving. NOW that the nation has reached the maturity of its Twenty-first Amendment, anxious individuals have expressed the fear that there will be an epidemic of Adiadochokinesis among operators of motor vehicles, which, being interpreted, means inability to perform skilled acts.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 23. -- The next-to-last day of racing at the current meeting s brought with it one of the biggest surprises of the session as Mrs. E.M. Doumani's Mobile romped home first in the fifth race at 55 to 1. It was his second victory in as many days and the exceptionally long price was a welcome windfall to his backers.

TO the lay mind the great public collections of books in this country seem to be located along the Atlantic or Pacific shore lines. But there is a library in Chicago that is great in a special and important sense. The most impressive feature of the Newberry Library is its disinterested devotion to scholarship, as is clearly shown in the recently published Handbook.

CHRISTMAS trade finished strong last week, with frequent instances throughout the country of total running 30 to 40 per cent ahead of last year. The peak was reached a week ago yesterday and held over the first two days of last week.

LEIPZIG, Dec. 23. -- The verdict of the German Supreme Court, which sentenced Marinus van der Lubbe to death for treason and revolutionary arson in connection with the Reichstag fire but acquitted all the other defendants, including Ernst Torgler and Georgi Dimitroff, was denounced today in official Nazi press statements as "a miscarriage of justice."

The machinery set up to coordinate the work of aiding refugees from Germany to find a new place in the world was discussed in detail by James G. MacDonald, high commissioner for refugees coming from Germany, in a statement prepared at the request of THE NEW YORK TIMES and issued shortly after his arrival last night on the United States liner Manhattan.

Colonel Jacob Ruppert, principal sponsor of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition, was thrilled yesterday by the admiral's flight over the unknown southern ocean. But he expressed concern for the good health and comfort of the hundred-odd men whom he had helped to send to the chill loneliness of the south polar seas on a vessel named in his honor.
PARIS, Dec. 23. -- Robert Gordon Switz, American aviator, and his wife denied today all knowledge of the espionage activities of the international ring which they are accused of aiding.

Miss Lucinda Corcoran has chosen a committee of several of her friends to assist her with plans for a tea dance Wednesday in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria in the interests of the benefit hockey match between the teams of Princeton and McGill Universities on Saturday night in Madison j Square Garden.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Prices of wheat more or less charted their own course here today, as the Christmas feeling pervaded the pit and trading was slim. Meager export buying met no opposition in the shape of offerings, with the result that values advanced to close near the top at 7/8 to 1 cent higher.
The Governors Island team vanquished the Squadron C trio, 8 -- 5 1/2, last night at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn in a Class B engagement of the Metropolitan Indoor Polo Circuit.

SEATTLE, Dec. 23. -- With thirteen dead, many injured, and thousands homeless, the Pacific Northwest tonight received a ray of hope of a cessation of the storms and floods that have been sweeping this part of the country. The hope came in a weather forecast of lower temperatures which would stem the floods.

MR. MORTON'S "In Search of Scotland," though a delightful book, had a serious limitation -- it did not discover everything in and about Scotland. It did not explore every glen, loch, mountain pass, fishing village, country town, parish kirk, tolbooth, and ruined castle; it neglected to mention the birthplace of every Macdonald now in New Zealand and McTavish in Newfoundland!

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Admirers of Woodrow Wilson, will be led in tributes to his memory on his birthday anniversary next Thursday by two who served under him in Washington -- President Roosevelt, who was Assistant Secretary of the Navy from 1913 to 1920, and Roland S. Morris of Philadelphia, who was Ambassador to Japan from 1917 to 1921.

THE almost simultaneous publication of the latest volume of poems by William Butler Yeats and his "Collected Poems" with "The Winding Stair included, is a particularly happy conjunction. For those who have followed Yeats down the decades it is sufficed only to bring the added sheaf into the granary; for those who have -- perhaps through the for tune of fewer years -- not known the poetry of Ireland's foremost minstrel.

PRAGUE, Dec. 23. -- The funeral of former Premier Anton Svehla has just afforded an ocular demonstration of how, although completely encircled by a sea of Fascist reactionary States, Czechoslovakia, in the words of President Franz Soukup of the Senate, "forms an island of democratic liberty in Middle Europe."

LEIPZIG, Dec. 22. -- The acquitted defendants in the Reichstag fire trial were held in Leipzig prison tonight and the fact that they were detained in Saxony after having been placed under the jurisdiction of the Reichstag was interpreted in various quarters an meaning that the efforts of a foreign committee, which arrived here seeking permission to accompany the Bulgarians to the border, had not been successful.

AGAIN the famous controversy between Orville Wright and the Smithsonian Institution has been revived and there now appears a faint possibility that the first machine to carry man in flight may receive its due recognition in the aeronautical museum in Washington.

In the holiday season filled with parties for the many young people at home from schools and colleges, one of the larger entertainments in prospect is the interschool and college dance to be held Saturday night in the Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

A NEW war book, "The Paris Front: A Diary, 1914-1918," by Michel Corday, is announced for publication on Jan. 15 by E.P. Dutton Co. It is a diary of the home front written by a gifted author, high in the civil service of France, whose closest friends were Anatole France, Painleve, Briand, Caillaux, Rolland,

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Hans Lange will give the first New York performance of Lopatnikoff's symphony No. 1 at its Thursday and Friday concerts this week. Lopatnikoff, who has lived in Berlin since 1921 and studied there with Ernst Toch, has written string quartets, two-piano concerti for orchestra and a scherzo played some years ago by the Boston Symphony.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 23 (AP). -- An intensive campaign will be started shortly after the first of the year to organize several minor baseball leagues in Texas and adjacent States, Joe F. Carr, promotional director of minor league baseball, announced today.
BOSTON, Dec. 20. -- Once more the municipal Christmas tree towers on Boston Common, seventy-five feet in height, agleam with a thousand colored lights and topped with a star aflame.

THE "Standing Room Only" sign for concerts will be displayed again if artists will take advantage of the opportunity radio offers to double their potential audience, according to Albert Spalding, violinist, recently returned from a concert tour of the Middle West.

AWAY back in the Eighteen Seventies when Detroit was budding from a frontier village into a thriving city, the firm of Candler Brothers stood high in reputation and importance in its commercial and civic life.

TORONTO, Ont., Dec. 23. -- Gold production in Ontario in November amounted to $3,587,975, an increase of $139,612 over the total in October, but $346,208 under the production in November, 1932. For the month, ore milled was down 839 tons to 483,867 tons, indicating treatment of higher grade.

ADVENTURERS and castaways in far-away places, lonely watchers of the lights that guard rockbound coasts and treacherous shoals, men who patrol waste lands and seaways, such minutemen as newspaper reporters and policemen -- to these, also, Christmas comes.

TOKYO, Dec. 5. -- In the next ten years Japan must find work and food for nearly 10,000,000 more people than she employs and feed today. It is true that the death rate and the birth rate run in double harness; while the young workers are coming forward the old are quitting the scene.

FANCIERS of antique furnishings no longer accept mere age as evidence of worth nor a dilapidated condition as proof of antiquity. They look for an all-around superiority. That includes beauty of design, fine craftsmanship, good condition, and proper authentication as to its period or better still as to the name of the maker of the article.

HOLLYWOOD. CHECKING the achievements and failures of the year now closing, the cinema views itself with a degree of pride and, frankly, some amazement. Hollywood believes it has turned out a greater number of the better pictures during "1933 than in any previous similar period, and, to its astonishment, it has found that in a greater percentage of cases than ever before the good films have made money.

MILAN, Dec. 6, 1933. IN compensation for shorter opera seasons, Italy's leading music centres are having a full symphonic diet this year. No fewer that four series are running at the present time, and a fifth is in the offing for January.

THE progressive spirit evident in American higher education in recent years is manifesting itself not only in curriculum changes and physical improvements, but also in efforts toward coordination and cooperation between institutions, in mergers and other reorganizations.

Membership in voluntary chain grocery groups this year expanded at a rate approximating that for the calendar year 1932, despite the fact that since January the chains have placed more emphasis on increasing the volume in existing units than on acquiring new members, the American Institute of Food Distribution, which makes an annual survey of developments in the voluntary chain field, disclosed yesterday.

In a letter sent to Richard Hoxsey, executive assistant of the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange, a special committee of the American Institute of Accountants has drafted a suggestion for the form of an accountant's report.

TORY" persists like a word that answers a human need. Four times in four centuries it has lapsed from usage only to be revived. From Ireland it crossed to Scotland, migrated to England, voyaged to America to have a part in opposing the revolt of the Colonies, vanished with the withdrawal or deportation of Tories and the end of royalism.

The appointment of James E. Finegan, Fusion nominee for Controller in 1925, as chairman of the Kings County executive committee of the City Fusion party was announced yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, its city chairman.

Several performances of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe at the St. James Theatre have been taken over to raise funds for various organizations in the city. The one on Wednesday afternoon will aid the Schola Cantorum and that Tuesday night the Neurological Institute.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 23. -- Advices received here tell of heavy fighting between Nanking troops and rebels in Fukien Province.

Despite the diminished volume of business of the Bank for International Settlements, now in the fourth year of its existence, and the apparent defeat of many of the hopes entertained for it by force of "harsh circumstances," an estimate of the future of the institution must consider that it is the only existing machinery for the eventual establishment of international monetary stability, according to the Midland Bank of London in its current monthly review.
The limited stocks of legal liquor in many stores in the city were sold out completely yesterday as the result of the heavy holiday demand for wines, whiskies and liqueurs.

SIXTY-FIVE years ago a French traveler in China was so fascinated by the behavior of a small fish from the rice-field ditches that he sent a few home as curiosities. Thus the paradise-fish started a hobby that has spread all over the globe.

LONDON, Dec. 9. I AM beginning to develop a distrust of plays that rely upon pretenses. When one of the characters says, in effect. "Let's pretend that you and I are married, though, in fact, we are not," I know, and we all know, with painful intuition what will happen.
SOMETIMES the thoughts that are in the minds of actors in historic scenes must be a great deal different from those which the portrait painters and the conventional historians would have us imagine.

The agricultural South is leading the nation in a business recovery which carries indications of progressive improvement, according to results of a national business survey just completed by Fenner, Beane Ungerleider, members of the New York Stock Exchange and other Exchanges.

REPORTS of the Reichstag arson trial before the Reichsgericht, the Supreme Court of Germany, have aroused interest in this country concerning the differences between American and German criminal procedure.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Hilton S. Crouch, 29 years old, member of the Indiana gang headed by John Dillinger, was arrested here today and was said by Police Captain John Stege to have confessed participating in the Massachusetts Avenue bank robbery at Indianapolis along with Dillinger and Harry Copeland, another member of the band, in which "about $25,000" was taken last Summer.
Columbia enjoyed marked success in football and baseball during 1933, while the wrestling and waterpolo squads compiled the best records among the so-called minor sports teams.

ANOTHER chapter wag recently added to the colorful history of the United States Marine Corps when the expeditionary forces at Quantico, Va., and San Diego, Calif., were abolished and merged into a new fleet marine force directly under the commander-in-chief of the fleet.
DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 20. -- With Uncle Sam in the role of Santa Claus, Detroit is celebrating a far happier Christmas than seemed likely a few weeks ago.
PARIS, Dec. 23. -- During the past week France held her second Colonial Conference, where important matters pertaining to the trade with her vast colonial empire were discussed.

PEIFING, Dec. 2. -- A Swedish scientist, Erik Norin, who more than five months ago plunged into the wilderness of Western China in search of a missing fellow-country-man, has returned to Peiping after an adventuresome journey.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- The city's milk supply was curtailed seriously today and minor out-breaks of violence were reported as leaders of Philadelphia's truck strike sought to increase its effectiveness in the face of outright disapproval from the International Executive Board of the Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers.

IN addtion to "Flying Down to Rio," the present occupant of the Radio City Music Hall, RKO-Radio has two other pictures ready for national release. The first is "If I Were Free," based upon John Van Druten's play of last season, "Behold We Live."

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 23. -- Congress approved today the 1934 budget of 243,000,000 pesos, an increase of 10,000,000 over this year. Acting Finance Minister Mate R. Gomez set apart 40,669,180 pesos for internal and external debts, as against 25,468,709 this year.

Retailers need have no fear of monetary inflation affecting instalment selling adversely, according to a study made by Arthur Fertig of the accounting and auditing firm of the same name. Only the wildest type of inflation, in which price levels would soar from week to week, could affect the consumer credit structure to the point of hazard, he said yesterday.

EDMONTON, Alta., Dec. 21. -- Out of the frozen north country from Fort McMurray in Northern Alberta and from other northern outposts down the Mackenzie River basin as far as Great Bear Lake and Aklavik, N.W.T., on the Arctic Coast, pilots who fly the cold northern air lanes are sending novel Christmas and New Year's greetings this holiday season.

A NEW opera company, the Royal Opera House Company, Ltd., is being formed in London, according to a recent article in The London Times. Sir Thomas Beecham will be the principal conductor and artistic director. The company has obtained an agreement to lease the Royal Opera House from the Covent Garden Properties Company, Ltd., which is making important improvements in the building.

Christmas week, which customarily has been the gayest period of each Winter in parties for debutantes, will be distinguished this year by the opening of the Metropolitan Opera season on Tuesday night.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Arsenal, English League champion and present leader, got off on the long holiday soccer grind right today by trouncing Sheffield United, 3 to 1, at Sheffield. Derby County, in a gallant fight to gain undisputed possession, of second place, was held to a scoreless draw at Sunderland.

DUBLIN, Dec. 23. -- The tussle between the de Valera government and General Owen O'Duffy, Opposition leader, took a dramatic turn this evening when it was announced that the government would bring General O'Duffy before a military tribunal on Jan. 2 on a charge of incitement to murder the President of the Free State Executive Council.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- The merchants of this community in the heart of the Mohawk Valley dairy country have found a way of stimulating Christmas trade in a depression year, getting their customers to pay up back bills and keeping trade from going to neighboring cities and chain stores.

The horses had a Christmas tree on the sidewalk, but the dogs had to trot up a flight of stairs, while the cats were carried up in sweaters and zipper vests yesterday to attend the annual party given by the Humane Society of New York at 49 Seventh Avenue.

THE Metropolitan's official opening of the new opera season will take place Tuesday evening with a performance of "Peter Ibbetson." Lucrezia Bori, Edward Johnson and Lawrence Tibbett will be heard in the leading roles.

TORONTO, Dec. 23 (AP). -- The group-leading Toronto Maple Leafs grave a pre-Christmas crowd of 13,000 a thrill tonight by defeating the Montreal Maroons, 8 -- 2, in a wide-open National Hockey League game in which the Maroons tried vainly to match the Leafs in speed.

American manufacturers booking Russian orders are scheduled to play a considerable part in helping the Soviet build up exports to this country, according to information supplied here yesterday by those in close touch with current Russian trade negotiations.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 21. -- Virginia in general and Loudoun County in particular acquitted themselves quite creditably in the recent trial at Leesburg of the Negro, George Crawford, for the murder of Mrs. Agnes Boeing Ilsley, who was found beaten to death in her Middleburg home nearly two years ago.

The national recovery program has brought Jobs to more than 140,300 persons in the department store field, has raised payrolls to a high level and placed department store employment conditions as a whole on a basis comparing favorably with 1929, according to the results of a survey announced yesterday by the store management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

BUFFALO, Dec. 23. -- Preparation for capacity production in the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation factory here was begun, following receipt of word from Washington that a contract for twenty-one large patrol planes had been awarded as part of a $10,000,000 navy aircraft order.
Son of Charles Dickens. "WHAT did Christmas mean to Charles Dickens?" or, putting the question in another form, "What was my father's attitude toward Christmas?"

LONDON, says the cable, is having its usual fill of pantomimes and revivals, and with only one opening this week. That would be "Without Witness," by Anthony Armstrong (he wrote "Ten Minute Alibi") and Harold Simpson.

IN his preface the author says: "By reputation he (Barry) is universally known and beloved, but the particulars of his career are not so familiar to his fellow-Americans of the present generation as they ought to be." It was not until May 16. 1914, that a statue of Commodore Barry brought the hero of this book to the notice of his countrymen of a later day.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21. -- On Jan. 23 the first Matas Award in Vascular Surgery will be presented in this city to Dr. Mont R. Reid, Professor of Surgery at the University of Cincinnati and for many years a student of the teachings and methods of Dr. Rudolph Matas, for whom the award is named.
AT Christmas, remember the Neediest! Remember those who, in the season of friendliness, are friendless; those who, of all in the city, are in deepest need of good-will.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 23 (Canadian Press). -- Anxiety concerning the crop outlook in Europe, freer puts chasing by exporters and the Washington government's silver-buying policy helped turn wheat values upward at the close of a week of holiday trade.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Demand that the railroads restore the 10 per cent wage deduction made in February 1932, and accompany it with a substantial wage increase was made today by F.H. Fljozdal, president of the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employes.

LONDON. WHEN the representatives of the powers assemble in Geneva for the meeting of the League Council on Jan. 15, they will decide whether there is any hope of resuscitating the unhappy Disarmament Conference or whether the nations of Europe -- all professedly bent upon keeping the peace -- shall continue to arm, perhaps on a greater scale, in anticipation of an inevitable war.

MADISON, Wis. THE time and money of both university and student are being saved under a new policy evolved by the language department of the University of Wisconsin in the course of two and one-half years of experiments.
LONDON, Dec. 23. -- England is going to have a merry Christmas, with the reasonable expectation that the New Year will be more comfortable than the old one.

Fishermen and their needy families in North Newfoundland and Labrador will be aided by a special performance of "Rigoletto" Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera, which has been taken over by persons interested in the work of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Mission to raise funds for the organization.

SOME of the results of the four-year scientific research into the effects of motion pictures upon children and youth are already, in a measure, familiar to the public, owing to the wide publicity given to the summary popular volume, "Our Movie-Made Children."

THE new system of pedestrian-vehicular traffic control being tried out on Fifth Avenue between Fortieth and Forty-fifth Streets marks another attempt to coordinate regulation of the city's enormous volume of foot and motor traffic so that both may move expeditiously and safely.

TO compile a dictionary seems to require not only a strong mind but ample time at the disposal of the compiler. Dr. Johnson's famous dictionary took him eight years to complete, with the help of assistants. The New Oxford Dictionary, a far more complete and voluminous work, took the editors more than fifty years to finish.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP). -- Knocking each other about like ten-pins in an intensive scrimmage, Stanford's Cardinals completed their "at home" practice today before leaving for Pasadena to meet Columbia in the Rose Bowl football classic New Year's Day.

ROBERT A. TAFT was graduated from Yale in 1910. Charles P. Taft. his younger brother-both are sons of the late President and Chief Justice -- was graduated in 1918. Both were high stand men and active in undergraduate affairs.

MR. BOOTH'S very interesting book is the outcome of much study of the conditions and characteristics of the environment In which Jesus lived, as that surrounding world has been at least partially cleared up and illuminated by modern research.

Still "Peace on Earth." To the Drama Editor: "Peace on Earth" is the most exciting play I have seen in some years. Presented with great skill by the Theatre Union, it serves to renew one's wavering faith in a living theatre.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Walter Duranty's information that the Soviet Government will rush people to Siberia, stressing the necessity of extensive colonization in Eastern Siberia, recalls some of the colonization activities of the previous Russian Government, which I had an opportunity to study during my years in Siberia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, appearing instead of Santa Claus today at the Salvation Army Christmas-basket party, spontaneously made three speeches instead of one.

The nature of the report that Colonel LINDBERGH will make to the Pan American Airways, for whom he undertook a survey of transatlantic air routes which covered 29,081 miles, lasted five months and embraced four continents and thirty-one countries and colonies, is known only to himself.

Crookedness in American finance and banking at large has not been demonstrated by the Senate's investigation of the affairs of a few prominent bankers, according to Dr. H. Parker Willis, whose article "Are the Bankers to Blame?", appears in January Current History Dr. Willis, for many years Professor of Banking at Columbia University, assisted the House Banking and Currency Committee during the drafting of the Federal Reserve Act.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- Connie Mack, veteran of half a century of baseball, passed the seventy-first milestone on his trail of life today by venturing eagerly into a new field for him.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 23. -- The Christmas period will afford little rest for the Pan-American Conference delegates, according to indications today. Despite a concerted effort in the committees with unfinished calendars to reach their final conclusions, divergent viewpoints held up certain projects.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- With infinite difficulty at last the French Chamber of Deputies and Senate have been persuaded, coaxed, manoeuvred and threatened into passing a measure of financial reform which will take up about two-thirds, if it is well applied, of the deficit in this year's budget.

ONE hundred years ago men were much perplexed. Their world, like our world at this Christmas time, was in rapid transition, the landmarks were disappearing and customs were changing. Faith was shaken.

Mayor-elect LaGuardia announced yesterday three additional appointments to his cabinet. Austin H. MacCormick was made Commissioner of Correction, Rufus E. McGahen, Budget Director, and K. J. McGrew Jr., Deputy Commissioner of Plant and Structures.

PASADENA. PASADENA is putting itself in readiness to receive more than a host of visitors on New Year's Day, when its Tournament of Roses, one of the great floral fetes of the world, will be held for the forty-fifth time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The export trade of the United States improved in each month from May through September, an analysis of the first nine months of 1933 by the foreign commerce department of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States shows.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Father Coughlin would have us believe that if silver were substituted for gold as the money standard our economic troubles would be solved. How any one can seriously advance this view puzzles me. A brief consideration of the elementary principles underlying commodity exchange will reveal the fallacies of his position.

OMAHA, Dec. 21. -- In three farm States Christmas will be celebrated this year with lighter hearts and a more widespread distribution of material comforts than last. It will still be a hard Winter for many, but the problem of coping with It has been vastly simplified by the intervention of Federal aid, and a general spirit of optimism spices the atmosphere of cheer natural to the season.

Tonight will be Christmas Eve. It will bring thousands of fortunate families together in joyful re-unions, yet it will find more of the Neediest unprovided for than on any other Christmas Eve in recent years.

UNDER trying conditions, involving not only economic stress but also spectacular competition from abroad, American dancers are proving themselves extraordinarily adaptable and ingenious. Without sacrificing anything of their high purposes, they have entered fields that are generally considered far removed from the rarified atmosphere of the concert stage, and have found unmistakably that the lay public is eager and able to accept "good" dancing.

J. Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., will foe the No. 1 junior player in the United States Lawn Tennis Association's ranking for the coming year, it was announced yesterday. The Oakland player is placed ahead of Gene Mako, the tall Los Angeles racquet-wielder, while Jay Cohn, also of Los Angeles, is third.

THIS book is so slight that you can hardly keep it from floating right out of your hand. It is young, exuberant, bubbling and a bit gushing. To one with vague memories of earlier novels by the same author -- and thirty-eight of them are listed in this book -- it seems a typical Berta Ruck story.

JERUSALEM. LIFE goes on in the little town of Bethlehem today very much as in the long ago when wise men from the East came with gifts for a child whose first cradle was a manger. Time has left its marks of change, yet the eyes of the visitor can still see Bethlehem as it was at that first Christmastide.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 23. -- The Naval Academy will meet nine opponents in football next season, so selected that it will not have to undergo so unrelenting a strain as during the season just closed. The midshipmen will play the Military Academy on Franklin Field in Philadelphia Dec. 1.

Sweeping through the preliminaries, semi-finals and final roundrobin with the loss of only a single bout, Fred Kornfeld, N.Y.U. junior, captured first place in the New York Athletic Club's annual invitation intercollegiate foils competition last night on the Winged Foot strips.

Premium lists for fifty-eighth annual bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club are now being received by prospective exhibitors all over the country, in Canada and in foreign lands. The familiar golden booklet tells all about the greatest canine show on earth.

Parke H. Davis, well-known football figure, recalls that President FranKlin D. Roosevelt was a tackle and fullback at Groton and played on informal class teams at Harvard; that Woodrow Wilson was coach at Princeton in 1878, 1879 and 1890 and coach at Wesleyan in 1888 and 1889; that Theodora Roosevelt assumed control of football in 1905 and reformed the game, and that Herbert Hoover was financial manager of the Stanford University team of 1894.

Because of the Christmas holiday business will be suspended tomorrow in all financial centres. The markets, the banks and business organizations generally will be closed. The usual activity will be resumed on Tuesday.

A PAIR of monumental lions carved to guard the portal of some splendid Chinese edifice of the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) have recently been set up at the entrance of a new wing of the Mills College Art Gallery in California.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Dec. 23. -- Two telegrams were read to the 1,400 disabled veterans today at the United States Veterans Hospital here. The first, from President Roosevelt, addressed to all disabled veterans, follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia won second place in the world's pocket billiard championship tournament tonight by defeating George Kelly, national titleholder, also of Philadelphia, in the play-off by the score of 125 to 38 in eight innings.

THE difference, often great and always present, between an artist's drawing and the print that is made from it was first illustrated for me many years ago when I had the privilege of going over Blake's famous manuscript book then in the collection of Mr. W.A. White of Brooklyn.
Infant Adjustment Administration. Alice and the Duchess returned from their walk to find the White Rabbit playing with the baby.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Ambassador Bingham, who recently returned from London on the first leave of absence since he went abroad in the Spring, brought to President Roosevelt in conferences last night and this morning a report of great improvement in the economic situation of Great Britain.

VANCOUVER, Dec. 21. -- The first conference of Premiers of Western Canada, which has concluded its sittings in Victoria recently, is the genesis of a fight to be carried on by a united bloc of Provinces west of the Great Lakes to obtain better terms from financially powerful, industrialized Eastern Canada.

Several performances of "The Lake" at the Martin Beck Theatre during the coming week have been taken over in behalf of charitable undertakings. The performance Wednesday night will aid the work of the Women's Auxiliary of Union Settlement, at 237 East 104th Street, which provides care and necessities for the needy of Harlem, irrespective of race or creed.

A meeting sponsored by the Women's New York Lacrosse Association will be held early in January to discuss organization plans that are expected effect the programs of club, college and school teams during the next year.

The bearings on extortion and irregularities in news stand licenses under former Commissioner James F. Geraghty will be continued Tuesday by1 License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine. Although Mr. Levine indicated yesterday that he expected to develop important testimony which may warrant immediate grand jury presentation, he would not divulge the line that he expected the testimony to take.

Columbia's chess team, which will participate in the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League beginning Tuesday, yesterday defeated a quartet of players representing St. John's College, 4 -- 0, in the second round of the championship of the newly organized New York City Intercollegiate Chess Association at the New York University Chess Club.

MANILA, Nov. 29. -- Events connected with and following the close of the current session of the Legislature in the Philippines have given Governor General Frank Murphy a new field in which to work. It now appears likely that in connection with his changes in administrative procedure he will also undertake to modify and correct some of the abuses in legislative methods.

Handling close to 225 cases of alleged violations of the retail code since the pact went into effect or Oct. 30, the New York Retail Code Authority has investigated and acted upon labor questions, misleading liquidation sale advertising free premiums, deceptive merchandise descriptions and misbranding, according to Maurice Mermey, executive secretary of the code authority.

Bela de Nagy won the New York Athletic Club saber championship in the annual fencing tournament yesterday at the New York A.C. He defeated Dr. John R. Huffman, national indoor saber champion, 5 to 3, in a fence-off for the club crown after each had won six matches in the regular round-robin competition.

OF real significance to the movement to provide adequate docking facilities for water-going aircraft at many of the key cities of the country, and notably at New York, which is gaining impetus as trial proves its soundness, is the experience in commuting by air which Richard F. Hoyt had last season.

DEPARTING widely from the work of her famous brother Marcel, whose "Nude Descending the Staircase" was such a focal point of embattled art a score of years ago, Suzanne Duchamp is represented, in the exhibition of her work at the Delphic Studios, by light, almost playful water-colors, more akin to Raoul Duty's suggestive shorthand.

"WASHINGTON, Dec. (AP). -- Legislation to require drastic reforms in Stock Exchange procedure was predicted today by Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Senate Banking Committee, as a result of data now being collected on market operations.

A YEAR has passed since the Emperor Has Taffari under-took to press on with anti-slavery reform measures in Ethiopia and to bring slavery to an end within a period of twenty years. Some advance in certain directions can undoubtedly be recorded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP). -- One main line of railroad between Chicago and the Puget Sound section was termed the best means of economy in railroad operation through the Northwest, in a study of possible savings based on the Prince plan for railroad coordination placed before Joseph B. Eastman, Federal coordinator.

Some Have Knowledge. I saw a truck tearing a sign, "Licensed Plumber"; another, marked "Licensed Electrician," showing that some knowledge of these trades is required of the persons who practice them. Your illuminating lines: "But in these days it is seldom deemed necessary to understand the mechanism of finance before instructing the public about it," furnish the key to the "New Deal" finance.

Fordham's varsity football team will face eight opponents in its 1934 campaign, according to the schedule announced by Graduate Manager Jack Coffey yesterday. The drive will begin on Oct. 6 against Westminster and close with the traditional encounter with New York University on Nov. 29.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Regulations under the code for the petroleum industry by which orderly development of new petroleum pools is provided were issued today by Secretary Ickes, thus adding another safeguard to those established for conserving the nation's petroleum resources and preventing waste and cut-throat competition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- A continuation of the increase in construction work, reflecting an expansion of public works, took place in November and the first half of December, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its monthly business review.

Berkeley Bell, who is beginning an intensive indoor tennis campaign, drew a step nearer his first objective when he reached the final round of the metropolitan title tourney at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory last night. He defeated Frank Bowden, the former Columbia ace, 6 -- 1, 9 -- 7.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 21. -- Texas is witnessing the passing of the political pussyfooter. A new era of frankness seems to be opening up here, a new deal of honesty in politics brought in by the Roosevelt administration. True, it is only opening up here, and many politicians feel that the old pussyfooting ways they have trod so long are still the safest.

VATICAN CITT, Dec. 23. -- Pope Pius in his Christmas message asspiled the German program for the sterilization of the unfit and exhorted those who seek the peace and welfare of the world to pray and persist in their prayers.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange rallied moderately yesterday. A number of leading foreign loans scored sizable, recoveries. United States Government bonds improved as a whole, ranging from 6-32 point higher to 2-32 point lower.

LONDON. VISITORS to the Tower of London a few years hence will find the now unlovely district around the famous fortress altered greatly for the better if a million-dollar improvement project now being put forward is carried into effect.
Today. Benefit Christmas Carnival begins at Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, at noon today and continues all week.

The flames from the burning Reichstag building last March lit up for the German people an abyss before their feet; that has been the official Nazi contention from the beginning. The reason and excuse for the Nazi revolution and its methods are to be sought in the Bolshevist revolution which threatened to engulf the nation.

The Kent School basketball team of Kent, Conn., will see action in fourteen games this season, according to the schedule arranged. The Kent five is booked to open its campaign on Jan. 16 against the Choate School team at Wallingford, Conn. R.L. Jackson is captain of the Kent quintet.

A belated confidential report of conditions in Nurnberg and Furth last July has become available here. The facts set forth could not be verified by American newspaper correspondents at the time of occurrence, but have since been checked in Berlin and found to be accurate.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 23. -- John D. Mikel's Ayston scored his second victory in a row at Epsom Downs today when he led home a field of ten in the best race of a featureless program.

WHEN the Christmas chimes of Old Trinity at the foot of Wan Street were first broadcast beyond the confines of Manhattan Island, listeners marveled at the performance of crystal radio sets and headphones. A few years later Big Ben in London participated in the celebration of American Yuletide and the wondrous vacuum tubes were credited with the transatlantic miracle that linked the Old and New Worlds in the Christmas spirit.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23. -- Football stars from practically every section of the country assembled here today and plunged into preparations for the charity game that annually pits the pick of the East against the West on New Year's Day.

Boston put off its annual horse show this year, but New England exhibitors will have an opportunity for competition early next month. On Jan. 5 and 6 the 110th Cavalry will give an exhibition in the Commonwealth Armory, with two evening sessions and a Saturday matinee.

Declaring that the year 1833 witnessed the most complete reversal ever recorded in textile history, Scheuer Co., textile brokers and consultants, in their annual review said yesterday that the NRA has given the industry its big opportunity.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 5. -- Ambitious plans for using wireless stations to assist in the unification of the country are announced by the Ministry of Communications at Nanking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The authority of Congress to endeavor to remedy social and economic ills by means of taxation was disputed today in a statement filed by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States with the Ways and Means Committee.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 23. -- Now comes Gene Sarazen, on whose head has rested virtually every major golf crown, with his slate of the ten greatest American golfers of the year.

Nationally known college stars will oppose each other in the second annual Northern-Southern foot hall game at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium this afternoon. A crowd of 12,000 is expected to see the conlest, which will be held for the benefit of the Kings County American Legrion's welfare fund.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Miss Esther Hawes, register announced today that 144 students of New Jersey College for Women had won scholastic honors during the last academic year. Sixty-six members of the senior class, forty-one members of the junior class and thirty-seven members of the sophomore class were thus honored.

The cost of conservation in the United States has risen steadily in recent years and promises to continue to rise in the future. The reasons are plain; broader programs have been adopted and each year finds the demands of sportsmen growing.
GENEVA, Dec. 23. -- Looking back over 1933, it is not as hard as it might reasonably seem for League of Nations quarters to find cause to be merry this Christmas.

DUBLIN, Dec. 23. -- A cheerful man, as cheery as can be found in Ireland, is William T. Cosgrave, who, as President of the Free State Council, gave Ireland ten years of peace and prosperity. And Merrion Square, the headquarters of his United Ireland party, which opposes the de Valera government and most of the methods it has adopted, is a busy place these days.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Santa Claus will ride again tomorrow into the snow-swept Escalant Desert of Southern Utah, 450 miles northeast of Los Angeles, to bring a merry Christmas to Alta Bonner and her nine children.

WITH more than 16,000 of Jersey City's 43,000 licensed automobile drivers enrolled, the traffic school recently opened by the Police Department is a distinct success. Inspector Harry Walsh, the supervising director, reported last week.

IT would be gratifying upon retiring from producing to be able to fling into the theatre's face the statement that no decent man can work in the theatre and cope successfully with its manifold, hidden chicaneries, its union outrages, its chiseling gyps, its insuperable confusions and its self-destroying financial problems.

To the Editor of The New TorTe Time: The notice taken by THE NEW TORE TIMES of the passing of the Dalai Lama brings to us evidence of the unfamiliar and apparently superstitious beliefs common in mysterious Tibet. It should, however, be clearly understood that popular Buddhism following the sad route of every other known world religion, has deviated immeasurably, thanks mainly to priestcraft, from the original teachings of its founder.

DUBLIN, Dec. 22. -- This will be a Christmas of comparative peace and plenty in Ireland. Despite the existence of the Irish Republican Army and the Blue Shirts there is no serious trouble in any part of the country and the people can enjoy the holiday festivities without any trepidation.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- Westchester prepared for a merry Christmas today by outlining plans for the distribution of food and clothing to the needy.

The proclamation of President Roosevelt on Thursday authorizing the free coinage of silver newly mined In the United States Introduced a new phase In the long and turbulent career of silver money In this country. It does not, however, involve a remonetization of silver In the sense of making silver a part of the monetary basis of the country, nor does it Involve bimetalism, according to the view of banking experts.

In the Cornell Law Quarterly for December, Mr. P.J. EDER of the New York bar calls attention to a clause in the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of which few people today know even the existence. It is a relic of Civil War days. Congress in the late Sixties had hot debates about payment of the war debt, huge for that time.

The current week brings more with it than Christmas and the holidays for most undergraduates. At the end of the week the City of Chicago will be host to the various college meetings which have been held for the past several years in New York City at this time.

THE LOCKED ROOM -- Tomorrow night at the Ambassador Theatre. As the lead-off for the holiday week we have a play by Herbert Ashton Jr. It used to be called "The Locked Door" and it was -- and presumably still is -- a mystery melodrama. Among the resident members of the cast are Robert Gleckler, Walter Gilbert, Valerie Bergere, Jane Kim, Nena Sinclair.

Telegraph orders for holiday merchandise for quick delivery were heavy during the week, with gloves, handkerchiefs, evening-wear types of jewelry, leather goods and lingerie outstanding, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

A list of "the 100 outstanding books" of world literature, compiled by thirty-five college professors for the National Council of Teachers of 'English as a students' guide to good reading, was made public here yesterday.

To the Music Editor: The passing of Richard Henry Warren brings to mind the splendid part this well-known musician played in the musical life of New York City for many years. Those who attended the famous vesper services in St. Bartholomew's when the church was located at Madison Avenue and Forty-fourth Street will recall the huge congregations that paused to worship through music at that beautiful shrine.
The Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly passed a local bill yesterday providing an eight-hour day for city firemen, beginning on Jan. 1, 1935.

SIX of the thirteen opera singers marked "new" in the Metropolitan prospectus are making their first appearances in the opening week of opera on Broadway. Lillian Clark, who will sing the unseen priestess in "Aida" next Saturday night, is a young soprano, educated at the San Francisco Conservatory and married to Orlando Rivera, a California artist.

Ralph A. Hamilton, complaint clerk of the magistrate's court in Ridgewood, Queens, died yesterday morning in the Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, after an operation for an abdominal ailment. He had been ill for two weeks. Mr. Hamilton was 50 years old.

Rules for the international motor boat races in Florida next March have been put out in printed form. They stipulate that the foreign boats must be entered by Jan. 20, and be In this country by March 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- In a final spurt of activity which has kept officials and their agents at work night and day, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and other governmental organizations have reached out into every section of the country to bring large banks and small into the grouping which, after Jan. 2, will have deposits up to $2,500 safeguarded against loss.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Washington was in a state of expectancy tonight as to further developments of President Roosevelt's monetary policy. This was heightened by the silence which has continued since the special meeting yesterday of the Federal Reserve Bank governors with the Federal Reserve Board.

Dr. and Mrs. William Smith Gregory and Mr. and Mrs. R. Randolph Hicks gave a tea dance yesterday in the roof garden of the Pierre for Miss Margaret Ungrich Gregory and Miss Jane Hall. Miss Gregory is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gregory, and Miss Hall, the niece of Mr. and Mrs. Hicks.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The Stock Exchange was closed today until Wednesday, money was plentiful in Lombard Street and loans over the holidays were available at one-half of 1 per cent. The rate for three-month bills weakened to 1 1/8 per cent.

HOLLY SPRINGS, Miss., Dec. 23 (AP). -- Wintry gusts sing through the corn and clover stubble and the quail whistle as they scurry through the broom sage where the first field trials of 1934, the All America, will start New Year's Day.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- Foreign observers with long training in postwar Germany are wondering how far Nazi propaganda has succeeded in making this German Christmas appear different than the other fifteen since the war. Measured by historic events, it does look very much different.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Lynn Hunt of the Whitcomb Gun Club of Felham Bay Park broke 93 targets to annex the high-gun prize in file annual Christmas 100-target shoot of the Climax Gun Club today. Forty gunners took part in the event, which was conducted under the Lewis class system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The Christmas greetings of the navy to disabled veterans of the World War, sailors, soldiers and marines, was voiced over the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight by Assistant Secretary Henry L. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- A grant of $4,000,000 to New York City for building a great incinerator and elimination system to end unsanitary disposal of sewage and to clean up New York Harbor has been approved in principle by the Public Works Administration.

Two hundred granite workers presented a plea yesterday at City Hall and at the offices of the Triborough Bridge Authority for employment on the new span. A parade between the Mayor's office and the bridge authority at 141 Broadway was orderly, and twenty patrolmen assigned to the demonstration had little to do.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 23. -- Jaines A. Moffett pf New York, who is on his yacht Bidou, entertained with a supper dance tonight1 at the Patio Margery for more than seventy guests.

Although the syndicate has not been formed to build a new America's Cup yacht for the defense next Fall against T.O.M. Sopwith's new challenger, Endeavour, work of constructing the big racer will be started this week at the Herreshoff yard in Bristol, R.I., where all the cup defenders since 1893 have been built.

PARIS. AT this season of the year attention has seemed to focus on details, perhaps because of the Christmas problem of presents -- to give or not to give, and if so how, usefully, ornamentally, or both.

NOW comes the season when this department, nestled all snug in its bed, dreams of a portly gentleman with a snow-white beard who comes sweeping down Broadway (Tecumseh hot on his trail) and fills all the empty theatres with Pulitzer Prize plays and every one's heart with gladness.
RYE, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- Members of the younger set home from schools and colleges for the Christmas, holidays were the guests of honor tonight at several dances held in Westchester County.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gordon Switz declared today that their arrest on suspicion of being "tools of an international spy ring" was a police "frame-up" and the result of a "plant." They were heard separately by Magistrate Benon.

Foreign ships in port tomorrow will be able to serve Christmas dinner with wine or beer, lacking since 1919. The crews of American ships will have their dinners in their homes because they are paid off as soon as their ships arrive. The Manhattan and the President Harding of the United States Lines got in last night.

Vigorous opposition by Leo McDermott of the Citizens Union and Cornelius M.
