Sheehan, former Deputy Commissioner of Water Supply, led Mayor O'Brien yesterday to lay over to the final meeting of the present Board of Estimate next week action on the plan to rent unused capacity of city conduits on Long Island to the New York Water Service Corporation.

The second meeting of the season between the Rangers and the Americans, New York's rivals in the National Hockey League, will take place at Madison Square Garden tonight. The action whenever these teams clash, regardless of their respective standing in the group races, should attract a large crowd to tonight's struggle.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This lunatic commotion and delirium in regard to repeal and drinking is perfectly disgusting to the American citizens who have always been refined and who have lived in accordance with the high ideals handed down from their earliest American ancestors.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 23. -- A magnificent, par-shattering round of 67, clipping four strokes from par, lifted 25-year-old Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., into the lead of the $4,000 Pasadena open golf championship today. This brilliant effort followed his 69 in the first round.
PARIS, Dec. 12. -- Quite a round of charity entertainments has marked the approach to Christmas and attracted well-known figures in the capital, including Americans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Enactment of a permanent Federal liquor control system by Congress will be delayed by the administration until after many of the problems confronting the Federal Alcohol Control Administration have been straightened out.

MAPRID, Dec. 23. -- The virtual entry into the republican fold of Spain's Catholic forces with the expressed approval of the Vatican and the Spanish ecclesiastical authorities is one of the most important events since the proclamation of the second republic and comes to stabilize the regime in a dramatic moment when anarchism was beginning seriously to undermine the State.

"Christmas Sunday" will be observed In the city's churches today. And it is so near the Feast of the Nativity that all denominational churches also will celebrate the birth of Christ. Roman Catholic, Protestant Episcopal and Lutheran churches will hold their regular worship today, Christmas Eve services tonight and Christmas services tomorrow.

ROCKEFELLER CENTER is still in the making, but much material has been put in place since last this department undertook to comment upon the grandiose project that it will be well, perhaps, to devote some attention today to the works of art installed since the opening of the Radio City Music Hall and what is now called the RKO Center Theatre (it used to be the New Roxy).

Savings banks in this State are permitted to borrow funds from the RFC on debentures, according to an opinion rendered yesterday by the State Attorney General, John J. Bennett Jr., and sent to the Superintendent of Banks, Joseph A. Broderick.
The National Academy of Design's gold medal for "distinguished services to the fine arts" will be presented to Edwin Howland Blashfield, 85-year-old dean of American mural painters, on Jan. 4.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Starting their drive for three Christmas vacation, contests and the games which lie beyond, eighteen members of the undefeated Tiger hockey squad will assemble for practice at Madison Square Garden Wednesday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 23. -- A large number of social activities are being arranged for the holiday season at the clubs and in private homes for the members of the younger set who are home from schools and colleges during the Christmas recess.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 23. -- Miss Helen Grawn of Detroit, the defending champion, was seeded first in the draw for the annual girls' national indoor tennis championship, which will begin on the Longwood covered courts, Chestnut Hill, Monday.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 21. -- Mayor Harry L. Davis has just found "bankrupt" the city treasury to which he fell heir by election last month.

THE task of the modern school is to form the character of children and to train them for citizenship, not merely to teach subjects. This idea has been repeated so often in the past few years that it has become a platitude.

The New York A.C. and the Baltimore Orioles will clash in the feature game of the amateur hockey double-header at Madison Square Garden this afternoon. The Orioles are among the leaders in the newly formed Eastern Amateur League.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- Handless, elbow - length, funnel-shaped cuffs, matching the frock, are replacing evening gloves when muffs are carried. The latest novelties in costume jewelry are life-sized, egg-shaped, prystal pendants that hang from prystal, steel or rhinestone chains.

BOGOTA, Dec. 19. -- President Olaya Herrera has finished signing the last of the bills enacted by the 1933 Congress, which remained in session 125 days. This year's small output of important legislation may be attributed to three major causes.
TOKYO, Dec. 23. -- A spirit of revelry reigns in Tokyo tonight as thousands of citizens parade in the decorated streets, celebrating the birth of the Prince, heir to the throne.

BERLIN. I MAT confess that It was with some misgivings that I looked forward to the new book by the German Nobel Prize winner. Thomas Mann: a trilogy based on the Old-Testament stories of Jacob as seen by a modern mind.

Holiday trade attained record-breaking proportions in the volume of merchandise sold in many sections of the country last week. The buying was great enough to force merchants to rush orders for additional gifts, and in some cases, the dollar volume appeared to be approaching record levels.

DUBLIN, Dec. 23. -- Ten days do not constitute a long time in which to observe and digest as complex and difficult a national situation as that in Ireland. Nevertheless, diligent inquiry, with an open sesame to the chief characters in the political arena, can in that time elicit many of the facts, and these lead to certain conclusions.

THE burley tobacco "holiday" called last week in four States -- Kentucky, Virginia, North Carolina and Tennessee -- to raise the price of the product, centres attention on a long struggle in the tobacco industry. For more than twenty-five years there have been attempts to control prices.

Most of the commodity markets were closed yesterday in advance of the holiday and speculative attention was centred largely in the Stock Exchange. Business was slow on all the markets and there was no positive trend anywhere, which conformed to the pre-holiday custom.
DODGE CITY, Kan., Dec. 21. -- If you want to see an empire reclaimed come out here to the great Southwestern Wheat Belt, when the wheat allotment checks now are being distributed to farmers.

Reflecting upon the financial casualties resulting from last week's stock-market irruption, Wall Street wondered whether something might be done to prevent such needless dislocations. In this particular instance holders of shares in a wide variety of companies suffered incalculable loss because of publicity given to special market situations that at first affected only two or three stocks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Nine members of Stanford's starting eleven had to lay off work to go to Pasadena tonight to play Columbia in the Rose Bowl game New Year's Day.

Although, the Vast majority of the city's scholastic sports teams will be idle this week because of the Christmas holiday recess period, a few will see action and among them will he two teams representing poly Prep of Brooklyn.

SOFIA, Dec. 9. -- Trouble is afoot in Sofia University, where there are upward of 5,000 regular or attached students. A partial strike, which threatens to assume serious proportions, is in progress against increased fees, and relations between the Nationalist or Fascist elements and the Specialists or "popular" students are becoming daily more strained.

Despite foreign skepticism over the success of American recovery plans, a distinct trend is developing in European countries to some of the agricultural and industrial features of our program, Major Lyndall Urwick, managing director of the International Management Institute, of Geneva, told THE TIMES yesterday.

OUT of the Richard Aldrich-Alfred de Liagre Jr. office come tidings of considerable moment. All of them about the play called "By Your Leave." It seems that Miss Dorothy Gish is to have the role of the leading lady in that one, and Howard Lindsay is to be the leading man.

Max D. Steuer announced yesterday that, while he had approved in principle the corporate organization of guaranteed mortgage certificate holders for the protection of their interests, he reserved the right to initiate a different and more satisfactory plan if the procedure under the Schackno Law should not work well.

The United Hospital Fund has sent to Mayor-elect LaGuardia copies of resolutions asking that the new city administration increase its payments to non-municipal charitable hospitals for the care of public wards. The resolutions were adopted recently by the board of trustees of the fund.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- More or less recovered from the joys and sorrows of the 1933 gridiron season, 800 members of the American Football Coaches Association will give the game a verbal going-over in their thirteenth annual meeting Tuesday and Wednesday.
NEW YORK. Adolph Lewisohn will give a reception New Year's Eve at 881 Fifth Avenue.

YOU might as well start polishing up your Mexican. Begin with something simple, like "Buenos dias, senor" and get yourself a big sombrero, for it's going to be a Mexican season. We've already hinted at it, and soon we shall tell you more.

By breaking 96 out of 100 targets, T.H. Lewis won the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. There was a tie for the second cup between Fred Cauchois and T.H. Lawrence, each returning a card of 95.

Discoyery of a fossilized miniature flesh-eating dinosaur, midget member of the species of monsters that roamed the earth 120,000,000 years ago, was announced here yesterday, as a Christmas gift from the remote past to the present, by the American Museum of Natural History.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Tear gas bombs and night sticks were used here tonight by the police to quell a riot among striking hotel workers to whom permission to parade had been refused. Six persons, four of them women, were arrested.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Christmas happiness has been brought by the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation to 245,000 families who faced foreclosure, the corporation reported today. Loans for these home owners, either granted or tentatively approved, ran up to more than $750,000,000.

SO significant in every way have been the various sets issued in the Societies Subscription Series, sponsored by H.M.V. (London), that a source which a year or more ago was regarded as something of an experimental subsidiary now holds a position as important as any of the major companies.

MEETING in a distant capital and at a time when every country is preoccupied with domestic affairs, the seventh Pan-American Conference, now drawing to a close at Montevideo, has received comparatively little attention.

DUBLIN, Dec. 23. -- General Owen O'Duffy, outspoken foe both of the British and Free State Governments, will be tried Jan. 2 on charges of sedition and inciting to murder Eamon de Valera, President of the Free State Executive Council.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, left Paris tonight to spend the Christmas holidays at Capri, fully informed as to what France and her allies are thinking about the European situation. During his short stay in Paris he conferred not only with the French Premier and Foreign Minister, but conversed with influential leaders of nearly all French parties and held a long conference with Dr. Stefan Osusky, Czechoslovak Minister.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 12. -- When in 1929-30 the political group known as the "Allianca Liberal" began its political campaign to elect Senhor Getulio Vargas President of Brazil, foremost in its platform was revision of the national Constitution.

The slump, caused by repressive legislation, in New York racing, which has been growing worse in each of the past five years until now it is acute, is the direct cause of a collapse in the selling market for yearlings, breeding stock and horses in training, according to an announcement yesterday by Robert L. Gerry and Marshall Field.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 21. -- A proposal to apply to the Public Works Administration for a $500,000 loan has revived an interest, dormant for several months, in the approaching celebration by Arkansas of the State's admission into the Union.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- For the second time in ten months a man is held here charged with demanding money from Lessing J. Rosenwald, millionaire philanthropist, on pain of personal injury. The present prisoner is William J. Schultze, a dairyman, who is charged with sending three threatening letters to Mr. Rosenwald.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 23. -- Highlights in the 1933 sports campaign at Lehigh were contributed by the wrestling and track teams. The former won its sixth Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championship in seven years. The track squad was runner-up in the annual Middle Atlantic States intercollegiate track championship.

Miss Eleanore Talmadge Vietor made her debut last night at the River Club, where her parents, the and Mrs. John A. Vietor, gavez a large dance in a floral setting of evergreens, poinsettias and holly. Miss Vietor wore a gown of silver lame and carried a muff of white orchids and gardenias, and her mother wore a gown of white satin and carried gardenias.

Miss Marion-Linn Somerville was presented by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Alexander Somerville, yesterday at a reception with dancing in the ballroom of Sherry's. The debutante, who was graduated from the Brearley School, is home for the holidays from Vassar Colege, where she is a sophomore.

Indications of an upswing in the concert business, noticeable particularly in the East and South, are observed by George Engles, managing director of the NBC Artists Service, in a survey just made public. Mr. Engles reports increases in concert attendance of from 10 to 66 per cent over last year in twenty large cities, with only four showing a decline.

LONG cablegrams came from the Pan-American Conference at Montevideo last week, telling that the delegation from the United States had refused to vote in favor of equal nationality rights for women, although fourteen other countries approved.

Armando Infante, wealthy real estate and cattle man of Santiago, Cuba, and member of the Cuban Congress under President Machado, was assaulted by two men yesterday morning in his room at the McAlpin Hotel. One of the assailants, arrested as he was fleeing, told the police that he and his accomplice were to get $5,000 fat killing Mr. Infante, but detectives charged that they had sought to extort that amount from their victim.

LAGNY, France, Sunday, Dec. 24. -- One hundred and eighty Christmas travelers were killed last night in a ghastly train collision near here, fifteen miles east of Paris. This number is the official estimate this morning.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 23. -- President Roosevelt's Pan - American highway project, almost the exclusive subject-matter of his Pan-American Conference statement on Nov. 9, was received and added to the conference records late this afternoon by J. Butler Wright, United States Minister at Montevideo.

A LITTLE while ago fashionable beach-combers were on the long side of the market -- you remember every one went pajama mad ? -- now they are buying shorts. It is just another case of the ups and downs of fashion.

NINETEEN HUNDRED years ago a flood of light photo-graphed an unfading memory on the mind of man. The illumination, once local to Galilee and Judea, now spreads like the dawn over the world and on people of all races and religions.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- The University of Rochester basketball team could not stop Johnny Ferraro's scoring streak tonight and as a result Cornell triumphed by a score of 28 to 24.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The following table, based on latest available statistics, gives a picture of the banking set-up, as the beginning of operations wears under the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's temporary fund.

SUMMIT, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Mrs. Gladys M. Kraeuter resigned as superintendent of the Arthur Sunshine Home and Kindergarten for Blind Babies today, following a hearing at which she was absolved of charges of mistreating the children in her care.

FORESEEING "impressive possibilities" in the use of new alloy steels and alloys of the light metals, the automotive industries representing high-way, air and water transportation have joined the iron and steel industries to further research in that field.

HIS DOUBLE LIFE," a film which was at the Para mount last week, is endowed with an intriguing theme, subtle humor and note worthy performances by Roland Young and Lillian Gish. It owes its story to the late Arnold Bennett's novel "Buried Alive."
James A. Farley, Postmaster General, returned yesterday with Mrs. Farley on the Manhattan, of the United States Lines from his six weeks trip to Europe.

UNLESS there is a sharp change in the order of things as they have prevailed in the year 1933, there can be only one outcome to the impending Rose Bowl classic. There really can be no other, for everything points to it.

THE child labor amendment, which was proposed in 1924 and has been slowly fighting its way to the goal of ratification by the required thirty-six States, has received a new lease of life. Last week Minnesota, Maine and Pennsylvania became the eighteenth, nineteenth and twentieth States, respectively, to put their stamps of approval on the measure.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- A year will have passed on Jan. 30 next since the National Socialists, headed by Adolf Hitler, came into power in Germany. The changes that have been wrought In that period have been so sweeping, have affected so profoundly every phase of human effort and existence, that history affords no parallel for the developments or for the present situation.

Pointing out that construction in the United States is now at the lowest level in more than fifteen years, J.H. Manning, president of the Stone Webster Engineering Corporation, said yesterday that the reaction which had followed the boom period of the Twenties was natural, but that the pendulum had swung too far.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 23. -- Perhaps the bravest man in Hollywood, Maxwell Arnow, casting director for Warner Brothers studio, made his selection today of the ten brainiest women in the movies.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- With a soft sprinkle of snow sifting down from a leaden sky, Lake Placid's Winter sports season was formally opened this afternoon when the blue and gold banner of the Lake Placid Athletic Club was raised In front of the Olympic Arena.

A MARKED increase is reported in the number of cruising yachts which at this time of year set out from the English Channel on the voyage to the Riviera through the French canals. The distance is about 980 miles and the voyage, which is made by stages, takes about four weeks.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- The Gordon International Medal, ancient curling trophy which brings Canadian and United States athletes into competition every year, will be at stake March 10 at Brookline, Mass., according to the schedule of the Grand National Curling Club of America, released today by William A. Clark, secretary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Seven new security issues amounting to $3,315,600 have been filed with the Federal Trade Commission under the Securities Act, all representing new capital. Two bondholders' protective committees also filed applications.

LONDON. DR. A.S.W. ROSENBACH'S "Early American Children's Books" and C. Geoffrey Holme's "Children's Books of Yesterday" (The Studio) are jointly taken by The Times Literary Supplement as the text for a front-page leading article on "The Child and the Artist."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 23. -- Naval Academy oarsmen, facing a heavy schedule, which includes four dual matches, the Adams Cup race and the Poughkeepsie regatta, will begin work next month under Head Coach Charles Walsh.

CAIRO, Dec. 23. -- Loutfieh El Nadi, an Egyptian girl, and the only woman competing, was the winner of the international air race held here today. Her time was 2 hours 5 minutes from Almaza airdrome in Cairio to Alexandria and return.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an article on public utilities in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 26 Dr. Albert Levitt made a serious indictment against privately owned public utilities. He stated that:

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP). -- Eyes dancing with excitement, two little girls and a boy tugged at their mother's hand today as they joined last-minute shoppers on University Avenue to buy Christmas presents, at least some of which probably were for former President Hoover.

MONTREAL, Dec. 23 UP). -- The Montreal Canadians tonight chalked up their second victory of the National Hockey League season over Detroit on local ice when they shut out the Red Wings, 3 -- 0, before 5,000 fans.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 21. -- Two thousand men, hungry, helpless and hopeless, after months, even years, without work, with wives and children suffering for want of food, clothing and adequate shelter for the coming Winter, crowded into the little town of Dayton, Tenn. Roseate dreams of government work for all were held by these disheartened individuals.

CAMOQLI. IT has always been our fashion to poke fun at those who herald a new talent with purple phrases about a "French Goethe," a "German Dickens." or a Lithuanian Vasari," suum cuique, so much and a wee bit more, but let the illustrious dead repose in peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- With three aircraft carriers under construction and one, the Ranger, nearing completion, the Naval Bureau of Aeronautics finds itself with no airplanes provided for their fighting equipment. Unless Congress acts, the bureau must curtail other activities or the carriers will have no planes to carry.

THE Oratorio Society, New York's oldest singing ensemble, will begin its sixtieth season with Handel's "Messiah," which Albert Stoessel will conduct at Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening. Lillian Clark, soprano; Sonia Essin, contralto; Dan Beddoe, tenor, and Julius Huehn, bass-baritone, will be soloists.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 23. -- Three thousand scientists from the United States and Canada will assemble here Wednesday, when the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the American Association for the Advancement of Science meet.

AMERICAN forestry is at the beginning of a new epoch. Under the leadership of Franklin Roosevelt the forest conservation movement has taken on renewed vigor and already has made remarkable advances. Curiously, progress in forestry during the epoch that is just closed also owed much of its original impetus to a Roosevelt.
A dinper with dancing was given last night in the Georgian Room of the Pierre by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Lewis Campbell to introduce their daughter, Miss Ann Robertson Campbell.

FOOCHOW, Dec. 23. -- Reports from Kienning indicate growing public restlessness because of increasing military requisitions for the Fifty-sixth Division, which is continually demanding large additional sums in cash from the Chamber of Commerce and is daily conscripting coolie laborers.

Comparing this Christmas with, last, one could not find a perceptible difference in the attitude of individuals, Then, as now, the sweet influences of the season were everywhere visible. The flow of the milk of human kindness did not cease. The neighborly spirit was quickened as usual.
City College gave a superb demonstration of basketball skill and technique against Dartmouth last night as the undefeated Lavender forces administered a crushing 42-to-26 setback to the Hanoverians.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 23. -- Spike Webb will pilot an aggregation of American amateur boxers on an invasion of Japan next Spring.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Indiana beat Illinois in statutory preparedness for liquor control, but from all reports its forehahdedness has brought no better results than are evident from the latter State's continuing lack of regulatory laws. Indiana's good intent to abolish the bootlegger and avoid return of the saloon is said to have failed almost completely in performance.

Science swept away yesterday the air of mystery that surrounded the deaths of Frank Gibney, 70 years old, and his brother, Thomas, 72, found Friday in their four-room flat at 226 East Twenty-second Street, and a sister was found who explained much of their past.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Continued improvement in the steel industry was noted in the review of domestic business conditions by the Department of Commerce for the week ended on Dec. 16, made public today. A further gain is looked for the report said.

Ten games will be played by the New York University girls' basketball team this season, according to the schedule-announced yesterday by Miss Frances V. Froatz, director of women's athletics at N. Y.U. The dates for the usual home series with Hunter will be made public later.

THOUSAND college students will convene in Washington this week in the largest organized attempt in our history to launch an American youth movement. While their campus confreres are dancing the holidays away or earning some of the where-withal to come back next semester, these ardent spirits will be trying to agree on a student stand on national and international issues.

No call to arms, but only the Maccabean call to spiritual courage and devotion to the right, can aid the German Jews whose loyalty and love for their country has been betrayed, Governor Herbert H. Lehman declared last night in a speech at the repetition of the annual Maccabean festival at Madison Square Garden.

The State Barge Canal has not yet carried the volume of traffic equal to that of its predecessors, the combined Champlain and Erie Canals, according to a survey by H. E. Cartwright of Pelham, vice president of the Railway Express Agency.

In India and China live 750,000,000 people. India has large hoards of silver. China is on the silver standard. The world price of that metal was severely depressed in 1931-32. It is still relatively low. If international action should now increase the value of silver, would not this improve the purchasing power of India and China, thereby enabling them to make larger purchases of surplus goods in the United States and elsewhere?
LONDON. THE Prince of Wales, himself an enthusiastic listener, proposed the toast of "The Radio Industry" at the annual dinner of the Radio Manufacturers Association at the Savoy Hotel.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- John Bull Is smiling this Christmastide. Everywhere in Britain comes glad news of confidence, cheerfulness, good trade and money freely spent -- a return to the old times when the season spelt jubilation and festivity for all.

The Florida racing season, now the most important of the entire Winter, will get under way on Saturday, when the Gables Racing Association opens a twenty-four day meeting at Tropical Park. This will be followed by a session at Hialeah Park from Jan. 25 to March 17 and another meeting at Tropical Park.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Dec. 21. -- Curtailed incomes resulting in tax delinquencies have worked the heaviest hardship on Kansas rural schools. A thousand fewer rural schools are open now than a year ago and before Spring two or three hundred others will have to close because of inadequate funds.

Some permanent plan of financing for the railroads is seen in financial quarters as a possibility in the next Congress. The life of the RFC is due to be renewed at its expiration in 1934, so that the immediate needs of the railroads would seem to be met, but this is held not to lessen the desirability of a final settlement of the problem.

BERLIN, Sunday, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Leaders of the Protestant Youth movement revealed early today that they had lodged protests with the Berlin State's Attorney accusing Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller of "desertion, breach of faith and concealment."

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 23. -- Ties marked the shooting at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. In the contest for the high scratch cup, T.B. Pettit Jr. and R. Marano each had 48 but of 50 targets. The former gunner scored in the shoot-off, 24 to 23.

WHEN radio was audacious enough on Nov. 22, 1922, to attempt a broadcast of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra there were many music lovers who shook their heads and deplored the electrification of works of the masters.

During the half-forgotten war of the American humanists and anti-humanists a malevolent neutrality may be said to have been maintained by the uninterested or disinterested public. Whatever the merits, visible only to experts, it seemed clear that the antis were distinctly inhumane.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The keen practical interest of the Prince of Wales in the housing question is shown in a transaction formally completed yesterday, the sale of about fourteen acres in the Duchy of Cornwall estate adjacent to Kensington SpOrts Oval for a housing scheme of the London County Council.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 23. -- After being lost in the woods near this city for about twenty-four hours, Miss Marjorie Gould Drexel, 17 years old, was found exhausted at 4 o'clock this afternoon. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Jr.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 23. -- The Pan-American Conference marked time today on the Chaco situation, awaiting the inauguration of peace negotiations early next week by the League of Nations Chaco Commission.

MR. PUNCH, of all people, helped the Oxford Dictionary to to define an American gangsters' phrase. That weekly (which. Englishmen are fond of saying, will soon publish its humorous issue) settled the matter on the 16th of April. 1930, when a contributor remarked: "You get rid of inconvenient subordinates by putting them on the spot.'"

To the Editor of The New York Times: Hundreds of merchants and manufacturers protested to the State Tax Commission against the 1 per cent sales tax wmch is "due to pass out of existence July 1" and the proposal for a 2 per cent tax on sales and services advanced by Commissioner Merrill.
The Retail Code Authority, through its chairman, Grover A. Whalen, went on record yesterday as opposing the proposed 2 per cent State sales tax.

This automobile, carrying out the idea of streamlining further than has hitherto appeared in production cars in this country, is one of the new models developed by the De Soto Motor Corporation, a division of Chrysler Motors. It was shown at the meeting of company dealers in Detroit on Friday, but will not be formally presented to the public until the opening of the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace on Jan. 6.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 21. -- Los Angeles and San Diego are facing one of the most serious setbacks that have yet confronted the rehabilitation program in the possible loss on their principal fishing industry, involving a capital investment of $30,000,000, the yearly addition of from ten to fifteen million dollars in new wealth and the employment of 12,000 workers at better than average pay.
LONDON, Dec. 23. -- New Atlantic fare schedules were issued today by the White Star and Cunard Lines, making first-class travel on the big express liners considerably cheaper than before.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Christmas will be celebrated variously, but joyously by all, in the diplomatic households of the foreign Ambassadors, Ministers and attaches at "Washington, where the Corps Diplomatique is larger than at any other capital in the world.
TOKYO, Dec. 23. -- All Japan turned to an age-old way of expressing the highest jubilation tonight and paid homage to their new-born future ruler with lantern processions.

THE Federal Government has just taken a straw vote to ascertain what the American graveling public wants in the way of railroad passenger service and what it would pay for super-service. The canvass is part of an effort to solve the old "transportation problem," but with particular emphasis on newer phases of that problem.

Fifty-seven members of three teams at Duke University have been honored with letters and numerals. Of this number, twenty-five have gone to varsity football men, twenty-six to freshman players and six to cross-country runners. The freshmen received numerals.

FOR an honest observance of Christmas, go to the drama. Not to the theatre, which is a pagan institution that esteems Christmas chiefly for the holiday trade. Between Christmas and New Year's the Broadway box-offices make merry.

THIS literary and historical study of George Crabbe is a scholarly and well-documented book. It happens that much of this poet's life is written down in his own poems, and the actual events of his biography are far from exciting.

VIENNA, Dec. 23. -- Great excitement was caused in pro-German circles today by the publication in the clerical newspaper Relchspost of a statement that Germany was endeavoring to bring about a split in Austria.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 23. -- An improved outlook for the solution of Newark's financial difficulties now that bankers are willing to modify the conditions under which a syndicate may set up a $24,000,000 revolving fund to meet Newark's needs for the next three years was announced after a conference today of the City Commission and Horace K. Corbin, secretary of the Citizens' Advisory Finance Committee.

THAT dashing Pittsburgh boulevardier, Adolphe Menjou, is implicated in the tomfoolery of "Convention City," at the Strand. The faultless Adolphe was born in Pittsburgh (not Cleveland) Feb. 18, 1890. His father, a Frenchman, was also a successful restaurateur and hotel man who always believed that when the cinema claimed Adolphe the country lost a good maitre d'hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The advent of the Christmas season finds a majority of the twenty countries interested in the newly opened United States liquor market considering ways and means of doubling or trebling their export quotas by buying more American goods.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 23. -- Premier Duca stressed today that Sunday's election results showed the fairness of the balloting machinery.
ROME, Dec. 23. -- Italians celebrate Christmas differently from other people, for they have their fun on Christmas Eve and spend Christmas Day recovering.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico., Dec. 23. -- The thunder of galloping horses will open the spacious Agua Caliente Jockey Club race track's fifth Winter meeting tomorrow. A crowd of more than 12,000 fans is expected to watch the inaugural program.

A last-minute goal by Lieutenant Aleck George gave the First Division polo team victory over the New York Athletic Club, 9 to 8 1/2, at Squadron A Armory last night and a triumph in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League. The game was the feature of the first evening of play in the new season at the Madison Avenue armory and was fast and close all the way.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The "regulation-of-profit" theory that is being developed "by the academic economists at Washington, I am afraid, is not founded on very scientific thought. In the first place, no attempt is made to define profits, a rather crude term to use in economic reasoning.

THE subscription opening of the Metropolitan Opera season in New York, preceded by a Christmas Day matinee of "Hansel und Gretel," takes place Tuesday night with a performance of Deems Taylor's "Peter Ibbetson."

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20. -- Long entertained as visions of an indefinite future, two of Baltimore's ambitions now appear to have good chances of becoming realities as soon as the Public Works Administration turns its attention to them. The two projects long dreamed about are a bridge spanning the Chesapeake Bay and enlarging the present Chesapeake and Delaware Canal for ocean-going vessels.

RECENT mob outbreaks have led to inquiry into the origin of the word "lynching." The first lynchings in this country took place a century and a half ago, and efforts were made to penalize the lynchers. Perhaps the earliest literary record of such trials appears in the 1817 edition of Roane's "Life of Patrick Henry."

At the hearings held during the past week before the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives, for the purpose of devising means for preventing avoidance and evasions of income taxes, much stress was laid upon the desirability of eliminating the privilege now afforded certain affiliated groups of corporations to file consolidated returns.
LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The verdict in the Reichstag fire trial today probably did more to improve British opinion of present-day Germany than any single event since the Nazi revolution.

A BRILLIANT opera season is expected in Barcelona this year, according to a correspondent in the Catalan capital. During the days of the monarchy its lyric stage enjoyed an enviable reputation, but with the republic it fell upon hard times-chiefly because the aristocratic support of the former regime was withdrawn and no adequate substitute could immediately be provided by a government concerned with far more urgentsocial problems.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 2. -- The stupendous task of photographing in actual size every page of a Chinese encyclopedia which fills 1,500 volumes has been begun in Shanghai by the Commercial Press, a Chinese publishing firm, which has a contract with the Chinese Government to complete the work in six months.
The merry saint with the white whiskers and the rotund figure arrived in the metropolis yesterday two days ahead of the calendar.

BOSTON, Dec. 23. -- The Chicago Black Hawks gained the leading American Division berth in the National Hockey League by out-playing the Boston Bruins for a 3-1 victory tonight before 5,000 the smallest crowd of the Boston season.

The production committee for the Beaux-Arts Ball, under the direction of Pierpont Morgan Hamilton, has begun casting for the elaborate pageant to feature this famous annual ball on Jan. 19 at the Waldorf-Astoria. About 500 persons are required for the various episodes of pageantry which will depict incidents in the romantic travels of Marco Polo during the thirteenth century.

A world that is "bristling with military preparedness, suspicion and hatred," but that still has revealed in many quarters the spirit of Jesus, was scored by the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Brown, dean emeritus of the Divinity School of Yale University, in his sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday morning.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Life to Opie Read, the author, is "largely a series of worries."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24. -- The general strike of Philadelphia transportation workers was called off today at a stormy session of the joint council representing the nine unions which voted for the walkout last Thursday night.

STONY CREEK, N.Y., Dec. 24 (AP). -- The Santa Claus of the Adirondacks and his aides rode again tonight through the snow-swept North country distributing toys, food and clothing to the folk of the mountainous settlements.
"Dawn to Dawn," a film produced independently in Hollywood by Josef Berne, who also collaborated on the story with Cameron McPherson, will be presented at the Little Carnegie Playhouse today.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Dec. 24. -- Marceita, carrying the colors of the Meadowbrook Stable, won the Inaugnral Handicap at six furlongs as the Agua Caliente Jockey Club opened its fifth Winter race meeting today. Mrs. A. M. Creech's Desert Call, the favorite, was second, beaten a head, and G. B. Towne's Noah's Pride was third.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Discovery of definite evidence that a wrecking of the Southern Railway's Royal Palm Express, with a loss of two lives, near Powder Springs, Ga., last night resulted from the removal of spikes from the track was announced today by Hugh C. Couch, assistant to the vice president of the railroad.

RYE, N. Y., Dec. 24. -- P. M. McHugh. and R. E. Boesel tied for the high scratch cup at the traps of the Westchester Country Club today. Each broke 84 out of 100 targets. As a heavy fog was beginning to settle over the traps no attempt was made to stage a shoot-off.

SUMMIT, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Miss Edith McCully, field worker in the New Jersey Department of Institutes and Agencies, is likely to be the next superintendent of the Artbur Sunshine Home and Kindergarten for Blind Babies, it was revealed here today.
The Irish-American soccer team scored a 3-to-0 victory over the Brookhattan eleven at Starlight Park yesterday in an American League game before 1,500.

The form of label required by the Board of Health on bottles of domestic and imported whisky after Jan. 5 will be submitted tomorrow by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Commissioner of Health, to importers of liquors and to Dr. James M. Doran, head of the National Distillers Institute.

The code for the millinery industry, affecting 35,000 workers, about 15,000 of them in New York City, goes into effect today as "a Christmas present by the President of the United States to the industry," Max Zaritsky, president of the Cloth Hat, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, announced yesterday.

The "divorce of education and economics from morality and religion" has given rise to the "pagan ethics" that are accepted and practiced today and that are "undermining the very foundation upon which our whole social structure rests," the Rev. John D. McCarthy declared yesterday in a sermon at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Two passersby were Injured and several pedestrians thrown from their feet at 6:20 o'clock last night when a gas explosion in a cable conduit in Thirty-sixth Street, ten feet east of Eighth Avenue, hurled a 300-pound manhole cover twentyfive feet in the air and shattered it.
"This is a friendly church with a human touch -- Welcome!"

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The awarding of the Cross of Honor of the United States Flag Association to Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh for her epochal flight of 30,000 miles with her husband was announced today by the association. It will be sent by airplane tomorrow morning as a Christmas present to Mrs. Lindbergh at the home of her mother, Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, in Englewood, N. J.

Four pedestrians were killed yesterday in automobile accidents in the city and two persons were injured seriously. In four of the accidents the drivers sped away without aiding their victims. Those killed were:

MOSCOW, Dec. 24. -- The Pravda and the Izvestia give most of their front pages today to the acquittal of the Communists in the Reichstag fire trial, which produced here an effect rather like that of a householder who goes downstairs at night to tackle a burglar, only to find that the intruder is the neighbor's cat.
ROME, Dec. 24 (AP). -- All Italy paused to pay tribute to motherhood today before turning to the celebration of Christmas.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24. -- Salem High of Massachusetts bowed before the manpower of Urban Military Academy of Los Angeles today, the cadets triumphing, 18 to 0. The contest, played in cold, dreary weather, attracted less than 5,000 fans.

For its Christinas concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra directed by Hans Lange, played Manfredini's tranquil and lovely 'Concerto Grosso per il Santissimo Natale"; the "Rejoice Greatly,' recitative and aria, from Handel's "Messiah," with Margaret Olsen soprano, as soloist; Chadiwick's "Noel"; Rimsky-Korsakoff's concert suite from the opera "Christmas Eve," and R. Vaughan Williams's "Fantasia on Christmas Carols" for orchestra, organ, baritone solo and men's chorus.

BOSTON, Dec. 24. -- "I am reasonably optimistic regarding the future of New England industry," declared W. L. Carter, chairman of the industrial committee of the New England Council, in his final report of the year. Business in New England in the year just closed, according to the report, was 10 to 12 per cent higher than at the end of last year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Lack of definite trends in all commodity markets, and particularly grains, has created a situation that tends to restrict operations as well as to limit the range of prices. Much confusion has been caused by reports from Washington regarding the processing of grain and hog products by lack of export demand for wheat and by uncertainties as to the stock market and the government's action on gold and silver.

BOSTON, Dec. 24. -- Branding the proposed code for hotel and restaurant employes under the NRA as "inconsistent and un-American," more than 1,000 of these workers, at a protest meeting today, adopted a substitute calling for a forty-hour week, "one day's rest in seven," elimination of payment for meals and restoring of wages paid on a weekly basis prior to adoption of the tentative code.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Dec. 24. -- The largest field of the year took part in a turkey shoot over the traps of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today. There were two 50-target regular events and a 25-target skeet contest.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Government purchases of hogs, estimated at 175,000 head in eight leading markets, at an expenditure of close to $10,000,000, did not help the market for hogs to any extent last week. The hogs averaged 160 to 210 pounds each, or about 33,250,000 pounds for all the hogs.

The two appointments Mayor O'Brien will make this week to fill the vacancies on the Board of Transportation created by the retirement of Chairman John H. Delaney and Commisisoner Daniel L. Ryan. will be carefully scrutinized by Mayor-elect LaGuardia, it was indicated last night.

Early in the month the Oxford Preservation Trust issued a statement showing the damage done to the High Street front of University College by heavy motor vehicles. An extension of the northern by-pass road to relieve the pressure of commercial traffic on central Oxford was urged.

Mayor-elect LaGuardia and his advisers have been concentrating for the last week on the preparation of the legislative program to be presented at Albany after the session begins on Jan. 3. Work on the plan will continue this week.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 24. -- Out-stripping the greatest field ever entered in a California tournament. Paul Runyan, White Plains (N. Y.) professional, won the Pasadena open golf championship today with a par-shattering 282 for the 72 holes.

Leading commodity futures on local exchanges moved with great irregularity last week and closed unevenly. Silver was higher at the close, but some of the others failed to overcome earlier losses. Trading was dull until Friday, when it became active.
UTICA, N. T., Dec. 24. -- Wolves In the northern Adirondacks are beginning to reduce the-deer herd, the gnawed carcasses of six deer having been found on Lily Pad Pond.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- A Christmas party unique in White House history was held today.

HARVARD, Mass., Dec. 24. -- Extensive new research into the fastnesses of space is to result now following the swinging of the huge sixty-inch telescope mirror of the Harvard College Observatory onto its new mounting at the Oak Ridge station here.

Cotton prices fluctuated within a narrow range in the early part of last week, but the announcement of the President's silver-buying policy near the close brought about a rather sharp upturn. At the close of the week active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 10 to 17 points, or 50 to 85 cents a bale, from the close of the previous week.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24. -- Gridiron stars who will meet in the annual East-West charity football game here on New Year's Day went through brisk workouts today, each squad stressing offensive tactics.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- By written questions published in the latest issue of the Official Journal, Jacques Doriot, Communist Deputy, asks the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Joseph Paul-Boncour, about French shipmeats of armaments to Japan. According to the Jaw, a written answer must be published in the Official Journal within twenty days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Although some were war-saddened and others puritanically simple, White House Christmases from John Adams to Franklin D. Roosevelt have emphasized the home-loving note as a national symbol. Washington never lived in the White House he helped to design, serving his Presidential terms in New York and Philadelphia.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Dec. 24. -- Bennington College students have just disbanded for a two-month field and reading period, during which the 160 young women will continue their studies in various metropolitan centres of the United States, in Mexico, the West Indies and European countries.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 24. -- Revolt broke out in the ranks of the Inter-American Commission of Women during the Pan-American Conference plenary session when Angel Alberto Giraudy, Cuban delegate, moved today that women delegates at the conference, who had received the recognition of their own governments, form a committee to continue studies of women's topics.
That Paris Conference. Something might be said against the propriety of Postmaster General FARLEY'S visit to ex-Mayor WALKER in Paris. More can be said for it as a natural, human action.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- In a Christmas address to the nation tonight President Roosevelt voiced a message of cheer, while earlier he exemplified the Christmas spirit by restoring civil rights to about 1,500 persons who had served sentences for opposing the World War.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 24 -- Henri Mouquin, whose rare wines, onion soups and delicious French dinners made him well known to several generations of New Yorkers, died today at the age of 96.

Radio programs in keeping with the Christmas spirit will occupy most of the time on the air today. A large number of foreign countries have announced broadcasts scheduled to be heard by listeners in this country. The international programs begin early this morning and will continue until late this afternoon.

Expressing disappointment at the withdrawal of Joseph Nemerov, and his counsel, Max D. Steuer, "from the contemplated litigation against the Superintendent of Insurance to protect the rights of holders of guaranteed mortgages," Samuel Untermyer disclosed yesterday that he planned to organize a protective committee and proceed to act.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Three masses, recited in the intimacy of his private chapel at midnight, marked the climax of Pope Pius's Christmas Eve celebration. The intimacy and quiet of his devotions followed a custom of nearly a quarter of a century.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Increased industrial activity and the low level of domestic stocks resulted in a sharp rise in American import trade during the Summer and early Fall of 1933, according to an analysis made public today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States covering the first nine months of the year.

Set upon by assassins while he was proceeding to the altar to celebrate the divine liturgy, Archbishop Leon Tourian, supreme head of the Armenian Church in this country, was stabbed to death yeserday in view of 200 worshipers at the Holy Cross Armenian Apostolic Church, 578 West 187th Street.

With her coat and two potato sacks tied over her head and both hands bound at her sides, the body of Sarah Weiss, 15 years old, of 635 East Ninth Street was found early yesterday propped against the wheel of a wagon in front of the livery stable at 353 East Fourth Street.

POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N. J., Dec. 24. -- Two men and two women were drowned early this morning and another man was rescued when a sedan with a party of merrymakers ran off the public pier here into the Manasquan River.

GREENCASTLE, Ind., Dec. 24 (AP). -- The trend in Methodist churches toward a more ritualistic order of worship will be shown in the new Methodist hymnal and psalter, according to Dean R.G. McCutchan of De Pauw University's School of Music, editor of the book.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In "Labor's Point of View" William Green points out how from 1899 to 1909, thanks to invention and improved methods, the average factory week was reduced from fifty-nine to fifty-two hours while the work done in the former fifty-nine hours was done in forty-seven hours.

Friends of W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, may extend the fight that Mr. Macy has started against Fred W. Hammond, clerk of the Assembly, and Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies to include Senator George R. Fearon, Republican leader of the State Senate, it was learned yesterday.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 24. -- Dominating today's and tomorrow's program are Christmas dinner's, many of them small family gatherings at homes, which are settings for holiday house parties.
The determined generosity of friends of the Neediest has carried the Fund past another milestone.

ST. PAUL ISLAND, Bering Sea, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Santa Claus came to the icy Pribiloff Islands tonight and found in the land of the seals and foxes a happy group of little frosty Eskimos and Indians, for there is no depression here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- President Roosevelt is considering appearing: personally before Congress next month to read his annual message and allowing it to be sent over the nation by radio.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 24. -- Texas won an international polo match from Mexico today by a score of 11 to 8. Cecil Smith, who scored six goals for the victors, was all over the field and his stickwork was superb. Julio Muller, captain of the Mexican team, failed to score, but played a stellar game.

William Siegel, librettist for the operetta, "Messiah's Coming," which was presented at the Public Theatre on Saturday night, evidently patronizes the Yiddish playhouses and is not averse to picking up an idea here and there. He has embellished his slight story of the love of a blind girl and a village idiot with some touches of Art smacking of some recent productions.

HAVANA, Dec. 24. -- Hundreds of relatives of 404 former Cuban army officers waited in vain last night and today at the gates of Principe prison and Cabana Fortress for the carrying out of the order of the Audencia Court for their release on parole.

Christmas, with its message of joy and of hope for mankind, was hailed by the city's clergy in their sermons yesterday morning. There were some, however, who deplored the trend away from religious observance of the day.

SEATTLE, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A hillside softened by incessant rains crashed down on a farmhouse near here today, burying two women, while lower temperatures and an ending to continuous downpours brought relief to other parts of the flood-besieged Pacific Northwest.

ATLANTA, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A million dollar farm colony, designed to show the world a thing or two about farming, and also to demonstrate how the section's agricultural industry can be lifted by its own bootstraps, is to be established in Georgia under the sponsorship of the Federal Government.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 24. -- Stanford's football Indians arrived from Palo Alto today in a dense fog, but they were not hazy about the fight they expect when they meet Columbia in the Rose Bowl battle New Year's day.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24. -- The central committee of the Communist party publishes today a cordial message to the workers and executives -- in that order -- of the gigantic chemical plant at Bobriki, which has just been completed ahead of schedule.

BETHLEHEM, Monday, Dec. 25 -- Where Jesus Christ was born nearly twenty centuries ago, a multitude of worshipers reverently hailed another Christmas. At midnight an electric star of Bethlehem burst into light above the altar in the Church of the Convent and the drawing of a curtain revealed a superb effigy of the Holy Infant.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 24. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.4, which compares with 72 a week ago, 71.7 two weeks ago, 71.4 three weeks ago and 71.7 four weeks ago. The average of Oct. 15, at 72.2, was the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

No more welcome holiday gift could have come from the Treasury and the Administration at Washington than assurance that gold, silver and the currency would be let alone while the people were eating their Christmas dinners. That ghost will not haunt the feast.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- A check-up by the authorities has shown that the casualties in the Lagny train wreck of last night exceed the worst fears. Already 189 bodies have been recovered, while more than twice that number of persons were injured, half of them seriously.

BERLIN, Dec. 23. -- The Reichs-bank's reduction of the interest transfer on German external bonds to 30 per cent has had no effect on the Berlin market for certificated external bonds which remained firm. This was contributed to by the decision, of virtually all bond debtor corporations to offer to convert Germans' holdings to a mark basis at the favorable exchange of three marks to the dollar, against the current official rate of 2.7.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- For "nigh on to thirty years" some of the guests of today's Christmas party at the White House had been giving service around the Executive Mansion, and they said they had never seen anything like it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Administration officials were described tonight as prepared for an intensive effort to have written into the laws of the individual States the labor features of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

PARIS, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Midnight mass, which brought hundreds of thousands of devout worshipers to the churches of France tonight, was marked here with the singing of an American cantata. It was the first time an American composition had been so presented

The five-story building fronting twenty-five feet at 146 East Forty-fourth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, in the Grand Central zone has been purchased from Mrs. Lillie Cohen by the Hildegarde Realty Company in which J. R. Elyachar and H. L. Blair are interested.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Some of the notables of the screen will spend Christmas in the snow, some will go to the desert for sun-baths, but most will remain at their own firesides.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 24. -- A completely new vista in boundary relations was opened up today when a plenary session of the Pan-American Conference adopted an Argentine proposal for a conference at Buenos Aires to settle the Chaco conflict by considering the economic and geographic problems of Bolivia and Paraguay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to the account in THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Rev. Ignatius W. Cox in a sermon denounced those who "discount the joys of motherhood through the practice of birth control" and "never seem to understand that children are more precious than vacations, automobiles, jewelry and finery."

Expressing regret that "any rift" should come between "those who work on the side of Fusion," George Boochever, Brooklyn Fusion campaign manager, explained last night what he considered some differences between the city Fusion party and the Kings County Fusion Organization.

The approach to the Lower Harbor from the Ambrose Channel Lightship was blocked yesterday by a dense fog which hung over the water from 7 o'clock until 4 in the afternoon when it lifted a little but then came down so thick that the twelve steamships assembled outside Sandy Hook bar had to anchor again.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amounted to 53,193,210,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

An arbitration board to be formed under the auspices of the American Arbitration Association will decide a claim brought by Pola Negri, screen star, against the Shuberts' for salary amounting to about $4,000 on the unexpired portion of her agreement with them.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Illinois and Chicago are engaged in a controversy over proper tavern and liquor control legislation.

BERLIN, Dec. 23. -- Year-end summaries here of President Roosevelt's economic policy are either non-committal or unfavorable. It is commented that the policy lacks unity and contains elements of planning without going to the planner's logical extreme of directly controlling capital.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The ninth annual Congress of the National Student Federation, and the first to be held in Washington, will open here on Wednesday and continue to the end of the week.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 24. -- This year the light of Christmas pierces vast clouds hanging over half the world, and more hopefully than ever the world grasps at the good tidings, the Most Rev. James de Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, said in a Christmas message broadcast today from station WEAN over the Columbia network and WABC.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Playing St. Nicholas to nine children and their widowed mother, pilots of a huge mail-passenger plane circled above the humble home in the Escalante Desert of Southern Utah late today and dropped gifts.

BERLIN, Dec. 24 (AP). -- With only a few exceptions, German newspapers accepted with satisfaction today the verdict of the Supreme Court acquitting four of those charged with high treason in the burning of the Reichstag last February and the sentencing to death of the Dutch brickmason, Marinus van der Lubbe, for the crime.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls gained undisputed possession of second place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League by repulsing the Bronx Hockey Club, 5 to 3, in an overtime battle at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of more than 1,000 saw the contest.

OTTAWA, Dec. 24 (Canadian Press). -- The government wound up a comparatively busy Christmas week by appointing the long-awaited board of trustees for the Canadian National Railways and calling a dominion-provincial conference to meet in Ottawa on, Jan. 11.
MOSCOW, Dec. 24. -- Before Soviet eyes and in Soviet opinion the Japanese war cloud on the Eastern horizon is growing daily in size and darkness.

PORT WASHINGTON. L. I., Dec. 24. -- Egbert Moxham Sr. and Ted Clark were the outstanding winners in a day of dinghy sailing off the North Hempstead Yacht Club today. More than a dozen boats drifted around the course in five races through water that apparently was as motionless as a sheet of glass.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 24. -- A blinding fog, said to have been the worst in the harbor here in thirty-five years, enshrouded the sailing dinghies today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's pre-Christmas regatta.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- Variations in quotations on the dollar continue to disconcert financial circles, with no one now doubting that President Roosevelt's policy is progressively to accentuate currency depreciation. The incentive to do so, moreover, is obvious, since as soon as the dollar hardens, commodity prices fall in the United States.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The arrest of Hilton O. Crouch, a member of the notorious Dillinger gang, caused an exhaustive investigation by police today to determine the extent of gangster and political incursions into the tavern field in Chicago.

Two hundred lonely old men and women, who have fallen on evil days, were guests at the seventh annual Christmas dinner given by the Advertising Club of New York yesterday at 23 Park Avenue. Gentlefolk , with barely enough to keep body and soul together, it had been at least a year since most of them had enjoyed turkey and cranberry sauce, not to mention a five-piece orchestra.

A novel entertainment in behalf of philanthropy has been arranged by members of the Junior League of New York for Jan. 4 at the Park Lane. After luncheon, which will be served at small tables in the ballroom of the hotel, there will be a fashion show, "Off on a Cruise," in which many young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons will display the latest costumes for cruises.

The immediate need for wild waterfowl, according to the authorities who have studied the subject, seems to be a sufficient number of refuges. The devastation which natural refuges have suffered in recent years has done as much as, if not more than, any other factor to decimate the flocks of ducks which came over this country in vast droves.

The telegraphed Christmas carol, trolled at the regular message rates, is the Western Union's latest contribution to the celebration of the holidays by proxy. It takes its place with the wired Valentine, wired flowers and wired birthday greetings.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 24. -- Harold W. Baker, Director of Public Construction for the District of Columbia, will succeed Theodore C. Briggs, Republican, as city manager Jan. 1, as the result of a Democratic caucus. He will be the first Democrat to hold that post.

An exhibition called "Chinese Paintings Through the Ages," assembled by C. Edward Wells for the College Art Association and catalogued by Benjamin March of the University of Michigan, is in progress at the Edward Wells Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 24 (AP). -- A thorough investigation into the "many rumors and reports of conditions at St. John's College" here, was asked today by Dr. Vernon P. Scheidt of Baltimore in a letter to Luther S. Tall, president of the newly-organized Alumni Association.

DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Gar Wood, who made thousands gasp last September when he sent his speedboat Miss America roaring over Lake St. Glair in the annual Harmsworth races, did a little gasping himself today when he stood beside a modern newspaper press.

The bird of dawning has indeed sung all night long and given promise of a more gracious time this Christmas season. It is gratifying to report that the Fund for the Neediest has passed $200,000. When all the conditions this year are taken into account, it is clear that New York has made fresh demonstration of a grace which, "once forgot, would let nothing go right."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Taking note of the "holiday season of the most eventful peace year" in American history, General Johnson, Recovery Administrator, declared in a statement today that 1933 would go down in history as that in which "the greatest economic change of all time had its inception."

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Country holders are bullish, because of the government's policy of lending 45 cents a bushel for corn on farms, the loans to run until Aug. 1, 1934. This makes movement from farms disappointingly small and tends to induce fair speculative buying on all price recessions.
FAIRLAWN, N. J., Dec. 24. -- Members of the Radburn Skeet Club competed for Christmas ducks today. The five prizes went to B. Pielaet, V. King, A. Edmunds, C. R. Rogers and J. N. Boucher.

Younger members of the Summer Play Schools Committee of the Child Study Association of America will hold their annual dance in behalf of the organization tonight in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- The discovery of two golden engraved goblets that are the oldest metallic vases of Phoenician origin known, and other finds of the highest importance to the history of languages and art, have been announced by the Academy of Inscriptions.

ABOARD THE S. S. JACOB RUPPERT, Exploring Off Antarctica, Dec. 23. -- For seven and one-half hours the flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition has been fogbound a few miles north of the Antarctic pack. Another attempted easting to the 142d meridian has accordingly been temporarily halted.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Halsted Vander Poel will have their annual Christmas tree reception this morning at their home, 830 Park Avenue, for their relatives and intimate friends.
"The Locked Room," by Herbert Ashton Jr., opens tonight at the Ambassador Theatre, with Robert Gleckler, Walter Gilbert and Valerie Bergere in the cast.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Chinese and Japanese football warriors, reviving an annual contest that was dropped in 1930, battled today, with the sons of Nippon winning, 13 to 12.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Infantile paralysis sufferers at the Warm Springs Foundation are celebrating Christmas in elaborate ceremonies centring around Georgia Hall, the gift of the people of Georgia to the institution.

LAGNY, Dec. 24. -- The engineer and fireman of the Paris-Strasbourg flier that plowed through four coaches of the Nancy express last night were jailed today. Railroad officials said they had run through a closed signal in a thick fog at sixty-five miles an hour, and they were charged with having caused the catastrophe by imprudence.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 24. -- A last-minute attempt to eliminate the Inter-American Commission of Women failed today when the Pan-American Conference at its final working session laughed out of existence a project which the steering committee had adopted a few minutes earlier, providing for the creation of a new women's committee to take over the work now being done by the commission.

Reports from the building industry not only in New York City but in many parts of the country show that the year 1933 is closing with a much larger volume of operations under way and projected than was the case during the preceding year.

This week will bring to an end a very remarkable year in our financial history; a year of which it may truthfully be said that past American history provides no parallel or precedent. The same assertion, it is true, was made in regard to other recent years;

THERE is no heartening story of Bethlehem and the three wise men bearing gifts in Mary Borden's "Mary of Nazareth" (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50), which is a novelist's attempt to re-create in grave, sometimes biblical prose the life of the mother of Jesus. Nor is there any of the expansive spirit that makes Christmas a festival which even that doughtiest of anti-clericals, Ernest Boyd, can thoroughly enjoy.

After much discussion the House Ways and Means Committee has agreed on a program of liquor taxes. It includes a levy of $2 a gallon on distilled spirits, $5 a barrel on beer and from 10 to 80 cents on wines containing not more than 24 per cent of alcohol. These are far more moderate rates than seemed probable some time ago, but public sentiment regarding liquor taxes has undergone a change.
PROVIDENCE, Dec. 24. -- Two Providence policemen were shot to death today on a deserted down-town street.

When it came to deal with bus franchises the expiring Board of Estimate took its courage in both hands. In few matters of city policy has Tammany promised more or accomplished less. HYLAN hoped that great fleets of buses would soon be swarming over the streets.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- The body of 8-year-old Josephine Waropay of 8 Washington Avenue, who had been reported missing to police at 9 o'clock last night, was found this morning hidden under the rear end of St. Matthew's Lyceum Building here, a few blocks from her home.

A 45-yard field goal by Arman Niccolai of Duquesne early in the second period gave the North a 3-0 victory over the South in the charity football game at the Brooklyn Sports Stadium yesterday. A crowd of 5,000 witnessed the fray, which was staged under the auspices of the Kings County American Legion.

William Steiner, German-American A. C. star, holder of the national twenty-mile championship, annexed the Manhattan Athletic League cross-country title yesterday when he finished first in the four-and-a-half-mile test at Van Cortlandt Park.

The cooperation of the United States Bureau of Entomology in the war for the extermination of mosquitoes in New York City has been requested by the Health Department of the city. Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.

A team of seven chess players from New York University, meeting a strong side representing the Isaac L. Rice Progressive Chess Club at the latter's rooms yesterday, suffered a 5 -- 2 defeat. Victories by S. Baumblatt, N. Dalu, M. Newman and M. Chaikin accounted for the success of the home team.

Contributions and pledges to the United Hospital Fund of New York, 122 East Twenty-second Street, for the support of the fifty-six member institutions, reached a total of $301,559 yesterday, it was announced by Henry J. Fisher, president of the fund.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Business in this district is the best in recent years in most leading lines, according to reports issued in the last few days. The rush of buying has surprised even the most optimistic. Gains in the last three months are estimated largely to have offset previous losses.
TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 24. -- Thirty Columbia football players spent a quiet day before Christmas today, in sharp contrast to what it might have been in the immediate vicinity of Morningside Heights.

Three British authors are finishing off trilogies, some of which were started many years ago. Eden Phillpotts completes his chronicle of Avis Bryden in "A Shadow Passes," which is to be published on Jan. 23 by Macmillan. The two earlier books were "Bred in the Bone" and "Witch's Cauldron."
MISSOULA, Mont., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Passengers from the eastbound Olympian, a Milwaukee train stalled by mudslides and flood waters of the St. Regis River, are to spend Christmas Day traveling.

PROVIDENCE, Dec. 24. -- The roar of guns today attracted a cab driver, who went to the street to find, near a police box Patrolman Murray dead and Patrolman Kelly dying. No one could be found who had witnessed the shooting.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 24. -- The first step toward giving the University of Kansas City an outstanding liberal system of education was taken when the faculty adopted what may become known as "the University of Kansas City system."
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A large holiday crowd at the Jefferson Park charity races today saw Frank Seremba's Nyack capture the featured fifth event from Flo M. and Felaxe.

Strict regulation of vessels transporting explosives and other dangerous freight in American harbors and inland waterways is urged in a statement to the Interstate Commerce Commission by the American Association of Port Authorities, the Port of New York Authority and the Waterfront Property Owners in New York Harbor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The 1932 city budget provided for 147,000 city employes. The latest figures for the end of 1933, according to city authorities, show the personnel to be about 131,000. This is a reduction of about 16,000 within the last two years.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- A blast of subzero weather in Chicago and the suburbs will usher in Christmas tomorrow, J. R, Lloyd, forecaster, predicted today.

Activity in steel mills last week continued to increase, contrary to the seasonal trend, and operations rose 5 points to 38 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. Because of the deadline of Dec. 31 on shipments against expiring contracts, the publication states that holiday observance will scarcely impair this week's showing.
MONTREAL, Monday, Dec. 25 (Canadian Press). -- The Gazette today published the following:

BERLIN, Dec. 23. -- The Nazi Government's currency and financial measures in the furtherance of its trade policy in the last year have been less revolutionary than was expected. The party's original program, however, has been in nowise fully carried out.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- George Kelly of Philadelphia defeated a fellow-townsman, William Mosconi, by 125 to 100 in seventeen innings tonight to take possession of third position in the final standings of the world's pocket billiard tournament.

From the restrictions of the eight-hour day and the five-day week one members of the next city administration will be conspicuously free. But then RUFUS MCGAHEN of the Citizens Union, the new Budget Director, is accustomed to hard work and long hours. He has burned the midnight lamp fer many years at Albany.

Careless handling of an "unloaded" pistol caused a Christmas Eve tragedy in Brooklyn last night. The victim, Philip Nasuto, 21 years old, of 101 Garfield Place, was shot through the head and killed instantly.

BERLIN, Dec, 24. -- Self-congratulation on the business achievements of the first Hitler year and predictions of even greater achievements next year "characterized the year-end reports of the German Chamber of Commerce and other similar institutions, including the Institute for Business Research.

THIS being a time of the season when a feeling of good-will, or at least of calm endurance and tolerance, toward your neighbor seems to pervad the atmosphere, it might be in order to note that not the least of the many startling upsets which enlivened 1933 were the passing of some of the most outstanding feuds in sport.

What is wrong with Christianity in America is not too few church members but too many church members who do not appreciate the meaning of Christ, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

BOSTON, Dec. 24. -- Beacon Hill, bright with thousands of candles and echoing with carols and music, had more than 15,000 visitors tonight as it became again the centre of Boston's Christmas Eve celebration.

Four men were shot dead in Hudson County over the week-end. Three shootings occurred in Hoboken and the fourth at Secaucus, N. J. Police said the murders had no connection. Two men, believed to have been implicated, were arrested and charged with homicide.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 24 (AP). -- The most severe cold wave of the season, with temperatures ranging as low as 30 degrees below zero, following snow storms that brought falls of an inch to more than a foot, gave the northwest real old-fashioned Christmas weather today.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 24. -- A system of control which would restrict sales of hard liquor to State dispensaries and leave beer and wine to private licensees, such as clubs, hotels and restaurants, will be recommended to the January session of the General Assembly by the Virginia Liquor Control Commission.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Although there were fair rains over the Southwestern Winter wheat States last week, the whole section west of the Missouri River remains in need of moisture and conditions are becoming less favorable for next year's crop.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Former President Hoover and Mrs. Hoover went quietly about their Yuletide observance today with an accompaniment of the happy, expectant chatter and merry laughter of their grandchildren.

New York prepared yesterday for its merriest Christmas in several years, somewhat handicapped by Springlike weather, but fortified by legal quaffing of good wines and spirits and by the general feeling that happy days are here again.

Jose Richling, Charge d'Affaires of the Uruguayan Government at Washington, announced here yesterday that he had received cabled advices from the Minister of Finance saying that the government had decided that its foreign debt should receive payment of interest for 1934 at a rate not lower than 3 1/2 per cent.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24. -- The approach of the Christmas holidays and uncertainty regarding the government's future financial policy, next year's crop reduction and the forthcoming session of Congress, combined last week to reduce trading sharply in the cotton contract market here.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- Foreign trade figures for November show imports at 2,289,000,000 francs, an increase of 59,000,000 from October, and a decrease of 240,000,000 from November, 1932. Imports of foodstuffs were 757,000,000 francs, or 9,000,000 less than in October and 212,000,000 less than in November, 1932.
