John Mawhinney of the St. Raphael's C. B. C. won the Invitation handicap road run staged by the St. Anselm's A. C. in the Bronx yesterday.

Disregarding the holiday spirit, the New York Rangers sought revenge last night, and they got it. Meeting their rivals for local favor, the Americans, for the second time this season, the blue-jerseyed stick handlers registered a decisive 3 -- 1 triumph and evened matters for the defeat they suffered at the hands of Joe Simpson's men on Dec. 12.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 24. -- With a further rise in production of steel last week, the trade looks for a correspondingly greater drop after the turn of the year than was expected recently, but this leaves the prospect for January much better than when production was at its low rate, in the week ended on Nov. 11.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 24. -- "Sentimentalism in Christianity is particularly tragic when we think of the heritage of realism which rightly belongs to Christianity," said Professor Halford E. Luccock of the Yale Divinity School in his sermon at the Yale Christmas service today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Heated debate over proposed changes in college football rules was predicted tonight on the eve of the thirteenth annual meeting of the American Football Coaches Association.
MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 26 (AP) -- At least thirteen deaths and much property damage were reported from a volcanic eruption and a typhoon and tidal wave in the Philippine Islands today.

BARCELONA, Dec. 25 -- Claude G. Bowers, United States Ambassador to Spain, transmitted condolences of the United States Government through Consul General Dawson when he learned of President Macia's death.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 25 (AP) -- A. wisp of sandy hair protruding from a mass of cotton waste in a deserted house near Columbia today solved the forty-eight hour disappearance of Herbert H. Harris Jr., 15 years old.
Robert Edison Fulton Jr., son of the president of the Mack International Truck Company, returned to New York on Friday after completing a two-year trip around the world on a motor-cycle.
PROVIDENCE, Dec. 25 (AP) -- After thirty-six hours of intensive investigation, the shooting to death of two policemen on a downtown street yesterday remained a mystery tonight.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP) -- While telegrams and messages in a steady stream brought greetings today to a former President from all parts of the world, the Herbert Hoover household celebrated Christmas in their family circle on San Juan Hill.
AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Bahamas, flaunting the colors of Bill Hartman, galloped to victory in the Christmas Handicap, first stake of the eighty-day Winter race meeting, today.
BARCELONA, Dec. 25 -- Colonel Francesc Macia, president of autonomous Catalonia, died this morning after two operations for internal disorders. He was 74.

Evelyn Fentry, 6 years old, of 410 West Fiftieth Street, was shot in the left leg yesterday as she was skating with friends on the side-walk at Fiftieth Street and Ninth Avenue. The police were unable to determine who had fired the shots, but learned that several roisterers had been arguing on the corner.
George Evans Turnure, investment banker of this city, died last night after a long illness at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 77 years old.

Five men, four of them admittedly members of Tashnag, a revolutionary organization whose aim is the restoration of the old Republic of Armenia, were under arrest early today in connection with the assassination of Archbishop Leon Tourian in the Holy Cross Armenian Church, 578 West 187th Street, on Sunday.

The board of directors of the Container Corporation of America has approved the expenditure of a substantial sum for modernization and improvement of equipment at two of its Chicago plants, it was announced yesterday.

The Public Accountants Guild, recently organized by the American Federation of Labor, has asked Grover A. Whalen, NRA Administrator for the City of New York, to receive a committee of Guild and A. F. of L. representative, who will solicit his endorsement of the principle of a code of fair practices for public accountancy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- What is to be done with the 14-to-16-year-old boy or girl who has completed school attendance requirements and still is too young for wage-earning employment?
Play In the national Junior and boys' indoor tennis championship tournaments will get under way this morning on the Seventh Regiment Armory courts without a defending titleholder in either division.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 -- A 2-year-old upset calculations in the all-age Christmas Handicap at Jefferson Park today when Mrs. John Zoeller's filly Tatanne won by two lengths from Contraband. It was Tatanne's fourth straight triumph here and her sixth in her last seven starts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- White House police yielded to the soft notes of Christmas carolers last night.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25 -- Astronomers here are working on a better yardstick to measure distances to the outer reaches of space.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 25 -- Paraguay formally notified the League of Nations Chaco investigating committee this afternoon that she would not begin peace negotiations until the Gran Chaco was evacuated by the Bolivians, according to information obtained tonight from a reliable diplomatic source.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Women whom the depression has driven even into subway corners and city jails for a warm corner in which to sleep are the object of the government's first concerted effort to care for the "forgotten woman."

The Capitol and Empire String Quartets and the Harlem String Trio will give a series of free concerts in the city's public libraries, schools, churches and Y.M.C.A.'s during the week under the auspices of the State Department of Education.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The Federal army of 300,000 men who forsook civilization with its depression and plunged into the forests have done a splendid job, Robert Fechner, director of Emergency Conservation Work, reported to President Roosevelt today.
More stories of extortion and grafting in connection with news stand licenses are expected to be told today when License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine resumes his investigation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's first annual message to Congress will be delivered on Jan. 3, the first day of the session, for reading by a House clerk.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, Exploring Off Antarctica, Dec. 24 -- The night before Christmas the flagship of the Byrd Antarctic Expedition was still fogbound a mile off the main Antarctic ice pack. Her noon position was 66.15 S. 143 E.

A lone sea-gull, banking and executing side-slips in the bitter wind that swept Camp Thomas Paine, on the West Seventy-fifth Street river front, yesterday morning, observed beneath him a scene of almost total desolation. In the zig-zag "avenues" between the flimsy shacks, nothing stirred but the tattered flags whipping in the wind, the crude weathercocks, and the twenty-seven adopted cats.

If Mayor O'Brien should make appointments to fill the vacancies on the Board of Transportation left by the recent retirement of Chairman John H. Delaney and Commissioner Daniel L. Ryan, the way will be paved for abolition of the board, Samuel Untermyer, special counsel to the Board of Estimate, declared last night.
The cellar berth in the American group of the National Hockey League was vacated by the New York Rangers last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Congress, at its next session, will be asked to provide Federal aid to cities whose finances are in the worst quagmire of their history.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Silent thousands of Japanese subjects lined the route taken by Emperor Hirohito today in a procession of state from the royal palace to the Parliament building for the formal opening of the Diet. There were many more than usual, and their reverence gave evidence of the intensified popular homage for the reigning house following the birth of the Crown Prince on Saturday.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 25 (AP) -- All was in readiness tonight for the beginning tomorrow of the thirty-first annual midwinter golf championship. George T. Dunlap Jr., national amateur champion who won the midwinter crown seven times in eight years, will make another attempt to capture the title.

SEATTLE, Dec. 25 -- Four names were added today to the list of dead in the storm-ridden Pacific Northwest as flood waters, pent up by a natural dam, were unloosed in sudden fury in a small creek bed near Clatskanie, Ore. A man and three of his sons were crushed to death, their residence buried in a mass of mud, rocks and logs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt celebrated today their "happiest Christmas," surrounded by a family house party representing four generations. The group also included an uncle and several nephews, as well as sisters, cousins and aunts.

Although entertaining yesterday was confined chiefly to family reunions and Christmas-tree parties for young children, the debutantes were not forgotten. Many New York debutantes went to New Jersey last night for the large supper dance given jointly by Mrs. James Graeme Lidgerwood and Mr. and Mrs. George Albert Easley of Morristown at the Morris County Golf Club to introduce their daughters, Miss Jean Graeme Lidgerwood and Miss Frances Virginia Easley.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- T.E. Hough, vice president of Halsey, Stuart Co., has prepared the annual bond review for his company this year. His statement says, in part:

The predicted liquor shortage failed to materialize yesterday. Ample stocks of wines and spirits were available in liquor stores, hotels and restaurants to add exhilaration to the Christmas celebration.

MADRID, Dec. 25 -- The death of Colonel Francesc Macia is seen here as complicating the delicate situation in the Catalan party and thus introducing still further difficulties in national politics. President Macia had lost much of his personal popularity during the last twelve months and in the recent Parliamentary elections his party won only twenty-two seats, compared with the twenty-five of the Conservative League.
HAVANA, Dec. 25 -- More than 300 civilian prisoners, taken at the battle of Atares early last month, were liberated early today after they had threatened to go on a hunger strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- An inside story of the Hoover administration is to be given in a book, "Hoover -- Off the Record," by Theodore G. Joslin, who was secretary to the President from early 1931 until the close of Mr. Hoover's administration.
LONDON, Dec. 25 -- The Arsenal won again today, beating Leeds United, 1 -- 0, to maintain its three point margin at the top of the first division of the English Football League.

Calling for a rapprochement or alliance between banking and the government, the Guaranty Trust Company, in the current issue of its monthly review, The Guaranty Survey, criticizes the provisions of the permanent deposit-insurance plan and advances proposals for banking reform which include unified Federal regulation of banks and limited branch banking.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in his annual report to the trustees, made public yesterday, says that the service motive must supplement the profit motive if our civilization is to endure.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Dec. 25 -- An old-fashioned Christmas family celebration was held today at Sagamore Hill, the home of Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, widow of the former President. It was the first time in five years that Mrs. Roosevelt's son, Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, former Governor General of the Philippines, had been here to celebrate Christmas with his mother and the rest of the family.

FOR eleven years now Minton, Balch Co. have been collecting reproductions of the finest contemporary etchings, engravings and dry-point work for annual publication. This year's book, "Fine Prints of the Year 1933," is edited, as were the previous ones, by that veteran connoisseur of the etcher's needle, Malcolm C. Salaman, who contributes an essay on the British prints and a few notes on the Continental prints.

Hardly a place was left at the Christmas Eve supper table in the Brace Memorial Newsboys House of the Children's Aid Society at 244 William Street when Jimmy Eatwell appeared. But Jimmy found a place, although he did not begin to confide until after his Christmas dinner yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The Secretary of War and Mrs. Dern and Mrs. Swanson, wife of the Secretary of the Navy, were the guests of honor at the sixth annual midshipmen's and cadets' ball tonight at the Mayflower.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Minot Amory, Mrs. Amory's daughter, Miss Gloria Baker, and her son, George Vanderbilt, entertained tonight with a dinner dance at their villa on Banyan Road.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- Two hundred delegates from various parts of the country meeting here today organized Masada, the young men's Zionist organization. Isaac Imber of New York was elected president and six vice chairmen and an executive committee were chosen.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 5 (AP) by Mail) -- Syrian Nationalists are conducting a campaign against the recently negotiated treaty calling for a twenty-five-year alliance with France. Street parades and minor rioting greeted the opening of Parliament when Nationalist Deputies presented a petition asking for rejection of the treaty without consideration.

The Federal budget which goes to Congress next week is expected to carry about $2,600,000,000 for the "ordinary" expenditures of the Government. Since revenues of $3,500,000,000 are now thought to be in sight, this would leave a margin of nearly a billion for public works and other "emergency" outlays.

All the world seemed happier yesterday than for several Christmas Days past. In the White House, President Roosevelt, his mother, his wife, their children and their aunts and uncles held an old-fashioned family party on what they said was their "happiest Christmas."
Contributions for the relief of New York's Neediest slumped sharply yesterday. They numbered 160 and made a total of $2,955.85.
TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 25 -- Tampa University climaxed its first year of intercollegiate football today with a 7-to-0 victory over the Haskell Indians of Lawrence, Kan., before 5,000 persons.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Probate Court Judge John F. O'Connell announced today that he had made an award of $250,000 to Mrs. Katharine Dexter McCormick, wife of Stanley McCormick, for her maintenance during the coming year. Mr. McCormick has resided on his estate at Santa Barbara, Cal., since 1906, when he was declared an incompetent and a ward of the Probate Court.

BEACON, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- Ill of a lung ailment that has caused him to spend every night, for the last twenty-seven months, in an artificial respirator at the Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N. Y., Birdsall Sweet, 15 years old, returned home for his Christmas dinner today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Larger purchases of American merchandise by twenty-nine countries in the first nine months of 1933, compared with the corresponding period of last year, were shown in a survey made public today by the United States Chamber of Commerce.
RODANTHE, N.C., Dec. 25 (AP) -- In this village off the coast most of the natives went about their business as usual today waiting for Old Christinas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- While the Christmas spirit prevailed elsewhere, there was far from peace and harmony among Philippine political leaders here and in Manila today when lines were drawn for an independence fight -- about which something must be done by next Jan. 17.

Sir ARTHUR SALTER has an article in the January Atlantic, "Toward a Planned Economy." One might think that we were not only moving" toward it but were deep inside of it. Never were so many writers busying themselves with it in books and periodicals. Some confine themselves strictly to a selfsufficient national plan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Asserting that $50,000,000 in direct wages to the nation's unemployed were being held up because 307 agreements and bond purchase contracts sent out to cities on allotments already made had not been returned. Secretary Ickes demanded today that local governments end dilatory tactics which kept men from jobs.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 -- Twelve cities and towns in Massachusetts, four of them important textile centres, reported sales gains in November over November last year, making the third consecutive month of increases over the corresponding month of the previous year.

"May it not be," asks President BUTLER in his annual report for 1933, "that "the true fountain of youth is the uni"versity?" For the water of this worldsought fountain was not to make man immortal but to renew his vigor. Whatever the calendar of passing years may chronicle, he "who really knows the "university's spirit and understands "its companionships may remain for"ever young in spirit and in truth."

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 25 -- With steel production in the Youngstown district for the five working days of the year's last week at 40 per cent of theoretical capacity and rolling mill schedules still higher, 1933 will end in this section with greater activity than even at the end of the banner year of 1929.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 -- Edward Yarnall Hartshorne, a retired banker who was active in charitable work, died at his home in Haverford last night after a brief illness. He was 72 years old.

John P. Curry, leader of Tammany, has asked Governor Lehman to appoint Mayor John P. O'Brien a Justice of the Supreme Court to succeed Justice Curtis A. Peters, who died on Dec. 17, it was reported last night. The appointment, if made, will be after Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- An increase of the enlisted strength of the marine corps to 17,000 men was recommended today by Major Gen. Ben H. Fuller, commandant of the corps, in his annual report to Secretary Swanson.

When all reports are In from the various States on bags of deer, pheasant, quail, rabbits, , experts will sit down and figure just what percentage of the game crop was taken throughout the season. In every fish and game commission office in the country there will be created a replacement program.

ALBANY, Dec. 25 -- Of the 1,889 law students who took the October bar examinations only 847 passed, it was announced today by the State Board of Law Examiners which consists of John Kirkland Clark of New York, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 -- Santa Claus came today to seventy lonely lighthouses and Coast Guard stations strung along the New England coast from Boston to Monhegan Island -- off the coast of Northeastern Maine.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 -- Exhausted by a half-mile tramp into Weymouth Woods at 2:30 A.M. to "cover" an incendiary fire, Alfred Hollis, 69, for forty-one years Weymouth-Braintree correspondent for The Boston Globe, died suddenly today.

The troubles of the present day were likened to the difficulties faced and overcome by the early Christians, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, delivered by Dean Milo Hudson Gates. Bishop William T. Manning participated in the Christmas procession which preceded the sermon.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Dec. 25 (AP) -- His automobile crashing into a bridge abutment and overturning into a shallow creek, Louis D. Meadows, 28, of Akron, Ohio, was killed this afternoon near Taylorstown, seven miles west of here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- One of these days the President will take the advice of those who, as every important public occasion approaches, urge him to go to Congress and broadcast a message to that body over a nation-wide radio hook-up to the people of the United States.

With a warning that "a long, tedious repair job" must precede constructive efforts in the city government, Mayor-elect LaGuardia, in a Christmas radio address yesterday over Station WOV, promised that nevertheless he would "strive to make the biggest city in the world the greatest city in the world."

VIENNA, Dec. 25 -- There is less of the spirit of peace and good-will in Central European politics than at any Christmas since the war. During the pacifistic period following five years of slaughter Christmas always was marked by big political amnesties, but there has been none this year.
NEW YORK. Lord Decies and his daughter, the Hon. Moya Beresford, will arrive on the Champlain and will be at the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The United States has only four vacancies in its foreign service and at least two of them are likely to be filled in a few days.

GALLUP, N.M., Dec. 25 -- While the Zunis engaged in a sacred fast, Navajo Indians today made their annual trek to find the "paleface Santa Claus" who presents them with tidbits and sweets on Christmas Day.

The growing trend toward modernization of old Manhattan buildings was emphasized yesterday in deals involving changes in control of two houses, one on the East Side and the other on the upper West Side. In both cases it was announced that the buildings would be modernized immediately.

PARIS, Dec. 25 -- An indication of the frightful shock of the crash of the Strasbourg flier into the fogbound Nancy express near Lagny, seventeen miles from here, Saturday night, was the fact that 165 passengers in the wooden cars of the standing train were killed outright.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 25 -- Christinas festivities and the packing of trunks occupied the United States delegation to the Pan-American Conference today. With thoughts naturally turned homeward, what attention was given to the conference, which formally closes tomorrow, was concerned mainly with translating its program into terms of United States action.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 25 -- Frederick A. Griffith's 3-year-old Sarada flashed to victory in the $2,000 added Christmas Handicap at Epsom Downs today before a large holiday crowd. Quatre Bras II was second and Frank Ormont third.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 25 -- In keeping with the spirit of Christmas, Coach Lou Little "gave" Columbia's football team a thorough, workout today in preparation for its New Year's Day game with Stanford at Pasadena.

The list of the steamship Excalibur of the American Export Lines, leaving today for the Mediterranean ports, includes: Mr. and Mrs. Eugen Bossevain, Frank J. Bovey, Francis P. Blair, J.E. Dorward, Mrs. Winston Hagen, Joseph S. Keene, Miss Ruth Starrels and Mrs. A.F.T. Tatum.

PARIS, Dec. 25 -- The latest tabulation of victims of Saturday night's train wreck near Lagny gives 191 dead, of whom fifty are still unidentified. The number injured approximates 300, and it is feared some of these will not survive.

"The Lake" opens this evening at the Martin Beck Theatre, with Katharine Hepburn -- returning from the films -- playing the leading role. Others in the cast are Colin Clive, Blanche Bates and Frances Starr.

On Both Cheeks. DORIS STBVENS, leader of the equal-status-for-women forces which have been carrying things before them at Montevideo, was kissed by several Latin-American delegations publicly and enthusiastically on Christmas Eve.

Port officials and grain exporters awaited word yesterday from Liverpool on the decision of British, customs officials regarding a shipment of Canadian grain that left New York Dec. 7 on the Cunard liner Ausonia. Upon the decision of the British authorities will depend the return of New York to its former position as an export centre for Canadian grain.

Cardinal Hayes sang a pontifical mass in celebration of Christmas yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral in the presence of a throng that filled the edifice. Afterward, from his throne, he imparted the papal benediction.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- King George broadcast a fatherly Christmas greeting today to uncounted millions of his devoted subjects throughout the British Empire and to millions of other listeners in the United States.

If there had been two of Robert Gleckler on the Ambassador stage last evening it is possible that "The Locked Room" might have amounted to something. For Mr. Gleckler, who is frequently turning up in dramatic mares' nests, is the most flavorsome ruffian in the American theatre.

ST. PAUL ISLAND, Bering Sea, Dec. 25 (AP) -- There was a happy group of Eskimos and Indians on this rocky island tonight, for their larders were filled with reindeer and sea lion meat, and old Saint Nick had not failed to stop by last evening.

Professor Irving Fisher of Yale University has listed only eighteen, men in the world "who understand the real meaning of money" in response to a request by the Consumers Guild of America, which yesterday made public his list.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- In my eighth article I pointed out that the policy of liberal prices for materials and wages that had been adopted in public relief works was based, at least in part, upon the view that an increase in consumer purchasing power would aid in bringing about a trade recovery.

The body of Daniel Foley, 32 years old, of 56 Sullivan Street, who had been missing for two days, was found last night at the foot of an elevator shaft in an office building at 677 Fifth Avenue, where he had been employed as an elevator operator.

Laurence Schwab, the theatrical producer, is starting a newspaper, The Miami Beach Tribune, according to word received here yesterday. He is associated in the enterprise with O.S. Farmer. Hal W. Lanigan is to be the managing editor.
BOSTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Irvin (Ace) Bailey, injured member of the Toronto Maple Leafs hockey team, cheered his family on Christmas Day with a further improvement in his condition.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 25 -- Larry MacPhail says one reason why he doesn't want to part with Chick Hafey is that Hafey is a better batsman than Chuck Klein, even if Klein did win the National League batting championship this year.

The bill proposing a three-platoon, system for the Fire Department is opposed in a statement issued yesterday by Peter Grimm, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission. Mr. Grimm said that there was reason to question the sincerity of those pushing the bill at the present tme.
The New York Americans soccer team turned back the Brooklyn F. C. in an American League game yesterday at Starlight Park before a crowd of 1,500. The score was 2 -- 1.

Speyer Co., one of the oldest international banking houses in the United States, will admit George N. Lindsay, Henry Herrman and Charles G. Stachelberg as members of the firm on Jan. 1, and Ralph Wolf and Leon H. Kronthal will retire on that date.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Change in legal theories under the New Deal, and recent innovations in the teaching and practice of law will be discussed here in the thirty-first annual convention of the Association of American Law Schools, which opens at the Stevens Hotel Thursday.

MARSHALL, Ark., Dec. 25 -- National guardsmen patrolled this small mountain town today as officials sought to make peace between two families in a feud which broke out afresh Christmas eve with shots menacing lives on Main Street.

The fifty-six hospitals comprising the United Hospital Fund will have deficits for the coming year aggregating $7,000,000, making it imperative for them to obtain increased support if they are to perform their functions properly, Homer Wickenden, general director of the United Hospital Fund, said yesterday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- Gold is not the least of the factors in the problem of developing trade between the United States and Russia, and it is therefore satisfactory to note that Soviet gold production last September, after a steady growth in the preceding months, reached a total 83 per cent higher than for the same month last year.

There is one weapon in the war against entrenched political privilege and in favor of more humane and efficient government which is just as effective today as it was when it was first discovered: the merit system. Do away with the spoils, chiefly to be found nowadays in exempt positions, and you do away with the very food on which the predatory political organization subsists.
DETROIT, Dec. 25 (AP) -- In a wide open, fast game, the Ottawa Senators, with Earl Roche leading the attack, beat the Detroit Red Wings, 6 to 3, in a National League hockey, match tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 -- A fighting Californian, young Frankie Klick, today rose to great boxing heights to gain recognition in Pennsylvania as the world's junior lightweight champion by defeating Kid Chocolate of Cuba in the seventh round of a scheduled fifteen-round Christmas Day encounter.

Berkeley Bell vanquished Dr. Eugene McCauliff to gain the metropolitan indoor tennis title last night at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory. A large gallery saw the Texan launch an effective assault after dropping the first set and triumph, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4.

Prior to the opening of its subscription season tonight, the Metropolitan Opera Company grave yesterday afternoon in its historic theatre a Christmas matinee performance of the fairy opera of Humperdinck, "Hansel und Gretel." If the attendance, in a great majority that of children, was a token of the interest of the rising generation in opera, it could be said that the Metropolitan can count on a very substantial patronage in the years before it.

Ottawa, Dec. 25 (By the Canadian Press) -- Messages from the far Canadian north tonight tell how Christmas Day was observed at these outposts. In cryptic form, they related to eleven white people at Coppermine, within the fringe of the Arctic Circle, a more substantial gathering at Chesterfield Inlet on the northwest coast of Hudson Bay, and three sole white residents of Nottingham Island in Hudson Strait.

Copies of the proposed NRA code covering the realty brokerage business, revised in Washington following preliminary hearings in Washington early this month, have been presented to the National Association of Real Estate Boards and are being distributed throughout the country.

Details of charges of an organized racket among freight loaders on the waterfront piers which have been submitted by trade groups of the port district to the New York Shipping Association were made public yesterday by Louis K. Com-stock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, a participant in the complaint against existing conditions.

All markets in Christendom were closed yesterday for the holiday, and on many of them business had been suspended on Saturday as well. Normal operations will be resumed this morning, except to the extent that the usual Christmas week observances may retard trading activity.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 -- Stars who will roam the gridiron New Year's day in the annual East-West charity football game mixed up lively practice sessions today as part of their Christmas celebration.

EAST PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 25 -- Two women were killed instantly by an automobile here early today as they were crossing the street directly in front of a church where they had attended midnight services.

The sharp spurt in retail sales last week cleaned out store stocks completely and a flood of last-minute purchases came into the local markets. Stores demanded rush deliveries on dresses, particularly evening types. Gift merchandise was reordered freely and manufacturers were pressed to deliver handbags, handkerchiefs, jewelry, kid gloves, hosiery, children's silk dresses and other holiday goods.
LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 25 (AP) -- A plea to all prohibition forces to oppose the organization of a new political party was voiced today by R.P. Hutton, Nebraska Anti-Saloon League superintendent.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 25 -- A supper dance for members of the younger set was held at the Greenwich Country Club tonight at which more than 250 persons were present. Several dinner parties preceded the event.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Conditions have grown increasingly difficult for city schools, it was said today by United States Commissioner of Education Dr. George F. Zook.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Warning was given to the Chicago police today that six desperate men intend to spread death rather than be captured. They are members of the Dillinger gang of escaped Indiana convicts, and the man who told of their plans was one of them until a week ago.

One of the first "Gentleman With a Duster" type of books to deal with the Roosevelt administration will be "The New Dealers," by The Innocent Bystander, which is on the Simon Schuster list for March. Some fifty-odd personalities in the New Deal will be looked over.

The Federal Bar Association announced yesterday, through its president, Henry Ward Beer, that it had appealed to Governor Lehman to send a special message to the next Legislature requesting emergency legislation to clear the congested calendars of the courts.

Two women and the daughter of one of them were burned to death and a man was injured early yesterday when fire swept through a rooming house at 273 West 134th Street. The cause of the fire was not definitely established, but the police believe it began with a cigarette stub carelessly flicked away during a late Christmas party.
MIAMI, Fia., Dec. 25 -- The Miami High football team defeated Central High of Syracuse, N.Y., 18 to 7, to win its third intersectional game of the season before a large holiday crowd today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The birth of the Prince of Peace was celebrated today aboard the slate gray sea guardians of the nation's peace.

Continuing its crusade for a return to the gold standard, the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York made public yesterday a letter written by Lenor F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company, to James Brown, president of the chamber, which predicts that industrial civilization will perish if the capitalist is destroyed.

The fact that the loading "racket" has been stopped, or lessened, at some of the piers may have encouraged merchants to believe that it would be done away with on every pier where freight is put off or on a ship. But that has been an ill-founded hope, judging from the experience of many consignees.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 25 -- A supper dance for members of the younger set was held at the Greenwich Country Club tonight at which more than 250 persons were present. Several dinner parties preceded the event.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Conditions have grown increasingly difficult for city schools, it was said today by United States Commissioner of Education Dr. George F. Zook.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Warning was given to the Chicago police today that six desperate men intend to spread death rather than be captured. They are members of the Dillinger gang of escaped Indiana convicts, and the man who told of their plans was one of them until a week ago.

ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 26 (By Wireless). -- It is said that bad luck always comes in threes. Well, we are held up by ice, having progressed but thirty miles since Dec. 15, and Christmas Day the crank-shaft of the dynamo engine broke, which leaves us without our main source of electric light and heat. I wonder what next.

Second Christmas came yesterday to 1,500 children of the Second Assembly District, the Bronx. They were guests at a party at the Luxor Theatre, 208 East 170th Street, given by the Julius Corn Association, a Democratic organization headed by Julius Corn, an employe of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

MANILA, P.I., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Floods sweeping down the sides of the inactive volcano Bulusan in Sorsogon Province drowned at least nine persons today. A typhoon, tidal wave and torrential rains caused heavy damage in the eastern and southern sections of the Philippine Islands.
One of many debutante parties last night was the supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. H. Smith Richardson at the River Club to introduce their daughter, Miss Grace Stuart Richardson.

A brilliant gathering of society was in evidence last night for the premiere performance of the fiftieth subscription season of the Metropolitan Opera. Months ago it had been feared that there might be no season of Metropolitan Open this year.
Following is the text of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech in Montevideo, Uruguay, as taken down by stenotypists in New York of the National Broadcasting Company:

Intercollegiate hockey will be the feature in Madison Square Garden tonight, when the Dartmouth sextet clashes with the McGill University team, of Montreal. The McGill puck-chasers are regarded as one of the strongest teams to represent the Montreal college in recent years, and already have victories over Harvard and Princeton to their credit this season.

Martin Conboy, President Roosevelt's appointee as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, took the oath of office yesterday in headquarters in the Federal Building which his predecessors have occupied, for the last fifty years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- A plan for licensing stock brokers under the Securities Act, making it effective through Federal control of the mails, has been laid before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, according to Senator Fletcher the chairman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Income taxes totaling $32,674 were assessed against the estate of Thomas Fortune Ryan, former New York financier, in a stipulation judgment filed today by the Board of Tax Appeals.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- New light on the monetary and social phases of the Roosevelt program is expected here tomorrow when the American Economic Association and thirteen allied organizations open their three-day joint convention.

While the snow whirled and the wind whistled around his father's automobile yesterday afternoon an eight-pound boy yelled his protests on his arrival into the cold and stormy world. The automobile was caught in a snow drift outside the Bronx Maternity Hospital, Grand Concourse and 166th Street, and the father had run inside, calling for a stretcher.

New York City firemen who believed they had obtained an eight-hour day through a local bill passed by both branches of the Municipal Assembly will have to struggle for the measure all over again, it was said last night in authoritative quarters.
Several more Neediest Cases were removed from the waiting list yesterday as additional contributions came to the Fund.

LONDON, Dec. 26. -- President Roosevelt's decision on silver may prove to be one of the most far-reaching steps yet taken toward world economic recovery in the opinion of George Nicoll Barnes. one of the British delegates to the Versailles Peace Conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Senator Heed, Republican, of Pennsylvania, declaring today that President Roosevelt had made four "mistakes" in monetary policy, urged the President to take a stand against real currency inflation. Unless Mr. Roosevelt does so, the Senator contended.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 26. -- Evidence is accumulating that despite the assurance of the German Government, German Nazis as well as Swedish Nazis are making determined efforts to win adherents and sympathizers in Sweden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Senator Dill, chairman of the Commerce Committee, expressed doubt today as to Congress's ability at the coming session to enact legislation combining the wire communication systems, as recently recommended by the President's special committee.

NANKING, Dec. 26. -- The headquarters of General Chiang Kaishek in Hangchow telegraphed instructions here today forbidding publication of dispatches from the Fukien area on activities of the Air Force. No reason was assigned for the ban.

Laurence J. Gallagher, a stockholder of the New York Dock Company, Inc., who is suing the past and present officers of the company in behalf of himself and other stockholders for an accounting of alleged losses due to waste, applied in the Supreme Court yesterday to examine David L. Tilly, president, and Clifford E. Hicks, secretary, before trial.

BOSTON, Dec. 26. -- New England was in the grip of one of the worst blizzards in many years today with its coast lashed by a fifty-mile northeast gale. The snow stopped falling in Boston at 10:30 tonight, with fair weather predicted for tomorrow. The temperature tonight was 9 above zero.

The names of two firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange will be changed at the end of the year. Kohler, Sheerin Co. will become Kohler, Sheerin Fish on Jan. 2. Robert S. Potter, general partner in Lapham, Potter Holden, and Bayard Warren, special partner, will retire on Dec. 30, land the firm's name will become Lapham, Holden Reimer.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 26. -- Favorites advanced easily and without exception as the girls' national indoor tennis championship grot under way at the Longwood Cricket Club today.

When the Consumers Guild asked Professor FISHER of Yale to name "ten "persons in the world who understand ' "the real meaning of money," it apparently had in mind the ten righteous men who -- if they existed-would have saved Sodom and Gomorrah from destruction. But Professor FISHER is generous and supplies an ampler margin.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26. -- A.G. Tarn's Pulis finished a length and a half in front of Leonard Wilson's Culloden in the featured Biloxi Purse at Jefferson Park today to win his fifth consecutive race. Plumage was a poor third, four lengths further back.

The Regional Labor Board intervened yesterday to stop the threatened strike of some 30,000 organized waiters in New York City, scheduled for New Year's Eve. The unions preparing the strike hope to enlist the support of an additional 20,000 unorganized waiters.

Travel to national parks has kept up later than usual this year and in larger volume. This may be partly the result of the several hundred Civilian Conservation Corps Camps maintained in and about the parks in the Summer and Fall, many of which are being continued through the Winter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The extent to which the government may help the railroads through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation or other agency to meet securities maturing in 1934 is under consideration by the administration. Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, said today that it looks now as though the government could do only a small part and that the banks would have to carry the larger load.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In answer to the letter of Eleanor Dwight Jones in THE TIMES for Dec. 25, let me say that it is contraception which is immoral and cruel.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 26. -- The closing session of the Seventh Pan-American Conference this afternoon was a dramatic and exciting festival of peace at which the American nation turned over to the League of Nations their one war problem, that in the Gran Chaco.

Samuel Untermyer will go before Supremo Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler tomorrow in an effort to get back the releases on mortgage guarantees given by certificate holders to George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, as rehabilitator of fourteen mortgage guarantee companies defaulting on their issues.

"Dawn to Dawn" is as interesting because of the circumstances of its production as for its definite intrinsic merit. The cinema has never been especially hospitable to the independent artist. "Dawn to Dawn," which is offered by the Little Carnegie Playhouse, was produced by Cameron Macpherson, who also wrote the musical score and collaborated with Josef Berne on the scenario.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Robert H. Wiles 49-year-old unemployed mechanic, was quoted by Sheriff T. Alex Heise as confessing today that he was "hired to kidnap" Herbert H. Harris Jr., 15, and had beaten the boy to death to prevent his escape.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The Federal Reserve Board's weekly condition statement of reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Dec. 20 shows increases for the week of $140,000,000 in United States Government securities, $47,000,000 in other securities and $151,000,000 in government deposits, and decreases of $12,000,000 in loans and $95,000,000 in net demand deposits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The Boston Maine Railroad today notified the ICC that it expects to apply in the near future for a public works loan of $1,100,000 with which to make repairs and improvements to locomotives and freight and passenger cars, station buildings and other structures.

Making his debut in a national Junior indoor tennis championship, Frank Parker of Lawrenceville, eighth ranking player of the United States, scored two victories yesterday as play started at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Further details of the "airflow" models produced for 1934 by the De Soto Motor Corporation, a division of Chrysler Motors, were made public yesterday by Byron C. Foy, president of De Soto. He described the cars as "revolutionary" in design, breaking away from the conventional in several particulars.

Holiday Cut Buyers' Total. Due to the holiday the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a large drop in comparison with the figures for the previous wreck. The total was also slightly under the number listed in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
SAN FRANCISCO. Dec. 26. -- This is a story of Christmas time, of a missing figure of the Christ Child and of a boy and his coaster.

MANILA, Dec. 26. -- Although great indignation has been aroused here by the repeated attacks upon Manuel Quezon, head, of the Philippine Independence Commission, and the legislative majority by Camilo Osias, the Philippine resident commissioner in Washington, the majority of leaders announced tonight they planned no action against the commissioner.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- On the eve of the public hearing scheduled for tomorrow, the committee of seven, created by a caucus of Republican Assemblymen and Assemblymen-elect which met here last week to sift charges launched by W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, to the effect that the Republican Assembly has been dominated by the power interests, challenged Mr. Macy tonight to appear at the hearing and make good his charges.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 26. -- Assets of more than $8,000,000 in the estate of Archibald D. Russell of Princeton were shown here today in an accounting approved by Judge Godfrey W. Schroth in Mercer Orphans Court.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- The session on the Bourse today was extremely quiet and practically without interest. Attendance, owing to the holidays and the fact that both the British and Berlin markets were closed, was only scattering, and so little business was transacted that leading stocks showed only one quotation during the day.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- With their defensemen performing in efficient fashion, the Boston Bruins managed to hold the speedier Toronto Maple Leafs to a 2-2 overtime tie tonight before a crowd of less than 3,000, the smallest National Hockey League gathering in this city in nine years.

Sewing machines ceased humming in the dress factory of Rilander Schwartz, on the nineteenth floor of 589 Eighth Avenue, a little earlier than usual last night. Carbon monoxide gas filled the loft and overcame twelve operators, most of them women; the rest -- about forty -- went to the aid of those stricken.

Banking houses here which marketed German dollar bonds in the last few years cabled yesterday a protest to Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, against the arbitrary reduction in the German interest payment for the next six months of 30 per cent in cash and 70 per cent in scrip compared with the arrangement of 50 percent in cash and 50 per cent in scrip for the six months just completed.
GORMANIA, W.Va., Dec. 26 (AP). derbilt car and it was then that another automobile struck him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- President Roosevelt returned to his desk today to plunge into preparation of the budget for the next fiscal year, the writing of his general message to Congress, the supplementary studies expected to advance the "new deal."

The first Colony dance for this season was held last night In the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. Large Christmas trees and colors appropriate to the holiday season were used in the decorations.

The North German Lloyd Line will transfer its docking operations from the Army Base pier at Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, to Piers 84 and 86, Hudson River, shortly after the New Year, it was disclosed yesterday. The Manhattan piers are occupied by the Hamburg-American Line, which was recently merged with the North German Lloyd at the request of the German Government and will be used jointly with that line.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 26. -- A new stereoscopic device which will show the results of a collision between "an irresistible force and an immovable body" will be put on display at Memorial Hall here at the opening tomorrow of the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 26. -- Quiet, unassuming Cliff Montgomery, Columbia's football captain and quarterback, offered the opinion today that Stanford's stalwarts are not going to be pushing the Lions around promiscuously in that rose-bedecked bowl in the Arroyo Seco New Year's Day.

A clear distinction should be made between the temporary plan for guarantee of bank deposits which goes into effect next week, and the more permanent system which will be set up on July 1, unless Congress meantime modifies existing law. The temporary plan applies to individual deposits only up to $2,500.

Today is the last field day on which the thousands of bird lovers in various sections of this country may collect data for the annual Winter census of the approximate numbers and species of birds to be found in their respective localities.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press). -- The Arsenal has strengthened its hold on first place in the first division of the English Soccer Football League, the only team in the group to come through, the Christmas grind with three victories.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In my opinion, never again will America see abundant prosperity until capital ceases to be crucified on the cross of political persecution.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Major J. Andrew White, founder and former president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, was divorced today by Mrs. Katherine Titus White, former Follies girl, in Superior Court.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was much interested in your editorial on "British Courts and Gold." This stated that the highest British court had reversed the decision of the High Court of Chancery to the effect that interest and principal on an issue of sterling bonds of a Belgian industrial company might be paid in paper pounds in spite of the gold clause contained in the issue.

The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board gave official recognition to the celebration of New Year's Eve with a ruling yesterday that liquor and wine may be sold until 5 o'clock next Monday morning in hotels, restaurants and clubs that have licenses to dispense liquor.

The Newmont Mining Corporation, in conjunction with Bralco, Ltd., has underwritten an issue of 400,000 shares of Bradian Mines, Ltd., a new company, at $1 a share, subject to the approval of stockholders of Bralorne Mines, Ltd., owner of the twenty-six claims that the Bradian company will acquire.

Approval of three large city projects involving a total expense of $92,669,000 was voted yesterday by the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate, with all three slated for final action by the board at Friday's meeting.

The New Jersey Board of Fish and Game Commissioners yesterday issued its annual report, and, while much of the data contained therein covers only the fiscal year which ended before the advent of the recent hunting season, it details many interesting accomplishments.

The Monte Carlo Ballet Russe added a new ballet to its program last night at the St. James Theatre, with the first New York performance of Leonide Massine's "Jeux d'Enfants." It is a gay and merry little piece dealing with the awakening of toys and the efforts of their childish owner to participate in their life.

Mayor-elect F.H. LaGuardia announced last night that he had asked Mayor O'Brien either to reappoint John H. Delaney chairman of the Board of Transportation or not to appoint a successor so that the incoming administration might have the benefit of Mr. Delaney's experience in transit matters.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- Direct conversations between France and Germany were definitely rejected today, it is understood, at a meeting of the Ministers of national defense -- the Ministers of War, Marine and Foreign Affairs -- and Premier Camille Chautemps.

Livingston Lyman Short gave a large dinner with dancing last night in the ballroom of the Park Lane for his debutante niece, Miss Anna Livingston Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Herbert Jones. The debutante, who received with her uncle, wore a gown of white and gold lame, a corsage of gardenias and carried a bouquet of Talisman roses and lilies-of-the-valley.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- Former Premier Edouard Herriot stood by his opposition to the French war debt policy in reviewing the year and advising on future policies in an article published in the Agence Economique et Financiere today. M. Herriot declared France had been short-sighted in becoming isolated over the war debt question and losing both American sympathy and British support by pursuing a course independent from that adopted by Britain.

Columbia University and Yeshiva College carried off the honors on the first day of the annual championship tournament of the Inter-collegiate Chess League, the first round of which was contested at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.
Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler said in a statement yesterday that there were five major causes for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. They were griven as follows:

An overheard conversation between former License Commissioner James F. Geraghty and an agent identified only as "Louie," involving $2,700 allegedly paid by Benjamin Piatoff for a news-stand license at Wall and William Streets, became part of the record yesterday in the inquiry conducted by License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine.

ABOARD THE JACOB RUFPERT, Exploring Off Antarctica, Dec. 26. -- The ninety-five men composing the crew of the flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition celebrated Christmas yesterday in a manner that yielded the full traditional content of the day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Seven changes in the college gridiron rules for 1934 designed to open the game for the benefit of thrill-seeking spectators were suggested by the American Football Coaches Association today, but not one coach was brave enough to predict they ever would become more than suggestions.

Retailers will concentrate on a program for the modification of some approved codes to which they object, in a series of conferences planned by the National Retail Dry Goods Association to take place after Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

With New York, blotted out from above by the snowstorm yesterday, an airplane was reported wandering blindly above the towers of Park Avenue and Harlem's tenements. Although many heard, or thought they heard, an airplane engine, no one reported seeing the plane.
The letter of W. Kingsland Macy chairman of the Republican State Committee, to Harry F. Dunkel chairman of the Assembly Investigating Committee, follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- That part of the Federal plan for the development of the Tennessee Basin whicn calls for the expenditure of $75,000,000 for a 9-foot channel in the Tennessee River and an ultimate expenditure in this river and tributaries of $230,000,000 for navigation facilities was condemned today at the opening session of the Association of American Geographers by A.E. Parkins, head of the geology department of Peabody College in Nashville.

Efforts to speed up completion of its payroll machinery In order to put a stop to the delays suffered by some groups of workers in receiving their pay checks were being made yesterday by the Civil Works Administration.

The Board of Aldermen, at its final meeting of the year, voted yesterday the authorization of $450,000 in special revenue bonds to make up a deficit in the Dec. 31 payrolls of the Education Department.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 26. -- John D. Mikel's 5-year-old Gaillardia just lasted to score a neck victory over C. Morris's Uncommon Gold In the mile of the Corpus Christi Claiming Purse which featured today's post-holiday program at Epson Downs.

The United States Marine Corps should always be fit and ready for duty. It would have been reduced by about 1,700 men during the last month of President HOOVER'S Administration if the House Committee on Naval Affairs had not adopted a subcommittee report setting forth that the Marine Corps "has already been impaired by the reduction to its present strength" (15,843).
To the Editor of The New York Times: The letters of G.R. Glendinning and others anent home loan bonds which have recently appeared in THE TIMES are timely and interesting.

Alderman Timothy J. Sullivan of the Eighteenth Assembly District in Manhattan is slated for selection as Vice Chairman of the Board of Aldermen at a caucus of the Democratic members to be held this afternoon in the City Hall.
PARIS, Dec. 26. -- Former Mayor James J. Walker would like to be back in New York politics, but as yet has no definite plans for returning.

The National City Bank announced yesterday the resignations of three important directors in conformity with the provisions of the Banking Act of 1933, which bars from the boards of national banks all persons dealing in securities.

Coming on the heels of the Christmas festivities, yesterday's heavy snowstorm seemed also to blanket the realty market. Little activity in the metropolitan area was reported outside of the auction rooms.

Dolphins, sacred fish consecrate to Apollo and friendly to man, have an ancient connection with poetry. The Sirens, sometimes represented in Greek art as birds, were all too suasive singers. Reptiles have hitherto had no voice in the choir. But in The Virginia Quarterly Review Mr. ARCHIBALD RUTLEDGE, himself a distinguished poet, lays an unexpected laurel on the alligator, whom he has studied since boyhood, hunted, raised in numbers on his plantation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- It is easier to drive from the back seat, and hind-sight is better than foresight. These two trite apothegms may be borne in mind from now on, for members of Congress are beginning to assemble in Washington and the critical mood has arrived for the administration.

Whateyer may be President HOPKINS'S report about educational or other conditions within his purview in Puerto Rico, it will certainly prove to have been searching and its recommendations to be sound. Puerto Rico is only one-third the size of the State in which the college of DANIEL WEBSTER still stands (no longer "little"), but it has a population three times as great.

Mrs. Robert Clifford Black gave a large dinner dance last night in the ballroom of the Pierre for her debutante daughter, Miss Deborah Black. The guests later attended the supper dance for Miss Deborah Locke at the Waldorf-Astoria. Among them were:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Evidence concerning an alleged "whisky trust" is being investigated by attaches of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee. A public inquiry will be ordered early in the New Year if the preliminary investigation substantiates the charges.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- Stories of violence and fear accompanying the taxicab strike were told today before the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, which has been requested by City Controller Wilson to revoke the operating certificates of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit cab companies.

Grover A. Whalen, local NRA Administrator, left here for Washington last night to confer with General Hush S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, on the question of continuing the life of the NRA organization in New York City for four months.
The report of the Canadian Bank of Commerce for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 fallows total resources of $574,196,003, comparing with $600,315,126 at the end of the preceding year.

Opening quotations on most local commodity markets were lower yesterday. After that, however, prices held steady and closed irregular. Trading was quiet except in the silver futures market, which continued fairly active. Most cash prices were lower.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Chicago once again has its own opera company and "Tosca" was the work wherein the new organization introduced itself to the public tonight. It made itself known in no uncertain terms. The new season went off with a bang.

LONDON, Dec. 26. -- A chorus of praise for the German Supreme Court arises tonight from the British newspapers, which have their first opportunity after the four-day holiday to comment on the Reich-stag fire verdict.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26. -- Ed Howe, the "Sage of Potato Hill," has ended publication of that four-page receptacle of his thoughts in retirement, E.W. Howe's Monthly Magazine, because "I'm not satisfied with what I write. I'm capable of doing better."

So much has been generally expected of Katharine Hepburn in "The Lake" that this morning's tidings are likely to sound jaundiced. For the drama by Dorothy Massingham and Murray MacDonald, which Jed Harris staged at the Martin Beck last evening, has considerable human frailty after all.

Miss Deborah Locke was presented to society last night at a supper dance given by her father, Campbell Locke, in a moonlight setting in the Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. Silvered cedar trees ablaze with blue lights were arranged around the room, giving the effect of moonlight, and the windows were hung with blue silks festooned with silvered smilax.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Southern Ice Company has been called for Jan. 26 to act on a plan for readjustment of the capital structure dated Dec. 15, formulated by holders of a substantial amount of $692,600 first mortgage twenty-year sinking fund Series A 8 per cent bonds of the Carolina Public Service Company, an asaumed obligation of Southern Ice.

New York's million dollar opera subscription opened last night with an American composer's admired opera, sung in distinguished English text by at least three international stars, who, through their public appeals spread country-wide on the upper air, had "saved the Metropolitan" from the big, bad wolf of depression not so long ago.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Dr. Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago chooses a deistic view of the intelligence and order of the world.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- Stanley W. Pearson Jr., son of the veteran Philadelphia tennis star and former national squash champion, advanced to the quarter-final round of the Philadelphia and district junior squash racquets championship tournament by winning two matches as the event opened today at the Merion Cricket Club.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 26. -- Instead of closing with the customary solemn ceremony of signing the treaties, conventions, declarations and resolutions agreed upon during its three weeks' deliberations, the seventh Pan-American Conference broke up in a grand scramble to catch tonight's river boat for Buenos Aires.

President Roosevelt has oust signed a contract for the publication of a new book, "On Our Way: the First Year," which John Day will publish early in March. The publishers describe the book as "an expansion of his theories of government as publicly expressed during his first year in office," which seems to mean that the President's speeches will make up the bulk of the book.

LONDON, Dec. 36. -- The British public will have its first opportunity tomorrow to see the Codex Sinaiticus, the Fourth Century biblical manuscript that the government considered to be worth u50,000 of the taxpayers' money.

ARCHER BUTLER HULBERT was preeminently the historian of the paths of adventure and commerce in America -- the chronicler of trail, road and waterway. In his many-volumed story of the building of the Republic every problem was, in the last analysis, as he saw it, one of transportation.

BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Dec. 27. -- Jimmy Wedell, the speed filer rushing Baby Sue Trammell of Houston here for an emergency brain operation, roared out of the night at 1:57 o'clock this morning and made a hazardous landing on snow-encrusted Logan Field.

OTTAWA, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press). -- For the eighth consecutive month a gain was shown in employment on Dec. 1, according to a statement issued today by H.H. Stevens, Minister of Trade and Commerce. The number of employed at the beginning of the month was 850,486, compared with 845,793 on Nov. 1, an increase of 4,693.
The new America's Cup defense yacht became a material fact yesterday instead of just an idea. Work was started on the big racer at the Herreshoff yard in Bristol, R.I., on Narragansett Bay.

ROME, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Italy's opera season opened brilliantly in many cities tonight, playing to packed houses, in some cases attended by royalty. This day, the Feast of Santo Stefano, has been the first night of opera for many generations.

SOUTH HAVEN, Mich., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Whipped into fury by the worst storm in years, the waters of Eastern Lake Michigan took eight lives today as two fishing tugs foundered, carrying their crews to death within sight of the shore and safety.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26. -- Weary from six days spent in circling monotonously through the skies, Frances Marsalis and Helen Richey were within striking distance tonight of a new women's refueling endurance flight record.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- Formation of a commission for the study of the educational problems in penal institutions for the aid of youth was announced by Governor Lehman today. For more than a year the Department of Correction has been at work on a program of education for inmates of State institutions.

Funeral services for Archbishop Leon Tourian, who was assassinated on Sunday in the Holy Cross Armenian Church on Washington Heights, will be held in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, it was announced yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26. -- Captain the Right Hon. Frederick E. Guest and Mrs. Guest are expected to reach Villa Artemis on Thursday from New York, joining her nephew, Townsend Martin, and his nephew, John Guest.

It is significant of changes taking place on the American musical horizon and the gradual emergence of a native school of composition that Mr. Gatti-Casazza opened the Metropolitan Opera season of 1933-34 last night in the Metropolitan Opera House with Deems Taylor's "Peter Ibbetson."
Mr. and Mrs. Dean C. Osborne gave a dinner last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for their niece, Miss Elizabeth Fawcett. The other guests were:

All domestic markets were under some restraint yesterday after the extended holiday. Price movements were irregular except where there were no quotable changes at all. Many stocks and bonds did not deviate from the final figures of Saturday, and much the same indecision was shown in the restricted rotation of the more active contracts on the commodity markets.

IT was apparent that the snow had done something to the visitor. Obviously he was not seeing steel and concrete buildings through the haze of wet air and it was equally obvious that he had come through something besides the slush of city streets. His conversation bore that out. He was seeing the pine rim of mountain tops and beyond that the pure white of snow left alone except for the tracks of wild things.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt categorically denied today having taken any part either for or against the equal nationality rights treaty at the Montevideo conference, or in the reversal of the instructions from Washington as a result of which the United States delegation joined with the other countries in signing the convention.

His associates in the financial world, his relatives and other intimate friends gathered at the home of Henry Seligman, 30 West Fifty-sixth Street, for the funeral yesterday morning. The service was conducted by the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, rabbi of the Free Synagogue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Floyd R. Eastwood, New York University instructor, who has conducted three annual surveys of football deaths and accidents, reported today to the American Football Coaches Association that more than one-quarter of the injuries to college players during 1933 might have been avoided by "adequate leadership."

W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, will not appear today at Albany to submit to a committee of Republican Assemblymen proof of his charges that power interests through former Speaker H. Edmund Machold and Assembly Clerk Fred W. Hammond have exercised undue influence on the Republican majority in the Assembly, particularly in regard to action on proposed public utility legislation.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 26. -- Announcement has just been made of the election on Dec. 20 of Porter H. Adams, a leading aeronautical expert and a navy aviator in the World War, as president of Norwich University. He is 38 years old.
The snow caused numerous accidents in and around New York yesterday. Few of them were serious, and only one indirect fatality was reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a children's party this afternoon for their grandchildren. "Grown-ups" were excluded as the White House was taken over for several hours by the young visitors. The party began in the East Room and terminated in a grand romp up and down the wide corridor and around the Christmas tree on the second floor.

Recent Perpetual Motion. Two women in an airplane over Miami had completed on Christmas night the fifth day of a refueling flight. They may at this moment be within striking distance of the endurance record for women aviators.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Donald Carr have left Sunnyridge, their country place in Mount Kisco, and are at 60 East Sixty-seventh Street.
A story of being hanged by a Louisiana mob and of surviving the ordeal was told here yesterday by Norman Thibodeaux, 19-year-old Negro of New Orleans.

It was a delightful and appropriate gesture to bring forward at this time the drawings made by Fragonard for Ariosto's "Orlando Furioso," which are now being exhibited at the galleries of the Rosenbach Company, 15 East Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The administration's gold program brought the announcement of no new step today and the RFC price was quoted at $34.06 for the seventh successive business day. Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, said domestic purchases now total 525,000 ounces at a cost of $17,594,000.

PASADENA, Cal., Dec. 26. -- While his coaching rival, Lou Little, was trying to add weight to his Columbia Lions at Tucson, Claude (Tiny) Thornhill spent today in an effort to scale down the poundage of his Stanford Indians.

Prohibiting short selling and limiting pool operations entirely to the orderly marketing of new securities by their underwriting groups were among regulations of trading on the various security exchanges of the country proposed yesterday by E.W. Marland, a Representative in Congress from Oklahoma and founder and former president of the Marland Oil Company, now the Continental Oil Company.
PARIS, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The death list in the Lagny railroad catastrophe reached 200 today as all but two bodies were identified. One child on the ill-fated Nancy Express could not be found.

MONTREAL, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Earl Roche, continuing his excellent sharp shooting from the port side of the Ottawa Senators' second forward line, scored three points at Detroit last night to hold a good margin at the top of the National Hockey League scoring lists.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Prices of grains on the Board of Trade held within narrow limits today. A holiday dullness prevailed. Wheat moved up fractionally early on buying attributed to removal of hedges by mills, presumably representing flour sales, but the upturn was lost and closing prices were 1/3 cent net higher to 1/3 lower.
Howling winds, subzero cold and blizzards that buried half the nation in snowdrifts swept across the country yesterday and increased the holiday death toll to more than 200.
Police Commissioner Bolan announced yesterday that Chief Inspector John O'Brien would retire from the force next Sunday at midnight after forty-one years of service.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26. -- Alexander Troyanovsky, Soviet Russia's first Ambassador to the United States, left Moscow tonight in a race against time in order to sail to America on the same boat as William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to Russia.

Allegheny County, Pa. Allegheny County, Pa., has set 11 A. M., Jan. 9, as the time for opening bids on a new issue of $6,806,000 of 4 per cent bonds. The issue will consist of $1,206,000 of road bonds, due in from one to thirty years; $600,000 park bonds, due in from one to thirty years, and $5,000,000 of uncollected tax bonds due in ten years, callable on and after Nov. 1, 1933.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The Recovery Administration tonight announced Presidential approval of seven new codes covering electrotyping, photoengraving, medium and low priced jewelry, watch case manufacturing, silverware, the commercial refrigerator industry and the paper distributing trade.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,289,900 barrels, compared with 2,352,950 barrels in the preceding week, a decrease of 63,050 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Decreases of 44,140 barrels in Oklahoma and 19,500 in California were the most important changes.

An average of 10 per cent of the deposits of the leading banks in this city will be covered by the temporary guarantee plan of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, a survey of twelve institutions indicated yesterday.

Paul Dean of the Columbus Club, who is to report to the Cardinals next Spring, was the most effective pitcher in the American Association, according to the official figures released for publication through The Associated Press. Dean, appearing in forty-three games.

BARCELONA, Dec. 26. -- A queue more than a mile long stretched tonight before the Gothic palace of the Catalan Generalidad in St. George's Hall, where the body of Francesc Macia lay in state before its burial tomorrow with the military honors due to the general's active service.
The Chicago Black Hawks turned back the New York Americans in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 26. -- The Rational amateur golf champion, George T. Dunlap Jr. of New York, won the qualifying medal in the Pinehurst midwinter tournament today when he carded a 37, 35 -- 72, one over par.

Excitement and confusion reigned yesterday afternoon in front of the Hotel Madison, 15 East Fifty-eighth Street, as the packing snow silenced the usual hubbub of traffic. Horns screeched, passengers scowled from taxicab windows and drivers muttered.
With the Liverpool Cotton Exchange still closed, trading on the Cotton Exchangre here was of a holiday character yesterday and prices closed with losses of 5 to 12 points.

United States Government long-term issues led the general bond market higher on the Stock Exchange yesterday in fairly active trading. The government issues climbed 1-32 to 19-32 point with the exception of the Treasury 3 3/8s, due in 1943 and callable in 1941, which sold off 1-32.

Speculators In the various markets may have been so distracted yesterday by holiday observances that they gave little attention to trading operations on the various Exchanges. Certainly there was no stimulus for market operators. Business was smaller than it ordinarily is, even for the first day after Christmas.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 26. -- Foochow, the capital of the rebel Fukien Government, was subjected to bombing on Saturday, Sunday, Monday, and today according to detailed circumstantial reports from Japanese and Chinese sources.

In a supplementary notice filed with the New York Stock Exchange, the Coca-Cola Company has announced a change in its setup whereby it will cease to be an operating company and will become a holding company. The changes will become effective on or before Jan. 1, having been approved by the majority of the outstanding stock.

The threatened strike of waiters in New York City on New Year's Eve, as it might have affected leading hotels and restaurants, was believed to have been averted last night following an agreement reached between representatives of the Hotel Association of New York and the Federation of Hotel and Restaurant Guilds, commonly known as the Hotel Guild.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- At a four-hour Ministerial council this afternoon at which President Lebrun presided the French Government approved the main lines of the memorandum which is being sent to Ambassador Francois-Poncet in Berlin for transmission to Chancellor Hitler.

A motion on behalf of the city asking the Public Service Commission to temporarily fix the rates of the Bronx Gas and Electric Company at $1.15 per thousand cubic feet of gas, instead of its present rate of $1.45, was presented at yesterday's session of the hearings into the company's rates.

Few will deny that a judicial determination of the issue between the depositors of the Harriman Bank and the Clearing House should be had as soon as possible. This is the object of the suit in equity filed yesterday in the name of the Controller of the Currency. In the summons and complaint the tangled history of the affair is recited.

MONTREAL, Dec. 27 (Canadian Press) -- Liquid assets of $362,471,645, or 55.76 per cent of liabilities to the public, are shown in the annual statement of the Royal Bank of Canada, issued today. The fiscal year ended on Nov. 30.

The Oratorio Society of New York, celebrating this year the sixtieth anniversary of its founding, gave its 110th performance of Handel's "Messiah" last night at Carnegie Hall. Albert Stoessel conducted. Lillian Clark, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company; Sonia Essin, contralto; the veteran Dan Beddoe, tenor, and Julius Huehn, bass-baritone, were the soloists.

Transferring Conrad Nagel to the stage involves a cozy little romance by Lynn Starling, "The First Apple," which ripened on the bought of the Booth last evening. Mr. Nagel behaves himself like a gentleman within the segregated district of the legitimate theatre, and "The First Apple" is an unobjectionable bit of romantic and comic twittering.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Government operation and control of the meat-packing industry, accompanied by the fixing of prices for meat products to both producers and consumers, was proposed today by Henry T. Rainey, Speaker of the House of Representatives.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- France is willing to destroy half her bombing planes immediately, if other nations do likewise, as a sign of her will to international peace, it was learned on high authority tonight. A proposal along this line is to be made at Geneva.

An intensive campaign to rid the city of professional panhandlers and to direct deserving mendicants into channels where they may obtain jobs, food, clothing or medical attention will be begun on Jan. 1. Under the sponsorship of the Welfare Council, the plan has the support of the incoming Police Commissioner, the new Public Welfare Commissioner, the magistrates' courts, the Civil Works Administration and the city's private welfare agencies.
