PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- Hiram G. Hallinger of Penn Charter School and Stanley W. Pearson Jr. of Springfield High today reached the final round in the Philadelphia junior squash racquets championship by winning their quarter and semi-final round matches at the Merion Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Exposition of the administration's monetary policy by the President is awaited with intense interest in official and Congressional circles. Continuation of the RFC price for newly mined domestic gold at $34.06 an ounce is interpreted as forecasting that a broader program will be substituted for the efforts which have been made up to this tune to stimulate commodity prices.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- Vincent Richards of New York appeared in rare stroke as he won his opening match from Walter Kinsella, veteran New Yorker, in the national indoor professional tennis championship tournament at the Penn. A.C., this evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Roosevelt spent two hours today studying a detailed plan for long-term job insurance, combined with an emergency credit issue "to expand purchasing power immediately."

Sir Henry Wellcome, English chemist and scientist, is due today from London on the White Star liner Majestic. Others on the ship include Princess Margaret Boncompagni, Vicomtesse Leon de Janze, Mr. and Mrs. Rae Robertson, Countess Piercy Dimignamo, Marchese I.M. Origo and John Mackman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A seasonal decline of about 5 per cent cut the value of November export to $784,000,000, or nearly $10,000,000 less than for October, while imports declined nearly $23,000,000 to a value of $128,000,000, the Commerce Department reported today.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- American-owned jumpers today triumphed at two English race meetings. George H. (Pete) Bostwick's Chenango won a handicap hurdle race at Wolverhampton and J.H. (Jock) Whitney's Thomond II led a crack field of steeplechasers at Kempton Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Trunk line railroads serving the Port of New York were ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to end promptly discriminatory practices resulting from their warehousing and storage operations for large shippers at less than compensatory rates.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 27 -- Miss Sylvia Hatch of Winchester, Mass., fourth seeded player, advanced to the semi-finals in both singles and doubles as play in the girls' national indoor tennis championships continued today at the Longwood Cricket Club.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 27 -- The Chaco peace negotiations were at a standstill today as the League of Nations commission awaited the acceptance by Bolivia and Paraguay of its telegraphic request that their armistice be extended to midnight Jan. 14.

City detectives asked the police of neighboring States yesterday to help them dig into the past of James Lewis Williams, an unemployed baker's helper, whom they arrested Tuesday night in the hallway of his home at 409 Fifth Street on charges of violation of the Sullivan Law.

It cannot be said that the death of Colonel MACIA will bring on a crisis in the relations between Catalonia and the Spanish Republic. They have been in continued crisis ever since the revolution of April, 1931. Directly after that there was set up a so-called Catalan Republic in Barcelona.

Captain Alfred B. Devlin, oldest ferryboat master employed in the Port of New York by the Pennsylvania Railroad, died on Tuesday at the Medical Centre, Jersey City, from injuries suffered when an automobile ran him down on Christmas Eve while he was on his way to midnight mass.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 27 -- New Hampshire's forty mutual savings banks and ten guaranty savings banks declined today to participate in the Federal Government's deposit insurance program and an- nounced the organization of the New Hampshire Savings Banks Association and the creation of a protective plan of their own.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 27 -- George T. Dunlap Jr., national amateur golf champion, today moved a step nearer his eighth midwinter golf tournament victory in nine years when he subdued F. C. Robertson of Manchester, Vt., by 5 and 4.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Roosevelt was cheered today when Grover Whalen, head of New York City NRA activities, brought to him an optimistic picture of changed conditions in the metropolis under the recovery program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- I think it very certain that the coming session of Congress will be a harmonious one. There will doubtless be earnest debate of such problems as taxation, appropriations, farm relief, the codes and currency.

Wnat would normally constitute a two days' business in the listed bond market was done in a single session yesterday, when total transactions reached $21,368,000. This was the largest turnover for a single day since July 21, when the figure was $23,106,500.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- Joseph Stalin, general secretary of the Communist party, received me at 7 P.M. on Christmas Day in his Kremlin office for an hour's interview. I began by asking him, Would Joseph Stalin give to THE NEW YORK TIMES a message to transmit to the American people?

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The London Times in an editorial tonight, which both praises and condemns President Roosevelt's policies, says there is no sign that he is in the least perturbed at the prospect of a great struggle of competing interests and competing ideals in Congress, in which he must play a decisive part.

The Federal Government filed an equity suit here yesterday against all twenty banks of the New York Clearing House Association and the bankers who served as the clearing house committee during the last two years, to compel them to pay the depositors of the bankrupt Harriman National Bank and Trust Company in full.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 27 -- Illinois today abolished real estate and personal property taxes so far as State assessments are concerned. It was the first complete substitution of a sales tax for property taxes in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained fifty-six guests at dinner tonight, and a group numbering several hundred at a musicale given afterward in the East Room by the Agruilar lute quartet. The program of entertainment also included a musical comedy dance, "Tea for Two," and other dances in which "modern moods" were interpreted by Mayris Chaney and Edward Fox.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- The problem of remodeling the system of secondary education to fit it for greater usefulness was advanced today as delegates to five educational conventions began to arrive for the opening sessions.

Eight directors have resigned from the board of directors of the Phoenix Securities Corporation in the company's broadest shake-up in personnel since it was divorced from the firm of Prince Whitely in 1931. The move is seen as reflecting the influence of Wallace Groves, who in recent months has acquired two large blocks of stock and has become the largest stockholder.
The fund for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases moved ahead to $210,867.51 yesterday as 301 contributions added $4,974.55 to it.
TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 27 -- Columbia's football team cleared the last high hurdle today in its preparations for the Rose Bowl game with Stanford, driving vigorously through a final hard workout.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today met the Philippine Independence Mission sent here to object to the Hawes-Cutting Independence Bill passed by Congress, and after an informal luncheon conversation told the dele- gates to submit a concrete independence proposal in writing.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull is definitely encouraged by the prospects of economic consolidation of the Latin-American countries and the United States into a loosely knit answer to the Ottawa agreements of the British Empire, he indicated today.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 27 -- Shaking off two hazards which endangered their flight in the final stages, Helen Richey and Frances Marsalis tonight were within less than one full day of their goal, a new woman's refueling endurance record.

Bishop Manning announced yesterday that contracts had been let for new work on the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to cost $167,000. Work for 135 men for several months will be provided. At the same time the Bishop replied to those who criticized the building of such a structure during hard times by pointing out that very little of the money spent was for materials, but almost all for the actual design and labor.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Ann Ross of 51 Carmine Street, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ross of Boston, to Tracy H. Lewis of this city, son of the late William E. Lewis, one-time publisher of The New York Morning Telegraph.

New York and the nation shivered yesterday as the frigid weather which has glazed a large part of the continent with ice and snow swept into the South and brought death and distress to many parts of the country.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Wrapped in ordinary brown paper and tied with a piece of string the world's most valuable manuscript, the Codex Sinaiticus, fourth-century Bible, was handed over today to the British Museum on behalf of the nation, which is buying it from Russia for L100,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The complicated problem of the contract for the New York City postoffice annex at the Pennsylvania Railroad station moved into a new phase today when bids were received by the Treasury for the third time.

BERLIN, Dec. 27 -- General Kurt von Hammerstein-Equord resigned today as chief of the German army command, a post he had occupied since October, 1930. His resignation, which came as a complete surprise, was announced in a brief communique stating that "in complete agreement with the Reich government" he had decided to quit his post Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A large audience headed by the wife and mother of President Roosevelt, and a diplomatic contingent, including the Ambassadors of Brazil, Argentina, Spain and France, attended Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's musicale this morning.

Nigal Odabashian, cutler, of 135 East Twenty-seventh Street, was held in $10,000 bail by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions yesterday as a material witness in the assassination of Archbishop Levon Tourian, Armenian prelate. Odabashian is a member of Tashnagtzagantz, the political group within the church which opposed the Archbishop's policies.

Music of the Orient, performed on Occidental instruments by the New Symphony Orchestra of Japan on the occasion of a special broadcast for American listeners in celebration of the birth of the heir to the Japanese throne, was heard throughout the United States yesterday with unusual clarity.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 -- Eastern football stars faced organized opposition today in a lively scrimmage preparatory to the annual charity game against the West on New Year's Day.

Much to the surprise of the commission houses, trading on the Stock Exchange assumed large proportions yesterday. Transactions exceeded 3,000,000 shares, making the heaviest day's business since Sept. 22. Measured by the individual issues involved, the market was the broadest since July 21.

An unexplained transaction in earmarked gold which may reflect the repatriation of some gold bought abroad recently by the RFC was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. A reduction of $3,201,900 in the amount of gold held under earmark for foreign account was announced, but the bank did not follow its standardized form of giving out the reduction in earmarking as a "net gain" to the monetary gold stocks.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agar Salvage will give a dinner with dancing tonight in the salon of the St. Regis Seaglade for their debutante daughter, Miss Margaret Salvage.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 27 -- Complimenting Miss Nancy Rogers and her brother, Frederick Van Dusen Rogers, who are visiting their grandmother, Mrs. Frederick C. Van Dusen of Clark Avenue, and Theodore Noll, who is the holiday guest of his mother, Mrs. William Guy Noll, at the home of Bishop and Mrs. Nathaniel Seymour Thomas, Mr. and Mrs. George C. Van Dusen entertained today with a tea dance at Patio Margery.

NOT so long ago, when it was more of the fashion than it is at present to view with alarm the sport of intercollegiate football, there was a perennial campaign "to give the game back to the boys." Just how this was to be accomplished never was made clear. One of the suggestions for rule changes now made by the football coaches in assemblage at Chicago opens some delightful possibilities.
PARIS, Dec. 27 -- France and Britain announced today agreement on their major trade differences, while negotiations seemed to be progressing favorably between France and many other countries.

HAVANA, Dec. 27 -- "We are not going to pay those loans [from the Chase National Bank] because they were illegal loans contracted by Machado's illegal Congress," said Secretary of the Treasury Despaigne today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Following hard upon the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment comes evidence that American public opinion must again be quickly aroused to prevent the possibility of another and equally serious attack upon the fundamental principles of our government and social order made by those well-meaning persons who do not stop to think.

Various midtown store and loft rentals were among the business leases reported yesterday, some of the changes in location being advisable, it was stated, because of increasing requirements of business. The tenant list included the Famous Infants Knitwear Company, which took the second floor, 22,500 square feet, in 16-20 West Twentieth Street.

The resignation of Deputy Chief Inspector John J. Hennessy, in command of the uniformed force in the Bronx, and the transfers of an acting lieutenant and seven detectives, mostly from posts at Manhattan police headquarters, were announced yesterday.

Legislation designed to bring title and mortgage companies within the scope of the Federal bankruptcy statutes will be introduced in Congress when it convenes next week, Representative Emanuel Celler announced yesterday.

A fee of $14,000 asked by Basil O'Connor, a former law partner of President Roosevelt, for services of less than a month as special master in the I.R.T. receivership case, has been disallowed by Federal Judge Julian W. Mack, it was disclosed yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 27 -- Discovery of the existence in the skin of a power of immunity ten times greater than that found in the blood stream was reported here today before the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 27 -- Miss Julia Converse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan D. Converse of Greenwich, gave a buffet supper this evening for Miss Kate Shepard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otis Norton Shepard of Rye, N.Y., and New York City, and Miss Barbara Stevens, daughter of S.E. Stevens of New Canaan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Cut-throat competition by the taxicab industry is ruining the business of the street railways, NRA officials were told today by transit line officers who urged a code for taxicabs at once. Their demands were backed by a resolution adopted by the code authority for the Transit Industry complaining of "most unfair" taxicab competition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Pleased at the November strength of America's export trade, officials tonight interpreted it as the partial result of depreciation of the dollar abroad coincident with the Roosevelt gold-buying program.

Recovery was the rule yesterday on all the security and commodity Exchanges and the volume of business was much above the recent daily average. The dollar advanced widely in the international market, a circumstance with which the speculative elements in the domestic markets again did not appear to be greatly concerned.

Mayor O'Brien yesterday appointed John H. Delaney of Brooklyn as member and chairman of the Board of Transportation to serve until June 30, 1934, filling the vacancy created when Mr. Delaney retired from the same office last Thursday.

After opening slightly lower, most commodities traded on local futures exchanges rallied and closed with good gains for the day, following the general trend in outside markets. Trading volumes improved. Cash prices also advanced.
A dinner dance was given last night in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton by Mrs. Ernest Valentine Hubbard to mark the debut of her daughter, Miss Emma Berry Hubbard.

To the accomplished and athletic students of the women's colleges of today, roaming 'mid pleasures and palaces, a glimpse of their predecessors of almost a century ago may be instructive, not for reproof and admonition, but as evidence of their own better fortune.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Optional plans for expansion of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, as well as for its continuance beyond Jan. 22, are being prepared by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the corporation, for submission to President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A Federal budget for 1934-35 which would provide an $800,000,000 surplus on the government's general operating costs and supply possibly $1,500,000,000 for emergency outlays was discussed today on Capitol Hill.

The speech of President Roosevelt is an example of the best "American English" spoken in this country, in the opinion of educators attending the eighteenth annual convention of the National Association of Teachers of Speech, which opened yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, Exploring Off Antarctica, Dec. 27 -- The flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition tonight was clawing her way into the eye of a northwest gale, struggling to protect both her own skin and the big twin-engined plane cradled on a high timbered tier on the afterwell deck.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- University, college and high school football coaches are going to fight back the tide of "unfair" criticism that annually washes scores of them out of their jobs.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The stock markets reopened cheerfully today after the four-day holiday and buying orders raised prices to a small extent. There was some investment buying of British funds on the reports of good revenue returns. German bonds strengthened in the foreigrn market.

The furtherance of the Christmas principle of "peace on earth, good-will among men" requires a spirit of kindness and fairness in judgment, but it requires also courage to speak out against injustice and against any manifestation of racial or religious persecution, the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, declared last night.
U.S. Department or Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Insisting that he did not want "the conditions of the old days to be renewed, where workers had to go into a corner saloon and buy a round of drinks before their checks would be cashed," Mayor-elect LaGuardia wrote a letter yesterday to George W. Davidson, president of the New York Clearing House Association, requesting that banks doing business with the city make arrangements for the cashing of Civil Works Administration pay checks.
BERLIN, Dec. 27 -- The German position on disarmament was restated in a retrospective summing up by Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, today in an interview for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

HAVANA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Cuban Government decided today not to pay more than $2,000,000 on certificates due Monday on a $20,000,000 bond issue originally sponsored by the Chase National Bank of New York.

Good Stork Tradition. An airplane flew fast enough through the snowstorm to bring a sick child from Houston, Texas, to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore in time. A local automobile did not go fast enough through the snow to bring a New Rochelle woman in time to a New York City maternity hospital.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Under the guidance of Wayne Wright, the country's second ranking jockey, J.P. Ebelhardt's Gift of Roses today outstepped six other sprinters to win the Amarillo Badgers Handicap at Epsom Downs.

Acting on the recommendation of Mayor-elect LaGuardia that the Department of Docks investigate the alleged racket of freight loaders on the waterfront piers, Commissioner John McKenzie asked yesterday the various trade organizations in the port district which have complained about the situation to submit all available evidence.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- H. Edmund Machold today challenged W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, to submit to the District Attorney of Albany County his charges that Mr. Machold had exercised improper influence on Republican Assemblymen in regard to water power and public utility legislation.

Mayor-elect LaGuardia announced yesterday the appointment of Maurice P. Davidson as Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, Byron R. Newton as member of the Board of Taxes and Assessments, and David Marcus as First Deputy Commissioner of Correction.

Dr. and Mrs. C. Jonathan Slocum of Beacon, N.Y., gave a tea dance yesterday for their debutante daughter, Miss Jessica Slocum, at the Park Lane. Baskets of heather, Southern smilax, woodwardia ferns and Spring flowers decorated the ballroom, and Mrs. Slocum and her daughter received in a bower of palms, ferns and heather.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The British and French Governments have declared what is virtually an armistice in the commercial conflict which, for some months, has raged around the imposition by the French of an exchange surtax and other charges on British goods imported into France.

A meeting of all foreign short-term creditors of Germany under the standstill agreement has been called in Berlin for Feb. 5 to prepare an agreement to succeed the present one, which will expire on Feb. 28, it was announced here yesterday by F. Abbot Goodhue, president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- There was no material pressure today on the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and with a broadening in speculative interest and a change in sentiment, prices advanced about 3 cent a bushel after a small early dip and closed within a fraction of the top at net gains of 2 1/4 to 2 3/8 cents.

John. W. Dickinson, Scarsdale banker and philanthropist, who died Sept. 24, 1932. left an estate valued yesterday at $282,870 gross and $175,459 net. He left specific public bequests aggregating $40,000 and divided the residuary estate between the village of Scarsdale and the Scarsdale Congregational Church.

PARIS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The friendship of a 23-year-old French teacher, Madeleine Mermet, and Mrs. Robert Gordon Switz of New York, both of whom are accused by police of being members of an international spy ring, was investigated today.

With the addition of eight operas to the Metropolitan's active repertoire next week, the total number of works presented in the first two weeks of the season will be fifteen. Among the important events of the week will be the return to the company of Claudia Muzio, soprano, after an absence of several years, and the season's first "Don Giovanni," "Emperor Jones," "Tristan und Isolde" and "Simone Boccanegra."

Miss Jane Harrison Holmes was introduced to society last night by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Edwin Holmes, at a dinner dance in the roof garden of the St. Regis. Guests were debutantes of this season and last and young college men.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Anthony Armstrong, whose "Ten Minute Alibi" will reach its four-hundredth performance at the Haymarket on Saturday and has been produced in many countries, has collaborated with Harold Simpson in a new thriller, "Without Witness," which opened here at the Embassy Theatre in Hampstead tonight.

Plans for establishing four fellowships of $2,500 each for German Jewish scholars of distinction was revealed yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Academy for Jewish Research at the Jewish Theological Seminary, 122d Street and Broadway.

BARCELONA, Dec. 27 -- More than a million Catalans paid silent homage today to General Francesc Macia, under whose leadership the region of Catalonia won back its autonomous privileges taken away two centuries ago by the Bourbon monarchy.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler ruled yesterday that the principles of international law required the dismissal of the suit brought by Silas Ezra of Chicago in behalf of himself and other owners of defaulted Mexican bonds to collect more than $6,900,000 held here by the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, of which Thomas W. Lamont is chairman.

Twenty-one properties in Manhattan and nine in the Bronx were sold under the hammer yesterday in one of the busiest days in several months in the auction rooms. Several scheduled sales were postponed.

The second night of the Metropolitan opera season offered the first hearing of a Wagner opera: "Tannhauser," with a new bass who proved his worth and a cast which offered unhackneyed interpretations of the principal parts. It is true that there were few commanding personalities on the stage last night, and it may be that "Tannhauser" needs interpretive flame to give it vitality and puissance in the eyes of the rising generation.

Short-date money was slightly easier, with the appearance of 60-and-90-day funds, which went at 3/4 and 1 per cent, respectively. Later periods were quiet and nominally quoted at 1 1/4 @ 1 1/2. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 1 per cent, while counter trading was arranged at 7/8.

The Chase National Bank announced yesterday a program of recapitalization involving the sale of $50,000,000 of preferred stock to the RFC and a write-down of $47,730,000 in capital through a reduction of the par value of its ordinary shares from $20 to $13.55 a share.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27 -- The speed of light is placed at 299,774 kilometers, or 186,271 miles a second in a new estimate made here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Ninety-seven per cent of all bank accounts of the United States will be insured 100 per cent on and after Jan. 1, when the temporary fund of the Federal deposit insurance becomes operative, Chairman Walter J. Cummings announced today.

BERLIN, Dec. 27 -- The first session on the Boerse following the three-day holiday responded to confident business surveys published in the meantime with a generally buoyant tone. Toward the close, however, the market turned soft and part of the gains were lost.

A second-period scoring surge which produced five goals helped the McGill College hockey team of Montreal to defeat Dartmouth at Madison Square Garden last night. The fast Canadians, flashing a fine, steady passing attack, turned back the Hanover sextet, 7 to 1.
Exchange of a Morristown house for a Cranford residence featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday:

Many members of Congress returning to Washington insist that prices must be raised substantially if they are to be brought back to normal. The most comprehensive index of prices is the average of 784 commodities compiled by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Included in the annual report of the Secretary of Commerce is an account of progress in the Lighthouse Service. The ninth law enacted by the first Congress, on Aug. 9, 1789, provided for an organization to maintain lighthouses. The Colonies had built a considerable number of these aids to navigation.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Third period goals by Ferry and McKenzie of Hamilton College broke a 2-2 tie and gave Hamilton a 4-2 victory over Williams in the first of a three-game hockey series in the Olympic Arena tonight. The game was the opening event of the Lake Placid club's thirteenth annual college week competitions.

BACK in 1905 James Weldon Johnson visited Atlanta University, his alma mater, to receive an honorary degree, and there it was that he met W.E.B. Du Bois, one of the professors, who had just published "The Souls of Black Folk." This militant and powerful book, Mr. Johnson says, "has had a greater effect upon and within the Negro race in America than any other single book published in this country since 'Uncle Tom's Cabin.' "
Harold S. Vanderbilt, skipper-manager of the new yacht now being built for defense of the America's Cup next Fall, yesterday gave out his first interview regarding the boat.

BERLIN, Dec. 27 -- The emergence of Captain Ernst Roehm, chief of staff of the Nazi storm troops, as Minister of Defense was envisaged in well-informed political circles tonight as one likely sequel to the retirement of General Kurt von Hammerstein-Equord as chief of the Reichswehr.

Federal regulations to put an end to the abuse of import permit privileges was suggested yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, Chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, in a letter to Joseph H. Choate Jr., director of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration in Washington.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 -- The Shandon Farm completed a double when La Salle came up in the closing strides of the featured New Iberia Claiming Purse to triumph by a half length over W.C. Weant's Flying Home at Jefferson Park today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Russia followed France's example today by informing the State Department she woud like to have her liquor quota into the United States increased, indicating she would be prepared in turn to offer compensatory advantages to American export trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Conciliation of the insurgent Senate Republicans and the winning back of the group which deserted to Roosevelt last year is being attempted by Senator McNary, Republican leader.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 27 -- Felix J. Koch, prominent newspaper and magazine correspondent, died at Deaconess Hospital today after a brief illness. He was 52 years old.

The Board of Education held yesterday its last meeting of the year without electing a successor to Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, who will retire on Jan. 31. There was no item on the calendar with reference to a new superintendent.

James F. Geraghty, former License Commissioner, will be invited to take the stand at the close of the inquiry into extortion and irregularity in news stand licenses, and to make any statement he may wish concerning his conduct of the department.

Improved opportunities for Negro medical education throughout the United States are urged in the report of the Harlem Hospital investigating committee, made public yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 27 -- Although in a serious condition from the brain malady which caused her parents to make a perilous air trip from their Texas home to Baltimore, Sue Trammel, 5 months old, was sleeping in Johns Hopkins Hospital today in no way affected by Jimmy Wedell's 1,400-mile race through fog, snow and cross-winds to bring her here.

Columbia took the lead in the annual series of the Intercollegiate Chess League by defeating Seth Low, 4 -- 0, in a third-round match at the Marshall Club last night. The victory was the second straight for the Blue and White representatives.

By way of giving the man in the street something pleasant to contemplate while he struggles against icy blasts and slippery pavements, the Giants and Yankees simultaneously chose yesterday to announce their Spring training exhibition schedules.

The following is the text of the complaint filed by the Federal Government here yesterday in an equity suit in the New York State Supreme Court to compel the banks of the New York Clearing House Association to pay the depositors of the bankrupt Harriman National Bank and Trust Company in full.

The reorganization managers of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway announced yesterday that they had abandoned their attempt to reorganize the company in accordance with a plan they put forward in June, 1932. This action was taken in spite of the managers having received the approval of two-thirds of the bondholders necessary under the bankruptcy law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Some 200 college juniors from all parts of the country will spend the first three months of each year here studying public affairs under the tutelage of Cabinet members and Congressmen, if a plan proposed by Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, and presented today by his assistant, Chester H. McCall, to the annual convention of the National Student Federation, goes into effect.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- The depression, and how can we safeguard the present trend for the better and avoid future crises, constituted the main topics of public interest discussed at today's sessions of the American Economic Association and thirteen allied organizations of experts in the social and economic studies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The navy is planning to ask Congressional authorization for a ship construction and replacement program, designed to establish the service on a treaty parity basis by 1939.
William C. Dodge, who resigned recently as a magistrate, was sworn in as District Attorney yesterday to take office on New Year's Day.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 27 -- Confirming the extensive damage done in four successive days of aerial bombardment of Foochow, the Fukien rebel capital, various Fukien, Kwangtung and Kwangsi Chambers of Commerce and similar organizations telegraphed protests to Nanking today.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Jay Bruen introduced their daughter, Miss Evelyn Bruen, last night at Sherry's, where they gave a large dinner dance. Miss Bruen, who received with her parents, wore a gown of pink satin and carried a bouquet of white orchids.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Legislation to tighten up the collective bargaining provisions of the Recovery Act, and particularly to prevent evasions through company-dominated unions, has been prepared by Chairman Wagner of the National Labor Board and will be introduced by him when he resumes his seat next week as Senator from New York.

Edward F. Doran, assistant clerk in the West Farms Magistrate's Court, announced yesterday that through his attorney, John J. McGinity of 900 Grand Concourse, he had filed with the grievance committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York a complaint against Magistrate Overton Harris.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ludlow Fowler Jr. of this city and Katonah, N.Y., gave a supper dance last night at the River Club to present their daughter, Miss Angela Fowler. Standards of silvered twigs and similax and myriads of poinsettias lent a holiday atmosphere to the ballroom.

Two more art galleries have been added to the rapidly lengthening list at Rockefeller Center. Both the Empire Galleries, in the British Empire Building, and the new Cronyn and Lowndes branch at 113 Rockefeller Plaza, are to have formal openings next month.

George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, sent instructions yesterday to all insurance companies and societies under the jurisdiction of his department regarding the valuation of securities as adopted at the recent national convention of Insurance commissioners.

To those who do not know JOHN DELANEY, Mr. LAGUARDIA'S request that Mayor O'BRIEN allow him to carry on may come as a surprise, and even a shock. Wasn't the chairman of the Board of Transportation appointed by Mayor HYLAN, the merry-andrew of rapid transit?

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to Russia, who has been passing the Christmas holidays in Paris, will sail on the liner Washington on Saturday highly pleased with the cordiality of the reception he received from officials on his recent visit to Moscow.

Formal announcement of the transfer of the docking activities of the North German Lloyd Line from the army base pier at Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, to the city-owned Piers 84 and 86, North River, awaited yesterday the decision of Dock Commissioner John McKenzie.

The English version of "Yoshe Kalb," prepared by Fritz Blocki, will have its premiere this evening at the National Theatre. With it, Daniel Frohman returns to Broadway as a producer. Fritz Leiber, Horace Braham and Erin O'Brien-Moore are in the cast.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 27 -- Bloc politics, and particularly bloc economics, are about to invade Pan-Americanism again. Even as the delegates to the seventh Pan-American Conference were scattering on their homeward ways today, this correspondent learned that a strong probability exists that the eleven Caribbean countries may meet in the very near future to map out a program for joint action at the forthcoming Pan-American Economic and Financial Conference at Santiago, Chile.
YANKTON, S.D., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The possibility that twins might have a split paternity was, in effect, upheld here today in a divorce decree granted by Judge R.B. Tripp in Circuit Court.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- A Supreme Court suit to test the constitutionality of the Schackno Law was started here today when Ray W. Aylesworth, counsel for Mrs. Mary T. Schmaling of this city, submitted a motion to Justice Joseph Morschauser for judgment on the pleadings.
Many important meetings of conservationists are slated for next month, with the American Game Conference session in this city the chief one.

KEANSBURG, N.J., Dec. 27 -- For twenty years Thomas Hessian, 41 years old, was sought by his two brothers. Last week he was located by one of the pair, Michael Hessian of 234 East 123d Street, New York City, and a reunion was held by the trio at the latter's home on Christmas Day.

Turning back five opponents in a row in the final round-robin, Miss Natalie Seiden of N.Y.U. won the invitation foils competition for undergraduate college women last night at the Fencers Club. Second place went to Miss Madeline Dalton of Hunter and third to Miss Stella Fox of Brooklyn College.
James Weldon Johnson, Negro poet and leader, received last night before a distinguished gathering of authors at the Shelton Hotel the W.E.B. Dubois prize of $1,000 for Negro literature.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange rose 10 to 17 points yesterday to the best figures in more than a month under the most active trading in several weeks.
Control of the State Senate hinges on the result of the special election to be held today in the First and Second Assembly Districts in the Bronx, which comprise the Twenty-first Senatorial District.

SAN JUAN, Dec. 27 -- Boaz Long, NRA coordinator, listened all afternoon to complaints of striking taxicab chauffeurs against an alleged gasoline monopoly maintained by two American and two English companies, which are selling at 25 cents a gallon, including the insular tax of 7 cents.

Accusations of unfairness and favoritism on the part of the New York Regional Committee of the Public Works of Art Project flew thick and fast last night at a meeting in the Russell Sage Foundation of about 150 unemployed artists.

MARLIN, Texas, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Miss Andrew Peyton, 28-year-old bookkeeper; M.V. Bradshaw, 50, vice president, and Lee Humphreys, Negro porter, were kidnapped in a $41,000 hold-up of the First State Bank here this morning.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27 -- Stanford football players left the double workouts behind them today and from now until the New Year's Day game with Columbia in the Rose Bowl will be content to practice once each day.

Final arrangements for the hockey game tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden between the teams of Princeton and McGill Universities will be made at a reception this afternoon for members of the executive committee, which will be given by Mrs. Giles Whiting in her apartment at the Pierre.
DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Informed tonight of the Canadian's plans GarWood, designer and driver of speed boats and long-time holder of the trophy, voiced an enthusiastic welcome for his new rivals.

Mr. McNARY, Republican leader of the Senate, is regarded as far more sympathetic to the Western Progressives than his regretted predecessor. JIM WATSON; yet his remark that "all Republicans look alike" to him has all the effusive heartiness and pained why must-we-differ spirit of the Hoosier tribune.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 28. -- Miss Lenore Kight, Homestead (Pa.) free-style champion, added two new national records to her laurels, and Miss Alice Bridges of Whitinsvllle, Mass., and Miss Anne Govednik of Chisholm, Minn., captured one each as the second annual national Olympic stars' aquatic meet opened today in the Biltmore pool.

Ray Impellittiere, 260-pound battler from Peekskill, will face Walter Neusel, hard-hitting German, in the feature bout of ten rounds in Madison Square Garden tonight. It will mark Impellittiere's second appearance in a New york main event. Last month he dropped a close tenround decision to Tommy Loughran at the New York Coliseum.
Organizations active in support of the Federal child labor amendment replied yesterday to the criticism of their activities made by Dr. Nicholas Mrray Butler, president of Columbia Universits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The establishment of a monetary system and the determination of monetary policies that will yield a dollar of reasonably stable purchasing power in the future is an entirely different problem from that with which we have been concerned in the examination of monetary and business policies directed toward the immediate need of bringing about a trade recovery and a rise in prices.

An important deal in the midtown section was reported yesterday with the purchase of the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Forty-first Street by Charles Francis Taplin of 421 East Sixty-fifth Street for a stated consideration of $295,000.

A dinner dance was given at the River Club last night by Mr. and Mrs. J. Barstow Smull to introduce their daughter, Miss Katharine Smull. The debutante wore a gown of blue satin and carried orchids, and her mother wore a gown of gray lace.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Following is the text of the statement by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, on the boycott of German-made products:

Clashes between counsel marked the hearing before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday on an informal application by Samuel Untermyer for an order directing George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, to reinstate guarantees of $770,000 on mortgages held by the Andrew Freedman Home, of which Mr. Untermyer is president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- President Roosevelt declared in an address tonight that the policy of the United States Government "from now on" would be one unalterably opposed to armed intervention in dealing with her neighbors.

BUFFALO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The $148,579,818 suit against the Niagara Share Corporation and its management was dismissed today by Supreme Court Justice Alonzo G. Hinkley. He ruled there was no proof of fraud, as charged in a stockholders' suit in which $300,000,000, the largest sum ever asked in Western New York Courts, was originally demanded.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28. -- The Campbell Stable's fleet daughter of Master Charlie, Annarita, scored a head victory over Flowery in the six-furlong dash for 2-year-olds which held the feature position on the program at Jefferson Park today.

Deputy Chief Inspector Thomas J. Kelly, in charge of the Queens division of the Police Department, slipped into Police Headquarters last night and left his retirement papers with the chief clerk. The resignation of Inspector Kelly came suddenly after several days of indecision.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 28. -- Jack Westrope, America's 17-year-old ranking jockey from Baker, Mont., today reached and passed his goal of 300 winners during 1933 when he signalized his return to the saddle, following a five-day suspension, with two victories at Epsom Downs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Charging that bar associations were inert and would not act on their own initiative, Professor Karl N. Llewellyn of Columbia University declared today before the Association of American Law Schools that action by the government was necessary to form a "guild sense of responsibility" for the bar.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The text of President Roosevelt's, speech at the dinner of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation tonight was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Organized labor and its friends were called upon today by President William Green of the American Federation of Labor to make effective the declaration of the convention of the federation held here last October for a boycott against German-made goods and German service.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Superb goal tending by Bill Beveridge gave the Ottawa Senators a 2-all tie with the Chicago Black Hawks in a furious but clean National League hockey game before a crowd of 7,000 spectators tonight. Only one penalty was called during the contest.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade became reactionary today. Buying of wheat and other grains lacked yesterday's snap, despite the continued strength in stocks and other commodities.

MONTREAL, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins moved out of last place in the American division of the National Hockey League and gained a tie with Detroit for second place tonight by beating the Montreal Canadiens, 4 -- 3.

Cardinal Hayes and former Governor Alfred E. Smith joined in assisting Santa Claus in distributing Christmas gifts yesterday afternoon to children in the New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street. It was Holy Innocents' Day, when the Cardinal annually makes it his practice to visit the institution.

Blighted areas fit for rehousing projects are to be found in one out of every four of the 269 sanitary districts of Manhattan, according to a report made public yesterday by the Regional Plan Association. The survey urges that studies of rehousing be confined to sixty-four districts on the island.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.

A suit to restrain the City of New York from starting to remove rubbish, in Brooklyn at midnight tonight was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Lillian Mandell, a taxpayer, of 206 Stockton Street, Brooklyn, on the ground that municipal operation would result in a waste of city funds.

Miss Lillias Pomeroy Dulles was presented to society last night by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Foster Dulles at a supper dance in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The debutante, who received with her mother in a bower of farleyense ferns near the entrance to the ballroom, wore a gown of pink tulle embroidered in silver, and carried a Colonial bouquet of roses.
Mayor O'Brien announced yesterday that he had appointed three new trustees for the Brooklyn Public Library as one of his last official acts in City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A tentative agreement has been reached between Secretary Ickes and Secretary Dern concerning the inclusion of all of Bedloe's Island in the Statue of Liberty national monument.

Futures prices continued yesterday their upward trend in dealing's on local commodity exchanges as the volume of trading in most cases showed a substantial improvement. Cash prices were irregular, with gains and losses about evenly divided.

In a continuation of the extensive auction activity last Wednesday, thirteen Manhattan properties and twelve Bronx holdings were offered in foreclosure proceedings yesterday. With one exception the parcels were bid in by the plaintiffs in the various actions.

Richard Strauss's "Salome," which caused indignant protests at its one and only public performance at the Metropolitan Opera House in 1907, will be revived by the Metropolitan on Saturday evening, Jan. 13, General Manager Giulio Gatti-Casazza announced yesterday.

Kenneth MacKenna, who has been a screen actor since his last appearance on Broadway several years ago, has been engaged by Richard Aldrich and Alfred de Liagre Jr. for an important role in "By Your Leave," the comedy by Gladys Hurlbut and Emma Wells, which they intend to present during the week of Jan. 22, with Dorothy Gish and Howard Lindsay.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 28 -- A gasoline boycott as a public protest against the price of 25 cents a gallon completely paralyzed from noon on today all normal means of transportation throughout the island.

MANILA, Dec 28. -- According to estimates given out by E. D. Hester, the United States Trade Commissioner, the Philippine Islands have again been saved from major financial disaster through the benevolent effects of the American market.

BERLIN, Dec. 28. -- Because recent college graduates are having a hard time getting professional positions, the number of students admitted to German universities next year will be sharply limited, with one woman to every ten men.
Varsity teams at City College compiled an excellent record during 1933, according to the statistics announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics.

ALBANY, Dec. 28. -- Selection of Rudolph Reimer of Brooklyn as a Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of John F. Galvin was announced by Governor Lehman today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A comparatively brief congressional session with no disturbance of the administration's monetary and other programs, quick action on necessary legislation and adjournment early in May was predicted without qualification by Speaker Rainey during a White House visit today.

The expenditure of $110,000,000 on unemployment relief in the city during the thirty-five months between Jan. 1, 1931, and Nov. 30, 1933, was reported yesterday to Mayor O'Brien by Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare. The money came from Federal, State and city funds and was exclusive of amounts used for other official and semi-official relief purposes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- To make possible the widest general use of the new Federal bank guaranty plan, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, announced today that purchases of preferred stock or capital notes have been authorized up to today in 3,883 banks, involving a government outlay of $736,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Drastic tightening or the government's regulations to bring all gold into the treasury with the exception of that legitimately held were issued today by Acting Secretary Morgenthau.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- Professor George F. Warren of Cornell University, monetary adviser to President Roosevelt and now the most influential member of the "brain trust," explained and defended the administration's gold policy at the annual meeting of the American Economic Association today.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 28. -- Stanford football players, reduced to a once-a-day routine in preparation for the Rose Bowl game with Columbia Monday, worked this afternoon under a beaming sun. Old sol has been conspicuous by his absence for the last few days as heavy clouds threatened, but produced no rain.

The Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service has received $50,000 in contributions and pledges in its campaign for an emergency fund of $360,000, Mrs. Stella A. Koenig, secretary, reported yesterday. The largest gift is one of $10,000 from John D. Rockefeller Jr.

Contracts valued at approximately $730.000,000 have been dealt in on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., in its first seven months of operation, according to the annual report for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, issued by Jerome Lewine, president.

Although more than the usual number of cash transactions appeared yesterday on the Stock Exchange tickers, the aggregate volume of business -- which was about half that of Wednesday -- indicated that the greater part of the year end tax transfers of security ownership had been completed in time for regular clearances.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 28. -- Work designed to add to the speed and deception of Columbia's football team marked the practice session today as the Lions tuned their offensive strategy for the game with Stanford in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena on New Year's Day.

Among the reports that cropped up yesterday out of the secretive batch of plans for defense of the America's Cup was one that an amateur crew of Harvard graduates and undergraduates might man the yacht Yankee, built by a Boston syndicate four years ago.

Stalin Predicts Recovery. JOSEPH STALIN told Mr. DURANTY that in his opinion the depression in the capitalist countries has passed its low point and a revival is probable, though with some fluctuations.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 28. -- A 12-year-old girl admitted tonight that she alone was responsible for the killing of Josephine Waropay, 8 years old, who was found last Sunday morning beneath the St. Matthew's Lyceum Building at Hastings-on-Hudson with her skull crushed and the strands of a mop twisted around her neck.

Mayor-elect LaGuardia warned yesterday that his forthcoming "experiment in municipal government" might be wrecked by sabotage attempts of "a combination of politicians." He spoke as the guest of honor of the Columbia University Alumni at their twenty-fifth annual holiday luncheon at the Columbia University Club.

Shipping men of the Gulf and Pacific Coast ports have been summoned to New York to discuss wages for longshoremen with the committee which is drafting the labor clause of the new code for the shipping industry. Conferences in Washington and New York in the last week settled several features of the code which concern wages, but reached a deadlock on longshoremen's terms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Standard fair-practice rules for banks intended primarily to prevent unjust competition between small and large institutions and to insure that banks shall not operate at a loss were approved today by General Johnson.

Returns to date indicate that the country's Class I railroads earned a net operating income of $39,300,000 in November, against $34,179,000 in November, 1932, an increase of 15 per cent. Net operating income in October was $57,264,000, but November's decline was seasonal and less than in the corresponding time in 1932 and 1931.

Many dialects and mumbling voices may be explained from X-ray studies of vocal mechanism in action, according to Professor G. Oscar Russell of Ohio State University, who demonstrated his experiments in vowel sounds yesterday at the convention of the National Association of Teachers of Speech in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 28 -- Paraguay refused today to agree to an extension of the armistice with Bolivia until Jan. 14, thereby completely changing the entire aspect of the Chaco war question.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- In his paper read before the American Economic Association today Professor E.W. Kemmerer of Princeton University, who believes that controlled inflation is sure to fail, said, in part:

BERLIN, Dec. 28 -- The Boerse suffered a sharp reaction today, losses ranging up to 4 points. The weakness was credited to foreign sales, principally Russian, for the purpose of building up blocked marks accounts with which to pay bills due; disappointment over the French answer to Hitler's rearmament proposals and general yearend liquidation.

The twenty banks of the New York Clearing House Association that are being sued by the Federal Government on the ground that they should make good any losses sustained by depositors in the bankrupt Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, took the general position yesterday that there were two ways of interpreting the correspondence which the government regards as an agreement to keep the bank from failing.

Chairman MACY, in his effort to establish control of the Republicans in the Assembly at Albany, has made much use of the charge that an "invisible government" has really been dominant at the State capital. By that phrase he means the so-called Power Trust.

A syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company and the Guaranty Company of New York won yesterday the award of a new issue of $7,000,000 State of New Jersey educational fund bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1934, and due from 1936 to 1942. The price paid was 100.619 for the bonds as 4 3/4s, equivalent to an interest cost to the State of 4.61 per cent.

Columbia's chess team, competing in the annual Intercollegiate Chess League tournament at the Marshall Club, virtually clinched the championship yesterday. In addition to taking its fourth-round match from Yeshiva, 3 to 1, the Blue and White representatives also won two of the four games from their unfinished match in the second round with City College.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Stretching beneath the surface of the North Pacific lies a continent, hitherto unknown, with huge plateaus broader than an above-surface continent, with twice the width of America, with mountains taller than Mount Everest and with great deeps, separating it from Asia, which drop more than six miles to their bottoms.
"Lady Killer," with James Cagney and Mae Clarke, will be presented at the Strand today.

Mr. and Mrs. Quincy A. Shaw Jr. of Boston gave a dinner with dancing last night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre for Mrs. Shaw's goddaughter, Miss Peggy Pardee. The debutante, who is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler Pardee of Greenwich, wore a gown of gold and white lame and carried a muff of gardenias.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The British and French viewpoints on disarmament swung together again today following the collapse of the Franco-German diplomatic negotiations.

TOKYO, Dec. 28 -- Summaries of Walter Duranty'a dispatches to THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 19 and 24, telegraphed from the Japanese Embassy in Washington, were mentioned by the Foreign, Office spokesman this morning.

While frozen snow was being shoveled outside, the drill hall of the 165th Regiment Armory, at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street took on something of the aspect of a tropical jungle yesterday. Scores of tiny model airplanes, their wings brilliantly iridescent sheets of gossamer microfilm, circled and swooped like butterflies.

After successfully experimenting with a popular-price circuit of five legitimate theatres in the Middle West since Nov. 3 in an effort to rehabilitate the road, Arthur M. Oberfelder, who heads the circuit, has applied to the Council of the Actors Equity Association for permission to add four more cities to the chain, to be operated under existing arrangements.

Permission to change their hours of store operation after Dec. 31 was granted yesterday by the New York Retail Code Authority to the 60,000 stores under, its jurisdiction. Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the code authority, announced the conditions under which the change may be made.
Jockey Jack Westrope, who booted home two mounts at Epsom Downs yesterday to bring his total for the year to 301 winners, has had a racing career little short of meteoric.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange rose yesterday 2 to 4 points.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, Dec. 28 -- Defense Minister A.A. Oksala charged today at a Cabinet meeting that spies had endeavored to poison leading technical experts of the national defense departments.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- The Economists' National Committee on Monetary Policy, meeting here today in connection with the annual convention of the American Economic Association and allied groups, adopted a resolution demanding immediate adoption of a policy for "the return to a gold standard."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- The Williams College hockey team lost its second game in succession to Hamilton in the Olympic Arena tonight, but snowed the Lake Placid Club college week crowd a much better brand of play than last night. Hamilton won the second clash, 2 to 0, after taking the opener last night, 4 to 2.

Thomas J. O'Neill, an attorney, of 405 Lexington Avenue, was censured yesterday in an opinion by the five judges of the United States District Court, in Brooklyn who last October sat as a disciplinary court and considered charges of unethical conduct against him.
COMMEBCIAI, PAPER. Yesterday, Wednesday. For the best names.... ,114% 1 3/4% The quotations are for 3-4 months' paper.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 28 -- James A. Moffett entertained tonight with a dinner aboard his yacht, the Bidou, having Captain and Mrs. R, Amcotts Wilson and their house guests, Lady Mendl, Mrs. William Randolph Hearst and John E. McMillan, and his own house guests, Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cutler, Mr. and Mrs. Wedell Catching, Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Spring, William J. Baxter and L. W. Robert Jr.

Moving a step nearer his goal, Frank Parker of Lawrenceville reached the quarter-finals of the national junior indoor singles tennis championship yesterday by turning back the Yale freshman, Barclay A. Kingman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Two rival delegations of the college youth of the nation bore down on the White House today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- A formation flight by the six seaplanes of Patrol Squad VP-10-F from California to Honolulu was authorized today by Admiral William H. Standley. Chief of Naval Operations.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- William Tilden 2d tonight advanced to the semi-final round, with a straight set victory over Emmett Pare of Chicago, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, in the national professional indoor championship tourney at the Penn A.C. Earlier in the day Pare won his first round match from Thomas Murray of Palm Beach, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 29 -- In solemn ceremony, for which the imperial shrines were unveiled, the baby Crown Prince received today the name Akihito. The name means "enlightened benevolence."

The program given by Hans Lange, who conducted, and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall contrasted cunningly an unpretentious overture of Mendelssohn and an ultra-modern symphony by Lopatnikoff, played for the first time in New York.

In Dr. GOLDWATER, whose selection as the new head of the city Hospitals Department had been forecast, Major LAGUARDIA is confident that he has found the best-qualified man in the country for this important post. That he happens to be a New Yorker born and bred is cause for added satisfaction.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28. -- The Soviet Central Executive Committee, which is equivalent to the United States Congress, opened its session in the Kremlin today. Instead of meeting in the old throne room of the Czars, the congress met in the theatre of the Kremlin Military School.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- President Roosevelt expressed the view today that "we enter the new year with a realization that we have crossed the threshold of a new era." This was contained in a letter he wrote to Mrs. Grace Morrison Poole, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

An investigating bureau of super-trained police agents to accumulate evidence of racketeering and organized crime was recommended for this city yesterday by a special committee of the New York City Bar Association, with the added information that the recommended bureau already had been approved by the incoming Police Commissioner, John F. O'Ryan, and by the incoming District Attorney, William C. Dodge.

Officials of a dozen States in the Midwest and East yesterday sent out urgent calls to sportsmen to come to the rescue of millions of game birds which are threatened with starvation and freezing as a result of the storms which have covered sections of the country with snow and ice.

Heating and elevator service in Mount Sinai Hospital was crippled for several hours after 7:15 o'clock last night and power and heating plant apparatus, food supplies and equipment in the basement of the semi-private wards building were damaged to the extent of $75,000 when a 20-inch water main under Fifth Avenue burst at 100th Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Unemployment is increasing faster now than at any time since January, President William Green of the American Federation of Labor reported today, appealing at the same time against a slackening of efforts toward recovery.

WHITE PLAINS, N, Y., Dec. 28. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors by a vote of 24 to 10 this afternoon adopted the proposed 1934 county budget of $6,501,950 net, an increase of $167,530 over the net budget for 1933, and rejected by the same vote an amended budget with savings of $250,000 offered by the Democratic minority of the board.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 28 -- A pint of coffee, moderately strong, will counteract the effect of a stiff drink of gin, according to scientific tests reported here today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 25 -- Julius Kahn, president of the Truscon Steel Company, who returned today from Japan, said the company would retain a half-interest in its Japanese subsidiary, the Japanese Steel Products Company", and the other half-interest would be controlled by the Mitsui Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28. -- After seeing Eastern football stars shuffled about in practice for the last five days, observers had there first glimpse today of what is expected to be the team that will line up for the kick-off against the West in the annual charity game here New Year's Day.

Although declining sharply from the preceding week, bank clearings throughout the country in the week ended on Wednesday showed a moderate gain over the reduced amount of a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. In the last week, as in the corresponding period last year, there were only five business days.

Trading in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday aggregated only $11,946,000, compared with $21,368,000 on Wednesday. Domestic corporation bonds showed considerable strength, United States Government long-term issues finished irregularly higher, and leading foreign loans averaged somewhat lower on the day.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 28 -- A new mathematical theory which builds an intellectual "bridge" linking the material and the non-material, and explains how something possessing no dimensions may assume three dimensional existence, was presented here today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Five men held up the offices and workshop of Hendricks Brothers, Inc., un dealers, at 49 Cliff Street, yesterday morning and escaped with forty pigs of tin weighing 100 pounds each. The loot was valued at $2,120. The robbers came prepared for heavy duty.

Retention of Democratic control of the State Senate was assured yesterday when Lazarus Joseph, Democratic candidate, was elected at the special election in the Twenty-first Senatorial District, the Bronx, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Henry G. Schackno, who was chosen City Court justice at the November election.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles E.F. McCann will give a reception for Lord Decies and his daughter, the Hon. Moya Beresford, on the afternoon of New Year's Day in The Playhouse, which is on their estate, Sunken Orehard, at Oyster Bay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Governmental departments and emergency organizations rushed to President Roosevelt and his advisers today their last-minute estimates on expenditures for the current year and probable requirements in the next as the administration grappled with the difficulties of the budget.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The young liberals differ among themselves and unite against the young conservatives in the administration effort to provide a "more abundant life" for the citizens of the United States. NRA and CWA have a spat over wages. The Bureau of the Budget labors terrifically to keep the gigantic deficit that will be revealed next Wednesday from being made greater by PWA and RFC.

Two prisoners, bringing to seven the number of suspects held in connection with the assassination of Archbishop Leon, Tourian in the Holy Cross Armenian Apostolic Church on Washington Heights, were arraigned in Homicide Court yesterday and held without bail for hearing on Jan. 3.

Mayor-elect LaGuardia announced last night that the bill for reopening of the city budget, to be presented shortly to the State Legislature, would be an act patterned along the lines of the "economy bill" passed by Congress last Spring at the behest of President Roosevelt.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Mrs. Mary Gertrude Abbey, widow of Edwin Austin Abbey, American painter, showed that she had left $1,313,025 in public gifts in memory of her husband, but because the estate had been insufficient to pay the bequests in full, these gifts were reduced to $1,124,619.

WHEN Dexter Fellows next comes to town with his Ringling circus we intend to take him to task. In his old-fashioned addiction to good, clean fun he's been missing some pretty smart tricks. Only the other day we were reading, in Margaret Goldsmith's "Christina of Sweden," about the retinue of dwarfs which the neurotic Queen Marie Eleonore of Brandenburg kept around the palace as court jesters.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 28 -- "If there ever was any fear of the United States in South America it has completely disappeared as a result of Secretary Hull's activities at the Seventh Pan-American Conference here," President Gabriel Terra of Uruguay told this correspondent this afternoon.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 28 -- Helen Richey and Frances Marsalis today broke the women's endurance flying record by remaining in the air over Miami 8 days 5 hours 5 minutes.

The membership of Alexander V. Roe in the New York Stock Exchange has been transferred to William J. Hennessey, who is at Charles D. Barney Co. Mr. Hennessey will become resident partner in New York and floor member on the Exchange for Newhard, Cook Co. of St. Louis on Jan. 1.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- Ernest Maggs, Bond Street bookseller, revealed today his firm had made "practically nothing" from the sale of the Codex Sinaiticus, fourth century manuscript of the Bible, for the unprecedented price of u100,000.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Dec. 28 --Application by the former Janet Elizabeth Snowden, daughter of the late James H. Snowden, millionaire oil producer, for an annulment of her marriage last Aug. 17 to Don Francesco Caravita, Prince di Singgnano of Naples, was denied by Supreme Court Justice Taylor in a decision handed down in White Plains, but filed here today.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Merriam Chadbourne and William Merriam Chadbourne gave a reception with dancing yesterday afternoon at the latter's home, 810 Fifth Avenue, to introduce his niece, Miss Emily Chadbourne, daughter of the former.
The wettest and noisiest New Year celebration in years will begin tomorrow night, a day in advance, according to predictions yesterday by hotel, restaurant and club managers.

Directors of the Marine Midland Trust Company will recommend to stockholders at their annual meeting on Jan. 10 that the capital of the company be reduced from $10,000,000 to $5,000,000 and the amount charged off transferred to surplus, it is announced by James G. Blaine, president.

Rules and regulations governing fair competition in banking practices, as approved for submission to the Banking Code Committee representing the national Recovery Administration and the American Bankers Association, follow:

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- There in feverish activity at the Commerce Ministry because France's new import quota system is supposed to go into effect Jan. 1. The plan, which was adopted by Parliament Sept. 15, provides for the opening of negotiations with all countries trading with France with the object of favoring nations which will take most goods from her.

HAVANA, Dec. 28 -- A girl was injured late this afternoon in a riot when former employes of Woolworth's Havana stores attacked the San Rafael Street branch. This company recently opened its stores after a strike of almost three months.

After the burst of activity on Wednesday, when there was a flood of "tax selling," the share market quieted down yesterday, as Wall Street expected it to do. But considerable significance was attached to the spirited rise and brokers began to talk, with hopeful enthusiasm, of a "New Year's market."

SKYTOP, Pa., Dec. 28. -- Two games were played in the Skytop Club interscholastio hockey tourney today. A fast Brooklyn Poly Prep six topped Montclair Academy in the morning, 2 to 0. Captain Hull scored both Poly goals. Captain Baumgard of Montclair excelled in goal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning, contending that the attempt of several States to change their negative vote against the child labor amendment was illegal, drew attention, according to an administration official today, to an issue upon which the Supreme Court may have to rule.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 28. -- A ten-year old rivalry begun here in junior tournaments will be continued tomorrow when George T. Dunlap Jr., national amateur champion, clashes with Dick Wilson, the former Georgetown star, in the final round of the midwinter tournament.
BERLIN, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- The Roosevelt new deal in various aspects in addition to the monetary policy came in for both praise and denunciation today at meetings of the joint convention of the American Economic Association and thirteen allied organizations.

Several more of the waiting a Neediest Cases were assured of relief yesterday by 163 gnerous contributions. They made a total of $3,019.59 and brought the sum contributed thus far this year to $213,887.10.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 28. -- Tom Sanger, nationally known circus clown, and Mrs. Bernadlne Forero, former wife of Robert Forero, one-time Colombian Consul at Baltimore, were married here last night at the home of the bride.

The seasonal return-flow of currency to the banks after the peak of the Christmas demand began this week with a reduction of $25,000,000 in the amount of money in circulation, the weekly report of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday, showed.

MONTREAL, Dec. 28 -- The value of newsprint exports from Canada last month was lower than in October and a year ago, according to the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. The value was $5,828,878, as compared with $6,285,008 in October and $6,631,241 in November, 1932.

During November the average daily depreciation of the American dollar in terms of currencies still on gold was 37.6 per cent. This must be taken into consideration in comparing last month's foreign trade with that for the same month of 1932. In terms of dollars our exports were 33 per cent above the figure for last year and our imports 23 per cent above.

The ten articles on economics and recovery which Professor SFRAGUE has been contributing to our columns since his resignation as financial adviser to the President have not been of the tenor which some people expected. They looked for something bitter and bellicose. A violent attack upon the Administration's monetary policy they thought to be indicated.
RENO, Dec. 28 -- Mrs. Emilie Kennedy Bishop divorced Julian T. Bishop today, attempts at reconciliation having failed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Pan-American Conference which has just concluded its sessions at Montevideo has done more good for the United States and its Latin American neighbors than anything heretofore accomplished, Representative McReynolds of Tennessee, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dep. 28. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 27, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,698,000,000, an increase of $11,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $509,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Members of the American Football Coaches Association headed for the scenes of all-star games or Winter quarters today.
While the uptown galleries drew a long holiday breath, the Greenwich Village region blossomed out with at least three new exhibitions.

In the Golden Agre, when Saturn reigned, even to mark a field or divide it with bounds was unlawful. So did we read in our school-day Georgics. Earth yielded freely and without measure. But now she is put under restrictions. Not only are there metes and bounds as between farms, but an all-seeing Government limits production and is preparing to make record of how the individual farmer divides his crops in the fields.

Threat of a general strike of 50,000 waiters and restaurant workers in New York City on New Year's Eve definitely was averted last night as a result of the intervention of the Regional Labor Board, which brought about an agreement between the major portion of the workers involved and their employers.

Thursday, Dec. 28, 1933. Money on call was fractionally higher in the counter trading, where it ruled at 1 per cent, compared with 7/8 on Wednesday. The Stock Exchange rate continued at 1 per cent. There was little else of interest in other sections of the money market, all departments being quiet and unchanged in quotation.

BERLIN, Dec. 28. -- The sea monster recently reported seen in Loch Ness, Scotland, has a new champion in Captain Werner Loewisch, commander of a German submarine during the World War and now navigation officer of the Battleship Schleswig-Holstein.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- In a two-hour conference with his chief advisers on foreign affairs and agricultural problems, President Roosevelt today made a survey of economic conditions as they affect the export situation.

The 2,800-ton freighter Wellhart, with a crew of twenty-eight men, ran aground shortly after 5:30 P.M. yesterday in the East River under the shadow of Hell Gate Bridge when her steering chain parted. The ship Was in no immediate danger and none of the crew was injured.

TOSHE KALB (English version), a play in two acts and twenty-eight scenes. Adapted by Fritz Blocki from the novel by I.J. Singer. Dramatized and staged by Maurice Schwartz. Music by Leo Koutzen. Dances arranged by Lillian Shapero; settings by Alex Chertov; produced by Daniel Frohman.

ALBANY, Dec. 28. -- The rift in the Republican State organization has been widened by Chairman Macy's refusal to appear at yesterday's bearing before a committee of the Republican Assembly caucus on his charges that Republican members had been subjected to improper influences in connection with public utility measures.

Henry Hoyns left public school to work for Harper Bros. as an office boy on Dec. 31, 1884. He is now chairman of the board of directors and executive committee of Harpers and at 63 is one of the most active publishing executives in the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The right of the President to remove a member of the Federal Trade Commission because their minds do not "go along together" was attacked in a petition filed today in the Court of Claims by William E. Humphrey of Minnesota.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The right of the President to remove a member of the Federal Trade Commission because their minds do not "go along together" was attacked in a petition filed today in the Court of Claims by William E. Humphrey of Minnesota.
Several flats were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

Verdi's "Rigoletto" was given a special matinee performance yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Medical Mission in Labrador. The beneficent and admirable purpose of the fund was well served by the financial returns of the occasion.
Evidence of economic recovery were cited by speakers at the annual dinner of the New York Department of the New York Life Insurance Company at the Hotel Astor last night.
