WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The recent downward movement of wholesale commodity prices was continued last week, the decrease in the index number amounting to sixtenths of 1 per cent, Isador Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor, announced today.
MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 28. -- Cecil Smith's all-star polo team from Texas bowed to Mexico's champion combination today to the tune of 13 to 5 after an encounter which thrilled a full gallery.

MADRID, Dec. 28. -- Spain will introduce an important system of import quotas, to apply primarily to nations which have favorable trade balances with her. In this category stands the United States, which in the first nine months of this year sent goods to Spain to the value of $19,000,000 and took only $8,000,000 worth of Spanish goods.

Dr. S.S. Goldwater of Mount Sinai Hospital will be Hospitals Commissioner, and Dr. John L. Rice of New Haven, Conn., Commissioner of Health, in the LaGuardia administration, the Mayor-elect announced yesterday.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 28 -- The first upset of the 1934 girls' national indoor tennis championships under way at Longwood occurred today, when Miss Virginia Hollinger, Dayton, Ohio, eliminated Miss Helen Grawn of Grosse Point, Mich., defending champion and top seeded player.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Prices of hogs here dropped 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight today and large packers then took hold freely. No government buying appeared. The packers are said to have submitted bids to slaughter 300,000 hogs for the government in January.

Mrs. Paul Gibert Thebaud gave a large dance last night in the ballroom of the Colony Club to introduce her granddaughters, the Misses Dorothy Mathilde and Marie Eugenie Thebaud, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gibert Thebaud of White Plains, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Emergency Board of Mediation reported today to President Roosevelt that "all substantial causes" for the threatened strike on the Southern Pacific Lines in Texas and Louisiana have been removed.

William C. Dodge, District Attorney-elect, turned thumbs down yesterday on ten members of District Attorney Thomas C.T. Crain's prosecuting staff, including two women. He notified them in an unusual manner that he would not reappoint them and indicated that more may join the ten.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The stock markets again were cheerful today, although there was some reaction owing to profit-taking. The Stock Exchange will be closed Saturday and Monday for New Year's holiday. The undertone in British funds remained firm today, but some issues were weaker.

A complete overhauling of the License Department to end graft in news-stand licenses was forecast yesterday by Mayor-elect LaGuardia following a conference with the representatives of publishers and circulation managers of the New York newspapers.

Banking in New York City would be put on a "metered service plan" involving fixed charges for every banking function, under a schedule of rules and regulations drawn yesterday at a meeting of representatives of more than 100 banks and submitted for approval to the Banking Code Committee of the NRA and the American Bankers Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The $3,300,000,000 public works fund authorized by Congress as one of the foundations of President Roosevelt's recovery program is practically exhausted. Secretary Ickes, administrator of the PWA, so stated this afternoon in announcing allocations for Federal and non-Federal projects totaling $83,931,892.
New Yorkers donned their warmest garments yesterday as the thermometer fell to the lowest point for 1933, the lowest for any Dec. 28 on record and the lowest since Feb. 17, 1930.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 28 -- A study of war through the ages, including 902 major wars since 500 B.C., shows that universal peace could come only by "a miracle," the American Association for the Advancement of Science was told today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr. made a sharp attack here today on many policies of President Roosevelt, his cousin. He declared the nation was headed for ruinous inflation unless expenditures were restricted.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Dec. 28 -- William Lester Wemple, who was Assistant United States Attorney General in charge of customs in New York City from 1911 to 1914, dropped dead of a heart attack about midnight last night at his home on Foothill Road here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Widespread interpretation and general commendation was the Washington reaction today to President Roosevelt's latest and most emphatic "good neighbor" policy enunciated last night in honor of Woodrow Wilson.
The hockey teams of Jamaica and Brooklyn Technical high schools triumphed over their respective alumni sextets at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Jamaica won, 3 to 0, and Tech scored, by 2 to 0.
LYNCHBURG, Va., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Asked today what he thought of the list of nineteen men selected by Professor Irving Fisher as those who know most about the value of money, Senator Glass remarked:

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- George A. Ranney, vice chairman of the Commonwealth Edison Company, tonight withdrew his candidacy for the position of chairman of the board of directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, giving as his reason that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, owner of $50,000,000 of the bank's preferred stock, had failed to approve his election.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 -- Mrs. R.T. Flippen's 3-year-old gelding Uncle Donald upset calculations at Jefferson Park today by winning the mile and a sixteenth featured Opelousas Purse with surprising ease.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Samuel Insull and his brother, Martin, former utility operators, were disclosed today as owing the Reconstruction Corporation $766,873 on notes turned over as collateral for the $90,000,000 loan to the Dawes bank of Chicago.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 29 -- The New York Athletic Club swimming team defeated the Newark A.C., 43 to 40, tonight. The New Yorkers swam without their two stars, Walter and Wallace Spence.

BERLIN, Dec. 29 -- President Roosevelt's plea for world peace received preferred front-page position in this evening's press. Its preliminary reception in official quarters was equally flattering, although fuller appraisal of its scope and import, it was observed, must be deferred until the official text was at hand.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Massachusetts's "prudent investment" theory of public utility regulation, subject to national commendation and condemnation at various times during its history, today was put to a new test, one which will focus the eyes of the utility world again on the Bay State.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- The dispute between hard and paper-money adherents over President Roosevelt's gold policy, which has been the chief subject of interest among the economists and statisticians holding their joint annual convention here this week, broke into an open row this afternoon at the annual election of officers of the American Statistical Association.

Winning its final match against Seth Low, 3 1/2 to 1/2, in the fifth round at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday, City College gained a tie for first place with Columbia in the annual Intercollegiate Chess League championship.

Renewed activity in the realty investment field was reported yesterday. A fifteen-story apartment house at 50-58 West Ninety-sixth Street was sold by the Liberdar Holding Corporation, a subsidiary of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, to an investor represented by Louis Weiss of Cohen, Cole, Weiss Wharton.

Seven locals of the International Fur Workers Union, consisting of about 3,000 fur dressers and dyers, voted yesterday to call a strike in protest against the code approved for their industry by the National Recovery Administration. In making known this action, Pietre Lucchi, international president, said strike plans would be completed at once and placed into effect "without delay."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The rigid fair practice rules drawn up by the New York Clearing House for approval by the National Recovery Administration in conjunction with the Bankers' Code of Fair Competition have been neither submitted to nor approved by the Recovery Administration, Hugh S. Johnson, the administrator, said tonight in a strongly worded comment on the proposed regulations.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 -- A very successful Florida racing season is in prospect as the first of the three major meetings opens at Tropical Park tomorrow. Officials expect an attendance of 15,000 and seven well-filled races are on the program.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Local professional operators who thought early this week that they saw evidence of a bull market developing in grain on the Board of Trade have been disappointed by the failure of outside trade to broaden, and they found little support today when they tried to take profits.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 29 -- Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York and Miss Virginia Hollinger of Dayton, Ohio, won their way into the final round of the girls' national indoor tennis championship today. They defeated Miss Sylvia Hatch of Winchester, Mass., and Miss Louise Harding of Brookline, Mass., respectively, at Longwood.

Fifteen firemen were injured, three seriously, early this morning when they were caught in a backdraft while fighting a fire that swept from the ground floor to the roof of a five-story loft building at 38 West Thirty-eighth Street.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 29 (AP) -- At home in the heavy going, Quick Step, a 6-year-old gelding racing for W.H. Gallagher, made a show of his field in the mile feature at Epsom Downs today.

Price movements in local commodity futures markets were irregular yesterday. In most cases, opening prices were the highest of the day, but several staples closed with net gains. Trading was somewhat smaller. Cash prices were mixed.
Several flats and business structures were among the New Jersey properties reported sold yesterday.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, EXPLORING OFF ANTARCTICA, Dec. 28 -- Released at least temporarily from the grip of gale and fog, the flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition, having yesterday resumed its southeasterly advance, today reached the Antarctic circle and swiftly attempted another record.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29 -- The marriage of Miss Virginia C. Thompson, "color girl" at the graduation exercises of the Naval Academy, Annapolis, in June, was revealed today. She became the bride of John B. Bronnor in Ellicott City, Md., on Nov. 20.

Although the recent advance to the highest quotations of the month attracted some selling by holders, prices on the Cotton Exchange displayed resistance yesterday and ended unchanged to a loss of 5 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Secretary Ickes today signed contracts under which the Public Works Administration will lend to t!ie Pennsylvania Railroad $77,000,000, of which $45,000,000 will be used in completing electrification of the line between Wilmington and Washington and $32,000,000 for building 7,000 new freight cars and 100 electric locomotives, supplying more than 45,000,000 man-hours of direct employment in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- President Roosevelt definitely put aside today any plans for signing the major pending recovery codes until next week at the earliest, and arranged for a hearing before him of protests against that for the construction industry.

All markets declined slowly yesterday in the last full five-hour business day of the year. Trading today will be confined to a half-day on the various domestic Exchanges and there will be an even quieter market schedule elsewhere.

An increase of about 10 per cent in the volume of production and trade for 1933 over 1932 is indicated in a preliminary estimate made public yesterday by the Federal Reserve agent at New York in his monthly review of credit and business conditions.
PARIS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- France began heightening her trade wall today with new agricultural import quotas and increased taxes hitting at American apples, pears and lard.
During his last day as Mayor today, Mayor O'Brien expects to make three judiciary appointments, filling one vacancy on the Special Sessions bench and two in the magistrates' courts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- The forty-three commercial banks open for business in Westchester have adopted rules of fair trade practices under the bankers code of fair competition that differ from the New York City code principally in respect to lower service charges for small checking accounts.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- President Roosevelt will probably be more surprised than any one else at the interpretation in official circles here of his speech last night.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- With the mercury hovering around 25 below zero, Eddie Blood of New Hampshire University triumphed among a field of thirty-four in the three-quarter mile downhill ski race as the thirteenth annual intercollegiate Winter sports tournament opened today at the Lake Placid Club.

Instructions issued by Lord TRENCHARD, Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, in regard to the outfit to be provided and the examinations to be passed by candidates for admission to his new Police College for training men for the higher posts in the service, were the subject of a debate in the House of Commons the other day.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- District Attorney Frank H. Coyne of Westchester. County was noncommittal today on whether he would ask the death sentence for 12-year-old Mary Kavala of Hastings-on-Hudson. She is alleged to have confessed yesterday to the killing of 8-year-old Josephine Waropay, a playmate. Mr. Coyne admitted he had no corroborative evidence.

DUBLIN, Dec. 29 -- Claiming journalistic privilege, Joseph Dennigan, political writer for Eamon de Valera's newspaper, The Irish Press, refused to disclose to a military tribunal in Dublin today the source of the information on which he had written that members of an association banned by the government would have a short period of grace to abandon membership.

SKYTOP, Pa., Dec. 29 -- An aggressive Hun School hockey team won the annual Skytop Club interscholastic hockey tournament today by overwhelming the plucky Poly Prep six of Brooklyn, 5 to 1. A last period onslaught netting three goals conclusively demonstrated Hun's superiority.

CARSON CITY, Nov., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Dr. A.J. Schur was named as receiver of the new Monte Cristo Mining Company by Federal Judge Frank H. Norcross today upon petition of G.L. Merrick of Los Angeles. Mr. Merrick testified the firm has heavily in debt because of "careless and fraudulent manipulation of assets" by a board of directors named by C.C. Julian, fugitive promoter now in China.

SINAIA, Dec. 29 -- The Rumanian Cabinet met in extraordinary session tonight shortly after the assassination of Premier Duca and ordered a round-up of known members of the Iron Guard. By midnight word from Bucharest said 1,300 had been jailed, in that city alone.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29 -- A state of siege was declared for an indefinite period tonight by the Argentine Government as the result of a revolutionary plot leading to violent disorders in four provinces.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 -- Five national swimming records were swept into the discard today, for a total of nine and a mark established in a previously unrecorded distance in the first two days of the Olympic stars' meet in the Biltmore pool.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers.

Under pressure to complete their task before Dec. 31, the date set as a deadline by the National Recovery Administration, the New York City banks have proposed a code which plainly calls for reconsideration. Some of the rules contained in it can scarcely fail to inconvenience bank depositors and cause many of them to think that the regulations are unnecessarily sweeping.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A slight decrease in bituminous coal production in the week ended Dec. 23 and an increase in both stocks and industrial consumption in November were reported today by the Bureau of Mines.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The Canadian Government has decided to revoke the resolution adopted in the Canadian House of Commons which for nearly fifteen years has prevented titles of honor from being bestowed on Canadians.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many times I have felt like applauding the informative articles by Arthur Krock, but what happened to his usual good sense in the article he presents today I cannot imagine. Here we find him, by the tone of his article, evidently "aghast at the suggestion" that the government should own the four-billion profit from dollar devaluation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Knocked down seven times, Don McCorkindale, the British South African, proved to be no more than a punching bag in his ten-round Heavyweight battle with King Levinsky, Chicago, at the Chicago Stadium tonight.

The outlook for the building industry is better than surface appearances indicate, according to a survey published yesterday by the Hegeman-Harris Company, Inc., builder of the main unit in Rockefeller Center and other structures. If the country's economic condition shows any sustained improvement, the present surplus of buildings will vanish "like snow in the sun," the company declares.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A strong conservative tendency and an inclination to leave controversial questions, in college and out, to the decision of older and presumably wiser heads marked the deliberations of the 250 student government heads and other campus leaders gathered here from colleges from coast to coast at the ninth annual convention of the National Student Federation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude oil at the close of the week ended Dec. 23, totaled 342,639,000 barrels, the same total as reported for the preceding week, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and administrator of the code of fair competition for the petroleum industry, announced today.

Walter Duranty has just signed a contract with Viking Press for the publication of a book of his dispatches, sent from Russia to THE NEW YORK TIMES. It will be edited by Gustavus Tuckerman Jr. of New York University and will cover the whole range of Mr. Duranty's experience as a foreign correspondent in unrecognized Russia.

CANON CITY, Col., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Walter Reppin, 18-year-old orphan who killed a taxi driver for the change he had in his pockets, will be the first to breathe death in Colorado's new lethal gas execution chamber unless a last-minute court action saves him.

American women, judging from the views expressed by 40,000 of them in four cities, have overwhelming confidence in the Roosevelt Administration and all its policies, and believe the nation is on its way out of the depression into a period of unprecedented prosperity.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- The constitutionality of the Schackno law was upheld in a decision handed down today by Supreme Court Justice Joseph Morschauser on his last day on the bench. Justice Morschauser retires Monday because he has reached the age limit.

The problems that confront the non-professional and so-called "little" theatres throughout the country were discussed at the National Theatre Conference yesterday afternoon at the quarters of the Beethoven Association, 65 West Forty-fourth Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 29 -- An "electronic telescope," based on a new principle in telescope design, which will make it possible to build an instrument equivalent to a 2,000-inch lens or mirror, was described here today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Miss Virginia Hoyt made her debut last night at a dance given by her mother, Mrs. K. Stone Hoyt, at the Court House, 205 East Sixty-fourth Street. Christmas trees had been arranged around the ballroom and silvered, white and pink balloons were suspended from the ceiling, giving a holiday atmosphere to the place.

The Sunday opening hour for the sale of wine and liquor in restaurants, hotels and clubs was advanced from 2 P.M. to 1 P.M. under a ruling yesterday by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. The order goes in effect tomorrow.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Spencer Childs presented their daughter, Miss Virginia Childs, at a supper dance last night at the Pierre. The scene was the ballroom, which had been decorated with evergreens and ferns. Miss Childs wore a gown of ivory-colored transparent velvet and a corsage of orchids.

The East Side Chamber of Commerce exults that "a son of lower East Side goes to City Hall" when Major LAGUARDIA takes office next week as Mayor of the city in which he was born. A street on the lower West Side makes more specific claim, though it is admitted that the father lived before the son's birth on the "teeming East Side."

Indictments charging two men with extortion and coercion were returned yesterday by the New York County grand jury, which has been hearing evidence of racketeering in the building trades. The identity of those indicted was not revealed pending their arrest.

In accordance with the Banking Act of 1933, Roosevelt Son will no longer engage in the business of dealing in securities after the close of business today, the firm announced yesterday. The old partnership accordingly has been dissolved.

The record in the case of Mrs. Lena Feldman, who testified that Joe (The Goniff) Solomon asked her for $1,000 in order to have her news stand license renewed at Fiftieth Street and Eighth Avenue will be forwarded to the office of the District Attorney for possible grand jury action next Tuesday, Sidney S. Levine, License Commissioner, announced yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 29 -- The government crisis that was averted two weeks ago materialized today when Osvaldo Aranha, Finance Minister; Dr. Alfranio de Mello Franco, Foreign Minister, and other officials resigned. Their resignations may bring others, and some political circles are much disturbed.

The annual solemn high mass of the Holy Name Societies of the Archdiocese of New York will be sung New Year's morning at 11 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral. It is expected that Cardinal Hayes will preside and give his blessing after the mass.

American shipyards in 1933 reached their lowest total of production of merchant and naval shipping for the last twenty-five years, but as the end of the year approaches a new impetus of construction has set in which promises a definite upswing in 1934, accord- ing to a survey by Marine Engineering and Shipping Age.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 29 -- George T. Dunlap Jr., national amateur champion, annexed his eighth midwinter golf title in nine years by defeating Richard Wilson of Southern Pines, former Georgetown ace, in the eighteen-hole final today, 2 and 1.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 29 -- General Plutarco Elias Calles will retire on Monday from the post of Secretary of Finance, which he has held for the last three months, according to an official statement tonight by the Secretary of the Interior.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 29 -- Martial law was declared throughout the Argentine Republic tonight and a strict censorship was established on newspapers and foreign correspondents, according to the meager and sketchy dispatches received here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Senator Borah today sent another letter to Secretary Ickes, in which he vrigorously attacked the pending oilpool agreement as leading to the ruination of independent oil companies.

Although W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, had no comment to make yesterday on his controversy with the Republican legislative leaders, he indicated that he still expected developments that might prevent Fred W. Hammond from continuing as clerk of the Assembly.

Words and Music. The case for grand opera in English is stronger on grounds of patriotism than on grounds of intelligibility. Dr. HOWARD HANSON of the Eastman Conservatory at Rochester denies that certain foreign languages are more easily set to music than English.
GENEVA, Dec. 29 -- President Roosevelt's speech on the anniversary of Woodrow Wilson's birth was warmly welcomed by the few League of Nations officials here during the Christmas holiday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 29 -- A plea to engineers to aid in the building of a cooperative society in the United States, to replace the present laissez faire system, was made here tonight by Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, before a general session on agriculture and engineering of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
A dinner was given for Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, by Mrs. Alma Clayburgh last night in the Tapestry Room of the Ritz Tower. Additional guests came later for a musicale and supper.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- The United States may have to withdraw 50,000,000 acres, or one-seventh, of all its cultivated lands from production unless the demand for farm products can be increased, Professor Rexford G. Tugwell, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture and a member of the "brain trust," told the American Farm Economic Association today.

BERLIN, Dec. 29 -- Encouraged by the cessation of the year-end and foreign sales, the Boerse staged a fairly brisk recovery today. Although business remained wholly in the hands of professionals, market leaders were able to score gains reaching four points.

Mayor-elect LaGuardia and his advisers have drawn up a fairly complete program for cutting city expenses in connection with the reopening of the city budget and the proposed enactment by the State Legislature of an emergency economy act giving the Mayor powers similar to those given President Roosevelt by Congress last Spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- When a powerful Senatorial silver bloc organized today behind a program for remonetization and claimed enough votes to put it through provided President Roosevelt does not come out openly in opposition, any attempt to block the President's silver-purchase policy was disclaimed.

For the first time since the depression New Year travel this year will exceed that of the preceding year, railroad executives said yesterday. The New York Central reported an increase of 35 per cent in passenger travel, while the figure given by the Pennsylvania was 40 per cent.

The first "Walkure" of the season was given last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. The true Wagnerites, who met in large numbers, rejoiced. For is not this really the first opera of the full-fledged Wagner? The first one in which all his amazing capacity as a musician and a poet reach complete and unfettered freedom?
Another convincing exhibition of tennis was given by Frank Parker in the national junior indoor championship tourney yesterday as the Lawrenceville ace advanced to the semi-final round.

The fund for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases moved ahead yesterday to a total for the year thus far of $216,093.35. This gain cut down the margin by which this year's fund is lagging behind the total contributed last year to $49,306. Last year a total of $265,399.53 was contributed, providing lasting relief for 428 cases.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor gave a dinner with dancing last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for two debutantes, Miss Audrey Achelis, daughter of Mrs. Frederic G. Achelis of Greenwich, and Miss Eleanore T. Vietor, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Vietor and a niece of the hosts.

Glenn Cunningham of the University of Kansas and Bill Bonthron of Princeton, two of the outstanding middle-distance runners of the world, have yet to match strides in a footrace. But no race between the two could be any closer than the battle they waged for the James E. Sullivan Memorial Medal.

A profit of more than $600,000 was made in the recent spectacular rise of the stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation by Philip H. Philbin Jr., who gained control of the company before the stock collapsed, according to testimony yesterday before John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, in his office in the State Building.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I should like to point out that the illustration made by Dr. Albert Levitt on electric rates is most unfair. He compares a giant plant, fostered by the government, with rates in the small city of Oswego. Once upon a time I enjoyed a debate with Dr. Levitt on prohibition, so I know something of his manner of treating great problems.
"Ten Minute Alibi" will close its run after this evening's performance at the Bijou Theatre. It has been on Broadway for eleven weeks and will go on a road tour.

Departmental honors for policemen who have performed unusual service in the line of duty were announced yesterday by Commissioner Bolan. More than 150 members of the department were named in citations, recognition being accorded to some of them under more than one of three types of citation used in the department -- honorable mention, commendation and excellent police duty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 19 appeared an editorial, "Monaco vs. Mississippi," which, said: "Yesterday the Principality of Monaco, owner of the Mississippi bonds in default for something over ninety years, applied to the Supreme Court of the United States for leave to bring suit in that court against the State of Mississippi for judgment for principal and interest."

Although he left a deathbed will giving $1,000,000 to Stanford University and an equal sum to the All University Club at 249 West Forty-sixth Street, the estate of Dr. George Alfred Lawrence, neurologist, was appraised yesterday as insolvent. Dr. Lawrence, who was a lieutenant colonel in the World War, died on Dec. 28, 1928, at 142 West Eighty-sixth Street.

Bernard S. Deutsch, Aldermanic President-elect, notified thirteen members of the Board of Aldermen's secretarial staff yesterday that their services would not be required after Jan. 1, when be takes office.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- President Roosevelt's speech has been officially "warmly welcomed by France because of its declaration of American adherence to those principles on which French policy is founded -- that there must be no rearmament by Germany and that the League must remain a democratic institution representing the will of peoples of the world for peace."

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 29 -- Paraguay agreed today to extend the armistice with Bolivia seven days. She made the distinct proviso, how- ever, that she will not agree to further extension of it unless the Bolivians withdraw their troops to the Robore-Villamontes line by that time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 -- Through steady rain this afternoon, coaches of the Eastern and Western squads drilled their players in final heavy workouts for the annual East-West charity football game here New Year's Day.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 29 -- A cotillion led by Henry D. Brigham, a minuet with performers dressed in costumes of the period of 1830, and quartet singing of songs that were popular a hundred years ago were features of the Junior League ball held tonight at the Wendell Hotel.
There is an air of optimism among conservationists these days regarding the wild waterfowl situation, but it is not one which is likely to result in inaction.

Since there is no doubt that housing, especially for the lower-income groups, is close to the hearts of Mr. LAGUARDIA and his associates in the new administration, any information bearing on the complex local problem is of more than usual interest. To add to the mass of accumulated material, a number of new studies are now being pursued, under public as well as private auspices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A warning that distillers would be forced to withdraw from legal markets where "ill-considered regulations" on whisky were being imposed was sounded today by Dr. James M. Doran, Supervisor of the Code Authority for the Distilling Interests.

The first week of the new year will have only $2,947,003 of new municipal bond issues up for award, compared with this week's revised figure of $14,072,461. The weekly average of new State and municipal offering's during 1933 was $15,166,169, compared with $18,615,660 in 1932, $31,729,034 in 1931 and $30,036,316 in 1930.

A clash between General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, and the banking code committee of the American Banker Association was precipitated last night out of the storm of protest evoked by the schedule of heavy service charges on small depositors proposed by banks of New York City under their "fair-practice code."

BREMEN, Dec. 29 -- G. Carl Lahusen, principal owner of the ruined Nordwolle textile concern, "uncrowned king of Bremen" and looked upon as the "father" of the German financial collapse that soon led to the world crisis, was sentenced today to five years in prison and a fine of 50,000 marks on charges of falsifying balance sheets and violating the bankruptcy laws.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
New Yorkers awoke yesterday to face the coldest day the city has had in fourteen years.
To the Editor of The New York Times: As one of the members of the Transit Commission, my attention has been called to a statement to the following effect:

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 29 -- As a result of his conclusions that William C. Durant, automobile manufacturer, was entitled to $63,984 and that Benjamin Block Co. of New York, stock brokers, were entitled to $84,474 as a result of losses sustained in market operations, Circuit Court Judge Rulif V. Lawrence filed today in the Supreme Court a final award of $20,490 in favor of Block Co.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission told Western trunk line railroads today that they must cease favoring country live-stock markets over those at Kansas City, Chicago, St. Joseph, Omaha, Sioux City, Sioux Falls, St. Paul, Wichita and Fort Worth.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 29 -- Albert C. Middleton, State Treasurer, a member of the State Sinking Fund Commission, was subpoenaed today to appear next Thursday as a witness at the investigation by the Legislature into the commission's transactions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Senator Wagner changed today his plan to resign from the chairmanship of the National Labor Board at the opening of Congress and will continue indefinitely in that post.

Retail Showing Good in Week. Although volume was reduced by the blizzard on Tuesday, retail trade on other days of the week made a notably good showing, retail executives here reported yesterday. The usual post-Christmas lull was not particularly noticeable and the sharp drop in temperatures made for a good response to clearance offerings of cloth and fur coats.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Football fans, unlike those of the good old days who used to stick with one team all season, now pick out headline attractions to attend, Coach H.O. (Fritz) Crisler of Princeton said in a round-table discussion at the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention today.

Dr. Henry C. Sherman, Mitchill Professor of Chemistry in Columbia University and internationally known for his research and discovies in vitamins, has been chosen for the William H. Nichols Medal for 1934. This award, presented annually by the New York section of the American Chemical Society, was announced yesterday by Professor Victor K. La Mor, chairman of the jury of selection.

Business will proceed as usual today in Wall Street, with the security markets, the banks and most business organizations carrying on. All business will be suspended on Monday. Most of the commodity markets will observe today as a holiday.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 29 -- Miss Sarah Ripley, daughter of Mrs. Bertram Ripley of 137 Upper Mountain Avenue, Montclair, and the late Mr. Ripley, was married to Lieutenant John Hardy Lewis, U.S.A., son of Mrs. John O. Lewis of Elm City, N.C., this evening in the First Congregational Church by the Rev. Archibald Black, the pastor.

NEW YORK. The first of this season's Metropolitan Dances for debutantes of next season took place last night in the main ballroom suite of the RitzCarlton. The guests were received by members of the committee, including Mrs. Grafton H. Pyne, Mrs. Lyman Delano, Mrs. Philip B. Weld, Mrs. Eugene H. Pool, Mrs. Childs Frick and Mrs. Richard Derby.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 29 -- A youthful team of Texans lost to an all-star Mexican combination, three matches to one, as the four-day tennis series for the cup presented by President Rodrigues got under-way today. The Mexicans took two out of three singles matches and the only doubles contest played.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull told the American Club of Buenos Aires today that the outstanding achievement of the recent Pan-American Conference was "the frank and open acknowledgment" of the essential unity of the aims and aspirations of the twenty-one republics of this hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Regret that Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell would "not get down into the saw dust instead of standing aside and conjecturing results on purely academic consideration" was expressed by General Johnson in a letter to the former Harvard president, who declined to serve on the code authority for the motion-picture industry.

NEVER mind the Erskine-like title. "Private Affairs of George Washington," by Stephen Decatur Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $5) is not hammock fiction in antique dress. Neither is it a new, earnest declaration that Parson Weems made up his story about the hatchet. The direct opposite of both these well-established brands of biography, it is a rich, intimate history in fine detail of a man and a period.

Walter Neusel, husky young German heavyweight, gave Ray Impellittiere, Cold Springs (N.Y.) ring giant, every physical advantage in their ten-round bout before about 6,000 boxing fans in Madison Square Garden last night. Then he proceeded to give him a consistent beating.

PALM PEACH, Fla., Dec. 29 -- A large subscription dance was held tonight by students here from schools and colleges. A buffet supper and floor show were features of the evening. On the reception committee were the Misses Gloria Baker, Anita Key, Katherine Wait and Annette Reynolds, and on the floor committee Hood Bassett, Theodore Noll, Edgar P. Sawyer 2d, Wiley Reynolds Jr. and Paul Wait.

Court action by the Brooklyn Ash Removal Company prevented the city yesterday from carrying out its plans to start municipal operation of ash and refuse disposal last midnight and forced the Board of Estimate to continue the company's temporary permit to do the work on a day-to-day basis.

SINAIA, Rumania, Dec. 29 -- Rumania's recently named Premier, Ion G. Duca, leader of the Liberal party, was assassinated at 10:30 o'clock tonight on the platform of the Sinaia station as he was waiting for a return train to Bucharest after having had an audience with King Carol.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- With comparative ease, William T. Tilden 2d defeated Francis T. Hunter of New York in the first of the round robin semi-final singles of the national indoor professional tennis championship at the Penn A.C. today.
The Argentine Radical party has been trying to regain its strength and power ever since the late President Hipolito Irigoyen, its leader, was overthrown in September, 1930.

SINAIA, Rumania, Dec. 29 -- THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent reached Sinaia within a couple of hours after the assassination of the Rumanian Premier, Ion G. Duca, and obtained an exclusive interview with the assassin, Radu Constantinescu.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- The name of President Roosevelt, when mentioned today by Foreign Commissar Litvinoff, was greeted by the Soviet Central Executive Committee with spontaneous applause. It is the first occasion the writer can recall when a Soviet "Congress" thus whole-heartedly cheered the head of a foreign State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 23 amounted to 527,067 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 27,765 cars, or 5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 32,557 cars, or 6.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 86,168 cars, or 19.5 per cent more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Dick Metz, young assistant to Craig Wood at Deal, N.J., and Jack Dumphy, Los Angeles public links golfer, tied with Henry Ciuci of Flushing, L.I., and A.K. Barbee of Los Angeles for the lead in today's first qualifying round of the Santa Monica $2,000 pro-amateur best-ball tournament.

The protective committee for holders of the first preferred stock of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation has written to holders of certificates of deposit of the preferred stock that "after almost two years of arduous labor on the part of the committee, without compensation, it is evident that no recovery whatsoever can be effected for the stockholders."

Mr. ROOSEVELT in his address at the dinner in commemoration of WOODROW WILSON on Thursday evening passed over what might have been controversial topics to seize upon one phase of the foreign policy of his predecessor. He took for a sort of text the statement made by President WILSON at Mobile: "The United States will never "again seek one additional foot of ter" ritory by conquest."

New Yorkers whose knowledge of the art of Joan Miro extends, thus far, not beyond the famous "Dog Baying at the Moon" will want, no doubt, to hasten to the Pierre Matisse Gallery, where a large Miro one-man show opened yesterday.

The legislation authorizing the setting up of a Municipal Housing Authority has been drafted and is ready for introduction in Albany, Mayor-elect LaGuardia said at his press conference yesterday after- noon.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29 -- "Baby Sue Trammell's condition is very good. She may be able to go home in two to three weeks," said Dr. Walter E. Dandy, famous brain specialist, after he had completed a delicate brain operation on the 5-month-old child.
TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 29 -- Lou Little surveyed his coaching handiwork today and pronounced the Columbia football team ready for its Rose Tournament game with Stanford New Year's Day.

Sixty-five per cent of the supposedly service connected cases before the eight Veterans' Regional Boards of Review in New York City were rejected as being unable to substantiate assertions of service connection under the new law or justify the continuance of gratuities, according to a statement issued yesterday by the American Veterans Association, 420 Lexington Avenue.

Notice having been received that the interest due on July 1 last, with interest on the overdue payment of 4 per cent to Monday, on Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad general mortgage bonds due in 1988, will be paid, the New York Stock Exchange has ruled that the securities shall be quoted ex-interest of 2 per cent on Tuesday and that the bonds shall continue to be dealt in "flat."

Robert J. Shawkey, baseball's famous Bob the Gob of a decade ago, yesterday was appointed manager of the Newark Bears for 1934. Announcement of the appointment was made by George M. Weiss, generalissimo of the chain-store system of the New York Yankees, who operate the Newark Club as their principl farm.

The route of the Rockaway Division of the Long Island Railroad was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate as a location for the proposed extension of the city's new subway system through Queens to the Rockaway peninsula.

There was a general uplift in prices in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday in moderately active dealings. United States Government bonds were up 1-32 to 3-32 point with the single exception of the Treasury 3 3/8 s due in 1943, callable in 1940, which sold 2-32 point lower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Important interpretations of the operation of various sections of the Securities Act of 1933 were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission in the form of extracts from letters which it had sent to individual inquirers seeking information about the application of the act to specific transactions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The intention of President Roosevelt to ask tariff legislation in the forthcoming Congressional session was announced today, opening up the possibility of speedy action on the administration's program for reciprocal tariff arrangements abroad.

WINDSOR, Ont., Dec. 29 (Canadian Press) -- James R. Ardiel, 20-year-old holder of the British Empire outboard championship, has agreed to drive the proposed Canadian entry in the Harmsworth Trophy race as challenger against Gar Wood of Detroit, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Roosevelt and Lewis A. Douglas, Director of the Budget, wrestled today with the problem of keeping down the estimates of expenditures for the fiscal year 1935 in the face of demands for new emergency outlays.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- New regulations under the NRA and possible legislation to protect small industries against monopolistic competition are being considered by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A resolution calling for the free coinage of gold and of silver at a prescribed ratio of value to gold was adopted today by eighteen Senators at a conference summoned by Senator Wheeler, Democrat of Montana, author of a 16-to-1 bill.

A cut of one-eighth in yield on bankers' bills running one, two and three months was the only change of importance registered in the day's money market. This was the first variation since early month. Dealers reported a good demand for bills, but portfolios were light.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 29 -- With their New Year's Day football adversaries less than forty-eight hours away from the battlefield, Stanford's Indians today set about a two-day schedule of learning as much as possible about Columbia's plays.

ATMORE, Ala., Dec. 29 (AP) -- A band of Negro convicts, part of twenty-nine whites and Negroes who had escaped from the State prison farm near here early today, moved north tonight heavily armed after killing one man and wounding three others in their drive to freedom.

BERLIN, Dec. 29 -- As a result of a protest by the Catholic Church, the Hitler government has consented to modify the law under which some 400,000 German men and women were to he sterilized after it became effective Jan. 1.

Shipping executives view the close of 1933 as the end of a bitter experience and the arrival of 1934 as the beginning of a period of experiment designed to improve conditions in domestic and foreign transportation. Practically all ship lines report losses for the year and few are optimistic that conditions can be so improved in a single year as to replace losses with profits.

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- Archaeological finds of great diversity and richness have been unearthed from an extensive Roman burial ground discovered by an amateur archaeologist, Dr. Pierre Filloux, at Soingsen-Sologne, not far from Blois in the Loir et Cher Department.

DETROIT. ADVANCE preparations for the National Show are proceeding under difficult conditions confronting manufacturers in the Detroit area. With the opening in New York scheduled for Saturday next, the prospect is that a large percentage of the makers will be represented by hand-built models as distinct from production cars that ordinarily would come off assembly lines.

Reversing an eight months' trend of successive monthly increases, employment in manufacturing industry decreased 5 per cent in Novembers, according to the regular monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board, announced yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- District Attorney Frank H. Coyne of Westchester said today he was not satisfied with the alleged confessions of 12-year-old Mary Kavala of Hastings-on-Hudson that she killed her 8-year-old playmate, Josephine Waropay.

In a year filled with many changes in the turf structure from coast to coast. C.V. Whitney's Equipoise stood out as the only thoroughbred with a clear claim to championship honors. Yet, despite the greatness of this son of Pennant -- Swinging, he was humbled by Dark Secret in the Jockey Glut Gold Cup race.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- W.C. Wright, former national court tennis champion, came through the first round of the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet court tennis tournament at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club today, defeating W.A.W. Stewart Jr. of New York, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3.

THE presence of the first classically trained ballet to present a season here in a generation naturally gives rise to a great many observations, not only regarding the merits and demerits of this company in particular, but also regarding the status of the ballet itself in general.
HENRY WATSON FOWLER, who died last week in his seventy-sixth year, must have been a man of marked individuality. A profound English scholar, he hated pedantry.

The United States Intercoastal Conference, after meetings attended by fifteen American steamship lines, made public yesterday the text of the industrial code it will submit to the National Recovery Administration, together with a letter to William H. Davis, deputy administrator, from R.C. Thackara, chairman of the conference.

LONDON has licensed the first of a fleet of taxi-launches to ply on the Thames. It looks, says The Morning Post "as though the business man -- and his typist -- will be able to go to the office by water at last." Up to 1900 the River Thames had been used for commuting.

NANKING, Dec. 5. -- Since its establishment in China during the early centuries of the Christian era as the greatest living force in the religious thought and expression of the Far East, Buddhism today is preparing to make its first important bid for a place in the heterodoxy of Europe.

THE use of the axe for beheading of six Communists in a Cologne prison courtyard recently serves to recall a form of punishment that has been abolished by practically all civilized countries. The guillotine, hanging and the electric chair long since supplanted the masked headsman in all but a few countries, and even these instruments of death are condemned by opponents of capital punishment.

IN 1933 the United States, while trying some alphabetical experiments in government for the people, has tried one in government by the people. Usually, academic questions are not voted upon, directly, but representatives are chosen who are supposed to endeavor to interpret the popular will.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The distinguished Filipino statesman, Senator Manuel L. Quezon, braves the dangers of an American Winter to seek amendments to the Hawes-Cutting Bill for gradual independence of the Philippines over about thirteen years.

THE concern which has been felt over rumors that Ignace Paderewski was seriously ill in Europe signifies the singular place that he occupies in the public mind. No other living virtuoso has such a position. Other men of musical genius have had as many honors as Paderewski has enjoyed in this particular field.

NOTABLE progress in practically all its categories has marked aeronautics during the year which closes to day. For the third year in succession real gains have been made by commercial aviation in the face of general business conditions which, for a substantial part of the year, were at the low, the depression ebb and for the balance of the year could be described as convalescent rather than healthy.
A European Invasion by an American team was the outstanding feature of the 1933 speed skating season.

MR. CREEDY'S somewhat summarized examination of this economic problem has two distinctive qualities. It integrates all of the economic institutions and practices of a modern nation into one great organization aiming at a single purpose, and so enables the reader to envisage that economic organization as a whole, its parts all functioning together to produce the goods and services needed by all the people of the nation.

FROM the aeronautics branch of the Department of Commerce has come an interesting suggestion that automobile owners who use radio sets in their cars can secure a real service from the department's weather stations if the sets are capable of receiving frequencies between 200 and 400 kilocycles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the interest of historical accuracy I call your attention again to your editorial "President and Treasury," in which you discuss the experiences of President Jackson with three Secretaries of the Treasury, and draw therefrom certain conclusions as to what is desirable in such relationships.

Barefoot in the coldest blizzard in fourteen years, Lucrezia Bori took her curtain calls as the heroine of Thomas's "Mignon" at the Metropolitan yesterday afternoon, while 4,000 women in furs applauded in a theatre sold out to the doors.

A SPIRIT turbulent and untamed pervades the work of Hans Foy, whose paintings and drawings make up the current exhibition at the Eighth Street Gallery. Versatility and draftsmanship are obvious qualities in the artist's work.

Bench shows held during 1933 under the jurisdiction of the American Kennel Club numbered 231. These figures represent a gain of ten over the number of official exhibitions given during 1932. Forty-one field trials were held -- one more than during the preceding year.

An elaborate and diversified entertainment continuing, in the words of the committee, "from 10 o'clock until dawn," will feature the third annual Peacock Motor Show Ball on Friday night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

BERLIN, Dec. 15. GERHARDT HAUPTMANN, the dean of the German literati, has been coordinated. Last week he was present officially at the founding of the Reichskulturkammer (Chamber of National Culture), of which he was made honorary member.

Value of Dollar on Exchange Market The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

THESE pamphlets represent the poets who are experimenting with new forms and whose eyes are fixed upon the contemporary scene. A single poem cannot, of course, define a poet's work, but such adventures in publishing as these serve to make better known the poetry of today.
PARIS, Dec. 22. -- Paris, renowned the world over as the City of Light, of laughter, gayety and pleasure, has become above all a city of excellent and healthy morality.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 30. -- A new hypodermic which promises to call back from the verge of death persons suffering from too much alcohol, drowning, electric shock, surgical shock and asphyxia was announced by the American Association for the Advancement of Science today.

The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange in December was slightly heavier than in the preceding month. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, made a total of 34,877,616 shares, compared with 33,645,736 shares in November and 23,208,129 in the same month a year ago.

The first in a novel series of lectures, "What is Charm?" to be given by persons prominent in various fields of endeavor for the benefit of Mulberry Community House will take place Tuesday morning at Sherry's. Mrs. J. Borden Harriman will preside.

Operating under the most radical rule changes it has had in decades, basketball enjoyed one of the finest seasons in its history during the 1932-33 campaign. With the installation of the ten-second regulation and the three-second pivot rule the game advanced rapidly in popularity.

THE books about Beethoven that continually appear, and have appeared more than ever since the centenary of his death in 1927, seem to invalidate the idea advanced by some modern thinkers that there is a Beethoven twilight beginning to fall. Mr. Specht opposes such an idea with all the energy that is in him.

In the year of the new deal, intercollegiate football came back from the depression and gloom of 1932 and 1931 with a recovery act that allayed the widespread fears that the gold standard days of the game were ended.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins signed an order yesterday requiring Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Control Board, to show cause at a hearing next Thursday why the board should not be restrained from enforcing its regulations prohibiting signs advertising beer and liquor on the exterior of licensed premises.

Against seemingly adverse conditions because of the popular conception of its costliness, yacht racing in 1933 enjoyed one of its banner years. International contests did not loom to the fore, but there was far more competition along the Atlantic Coast than in any previous season, and the number of boats pitted against each other was close to record proportions.

Both major cross-country championships went to the mid-West during the past season as Tom Ottey of Michigan State captured the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. title and Ray Sears of Butler University annexed the national senior A.A.U. crown.

GERTRUDE STEIN, about whom Americans are growing increasingly curious, and her partner in operatic adventure, Virgil Thomson, modernist composer, have chosen Hartford, Conn., for the world premiere of their first opera.
THE "Airflow" De Soto models for 1934, some details of which were announced last week, will be presented to the public for the first time at the forthcoming automobile show.

PROBABLY since "Parsifal," with its entr'acte table d'hote in 1903, when the Metropolitan cafe did a business in six figures equal to that of the music drama itself in its first season, there has hardly ever since been a demonstration of operatic thirst like that following the return of legally licensed liquor at the opera season's opening last Tuesday.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 30. -- Closely censored dispatches from Buenos Aires today indicate that the Justo government of Argentina has successfully crushed the attempted revolution in one of the four northern provinces where outbreaks occurred yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Dec. 30. -- Fourteen hundred leading members of the Iron Guard were arrested today in the government's efforts to curb the anti-Semitic Nazis who were responsible for yesterday's assassination of Premier Ion G. Duca.

WITH the announcement that France has agreed to quadruple her present import quota of American apples and pears in exchange for the doubling by the United States of its French wine import quota, attention is once more focused on this country's fruit industry.

AIR mail operators, investment trusts interested in aeronautics, officials of air transport and aeronautical holding companies can complain little of a lack of something to do these days. A Senate committee, under the chairmanship of Senator Hugo L. Black of Alabama, has sent each one of them a questionnaire asking searching questions concerning their dealings in aeronautical stocks, their company incomes their personal incomes -- from aviation sources -- covering the last nine teen years.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- Philadelphia and Pennsylvania view the New Year with hope and uncertainty. That is not a model economic forecast, but a survey has proved that few responsible persons are willing, even privately, to guess what 1934 may have in store for this district, proudly claiming distinction as the "workshop of the world."

The sports world again was hard hit by the deaths of many outstanding figures during the past year. Baseball suffered severely in the passing of William L. Veeck, president of the Chicago Cubs, and Phil Ball, owner of the St. Louis Browns.

JAN. 1, 1933, found the army showing definite though, curiously enough, not universally deleterious effects of three years of economic depression. Successively decreasing appropriations had prevented procurement of improved types of needed equipment and even necessary replacement of worn-out items. Pay increases for all personnel had been suspended and salaries of officers had been cut 81-3 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 30. -- While the French Government rendered official thanks today for President Roosevelt's benediction on disarmament and the League of Nations, it is clear that it will continue to act along the lines it has established in dealing with the arms proposals by Chancellor Hitler of Germany.

An order permitting guaranteed mortgage certificate holders to organize corporately under the Schackno Law to take title to and operate the largest apartment property in Newtown, Queens, was signed yesterday by Justice John B. Johnston in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

TWO days before Christmas Tokyo was awakened by a siren. The 5,000,000 people within earshot sat up on their mats. When a second long blast rent the air they danced for joy and hastened to their bedroom shrines to kowtow in thanks to the gods.

Professor WARREN, commonly regarded as the President's monetary adviser and considered the actual conductor of the recent "dollar-manipulation policy," had until last week refrained from personal public statements. On Thursday last, however, he gave at the American Economic Association's annual meeting his views of the experiment.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The decision of the House of Lords a week ago upholding the validity of the "gold clause" in bonds is of world-wide significance at the present time, when the gold standard is in almost universal suspension and debtors are attempting in all countries to scale down their obligations.

The City College quintet set a new all-time record in the history of metropolitan basketball as it scored 31 points in a row and defeated the lighly touted George Washington University five by 51 to 25 last night.

THERE is a flew of literature -- the most important field of all, measured by its influence and the number who read in it -- in which no Pulitzer Prizes are awarded, and whose practitioners toil in anonymity.
WARSAW, Dec. 29. -- On Christmas Eve of 1932 the Polish-Soviet non-aggression pact was ratified, opening a new era of friendship and closer cooperation between the two nations.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30. -- Details of a new industrial five-year plan which would triple the production of 1932 and under which Soviet Russia Would be made essentially self-sufficing were announced today to the Soviet people.

Members of the board of managers of the Bowery Young Men's Christian Association have taken over the performance of "The Lake" Tuesday night at the Martin Beck Theatre to raise funds for the organization. There has been an encouraging subscription for the benefit.

SIX months ago American in- dustry was in danger of collapse. Markets had shrunk greatly because of reduction of buying power, capital resources bad been depleted, bankruptcies Were increasing. So grave was the situation that an industrial leader's desperate plea to a Congressional committee, asking that the government take over industry, brought scarcely a ripple of protest from the business community.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 30. -- Members of the Round Hill Club, Greenwich Country Club and Field Club celebrated the New Year tonight by holding entertainments.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 30 (AP). -- A large increase in bank loans would quickly lead the country out of the depression, and could be accomplished if the banks would bring into vogue the form of commercial credit known as the trade acceptance, in the opinion of Irenee du Pont.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- Vincent Richards, defending champion, and Big Bill Tilden today reached the final round of the national professional indoor tennis championship by winning their round-robin singles matches at the Penn A.C. court.
Curt Sachs, formerly Professor of Musicology in Berlin University, has left Germany on political grounds, according to foreign news dispatches, and has recently been in London.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- Drastic amendments to correct abuses in the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law are recommended in a report submitted to Governor Lehman by his Medical Committee on Workmen's Compensation Insurance.

John D. Hertz has been admitted to partnership in the firm of Lehman Brothers, investment bankers and members of the New York Stock Exchange. Until he moved recently to this city, he made his home in Chicago.

SOFIA, Dec. 15. -- The Bulgarian ecclesiastical authorities are preparing fresh and very liberal legislation for the regulation of marriage and divorce. These are exclusively ecclesiastical matters in Bulgaria, where there is no civil marriage or divorce.
DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Colonel Frederick M. Alger, a leader in Detroit's social and civic life for a generation, died tonight following an illness of more than a month. He was 57 years old.

ECONOMY in government reduced the appropriation of the eight government bureaus administered by the Smithsonian Institution by 34 per cent compared to 1932. Hard times also reduced the private income of the institution considerably.
New York will celebrate New Year's Eve tonight in a manner such as the younger generation, and even those a little bit older, have never seen before.

Sixteen years of uninterrupted Tammany rule of the City of New York came to an end last night. Today, a legal holiday, the city will be virtually without a Mayor until shortly after midnight, when F.H. LaGuardia will take the oath of office.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the interest of accuracy we are again compelled to point out the further error Dr. Levitt makes in interpreting the Tennessee Valley Authority's rate in his letter to THE TIMES of Dec. 13.

It is not the conclusion but the mathematical method that is new in the theory propounded by Professor J. R. OPPEN HEIMER to explain the transformation of intangible radiation into tangible matter. Both British and American experimenters have seen light converted into positrons and electrons, which are the bricks out of which matter is built.

SS JACOB RUPPERT EXPLORING OFF ANTARCTICA, Dec. 29. -- Still pushing eastward to the 120th Meridian, the flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition this afternoon was coasting along the edge of the main pack ice and occasionally forcing her bow through long tongues of pack that curved across her course.

TOWARD the end of 1932 several producers stated that in order to boost cinema boxoffice receipts they would be forced in future productions to supplant sophistication with hokum. Therefore the outlook was not particularly encouraging, but it so happens that in the last twelve months Hollywood has made even a greater proportion of intelligent pictures than in the previous year.

Figuring Three Bits. Some foreigner called 75 cents three bits. That, of course, is a gross error; 75 cents is six bits. How much three bits would be is harder to calculate. Theoretically, a bit is 12 1/2 cents. Practically, it is either a short bit, 10 cents; or a long bit, 15.

The first in a series known as the Crystal Club Dances will take place on Thursday night in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Subsequent events will be held on Jan. 12 and Jan. 19, the latter of which will be a dinner dance in advance of the Beaux-Arts Ball.

The list of titleholders in cycling underwent an almost complete revision in 1933. Only two riders succeeded in retaining their crowns, one a world's title and the other a United States championship, while eight other pedallers were shorn of their laurels as leaders of their respective divisions.
MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 30. -- The non-intervention policy announced by President Roosevelt finds here the most favorable editorial reception.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP). -- With even veteran Washington observers a bit groggy over the administration's growing "alphabet" of boards and corps and administrations, the new year may call for the printing of a new and different Federal directory.

Sales of department stores in the metropolitan area of New York during the Christmas shopping period, from Dec. 1 to 23, were 7 per cent higher than in the corresponding period of last year. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday a large part of the gain was due to liquor sales.

PARIS, Dec. 30. -- Andre Frangoia-Poncet, the French Ambassador to Germany, left for Berlin today with the memorandum containing France's refusal of Chancellor Hitler's disarmament proposals and the declaration that "disarmament is still possible."

TOKYO, Dec. 8. -- The Japanese army is about to discard the "tailor's" sword and equip all officers with, a weapon designed on the lines of the famous two-handed sword of the Samurai. The present sword is for parade only but the new one will be made of tempered steel and will be a really lethal weapon.
Frank Parker of Lawrenceville successfully passed his first real singles test in the national junior indoor tennis championship tournament yesterday to enter the final round.

R.C. SHERRIFF, the British playwright of "Journey's End," has signed a new contract with Universal. Mr. Sherriff, whose last handiwork was the adaptation of "The Invisible Man," will write three scripts during the new year.

At its Students' Concert In Carnegie Hall last night, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed by Hans Lange, repeated Mendelssohn's overture, "Calm and Happy Voyage," Lopatnikoff's Symphony, No. 1, and Dohnany'ls suite for orchestra, op. 19, from its Thursday and Friday concerts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- The Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railway, commonly known as the Monon, an important coal carrier and a strategic link between the South and Chicago, filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy today in the Federal court.

CLEVELAND, Ohio. NASH JUNIOR COLLEGE, the first junior college of the "progressive" type in a metropolitan centre, so far as known, is in the midst of its second year of pioneering, with a tripled enrolment.

As a result of a drastic reduction in appropriations, coupled with the assignment of many of its officers to other than their normal duties, air corps activities during the past year were necessarily curtailed. The air corps is still below the requirements laid down for it by the five-year expansion program enacted by Congress over seven years ago, both with respect to piloting personnel and serviceable airplanes.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 30. -- Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York, recommended for the position of fourth ranking girl player in the country, displayed her best tennis of the week today when she defeated the surprising challenger. Miss Virginia Hollinger of Dayton, Ohio, for the national indoor girls' singles title.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- Having regimerited the "nation of poets and philosophers" by silencing all open opposition, the Nazis are now training their guns on the few remaining independent persons who refuse to shout "Hail Hitler!" and would damn the national revolution with faint praise.

PARIS. AT St. Moritz Winter sports have added a whole new section to the mode. Even the youngsters can remember when Paris left skiing and such strenuous activities strictly to Scandinavians, professionals or a few brilliant amateurs; hut now everybody is snow-conscious and the tiniest children learn to balance on skis almost as soon as they can keep their feet.
The corridors of Police Headquarters trembled yesterday under the advance tread of the incoming administration and the departing footsteps of the outgoing Commissioner and his aides.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 26. -- Looking back over the year drawing to a close, with hearts more cheerful and hopes more high than were theirs Jan. 1, Kentuckians do not find much in which to take comfort and less to which they may point with pride.
GENEVA, Dec. 29. -- The world's prospects for a happy new year as seen from Geneva have been reported gloomy in these columns in the last few years.

Bank debt and security maturities facing the public utility industry in 1834 are approximately $443,000,000, or about 75 per cent of the maturities and bank debt of $580,000,000 at the beginning of 1933, which, in turn, was one-half of the $1,120,000,000 debt burden to be met in 1932.
THE year has been a period of unusual significance in the development of inter-American relations and has given further evidence of a growing spirit of solidarity among the nations of America.

A CAMPAIGN "to dramatize the importance of the motor truck" as a distribution medium opened at Cortland, N.Y., last Friday with a meeting of the executive, sales and engineering staffs of the Brockway Motor Company. The campaigm, to be known as a crusade for economic distribution through planned transportation, will extend over a period of ten weeks and include motor truck shows in ten Eastern cities.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 5. -- The fact that the United States and Soviet Russia have resumed diplomatic relations is having far-reaching repercussions in Eastern Asia. Not only has Washington's recognition of Russia served to modify definitely Japan's belligerent attitude toward Russia, but it has also had an effect upon Chino-Japanese relations and has heartened all elements in China opposed to the Nanking government.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP). -- Back to earth, Frances Marsalis and Helen Richey had to their credit a new woman's refueling endurange flight record of 9 days 21 hours and 42 minutes.

THE Buick cars for 1934, first of the General Motors group to be shown publicly With the "knee action" front wheel suspension, were placed on display here last week. The new models are presented in nineteen body types divided into three series of different wheelbase and engine power.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- Clear indications of a coming budget surplus are contained in Exchequer returns published tonight, covering the first three-quarters of the financial year which ends March 31.

Professor Strangely Absent. Alice and the Mock Turtle were crossing the campus on their way to the skating pond, when whom should they see but Bill the Lizard. He was having a thoroughly good time throwing snowballs at the flagpole in front of Psychology Hall.

Adel T. Katz will lecture on Wagner at the New School beginning Jan. 11, with philosophic and social interpretations of the texts. Thus "Rheingold," according to the announcement, suggests "the struggle for power through wealth"; "Walkure," "law as force in civilization," and "Tristan," "the problem of marriage; a study in ethical values."

Announcement by the readjustment committee for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway that it had abandoned a refinancing plan put forward in 1932 came as the culmination of a series of events, unusual in some respects, which reflected in part the changed conditions under which railroads operate today compared with the situation in 1929.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Dec. 27. -- The President's stroke in ratifying the agreement whereby the government will buy 24,000,000 ounces of silver annually has resulted in a rather cheerful feeling on the Coast. To the man in the street it augurs more hard money, more cart-wheel dollars in his pocket and less paper.

PARIS, Dec. 15 A MARCEL ACHARD play, a Sacha Guitry play and a Bernstein play in themselves make a rich harvest for the past fortnight, which has also included the production of "Coriolanus" at the Comedie-Francaise, to say nothing of Reinhardt's production of Johann Strauss's "Fledermaus" and the inauguration of Balieff's permanent home in Paris.

Six years ago they talked of a new economic era of unprecedented possibilities, of prosperity that nothing could check and stocks that "will go to a thousand." Bank presidents said that we had but started on our way, and economists of repute wrote that the soaring stock prices registered a permanent revolution in national well-be-ing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Aggregate assets of the 5,057 licensed national banks of the country operating on an unrestricted basis on Oct. 25 amounted to $21,198,649,000, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today. This compared with $20,860,491,000 reported by 4,902 licensed national tanks on June 30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- While one national student conference meeting here today discussed with college professors major political and economic problems, another tried to decide whether to endorse the junior NRA movement and whether to exclude Negro delegates from the annual ball and banquet this evening.

SPORTING pictures are, or ought to be, safe from the desiccating blight which (in the reconstructed minds of some of us) has fallen upon Pure Art, suprooted from reality and stripped of corporeal concern with the representation of things as they vulgarly are.
FOR several months Scotland has been much excited by an unexpected visitor. She is entertaining a "sea-serpent" and realizes the responsibility.

LINCOLN ELLSWORTH'S first sight of penguins in the Ross Sea ice pack, which the explorer described recently by radio as he made his way toward the Antarctic Continent, brought him just as much amusement as a glimpse of these droll and delightful little companions of solitude brings to other men who see them.
TOKYO, Dec. 30. -- A sense of storms safely navigated in 1933 and of smoother waters ahead is the keynote of New Year messages of Japanese leaders.

Cold weather and freezing water hampered the activities of firemen who were called yesterday to four major fires in Brooklyn and Queens. More than fifty families were routed from their homes, and many of them were left homeless.

THE second volume of Jules Romains's monumental work, "Men of Good Will." Is to be published on Jan. 29 by Alfred A. Knopf under the title of "Passion's Pilgrims." Like the first volume, which appeared early this year, it will consist of two books.
Baseball, which seems to thrive best on upsets, saw two spectacular form upheavals unfold themselves during the past year to place 1933 among the banner campaigns of all time.

New Year's will be marked by watch-night services this evening in virtually all of the larger churches in Manhattan, the majority of them beginning at 11 P.M. or 11:30 P.M., although some, as in St. Patrick's Cathedral, will start as early as 8 P.M.

Primo Camera's rise to the world's heavyweight championship was the boxing feature of the past year. The giant Italian, regarded lightly when he first made his bid for pugilistic prominence, ascended to the heights by knocking out Jack Sharkey in six rounds last June.

To the Drama Editor: Joseph Verner Reed overlooked, in his valedictory, the one thing that keeps the theatre alive -- devotion. The haggling, the bargaining and the brow-beating isn't quite as devastating as he asserts, and even if it were, the love of those who cling to the theatre for the theatre far outshadows the heartaches, the torments and the failures.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 26. -- Utah seems to have three State Treasurers, whereas the Constitution of the State specifies but one. The Supreme Court of the State has been asked to see what can be done about it, and arguments on the legal phases are to be presented next week.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 26. -- The tremendous impulse of around $40,000,000 in cotton checks, nearly $1,000,000 a week in CWA money, coupled with the Muscle Shoals development and the Mississippi flood control project, has effectively silenced, during the last three months, what few murmurings were formerly heard in the mid-South about currency inflation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- An unexpectedly large number of out-of-town buyers came into the local wholesale dry goods market in this between-holiday week, buying heavily to replace depleted lines and preparing for January and February sales.

THE development of the United States Employment Service of the Department of Labor has been one of the real achievements of the past year.
