It came into being, under the Wagner-Peyser Act, on July 1, and while it is only six months old, marked progress has already been made in setting up the machinery for putting men and women back to work as jobs become available.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- The "old dealers," those opposed to Roosevelt's recovery program, are the real radicals, according to Jerome N. Frank, general counsel for the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, in an address today at the final session of the annual meeting of the Association of American Law Schools.

If the plans drafted by the Board of Transportation for conversion of the Long Island Railroad's Rockaway division into a part of the city's rapid transit system are adopted, residents of the Rockaways will pay a 15-cent fare to and from Manhattan, according to the Transportation Board's report submitted to the Board of Estimate.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 30. -- The Chaco situation darkened again today in view of Paraguay's refusal to continue the peace negotiations until the League of Nations commission provides guarantees against the renewal of hostilities by Bolivia.

ANTICIPATION is raised by the first glimpse of this slender quaint octavo volume in pale green boards on which is reproduced the drawing made by Phiz (Hablot K. Browne) for the wrapper for the original issue in parts of "David Copperfleld," 1849-50.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The text of the silver regulations made public today was as follows:

Business conditions at the close of the year exceeded expectations in most sections of the country, although the West Coast reflected dragging tendencies and resorted to sales immediately after the Christmas holiday to liquidate surplus merchandise.

The action of General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, in repudiating the master code that had been sent out to all banking groups in the country and in postponing indefinitely the application of this code was welcomed yesterday by New York banks.

IF this life of Dorothy Wordsworth were but the biography of the passionately devoted sister of one of England's great poets it would be chiefly interesting only to Wordsworthians. But Dorothy Wordsworth, as we see her in her daily round of helpfulness as reconstructed by the skillful pen of Ernest de Selincourt, is not merely the sister of a great writer.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 -- Prosecution of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company and its taxicab subsidiaries for their refusal to obey the decision of the National Labor Board in the Philaadelphia taxicab strike was formally requested of the board today by S. Davis Wilson, city controller.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- A 6 per cent reduction of salaries of State employes earning less than $2,000 a year and a "pay as you go" policy instead of borrowing money and other suggested economies are the high spots in the recommendations which the Budget Advisory Board has submitted to Governor Lehman.

NOW that Newfoundland has surrendered its status as an autonomous community -- the result of its desperate financial plight -- and reverted to the status of a Crown colony, five dominions remain in the British Common-wealth of Nations: These are Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and the Irish Free State.

THE motto of the Department of State for 1933 as well as for the future may well be the statement of President Roosevelt in his inaugural address, "In the field of world policy I would dedicate this nation to the policy of the good neighbor."

The United States Commissioner of Education said a few days ago that we are now "faced with the greatest crisis in American education." The financial support of the public school system has suffered a "rude shock" and in a few places it has "all but broken down." But it is well to remember that a crisis means a decisive moment, a turning-point, for better or for worse.

RADIO programs should not be thrown together haphazardly; there is no excuse for carelessness, because it is easy to have a varied yet coherent broadcast, according to Jose Iturbi, noted pianist, who is soloist today with the symphony orchestra playing at WJZ's largest studio at 6 o'clock.

More than 1,000 guests thronged the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night when the second in a series of interschool and college dances was given by young women of society and undergraduates of many colleges and preparatory schools.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 30. -- The formal opening of the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club's new club-house at Albuoy's Point took place this afternoon, and was attended by W.J. Love, Herbert S. Stone, editor of Yachting, and Clifford Mallory.

The Treasury Department's complete monthly report of the stock of all kinds of money in the United States as of Dec. 1 shows the following principal changes in November. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted; gold released from earmark is added.

HANGCHOW, Dec. 30. -- Despite the fact that civil warfare is raging with growing intensity on a long front less than 200 miles to the south of Hangchow, this city, Chekiang's Provincial capital, which centuries ago excited Marco Polo's admiration, shows little interest in and no alarm over the Fukien rebels' attempt to conquer Chekiang.

The closing year saw little change in the muddle that surrounds the world's heavyweight wrestling championship. Five grapplers, four in this country and one in Europe, presented themselves as titleholders, and each received considerable recognition.

Improvement in business conditions was nation-wide this month, according to the report of the busines survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, made public yesterday. Checking against the situation prevailing at the end of November, the committee found that a general improvement in the unemployment situation, a rise in commodity prices, larger inventories and better collections marked the present month.

The crowning of the youngest champion in court tennis since Jay Gould was in the plenitude of his powers and the extension of the veteran Clarence C. Pell's reign as national champion in hard racquets to a twelfth year were the outstanding features of the past year in these two indoor court games.

I SEND you the following information concerning lynchings for the year 1933. I find according to the records compiled in the Department of Records and Research of the Tuskegee institute that there were 28 persons lynched in 1933.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 30. -- United States Senators have brains two ounces heavier than Representatives, if the ratio of a partial examination of living American statesmen continues unaltered to the finish of an experiment reported to the American Association for the Advancement of Science today.

Polo in the past year was without an international series when Great Britain found it impossible to challege, but the season saw a new event which was, in several respects, the most important occurrence in polo in modern years.

THE outstanding feature in the extension of legal protection for labor during 1933 is the adoption of codes of fair competition under the National Recovery Act which restrict child labor, limit hours of service, establish minimum wage levels and otherwise improve the standards and working conditions of labor.

NEW efficiency methods marked the removal of the midweek 10.7-inch snowfall from New York City streets. Of all municipal activities, the hurried clearing away of snow has been the one most likely to be attended by extravagance and even fraud.

TOKYO. WHEN ideas are scarce Japanese producers turn to the newspapers and when news stories fail them -- or are forbidden by the police -- they adapt a successful serial. One such picture of modern Japan, taken from a prize-winning serial published by the Sunday Mainichi, entitled "Life Today" and alleged to be rich in human interest, attracted this observer of life today to the Imperial Cinema Palace, Shinjuku.

SOFIA, Dec. 15. -- Recent investigations reveal that there are 158 persons in Bulgaria who are more than 100 years old. This figure, in proportion to the total population, gives Bulgaria third place for the world record, Lithuania being first and Portugal second.

THE history of man's wars by sea is studded with bright particular great occasions, romantic, spectacular, significant, but it is doubtful if any of them can excel in these aspects the expedition of the Spanish Armada. The vast amount of literature it has inspired is proof of how its qualities have won the attention of writers and public alike.

All restrictions upon withdrawals from savings banks in the State are expected to be removed this week by the Superintendent of Banking. The last reason for maintaining them will have passed, in the view of savings bankers, with the inauguration of the plan for temporary guaranty of deposits covering accounts up to $2,500 by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which organization the mutual savings banks have joined.

BOSTON, Pec. 29. THOSE who detected a change of mind and heart in the O'Neill of "Ah, 'Wilderness!" will be more confident of the new birth when they look upon "Days Without End." They may even say that the first piece is the reborn O'Neill writing homely comedy; while the second is the changed playwright busy with grave, tense drama.

A revised and rejuvenated National Horse Show brought to a close an interesting if not a brilliant season of equine exhibitions in and out of doors. The directorate of the Garden event eliminated many outmoded classes and offered a series of programs that pleased the largest gatherings in a number of years.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 30. -- All ten occupants of a British airliner were burned to death today when the plane crashed into a 762-foot wireless mast at Ruysselede, between Ghent and Bruges, and plunged to the ground in flames.

Douglas Sheridan, 65 years old, a stock broker, was found beaten to death in his apartment on the second floor of the Grinnell Apartments, 800 Riverside Drive, at West 157th Street, shortly before 2 o'clock this morning.

Last week's calling of securities for redemption before their dates of maturity was chiefly of issues to be paid next year, particularly after January. The calls consisted of small lots of State and municipal bonds and warrants, besides a few foreign loans.
RYE, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- Many New Year's Eve dances will be held tomorrow at the country clubs in Westchester County.

DISCERNING decorators appreciate the new bandwoven fabrics and the attention the makers give to original textures. The design often arises from the process of weaving. A robust appearance is now favored, and the rugged individualistic hand-woven fabrics present a pleasing foil to the smoother, machine-made textiles which may be used with them.

ROME, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Premier Mussolini announced tonight the names of thirteen new commissioners to take over the control of Italy's great confederations of industry, agriculture, commerce and the professions and centralize them under the Premier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Speaker Rainey predicted today that silver advocates in the House would insist upon a more liberal silver remonetization measure than was proposed yesterday by the group of Senate silver advocates.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- John H. McVeagh of New York City, second secretary of the American Embassy in Paris, has been designated as second secretary of the legation and consul at Monrovia, Liberia.

By breaking 95 out of 100 targets Z.G. Simmons annexed the high scratch cup in the shoot at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. J.G. Shattuck, who was the only gunner to return a full card of 100, took the handicap prize.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- Inexorably the juggernaut of the National Socialist revolution continues to roll over the last remnants of the "liberalistic era" of Germany and to crush the few remaining personal liberties and privileges of the German people.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30. -- Under sunny skies, the twenty-two-day meeting at Tropical Park got under way auspiciously today with the Shandon Farm's Evergold showing the way to a band of fleet sprinters in the Inaugural Handicap while a crowd of 15,000 looked on.

HARTFORD, Dec. 28. -- Governor Wilbur L. Cross, retired dean of the Yale Graduate School and still editor of The Yale Review, has before him a problem in English, namely, the definition of "emergency." The Connecticut Constitution, providing for biennial sessions of the General Assembly, authorizes additional sessions for "special emergencies" at other times and makes the Chief Executive the sole judge of what constitutes an emergency.

In preparing their famous annual entertainment -- the Beaux-Arts Ball -- members of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects are adapting to plans for decoration much of the skill and artistry that have brought international recognition to their professional work.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Beating Willis Ward of Michigan by the slender margin of two votes, Duane Purvis, Purdue's mighty man of football and the javelin, was named the outstanding Big Ten athlete for 1933 by conference coaches and sports writers.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 27. -- The answer to a currently popular song, "Where's Elmer?" is pretty much the answer to the question as to where Texas and Oklahoma stand on currency inflation. In this case, of course, Elmer is Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma.

HOLLYWOOD. WITH the approach of the new year, Hollywood solemnly and, no doubt, honestly issues the customary predictions and resolutions. There are to be no more cycles. Pictures are to be cleaner and better.

Paying tribute to the part which the NRA played in pulling the country out of the depression and in creating retail sales increase during the last half of the year, leading merchants predicted continued gains in 1934 in a telegraphic and local survey made during the week by THE TIMES.

London, Dec. 30. Dear Mr. President: YOU have made yourself the trustee for those in every country who seek to men the evils of our condition by reasoned experiment within the framework of the existing social system.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Dec. 30. -- President Roosevelt appealed indirectly to the Missouri Legislature today to guard against enactment of liquor-control legislation which would permit return of the open saloon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Dr. William A. Taylor, chief of the Bureau of Plant Industry in the Department of Agriculture, retired today after more than forty-two years of service, twenty of which were spent as head of the bureau.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- President Roosevelt today appointed Grenville T. Emmet of New York, Minister to the Netherlands.

DUBLIN, Dec. 30. -- Blue Shirts in the thousands, with women supporters wearing blue blouses, attended today at Bandon, County Cork, the funeral of Hugh O'Reilly, who will rank as the first martyr to the Blue Shirt cause.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 27. -- While this State is experiencing one of the coldest holiday seasons on records the Minnesota Historical Society appropriately has reprinted from its records accounts of a steamboat excursion on the Mississippi River from St. Paul to Fort Snelling as part of the New Year's Day celebration in 1878.

I HAVE been asked what two years of investigation by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency has disclosed. It is difficult to make an adequate reply in a brief article, for the hearings have already produced more than 5,000 pages of printed report, and not one of these pages is valueless as shedding light on Stock Exchange practices, banking and income tax methods.

LONDON. HAVING established himself in power by suppressing his opponents with an armed militia; having rallied millions to his support by appeals to race pride and race prejudice; having declared that he was out to destroy the Treaty of Versailles, upon which the peace of Europe (such as it is) reposes; having repudiated the only existing international machinery for adjusting differences between States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- President Roosevelt was represented in administration circles today as having approved a new and permanent policy under which some 50,000,000 acres of submarginal lands would be retired from cultivation at a cost of about $350,000,000.

A picture of former License Commissioner James F. Geraghty as one who dictated what racing sheets should and should not be sold on news stands, and as one who gave "the run around" to a spokesman for disabled veterans who had applied in vain for licenses, was painted yesterday by two witnesses before License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine, who continued his inquiry into news-stand license graft.

To the Drama Editor: Few "expressions of human genius" come in for such bitter and frequent condemnation as the theatre. Joseph Verner Reed's farewell to Times Square in THE TIMES of Dec. 24 is one of at least a dozen tolerant or angry dismissals that have appeared during the year in daily newspapers and liberal weekly magazines.

The New York Rangers brought the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world's professional hockey championship, to this city for the first time since 1928 by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, three games to one, in a tense series last April. Their achievement marked a precedent in the National Hockey League, for the Rangers were the first team ever to win the championship after finishing the league race third in their group.
Competition among speed boats grew to record heights during 1933. There were more regattas than in any previous year, and far more contesting craft and drivers.

It is understood that the North German Lloyd liner Bremen will dock at Pier 86, North River, when she arrives here on her next voyage on Jan. 18 in command of Commodore Leopold Ziegenbein. The Europa, which is due to arrive on Jan. 4, will be the last of the two express liners to dock at the foot of Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 30 (AP). -- The women came off second best today in a scientist's appraisal of what's wrong with the world before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 15. -- It goes without saying that the diamond trade and the diamond industry in recent years have suffered seriously from events in finance and economics. In a world of decreasing prosperity diamonds are finding fewer and fewer buyers, while the people who are still buying have, of course, smaller means available for the purchasing of precious stones.

TORONTO, Ont., Dec. 30. -- Ontario's mining officials estimate primary production in 1933 at $192,000,000, compared with $182,681,000 in 1932. This is an increase of about 5 per cent. Production is led by gold and nickel. Minerals will top wheat and forest products in value of exports.

HOW many of our unemployed university graduates could find jobs if they would turn their backs upon the lure of the big city? Most of them, answered President Butler of Columbia University in his report published last week.

LONDON, Dec. 14, 1933. THE Autumn season has been one of great activity. Orchestras and soloists in great numbers have performed before audiences which, alas! were seldom numerous enough to repay the gallant adventurers for their labors.

AT its annual "Winter meeting, held last week in Boston, the American Association for the Advancement of Science roamed as usual through the vast universe, contemplating stars and atoms, dinosaurs and microbes, in an all-embracing sweep of its scientific eye.

ONCE the excitement of Christmas is over there is nothing more thoroughly satisfying than to give new life to one's wardrobe. it is symbolic of starting the year afresh. Nineteen thirty-four is ushering in some more-than-pleasing new ideas, and telling ones, too.

WHATEVER emotion may be inspired today by the strains of the American national anthem, it can have little affinity with the original mood in which the lines were created. Stripped of the associations that nave grown up around them for 12O years, the words indicate through what anxious torment the author must have passed during that eventful night in the War of 1812.

Many debutantes of this season and former years are active in arranging the Yankee Doodle Ball which is to take place Tuesday night at the St. Regis. The event is being sponsored by Auxiliary No. 6 for the benefit of Stony Wold Sanatorium.
THE navy had 919 serviceable airplanes on hand at the end of the fiscal year 1933.

There once seems to have been a time when a world of sport, surfeited with performances par excellence and usually by the same performers, set up a great hue and cry. It shouted, "An upset, an upset, a kingdom for an upset."

BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- A further step to bring about what is declared to be "the inner union of the press" has been taken with the final organizing of the new Reich Press Chamber as a department of the Chamber of Culture established by Dr. Goebbels, with himself as president.

NOW that Maine has completed a 120-mile section of the great Appalachian Trail, and expects soon to finish fifty miles more, vigorous hikers in a few months will be able to walk from Mount Oglethorpe, Ga., to Mount Katahdin, Me., a distance of 2,056 miles along this master trail.

IN the waning sunset of each year marchers of previous weeks and months in sports pass in final review. Ranged like the battalions of infantry, each division moves once more through the spotlight. In front, carrying the glittering sabers of rank, are the champions and the winners, their records standing out for one last time on their way to the obscurity of record books.

Operating under radical changes in the playing rules, lacrosse had another thriving year in 1933, as the sport continued to show increased interest and activity. Once more it was Johns Hopkins which dominated collegiate play and won the national championship.

Devotees of chess in this country have every reason to look back with pride upon the happenings in 1933. A representative United States team scored a second triumph in the biennial tournament of the International Chess Federation, held at Folkestone, England, during July.
BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- Two World War comrades, Ignaz Westenkirchner, a carpenter from Reading, Pa., and Chancellor Hitler met this evening for the first time since the war.
As the last Sunday of the dying year arrives, the Fund for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases has reached $218,767.98.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30. -- The Soviet Government published today the basic figures and an outline of the second Five-Year Plan as it is to be presented for the consideration of the Communist party congress the end of the month by Premier Molotoff and V.V. Quibysheff, president of the State Planning Commission.

The downfall of Ralph Greenleaf, perennial holder of the world's pocket billiard championship, as he sought his thirteenth title, marked the 1933 billiard campaign. Unbeaten in the past two seasons of championship play, Greenleaf met with defeat seven times in the title tournament and yielded his crown to Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland.
Those who were fortunate enough to rank among the leading women's field hockey players in this country enjoyed not only a successful year in the sport but an unusual one as well.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Prolongation of studies by President Roosevelt today grave rise to reports in official circles that the Chief Executive might break another precedent and withhold delivery of his budget message beyond the second day of the new session of Congress, the customary time for its delivery.

THE recent discovery by archaeologists headed by Dr. Kirsopp Lake of Harvard of Jezebel's Tower in Samaria recalls the colorful history of that Queen whose name is still used as a synonym for an abandoned woman, or one who "paints her face."

To the Editor of The New York Times: When the New Deal went into effect in this country many English newspapers and public men relishingly announced to the world that it signaled the death of democracy in America and that we had Joined the countries committted to dictatorships.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 27. -- The currency issue in that part of the Middle West represented by Iowa, Nebraska and Kansas does not involve a conflict between support of the President's policies and a return to the gold standard. It is a question rather of continuing to support Roosevelt or of plunging into the maelstrom of a huge paper-money inflation.

HAVANA, Dec. 30. -- Conforming to the international sugar agreement signed at Brussels during the Machado regime President Grau San Martin today affixed his signature to the decree setting the 1933-1934 sugar crop at 2,315,459 long tons and ordering the grinding season to start on Jan. 15.

Opposition to a sweeping grant of power to Mayor-elect LaGuardia and to propose "ripper" legislation in the guise of reform was expressed yesterday by Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn, minority leader of the Assembly.
Members of the board of trustees of the American Colleges in the Near East have arranged for a special performance of "La Boheme" for the afternoon of Jan. 26 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

OSLO. IN two new volumes, "Men Livet Lever," Knut Hamsun brings to a close the trilogy that in leisurely fashion, beginning with "Vagabonds," has told the story of the restless, irresistible wanderer, August, whose name forms the second title in the series.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 30. -- The anatomy of a disordered galaxy, which is "in a way the key with which to unlock some of the mysteries in the cosmic spaces outside our own Milky Way system," was presented here tonight by Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard College Observatory and one of the world's leading astronomers and cosmologists.

FARGO, N.D., Dec. 25. -- A welldefined trend away from cash crops to feed crops and more livestock during the last twelve years is the story of farming in the Northwest as revealed in a very thorough agricultural survey just completed by H.R. Danielson and R.S. Kifer, farm economists of the North Dakota Agricultural College.

A dance was given last night by Jules S. Bache at the Park Lane for his two granddaughters, Miss Dorothy Richards, a debutante of this season, and her sister, Miss Muriel Richards, who made her debut a couple of years ago. They are daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Lloyd Richards.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Great Britain enters 1934 with a greatly improved economic outlook and a pugnacious determination that her further progress toward prosperity will not be impeded by what she regards as misdeeds of other trading nations.

All domestic markets that remained open yesterday managed to close the year with a hopeful flourish. This was in keeping with the New Year's tradition and it sent the members of the financial community away for the week-end in a cheerful frame of mind.

A FOREIGNER'S analysis of the United States is likely to be interesting for a reason different from that which interests us in a home-brew analysis. We learn something about French civilization by reading what a civilized Frenchman thinks about America.
If there has been a year in lawn tennis more filled with sensational developments than was 1933, the records fail to do it justice.

TORONTO, Dec. 30 (AP). -- The Maple Leafs launched a high-powered attack that swept them to an 8-1 victory over Detroit Red Wings tonight in a fast, wide-open National Hockey League game. The winners scored twice in the first period, then staged a furious five-goal splurge in the second and added another in the third.

READING, Pa., Dec. 30. -- This city on Monday will see the retirement of the last of the Socialists who at one time controlled every office in City Hall, having charge of five departments of the municipal government. Republican-Democratic Fusionists elected in November will hold every department for two years.

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- The scientific utility of flights into the stratosphere, even when scientific observations are not practical, was defended here in an interview by Professor Maurain of the Academy of Sciences and one of France's most eminent physicists.

AN extraordinary idea has taken root in the brain of Paul Muni. One of the most celebrated character actors in America, whose versatility during his twenty-seven years on the stage has earned him the title of the Man of 250 Paces, Mr. Muni has brooded and fretted himself into a conviction that he is a routine-type actor.

The financial position of the railways was discussed last week in Washington. It is estimated that obligations maturing in 1934 will amount to $480,000,000. "Some plan of Government assistance will have to be worked out," in the opinion of the chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 30. -- The State Sinking Fund Commission made public today a statement which the legislative committee refused yesterday to accept.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec, 30. -- In honor of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Gale, Mrs. James H. Kennedy was dinner hostess tonight at Kenlewinai. Her guests were Mr. and Mrs. Wlley R. Reynolds, Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Shaughnessy, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Oakes with Justice Courtney Kingston, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Howes, Mrs, Ward Ames, Miss Margaret Crowley, Miss Mary Crowley, Buckner Chipley and Nathan D. Bill.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- President Roosevelt returned to the States tonight the authority over their banks which was temporarily taken from them during the March banking crisis.

BOSTON, Dec. 28. -- New England enters the new year with sound warrant for good hopes of the future. These six States have been hard hit, but at no time did they slide as far into the depths as did other sections. There is a long climb ahead, but, speaking in general terms and with due regard for some bad spots, a real start has been made and the upward trend is expected to continue.

PARIS, Dec. 30. -- Georges Clemenceau's worries over the separation of the American Army from the French led him to say to Raymond Poincare that the Allied forces were being exposed to disaster, M. Poincare says in the tenth volume of his memoirs, the first extracts of which are just being published in La Matin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Industrial production remained virtually unchanged from recently prevailing levels in the week ended on Dec. 23, according to the Weekly survey by the Department of Commerce, made public today.

Stuttering is a natural phenomenon and should not be considered as an abnormality, in the opinion of Dr. Robert West, Professor of Speech at the University of Wisconsin, who spoke yesterday at the annual convention of the American Society for the Study of Disorders of Speech in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

OTTAWA, Dec. 30 (Canadian Press). -- The Canadian Government today filled seven of the thirteen Senate vacancies by appointing three from Ontario and two each from Quebec and Saskatchewan. No women were included.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 27 -- Interest in the Inter-American Highway has been revived and re- newed here by the statement of President Roosevelt on the Pan-American Highway prospects and the enthusiasm of the American Minister, Leo J. Sack.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Football rules for 1934 will undergo no radical revisions, in the opinion of Walter Okeson, renamed chairman of the football rules committee at the final day's session of the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention today.

A large increase in bond offerings and a slight rise in stock offering's marked new financing here in December compared with November. The increase in bond flotations was far from enough to raise the figures to or above those of a year ago.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 30. -- Nelson N. Moneypenny Jr., 38 years old, of 346 Fairway Road, Ridgewood, where he was a member of the Board of Education, was killed early today when his automobile struck a truck trailer on Maple Avenue, Glen Rock.

On his last active day in office yesterday, Mayor O'Brien picked two surprise appointees for the Magistrates' Court and at the same time appointed former Magistrate Thomas F. McAndrews, his secretary, as a justice of the Court of Special Sessions.

Largely because of the momentum from the President's silver proclamation at the end of the preceding week, prices for commodity futures on local exchanges moved slightly higher and trading increased in the short week ended on Friday.
All markets, as well as banking and business organizations generally, will suspend operations tomorrow for the New Year's celebration. Business will be resumed as usual on Tuesday morning.
DANVILLE, Ind., Dec. 30 (AP). -- Dr. Jonathan Rigdon, author and educator, died today at his home here, at the age of 75, after a brief illness.

AFTER twenty-six years of absence, Strauss's "Salome" will make its appearance again at the Metropolitan Opera House next week, with Gota Ljungberg in the title role. During that interval an immense change has been wrought in the conception of stage decor and the function of setting and costuming.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday an amendment to its rules concerning contracts for customers' men that will make it possible for member firms to renew the contracts of such employes at intervals of not less than three months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Please, on behalf of the thousands of your readers who are lovers of Charles Dickens and his immortal "Christmas Carol," allow me space to protest the sacrilege that has just been practiced in broadcasting over WABC the garbled monstrosity of that beautiful story.

A year that ordinarily would have been momentous because of the installation of the metric system as the official unit of track measurement in the United States, became one of the brightest seasons in many years as the result of races run at a mile.

Alex Hurd, the Hamilton (Ont.) flyer, will defend the Middle Atlantic senior men's outdoor speed-skating championship tomorrow in the annual meet on Polly Lake in Downing Park, Newburgh, N.Y. Hurd, a member of the Canadian Olympic team, annexed the crown last season with a total of 90 points.

The German point of view as to the present arms discussions and problems Europe is facing today was explained yesterday by Baronvon Kuehlmann, former Foreign Minister for Germany, just before he sailed for home on the Europa.

The listed bond market was generally higher in the final trading period of the year yesterday. Trading on the Stock Exchange aggregated $6,023,000, compared with $5,580,000 on the previous Saturday. United States Government bonds finished generally higher despite the weakness in the dollar in the foreign exchange market, closing 7-32 point higher to 4-32 lower.
The Neediest Cases published herewith are among the more than a hundred still awaiting relief. All these, like the others, have been investigated, and their worthiness and extreme need established.

MADRID, Dec. 12, 1933. SPANISH political unrest appears to have had little effect on the current activities, in the concert field, of the country's two leading music centres, judging from, the number and attendance at the Fall's recitals and symphonic offerings in Madrid and Barcelona.

PARIS, Dec. 30. -- The police today made further search among the effects of Robert Gordon Switz of East Orange, N.J., for information supplementing documents which the young American claims were placed in his hotel room by persons wishing to implicate him in an international espionage plot.

THE outstanding event of the year for the navy was the allocation of funds from the National Industrial Recovery Act by the President for the purpose of constructing and equipping thirty-two naval vessels. This program is in close accord with the purposes of the National Recovery Act, since it will substantially aid employment and the restoration of commercial, industrial and agricultural activity.

Francis Scott Key's autograph manuscript of "The Star-Spangled Banner," with a unique copy of the earliest printed broadside of the great American anthem, representing the first complete manuscript draft and the first printing, will be features of a sale at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday evening and on Friday afternoon and evening.

DENVER, Dec. 28. -- Despite definite statement from the Federal Relief Administrator, Harry L. Hopkins, that unless the Colorado Legislature made some effort to provide State relief funds, a Federal aid would be cut off Jan. 1, the Legislature has adjourned until Jan. 3.

The annual debutantes' New Year's ball will be held tomorrow night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. It will be under the patronage of Mrs. Moses Taylor Pyne Jr., Mrs. Warner Van Norden, Mrs. Harold O. Barker, Mrs. Loring Hoover, Mrs. Frederick Sturges, Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel and Mrs. Irving Berlin.
The staging of competition for the International Challenge Cup after a lapse of fourteen years was the outstanding development in canoeing during 1933.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30. -- Waves whipped up by a brisk wind defeated the efforts of all except two contestants to break records today in the final tests of the Olympic stars' meet in the Miami Biltmore pool.
NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. Albert Vander Veer and their debutante daughter, Miss Margaret Luisa Vander Veer are giving a New Year's reception tomorrow afternoon at 158 East Seventy-fourth Street.
ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- Following is the text of recommendations for amendments to the Workmen's Compensation Law, contained in the report of a committee of physicians to Governor Lehman:

MANY outstanding accomplishments mark the year just ended. I assumed the office of Secretary of the Interior on March 4. During the early Summer I was named Public Works Administrator, and still later was designated as Administrator of the Oil Code under the National Recovery Administration. Through the allocation of public works funds many Interior Department projects were speeded up and employment given to many thousands which otherwise would have been impossible.
A sharp rise in temperature yesterday afternoon heralded a break in the cold wave that, since Wednesday, has taken a toll of more than 100 lives throughout the nation.

LONDON. PARIS uncovers a spy plot and rumors fly about the capitals of Europe. A retired Yugoslav Colonel is hanged in a Belurade prison for selling military secrets to Italians and Hungarians. A petty officer in the Italian Navy is shot for espionage in favor of "a neighboring State."

To the Editor of The New York Times: With General Douglas MacArthur sounding alarm at the state to which Congress has permitted our army to reach, due to its caring for the Civilian Conservation Corps, it seems timely to recommend a plan economically sound and patriotically perfect, i.e., to increase the size of our little regular army to 18,000 officers and 250,000 enlisted men.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Characterizing the Securities Act of 1933 as "perhaps the most outstanding of the permanent reform legislation passed by the Seventy-third Congress," the Federal Trade Commission in its annual report, made public today, promised a careful and fair administration of its provisions.

Ten city P.S.A.L. senior high school team championships changed hands in 1933 and during the year no school won more than two of those titles. Just four crowns remained in possession of their 1932 winners and of those, two were kept by New Utrecht's track and field squad and one by Curtis High's cross-country team as those groups extended long winning streaks.

LONDON. ST. JOHN ERVINE has raised a question which has started all sorts of people writing letters to the newspapers. Mr. Eryine has been told by an unnamed reporter that "any person who becomes 'news' or in any way connected with 'news' immediately ceases to have any rights and may have his privacy invaded at any hour of the day or night by 'news-hounds' baying for 'copy'."

From practically every angle trotting and pacing enjoyed a better year in 1933 than had been the case for the last few seasons. Competition was better, the attendances improved at not only the big meetings but at almost every half-mile track, and interest seemed to have been wider as new owners and stables began to appear.

THE vast and largely unknown continent of the Antarctic is again being attacked by two expeditions, both of them American. The lure of the Antarctic is as strong as its area seems limitless; once a man has been there he generally wishes to return.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Dec. 30. -- Coming back strongly after nearly being headed at the turn into the stretch, the Pasadena Stable's Erech won the featured fifth race at the Agua Caliente track today. Prevue was second, beaten by a length and a half, and Andale was third.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- The Stock Exchange was closed today for the usual year-end holiday. Money was plentiful, with loans over the weekend at only one-half of 1 per cent. The discount market was weak, With three-month bills at 11-16 per cent.
To the Music Editor: The People's Chorus of New York has something to offer which I feel should be made known to the public.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Acting Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury made public today the regulations governing the purchase and coinage of silver under the terms of President Roosevelt's proclamation of Dec. 21.

HIGHLIGHTS of the second week of the Metropolitan Opera season include a New Year's Day performance of "The Emperor Jones," with Lawrence Tibbett in the name part; the return, after an absence of several years, of Claudia Muzio in "Traviata' and the season's first "Don Giovanni."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The retail food and grocery code, considered one of the most important government charters under the NRA, and involving 480,000 grocers who employ more than 1,000,000 persons, was signed today by President Roosevelt, making a total of 182 codes he has now approved.

HELSINGFORS, Dec. 30. -- The police reported today that a housemaid had confessed having killed by poisoning Lieut. Col. Walter Asplund, manager of the largest Finnish munitions factory, last Spring, at the direction of high Communist leaders.

HAVANA, Dec. 30. -- Unless the Cuban Government immediately modifies the recently enacted workmen's compensation law which has caused cancellation of insurance policies by foreign casualty companies effective Dec. 31 most large industrial and commercial concerns will close their doors Jan. 2.

The year 1933 marked the beginning of the ignoble experiment. All liquor plans so far in effect or proposed are far more experimental than prohibition was, and each has for its far from noble purpose the provision of conveniently accessible intoxicating liquor which is a narcotic habit-forming poison.
All utility reports are consolidated returns including subsidiaries unless otherwise specified.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- A supper dance such as has not been held at the White House in many years tonight marked virtually the only observance of the new year at the White House.

IF the theatre is trivial, the reason is clear. The great themes are difficult to express. The journeyman playwright who is blessed with facility and flair can produce without much difficulty the bits of fluff that keep the theatres lighted.

Columbia back-field legerdemain will be the chief reliance of the Lions at Pasadena tomorrow, when they pit their speed and deception against the Goliaths from Stanford in the Rose Bowl classic. On these qualities of their play, the New Yorkers will base their hopes of victory over their Coast rivals.

The Tournament of Roses football game at Pasadena on New Year's Day, now one of the gridiron sport's most glamourous spectacles, had a humble beginning forty-four years ago as a hunts meeting. At that time football was undreamed of as a Rose Bowl attraction.

PARIS, Dec. 29. -- Christmas was terribly saddened for France by the railroad catastrophe at Lagny last Saturday night, when more than 200 persons, mostly on the way to their homes in the country to spend the week-end, were killed, and 300 were injured.

The lowest death rate in the history of New York City in 1933, the fourth year of the depression, is shown in the annual report submitted to Mayor O'Brien yesterday by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, retiring Commissioner of Health. Dr. Wynne attributed the results to "practical, realistic, long-range planning."

AGRICULTURE may look back upon 1938 in either of two ways, each legitimate from a certain standpoint. It may say that the year gave hope in place of despair and lifted many farm enterprises out of the red. Or it may look upon the year as a challenge to develop new ways of thinking and acting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30. -- Apparently not yet satisfied with their squad's performance, coaches of the Eastern team that will meet the West in the annual charity football game here New Year's Day sent their charges through a vigorous workout today.

FOR its second annual exhibition of "American Genre Paintings" the Newhouse Gallery has assembled nearly seventy pictures, an effort having been successfully made to carry on the story of art's pioneer days in this country.
NOW that NRA has arisen to correct a lot of abuses abroad in the land, it is proposed that it shall abolish tipping.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- Foreign Commissar Litvinoff's reference to the present state of Soviet-German relations, which he made in the course of his address yesterday to the Soviet Central Executive Committee, provoked spirited, if not acrimonious, replies in a large section of the German press.

GRETA GUSTAFSON, better known in North and South America, Asia, Europe, Australia, and Antarctica, as Greta Garbo, has emerged at the Astor as the star of "Queen Christina." She was born in Stockholm, Sweden, Sept. 18, 1906, and at the age of 14 went to work soaping chins in a barber shop.

SHAWNEE, Okla., Dec. 30. -- The "Tri-State Terror," Wilbur Underhill, killer, bank robber, machine gunner and prison breaker, lay in a dying condition tonight, his body almost riddled by police bullets, and law-enforcement agencies checked off another name on the dwindling list of Southwestern bad men still at large.

A practical plan for the control of manufacturing costs, upon which uniform accounting systems of trade associations will be based, has been adopted in part by the National Recovery Administration, it was disclosed here yesterday by the originators of the program, W. Clement Moore, managing director of the bureau of trade analysis of the Philadelphia Board of Trade, and John K. Hulse, certified public accountant.

TOKYO, Dec. 30 (AP). -- A gain of 33 per cent over 1932 was shown in Japan's foreign trade in returns for 1933, just published, as the government closed the year's trade ledgers for the New Year holidays.

DURING the fiscal year 1933 there was a marked improvement in the postal finances. Notwithstanding a continued decline in the volume of mail of all classes, the higher letter postage rate enabled the department to maintain its revenues at approximately the level of the preceding year -- $588,000,000. On the other hand, expenditures for all purposes were reduced from $795,000,000 to $697,000,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Trading on the Chicago Stock Exchange in 1933 totaled 18,289,000 shares of stock and $1,433,000 par amount of bonds. The volume for December was 1,256,000 shares of stock and $111,000 bonds.
THE Old Year will be dramatized on the air whlie bells, songs and jazz bands turn the farewell to 1933 into a world-wide serenade for 1934.
THE aviation, industry in the United States will end the present year with many accomplishments and, at the same time two major problems are confronting it.

SINCE the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment many terms have been bandied about which are either misunderstood or misused. People speak of "straight" whisky, of "blended," "rectified" or "cut" whiskies, of whisky "bottled in bond," of "neutral spirits" and other things.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 30. -- Columbia's football team shook the dust of Arizona from its feet today an headed determinedly toward Callifornia, where on New Year's Day the Lions match, their speed against Stanford's brawn in the annual Rose Bowl classic.

Joe Miller of Buffalo won the national match game championship during the past season as bowling enjoyed another successful year. Miller first conquered Andy Varipapa and Barney Spinella, two leading New York players, to capture the Eastern elimination series.

Gold exports increased sharply in December over the previous month but were more than offset by reductions in earmarked holdings. It was the sixth consecutive month of exports without imports. The month's total of $9,086,000 compared with exports of $997,700 in November.

A movement to make officials and committees of the New York Stock Exchange more representative than ever before of the membership of the Exchange, through adoption of the principle of "rotation in office," is being sponsored by several firms holding membership in the Exchange.

PANAMA, Dec. 27. -- Kidnapping is not confined to the United States or other civilized countries. The savage Indians who inhabit the Goajira Peninsula in Colombia have some abvanced ideas on the subject, according to discoveries made by the Weston Carr Expedition now engaged in exploring this little-known region of Colombia.

DESPITE the fact that our public school kindergartens in America are sixty years old, they are still termed "fads" or "frills" in the modern school curriculum by many communities. Recent information from the Federal Office of Education reveals that fifty-two cities in twenty-four States eliminated kindergartens entirely in their public school systems during the period, September, 1930, to June, 1933.

Evening classes for adults in forty evening elementary schools, which were closed Dec. 13 as part of an economy program of the Board of Education, will reopen on Tuesday. The schools offer eight general courses.

A taxpayer's action has been brought in Supreme Court by Henry Fleischer, president of Fleischer Co., Inc., printers, of 480 Canal Street, against the Mayor, the Corporation Counsel and the Controller, as constituting the Board of City Record, to obtain an injunction against re-advertising for bids on city printing submitted on Dec. 19 and 21, it was announced yesterday by Edward I. Kaplan, attorney for Mr. Fleischer.

Debutantes of this and recent seasons will distribute programs at the Princeton-Toronto hockey match Wednesday night at the Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the free bed fund of the Post Graduate Hospital. Miss Victoria Brady heads the group of young women who will be assisted by twenty-five nurses in uniform from the Post Graduate Hospital.

Losses sustained during the season of 1933 by the five associations promoting thoroughbred racing in this State are estimated to be just short of $250,000, it was announced yesterday at the offices of the Jockey Club. During the year 1932 the same associations suffered a loss of $551,424.20.

Miss Isabel Ward made her debut last night at a dinner dance at the Pierre, given by Mr. and Mrs. James Lakerhan Ward. The debutante is the daughter of Mr. Ward and of Mrs. Atwood Ward, also of this city.

FOR one whose senses are attuned to the subtle manifestations of a dramatic artist, there is a never-to-be-forgotten thrill in first beholding one who stimulates those senses. The pulse quickens, the nerves vibrate and a strange excitation comes from the sudden realization that here is the theatre with its tresses unbound.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 27 (NANA). -- Any one really wanting to be a centenarian can do no better than settle in Verbasz, Macedonia. Of the 400 inhabitants twenty are over 100 years old and no death has occurred in the village for more than two years with the single exception of a new-born baby.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- The Catholic church, it became known today, has obtained three concessions from the Hitler Government which, in effect, exempt from the sterilization law in force Monday any Catholics unwilling to subject themselves to it.

Al Smith was 60 years old yesterday. He received a score and more of photographers, movie men and reporters in his spacious office overlooking lower New York and the East River, announced that politics was "absolutely out the window."

Recodification of the Fish and Game Laws will be proposed to the Legislature at the forthcoming session in Albany and it is the hope of every sportsman that the proposal will meet with the pleasure of the legislators and that the work will be completed as speedily as possible.

The spectacular sport of ski jumping enjoyed one of its most successful seasons during the 1932-1933 campaign. Especially in Eastern Winter sports circles, where several of the major tournaments in the country were staged under the auspices of the Eastern Amateur Ski Association, which is affiliated with the National Ski Association, did it flourish.

New Yorkers captured the lion't share of both the national and intercollegriate fencing championships during 1933 as interest increased in the sport. The supremacy of the New York entrants in many of the important competitions and an expansion of activity in the collegiate and scholastic ranks were the year's outstanding features.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Godfrey Merrill of this city gave a small dinner dance last night at Merle-brook House, their country home in Bedford, N.Y., to introduce their second daughter, Miss Priscilla Godfrey Merrill. The debutante was graduated last Spring from the Brearley School, and now is a student at Bennington College, Bennington, Vt., to which she will return after the holidays.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- How to beat Gifford Pinchot is the problem confronting Republican, organization leaders of Pennsylvania, who view with trepidation the approach of 1934, a critical year politically for the Commonwealth.

The inauguration of international competition for women with the invasion of a British team made the season of 1932-33 a red-letter one for squash racquets, while a full calendar of competition was carried out in both men's squash racquets and squash tennis.

Indications have recently been multiplying that the British Government is still resolved to maintain the entente with France. This relates principally, of course, to questions of foreign policy. It covers the attitude which both nations think it wise to assume in the presence of the new Germany.
THE year's vivid broadcasts are the sounds that echo in memory as the last day drops from the calendar.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 30. -- Professor Edward L. Thorndike, the psychologist, of Teachers College, Columbia University, was today chosen president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science to take office at its next meeting, at Pittsburgh in December, 1934.

The American Assistancy of the Society of Jesus has shown the greatest growth in membership and is the second largest assistancy in the order, according to the 1933 Prospectus of the Society of Jesus, published last week. The document, written entirely in Latin, was released locally by the Very Rev. Edward C. Phillips, Provincial of the Maryland-New York Province of the Order.

GROUCHO MARX, who is one of the four Chaplins of America, explained the other day that the firm (Harpo, Chico and Zeppo are still the other members) has finished with Paramount and the movies. At least for the time.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 29. -- The dramatic Gran Chaco peace negotiations have been more or less obscured by the fact that during its three weeks' deliberations the seventh Pan-American Conference brought forth a well-rounded economic philosophy for the American States.

DEAN of all the cowpunchers Patrick T. Tucker must surely be. But he modestly claims only to be "the oldest cowboy in Montana." He admits, says Mrs. Coates in her foreword, that there are men still living older than he who once were cowboys, but who are now? "magnates" of one sort or another, or merchants, or what not.

Rowing's season during 1933 included a new intercollegiate sprint regatta, the triumph of an American crew in the historic British Henley and a notable lapse when the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association at Poughkeepsie was suspended for the year.

ON the eve of the first commercially sponsored broadcast from the Metropolitan Opera, Giulio Gatti-Casazza, master of the "Met" for twenty-five years, looked back across two decades and traced the inevitable march of the microphone into the Golden Horseshoe.

THE National Automobile Snow, which will bring together for public presentation the products of more than a score of motor car manufacturers, will open in Grand Central Palace at 2 P.M. next Saturday. This thirty-fourth annual exhibition, scheduled to continue through Jan. 13, will present a greater variety of improvements and more significant ones than has been the case for several years, in the opinion of those who have gathered advance information about the exhibits.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 27. -- The majority of Missouri Senators and Representatives are either wary or hard to catch at home because telegrams dispatched to them relative to their views on the monetary program of President Roosevelt which will come before Congress failed to elicit replies.

More than one-third of the seagoing tonnage of the American merchant marine is laid up, according to information submitted by committees of ship operators to the National Industrial Recovery Administration. A wealth of data has been collected on wages, working conditions, capital investments and tonnage by groups concerned with the drafting of a code under the supervision of the administration.

Albert Silverschlage, 21 years old, of 523 East Thirteenth Street, was "taken for a ride" Friday night and shot with a revolver he helped to steal from a policeman, according to the police. After three bullets had entered his body Silverschlage played 'possum and lived to tell the police enough to get himself and four former comrades arrested for assault and robbery.

PUNCH-DRUNK prizefighters make new arrangements of vowels and consonants to express their inquietude. Blatant vaudevillians wrench syllables out of words to give vehemence to their staged emotions. Debutantes on dance floors and fishwives in Billingsgate, soldiers in trenches and touts at race tracks, all make slang.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 30. -- Stanford's football players put their last practice of the 1933 season behind them today and were ready for Monday and Columbia.

Swimmers made notable strides in 1933. Not only were fifty-two record-breaking feats officially claimed, thirty-two for men and twenty for women, but a number of others, equally authentic, went unchronicled because some one neglected to submit the required vouchers to the A.A.U.

LONDON. ONE of the principal measures before this Winter's session of Parliament is an elaborate scheme for the extension o the British system of unemployment insurance, and for the organization on a national scale of the relief granted to those who are involuntarily unemployed but unable to draw upon the insurance fund.

John. E. Joyce, referee in bankruptcy for the Louis K. Liggett Company, approved yesterday an offer of $9,915,863 by the United Drug Company for the assets of the bankrupt concern. Acceptance of the offer had been recommended by Thomas H. McInnerney, Chandler Hoven and R.A. Heyman, trustees in bankruptcy, who were authorized to proceed with the sale.

NEW YORK CITY'S school budget must be written so as to show Its purpose more clearly and its expenditures must be planned for several years ahead if a well-rounded school system is to be developed, in the opinion of the Public Education Associatlon.

M. THERESE BONNEY is an American woman who conducts a news service in Paris and whose avocation during the last ten years has been the collecting of interesting photographs, of more or less social, historical or personal consequence.
UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- Six suits involving more than $1,500,000,000 in guaranteed mortgages principally on New York City real estate, were filed in Federal court here yesterday.

A the survey in the adjoining columns indicates, retailers are moving into the new year with optimistic hopes that are in sharp contrast with the expressions of a year ago. They expect rising sales to continue and, what is more important, are backing up this belief with increased buying budgets.

THE "Fine Prints of the Year" are having their annual showing at the Brooklyn Museum, and offer one of the fine chances of the year to compare in character and technical quality the work of different nationalities.

DUBLIN, Dec. 29. -- The Irish Free State will enter the new year more sundered politically than it has been since the civil war in 1922. The unity President de Valera hoped to achieve during his administration is further from realization than when he assumed office two years ago.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins signed an order yesterday requiring five Manhattan bus companies to show cause next Friday why tfeey should not be temporarily restrained from operating under twenty-five-year franchises voted to them by the Board of Estimate on Dec. 22.

LONDON. IN Brazil they have been dumping unwanted coffee into the sea. In the United States surplus plantings of cotton have been plowed under. At first sight it might seem that the same tendency is illustrated by the growing movement among London publishers for a limitation of their output.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 27. -- The fear expressed in some quarters that the Congress soon to meet will take the financial bit in its teeth and bolt in the general direction of printing press inflation is not felt generally in the South. Naturally, among those who foresaw disaster if the United States left the gold standard there is an uneasiness concerning President Roosevelt's ability to keep Congress in the middle of the road.

RIO DE JANIERO, Dec. 30. -- The resignations of Jose Americo de Almeida as Minister of Public Works and Joaquim Pedro Salgado as Minister of Labor followed today those of Osvaldo Aranha and Dr. Afranio de Mello Franco as Ministers of Finance and Foreign Affairs, respectively.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 26. -- President Roosevelt's ratification of the London silver agreement has split the silver bloc and thus has nullified the demand for inflation so far as the intermountain States are concerned.
The past year was a bad one for favorites in golf, and in scarcely a single major tournament, certainly not one of the four outstanding championships, were the favored players successful.

ST. PAUL., Dec. 27. -- If questions concerning expansion of the currency come to a vote in the new session of Congress, the Congressional delegations of Minnesota and North and South Dakota will deliver practically a solid vote on the side of inflationism.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- General Hugh S. Johnson's suspension of the standard fair practice rules for banks, issued under NRA auspices but without the approval of the general himself, means that the banks must furnish new and satisfactory programs within thirty days or submit to regulations formulated by the Recovery Administration.

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- Since police investigation brought to light the theft by an art dealer of one of the stained-glass windows in the Cathedral of Fecamp and its subsequent sale in the United States there has been an epidemic of window verification in the churches throughout France.

Increases in holiday sales figures as compared with last year have encouraged retailers to look for good results during January, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. Retail stocks, the buying office added, are reported to be in good order, thus giving merchants the opportunity of making advantageous purchases for coming sales.

Federal relief payments to farmers are being made at a rate indicating that they will total one-third of the national income by the end of February, 1935, the American Economic Institute, 307 Fifth Avenue, declared yesterday.

A CRISIS in League affairs is shown by the fact that two members of the Council have given notice of their intention to withdraw from the League, and a third member has openly expressed her desire to see radical changes made in it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- New Year's is the time for frank appraisal of the year that is past and for the expression of our hopes and fears for the year that is to come.
VIENNA, Dec. 30. -- Victorious Hitlerism, which overshadowed South eastern Europe in 1933, will undoubtedly continue to do so in 1934.

The New Year finds statesmen of other countries rereading President Roosevelt's speech at the Wilson dinner in an effort to gauge the importance of his statements on the foreign policy of the United States. The reception of the address is remarkable in that it seems to have pleased both Paris and Berlin; that is no small accomplishment.

LONDON. JUST before leaving London to spend the holidays at home, Ambassador Bingham summed up his view of the English attitude toward the President and His policies. Unofficial observers have pointed out that no President since Wilson has caught the imagination, of the English, as Roosevelt is doing.

A "fog camera," which harnesses the infra-red ray, and is designed to extend the limit of visibility of the navigator from two to four times, has been installed for the first time on any ship on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. The camera will be made an official part of the liner's equipment when the Manhattan returns from a Bermuda cruise Tuesday.

A comprehensive system of unemployment insurance would be less costly to the American people than the immense sums now being disbursed for relief due to unemployment and would have resulted in a saving of $70,000,000 in cash alone in the year just past, the American Association of Social Security declared yesterday in an open letter to members of Congress and State legislators throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. Monetary problems and the strengthening of recovery and emergency laws enacted in the special session to restore prosperity will dominate the proceedings of the Seventy-third Congress which will convene at noon Wednesday for its first regular session.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 (AP). -- Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina paid tribute today to the participation of Secretary of State Cordell Hull in the Pan-American Conference, in a New Year's message to the people of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Re-employment of 4,000,000 workers, with reduction in hours of work and rises in basic rates of pay for fully five times that number in factories stores and mines was set forth by the National Recovery Administration today as justification for the first six months of its existence.

After more than three months of unchanged rates for call money, quotations were raised one-quarter of 1 per cent here in December to 1 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange and to 1 1/2 per cent on the Curb Exchange. Previous to the mark-up on Dec. 7, rates had remained stationary since Aug. 30.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP). -- Educators are preparing to request immediate action by Congress to prevent what they term "collapse of the American public school system."

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 1. -- Upon the "advice" of his Ministers throughout the empire, King George dipped into his store of royal honors today and bestowed almost a thousand titles, orders and decorations upon a carefully selected list of his subjects.
Never, perhaps, was there more need than today of the injunction which EDWARD EVERETT HALE gave an earlier generation:

Thomas C.T. Crain, as he was about to leave office yesterday on the last day of his four-year term as District Attorney of New York County, made public figures to show that his work as a chief prosecutor in that period was as good as or even better than that of some of his predecessors.

The story of the hit-and-run driver sentenced to three years in the penitentiary after having killed a 16-year-old girl at West End Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street is, in my opinion, a distasteful sample of present-day justice. The facts seem almost unbelievable when one thinks of the mild penalty imposed.

William C. Dodge, new District Attorney of New York County, announced in a radio speech over WOR yesterday afternoon that he planned to cut the salaries of the higher-paid men in his office. He explained also that he was not reappointing a number of the present assistant prosecutors because of the need for "new blood" in the office.
New York celebrated the first legally wet New Year's Eve in fourteen years with a minimum of drunkenness, disorder and arrests for violence.

When the first half of the fiscal year 1933-34 ended yesterday, the Federal Treasury showed a deficit well in excess of a billion dollars. Between July 1 and Dec. 31 the Government spent approximately $18 for every $10 it received in revenue. It bridged the gap by borrowing.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- As compared with the end of 1931 the present position and prospects are infinitely better.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- A message from President Roosevelt brought together for a brief final session this afternoon the two student organizations which have been holding independent conventions here.

Vigorous criticism of the Roosevelt "New Deal" is embodied in "The Economics of the Recovery Program," written by seven Harvard economists, which will be published tomorrow by Whittlesey House. The authors of the book are Joseph A. Schumpeter, Edward Chamberlin, Edward S. Mason, Douglass V. Brown, Seymour E. Harris, Wassily W. Leontief and Overton H. Taylor.

Those who are looking forward to recovering the conditions of five years ago are not only doomed to disappointment but are hindering the nation's progress, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.
Joseph McOwen of Lake Mahopac, N.Y., has been appointed Chief Deputy of the State Athletic Commission by Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, it became known yesterday.

Reorganization of the executive personnel of the North German Lloyd and Hamburg American steamship lines in the North Atlantic Union, which was recently created by their merger, was announced yesterday. The employes of both companies were notified a month ago that their services would not be required after Jan. 1.
TOKYO, Dec. 31. -- Japan ends the year not without anxieties, but with solid reasons to relax and enjoy the festive season.
BARCELONA, Dec. 31. -- Luis Companys, former Civil Governor of Catalonia, was chosen tonight to succeed the late Colonel Francesc Macia as President of the Catalan Generalidad.

Nearly all of the Broadway attractions will have special holiday performances this afternoon. "John Brown's Body," in which George Abbott will return to the stage as an actor, will be presented on Jan. 22 at a theatre yet to be announced.

THERE is to be a football game today in the city of Pasadena, Calif., between Stanford and Columbia. It has been decided in advance by the majority, on past performances and sundry other things, that Columbia is to be offered as the sacrificial lamb. The most general disagreement with that idea comes from the players of Columbia and their coaches.

The world today has little faith in predictions and even "professional prophets are out of jobs," the Rev. Dr. Charles E. Jefferson, honorary minister of the Broadway Tabernacle, declared in a sermon yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.
Two industrial properties were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Notice that France proposes to reduce her import quotas by 75 per cent created an unfavorable reaction here tonight among governmental experts who have been bargaining over the wine quotas from that country.

Five inspectors of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, implicated in charges of graft in connection with the issuance of liquor licenses, were summarily dismissed yesterday by Chairman Edward P. Mulrooney.
F.H. LaGuardia took the oath of office of Mayor of New York City at 12:05 A.M. today in a simple ceremony at the home of Samuel Seabury, 154 East Sixty-third Street.

Clouding the mind with liquor would be a mistaken way of ushering in this new year, which should find one thoughtfully preparing for definite action, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the rector, declared yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

The warm spell that ended New York's five-day wave of heavy snow and extreme cold yesterday will continue today, accompanied by rain this morning and possibly later, but much colder weather is due tonight, according to the Weather Bureau.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31. -- The second Soviet Five-Year Plan devotes particular attention to transportation, which admittedly is one of the weak points of the Soviet economy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP). -- High and low in the capital's official life watched the old year out and the new year in tonight, hopeful, like millions of fellow Americans, of better things to come.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Board, and officials of the regional labor board will confer here tomorrow on action to be taken by the government against New York concerns that have challenged the authority of the regional labor board and have declined to cooperate with the board in an amicable settlement of industrial disputes.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- A sudden burst of flame from behind the screen of the Plaza Moving Picture Theatre, Park and Prospect Avenues, during the matinee today sent 450 persons, many of them children, rushing for the exits and resulted in injuries to ten.

Carmello Colicchia, a retired musician, shot and killed his nephew and seriously wounded two other relatives yesterday in an argument over a debt, in the tenement in which they all lived at 1,057 Morris Avenue, the Bronx.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stock from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

DENVER, Dec. 31 (AP). -- Colorado's first lethal gas execution, by which Walter Reppin is scheduled to die this week at State Prison, seemed almost certain today to be delayed by a legal situation without precedent in this State.

KLAGENFURT, Austria, Dec. 31 (AP). -- The Nazi Prince Bernhard of Saxe-Meiningen, who with his young wife escaped dramatically to Italy three weeks ago, was caught by the police tonight trying to re-enter his castle of Pitzelstaetten, near here.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1933, as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

The cotton market, influenced by holiday factors, continued rather quiet last week, but business was more active than is usual in a Christmas week. Prices fluctuated in a narrow range, continuing the upward trend begun the week before, and reaching the highest prices since Nov. 22.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Buying of oats has been under way all season on the Board of Trade, the crop being small. The market has become overbought and is following other grains. The movement to Chicago is light. Cash oats are slightly under the May price.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 31. -- Johnny Goodman, a caddy come of age, makes a New Year resolution that may prove discomfiting during 1934 to his brethren of the greens and fairways, to wit:

The lid was off last night in the city's hundreds of hotels, restaurants and night clubs. Not since the beginning of the dry era fourteen years ago was there so great a New Year's crowd as that which turned out to greet 1934.

The entire personnel of the Fourth Avenue police station, Brooklyn, will be present at Headquarters this morning to see Captain Lewis J. Valentine, their commander, take office as chief inspector of the department. In the few hours that the 130 men of the precinct are absent a lieutenant, two sergeants and twenty patrolmen from other station houses will police the precinct.

SHAWNEE, Okla., Dec. 31 (AP). -- Eva Mae Nichols, Seminole beauty parlor operator, died today of a bullet wound in the stomach suffered in the gunfight which led to the capture of her friend, Wilbur Underhill, Southwestern desperado.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP). -- Southern California gave Columbia's football team a sopping-wet welcome as it arrived today for the game with Stanford.

DETROIT, Dec. 31. -- Four State retail liquor stores opened yesterday morning to find eager customers in line, ready to celebrate, with the passing of 1933, the passing also of prohibition in Michigan.

Having progressed to the final without the loss of a single set, Frank Parker, the eighth ranking player on the United States senior list, will meet Gilbert Hunt of M.I.T. for the national junior Indoor tennis championship today at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
All the scoring in the game between New York's rivals in the National Hockey League, the Americans and the Rangers, at Madison Square Garden last night was packed into the first period.

At least $500,000 changed hands last year in connection with the obtaining of licenses for news stands, Sidney S. Levine, Commissioner of Licenses, said yesterday. Mr. Levine, who has been investigating charges of news stand license graft, will continue with his public hearings tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Business on the Board of Trade for 1934 will start with wheat prices 29 to 30 cents a bushel higher than a year ago, with corn up 11 cents, oats up 10 1/2 to 11 cents, rye up 12 to 14 3/8 cents, barley down 5 to 15 cents and lard 15 cents lower on the May delivery.
MILTON, Mass., Dec. 31. -- John Candler Cobb, retired Boston capitalist, died at his home here, last night.
Gustav Bohland and Eileen Parnell are having a joint exhibition of their sculpture at the Marie Sterner Gallery. The work will be on view until Jan. 13.

Long Island University's undefeated quintet has a monopoly on the Metropolitan individual basketball scoring records as the season once more swings into action after the brief respite for the holidays. Four of the first five positions are held by members of the Long Island institution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- An assertion that economy has reduced the navy personnel to a point of danger, as regards both efficiency and preparedness, is made in the annual report of the Bureau of Navigation to Secretary Swanson.
LONDON, Dec. 31. -- Wives of naturalized aliens are among the millions directly affected by new laws which will become effective in Great Britain Jan. 1.

Both at home and abroad 1934 is sure to be marked by anxieties and doubts. Men of clearest vision cannot see at its beginning what the end will be. Yet it cannot bring heavier trials or graver upheavals than those of the past four years. A world which has survived these need not too dispiritedly fear what the coming twelve months may have as yet unfolded and hidden within them.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31. -- Future Soviet historians will call 1933 a decisive year in the country's progress. Indeed, it is already termed here a year of "perelom," a Russian word that means sharp change for the better.

Business in the various commodity markets was sharply curtailed last week because of the distractions of the holiday week. Many of the exchanges were closed on Saturday. Price movements throughout the week were highly irregular.
