CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Business in 1933, in this district, ended more satisfactorily than leaders expected, and prospects for 1934 are the best in three to four years. Business men have expressed surprise at the gains in distribution, in manufacturing, in employment and in profits.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- John Dillinger and his band of escaped Indiana convicts shot their way out of the Beverly Gardens, a roadhouse on the far Southwest side, following a robbery today, and wounded policemen.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Dec. 31. -- W.A. Dutton's 4-year-old colt, Dis Dat, held at odds of almost 5-1, sprinted to victory in the Warnicker Handicap today. A field of seven started, with Noah's Pride second and Bissagos third.
The new year was ushered in by churches throughout the city at watch night services last night.

PARIS, Dec. 30. -- The situation as it appears at the beginning of 1934 is characterized by uncertainty from the monetary point of view. If it were possible to set aside this question, it should be established that prospects are favorable rather than otherwise.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 31. -- Despite the continuance of prohibition, Puerto Rico prepared to greet the New Year at many gay parties when assured of transportation by the ending of the chauffeurs' strike. But other strikes and threats of strikes may mar some of the festivities.

Nine appointments were announced yesterday by James J. Lyons, new Borough President of the Bronx. Robert L. Moran, former Sheriff, was named Commissioner of Public Works; William Lyman, former Assemblyman and executive member of the Fifth Assembly District Democratic organization, his deputy, and Eugene G. Schulz, Assistant District Attorney under Charles B. McLaughlin, secretary of the borough.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- Tonight's jubilation failed conspicuously to measure up to Berlin's traditional brand of New Year's Eve revelry and the crowds along the main-traveled streets were also considerably smaller than in former years.

All in all, the weekend has brought events of greater world significance than the fight between the "hard-money" men and the "soft-money" men in electing a new president of the American Statistical Association.

Schedules for three varsity teams in Spring sports were announced at City College yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics. Thirty-one engagements are listed as follows: Five track meets, including two dual encounters; nineteen baseball games and seven lacrosse meetings.

Government loans and mail contracts saved the American merchant fleet in the foreign trade during the trying year 1933, according to R.J. Baker, secretary of the American Steamship Owners Association.
Hopefully, with the feeling of men who have seen the worst and know anything that follows must be better, the sports leaders of the nation look forward into the bright new year of 1934.

The member agencies of the Welfare Council of the City of Hew York have been asked to cooperate in creating a municipal-housing authority and to support a legislative program for slum clearance and replacement. This is undoubtedly a commendable action, and will find due appreciation by all who are in any way connected with slum population and its problems.
Lighter-hearted thousands jammed Times Square and Broadway last night for the happiest New Year's Eve celebration the city has had in fourteen years.

LONDON, Dec. 31. -- President Roosevelt's proposal, in his speech Thursday night, that all nations rid themselves of offensive weapons has caused a renewed demand by certain strong political interests in Britain that the London government cooperate closely with the United States for world peace.

Governor Lehman is disinclined to appoint former Mayor John P. O'Brien a justice of the Supreme Court to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Curtis A. Peters, it was reported yesterday on good authority. The appointment of Mr. O'Brien has been recommended to the Governor by John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- Summarizing the financial history of 1933, experts mostly agree that it witnessed undoubted improvement, chiefly through the arrest of the fall in prices and increase in production, but it is observed that different countries showed a marked difference both as regards the date of the first increase in activity and the pace of the subsequent progress.

F.H. LaGuardia declined yesterday an invitation to address the mass meeting of the Farmer Labor Political Federation at Cooper Union next Thursday evening. Mr. LaGuardia notified J. Charles Laue, city chairman of the federation, that he would ask Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, to represent him.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31. -- Production of steel ingots decreased last week, being officially forecast at 31.6 per cent of capacity, against 34.2 per cent for the preceding week. Even then production of ingots, with the decrease, was the highest with the one exception since late in October.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 31. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 71.8, which compares with 71.4 a week before, 72 two weeks before, 71.7 three weeks before and 71.4 four weeks before.

BUCHAREST, Dec. 31. -- Ten thousand persons passed in mourning before the body of Ion G. Duca, murdered Rumanian Premier, today as it lay in state in the hall of honor of the Bucharest Atheneum. They were compelled to wait in a long line in a pouring rain for hours before they could obtain admission.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- Germany tonight closed the doors of an old year of changes, the fullest and most pregnant she has passed through since the great war. Tomorrow she opens a new account for a year fraught with even greater responsibilities, big already with the necessity for decisions that will affect not only her own future but that of Europe and the world.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 31. -- President Abelardo Rodriguez issued a New Year's message to the Mexican people this evening outlining the main planks of the program the government has adopted during his period in office, and its plans for the future, which in all probability will be continued by his successor to be elected next July.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 31. -- Fifty-two football players, including some of Dixie's most colorful stars of 1933 and former years, will play on the University of Tennessee gridiron tomorrow for charity.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31. -- The main trouble with the constructive suggestions made by John Maynard Keynes in his "open letter to President Roosevelt," according to Professor Raymond Moley, is that the distinguished British economist doesn't realize most of these suggestions have already been adopted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- With about 99 per cent of all the banks of the nation members now of the temporary fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, operative tomorrow, Chairman Jones of the RFC said tonight that the authorizations made by his organization for purchases of preferred stock and capital notes of banks to help fit them for deposit insurance totaled $800,000,000.
What shall be the principal objective of the new city administration's fiscal policy ?

PARIS, Dec. 31. -- Looking back over 1933, France finds it filled with disillusions and disappointments, and, looking forward to 1934, those who dare risk a forecast think it prudent to avoid optimism.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31. -- Vincent Richards of New York relinquished his national indoor professional tennis championship to the veteran William T. Tilden 2d in the final at the Penn A.C. today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 31. -- The total cash income of New Jersey agriculture in 1933 is expected to exceed the $61,000,000 received in 1932, according to Professor A.G. Waller, economist at the New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station here.

OTTAWA, Dec. 31 (Canadian Press). -- A plea for world peace and an expression of hope "that the lingering ghosts of the World War are now making exit from the world stage" were coupled with Prime Minister Bennett's New Year greeting to the people of Canada tonight.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31. -- Large parties at villas and capacity throngs at clubs and restaurants marked New Year's Eve here as the gayest in many seasons.

Increase in the costs of building materials and labor represents a rise of 30 per cent over the prevailing prices of Jan. 1, 1933, points out Myron L. Matthews in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports. This means, he explains, that a home costing $4,500 to build one year ago would cost $5,850 today.

ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., Dec. 31. -- Arthur Williams gave a luncheon today at his country home. Brook Corners, in honor of Lord Decies and his daughter, the Hon. Moya Beresford of London. Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly was hostess for Mr. Williams.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- It is considered noteworthy that even the Nazi Ministry of Economy in a newly issued survey of Germany's commercial relations affirms that the present spreading of State monopolistic regulation of foreign trade involves a similar complete State regulation of internal economy and, vice versa, that the government which begins with domestic monopolistic regulation cannot succeed without a simultaneous dictation in export and import activities.

LONDON, Dec. 31. -- Moving picture photographs purporting to show the "sea monster" of Loch Ness, Scotland, were received tonight at The London Times' office by telegraph from Glasgow. They were vouched for by Malcolm Irvine, a member of the staff of Scottish Films, Ltd., who took them, and by two other operators.

In a season when the managers of the Yiddish playhouses are having a hard time attracting sizable audiences, the Second Avenue Theatre presented on Saturday an operetta intended to please everybody. In "The Organ Grinder," written by Louis Freiman, are a well-worn triangle and gobs of familiar comedy to appeal to the general and bits for the more particular.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 31. -- Tightening of the Argentine censorship this afternoon and the receipt of news of a serious clash last night at Concordia, Entre Rios Province, give the impression here that the Argentine situation is graver than has been admitted.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31. -- They may have to play water polo instead of football but Columbia and Stanford will play something in the Rose Bowl tomorrow afternoon as scheduled, it was definitely decided tonight at a conference of Tournament of Roses, Stanford and Columbia officials.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler in a New Year's statement made public yesterday by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, of which he is president, declared the world's supply of monetary gold should be concentrated in the Bank for International Settlements as an important move to aid recovery.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- A situation has developed in corn that is entirely new to the trade, and operators express a belief that it will revolutionize all ideas about corn, for a time at least. The adjustment of supplies of corn and hogs that the government is trying to work out is expected to give its advocates many thrills.

DETROIT, Dec. 31 (AP). -- Asserting that the new Congress is "the most momentous since the birth of the Republic," the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin declared today that "the Herods of high' finance already are plotting against the New Deal -- plotting among the ruins of their own structure."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Reports were circulated tonight to the effect that the President would make an important monetary move before Congress meets. Counterbalancing them was the assertion of some administration advisers that the President has decided to recommend that Congress chart the course to be pursued in the devaluation of the dollar and decide what is to be done about any profit on gold held by the Federal Reserve Banks.

Modern womanhood is undergoing a new self-revaluation in the revolt against feminism and new standards must emerge if the gains of woman's emancipation are to be held, Rabbi Louis I. Newman of Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, said in his morning discourse.

Seventy-two contributors cut substantially yesterday into the balance of $4,118.02 still needed to fill the budgets of the last nine of the 368 cases thus far relieved by the Neediest Cases Fund. They sent $1,670.50, in gifts ranging from $1 to $500.

There is one slight ambiguity in your editorial of Dec. 24, on the "Forgotten Section" of the Fourteenth Amendment, which might possibly mislead people who did not read the article to which you so kindly refer.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amounted to $3,219,018,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 31. -- Mexico's polo stars defeated the crack Texas quartet headed by Cecil Smith, 11 to 8, before 7,000 frantically enthusiastic fans today, thereby capturing the three-game series. The Texans won the first game, 11 -- 8, and lost the second, 13 -- 5.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 31. -- Miss Dorothy Mittendorf, daughter of Mrs. Ella Mittendorf of Field Point Park, gave a large tea at her home this afternoon for Miss Constance Malley and Noel Armstrong, whose engagement was announced this Fall. Among the guests were:
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- Financial markets have ended the year in a spirit of marked optimism which is more pronounced now than at any time since business first began seriously to contract in 1929.

HAVANA, Dec. 31. -- President Grau San Martin late last night signed a decree modifying the workmen's compensation law which threatened to bring about the closing of all Cuban commercial and industrial concerns Jan. 2 because of the cancellation of accident policies by casualty insurance companies. Few of the many changes requested by the insurers were granted.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31. -- Tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock in Moore Park, Elmer Layden will send his Duquesne University football team against the University of Miami eleven in the second annual Festival of the Palms game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Cash payments to farmers of nearly $250,000,000 and commitments to pay them five times that amount, or more than $1,250,000,000, by February, 1935, in consideration of their pledge to reduce the size of various crops, is the record achieved by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration in 1933.

On Dec. 22 an article appeared in your paper entitled "Few in Slums Able to Try New Homes." Quoting the first paragraph, "The living habits of 83 per cent of the families who vacated the 'Lung Block' on the East Side to permit model housing construction will remain unchanged, according to a study by the Fred L. Lavanburg Foundation and Hamilton House."

MOSCOW, Dec. 31. -- Structural changes in the organization of the Communist party of the Soviet Union, entailing sweeping alterations in the Soviet government itself, have been approved by the party's Political Bureau.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- The First National Bank of Chicago in its 1933 statement, issued tonight, reported earnings for the year of $4,840,909 before bond depreciation and contingencies. After these extraordinary charges, including $10,644,624 for bond depreciation and $312,224 for premium paid to the Deposit Insurance Corporation, the bank showed a reduction in profit and loss surplus of $988,454 for the year.

DUBLIN, Dec. 31. -- The Blue Shirt movement and its ideals appear to have captured support in large areas in Southern Ireland, judging by the welcome to General Owen O'Duffy who made a triumphal entry today into Clonmel, Tipperary, where he addressed a meeting of several thousands.

PARIS, Dec. 31 (AP). -- A new drastice quota bargaining policy on industrial products, reducing import quotas by 75 per cent and hitting many American goods hitherto untouched, was decreed by the government today, to take effect tomorrow.

PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- The Lake Placid A.C. and the St. Nicholas Club of New York put on a speedy exhibition of hockey in the Olympic Arena today, the local sextet taking the second contest of a three-game series, 3 to 2. The New Yorkers won last night, 6 to 4.

A notable advance in religion in 1934 is forecast in a New Year's message to the clergy and members of the Congregational and Christian churches sent by the united denomination's commission on evangelism and devotional life. It was prepared by the commission's secretary, the Rev. Dr. Frederick L. Fagley, and read:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Stimulation of operations in the capital goods industries through Federal aid is one of the most important tasks confronting the administration during the new year, Secretary Roper said in a statement today in which he reviewed efforts on various recovery fronts during 1933.

In a New Year's statement made public yesterday, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, declared 1933 "is likely to be described by future historians as the year of the great transition."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31. -- Football's grand old man, Amos Alonzo Stagg, was named president of the Pacific Coast and Rocky Mountain Football Coaches' Association at its annual meeting here today to consider proposed changes in rules for 1934.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 31. -- The eleventh annual award of the American Association prize of $1,000, given by the American Association for the Advancement of Science to the author of a noteworthy paper presented at its Winter meeting, was voted today to Dr. Reuben L. Kahn, Professor of Bacteriology at the University of Michigan Medical School, for his paper, "Tissue Reactions in Immunity."

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- W.C. Wright of Philadelphia and Ogden Phipps of New York for the second year in a row will be the finalists in the annual Tuxedo gold racquet court tennis tournament tomorrow. Both won their matches today in the semi-final round at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club.

WILL DYSON, a great cartoonist and etcher, is not very well known in the United States. It is rather a shame, therefore, that his introduction comes in his guise of disciple of Major C.H. Douglas, author of the Social Credit plan for putting a dislocated economic system to rights by a scheme of financial prestidigitation. Dyson has swallowed Douglas, hook, line and sinker.

By comparison with the same month in 1932, the total of dividends declared in December was the most favorable for any month last year. Shareholders received greater returns on their investments through extra payments, increases in regular rates, initial dividends, and the resumption of payments on stocks long non-dividend payers.
In spite of the efforts of 400 firemen from fifty-six companies, fire destroyed yesterday the half-century-old apartment and store building at 47 Brevoort Place, Brooklyn.

KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 31. -- Poisonous coke gas which suddenly broke through an ice-blocked pipe at the bottom of a pit in the yard of the Koppers Seaboard Coke Company at the Hackensack River, killed two men today and overcame two others who were attempting a rescue.

Two detectives, Frank Nowicki and James A. Corey of the East Fifth Street station, were arrested by fellow-officers yesterday on charges of homicide in the shooting Saturday night of Peter Martinick in his bar and restaurant at 512 East Sixth Street.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 1. -- Prime Minister MacDonald, in his New Year's message to the country, said he was confident prosperity was returning. His message follows:

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, probably will go to Albany tomorrow for the caucus of the Republican members of the Assembly, at which a vote will be taken on the candidacy of Fred W. Hammond for re-election as clerk.

Alex Hurd of Hamilton, Ont., and Miss Kit Klein of Buffalo will defend their Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating titles today on Polly Lake in Downing Park, Newburgh, N.Y. Each champion will be pitted against a formidable field, with a number of the leading skaters present.

Mrs. Catherine Phelan, a gray-haired, 52-year-old housekeeper, was placed under arrest yesterday, charged with slaying her employer, Douglas Sheridan, a customer's man employed by Clark, Childs Keech of 11 Broadway. His body, the skull crushed by what detectives believed to have been a hammer, was found early yesterday morning in his apartment at 800 Riverside Drive.

Since it is commonly understood that the purpose of the Federal Securities Act of May 27 was to protect investors by making information available on new security issues, and imposing liability on issuers and underwriters in case of various eventualities, it is interesting to note just how available this information is under the regulations of the Federal Trade Commission.
A third program of Silly Symphonies and Mickey Mouse cartoons will be shown continuously at Carnegie Hall today beginning at 11:30 A.M.

HAVANA, Dec. 31. -- The Cuban Government today defaulted on public works obligations contracted during the Machado regime amounting to $4,718,860. This amount covers $913,403 of 5 1/2 per cent serial certificates which matured June 30, 1933, purchased by the Chase National Bank to avoid default.

WARSAW, Dec. 31. -- Adolf Hitler's access to power is unanimously mentioned as the most important event of the past year in the Polish press resume of 1933. The salvation of the League of Nations, weakened by the withdrawal of Germany and Japan and threatened by Italy's reform proposals, is regarded as the new year's most important task.

The old year ended on the markets uneventfully; old years usually have done so, except on the almost-forgotten occasions, under the pre-war banking system, of a "year-end money squeeze." Stocks and bonds advanced with due cheerfulness last week, but so they did in the closing days of 1929, when Stock Exchange records described a market "fairly buoyant"; which suggests that the round-up of a year does not always give a hint at the economic future.

Clad in the evening clothes he had worn at a dance a few hours before, his head resting on a pillow, James How, 28 years old, member of a wealthy and socially prominent St. Louis family, was found dead of gas poisoning yesterday morning in the kitchen of an apartment at 400 East Fifty-eighth Street. He had committed suicide, the police said.

In The Atlantic Monthly Mr. B.F. SKINNER has an acute and urbane article on GERTRUDE STEIN or the two GERTRUDE STEINS. One writes good or distinguished English. The other writes involuntary, more difficult, to Mr. SKINNER not "important" and sometimes apparently meaningless English or Steinese.

The year 1933 will he remembered in history for the advent of two world figures, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Adolf Hitler, John Haynes Holmes said yesterday morning in his sermon to the congregation of the Community Church, meeting in the Town Hall.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31. -- Football's greatest yearly parade of stars will take place here tomorrow when a brilliant mixture of All-Americans and unsung heroes of the last season compare gridiron mastery in the annual East-West charity game.

The Twentieth Century Fund, which is financed by Edward A. Filene of Boston, announced yesterday that the survey of the security markets, which it has been preparing for several months, was nearing completion.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP). -- On the last day of the year at the Jefferson Park track the namesakes of two notables of the musical world won their races.

The Federal Government has assigned thirty special civil works projects to New York State, which will provide employment for 25,000 persons above the quota of about 400,000 originally allotted to this State under the civil works program, the State Civil Works Administration announced yesterday from its office at 124 East Twenty-eighth Street.

On the eve of the new year men and women should resolve to withhold judgment on the offenses charged to others, the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon in St. Paul's Methodist Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Raisers of livestock early in the season had fair profits to help make up part of their losses of 1932. but the finish was at recessions from the best prices of 1933. High and low price levels here for the last two years follow:

Bobcats are increasing rapidly in some sections of Connecticut, according to an announcement from Arthur L. Clark, Superintendent of Fisheries and Game of that State. Serious damage to raccoons and deer is resulting, says Mr. Clark, and to such an alarming extent that his department has just secured the services of an expert trapper in an effort to exterminate the cats.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- A total of $324,428,488 has been expended by the Federal Government within seven months for the relief of the destitute unemployed throughout the country.

The letter of President Butler of Columbia University published in THE TIMES of Dec. 28 attacking the child-labor amendment ignores the long experience of organizations vitally interested in problems of social legislation. It has been found that attempts to gain adequate protection for minors or workers by passing legislation in the various States are utterly inadequate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP). -- The national capital, by word and music, tonight sent New Year's greetings to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, whose ships were nosing through the ice fields guarding the Antarctic continent.

The Hershey sextet moved out of the second division of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon as the result of a 2-to-0 victory over the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club. A crowd of 5,000 saw the Pennsylvanians tally on quick thrusts in the second and third periods, the triumph enabling them to tie the Bronx Hockey Club for third place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- The automatic discontinuance of $130,000,000 in Federal levies starts the New Year off right tonight for some taxpayers, who are assured of relief from another $80,000,000 in special taxes later in the year.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 31. -- Dr. T.V. Soong, chairman of the Chinese National Government's National Economic Council and former Minister of Finance, said in a New Year's statement today:

Set upon by seven young hoodlums on the southbound platform of the new Eighth Avenue subway station at Grand Concourse and 167th Street, Detective John Kelly was badly beaten with his own blackjack shortly before last midnight.

The dollar turned heavy at the week-end, sinking to a value of 63.04 cents, a loss of .96 cent from the previous week, based on the quotation for the French franc. The break on Saturday canceled the improvement in the dollar which set in last Monday and brought a high of 64.49 cents on Thursday. Range a year ago was 100.39 100.33 cents.

The average of steel operations on working days last week showed little change from the 38 per cent of capacity reported for the preceding week, according to the magazine Steel. The severe weather and a shortage of cars complicated deliveries in many districts, but shipments reached a peak rarely exceeded in a year's final week, even in most prosperous times, the publication states.

Joseph Nemerov and his counsel, Max D. Steuer, will resume their fight in behalf of certificate holders against George S. Van Sehaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, rehabilitator for defaulting guaranteed mortgage companies, in the Northern District Federal Court in Albany on Wednesday.

The mileage of railroads in receivership or bankruptcy was doubled in 1933. It stood at 22,000 miles at the end of 1932, the highest since 1916, and by the end of 1933 it was more than 44,000 miles. About seventy companies are in difficulties.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Tatanne, a 3-year-old filly racing for Mrs. J. Zoeller, justified her short odds today when she easily defeated a smart field in the $1,200 New Year's Handicap at Jefferson Park.

The report of W.A. Harriman chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Campaign Committee for the State of New York, made public yesterday shows the recovery program in the fifty-seven counties outside the city to be "well on its way to fulfillment."

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, through its secretary, Walter White, made public yesterday its review of twenty-eight known lynchings last year, calling attention to an increase of 180 per cent in "mob murder" over 1932, when ten lynchings were reported.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1. -- Chicago awoke today after one of the most joyous receptions to the New Year in two decades, to a realization that the repeal of prohibition had put more gayety into the annual celebration and had taken much of the disorder out of it.

Chairman Edward P. Mulrooney of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board said yesterday he was determined to put an immediate stop to all forms of graft by the board's employes or outsiders in connection with the issuance of liquor licenses.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 1 (AP). -- Professor Erwin H. Schell told the annual business conference at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today that too many of the codes drafted under the National Industrial Recovery Act "have not reflected the needs of the small companies, and in many instances have incorporated features which bring advantages to the big plant at the expense of the smaller."

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, exploring off Antarctica, Dec. 31. -- The flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition again started south through the main Antarctic ice pack at 6 o'clock on New Year's Eve. The air was gloomy, the sky overcast, and there was a hint of snow in the air.

Cardinal Hayes was at home yesterday, in accordance with a custom of many years, at his residence, 452 Madison Avenue. Scores of his clergy and laymen active in the administration of the archdiocesan institutions called on him.

The letter of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler published in your issue of Dec. 28, which discusses the subject of the Child Labor Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, summarizes excellently and convincingly the principal objections to such an enlargement and extension of the jurisdiction and power of Congress.

For the first time since 1928, an old year has ended with recovery a reality. In no month between 1929 and last Spring did the traditional indices of business conditions fail to show heavy deterioration from the preceding year. But last April Stock Exchange prices and the volume of industrial production set the pace by passing the record of 1932.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP). -- Nearly 200,000 persons courted pneumonia in a driving rain today to see Pasadena's tournament of roses.

Three cases of starvation or undernourishment were reported by the police yesterday. Doubled up on the sidewalk close to the building line at Fourth Street and the Bowery, an unidentified man about 60 years old, was found to be a starvation case, according to Dr. Caruso of Columbus Hospital, who took the man to Bellevue Hospital.

Proposals for the construction of the under-river section of the new Hudson River tunnel, which will link Manhattan at Thirty-eighth Street with Weehawken, will be opened Feb. 6, it was announced yesterday by General George R. Dyer, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

The earnings of the National City Bank for 1933, after expenses, taxes, normal reserves, depreciation and other items, and with figures for December estimated, amount to about $12,000,000, it is revealed in the current bulletin of the bank.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 1. -- The Chaco peace negotiations have been transferred to Buenos Aires. The Bolivian envoys, Casto Rojas, David Alvestiguy and General Carlos Blanco Galindo, and the League of Nations Commission's Secretary General, Juan Antonio Buero, sailed for Buenos Aires tonight.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 30. -- Business in this Federal Reserve District has improved considerably, and there is an optimism among business men that was not present a year ago. Some fundamental troubles have not been solved, it is realized, but the emergency measures have furnished sufficient stimulant to encourage many to believe that the wheels of industry will gradually increase their momentum.

TUXEDO PARK. N.Y., Jan. 1. -- Ogden Phipps of New York dethroned W.C. Wright as holder of the Tuxedo gold racquet court tennis championship today at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club by scoring a victory, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4 6 -- 2 in the final round.

Fifty gunners reported at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. for the annual New Year's Day shoot of the organization. The competitors were divided into the four regular classes, with two scratch prizes offered in each division. The High-Over-All-Cup went to R.H. Helsel, a Class A nimrod, who broke 98 out of 100 targets.
ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- Perhaps the most important session of the New York Legislature in recent years will be convened at noon on Wednesday, with both parties in the throes of internecine warfare.
PITTSBURGH, Pa., Jan. 1. -- Stepping into Pittsburgh's highest office on this New Year's Day, Mayor William N. McNair proved to his fellow-townsmen he can wear a brown derby, too.

The old-fashioned cotillion, popular in the latter part of the nineteenth and the beginning of this century, was revived last night by Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Stoddard who gave one at their home at 106 East Thirty-seventh Street to mark the debut of their second daughter, Miss Anna Bailey Stoddard.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Jan. 1 (AP). -- Following a grand jury's voting of eleven indictments in the lynching Nov. 28 of Lloyd Warner, a Negro, and a recommendation that Sheriff Otto Theisen and members of the Police Department, which yielded to the mob, be ousted, Prosecutor Frank L. Kirtley will confer with Criminal Judge J.V. Gaddy tomorrow regarding possible action.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 1. -- The hitherto undefeated Princeton basketball team was upset by the Wittenberg College quintet, 37 -- 33, in an overtime game tonight. A strong rally that carried the home team from a 19-11 trailing position at the half extended into the second period as the Tigers were tied at the final whistle, 30 -- all.

Always a sensitive index, the stock market in 1933 wrote in vivid colors what Wall Street considers a true record of the public state of mind in a period of unparalleled financial dislocation. In point of volume or of price movement, the market was not exceptional, but it reflected accurately, and even eloquently, the varying reactions of the investing and trading community.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Headed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, members of official, diplomatic and resident society were present at the reception given this afternoon by the Secretary of War and Mrs. Dern to present to society their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Dern.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 26. -- The new year will begin in this section with hope that the government's experiments may succeed and, on the whole, with willingness to cooperate in giving them a trial. Farmers are disappointed in the failure of the high midsummer prices to be sustained, but they are relying on assurances of speedy increase in buying and debt-paying power.

BOSTON, Dec. 30. -- A canvass of leading bankers and business executives in New England discloses an indisposition to express an opinion as to 1934. There is, however, a general opinion that 1933 was materially better than 1932, and notes an undercurrent of confidence that the worst of the depression is past.
ROME, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Italians looked forward today to a new year of "fair prices" established by the State as part of an economic housecleaning.
Although the New Year started yesterday with milder temperatures, New York is destined to enjoy only a brief respite from the bitter cold that prevailed during most of last week.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 1. -- Family quarrels which had their origin nineteen years ago, shortly after the marriage of Mr. and Mrs. Herman E. Schuerer of Haworth Borough, near here, culminated this morning in the fatal shooting of Schuerer.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 1 (AP). -- William H. Woodin, who retired today as Secretary of the Treasury, expressed pleasure at having served "under the greatest leader of modern times" and predicted "a great success" for his successor, Henry Morgenthau Jr.

Merchants and manufacturers in most lines see reason to look hopefully to the early months of 1934, says the National City Bank in its current bulletin. Reports from trade and industry in the closing month of 1933 were the best since early Summer, the bank asserts, and it adds that there is evidence in the business statistics that a halt has been reached in the decline in Business which began in July.

We expect the level of farm prices to average higher during 1934 than 1933. Three factors usually predominate among the forces which control the level of agricultural prices. They are supply, consumers' income and monetary changes.
New York awakened yesterday with headaches, but no serious consequences, from the first legally wet New Year's Eve celebration in fourteen years.

BERLIN, Jan. 1. -- The most significant event in today's round of official and diplomatic New Year's ceremonies in the Wilhelmstrasse was the late afternoon call of Andre Francois-Poncet, French Ambassador to Berlin, at the chancellery, where he was received by Chancellor Hitler and Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- With the Democratic Congressional leaders grouped around him at the White House, President Roosevelt tonight held a final conference on the budget and appropriations before the convening of Congress Wednesday.

Abandonment of the gold standard and subsequent variations in the price for that metal tended to stimulate interest in platinum and associated metals in the metal trades, according to Charles Engelhard, president of Baker Co., dealers in platinum.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 26. -- Banking in the interior has passed through three stages in the year now closing. The numerous suspensions, followed by the bank moratorium of March, came first. Next came renewal of money-hoarding and failure to reopen promptly many of the banks closed for the moratorium, thus tying up their deposits and limiting credit.

NOT so long ago they were saying that a great Irishman, James Joyce, had killed the traditional form of the novel by writing "Ulysses." But the traditional novel is a phoenix. Sean O'Faolain (pronounced Shawn O'Phelan) proves, in "A Nest of Simple Folk" (Viking, $2.50), the adaptability and the strength of the form which post-Joyceans scorn; he has written, in this chronicle of some threescore years of Irish life, a fine, a very fine, novel.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1. -- Those roaring Columbia Lions were sea Lions today and they splashed their way to a surprising and clear-cut victory over the Stanford football team, 7 -- 0, in the annual Tournament of Roses classic.
Frank Marquart, in a letter to THE TIMES, writes "gold is 15 times as valuable as silver because it takes 15 times as much of society's labor to produce it."

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27. -- The South has had its full share of the country's business depression this past year, but the effect on the section's agricultural interests has been greatly alleviated by the various kinds of assistance received from the government.

After an investigation of the provisions of the Economy Act, aimed at finding to what degree the actually war-disabled veterans had been reduced in their government compensation, the American Veterans Association reported yesterday that the study had satisfied its members "that no actual hardship has been meted out to the war-disabled veterans."
Laird Co. have admitted Philip G. Rust and Walter G. Guy as partners. The new members will have headquarters at: the firm's principal office in Wilmington, Del.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Evans Sperry of this city and Greenwich, Conn., formerly of Baltimore, gave a dinner with dancing last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for Mrs. Sperry's debutante daughter, Miss Georgia G. Buck. Mr. and Mrs. Sperry and Miss Evans received in a bower of palms and Spring flowers.

An increase in railway freight traffic, which began in May, brought loadings of cars in the first fifty-one weeks of 1933 to 2.6 per cent above those of the same period in 1932. Toward the middle of the year there was a revival in passenger traffic, which continued with a few interruptions to the start of 1934.

For years the price of Rio coffee has fluctuated within a limit of 2 cents a pound and except for a brief flurry caused by strife in Brazil, the range in Santos coffee has been similarly limited. Prices of coffee have been more stable than those of any other commodity.

New State and municipal bonds offered to investors by New York banking houses in 1933 totaled $343,328,000, or nearly 60 per cent of the $587,801,000 bonds marketed here during the year. The municipal offerings compared with $608,139,000 in 1932, and with 223 individual issues in 1933 against 299 in 1932.

Under the stimulus of a financing plan put forward by the Washington administration, there was revival in the market for rails and railway equipment in 1933. At the same time the railroads made farther progress in improvements such as the air conditioning of passenger cars and stream-lining.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Derby County climbed within two points of the league-leading Arsenal team, which was idle, as a result of today's soccer engagements in the first division of the English league. Derby had little trouble in turning back Everton, 3 -- 0.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- Bringing its total to 31 points, Dartmouth today won the Harding Trophy in the Lake Placid Club's thirteenth annual intercollegiate Winter sports competition.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- The grain trade experienced in 1933 one of the most hectic years in its history. The monetary situation became a most disturbing influence in the closing months.

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- France, Italy and Belgium are absolutely determined to remain on the gold standard. Even extremely heavy purchases of gold on the Continent for England and America, although capable of assisting manipulation of their exchanges, cannot reach such proportions as to compel these three gold-standard countries to detach their currencies from gold.
The improved railroad traffic in 1933 is noted in year-end statements of executives of the carriers, who express optimism for the future also. The statements include:

Emphasizing the responsibility of courts to utilize new scientific discoveries, Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn made public yesterday a decision giving judicial recognition to the Landsteiner blood-grouping test as an aid in determining a child's parentage.

Dressed in a dinner jacket, a stiff-bosom shirt and spats, Harry Kaufman, 35 years old, appeared yesterday in West Side Court, charged with burglary and possession of burglars' tools. According to the police, he was arrested in the apartment of Gerhardus H. Van Senden, a vice president of the Shell Oil Company, at 25 Central Park West, about midnight on Sunday.

After the frivolous references to Harvard men in "Big Hearted Herbert," which was staged at the Biltmore last evening, it is difficult for former students of Professor Baker to put themselves in the dispassionate mood of criticism. According to what Professor Baker used to teach in Comp. Lit. 19, a responsible critic should observe that Sophie Kerr and Anna Steese Richardson have turned an amusing comic idea into hokum farce.

The Class I railroads earned a net operating income of $465,000,000 in 1933, compared with $326,298,000 in 1932, according to an estimate by R.H. Aishton, chairman of the American Railway Association. Increased freight traffic and reduced expenses explained the rise.

An attack on the Tugwell Pure Food and Drugs Bill was made yesterday by the New York Board of Trade, Inc., which announced that it had completed a nation-wide survey which showed that the present act was "overwhelmingly favored over experimentation by theorists."

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1. -- Lou Little stepped on Tiny Thornhill's foot in a pro football game fifteen years ago. He stepped on it again today as Columbia beat Stanford in the classic Rose Bowl game.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Dec. 31. -- Frank Booth, president of the Alaska Native Brotherhood, declares that half of the 5,000 Indians in the Alaskan Panhandle have not received the full benefits of public work and other programs, that other government agencies have passed the issue to the Bureau of Indian Affairs and that the latter has been slow in meeting the emergencies.

NASHVILLE, Jan. 1 (AP). -- A new county grand jury was given special instructions today to investigate the recent abduction and lynching of Cord Cheek, 19-year-old Negro, and to "promptly indict" the perpetrators if their identity could be determined.
The New York Americans registered their second triumph in two days by turning back the Ottawa Senators at Madison Square Garden last night.
The eagerness of friends of the Neediest to cut down the number of cases still awaiting relief inspired forty contributions to the fund yesterday.
The public utilities last year went through one of the most trying years in all their history, but at the close of the period were apparently approaching calmer times.

Active buying in both dress and coat lines featured the week's trading in wholesale apparel markets here last week. The demand for dresses centred mainly on popular and low price ranges. Print dresses were purchased in volume. Formal dresses for dining and dancing sold well throughout the week.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1. -- The play-by-play detail of the Columbia-Stanford football game in the Rose Bowl today follows:

CHICAGO, .Dec. 30. -- Steady improvement in general business conditions is looked for in the Seventh Federal Reserve District during at least the first quarter of 1934. Federal spending has reinforced a normal recovery in private business and created a confidence that sees but two possibles dangers -- inflation of the currency and heavy taxation as the Federal Recovery Bill comes due.

BERLIN, Dec. 27. -- The forecast in financial circles, regarding Germany's political, financial and economic outlook for 1934, is on the whole favorable. Provided no serious international complications intervene, the stability of the present government seems assured.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec, 30. -- Business men in the Northwest view 1934 with the greatest optimism. The entire situation has been altered in 1933. In the last six months there has been liquidation in all lines far exceeding the greatest expectations.

The entire complexion of the cotton industry was changed last year by the extensive efforts of the administration to raise prices and curtail production through subsidies. Upon the success of this program will depend the fate of the industry for 1934.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 1. -- John Vincent Hinchliffe was sworn in today for his fourth term as Mayor of Paterson and the Democrats took complete control of the Board of Chosen Freeholders. Mayor Hinchliffe is the first Mayor to be elected for more than three terms.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1. -- Manhasset Bay was frozen over solid today and the scheduled dinghy sailing was impossible. The Frostbite Yacth Club thus on its second anniversary was forced to forego its cold-water adventure for the second day in succession.

The working forces of American seaboard shipyards at the end of 1933 exceeded by more than 1,000 the total a year ago, while unfinished construction was valued at $130,000,000 more than a year ago, according to H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders.

The suggestion that Sinclair Lewis has written "his own best answer to Babbitt" in his new novel, "Work of Art," comes from the publishers, Doubleday, Doran. The new novel, which will be published. late this month, is about a hotel manager.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 1. -- The new Board of Freeholders of Union County organized at the court house here this afternoon and elected Peter H. Meisel of Springfield as director. The new board, comprising nine members, succeeds a twenty-five-man board which was ousted by a referendum vote in last Spring's election.

Presidents of the leading commodity exchanges here are unanimous in expressing confidence that a more stable price structure will develop in 1934. In statements reviewing the last year, the heads of the New York Cotton Exchange, the Commodity Exchange, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and the New York Cocoa Exchange all point to the general improvement in the price level in 1934.

Policeman Saves Seagull From Clutch of a Clam, Odd Cloud in Bulgaria Puts Quail in Every Pot, London Parrot Can Uncork a Bottle, Tortoise Seizes a Flying Hawk -- none of these recent headlines can have meant so much to so many thousands of local bird and beast fanciers as the news of the death in the Bronx Zoo of Dr. DITMARS'S vampire bats, mother and child.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- To England 1933 has in an economic and financial sense been a remarkable period. In retrospect it has a very distinct patchwork appearance. In England quiet, orderly progress toward recovery has undoubtedly been made.

Following the receipt of about $40,000 in contributions last week, the German Relief Fund being raised under the auspices of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee closed the year with pledges totaling $1,301,654.

Stock swindlers, with methods revised to meet present-day conditions, have renewed their operations hereabouts, according to a report of the activities of the Better Business Bureau for the five months ending Dec. 31, made public yesterday.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 30. -- The Eleventh Federal Reserve District enters 1934 with the most hopeful outlook in three years. Wholesalers report that retailers throughout the Southwest practically emptied their shelves during the holiday buying season, and retailers themselves report the best holiday business in the last three years.

An indication of brighter times in prospect for real estate during the coming year was furnished yesterday with the announcement of an important deal in the Seventh Avenue district, involving the purchase of the old Hotel Grenoble site at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street by the J.H. Taylor Construction Company, which did considerable building in Manhattan prior to the depression.

Plans for an "International Travel Exposition," aimed to transform Madison Square Garden into a realization of the dreams of stay-at-homes and whet the appetites of blase globe-trotters, were announced yesterday for May 5 to 19 by the West Side Association of Commerce in New York City, which is sponsoring the affair on a nonprofit basis.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1. -- Led by a crashing back-field star, George Sauer of the University of Nebraska, West conquered East by 12-0 today in the football classic played here annually for charity.

Our Washington dispatches state definitely that the President is to ask Congress for new tariff legislation. He affirmed this intention at a conference with newspaper correspondents, "but "declined to indicate what form the "proposed legislation will take." It is suggested, however, that he may request authority to modify existing duties at certain points and within specified limits, in order to facilitate negotiation of commercial treaties.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 1. -- In double celebration of the New Year and of his seventy-seventh birthday, which will be tomorrow, John Shepard Jr., Mayor of Palm Beach, with Mrs. Shepard, gave a large open-house reception today at Casa del Pastor, in accord with his long-established custom.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 1. -- Punting, passing and charging hard through a mighty opposing line, Ralph Kercheval, Kentucky's great halfback, led a group of Northern team-mates to a 7-to-0 victory over a Southern galaxy of stars in a charity game today before 12,000 cheering fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- A six-point program for a new approach to the problem of Philippine independence, designed as "a fair and equitable arrangement satisfactory to both the Philippines and the United States," was recommended to President Roosevelt today by a committee of American citizens sponsored by the Foreign Policy Association and the World Peace Foundation.

There was substantial progress in 1933 toward the recovery of the place once held by the United States in world trade, according to the National Foreign Trade Council. That body reports that the returns for ten months of 1933 show an increase in our trade both with Europe and Latin America.
Michigan bank crisis and moratorium, Feb. 14.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Dec. 30. -- Returning confidence in Newfoundland was evident in the best Christmas shopping in this city for the past three years, despite the fact that earning power showed virtually no increase. Commercial circles declare the buying could only have been psychological.

While 1933 was crowded with events "pregnant with ecomonic and social significance," says J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company, "the outlook is certainly more cheering than it was in the early months," but in many cases "efforts are being made to make the codes go too far."

More than 10,000 persons, including Governor Moore, Representative Mary T. Norton and others prominent in the State, city and county, attended the annual New Year's reception for Mayor Frank Hague and other city officials at the City Hall in Jersey City yesterday.
MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 1. -- The Argentine Government has not yet succeeded in quelling the revolt which broke out early Friday morning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Secretary Woodin has resigned from the Cabinet and Henry Morgenthau Jr., Acting Secretary, was sworn in today as head of the Treasury.

Primo Carnera will meet Tommy Loughran in a fifteen-round contest for the heavyweight championship in Miami on Feb. 22. The bout, previously arranged subject to the approval of Louis Soresi, the champion's manager, last night received the sanction of Soresi in a cablegram to Col. John Reed Kilpatrick, Garden corporation president.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- Internal trade in Germany recorded considerable improvement in 1933. A long but so far slow wave of general recovery, of which the first signs appeared in the Autumn of 1932, continued without, however, increasing its pace.

SAINT LOUIS, Senegal, Jan. 1 (AP). -- The French seaplane Southern Cross made a non-stop flight of 2,666 miles from Berre, France, to Saint Louis today as a test, preparatory to flying the South Atlantic to South America. The plane was built for the regular South Atlantic airmail service, soon to be inaugurated.

Complete reorganization of the office of the Commissioner of Accounts under its new head, Paul Blanshard, is scheduled to be announced this week, it became known yesterday. Both in purpose and in form the new set-up of the department will resemble the investigating organization maintained by Samuel Seabury for the legislative inquiry into the city government.

The course of insurance last year followed closely that of industry and banking, passing through a critical stage in the first quarter and steadily improving throughout the remainder of the year. The general opinion of insurance leaders is that the outlook for their business now is better than it has been for several years.

BOSTON, Jan. 1. -- Mayor Frederick W. Mansfield, inaugurated today as the fortieth Mayor of Boston, dedicated his administration to a policy of "broad and reasonable economy" intended to limit to a maximum of $4 per $1,000, an inescapable tax rate increase this year.

The 1934 welfare needs of the country not covered by Federal, State or local government aid will be met by a fund of over $80,000,000 raised by Community Chests and other coordinated social work organizations. This was announced yesterday by Newton D. Baker, chairman of the 1933 Mobilization for Human Needs, in a New Year's letter sent to President Roosevelt.

DUBLIN, Jan. 1. -- The lawyers retained for the defense of General Owen O'Duffy, Blue Shirt leader, in the big State trial to open before a military tribunal in Dublin tomorrow sprang a surprise motion today in the High Court here, which may effectively checkmate the State prosecutor's move to have General O'Duffy tried in a military court and may nullify the proceedings.

ROME, Dec. 27. -- It cannot be said, at the year-end, that the American experiments with the dollar have visibly influenced European economy or European opinion. They have resulted, however, in substantial reductions of the international valuation for European obligations to America, originally created in gold. This is Europe's gain and America's loss.

In the subjoined columns is told the financial history of 1933, particularly with reference to America. It covers what is probably the most highly varied and strangely interesting succession of events that any twelve months of our national history has contained.

READING, Pa., Jan. 1. -- Norman T. Pugh, Coatesville wing shot, scoring thirty-five straight fliers from thirty yards' rise, led a field of sixty-eight gunners today in the South End Gun Club's amateur flier shoot.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- A complete revamping of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to "establish a compact organization to deal more effectively and directly with major problems confronting American agriculture" was announced today by Chester C. Davis, who recently succeeded George N. Peek as administrator.

George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, wrote yesterday to Mayor LaGuardia that the Department of Sanitation had broken down in the work of street cleaning and garbage removal in Queens. He asked the Mayor to give consideration to a plan to "return these activities of government to a Queens bureau."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP). -- The Shipping Board today recommended legislation requiring that at least half the commodities purchased in the United States through loans abroad should be moved in American ships. This was one of eighteen legislative changes advocated in the board's report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1933.

In his first radio address as Mayor of New York City, F.H. LaGuardia declared yesterday that the city had now been "restored to the people," but that the task ahead was difficult. He added that the type of experts he had selected and just sworn in as department heads was "our earnest of a non-partisan, non-political city administration."

The ratio of surplus to capital in the 300 savings and loan associations in New York State is even more favorable than it was before the depression, according to George M. Bode, president of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

Borough President Joseph A. Palma of Richmond was inducted into office yesterday at the Borough Hall at St. George. The ceremonies in the local board room were attended by 200 persons, including relatives, friends, city and county officials.
MUNICH, Jan. 1. -- Cardinal Faulhaber's New Year sermon contained a rebuke of exaggerated Germanism and a message that in "the kingdom of God there are neither favorites nor stepchildren."

Business recovery is on the up-grade all over the world; such is the gist of well-informed opinion at the beginning of 1934. As a consequence, it is not hard to predict the character of the New Year statements for Jan. 1, 1935.

Seven Harvard economists say that the New Deal, especially the monetary program and the NRA plans for artificial control of hours, wages and industry, is holding back recovery rather than stimulating it, in a book out today under the title of "The Economics of the Recovery Program."
" Sweden, Land of the Vikings," a film produced in natural color by John W. Boyle, with a narrative in English, will open at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse tomorrow.

From articles which have appeared in the newspapers it is evident that the sportsmen are trying to further their interests by proposing laws in the name of conservation that would prohibit commercial fishing in certain waters of the State. For fifty years the commercial fishermen have had to combat this type of legislation, and their success has been justified by the statistics of Fulton Fish Market, which reports a large oversupply of fish this year.

" The age-old idea that local transportation traffic throughout the United States follows employment and general business conditions is supported by current riding figures," says Labert St. Clair of the American Transit Association in a review of 1933.

" I did not come here to fall." That statement was uttered by Lou Little when he signed as Columbia coach after the close of the 1929 season. And his listeners, catching the vibrant personality of the man, felt that he would not fail.

Humanization of the Department of Public Welfare, elimination of politics, an increase in the amount of funds and provision for cash relief were the aims outlined yesterday by William Hodson, the new Commissioner of Public Welfare.
The Borough President, the Sheriff nd the Clerk of Bronx County formally assumed office yesterday and swore in their staffs.

NEWCASTLE, Ind., Jan. 1 (AP). -- Russell Cook, national director of the Americanism Commission of the American Legion, told the United States Naval Veterans Association here today that the Legion wanted the army and navy strong enough to insure and, if necessary, enforce peace.

The drive against panhandlers through the Civil Works Service, with the cooperation of the police, courts, Board of Parole and other agencies, got under way last night when Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein, in Night Court meted out two indeterminate sentences in the workhouse. An indeterminate sentence cannot exceed two years.
" Halfway to Hell," a mystery melodrama by Crane Wilbur, will have its premiere this evening at the Fulton Theatre. Carleton Macy, Austin Fairman and Katherine Locke are in the cast.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- John Wesley Lewis today received a warm greeting from several hundred friends at a dinner and reception held in the Hotel Statler, in celebration of his hundredth birthday.
PARIS, Jan. 1. -- With the New Year France opens a campaign of trade protection which threatens to exceed in severity anything yet attempted by this highly protectionist country.

ROME. Dec. 27. -- The outlook as seen here for the world's wheat situation in 1934 does not seem to indicate any serious tendency in Europe to reduce production. The yearly surplus stocks, which were 67,000,000 quintals in 1929, have risen progressively to 140,000,000 in 1930, to 153,000,000 in 1931, to 160,000,000 in 1932 and to 187,000,000 in 1933.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Wider alternation of business conditions than those prevailing in 1933, greater contrasts between conditions prevailing at different times in the year, have seldom been experienced in our history. Taken as a whole, business has been decidedly better than in 1932; in some respects it has compared favorably with a great part of 1931.

Reports from the twelve Federal Reserve districts describing the results of 1933 and prospects for 1934 indicate the substantial nature of the recovery in employment and in production and sale of consumer goods, besides a more moderate revival in capital goods.

Investment trusts in this country progressed last year toward their goal, which is to provide a medium for group investment of an institutional nature. In view of the unusual financial problems which arose, their officers found it necessary to concentrate on the problems of management of the funds in their care.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- The special boards of review named in August by General Frank T. Hines, Veterans Administrator, to review the cases of "presumptive" disability claims of World War veterans, disallowed 57.13 per cent of the claims, General Hines reported today.

With our bankers so intent upon imposing bigger and more burdensome service charges, it might not be amiss to point out that here again, like hungry dogs, they are attempting to feast upon their own tails and that the elaborate cost analyses by which they fain would justify such charges are vitiated by the perfectly erroneous assumptions upon which they rest.

Presidents of leading textile factors, dry goods and department stores report a fairly prosperous year, with further improvement expected in 1934. Most of them attributed their better business in 1933 than in 1932 and the more optimistic outlook for 1934 to the efforts of the national administration under the NRA codes to bring about general recovery.

Secretary WOODIN'S departure from the Treasury was not unexpected. The condition of his health, which has long prevented performance of official duties, made his giving up the office unavoidable. It was known some time ago that he wished to retire, and that his resignation was in the President's hands.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 30. -- The Fifth Reserve District looks forward to a new year with measurably brighter prospects than was the case twelve months ago. Prosperity has not arrived, but better times seem in sight for 1934.

With the suspension of the gold standard in the United States last April and the subsequent fall of the dollar in foreign exchange to an extreme discount of nearly 42 per cent by mid-November, the dollar last year supplanted sterling as the storm centre of the foreign exchange market.
Frank Parker of Lawrenceville School, youngest member of the first ten in tennis, brought his initial quest for the national junior indoor singles crown to a successful conclusion yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 30. -- Merchants, men in other lines and professional men in the Sixth Federal Reserve District are optimistic for the new year. In all industrial centres in the area there are expressions of confidence.

A police department utterly free of political domination will war up-on gangs of criminals that have had official protection, Mayor LaGuardia told 200 ranking officers at Police Headquarters yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 1. -- President von Hindenburg gave all credit for the "spiritual regeneration" of Germany to Chancellor Hitler today in replying to New Year's greetings from members of the government. The President expressed "gratification and thankfulness" that the wish he had uttered on Jan. 1, 1933, had been fulfilled.
Battle lines were drawn yesterday between the Republican-Fusion members of the Board of Aldermen and the Tammany majority when they met together for the first time at noon in City Hall.

LONDON, Jan. 1. -- George Bernard Shaw, the Irish-born chairman, on behalf of the two Scots, two Welshmen and one American composing with him the advisory committee to the British Broadcasting Corporation on points of spoken English, has written to The Times of London defending their latest recommendations.

" The Emperor Jones," the opera which took in more money at the box office than any other production last season, returned to the Metropolitan stage yesterday afternoon as the second half of a holiday matinee. As was the order of events last year, "Pagliacci" was the first half of the double bill.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Roger Ames Burr, journalist and former diplomat, arrived in Boston today aboard the steamship Capulin and told immigration authorities he had been "expelled" from Germany because of an article he had written which criticized Chancellor Hitler.

NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J., Jan. 1. -- The organization meeting of the Council at Borough Hall here this afternoon was stormy from the start and ended in a free-for-all fight, with the two factions of Councilmen and their supporters taking part.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 1. -- Freddy Miller of Cincinnati, recognized by the National Boxing Association as featherweight champion, today bludgeoned Jackie Sharkey, Minneapolis contender, into submission in a fifth successful defense of his title.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., who became Secretary of the Treasury today, has in less than ten months as Federal official acquired the reputation of being one of the most effective executives ever included in the official family of a President.

Until last Spring production, transportation and trade activity in every field of American industry had reported without exception a decrease in each month since 1929 as compared with the same month a year before. The striking industrial phenomenon of 1933 was first the sudden change to a large monthly increase over 1932; also the violence of the recovery in production and trade activity between April and the latter part of July.

George S. Silzer, former Governor of New Jersey, announced yesterday that a comprehensive stockholders' protective committee was "in the course of formation" and would press suits of various sort against the Chase National Bank and the Chase Securities Company.

Although grave economic problems lie ahead, the feeling is general among business men that the worst has been passed, Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday in discussing the trend at the beginning of the new year.

Nearly 11,000 savings, building and loan associations in all parts of the country were to operate today for the first time under the terms of the NRA code for their business signed by President Roosevelt on Dec. 21.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Butter and egg brokers looked back over 1933 with pleased expressions today and held generally that it was satisfactory, trading having been heavy. Speculators, on the contrary, lost heavily as prices receded to low records.

The record of the savings banks in the State of New York was remarkably good last year, according to Henry R. Kinsey, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York. Deposits at the end of the year were 14.2 per cent above the total at the end of 1929, he said, while the number of depositors had increased 10.7 per cent.

The proclamation by President Roosevelt fixing a price of 64 1/2 cents an ounce for silver newly mined in this country and its possessions materially improved the outlook of the American silver industry for this year. The importance of the order to the industry lay largely in the fact that the government's price is roughly 50 per cent higher than the world price.

The North American continent is definitely headed for the greatest prosperity it has ever known, according to Case R. Howard, president of the Canadian-American Trade Corporation, in a review of industrial conditions in Canada for 1933.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1. -- Launching a sensational aerial attack in the last two periods after a scoreless first half, the strong Duquesne University football team from Pittsburgh today crushed the University of Miami Hurricanes, 33 to 7, in a New Year's Day gridiron classic before 6,000 spectators.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1. -- Sylvester W. Labrot's Maryland-bred mare Monel scored a driving length-and-a-half victory over Jamison in the New Year's Handicap at Tropical Park today. Mrs. Nat Ray's Stealingaway was third.

Estimated revenues of the electric light and power industry in 1933 were $1,772,325,000, comparing with $1,832,596,000 in 1932, according to the Edison Electric Institute, a decline of 3.3 per cent. Sales of electricity were 65,565,000,000 kilowatt-hours, against 63,765,000,000 in 1932, a gain of 2.8 per cent.
Upward of 2,500 men attended yesterday the annual New Year's solemn high mass of the Archdiocesan Union of Holy Name Societies in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The country will fear that the dignity, if not the collective head, of the Senate of the United States will be further swollen by the discovery that the brains of Senators are two ounces heavier than those of Representatives. This inference is based upon measurements of the skull.

" The Waterfowl Crisis and the Remedy" is the title under which discussions on this subject are listed for the twentieth conference of the American Game Association which will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania here on Jan. 22, 23 and 24. Under that general heading there will be read and discussed seven papers from which, supposedly, there will come at least the outline of a program which it is hoped will solve the problem.

Mayor LaGuardia will call his first official conference on rapid transit unification this week, he said yesterday. He and his advisers in transit and fiscal matters have already held a preliminary meeting with spokesmen for the B.M.T. and the Interborough.

Improvement in the consumption and output of steel is expected by the iron and steel industry in 1934, according to Walter S. Tower, executive secretary of the American Iron and Steel Institute. This expectation, Mr. Tower said, is based on signs of expanding demand together with a stabilized structure and more favorable marketing conditions resulting from the industry's code of fair competition.

Political factors were most important last year in the raw sugar situation and promise to play the leading part again this year, in the opinion of the trade. Sugar has been subjected to violent political disturbances in Cuba, as well as to the proposing and abandoning of numerous plans for its benefit under the recovery program in this country.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 1. -- A bell from the German cruiser Emden, stolen from the Sydney War Museum in April, has been found buried in park lands in the outskirts of Melbourne.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Oswald West, former Governor of Oregon -- out where cowboys are cowboys -- tosses a verbal lariat at the Western art of Charles Keck, New York artist, in the William Rockhill Nelson Gallery of Art here.

A feeling of confidence in marked contrast to that existing at the close of 1932 featured the end of the year in retail, wholesale and manufacturing circles in the metropolitan area. A wider movement of merchandise, a return to a profit basis and much more stable marketing and production conditions due to the NRA are cited as the major possibilities for 1934.

Investment banking has just ended its most disorganized and inactive year since the World War, and yet many investment bankers are definitely hopeful and confident in their outlook. This is the opinion voiced by Robert E. Christie Jr. of Dillon, Read Co., president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, in surveying the outlook for one of the nation's most important financial groups.
Banks began yesterday to issue reports of their condition at the close of last year.

Three questions have been constantly asked this year: (1) As a matter of history, has any of our great depressions ever been terminated by depreciation of the currency? The answer is, No. (2) Has the United States ever resorted to depreciated money in such depression? The answer is, Never. (3) Has currency agitation been usual in such periods? The answer is, Always.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1. -- Dr. Melchior Palyi, eminent German economist who was displaced by the Nazis from important academic and semi-official positions in Berlin because of his liberal convictions, has been appointed visiting Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago. Dr. Palyi arrived here last week and will begin teaching tomorrow.

The Federal gift tax as embodied in the Revenue Act of 1932 is designed to impose a tax which measurably approaches the estate tax and reaches gifts that otherwise would escape the estate tax, according to Fred L. Main, treasurer of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants.

Following one of their poorest years in more than a decade from the viewpoint of earnings, virtually all of the important copper companies in the United States are believed to have operated last year at a modest profit before allowances are made for depreciation charges.

THE NEW YORK TIMES average for fifty stocks stood at 85.66 at the close of 1933, comparing with a high mark of 98.05 on July 18 and a low one of 46.85 on March 2. The high point for 1932 was 80.88, and the low, 33.98. This also was the low mark for the depression and the lowest average in more than twenty years.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, has been appointed Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York. This office, which is the second highest in the archdiocese, was given to Mgr. Lavelle by Cardinal Hayes as a New Year gift.

GRAZ, Austria, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Jakob Wassermann, whose novels on social maladjustments brought him world fame but the displeasure of Prussian Nazis, had been living during the last few months at his country estate near here after a movement to encourage a strictly "German" literature had made him unpopular at home.

The New York Stock Exchange was a far different institution at the close of 1933 from what it had been at the beginning of the year. Under the threat of government regulation, many changes and reforms in the methods of the Exchange and its brokers, some of which had been under consideration for years, were approved. Almost all the changes were aimed to protect the trading and investing public.

VIENNA, Dec. 31. -- Austria's efforts for 1934 aim at using the interests of France, Poland and Italy in her independence for attaining the long-promised economic preferences. Public works, particularly road-building, having been financed for a whole year by an internal loan, are to reduce the number of unemployed by at least 50,000 under average level.

The Federal Reserve Board's policy during 1933 was expressed chiefly in the open-market operations of the system. During the first four months of the year the central banks confined their operations chiefly to an attempt to relieve the strain of the banking crisis and to preserve their own strength in the face of the wide-spread demand for currency and gold from hoarders at home and from central banks abroad.

Extension of the national government's activity in railroad finance was the major fiscal development in the transportation field in 1933. This took the form of the organization early in November of a railroad division in the Public Works Administration headed by F.C. Wright, vice president of the Bangor Aroostook Railroad.

MOUNT VERNON. N.Y., Jan. 1. -- Chief Inspector Michael I. Silverstein, head of the Mount Vernon Police Department, publicly commended today the heroism of Patrolman John Bradley, 33 years old, who suffered burns yesterday in rescuing six persons, including several children, from the Plaza Theatre here when a fire drove 450 matinee patrons into the street.
The dealings in stocks and bonds on the New York Stock Exchange in 1933 compare as follows with the preceding years:

With brisk and quiet efficiency F.H. LaGuardia took over the control of city government yesterday and started at once on the house-cleaning through which he hopes to establish a financially sound and well-managed community.

Holders of hotel securities can hope for little relief this year except in those occasional instances in which earnings last year were substantial, according to Ralph Hitz, president of the Hotel New Yorker and the National Hotel Management Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1. -- The strange sight of Democrats taking over positions in the Philadelphia city-county government held by Republicans for a generation or more was witnessed here today as a result of the Vare organization's defeat last November.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 -- Crushing walls of water raced down out of the Sierra Nevada foothills last night and today as the result of the heaviest rainfall in years and devastated large areas throughout Los Angeles County.
