WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 1. -- Small depositors in more than 95 per cent of the unrestricted banks of the country are insured 100 per cent against loss for the next six months, Walter J. Cummings. chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, informed President Roosevelt today.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 30. -- A survey of economic conditions by the Bureau of Statistics of the Dominion Government indicates a considerable betterment in the last year in Canada. Most of the statistical factors used in measuring the trend of general welfare are at higher levels than at the end of 1932.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- The outlook for 1934, as seen by most business leaders here, is for steady expansion in virtually all lines of trade, with greater employment, reduced relief rolls, enlarged distribution of work and money and better understanding of business conditions.

Concerted efforts in many parts of the country to fight the various forms of commercialized crime which has come to be known as racketeering are healthful signs for the new year. Here in this city, which has sometimes seemed to be a special resort and stronghold of racketeers, the movement against them is taking on a new and hopeful form.

The outlook for higher market prices for the shares of banks in this city depends upon three principal factors, according to Colonel Oliver J. Troster of Hoit, Rose Troster. These factors, he says, are:

Alfred E. Smith, former Governor, praised President Roosevelt again for his part in the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment in his leading editorial, "Happy New Year," in the January issue of New Outlook, out today.

Declaring that the nickel industry apparently has benefited from the recent years of depression, Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., states that "we are coming only now to appreciate the changes the depression has wrought in the industrial attitude toward better materials, better performance and lower ultimate costs."
VIENNA, Jan. 1. -- The Austrian Nazi leader Alfred Fraunfeld was released from jail today and the State Prosecutor was ordered to drop further legal steps against him.

Albert Marinelli and Daniel E. Finn, two of the small number of Tammany Democrats elected in November, assumed their new posts yesterday. Mr. Marinelli is the new County Clerk, succeeding Mr. Finn, who became the new Sheriff. Both are district leaders.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 1 (AP). -- About 150 persons appeared today before Magistrate John L. Draper and added their signatures to the $5,000 bonds which Paul M. Davis and Vance J. Alexander, bankers, made Saturday following issuance of a warrant charging them with conspiracy to defraud the State.

HOUSTON, Texas, Jan. 1. -- The Three Ds Stock Farm of W.T. Waggoner provided the winner of the W.T. Waggoner Handicap, which featured the closing day charity card at Epsom Downs today, when Quatre Bras II lasted to win by a nose from C. Leroy King's Pari-Mutuel.

The year 1933 was most trying for even the alert investment-trust managements, but year-end reports may show that the trusts generally performed their functions commendably, according to Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation.

Statements by leaders of American trade and industry at the beginning of 1934 show a marked unanimity of opinion that the recovery will progress, although slowly, throughout the year. Most of the leaders refer to some uncertainty which they feel with respect to the fundamentals of the new laws governing economic life in the United States, but they testify to real improvement accomplished under the New Deal.

The NRA has brought the United States into a new era of economic reformation and social renaissance which will have lasting beneficial results, according to Grover A. Whalen, Administrator of the NRA for New York City. He added that he was equally confident that the NRA as a factor in national life would become increasingly important as the people's understanding of its significance increased.

Columbia alumni throughout the city welcomed with almost delirious joy the Lions' victory over Stanford yesterday. At the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street more than 300 graduates crowded every inch of space on the first two floors to listen to the radio broadcast or to follow the plays on a chart set up in the main dining room.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 1 (AP). -- A brilliant display of fireworks on the snow-bound summit of famous Pike's Peak, 14,181 feet above sea level, was Colorado's outstanding greeting to the New Year.
LONDON, Jan. 1. -- Britain's New Year's Day was darkened by one of the worst fogs in years, covering an area of some 7,000 square miles.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Speculative trading in grains on the Board of Trade here this year was materially in excess of that in either of the two previous years, aggregate sales being 15,573,098,000 bushels, with yesterday's figures not included. This was 5,567,000,000 bushels more than in 1932 and 4,070,000,000 bushels in excess of 1931.

Reduction of retardation and of overage pupils, a higher promotion rate and smaller classes are noted by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, in his final annual report, a part of which was made public yesterday.
Last year was one of progress, according to James Brown, president of the New York State Chamber of Commerce. In summarizing the current situation, he said:

ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, arrived here tonight, determined to press his fight against re-election of Fred W. Hammond of Onondaga County as clerk of the Assembly.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 1. -- Two hundred thousand Bucharest citizens filed before the body of the assassinated Premier Ion G. Duca lying in state today in the Athenaeum. This afternoon members of the diplomatic corps visited the Athenaeum and the dean of the corps, the Papal Nuncio, placed a wreath on the bier on behalf of himself and his colleagues.

In The Financial Post of Toronto Professor KENNETH TAYLOR has an informing and judicious article on the outside companies that have established branches in the Dominion. Some came as early as 1880, but most since the war. In 1919 there were two hundred of them, in 1930 twelve hundred.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 26. -- Conditions in the last two months of 1933 provide a basis for judging what improvement ought to come in 1934. Of the four traditionally largest steel-consuming lines, only the automobile industry did even moderately well in 1933. In the last two months, on account of the season, even that industry absorbed little steel.

After discussing mergers of various types in the last ten years, the telegraph, cable and radio companies came closer late in 1933 to the fulfillment of this purpose than at any previous time in history. This resulted from submission to President Roosevelt of a report by the Interdepartmental Communications Commission in which considerable space was devoted to a merger of the telegraph companies.

LONDON, Jan. 1, -- The publication in The London Times yesterday of a section of film taken by a Scottish movie company and purporting to be a long-distance shot of the Loch Hess "monster" has failed apparently to convince skeptics, who hold that the picture is remarkably like that of a drifting tree trunk.

Members of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York were .urged yesterday to protest to Senators Copeland and Wagner against the ratification of the proposed treaty with Canada for the development of the St. Lawrence waterway.

William C. Dodge, who was elected District Attorney of New York County last Nov. 7 on the Tammany ticket, took office yesterday morning in the District Attorney's quarters, 137 Centre Street, and in vigorous talks told members of his prosecuting and clerical staffs that four years of arduous work were before them.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1. -- Setting a precedent in reporting on operations, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company mailed today to shareholders a "breakdown" of its account of earnings for 1933. The figures are part of the annual report made by James R. Leavell, president, to the stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP). -- In the first move to rebuild the Republican party since the overwhelming defeat of 1932, Senator McNary, Senate leader, today named a committee of nine to conduct the campaign for election of Republican Senators next Fall.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 1. -- Heartly W. (Hunk) Anderson, the late Knute Rockne's right-hand man at Notre Dame and who succeeded him there, today signed a three-year contract to coach football at North Carolina State College.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 2. -- The Essex County Board of Chosen Freeholders organized for 1934 today with the election of William H. Rawson of Bloomfield as director. Mr. Rawson succeeded Zenas G. Crane, who will resign to be appointed County Treasurer.
Trading on the Cotton Exchange started the new year with an advance of about $1 a bale, and under a liberal volume of business, ended with gains of 15 to 20 points.

The first public building here to benefit under the Public Works of Art Project will be the County Court House. Within a few days the erection of scaffolding there will herald the expected arrival of unemployed mural painters to begin the decoration of the entrance vestibule and great hall.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- The first working day of the new year on the Stock Exchange opened with a strong note of optimism. All sections were firm. Further improvement in unemployment was the chief favorable factor, while trade and revenue statistics helped.

It becomes every day more evident that for world trade as it has developed in the last two decades gold should furnish a stable and permanent pricemeasure, a common denominator for currencies, commodities and services all over the world. This, however, is very difficult if the gold price varies occasionally as far as $2 on the fine ounce of gold.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP) -- With collapse of its price-control system probable unless immediate action toward adjustment is taken, the New York Milk Board moved swiftly today to obtain the cooperation of other States in regulation of the milk industry.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2. -- A president of the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics has just been dismissed from his post and the news did not create a ripple in Moscow, not even getting a headline in the newspapers.
Several companies announced yesterday plans for paying extra, increased or resumed dividends. In the group were some that had deferred action last month.
MONTREAL, Jan. 2. -- The leading scorer on the league's leading team, Charlie Conacher of Toronto, went into the new year at the head of all point-makers of the National Hockey League.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- The City National Bank and Trust Company operated on a profitable basis in the last eight months of 1933 despite abnormally large cash resources and an absence of demand for commercial loans, according to the second annual statement of the bank, issued today by Charles G. Dawes, chairman, and Philip R. Clarke, president.
ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- Governor Lehman announced tonight a new State policy for unemployment relief, made necessary by the revision of Federal policy under the Civil Works program.

The LaGuardia Economy Act follows closely Washington precedents. It is modeled on the law enacted in the last days of the Hoover Administration, giving the President-elect power to reorganize Federal bureaus, and on the Economy Act passed a few weeks later, giving Mr. ROOSEVELT authority to make further reductions in government pay.
Extensive investigations into city departments and county offices will be carried on by Paul Blanshard, new Commissioner of Accounts, and his counsel, Irving Ben Cooper, it was learned yesterday.

The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California announced yesterday that it would offer on Jan. 19 a new issue of $8,064,000 of bonds. The issue will be dated Feb. 1, 1934, and will mature serially from 1949 to 1984. The rate of interest, to be named by the bidders, is not to exceed 5 per cent.

PEIPING, Jan. 2. -- The United States Legation is informed that the first withdrawal of Americans from Changchow and Siokhe to Amoy was completed today. In the Foochow district all the Americans from Yenping and Kiening have been evacuated and those from Kutien and Mintsing are expected to withdraw immediately on receiving consular advice.

Reduction of the salaries of city officials and employes on a wide scale appeared certain yesterday as Mayor LaGuardia moved to obtain power from the Legislature to fix the compensation of certain employes by executive order as well as to order furloughs of one month without pay for a majority of those in city service.

While attorneys for Captain Jacob Van Assen, 64 years old, of 135 Garden Street, Hoboken, were waiting yesterday in Kings County Supreme Court, for him to make an appearance as plaintiff in a lawsuit pending since 1929, Captain Van Assen was found dead in his apartment with a bullet wound in his body.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Canada has been placed in a much improved position, so far as her outside indebtedness is concerned, by the policy of the present United States administration, H. H. Stevens, Minister of Trade and Commerce, states in a review of conditions at the close of 1933.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 2. -- With tho 1934 Legislature convening a week from today, the Republican joint conference committee today futhered the majority plans for the session.

Agents of the Federal Department of Justice have been working for more than a week to trace the writer of a letter in which Kenneth O'Brien, son-in-law of Clarence Mackay, and his wife and children were threatened with death unless Mr. O'Brien paid $5,000, it was learned yesterday.

The first regular business day of the new year found realty trading light in the metropolitan district. The list of auction sales was small, only four parcels changing hands. An apartment building in the Bronx was reported in new ownership, and a large new restaurant was projected in midtown Fifth Avenue.
BOSTON, Jan. 2. -- The keels of four naval vessels, including a treaty heavy cruiser and three replacement destroyers, were laid today by the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation at Fore River.

BERLIN, Jan. 2. -- The Boerse began the new year today in a confident mood. The turnover was still small, but there were signs of increased interest. Both stock and bond quotations were buoyant, although the best prices of the day began to taper off toward the close.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP). -- The District of Columbia Supreme Court, in a suit involving Andrew W. Mellon and Ogden L. Mills, former Secretaries of the Treasury, ruled today that under facts developed in the test case former public officials were immune from suit for acts done while in office.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP). -Knee-deep in tons of mud, silt and debris, an army of relief and rehabilitation workers moved today into stricken areas where at least 35 persons died and 73 others were reported missing in Sunday night's disastrous floods.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- Hailing President Roosevelt and Premier Molotoff as "two real allies of peace," Arthur Henderson, president of the Disarmament Conference, said in The Daily Herald tonight that in spirit, if not formally, both the United States and Russia had been cooperating with the League of Nations in its attempts to further international understanding and agreement on problems that were the world's common concern.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2. -- Yesterday was the players' day for Columbia; today belonged to the alumni.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Jan. 2 (AP). -- The effort of Walter R. Reppin, 18, of Newark, N.J., to escape being the first victim of Colorado's new lethal gas chamber met a setback here late today when District Judge John C. Young declined to consider a petition to vacate Reppin's guilty plea to a murder charge.

I have read the solemn roll-call of the heroes of repeal. I agree it is right the accolade should be placed upon the shoulders of such as Governor Smith, President Butler, Captain Stayton and, especially, President Roosevelt. I should like to have seen a word of credit given to the old New York World, which was the first to fight against prohibition and which persisted in the fight until its death.

Plans were announced last night for the purchase of control of the Munson Steamship Line by the International Mercantile Marine Company and the merger of their operations at sea and ashore. A joint statement issued by Frank C. Munson and P. A. S. Franklin, presidents of the two companies, said that details had been completed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Substantial progress toward recovery at a rate which will be healthy for business and industry will be recorded during 1934, according to Malcolm Muir, division administrator of the NRA, who issued a statement today summarizing reports made to him.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP). -Secretary Wallace today announced appointment of a committee to develop and supervise a nation-wide plan for promoting and protecting wild life.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,139,850 barrels, compared with 2,289,900 in the previous week, a decline of 150,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Decreases of 110,350 barrels in the daily output of Oklahoma and 31,500 in that of California were the most important changes.
Columbia, by beating Stanford in the rain and mud of Pasadena's annual pageant, had revived morale in Eastern football circles yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

A minimum of $34,450 to back the twenty-eight books on their Spring list is guaranteed by Little, Brown. Their "big book" will be "Journey to the End of the Night," by Louis-Ferdinand Celine, which in Europe has been called both "the literary discovery of the year" and "an insult to the reader."

PARIS, Jan. 2. -- Efforts are being made to discover the status of the assurances given the United States Embassy on Sept. 1, that the United States would receive exceptional treatment when the French quota system became effective.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained fifty-eight guests at dinner tonight. A large company came afterward for a musicale in the East Room.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The banking inquiry by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency will be resumed tomorrow. Senator Fletcher, chairman of the committee, said today that it was his intention to conclude the investigation as speedily as possible.

HAVANA, Jan. 2. -- The election of a constituent Assembly will take place on April 22, according to a statement to the press this afternoon by President Ramon Grau San Martin, who asserted he would turn the reigns of government over to the Assembly on May 20.

Total net assets of the General American Investors Company, before deducting debentures, were increased $6,788,127, or 45 per cent, during the last year, according to a statement made by the company in connection with its report for 1933.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 2. -- Coming from far back with a great burst of speed, Joseph Hoskins's Bel Ora wore down the leaders to win by a length at Agua Caliente today. W. J. Davis's Leano, winner of his last start, was second and Fair Rose took the show.

Jack Sherry of Ohio threw Little Beaver, Cherokee Indian, with a body slam in 23 minutes and 9 seconds of the main finish wrestling match at the New York Coliseum last night. Sherry won before a crowd of 1,500 fans. Sherry weighed 218 pounds and Little Beaver 223.
Mayor LaGuardia faced two groups of unemployed women who went to City Hall yesterday demanding relief, one an orderly delegation of 100 and the other a dozen belligerents.

The committee on securities of the New York Stock Exchange ruled yesterday that the following bond issues, on which the interest due yesterday was not paid, will henceforth be dealt in flat with the Jan. 1, 1934, and subsequent coupons attached:
A tentative draft of a bill to abolish the city magistrates' courts and the Court of Special Sessions and to create in their stead a new Court of Special Sessions was completed last evening.

ALBANY, Wednesday, Jan. 3. -A conference of Republican Assemblymen, which began as a caucus, convened here last night for the purpose of nominating candidates for Speaker, clerk and some minor offices in the lower house, adjourned soon after 1 o'clock this morning after renominating Joseph A. McGinnies of Chautauqua for the Speakership and making nominations for all other offices with the exception of the clerkship.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 2. -According to the last accounting filed in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court here last May by Franklyn L. Hutton of 1,020 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan, as guardian of his daughter, Barbara, who is now the Princess Alexis Mdivani, the latter's fotrune amounted to $42,077,328.53.
Governor Lehman ordered yesterday Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, to prosecute promptly any of its employes found taking graft.

Doris Warner, eldest daughter of Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers, was married yesterday to Mervyn LeRoy, prominent young film director of the Warner company, in the presence of 200 film notables at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 2. -- Discovery of a revolutionary plot in Chile today makes that country the third in South America in which revolts have been attempted within the past fortnight. Scores of arrests were reported in Santiago, Valparaiso and Concepcion.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 2. -After running relays all last Winter to give three Princeton seniors a chance to win titles also, Bill Bonthron will compete in four individual races during the present indoor season, Coach Matty Geis of the Tiger trackmen announced today.

A PLAY in two acts and several scenes. Setting, the living room of Anyhouse, near New York, New Year's Day, A.D. 1934. The lead is played by a small, brown radio in fair condition. Among the supporting cast are Grand Stand Quarterback, Sideline Field Marshal, Neighbors, Innocent Bystander.

Seventy-one contributions added $638.09 to the fund for New York's Neediest Cases yesterday and brought the total given thus far this year to $221,585.07. This leaves the fund still $43,814.46 short of the amount contributed last year, which provided for 428 cases.

PHILADELPIA, Jan. 2. -- Mrs. J. S. Disston Jr. of the Philadelphia Cricket Club was the first entrant to reach the fourth round at the opening of the fourth annual women's Pennsylvania State squash racquets championship tournament at the Merion Cricket Club today.

An intensive drive to place at least 12,000 unemployed residents of the Bronx in jobs within the next six weeks was promised last night by Borough President James J. Lyons in a radio address over Station WBNX. Mr. Lyons said that he had already conferred with Travis Whitney, local Civil Works Administrator, and that he hoped to get a Federal grant of $1,200,000 for CWA projects.

The members of Mayor LaGuardia's official family took over control of the city departments yesterday, dismissing deputy commissioners and aides of the O'Brien regime and installing their own personal staffs.

BERLIN, Jan. 2. -- The United States Government has now protested to the German Government against the arbitrary reduction of the interest payments on German foreign indebtedness, it became known here today.
Bernard S. Deutsch, new President of the Board of Aldermen, went to work yesterday in an office which had been swept clear of furnishings, even down to the pens, ink and blotters on his own desk.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2. -- One of Sylvester W. Labrot's Maryland-bred racers won the featured event at Tropical Park for the second successive day when the Happy Time filly Toytime today galloped home the victor by a length and a half in the Homestead Purse.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 2. -- A temporary injunction restraining the National Recovery Administration, the Code Authority of the Suit and Coat Industry and Frank S. Bergin, United States District Attorney of Connecticut, from enforcing provisions of the code for that industry in the cases of five Connecticut manufacturers was granted today by Judge Edwin S. Thomas in the United States Court, pending a hearing on Jan. 15.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2. -- Fortythree men and women who have studied at first hand the foreign mission fields of the Presbyterian Church issued a statement today in reply to recent criticisms of the denomination's mission work by a Fundamentalist group.

Resolutions demanding that the Federal and municipal budgets be balanced have been formulated by committees of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and will be acted upon at the meeting of the chamber tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 2. -Mrs. Genevieve Switz, mother of Robert Switz, held by French police as an alleged international spy, is seriously ill in the home of New York friends, it was revealed here today at her home by Paul Switz, another son.

Mayor LAGUARDIA was at his desk in City Hall yesterday morning, his first working day, at 9:17. This is reassuring. If the new Mayor had turned up in his office yesterday at 6, and had announced that this would be his hour henceforth, the community might have been thrilled, but thoughtful citizens would have looked anxious.
The Toronto University hockey team, boasting a fine record, will oppose Princeton at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Lord BIRKENHEAD was the youngest man ever appointed Lord Chancellor. Had he the further distinction of being the only Lord Chancellor with gypsy blood in him? In a lecture before the Society of Genealogists, Lieut. Col. HAWKES mentioned the Lees of Sussex and the Hearns of Kent and other English gypsy clans.

Kinrey Matsuyama won the opening two blocks of his twelve-block three-cushion billiard match with Kay Bozeman at Kreuter's Capitol Academy yesterday. He triumphed in the afternoon, 40 to 26, in forty innings, and also took the evening session, 40 to 39, in thirty-eight innings.

Praise for Mayor F. H. LaGuardia as having a liberal viewpoint was expressed yesterday by former Representative Thomas R. Amlie of Wisconsin, who arrived here to attend the mass meeting of the Farmer Labor Political Federation at Cooper Union tomorrow evening.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Smith entertained tonight for their daughter, Miss Laura Smith, who is their holiday guest from Foxcroft School in Middleburg, Va., inviting several members of the school set to the boxing matches at the American Legion Arena and later to supper at Casa Invierno.

Once more the New York Rangers are out of the cellar. The Patrick skaters, who, save for a brief spell last week, have been the tail-enders in the American group of the National Hockey League since the start of the season, jumped into second place last night by defeating the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden, 3 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- As a result of complaints that imports of matches and wool felt hat bodies were endangering the new domestic industry in these articles, President Roosevelt today directed the Tariff Commission to make immediate investigations, into the effect of the imports on the industries.
ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- For the first time in the history of the Legislature, the Senate may have a woman clerk during the 1934 session.

Prosecutions for putting a turkey on roller skates, failure to restrain a monkey, tantalizing and teasing raccoons and failure to safeguard the public from a lion, were listed yesterday in the annual report of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

The personnel of the squash racquets team from the Jesters Club of London, which will arrive here on Jan. 22 for a tour of the United States and Canada, was announced yesterday by Edwin H. Bigelow, president of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Further banks and trust companies yesterday issued reports of their position as of the close of the year, although as yet no official calls for such statements have been made. The reports thus far issued show strikingly little variation from the figures of a year ago, so far as total resources and deposits are concerned.

The Metropolitan debut of Lotte Lehmann as Sieglinde in "Die Walkure," the revival of Strauss's "Salome" and the season's first "Manon" and "Cavalleria Rusticana" will feature the third week of the Metropolitan Opera season next week.

DELHI, India, Jan. 2. -- Investigation of the conspiracy which led to the recent assassination of King Nadir Shah at Kabul, Afghanistan, has resulted thus far in sixteen executions and two sentences of life imprisonment.

James Talcott, Inc., yesterday announced the following appointments effective Monday: Thomas J. McGann, to be vice president and controller; Marshall P. Blankarn, assistant vice president; Emanuel P. Lewis, assistant vice president and credit manager; John B. Ballantine, assistant secretary, and Sigurd B. Salvesen, assistant secretary.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP). -- In a sharp statement the State Civil Service Employes Association today attacked the recommendations of Governor Lehman's budget advisory commission for lower salaries for thousands of State workers as "a direct repudiation of the President's program."

The Veterans Administration reported yesterday that an examination has been made of more than 50,000 "presumptive" cases and that 57 per cent of the claims have been disallowed. The individuals affected are not veterans disabled in line of duty. They are rather men whose present disabilities were "presumed" by act of Congress to have had a service connection, despite lack of direct evidence.

Wall Street looked for nothing more than a sedate and colorless market picture yesterday and in this was not disappointed. The commission houses were satisfied that the business held up as well as it did. Speculators for the advance seemed pleased that the recent gains were added to, if only negligibly.

Twelve men prominent in real estate and financial circles were named in three indictments handed up yesterday by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn to Judge Mortimer W. Byers in the United States District Court. The bills charge using the mails to defraud, concealment of assets in bankruptcy and conspiracy.

The Seaglade of the St. Regis was the scene last night of the second Yankee Doodle Ball for the benefit of Stony Wold Sanatorium. The dance, sponsored by Auxiliary No. 6 of the sanatorium, featured a special entertainment enlisting Leah Ray and the Three Ambassadors in songs, and Caperton and Biddle, dancers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- In declaring today for granting powers to the President for the negotiation and approval of reciprocal tariff treaties the Senate Democratic Policy Committee laid the basis for a partisan conflict if the President should press his present plan of asking for this authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Vast new power was placed in the hands of General Johnson today by President Roosevelt in an order which left to the NRA administrator the right to put into effect all codes for industries which do not normally employ more than 50,000 men.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Congress will assemble here tomorrow, not so much to legislate as to ratify. The important legislation was done mostly while Congress was in recess.

Judge Owen W. Bohan of General Sessions, who was elected last November on the Tammany ticket, was installed in Part VI of the court yesterday in the presence of six of his judicial associates and many friends.
Our national game, I believe, has weathered the most critical year in its history.

Despite much irregularity throughout December, prices of stocks averaged slightly higher, although the improvement was not applicable to all groups. Trading was somewhat heavier and centered principally in a few old market favorites.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 2 (AP). -- Ronald Finney, the key figure in the State's forged bond scandal, was sentenced to hard labor in the State penitentiary for a term of not less than thirty-one nor more than 635 years by Judge Paul H. Heinz in a dramatic court session today.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 2 (AP). -Stanley Winborne, North Carolina Utilities Commissioner, issued an order tonight rigidly restricting the payment of dividends by utilities, on the issuance of additional capital stock and on the rates of depreciation.

PINEHURST, N.Y., Jan. 2. -More than 100 members of the Pinehurst Country Club attended a testimonial dinner tonight for George T. Dunlap Jr., the national amateur golf champion. Dunlap, a member of the Pinehurst club, learned to play the game here as a boy.

Commissioner of Docks John McKenzie has received a protest against the proposed transfer of the North German Lloyd Line's docking operations from the Army Basin piers in Brooklyn to Piers 84 and 86, North River, on the ground that it was unfair to Brooklyn businessmen and heads of families.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The United States Government, through its Ambassador in Berlin, has made representations to the German Government regarding the unilateral decision of the Reichsbank on Dec. 18 to reduce transfers for the service of German loans other than the Dawes and Young issues during the next six months.

The first decision by the Supreme Court of New York upholding the statute passed at the special session of the Legislature incorporating the requirements of the NRA as to maximum working hours and minimum pay was handed down yesterday by Justice William T. Collins in a suit against the Independent Theatre Owners Association and its so-called "company union," the Allied Motion Picture Operators Union, Inc.

The concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegic Hall was directed by its guest conductor, Eugene Ormandy. His talents had been shown in previous New York concerts. He has risen rapidly as a conductor in late seasons.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 2. -- William Milne, 84 years old, of Rye, formerly president of the Peoples Bank of New York, died at 11 o'clock tonight in the United Hospital here while police of Westchester and New York City provided an open road for an emissary sent to Manhattan for a heart stimulant.

The Columbus Council, K. of C., yesterday announced the complete fields for the four special invitation races which will feature its indoor track and field games at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn on Saturday. This will be the opening meet of the 1934 season.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 2. -Some of the leading figures in American aviation and a group of Westchester County's wealthiest estate owners debated this afternoon whether there should be an emergency landing field on the Simpson tract, Dobbs Ferry Road, Greenburgh.

When Mayor LaGuardia admitted his intention yesterday of replacing Sidney S. Levine as Commissioner of Licenses as soon as possible, it became a matter of doubt whether the investigation of news stand license graft which Commissioner Levine undertook as a result of revelations two weeks ago would pass immediately into the hands of District Attorney Dodge or of Commissioner of Accounts Blanshard.

Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong, former British Consul General, is sailing tonight for England on the White Star liner Majestic, accompanied by Lady Armstrong. Other notable passengers on the ship are Lady Lillian Boyd, Helena, Duchess of Manchester; Brig. Gen. Wallace Wright and Noel Coward, playwright. New Yorkers on beard include:
BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons, with Dave Trottier setting the pace, defeated the Boston Bruins, 1 -- 0, tonight in a game that started slowly and ended at breakneck speed.

With great satisfaction I read your editorial concerning the national parks. I have visited many of the parks and monuments and never will I forget the scenic beauty, the natural phenomena, the mass of interesting knowledge and the healthful, carefree time which I enjoyed there.

TOKYO (Wednesday) Jan. 3. -Important changes in the Japaneseadvised government of Manchukuo, including the previously predicted elevation of 28-year-old Henry Pu Yi to be Emperor, were reported imminent today in high circles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- NRA officials tonight informally questioned the authority of a Federal district court in Connecticut to issue a temporary restraining order against enforcement of the Coat and Suit Code on five Connecticut manufacturers.

MUNICH, Jan. 2. -- The Rev. Dr. Rossberger, director of the Catholic seminary at Freising, near this city, was tried before the summary court today on charges of sedition and sentenced to eight months' imprisonment.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Jan. 2. -The body of Dr. Frank Chambliss Johnson of New Brunswick, child specialist and treasurer of the Middlesex County Medical Society, was found by State troopers last night at the bottom of the Chimney Rock quarry, operated near here by the Bound Brook Crushed Stone Company.

CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 2 (Canadian Press). -- The touring M.C.C. eleven held a long lead over an Indian eleven as their match, started Saturday, progressed today after postponement owing to racing here. Scores at end of today's play were: M.C.C., 331 and 279 for five declared; India eleven, 168 and 152 for one.
Following is the text of the economy bill which will be introduced in the Legislature for the LaGuardia administration:

Holders of Gelsenkirchen Mining Corporation of Germany six-year 6 per cent notes have been notified that the company's exchange offer made last June cannot be declared operative in its present form, although the holders of 65 per cent of the notes assented to the offer.

Eugene Speicher's first one-man show in five years opened yesterday at the Rehn Gallery, where it will remain for a month, until Feb. 3. As it happens, his last previous show, at the Rehn Gallery, opened five years ago to a day, on Jan. 2, 1929.

When Crane Wilbur, the Bard of Athens, N.Y., gets to work on a play he does not spare himself. "Halfway to Hell," which strolled in that direction at the Fulton last evening, is a fair example of the ferocity of his imagination and the bountifulness of his giving.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 2. -- The police inquiry into the assassination of Premier Ion G. Duca has resulted in breaking down the story of the assassin, Radu Constantinescu, who has abandoned his previous attitude that he and his two arrested accomplices alone knew of the murder plot.

The 161st annual report of the Society of the New York Hospital, made public yesterday and covering the year 1932, shows that the number of bed patients in the hospital here more than doubled the month following the hospital's removal to its new quarters.

Enlistments by communities in the Mobilization for Human Needs, as announced by NEWTON D. BAKER, chairman of the national committee, have been wholly voluntary and not under draft. Especially encouraging is the fact that the total raised or in definite prospect has so closely approached the amount named last September as the goal for the community chests.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- Government buying of hogs will be resumed tomorrow, with about 4,400 expected here to be bought daily for the next three weeks. Demand was good today from smaller packers and others who professed to be unable to gauge the probable effect government buying would have on the market, and prices were steady to 10 cents higher.

After the longest session in its history, the committee in charge of New York State decided last night on the two candidates out of the field of twenty-seven, from sixteen universities, who will be finalists from this State in the Middle Atlantic division for Rhodes Scholarships for 1934.

Business in money in the new year picked up the threads of the old year's inactivity and steady array of quotations. Turnover was small and chiefly of a routine character, and charges for call loans, maturity money and the discount on business paper were unchanged from last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Ewing Y. Mitchell, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, has sent a $50 box of cigars back to the corporation that presented it to him with the notation that he did not think government employes should accept gifts from those with whom they have business dealings.

Mayor LaGuardia heard proponents of the local bill providing an eight-hour day for firemen during the statutory hearing on the measure at City Hall yesterday, but did not disclose whether he would sign the measure.

The Schackno Law, which was intended to buttress the enforcement of the National Industrial Recovery Act in New York State, was invoked in the courts of New York City yesterday in a case involving an alleged violation of an industrial code.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade had a firmer undertone early today, wheat moving 1 cent a bushel above Saturday's finish and corn gaining 1 1/2 cents to the highest level since Dec. 14. Wheat turned heavy later, however, on evening-up by some who had bought early in the day and on Saturday, and finished 3/8 cent lower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- As the temporary fund set up by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was applied today to guarantee deposits up to $2,500, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said that it had made authorizations of $823,000,000 for the purchase of preferred stock or capital notes in 4,524 banking institutions throughout the country.

Investment bankers in Wall Street have become disquieted in the last few days by a suggestion made in Washington that the Securities Act of 1933 be broadened so that firms doing both an underwriting business and a brokerage business be required to confine themselves to one line of activity.

More species of birds within and around New York City were seen during the annual Winter census than in any recent year, observers reported last night at the New Year's meeting of the Linnaean Society of New York.

An appropriation of $4,519,476.18 by the city to buy materials and equipment for civil works projects from Jan. 1 to Feb. 15 was requested from the Board of Estimate by Travis H. Whitney, local Civil Works Administrator, in a letter to the board yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 2. -- Premier Mussolini in a conference tomorrow with Sir John Simon will take the attitude that extreme care must be used to avoid "exasperating" Germany and precipitating a renewed arms race, it was reported tonight in informed circles.

The Board of Estimate will convene in special meeting today to request the Legislature to grant wide powers to Mayor LaGuardia to reorganize the city government. A resolution to this effect was introduced by the Mayor at a meeting yesterday.

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore reports for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30 a net income of $5,178,569 after depreciation, taxes and charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $3.52 a share on 1,167,397 average number of common shares outstanding during the period.

More than 200 persons attended a dinner last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania closing a series of celebrations commemorating the work of the American Bible Society which have been held throughout China during the last year.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (AP). -Wild Laurel, a lightly regarded 6-year-old gelding from G. W. Coffey's barns, today ran away from a large field of platers in the mile and 70-yard feature at Jefferson Park.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- Willie Macfarlane, one of the game's grandest old-timers, and the youthful, brilliant Paul Runyan are waging a close battle for gold and glory along this Winter's golfing trail.

William C. Dodge, former magistrate, in his first working day as Tammany District Attorney of New York County announced yesterday his intention to cooperate in every way with the LaGuardia administration in stamping out official corruption.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2. -- Under a State liquor monopoly voted by the special session of the Legislature, Pennsylvania went officially into the liquor business today and was able to meet the buyers demand in leisurely fashion until late afternoon.
The new cold wave arrived on schedule yesterday, but it will be followed today by rising temperatures and increasing cloudiness and possibly snow by nightfall.

The city is faced by an estimated deficit of about $25,000,000 this year, a figure which may be increased by $10,000,000 or so if the water rates are cut, Controller W. Arthur Cunningham announced yesterday after an intensive although brief study of the city's finances.
Two members of the official family of former Mayor O'Brien made it plain yesterday that they did not intend to let their names be stricken from the city payroll if they could avoid it.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 2. -- Governor Lehman's address broadcast tonight from the Executive Mansion to the National Public Housing Conference in New York follows:

CINCINNATI, Jan. 2 (AP). -- With a balance of nearly $4,000,000 in its exchequer, Cincinnati -- where the nonpartisan city manager charter form of government established a record yesterday by entering its ninth year -- starts 1934 with a comfortable feeling of security and pride.

The Monte Carlo Ballet Russe last night added two ballets to its repertoire at the St. James Theatre when it presented "Scuola di Ballo" and "Beach" for their first official performances. The former as a matter of fact, has been in the bill for several days on a preview basis, and is now in perfect running order.

In a speech to the January term of the Bronx grand jury, Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo declared yesterday that the racketeer evils of the prohibition era would branch out to many fields of industry if newspapers and financial leaders failed to arouse public consciousness against those who prey on business.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP). -- The Glasgow Rangers, Scottish Football League champions, surprisingly were held to a 2-2 tie by Partick Thistle at Ibrox Park today for their second draw in two days of the New Year's holiday schedule.

Bernard S. Deutsch, president of the Board of Aldermen, will represent Mayor LaGuardia tonight at a meeting of lawyers in the Hotel Astor, to be held under the auspices of the Non-Sectarian AntiNazi League. The speakers, besides Mr. Deutsch, are to include James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany; former Judge Victor J. Dowling and Samuel Untermyer, who is president of the league. Supreme Court Justice Arthur S. Tompkins of the Appellate Division will preside.

PARIS, Jan. 2. -- The first slice of the 10,000,000,000-franc loan the French Treasury has received authorization to make will be opened to public subscription tomorrow, Finance Minister Bonnet announced this evening. The total amount has been left blank, and subscriptions will not be closed until the Minister of Finance decides either that the public has taken as much as it wants or that the treasury has gotten what it needs.

An outdoor rowing tank on South Field will be added to Columbia's rowing equipment, it was announced yesterday on Morningside Heights. The tank, made of wood and canvas, will accommodate one eight-oared crew. Hubert Glendon and Alastair MacBain, Lion mentors, believe it will add to the ability, of the Lions before they take to actual shells on the Harlem River later in the Spring.

ROME, Jan. 2. -- A cry of alarm against the "menace" of Japan's naval policies and recent activities was raised in the Italian budget committee's report on naval expenditures, which was distributed today in the Chamber of Deputies.

Charges that the NRA is proving ineffectual in creating better conditions in the legitimate theatre and that certain labor groups, including the actors, stagehands and musicians, are avoiding cooperation with the managers were made yesterday by William A. Brady, chairman of the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority, to Sol A. Rosenblatt, the division administrator of the amusement industries for the National Recovery Administration.

To avoid chaotic litigation which he believed would otherwise result Samuel Untermyer urged Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday to appoint receivers for defaulting guaranteed mortgage companies and permit certificate holders to elect their own trustees.
Premiums collected by the Travelers. Insurance Company in 1933 amounted to $159,415,000, according to preliminary figures made public yesterday. The total income was $189,334,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Dec. 27 shows increases for the week of $186,000,000 in net demand deposits, $29,000,000 in investments and $17,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and decreases of $15,000,000 in time deposits and $62,000,000 in government deposits.

BERLIN, Jan. 2. -- Rumors that Russia will shortly apply for membership in the League of Nations were designated today as premature by an official of the Soviet Embassy here. The basis of such reports, he said, might be looked for in the recent speech of Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, in which he made certain sympathetic references to the destiny of the League in connection with the present international political situation.

General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, has called representatives of the Banking Code Committee of the American Bankers Association to meet in Washington for consultation on banking rules of fair practice, it was reported yesterday in banking quarters.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

BORDEAUX, France, Jan. 2. -Rumors of the existence of 30,000 cases of pre-war whisky, stored in Bordeaux at the end of the war and later sold to the French as part of the war stocks of the American Expeditionary Force, appear to be false.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a considerable increase over the number listed in the preceding week. The total also remained slightly ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

General satisfaction was expressed in Wall Street yesterday on the news that the State Department had issued a formal statement that it would inquire through diplomatic channels into the German debt practices as they affect American holders of German dollar bonds.

At a hearing yesterday before Magistrate Greenspan in Washington Heights Court, charged with keeping a valuable fur-bearing animal without a license and without notifying the State Conservation Department as required by law, Louis Cooper, 48 years old, keeper of a fur shop at 3,668 Broadway received a suspended sentence.

Two Socialists were convicted in Bronx Special Sessions yesterday of displaying a red flag at the head of a column of 125 young men in Pelham Bay Park last Sept. 10. It was said to be the first test of a 1919 statute that makes it a misdemeanor to display a red flag in a public assembly or a parade.

The 200-inch reflecting telescope of Mount Wilson, which is to weigh 1,600 tons, cost $12,000,000 and gather 2,000,000 times as much light as the human eye, is not yet built, but FRANCOIS HENROTEAU of the Dominion Observatory has already discussed before the American Association for the Advancement of Science an "electronic" instrument which will be equivalent to a 2,000inch mirror.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- Impending changes in the British diplomatic service both in China and Japan gave rise today to rumors that Anthony Eden, Lord Privy Seal, was to be sent to the Far East and Russia as Ambassador-at-Large to see what could be done to reduce tension.

Mrs. Charles Lawrence Riker gave a dinner dance last night in the grand ballroom of the Pierre for her debutante niece, Miss Louisa Lawrence Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Wood of Philadelphia.

BERLIN, Jan. 2 (AP). -- Stockholders of the Iduna Insurance Company today agreed to request criminal proceedings and to enter civil suits against officers responsible for what was described as the virtual loss of at least $4,000,000 invested with the company by Americans.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Board, conferred here yesterday with officials of the Regional Labor Board on measures to be taken against employers charged with defying the authority of the board and violating the collective bargaining provision of the National Recovery Act.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 2 (AP). -- Fears that Victor McLaglen, screen actor, might have met mishap in the flood that swept over his La Crescenta estate were allayed today when a motion picture studio communicated with him by telephone.

Congressional action on the varied problems of wild life in the United States is very likely to hold the centre of the stage, so far as conservationists are concerned, during the next few weeks, or even months. But to the average sportsman the chief question now up is this: What has become of the plan advancedsome months ago by whicha centralized Federal bureau or departmentwould be created to handlethe situation in a coordinatedmanner?

The executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America in a statement yesterday urged that "the best forms of control now possible" be established to meet the "emergency" of repeal.

This is a holiday. The last mail delivery was Saturday midforenoon. The next will be tomorrow morning. Pretty close to three days of silence! A week ago we had another holiday; likewise no mail delivery from the previous Saturday midforenoon to the following Tuesday morning.

All the boxes have been sold for the benefit hockey game between the teams of Princeton and Toronto Universities tonight at Madison Square Garden. Net proceeds of the admission receipts will be given to the free bed fund of the Post-Graduate Hospital.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP). -- Garden of Eve, Inc., and Chief Black Hawk, Inc., are two of 8,500 stock corporations which have been dissolved by Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn for failure to file annual franchise tax returns for five years. The companies may be reinstated if penalties and back taxes are paid within six months.

Four women and a man were slightly injured and several other persons were shaken and bruised at the height of the rush hour last evening when a skylarking youth pressed an escalator stop button in the Times Square station of the I. R.T. subway.

ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- The battle W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, is waging against the re-election of Fred W. Hammond of Syracuse, as clerk of the Assembly, is more than merely a fight for a clerkship. The title of the office actually is a misnomer, for in this instance the clerk really is second only to the Speaker in power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Entering upon the first business day of the new year, the administration left the RFC price of gold unchanged at $34.06, but meanwhile on the eve of the opening of Congress the capital expects early developments in the form of an announcement to the session in which President Roosevelt will specify future policy.

Prices for commodities traded on local exchanges opened the year with moderate rallies in rather quiet trading. Raw sugar, closing lower, was the only exception to the upward trend. Cash prices were irregular.

One person was burned and several firemen, including two lieutenants, were overcome by smoke yesterday afternoon as the result of a small blaze in Max Ravich's pawnshop at 72 Amsterdam Avenue, near Sixty-third Street. About seventyfive persons, members of fifteen families, fled safely from apartments in the building by climbing over adjoining roofs.

Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks for New York State, announced yesterday that he had taken possession of the businesses and properties of the Westchester Trust Company of Yonkers and the Huguenot Trust Company of New Rochelle.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 2. -Removal of John L. Lewis, international president of the United Mine Workers of America, as a member of the National Labor Board in Washington was demanded in a resolution introduced today at the special convention of the United Anthracite Miners or Pennsylvania.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Jan. 2 (AP). -- Countess Majorie de Aguirre, wife of Count Luis Marceleno de Aguirre, Spanish nobleman and resident of Buenos Aires, obtained a divorce here today on grounds of general indignities. It was her second divorce obtained under Arkansas's ninety-day divorce law within two years.
Conveyance of a large industrial parcel featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

Resuming business after the twoday New Year's suspension, the domestic markets gave what Wall Street considered a fairly satisfactory account of themselves yesterday. Prices were slightly higher, although there may not have been enough activity to test the speculative stamina adequately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Despite the furor caused before the last Congressional election by publication of the names of Representation whose wives and other relatives were found on the Federal payrolls, present members seem to be clinging to the old habit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The House tonight looked forward to several hours of heated debate when Mrs. Bolivar E. Kemp and Jared Y. Sanders Jr. present their rival claims tomorrow for the Sixth Louisiana District seat, left vacant by the death of Mrs. Kemp's husband.
The ten modern Americans who have done most to keep American jargon alive were listed yesterday by Wilfred J. Funk, poet and president of Funk Wagnalls, publishers.

Mr. LAGUARDIA'S first day as Mayor must have impressed the public as deeply as it did his subordinates. He showed himself alert, aggressive and downright. In his crisp words to one head of a department after another as they were sworn in he was direct and positive.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, the new Police Commissioner, expects to rid the town of speakeasies within a week after starting such a campaign, to reacquaint captains and lieutenants with the forgotten feel of pavement-pounding and to end midnight tete-a-tetes between lonely patrolmen.

ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Jan 2 (By Wireless). -- After three days of enforced idleness -- since last Friday -- the Wyatt Earp has been pushing along through mushy ice at the rate of two miles an hour. It will be a relief to escape from the clutch of the ice pack, where the monotony is relieved only by the ominous sounds of heavy floes crunching against the ship's solid oak timbers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- President Roosevelt tonight was planning to journey to the Capitol tomorrow to deliver in person his message on "the state of the Union" at the convening of the regular session of the Seventy-third Congress.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange began the new year with generally higher prices in all sections, although trading was only moderately active. The rise in THE NEW YORK TIMES average of ten leading foreign loans resulted in the establishment of the highest level since the compilation was begun many years ago.

A plan for integrating the work of the Foreign Missions Conference with that of the Federation of Woman's Boards of Foreign Missions of North America was adopted yesterday by the latter body at its annual and final separate meeting in the Hotel George Washington.

Dr. Jerome Granoff, Brooklyn physician, pleaded guilty before County Judge Nova in Brooklyn yesterday to second-degree arson for participating in the setting of a fire in his office at 141 Henry Street, Brooklyn, on April 9, 1932.

A new policy on housing and slum-clearance in New York City and State was heralded last night in speeches by Governor Lehman and by the new City Tenement House Commissioner, Langdon W. Post. The Governor spoke over the radio from the Executive Mansion in Albany.

Testimony that a financial news service in Boston had advised the purchase of shares of the Atlas Tack Corporation before and after their price collapse was given yesterday when Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. resumed his inquiry into the movements of that stock on the Stock Exchange.

BERLIN, Jan. 2. -- The French reply to Germany's disarmament proposals which Andre Francois-Poncet, French Ambassador to Berlin, delivered to Chancellor Hitler yesterday will be carefully examined, but a reply will not be forthcoming for several days, it was announced at the Foreign Office today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2. -- To Catcher Jimmy Wilson, a native son who made good in the "big time," today went the job of building the Phillies from a second division baseball club to a National League pennant contender.

Two openings are scheduled for tonight. They are "The Wooden Slipper," by Samson Raphaelson, which has its premiere at the Ritz, and "The Gods We Make," at the Mansfield. This latter is by George Henry McCall and Mme. S. Bouvet de Lozier.

For the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, 1933, the International Shoe Company reported a consolidated net income after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, of $9,090,566, equivalent, after 6 per cent preferred dividends paid, to $2.58 a share on 3,350,000 shares of no-par common stock.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 2 (AP). -- Warned by Governor J. M. Futrell that disaster lay ahead for the State unless its $155,000,000 highway debt was refunded successfully, the Arkansas Legislature met today in special session called for that purpose.

Charles Capalanotto, 32 years old, of 137 Central Avenue, Brooklyn, shot and wounded his father-in-law and brother-in-law, the latter seriously, and then committed suicide last night at his father in-law's home at 86-23 Sixtieth Avenue, South Elmhurst, Queens.

The first of the monthly index numbers for December, that of Dun's Review was published yesterday. It figured out an advance in average prices of 1 3/4 per cent during the month and of 26 1/4 per cent as compared with the low level of the year, reached on March 1.

Johnny Goodman, Omaha amateur who won the national open crown at the North Shore Golf Club last Summer, is ranked first among the amateurs by A. W. Tillinghast in the issue of Golf Illustrated which appeared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP). -Sully C. Pecot, who was managing partner of the old New York stock brokerage firm of Fenner, Beane Ungerleider, filed in the Supreme Court today a petition asking that tribunal to pass on the validity of the New York Blue Sky Law.

ROME, Jan. 2. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, arrived at Ostia at the mouth of the Tiber River by seaplane directly from Capri early this afternoon for his meeting with Premier Mussolini. He went immediately to the British Embassy, where he will reside during his stay in Rome.

Junius B. Powell. formerly vice president of the North American Securities Company, has joined the organization of Spencer Trask Co. The securities company has been dissolved. Mr. Powell was formerly assistant manager of the Guaranty Company's municipal bond department in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Vice President Garner today commented on national affairs for the first time since last March 4, to say of President Roosevelt's message:
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- The stock markets were cheerful again when they opened today, although later they became irregular because of profit-taking. The outstanding feature continued to be the strength of British funds, which were in demand on favorable monetary, conditions and revenue figures.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 3. -- The school set was entertained tonight at a dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Adam G. Thomson for their son, Alexander D. Thomson, who returns next week to St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H.
BERLIN, Jan. 3 (AP). -- A census of hereditary incurables was in full swing throughout Germany today preliminary to the operation of the new Sterilization Law.

John McHugh, chairman of the executive committee of the Chase National Bank, announced yesterday his resignation as an officer and director of the bank. He advised directors of the institution that he did not desire to be reelected at the annual meeting on next Tuesday.

President Roosevelt's message to Congress provoked much comment in Wall Street, but it had little visible effect upon the markets. Prices were steady in the forenoon when speculators, unwilling to hazard a guess as to what the President might say, simply held their position and waited.

ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Thursday, Jan. 4 (By Wireless). -- After days of slow progress the Wyatt Earp has passed through the ice pack and is now steaming south in the Ross Sea. Our position at noon today was 178.27 E., 71.43 S.
Columbia University Club's Class A squash tennis team moved into a triple deadlock for first place in the Metropolitan League race by turning back the New York A.C., 3 to 2, last night.

With the Joyce novel, "Ulysses" long famous and long banned, about to appear under the Random House imprint, Harrison Smith and Robert Haas are rushing into print a book which they say will "explain the novel's implications to the general reader."

A grave danger threatens the interests of every wage-earner, small merchant and business man in the State. At Albany there is talk of continuing special tax measures recently passed and even of increasing them. The sales tax and the emergency gross income tax affect each one of us, however low his earnings.
Work by both older and younger members of the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation comprises the current show at the Macbeth Galleries.

Determined that when the next snowfall comes there shall be plenty of men available to clear the streets, the Sanitation Department began a drive yesterday to recruit additional emergency workers from the ranks of the unemployed.
THE following missive has been received and is hereby duly noted:
CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- The uniform baseball will be born Friday at Philadelphia.
ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- Outstanding recommendations contained in Governor Lehman's annual message to the Legislature today were:

Repeal of the National Recovery Act as "an economic monstrosity" which has retarded business and the discarding of other economic experiments launched by the Roosevelt administration as having been demonstrated to be unsound, was urged last night in an address by Dr. Willford I. King, Professor of Economics in New York University.

GARDEN CITY. L.I., Jan. 3. -- Expressing confidence in the success of foreign missions, the Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones, missionary of the Methodist Episcopal Board of Foreign Missions, opened the forty-first conference of the Protestant Foreign Missions of North America here today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Following a plea by Dr. James M. Doran, Supervisor of the Distilled Spirits Institute, the Ohio Board of Liquor Control today indicated that it might modify its ruling that whisky sold in Ohio must he four years old, aged in charred wood and contain 47 per cent alcohol.

The banks and bankers are taking it on the chin again, this time from our admittedly conscientious, hard-working code administrator. He feels that the proposed service charges are too high, and that if the banks wish to commit suicide no one is going to worry overmuch. He depends for support, of course, on good old John Taxpayer, and that condition, I think, is the seat of the trouble in our country today.

In reply to the article in THE TIMES yesterday entitled "The New Cars," I would like to say that I consider all automobiles extremely uncomfortable, and am amazed that our engineers cannot invent something pleasant and comfortable. All comfort is sacrificed to speed.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, filed today with the Supreme Court here a statement of the assets of the Westchester Trust Company of Yonkers, the control of which he took over yesterday. Total assets are listed at $10,834,976.

BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- A report that the Soviet Union's production of gold has been pledged to the Reichsbank as coverage for German industrial credits was designated today as "bosh" by an official of the Soviet Embassy here.

In order to retell the Cinderella fable on the stage it is generally necessary to pretend that some stunning actress is ugly. That is the chief defect in the legend. In "The Wooden Slipper," which was put on at the Ritz last evening, Samson Raphaelson requires us to pretend that Dorothy Hall is an eyesore.

ROME, Jan. 3. -- A revision of arms figures calculated to strike a satisfactory balance among national armaments, rather than the wholesale slash previously favored by Italy, was said authoritatively today to have been suggested by Premier Mussolini to Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP). -- President Roosevelt, it was disclosed tonight, has under consideration a report from his Executive Economic Policy Committee recommending that legislation be sought to give him authority to raise and lower tariffs and use other measures such as the imposition of quotas to regulate imports.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 3. -- Cloiwald, the 6-year-old son of Cloister and Miss Waldo which races for J. McBride, came from behind to score a length and a half victory in the third race at Ague Caliente today. Prisa finished second, with Black Velvet third.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S address to Congress yesterday was partly a report of what has been done, partly a prophecy of what will be done. All was couched in general terms. Scarcely a single recommendation was made. Doubtless the President is reserving concrete proposals of legislation for later communications.

ATLANTA, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Ratification of the Twenty-first Amendment helped bring freedom today to Louis Greenstein, convicted in the Southern District Federal Court of New York of conspiracy to violate the prohibition act.

As an aftermath of the "heavy anticipatory specifications that were driven in during December," raw steel production has declined to 31 per cent of the theoretical capacity of the industry, compared with 37 per cent the week before, according to the midweek review of The Iron Age.

Federal agents and city detectives have been guarding the family of Hugh Knowlton, partner in the firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., since Dec. 28, when a letter demanding $10,000 under threat of kidnapping the Knowlton children was received at the Knowlton city home, 319 East Seventy-second Street.

At a meeting of the creditors of the Realty Associates Securities Corporation, held yesterday in the Federal Building in Brooklyn, Referee in Bankruptcy Eugene F. O'Connor Jr. said he would proceed tomorrow with the election of trustees for the concern.

Prices of commodity futures moved lower yesterday on local exchanges in improved trading volume. The markets drew little inference from President Roosevelt's address to Congress. The trend was also lower in cash prices.

DEANS, N.J., Jan. 3. -- The Spirit of St. Louis, a fast Pennsylvania express train, passing over the main line at an estimated speed of seventy miles an hour crashed into an apple truck at Deans Crossing, just south of New Brunswick, this afternoon, killing the truck driver and fatally injuring the engineer, who was pinned in his cab.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Securities issues totaling more than $19, 000,000 are contemplated in ten registration statements filed with the Federal Trade Commission under the Securities Act and made public today. Approximately $4,000,000 of the amount is involved in proposed reorganization plans.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt scored another personal triumph on their return to the London stage tonight in Robert E. Sherwood's "Reunion in Vienna," which Gilbert Miller presented at the Lyric Theatre. They were previously seen here in the Theatre Guild's production of "Caprice," several seasons ago.

Appropriations for unemployment relief for January totaling $6,215,000 were voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Of this, $5,000,000 was voted for home relief on the recommendation of Commissioner William Hodson of the Department of Public Welfare.

For the year ended on Nov. 30 last, the Endicott Johnson Corporation, manufacturer of shoes, reported a net profit after all charges, including depreciation and taxes, of $2,154,941, equivalent after preferred dividend requirements to $4.30 a share on 405,360 shares of common stock outstanding.
ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature today:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The text of the House Ways and Means Committee bill for taxing intoxicating liquors is as follows:

Dr. John L. Rice, new Health Commissioner, made his first visit to his office yesterday, accompanied by Dr. Shirley V. Wynne, his predecessor. It was an unofficial visit, however, as Dr. Rice will not assume the duties of Health Commissioner until Jan. 15.

Laces and linens which adorned the dining tables of the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick proved the leading attraction yesterday at the second session of the auction sale of her personal effects, house furnishings and art collection at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

The proposed purchase of the Munson Steamship Line by the International Mercantile Marine Company, announced Tuesday by officials of both lines, will result in a new allocation of tonnage in the Munson services and may lead to the construction of new ships, it was said yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- A drive to legalize betting at New York race tracks was begun today as the 1934 Legislature went into session.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 3. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull and his party arrived here today after a five-day trip through the Argentine and Chilean lake country. Despite slight digestive trouble on the trip, the Secretary expressed himself as thoroughly pleased and rested.

A plan of self-help for the unemployed, involving New York workers, railroad men and farmers, is to be presented to Mayor LaGuardia by Milo Reno of Iowa, president of the National Farmers Holiday Association, he said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel New Yorker.

Matthew S. Sloan has resigned his membership on the board of the Guaranty Trust Company but retains his position as a member of the board of directors and a member of the advisory committee of the Irving Trust Company in one of the first major changes resulting from the Banking Act of 1933.

The payment of compensation claims from an exclusive State fund rather than through private insurance carriers was suggested yesterday by Mrs. Justine Wise Tulin as she retired after four years' service as a referee in the Workmen's Compensation Bureau.

Preliminary reports of the three companies in the National Investors group of investment trusts, as well as those of the holding company for the group, issued yesterday, showed substantial increases in the value of net assets for the year ended on Dec. 31.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Determined to end an Evangelical church interregnum that has existed since Nov. 29, Protestant Bishops who are opposed to Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller and to the Nazi German Christians agreed to meet in Berlin tomorrow to strike what they called a decisive blow against Dr. Mueller.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- In resuming today its investigation of the Detroit bank collapse, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee struck a trail that led to judges, referees in bankruptcy, politicians and officers of the banks. Loans had been made, it was also declared, to stenographers, clerks land other moderate salaried persons who "obviously had no other purpose than speculation in the stock market."

Retailers both here and out of town have been surprised and gratified at the excellent showing of trade since the end of the Christmas shopping period. Nothing like the usual post-holiday reaction has set in, and all indications are that the month will show a healthy increase in dollar volume over a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Considering the occasion and the text of his remarks, it is not wholly clear why the President chose today for his first personal appearance before the Congress. What he said was of the highest importance, of course. But it was couched in general terms, and no such acute situation exists as that which faced this Congress when it met in special session.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3. -- If the followers of football need evidence that the game has become standardized in all parts of the country, the East-West game played in San Francisco New Year's Day for the Shriners' Hospital for Crippled Children furnished conclusive and concrete confirmation of this fact.

Mrs. Gertrude Devine Webster of Washington, D.C., testified all day yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer and a jury in her suit against her former husband, William M. Ritter, retired lumberman of Welch, W. Va., to enforce an agreement made in 1922 under which she received $500,000, homes in Washington and Manchester, Vt., and was to receive $70,000 a year for life.

The Southern Pacific Company has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to modify conditions imposed when the company received approval for a $1,200,000 RFC loan last May for the construction of a passenger station and terminal facilities at Houston, Texas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- President Roosevelt's departure from the usual form of making recommendations on legislation in today's message on the state of the Union left the opposition unable to do any specific long-time planning by which they might hope to arouse the country against measures in question.

TRENTON, Jan. 3. -- Of 419 candidates who took the October bar examination 202 were successful, the New Jersey Board of Bar Examiners announced today. The names of attorneys who qualified as counselors will be made known later.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Three Democratic leaders of the House fear that the Public Works Administration is spending lavishly and unwisely the funds which the Appropriations Committee itself should directly provide.

PEIPING, Jan. 3. -- Liu Kweitang's rebel rabble continues to carry on its campaign of looting in districts adjacent to Peiping. One large detachment passed close to Tungchow, twelve miles from Peiping, where an American school is situated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Vast increases in emergency expenditures brought the government's deficit at the end of December to $1,152,972,595, the Treasury announced today. A year before the deficit had been $1,636,420,124.

Acting on his pre-election promise that he would conduct personally investigations of racketeering on "tips" coming to him from private sources, District Attorney William C. Dodge, aided by two of his prosecuting staff and several detectives, spent all of yesterday afternoon "on the outside," laying what he believes is a successful trap for racketeers.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 3. -- Coach Lou Little took his Columbia football team away from the scene of its Rose Bowl triumph late today, homeward bound. Before departure Coach Little said that he hoped the Lions could meet Stanford again some time soon.
LONDON, Jan. 3. -- Malcolm M. Irvine's film of the Loch Ness "monster" was shown here privately today without convincing the audience one way or the other.
