It is difficult to understand the reasons for continued delay in the making of Federal appointments. It is inconceivable that the rank and file of the Democratic party should suffer for the mismanagement, if such there be, of leaders unsatisfactory to the boys in Washington.

A change of plans will bring Columbia's football team into the Pennsylvania Station at 8:30 o'clock Sunday night, it was announced yesterday at Columbia. The original itinerary called for the Blue and White to arrive at 7:55 on Monday morning.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- The plan of financial reorganization of Chicago's street car and rapid transit or elevated lines, which would give the public a unified transportation system, was submitted in detail today to Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson by Walter L. Fisher.

From a competitive standpoint, the New York Athletic Club "has enjoyed few years as successful as the past one," according to the sixty-fifth annual report of the club's board of governors that was released yesterday. The report is for the fiscal year ending Nov. 30, 1933.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn has reversed the conviction of Irving Klein, former Queens Highway Superintendent, who was convicted of certifying pay vouchers in connection with fraudulent claims against the city, it was reported yesterday.

A drive to eliminate the alleged defrauding of American consumers by German exporters who seek to conceal the origin of their products and so defeat the boycott was opened last night by the non-sectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights.

The famous airplane, Tingmissartoq, given by Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh to the American Museum of Natural History, made its final safe landing there yesterday in the Hall of Ocean Life. The red and black craft, christened "big bird" by the Eskimos of Greenland, arrived in three parts from College Point, Queens, where it had been prepared for exhibition.

Frank J. Quayle Jr., who started is second day as Kings County Sheriff, arrived at his office in he Brooklyn Municipal Building yesterday shortly after 9 A.M. to find the place almost deserted. Few of his fifty-odd deputies and assistant deputies had appealed.

An embarrassing bit of forgetfulness caused Harry Levy, 41 years old, to be held yesterday in $5,000 bail on a charge of petit larceny. The amount involved was only $3, but Magistrate Benjamin E. Green-span purposely made the bail high, announcing that it was his intention to make Levy an example of what will happen to those guilty of irregularities in or near courts in which he presides.

Declaring that the stage was set for the unification of all banking institutions through membership in the Federal Reserve System, Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, recommended in his annual report to the Governor and the Legislature, which was made public yesterday, a program of legislation designed to bring the banking laws of New York into conformity with those of the national government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Appropriation of $25,000,000 for river and harbor work and $13,180,000 for flood control in the next fiscal year was recommended to Congress today by Major Gen. Lytle Brown, former chief of army engineers.

The increased foreclosure auction activity apparent during the closing week of 1933 has carried over to the new year. Twenty-seven properties, including seventeen in Manhattan and ten in the Bronx, were bid in by plaintiffs yesterday. Two scheduled Manhattan sales and another in the Bronx were postponed to later dates.

Relieved of the restraint imposed by the fact that almost everybody in Wall Street was trying to guess what President Roosevelt would have to say in his message to Congress, the share market had a difficult time trying to find itself yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- The Boerse continued firm today and the turnover was larger than yesterday's. Gains ranged beyond 3 points, with electrical, chemical and textile shares in the lead. Strength in I.G. Farben and Reichsbank shares, each of which rose 2 points, provided a powerful stimulant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Appearing before a joint session of the House and Senate, President Roosevelt opened the regular session of the Seventy-third Congress today with the assurance that recovery is under way and the "new deal" as it has taken form since last Spring is here to stay.

Setting an example for their staffs, the new city commissioners reached their offices early yesterday morning and spent the entire day, except for brief luncheon recesses, working at their desks. Nearly every one of the new department heads was at his desk before 9 o'clock.

Important deals involving changes in ownership of properties in the Dyckman and Civic Centre sections of Manhattan were included in the list of Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday. Two apartment sales in the Bronx and rather active business leasing also served to enliven the day's trading.
LONDON, Jan. 3. -- The British press reaction to President Roosevelt's message to Congress is both sympathetic and critical.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP). -- So many new bills were introduced in the House today that facilities for recording and getting them to the government printers were swamped.

ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Thursday, Jan. 4 (By Wireless). -- The Wyatt Earp is a thing of life once more and is now within 400 miles of the Bay of Whales, her goal. Last night at 8 we broke from the ice pack with feelings such as a butterfly might have as it burst from chrysalis form.

At the last meeting of the executive committee of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America the Rev. Dr. Rivington D. Lord, recording secretary of the council, presented a message from King George V to the clergy of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Charges by Senator Nye of North Dakota that the General Electric Company and a few limited licensees monopolize the manufacture and sale of incandescent electric lamps and that the independents have been unable to obtain redress from the NRA, or from the Electrical Code Authority, will be before General Johnson tomorrow, when rehearings begin on the electric manufacturers' codes.
Columbia University Library has just bought a large collection of Hebrew manuscripts from Rabbi David Fraenkel of Vienna, it was announced yesterday by Librarian Roger Howson.

Vouchers listing payments asserted to have been made to city policemen on strike duty by the Cornell-Dubilier Condenser Corporation of 4,377 Bronx Boulevard, the Bronx, were marked for identification yesterday in a hearing in the Bronx Supreme Court.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- Judge George Smyth of Westchester County Children's Court ordered today a reopening of the Waropay girl murder case when Thomas Fasso. New Rochelle attorney, informed him that 12-year-old Mary Kavala of Hastings-on-Hudson again had changed her story.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Jan. 3. -- Glenn Cunningham of Kansas, who received the Sullivan Memorial Medal for a long list of triumphs at the middle distances last year, will inaugurate his 1934 competitive campaign in the Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose A.A. games in New York on Feb. 3.

The Broadway premiere of "The Ziegfeld Follies" will take place this evening at the Winter Garden. Included in the cast are Fannie Brice. Willie and Eugene Howard, Everett Marshall, Jane Froman, Patricia Bowman, Vilma and Buddy Ebsen and others.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 3. -- The reorganized Ohio State team, with two men playing their first full game of the season, took a fast contest from Princeton tonight, 41 to 34.
Residential properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The voting of twenty-five-year bus franchises to five Manhattan corporations during the closing hours of the O'Brien administration will be investigated by Corporation Counsel Paul Windels, under a resolution adopted yesterday by the Fusion-controlled Board of Estimate.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Jan. 4. -- The Nanking Government reluctantly admits that troops have been withdrawn from Kingyuen and Taishun, in Southern Chekiang Province, "purely for strategic reasons." A spokesman insists that Pingyanghsien, less than thirty miles northeast of Wenchow, is still strongly held and is not endangered.

Contracts totaling $10,399,810 for work on the Triborough Bridge have been prepared by the Triborough Bridge Authority, and many of them have been approved by Arthur S. Tuttle, State Engineer of Public Works, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Triborough Bridge Authority.

ROME, Jan. 3. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, had his first interview with Premier Mussolini this afternoon and talked with him for more than two hours in the Premier's office in the Palazzo Venezia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- A colorful gallery, which followed every phrase of the President's message with a sympathetic interest and enthusiasm seldom seen in Congress since that great night when President Wilson read his message leading to the declaration of war, broke all rules today to cheer Mr. Roosevelt at the close of his address.

An 18-year-old Harlem dance hall hostess who had been scheduled to go on trial yesterday morning on an indictment accusing her and a young man of harboring an escaped Tombs prisoner was found late yesterday hiding in the home of a friend on East Third Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The nation through the radio not only heard President Roosevelt address Congress today, but also listened to Congressional leaders give their views on the condition of the Union and discuss the prospects for legislation.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange moved forward again yesterday, with United States Government bonds and foreign loans, notably German issues, leading the way. The government's long-term issues advanced 1-32 to 19-32 point with the exception of the Treasury 3 3/4s and the called Fourth Liberty 4 1/4s, which were unchanged and down 1-32, respectively.

The drastic service fee boosts indicated by the published draft of the bank code are certainly justified and economically correct, and I would like to believe not seriously disputed by the average and larger depositors. But does it not seem inexpedient and unfortunate just at this time, under the prevailing circumstances, to burden and thereby discourage small deposit accounts?

MONTGOMRY, Ala., Jan. 3 (AP). -- Attorney General Thomas E. Knight Jr. called upon the Federal Radio Commission today to take action against H.V. Kaltenborn, radio news commentator, for a purported comment that the "Scottsboro boys" could not receive a fair trial in Alabama.
ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- Arguments looking to reorganization of the New York City Title and Mortgage Company and other mortgage concerns were continued to tomorrow noon by Federal Judge Frank Cooper today.
Wholesale and retail garment firms were largely in evidence on the business tenancy lists yesterday. Several restaurant rentals also were among the Manhattan items, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The future course of President Roosevelt's monetary policy was left open to speculation by the brief reference he made today in his message to Congress to the steps already taken.

John Sloan's last previous one-man show was held at Kraushaar's in April, 1930. The well-known American artist makes his reappearance as an exhibitor this week at the Montross Gallery with a group of more than forty canvases, old and new, and also with graphic work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Opposition to the present form of the proposed code for the natural gas industry was presented at a hearing today before Leighton Peebles, deputy NRA administrator, who was advised that the bituminous coal industry was the victim of unfair competition from natural gas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Marking perhaps the last year in many in which gold will be minted in the United States, mints in 1933 coined 758,000 pieces of gold valued at $12,035,000, the Treasury announced today.

The trustees of the Brooklyn Trust Company have decided, until further notice, to consider the payment of dividends semi-annually instead of quarterly, according to a letter sent yesterday to stockholders by George V. McLaughlin, president.

HAVANA, Jan. 3. -- More than 1,000 troops left Camp Columbia tonight to go down the island. It is understood they will be distributed at various points along the northern and southern coasts where revolutionary expeditions are expected to land shortly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Allotments aggregating more than $33,000,000 and including a major provision of $25,000,000 for the removal of submarginal lands from commercial crop production were announced today by the Emergency Administration of Public Works.

HERBERT LEHMAN has a right to be rather proud of the "empire" which he governs. It has met the test of adversity. In dealing with the needs of the reconstruction era after the World War, and later with the problems arising out of the depression, and still more recently with those born of the repeal of prohibition, it has shown the way to its sister Commonwealths.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had admitted to its list the $1 par value common stock and the no-par value preferred stock of the American Writing Paper Company, Inc., and had stricken from the list the company's voting trust certificates for $1 par value common stock, and voting-trust certificates for $6 preferred stock without par value.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- The United States Government's note of protest to the German Government against the arbitrary reduction of Germany's interest payments on her foreign indebtedness was duly presented to the Foreign Office yesterday evening.

Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, will confer with leading members of the Legislature in Albany today regarding recommendations to be made for permanent liquor control legislation.

James Brown, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, corrected yesterday an impression that, he said, seems to have existed in some quarters since the chamber adopted its "gold standard and recovery" resolutions that the organization has been opposing the policies of President Roosevelt.
The city's experimental campaign against panhandling was continued last night with the meting out of "scientific justice" in the old Night Court on West Fifty-fourth Street.

The investigation of graft in the granting of news stand licenses, which Commissioner Sidney S. Levine has been conducting in his own department for two weeks, was joined yesterday by District Attorney William C. Dodge, who sent his executive assistant, Frank E. Carstarphen, to sit as "observer."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Quiet Chat, winner of only four races in twenty-six starts last year, scored at long odds today when he defeated a field of platers in a six-furlong dash at Jefferson Park.

Continued buying yesterday on the Cotton Exchange carried prices in the morning to the highest marks since Sept. 23, but an afternoon reaction wiped out the improvement. After selling within a point of 10 3/4 cents for the May delivery under a steady absorption of contracts by domestic and foreign consumers, as well as for commission house account, reselling by recent buyers broke the market about a dollar a bale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP). -- A threat by Senator Long, Democrat, of Louisiana, to hold up the nomination of Henry Morgenthau Jr. as Secretary of the Treasury failed today to worry Senate Democratic leaders, who are determined to obtain quick confirmation of President Roosevelt's friend and fiscal adviser.

DETROIT, Jan. 3 (AP). -- The Detroit Board of Education has its own ideas regarding the type of art suitable for juvenile eyes and it does not believe that gnomes, pixies, Mother Goose characters or Cheshire cats belong on the list.

Among passengers arriving today on the Italian liner Rex are Stanislaw Patek, Polish Ambassador to Washington; Mr. and Mrs. Arturo Toscanini, Vladimir Horowitz, the Russian pianist, with his wife; Gregor Piatigorsky, Russian 'cellist; Yehudi Menuhin, young violinist; Bernardino Molinari, conductor; Frank Buck, big game hunter and writer, and Prince and Princess Colonna of Rome.

Martin Conboy, new United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, has received more applications for jobs on his staff than were received by any preceding holder of that office, it was said yesterday. Although only sixteen vacancies exist, hundreds of New York attorneys, many of whom have been members of the bar for years, have applied for positions.
DUX, Czechoslovakia, Thursday, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Fire started early today in the Nelson III coal mine, where a terrific explosion yesterday trapped 140 miners in the workings.

VIENNA, Jan. 3. -- The release of several prominent Nazi leaders in Austria in the last few days has given rise to sensational reports that Prince Ernst Rudiger von Starhemberg, leader of the Heimwehr, has been arrested in Germany and in exchange for his release these Austrian Nazis have been set free.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The administration favors the prosecution of all persons charged with having violated national prohibition before repeal.

A statement asking that "a nation-wide effort for moral and spiritual recovery and advance" be made coincident with plans for economic and industrial recovery was issued yesterday by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3. -- Jockey Earl Porter scored a triple at Tropical Park today, including among his winners Mrs. F.J. Heller's Agrarian, which won the featured Long Key Purse. Porter's triumphs brought his total for the three racing days of 1934 to eight.

In 1919 the Canadian House of Commons passed a resolution asking the King not to confer any more titles of honor or distinction, save such as were professional, vocational or official, upon Canadian citizens. Whether this was a "democratic" gesture, born of the war and representative of the preponderant public opinion of the time, or a protest against promiscuous recommendations for such glories, isn't clear to outsiders or perhaps to Canadians.

A drive to raise $88,000 will be started today by the New York Association for the Blind, for which Dr. John H. Finley is president. The money will be used to provide food, warmth, clothing and shelter for the destitute or needy blind, and to carry on other activities of the association on behalf of the blind.

Jack Sherry of Ohio threw Sid Westrich of the Bronx in the main wrestling match to a finish at the St. Nicholas Arena last night before 1,500. The end came after 12 minutes 54 seconds, Sherry pinning his opponent with an airplane spin and body hold.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Manuel Quezon, leader of the majority in the Philippine Legislature and of the legislative committee now in Washington to negotiate independence for the islands, has prepared the alternative proposals which President Roosevelt asked him recently to submit in writing as a substitute for the rejected Hawes-Cutting act.

Loans on securities made to members of the New York Stock Exchange and carried in New York increased $55,902,985 in December to $845,132,524, according to a compilation made by the Exchange. At the end of November loans were $789,229,539, while at the close of December, 1932, they were $346,804,658.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress today:

The Gallico Three-Piano Ensemble, consisting of Paolo Gallico, Stella Stamler and Mae Krieg, made its concert debut last night at the Town Hall, assisted by Alva Taylor, soprano. The ensemble, according to announcement, has played for various radio broadcasts.

A decline in retail failures to 144 featured business defaults for the last week of December, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The number compares with 149 in the preceding week and 373 for the corresponding week of 1932. Declines were also shown in the manufacturer and the agent and broker groups. There was an increase of two in failures in the wholesale group.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Dean Inge, who will retire this year as head of St. Paul's Cathedral, declares in the new edition of his book, "England," to be issued tomorrow, that "the American Government seriously contemplated taking action against us in the early part of the war."

I have read numerous articles by presumably learned writers pertaining to the present gold problem. Not knowing a blessed thing about monetary problems myself, in my innocence the following questions come to my mind:

Pig iron production in 1933, according to final figures compiled by The Iron Age, shows a gain of 52 per cent over 1932, as compared with an estimated increase of 71 per cent in steel ingot output. The pig iron total for the year was 13,208,190 tons, compared with 8,686,443 ions for 1932.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- The warfare between two powerful wings of the Republican party, symbolized by the strife over the election of the Clerk of the Assembly reached a climax today on the floor of the lower house as the 1934 legislative session began.

Hans Lange began his third week at the head of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night, presenting a program that consisted of Eric DeLamarter's overture from "The Betrothal." Brahms's violin concerto with Joseph Szigeti as the soloist and Sibelius's First Symphony.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 3. -- King Carol accepted this afternon the resignation of Premier Constantine angelescu's Cabinet, formed less than five days ago. He entrusted to Minister of Commerce George Tatarescu the task of forming a new Cabinet.

Call loan market showed distinct signs of an easy condition, offerings being more liberal than previously. However, fixed charges of 1 per cent on the Exchange and 7/8 in the counter market continued to prevail, since demand was light. Time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were all quiet and unchanged in quotation.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Reports of looting in one of the flood-stricken suburban districts added to the distress of the homeless and the burden of relief workers in the mud and debris covered lowlands about the city tonight.

Periodic dental examinations are often the means of saving lives through early discovery of cancer of the mouth and other serious diseases, Dr. Douglas Quick, consulting surgeon at the New York Hospital, said last night. He addressed a meeting of the First District Dental Society of the State of New York at the New York Academy of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Commander Robert Hewetson Skelton, flag secretary of Admiral Jehu V. Chase when the latter was commander-in-chief of the United States Fleet, met instant death early this morning when he fell from a second-story window of the Naval Hospital.

LEIPZIG, Jan. 3. -- The three Bulgarian defendants in the Reichstag fire case, Georgi Dimitroff, Blagoi Popoff and Wassil Taneff, who were acquitted Dec. 23 but are still detained, have now been deprived of the privilege of seeing their relatives, according to Leo Gallagher, Los Angeles attorney who has been active in their behalf.

A group of Eastern railroad presidents has been appointed by L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company and president of the Eastern presidents' conference, to represent the managements in this region at joint conferences with labor officials on a legislative program.

Another step in the government's control over interlocking relationships of the various phases of financial activity was seen yesterday when it became known that directors and officers of investment trusts had been advised by their counsel to apply to the Federal Reserve Bank for permission to retain any bank directorships which they might hold.
" If I Were Free," with Irene Dunne and Clive Brook, will be presented at the Radio City Music Hall today.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- Lord Inver-forth, writing for the publication The Shipping World, advocates "high-speed pocket liners of moderate comfort, operating in conjunction with aircraft," as the best way to satisfy the modern demand for speed and to eliminate the building of huge luxury liners.

ARTHUS WEIGALL, who was present when King TUTANKH-AMEN'S tomb was opened in November, 1922, is now dead at the age of 53. That brings to the fore again the Egyptian King's "curse" on all desecrators of his sepulchre.

The Brooklyn Navy Yard heard yesterday from the Bureau of Operations in Washington that no repair work had been assigned to the yard for January or February. This probably will cause the lay-off of about 1,500 men.
ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- A bipartisan movement to repeal the 1 per cent levy on "gross" incomes going into effect this year was begun here today as the 1934 session of the Legislature began.

Reinforced by a staff of trained investigators, the office of the Commissioner of Accounts was working at top speed yesterday under the direction of the new commissioner, Paul Blanshard, every available man being busy checking the activities of some city department or other.

A report showing reductions in freight claims because of new methods of packing and handling, and a vote to cooperate with the Federal Railroad Coordinator in his railroad questionnaires, marked the opening sessions yesterday of the tenth annual meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board at the Hotel Commodore.

Mayor LaGuardia and his transit advisers will hold their first official unification conference at 10 A.M. on Saturday with spokesmen for the B.M.T., the Interborough and the various committees representing holders of the securities of the companies and their rapid transit subsidiaries.

Not quite 40 and not exactly fat, but rather uncomfortably close to both, Babe Ruth, renowned homerun artist of the New York Yankees, yesterday inaugurated another Spring training campaign by starting his customary siege of intensive indoor calisthenics.

Prince and Princess Alexandre de Caraman-Chimay, who will sail today on a world cruise, gave a farewell luncheon yesterday in the Georgian Room of the Pierre. Their guests were Mrs. Watts Sherman, Mrs. H. Edward Manville, Mrs. Adolf J. Pavenstedt, Miss Anne W. Stuyvesant, Benjamin Welles, General Charles H. Sherrill, William Matheus Sullivan and Albert Morris Bagby.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 3 (AP). -- New evidence which he said caused him to believe that Verne Sankey, widely sought as an alleged kidnapper, might have been implicated in the abduction of the Lindbergh baby and also had contemplated kidnapping Babe Ruth and Jack Dempsey, was disclosed today by M.F. Kinkead, County Attorney.
President Roosevelt's message to the new Congress is unmistakably a speech of good omen.

Cooperation among the various industries using national and State highways, to combat the diversion of funds contributed by motorists, was urged yesterday at a roundtable discussion sponsored by the New York State Highway Users Conference at the Hotel Roosevelt.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- The London Times says it is too early to predict the ultimate repercussions upon Lancashire of the Indo-Japanese agreement but "it would be a mistake to found on it any exaggerated hopes."
The fund for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases was increased $2,861.25 yesterday by 114 contributions.
BERLIN, Jan. 3 (AP). The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 30 shows the following changes in reichsmarks.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3. -- All four seeded entries in the fourth annual women's Pennsylvania State squash racquets championship won their third-round matches to march into the quarter-final round at the Merion Cricket Club today.

TRENTON, Jan. 3. -- Governor Moore sent a petition today to Secretary of Agriculture Wallace urging Federal cooperation with New Jersey and other Eastern States in a united stand against practices detrimental to the milk industry.

While no legislative program on the subject as yet has been formulated, undoubtedly there will be some measure advanced at Albany this Winter having to do with the regulation of salt-water fishing in the marine areas controlled by New York State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- More than 16,000 white-collar unemployed in the country began today taking a business census, one of five such projects the funds for which are being furnished by the Civil Works Administration. The work is under the direction of the Bureau of the Census, and it is hoped to conclude it by Feb. 15.

THE great theme of Henry James, that of the American in contact with Europe, is given another twist by David Burnham in his "Wedding Song" (Viking, $2.50). And what a difference the years can make! With James it was often a question of the starry-eyed innocence of Americans amid a decadent Continental lot. But with Mr. Burnham the Americans have their own sophistication.

Workmen's compensation is one of the blessings of the modern industrial system. Unfortunately, it has been subject to grave abuses. With the technical details the general public is not familiar and does not need to be. But the more flagrant abuses are now matter of common knowledge and understanding.

Mayor LaGuardia intends to make personal appearance before both houses of the Legislature next Monday to press his economy bill, another hill permitting revision of the city's pension system and the court reform act consolidating the magistrates' and special sessions courts.

The Fusion "steamroller" in the Board of Estimate demonstrated its effectiveness for the first time yesterday when it brushed aside opposition to put the board's approval on Mayor LaGuardia's economy bill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The session of the House of Representatives was opened in an atmosphere of hope and thanksgiving today with a prayer by the Rev. James Shera Montgomery, House chaplain, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The first move including field as well as factory work in the recovery program was taken today with the appointment by Secretary Perkins of a committee "to take immediate steps to formulate a plan for reorganization of labor policies and to present suggestions for improving labor conditions in the sugar beet fields."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The Ways and Means Committee Liquor Tax Bill, proposing a basic levy of $2 a gallon on distilled spirits, was introduced in the House today by Representative Doughton, chairman, and was put in position to be brought up tomorrow.

PARIS, Jan. 3. -- French and American importers continued today to visit the United States Embassy and the Commerce Ministry without learning anything definite as to how France's new quotas will affect United States trade.

The shortening of prison sentences as a means of reforming the criminal and reducing taxes was urged yesterday by Bernard J. Fagan, State Parole Commissioner, at a luncheon at the Advertising Club of New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3.-- The grain markets on the Board of Trade came to life in the last half hour of the session today after having drifted aimlessly until President Roosevelt's message to Congress had been delivered. The message was construed by the trade as negative, and many who had bought early turned to the selling side because no concrete money program was presented.
BOSTON, Jan. 3. -- The golf year of 1933 brought its full share of surprises and upsets, many of which will influence the competitive season of 1934.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 3. -- Although none of the alcoholic beverages thus far tested by the State Department of Health has been found to be poisonous, many instances of poor quality have been disclosed. In some cases labels were found to be fraudulent, it was said.

DENVER, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Walter Reppin, 18-year-old Newark (N.J.) youth who was sentenced to "breathe death" this week in Colorado penitentiary's new lethal gas chamber for the murder of a taxi driver, won intervention today by the State Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Outstanding points in President Roosevelt's message to Congress follow:
Efrem Zimbalist, violinist; Helen Gleason, Metropolitan Opera soprano, and Colette D'Arville of the Paris Opera-Comique will be the artists this morning at the Hotel Plaza "artistic morning."
The value of the dollar on (he local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French ranc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- A divided Democratic majority in the Senate gave clear indication today as the 1934 Legislature opened that it would not look with very friendly eyes on Mayor F.H. LaGuardia's program for wide reform in New York City government.

The first "Don Giovanni" of the season was given last night by the Metropolitan Opera Company, Mr. Serafin conducting. The performance had exceptional animation and coherence of ensemble, and there was much singing of a high quality. Mr. Pinza had a cold, so that for a time in the afternoon it was questionable whether he would sing.

The indictment of organized labor for holding up the functioning of the NRA in the legitimate theatre which was made on Tuesday by William A. Brady, chairman of the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority, was branded yesterday as "smoke screens to hide managerial inactions" by Theodore Mitchell, president of the Association of Theatrical Agents and Managers.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- Under lowering political skies the 157th annual session of the Legislature began at noon today. Within an hour after the opening gavel had sounded the wheels of the legislative machinery were stopped as the result of the fight made by the Republican State Chairman, W. Kingsland Macy, against the re-election of Fred W. Hammond of Syracuse as Clerk of the Assembly.
Trailing by a goal with only five minutes left to play in the third period, the University of Toronto hockey team staged a thrilling rally to defeat Princeton at Madison Square Garden last night.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan's military attention to detail was observed yesterday at police headquarters when he inspected seventy-five patrolmen with a view to choosing chauffeurs for himself and the deputy police commissioners. The commissioner will make up a list of the twenty chosen later.

The United States was blessed with excellent health in 1933, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has calculated from records now available. It has concluded that probably the best health record "of all time" was established last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- An NRA office order threatens to abolish the advisory boards of consumers, labor and industry "if they cannot adopt an attitude of conciliation," according to directions issued by the executive officer, Alvin Brown.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 4. -- Fresh difficulties in the construction of a new Rumanian Government caused Premier George Tatarescu to postpone until tomorrow announcement of the Cabinet which had been due tonight.

Plans for welcoming Columbia's team when it arrives on Sunday night went along rapidly yesterday and all indications point to the most thunderous and enthusiastic reception ever given a Blue and White squad.

The Universal Pictures Corporation, Carl Laemmle, president, has leased the tenth, eleventh and twelfth floors in the western extension of the RCA Building, it was announced yesterday by Rockefeller Center, Inc. The lessee has been in 730 Fifth Avenue for ten years.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 4. -- Five men were killed and a dozen injured by troops putting down a riot yesterday at Tamboraque, a village 9,000 feet up in the Andes, seventy-five miles from Lima, in the Department of Junin, according to reports reaching here today.

The Associated Motion Picture Advertisers, composed of the advertising heads of the major film producing companies, placed themselves on record at a luncheon in Sardi's yesterday as resolved to forestall government action against objectionable film advertising by instituting a clean-up within the industry.

An immediate State-wide safety campaign to lessen the number of accidents and injuries among the 400,000 employes of the Civil Works Administration was announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner. He had met with Frederick I. Daniels, executive director of the State Civil Works Administration, and Graham Cole, director of safety of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, who has been appointed to direct the campaign.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- The staggering proportions of the deficit indicated in President Roosevelt's budget message, twice the size of the whole expenditure of the British Treasury, was breath-taking to most of the London newspapers. That is probably why the London Times withholds its comment on a matter considered here to be of far greater importance than the President's message of yesterday to Congress.

Rumors that graft had been paid for the issuance of liquor licenses were indignantly denied yesterday by John Sullivan and Mrs. John S. Sheppard, members of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Silver advocates pushed their campaign for an agreement on remonetization today, but developments indicated that President Roosevelt would maintain control by sending to Congress, if necessary, his own plan for using silver as a money base.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- A vigorous plea for the adoption of the panama Canal rules of measurement as the only standard in charging tolls for the passage of vessels through the waterway is made by Governor J.L. Schley in his annual report for 1933, issued today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- A Federal anti-lynching law, said by its supporters not to deprive States of a single opportunity to preserve constitutional rights, but providing for Federal action where States have failed, was introduced today by Senators Costigan and Wagner.
NEW ORLEANS. Jan. 4 (AP). -- Blue Day, veteran campaigner from A.G. Tarn's stable, today ran away from six other sprinters in the six-furlong Crescent City Handicap at Jefferson Park.

BERLIN, Jan. 4. -- The upward movement on the Boerse gained in scope and momentum today. Leading stocks advanced between three and four points, with one specialty registering a gain of eight points. Heavy industrials, electricals and public utilities headed the boom, which took in tow even such neglected values as the potashes and shippings, although some of the latter were almost the only issues to show minor losses.

Money market continued quiet. Street loans were arranged at 3/4 @ 7/8, but the rate on the Stock Exchange remained at 1 per cent. Time money developed no change, which was also true of the acceptance and commercial paper markets.
" By Candlelight," with Elissa Landi and Paul Lukas, will open at the Roxy today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress today the most extraordinary budget in the history of the United States, showing a contemplated excess of expenditures over receipts of about $7,000,000,000 for the current fiscal year as the cost of the war against depression.

President Roosevelt's budget message, in which he gave a thoroughly realistic picture of the government's financial problem, held the undivided attention of the markets yesterday. The varying reactions indicated a confusion of judgment and opinion with respect to the facts disclosed.

Three times the New York Americans succeeded in tying the score with the Montreal Maroons in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, but they were unable to do it a fourth time.

Chief Inspector Lewis J. Valentine and District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx ordered investigations yesterday into evidence that gratuities had been paid to city policemen on strike duty at the plant of the Cornell-Dubilier Condenser Corporation, 4,377 Bronx Boulevard, the Bronx.

The New York County Lawyers Association unveiled a tablet in its building, 14 Vesey Street last night in memory of Andrew Hamilton, designer of Independence Hall, Philadelphia, and who, at the age of 80, acted as voluntary counsel to obtain the release in 1735 of John Peter Zenger, then under sentence for criminal libel.
Realty investment deals in three boroughs of the city were reported yesterday, with the Bronx leading in the number of transsactions arranged.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The text of President Roosevelt's message transmitting the budget to Congress today is as follows:

SHANGHAI, Friday, Jan. 5. -- With Chinese officials at Hangchow and elsewhere contradicting previous admissions of losses at Taishun and other Chekiang border points, and now issuing unverified claims of important victories along the entire front, the war against the Fukien rebels is most obscure.

The twenty-three-story Hotel Paris at the southeast corner of West End Avenue and Ninety-seventh Street was sold last year by the Guardian Life Insurance Company to the Risap Corporation, James E. Knott president, for an indicated consideration of $1,400,000, a deed just recorded shows.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- As a result of failure to break the deadlock in the Assembly today supporters of Fred W. Hammond of Syracuse, candidate for re-election to the Clerkship, were digging in tonight in preparation for a long siege.

President Roosevelt's budget message calling for $6,000,000,000 of new financing by the government in the next six months in addition to $4,000,000,000 of refinancing, and forecasting a total government debt of $31,834,000,000 by June 30, 1935, staggered the financial community yesterday.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

The women's national squash racquets title, which went to an English player a year ago, will be regained by a contestant from North America by the end of next week, it was disclosed yesterday when the draw for the tourney was made at the Junior League clubhouse.

Spurred by the action of the Public Works Administration in Washington in authorizing a Federal grant of $2,500,000 for the construction of the proposed new Bayside High School, officials of the Board of Education moved yesterday to push plans for the building.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 4. -- South Orange suffered its first defeat in its last match of the season in the Class B division of the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League when it was beaten by Short Hills today, 3 -- 2. Montclair shut out Plainfield at Plainfield in the other match, 5 -- 0.

MONTREAL, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadiens took a 4-1 decision from Toronto tonight but still found themselves 10 points behind the Leafs in the battle for first place in the National Hockey League's International group. It was only the fourth defeat for the Leafs in twenty-one games.

The new year in New Jersey reminds Republican politicians that primary nominations are not far off. If they are to win back the Governorship in 1934, harmony must prevail in their ranks. But the party has not recovered its morale so rudely shaken by recent elections. Independent Republicans carried the State for Governor MOORE in 1931 and for FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT in 1932.

The President's staggering budget message has two redeeming features: It makes no further efforts to hide the cost of the New Deal even though there is much obscurity as to how some of the billions are to be spent; and it stresses the need of striking an actual and genuine balance of expenditures by income during the fiscal year 1935-36.

John J. Garvey, president of the New York City Teachers Association, was elected president of the Five Borough Association at a meeting held at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, last night. The Five Borough Association, a newly formed teachers' organization, will study and disseminate information regarding the proposed reorganization of the New York City school system.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the second in this year's series of State receptions, entertaining in honor of the judiciary.

A representative of the whisky interests has spoken up in opposition to the proposed requirements in the matter of labeling bottles. He says that if we insist on knowing what his people fill the bottles with, his people will not sell us any more at all and return our trade to the bootleggers.

TOKYO, Jan. 4. -- The new Indo-Japanese trade agreement will mean an end to the recent boom in American cotton purchases resulting from Japan's boycott of Indian cotton, but will still probably leave the demand for the American product higher than it was prior to the boycott.

The call to "spiritual advance" issued by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America is as the sound in the tops of the mulberry trees, summoning spiritual forces to bestir themselves and go forward. It is as if they were called to fight the hosts encamped in the Valley of Rephaim -- which is for us the Valley of Depression.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 3, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,686,000,000, a decrease of $12,000,000, compared with the preceding week, and an increase of $534,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

BERLIN, Jan. 4. -- The German answer to the American and British notes of protest against the arbitrary reduction of Germany's interest payments on her foreign indebtedness is now being prepared in discussions among the responsible authorities, principally the Foreign Office, the Economic and Finance Ministries and the Reichsbank.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Drastic changes in existing methods of financing railroad maturities, including the establishment of sinking funds to retire a portion of outstanding obligations prior to maturity, were suggested today by the Interstate Commerce Commission in its annual report to Congress.

PRAGUE, Jan. 4. -- All hope of rescuing the 120 miners still entombed in the wrecked shaft of the Dux coal mine, near Osseg, was abandoned today. Sixteen bodies have been recovered. Only four men in all have escaped alive.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 4. -- Dr. Walter S. Adams, director of the Carnegie Institution's Mount Wilson Observatory, and Dr. Theodore Dunham Jr. told today how they had used a part of the moon as a looking glass in which to see the earth.

James F. Fogarty was elected president of the North American Company at a special meeting of the board of directors yesterday to succeed Frank L. Dame, who died on Dec. 30. Mr. Fogarty has been with the company thirty-one years, and for the last eleven years has been a vice president.

Edwin Howland Blashfield, who painted his first mural at the Columbian Exposition at Chicago in 1893 while a cold wind from Lake Michigan whipped the turpentine out of his cup and stiffened his fingers, was honored last night as the dean of American mural artists.

Three persons were burned painfully last night when benzine with which they had been cleaning an automatic refrigerator in the kitchen of an apartment at 34 Seaman Avenue, Inwood, exploded and caused a small fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Passage tomorrow by the House of the new liquor tax bill, carrying a basic levy of $2 a gallon on distilled spirits, was expected tonight by leaders, who steered the measure through four hours of debate this afternoon.

Julia Nessy, announced as a "lyric-coloratura" soprano, made her New York debut in a song recital yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall. Mme. Nessy had been scheduled for an appearance earlier in the season, but illness postponed her concert.

Establishment of Health Department clinics for the treatment of intoxicated persons was suggested yesterday by Fred A. Victor, State superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, in a letter to Mayor LaGuardia. Mr. Victor declared that the method of arrest with a fine or imprisonment upon conviction was wrong.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Improved business in the retail furniture field in the first quarter of 1934 was forecast tonight by furniture merchants from ten sections of the country and by Dr. Kenneth Dameron, Deputy Administrator of the NRA in charge of distribution codes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- Directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company met this afternoon to draft a final plea to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation against the appointment by that body of Walter J. Cummings, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, as chairman of the bank's board of directors.

The reading of a message of greeting from President Roosevelt to the Camp Fire Girls officially opened the annual convention of the organization yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Lester F. Scott, national executive of the Camp Fire Girls, read the message.

A diamond necklace and breastplate with which the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick dazzled Chicago society passed from the possession of her estate and into the hands of a mysterious buyer for $15,000 yesterday afternoon at the third session of the auction sale of her personal effects, house furnishings and art collection at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

At the annual meeting of the directors of the National Horse Show Association of America yesterday J. Spencer Weed was again chosen president. The board also reelected Adrian Van Sinderen and Luther L. Blake as first and second vice presidents, respectively.

The progress of construction of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by instalments as the funds become available may seem to be provokingly slow in the minds of a generation accustomed to quick erection under the stimulus of anticipated income from a mortgaged investment.
ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- Open hostility to Mayor LaGuardia's program for drastic fiscal reform in New York City government was displayed by the Democrats in the Senate today.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, Exploring off Antarctica, Jan. 3. -- Flying in his biplane through snow squalls and under a thick layer of stratus clouds, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd today passed over the Antarctic pack ice toward the unknown continental front of the Pacific quadrant of Antarctica.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- The rebuff that it is understood the British have received in Berlin as a result of their official protest over the treatment of British holders of German medium and long-term bonds is likely to be followed by the establishment in London of machinery to insure that the funds paid for the import of German goods shall be employed to satisfy the claims of British creditors.

VIENNA, Jan. 4. -- Seventeen members of the Nazi Black Front were placed on trial here today on charges of belonging to a secret society. The Black Front is a revolutionary group which still claims to have millions of adherents in Germany.

ROME, Friday, Jan. 5. -- Premier Mussolini and Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Secretary, announced in a communique this morning that they agreed "it is absolutely indispensable to conclude the disarmament discussions as soon as possible."

Sergei and Marie Radamsky, the tenor and soprano who are among the foremost exponents of Soviet music, will tour the Eastern seaboard and Middle West immediately after their only New York concert of the season, to take place tonight at the New School.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Establishment of a new government corporation to facilitate the development of foreign trade in agricultural and other products, and enjoying powers heretofore exercised exclusively by the State Department, has been recommended to President Roosevelt by George N. Peek, his special adviser on matters of commercial policy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade were weak early today, but after the President's message on the budget had been delivered to Congress they more than recovered the early decline.

Isn't it time that Professor IRVING FISHER called a meeting of the House Committee of the Eighteen Club and did something about the club members who have been cutting up? On Dec. 15, in a letter to a correspondent, Professor FISHER drew up his list of eighteen men in this country and abroad who really understand the subject of money.
" Oliver Oliver," a new comedy by Paul Osborn, which was tried out during the Summer at Southampton under the title of "Perhaps We Are," will have its Broadway premiere this evening at the Playhouse.
Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan set at rest yesterday reports that the department was to undergo a drastic shake-up.

Bank clearings at leading cities throughout the country increased slightly in the last week over the corresponding period a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, who call the showing rather unsatisfactory.

Reorganization of the committees of the Port of New York Authority to meet the new conditions created by the start of construction of the new Hudson River tunnel was voted yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the commissioners. General George R. Dyer, who was elected chairman two months ago to succeed John F. Galvin was re-elected laud Frank C. Ferguson was re-elected chairman.

BERLIN, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The vigilant eye of authorities charged with carrying out the provisions of the national sterilization law turned today on criminals as a vast drive was started to round up the nation's hereditary incurables.
DETROIT, Jan. 4. -- A revamped Detroit team tonight handed the New York Rangers a 3-to-1 defeat in a fast National Hockey League match before a crowd of 12,000.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- The Democrats in the State Senate moved today to deal a death blow to the park consolidation bill sought by Mayor LaGuardia and Robert Moses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The navy fared well in the budget which President Roosevelt sent to Congress today.

A new organization to study and report on what the policy of the United States should be toward such problems as international monetary standards, foreign loans and other capital movements, and tariffs and other trade barriers, in the light of changing national and world conditions, was announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 4. -- Honoring Governor David Sholtz, who, with Mrs. Sholtz, arrived this morning to be the guests of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Sholtz of North Lake Trail, J. Leonard Replogle entertained tonight with a stag dinner at Train Side.

A Nazi plea for aid in restoring the breach between Germany and the world of music and art has been refused by the youthful virtuoso Yehudi Menuhin, violinist who returned from Europe on the Rex yesterday. He said that Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler, director of the Berlin Philharmonic Symphony and a member of the Prussian State Council, had made such an appeal.

Registration of the unemployed for emergency snow removal work in the event of another storm went forward yesterday in City Hall Plaza, with a Sanitation Department truck being used as a registration stand. During the day about 1,300 men were registered.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Main figures from President Roosevelt's budget message are:
Countess des Garets gave a luncheon yesterday in the Georgian Room of the Pierre for Mrs. O. Harry Gruner, Mrs. Fellowes Davis, Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop and Mrs. A. Duer Irving.
Slowly, but steadily, the fund for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases is growing.

Members of the Junior League of New York held a novel entertainment yesterday at the Park Lane for the benefit of the Clothing Information Bureau. Following luncheon, which was served at small tables in the ballroom of the hotel, there was a fashion show, "Off on a Cruise," in which many young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons displayed the latest costumes for cruises.

With a $25,000 contribution from John D. Rockefeller Jr., pledges and gifts to the United Hospital Fund in its current appeal now total $350,450, it was announced yesterday. Although the needs of the fifty-six hospitals affiliated with the fund in supplying free care to the sick poor are greater than ever before, the amount thus far raised is still below the figure for this time last year, it was said.
PARIS, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

TRENTON, Jan. 4. -- After taking the testimony of State Treasurer Albert C. Middleton and State Controller John McCutcheon, members of the State Sinking Fund Commission, the legislative Committee on Economy and Reorganization decided late today that its investigation had gone far enough.

Frank Buck, collector of wild animals, returned on the Italian liner Rex yesterday with Mrs. Buck, after spending nearly eleven months in Southern Asia and the East Indies. He said about sixty animals, including a rare male Indian rhinoceros caught in Nepal, were being shipped here on freighters.

Samuel Untermyer launched an attack last night upon certain critics of the NRA, some features of the NRA itself, and particularly the banking interests and the code recently presented by the Clearing House banks of this city.

Prices for commodity futures opened irregularly lower on local commodity exchanges yesterday but became firm in the afternoon and most of them closed higher on the day. Trading was in moderate volume. Cash prices were irregularly higher.

Bringing the personal greetings of President Roosevelt to members of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, Grover A. Whalen, local NRA administrator, told the gathering yesterday that the President would permit "no runaway inflation" and that the worst of the depression was over.

Something constructive has been accomplished toward the welfare of nations. Fannie Brice and Willie Howard have been lured into a production of the "Follies," which was staged at the Winter Garden last evening. It would be pleasant enough to have only one of them among the graces and tunes of a Broadway musical arcade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Treasury officials appeared confident today that they could handle the big financing problem laid on their doorstep today in the President's budget message, in which Mr. Roosevelt estimated that $10,000,000,000 would have to be raised in the next six months to meet maturities and cover expenditures under the recovery program.

The first concrete proposal for charter revision to be laid before the Legislature by the LaGuardia administration has already been bogged down in controversy. It is a carefully drawn bill to amend the charter in relation to the administration of the park system. The Park Board was to be abolished, along with borough autonomy in the control of the city's parks, which were all to be put under the jurisdiction of a single commissioner.

A new passenger and freight service between European ports in the Mediterranean and South Africa, which will make possible a nineteen-day trip from New York to Port Said, was announced yesterday by Aroldo Palanca, general manager of the Italian Line.
I have read the correspondence of Dr. Butler and William D. Guthrie concerning the child labor amendment.

Mayor LaGuardia was notified last night that the Public Works Emergency Housing Corporation had earmarked a sum not to exceed $25,000,000 for use by the proposed New York City Housing Authority which awaits establishment through an act of the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Public Works allotments of $38,294,237 for 167 additional non-Federal projects, and $1,380,494 for public works to be carried on by Federal departments, were authorized today.

HAVANA, Jan. 4. -- A solution to the Cuban political tangle under which Colonel Carlos Mendieta, 60-year-old physician, former soldier and former Congressman, would succeed to the Presidency next month was outlined tonight by Benjamin Fernandez de Medina, leading mediator.

The novelty of the concert given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, was an "Introduction and Hymn" by Igor Markevitch, the young Russian composer, now of Paris.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Confirmation of the nomination of Henry Morgenthau Jr. to be Secretary of the Treasury was virtually assured today when the Senate Finance Committee favorably reported his name and it was placed on the executive calendar, from which it is expected it will be taken Monday and approved.

The Bank of Amityville, Amityville, L.I., and the Peconic Bank, Sag Harbor, L.I., have been admitted to membership in the Federal Reserve System, according to an announcement by George L. Harrison, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The opening shot in a fight to gain a higher ranking for George Lott, Davis Cup player and Western champion, was fired today as the Chicago Tennis Association asked for "some satisfactory answer" as to why the Chicago star had been rated as far down as tenth in the proposed rankings for the year.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 4. -- Charging conspiracy to wreck his business, Abraham Zalon of the Riverside Coat, Apron, Towel and Linen Supply Company filed suit today for $100,000, and named the United States Internal Revenue Collector, Charles V. Duffy of the Newark district, as one of the defendants.

A diversified collection of rare books, autographs and manuscripts, ranging from a letter by Francis Bacon to a poem by Robert Burns, brought $25,691 last night at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. The property had been consigned by a number of collectors and estates.

LEONIA, N.J., Jan. 4. -- Five boys, all students at the Leonia High School, were missing from their homes today. The police discovered from other children at the school that the boys had left separately, intending to hitch-hike to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Station in Baltimore, whence they would start, in a group, for St. Petersburg, Fla.

The Federal Reserve System showed a net operating loss of $919,000 after dividends and all charges in 1933, the weekly report of the Federal Reserve Banks, published yesterday, revealed. This loss for the system contrasted with net earnings of $2,688,000 added to surplus by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, representing roughly a third of the system in volume of assets, after all dividends and other charges.
ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- Governor Lehman conferred today with Langdon W. Post, tenement house commissioner, on the LaGuardia housing program for New York City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The National Electric Light Manufacturers Association's proposal to amend the electrical code to provide price-fixing was challenged today by General Johnson and Donald Richberg, general counsel of the NRA.

President ROOSEVELT'S message submitting to Congress the Federal budget for the next fiscal year is to be commended for its absolute frankness. It does not in the least undertake to conceal or camouflage the hard facts. It bluntly gives the "demnition total." The deficit for the current fiscal year will be upward of $7,000,000,000.

The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange has made every effort to work with the administration in its recovery program but so far has discovered few changes essential to full cooperation. William H. English Jr., president, said yesterday at the fifty-second annual meeting of the exchange.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler, hearing plans for the reorganization of defaulted guaranteed mortgage properties, handed down a decision yesterday criticizing the procedure followed by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, as rehabilitator of fourteen companies.

The Board of Aldermen must go. As a purely partisan political body, with no ideas about municipal administration, it has no place in a nonpartisan city government. The Board of Aldermen represents the politicians; a new body of advisers is needed that represents the citizenry.

BOSTON, Jan. 4. -- Irvin (Ace) Bailey, injured Toronto hockey player whose escape from death probably will go down as a notable case in medical annals, today was permitted to make a fleeting contact with the world outside his sickroom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Congress can take it. But something like a shudder seemed to run through the two chambers today when the Senators and Representatives got the cold facts about the government deficit.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 4. -- Coach Lou Little and his Columbia University football squad homeward bound after a stunning upset victory over Stanford University in the Pasadena Rose Bowl Monday, rolled into this city at 2:30 P.M. today and spent the afternoon sightseeing.

The Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo and Adams, McEntee Co., Inc., bidding jointly, topped a field of four other bidders yesterday to win the award of a new issue of $1,100,000 Onondaga County (N.Y.) bonds. The price was 100.169 for the bonds as 4.40s.

Under the leadership of Thomas H. Beck of Connecticut the Federal Government now has embarked upon the experiment of centralization of wild-life conservation. The appointment this week of Mr. Beck and of J.N. Darling of Iowa and Professor Aldo Leopold of the University of Wisconsin was the first step in the nation-wide plan to put wild-life conservation on a sound basis.

Representatives of civic organizations on the Atlantic seaboard formed yesterday a body to be known as the Shippers' Conference on Railroad Consolidation for the purpose of investigating the effect on the public interest of the plans for railway unification put forward by Frederick H. Prince and others.

More than 1,000 persons, bent on self-destruction, visited the offices of the National Save-a-Life League, 299 Madison Avenue, last year and were dissuaded from committing suicide, according to the league's annual report issued yesterday.
A joint investigation of the bus franchise awards made by the outgoing Tammany Board of Estimate was begun yesterday by Corporation Counsel Paul Windels and Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard.

What might have been a tediously dull share market took on considerable significance yesterday as a result of the President's budget message and the inferences which Wall Street drew from it. The fact that the mining stocks led the "offside run" that featured the late recovery was an indication of the speculative trend of thought.

" The new year," says Secretary HALPIN, "will see the inauguration of "a war on wolves by the Conservation "Department of New York." Winter is bitter, and these "formidable" beasts, as Dr. HORNADAY calls them, are foraging for food. There are plenty of deer in the North or Adirondack Woods and, hunting in packs, the wolves pull them down, and even raid farmyards.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- Seventy-three of the leading equine jumpers of two continents, including three former winners, today were named for the 1934 renewal of the Grand National, world's most famous steeplechase, to be run at Aintree, March 23.
An exhibition containing fifteen canvases by Ernest Fiene is current at the Downtown Gallery -- the artist's first one-man show in several years. It will remain until Jan. 20.
Leading throughout, the De Witt Clinton High School quintet triumphed over Seward Park, 31 -- 17, yesterday on the Clinton floor. At the end of the first half Clinton was in front, 15 -- 4.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 4. -- Several hundred truck drivers and their helpers, employed on express and heavy trucking, went on strike in Essex County today after failure to reach a wage agreement with the Associated Express and Truck Owners of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Exports were larger in value in November than in October to twenty-three out of forty principal foreign markets and to five of the seven so-called grand divisions, but the total value declined from the preceding month from $193,948,442 to $184,256,227, the Department of Commerce announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The status of Earle Bailie, special fiscal adviser to Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, was discussed at a meeting today of the Senate Finance Committee, at which the confirmation of Mr. Morgenthau was considered.

THE publishers tell us that Phyllis Paul, a 23-year-old English woman, whose first novel, "We Are Spoiled," is issued in America by William Morrow ($2.50), has read none of the modern novelists. They also claim for her "a startlingly modern point of view." Modern her book is, but we wonder if Miss Paul herself is conscious of what she has done.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, exploring off Antarctica, Jan. 4. -- Following yesterday's dramatic flight through snow squalls, fog and low-hanging clouds to altitude 72.30 south, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd early today held his flagship hove to in the pack while he debated what his next move in this area would be.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- A clash between the administration and some manufacturers, advertisers and consumers over the Tugwell pure food and drug bill was brought into Congress today when Senator Copeland introduced a modified form of the measure, and Representative Black presented in the House a substitute voicing the attitude of the objectors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Wholesale prices during the week ending Dec. 30 reversed their previous trend and from a decline in recent weeks showed an increase amounting to six-tenths of 1 per cent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

The market for United States Government bonds, which had been steady during the morning yesterday, was severely jolted at midday when excerpts of the President's budget message appeared on the financial news tickers. Under the impetus of heavy selling, prices of the long-term Liberty loans and Treasury issues on the Stock Exchange dropped quickly to levels 1-32 to 18-32 point below the previous day's final prices.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 4. -- In a stiff northeast breeze nine class B iceboats competed today in two events for special prizes, marking the first racing on the North Shrewsbury River ice in four Winters.

Substantial increases in retail trade are likely to feature the first quarter of the year, according to views expressed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Specialty Stores Association, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria. The store owners present were in agreement with the prediction of an increase of 25 per cent in dollar volume for the period, made at the meeting by P.A. O'Connell of the E.T. Slattery Company, Boston.
Several apartment houses were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

The plan of the new city government to consolidate the magistrates' courts and the Court of Special Sessions was approved yesterday by a special committee of the Bar Association of the City of New York.
Several transfers of Stock Exchange memberships and applications by corporations for listing on the Exchange were announced yesterday.

Managements of public utility companies with large debts falling due within the next six months are now studying plans to meet the payments. At this stage it appears likely that most of the obligations will be handled through extensions in one form or another and that with a few outstanding exceptions there will be no underwriting or refunding with the assistance of investment bankers.

Several West Side and upper Manhattan properties were included in the list of sales by auctioneers yesterday. Seventeen parcels, twelve in Manhattan and five in the Bronx, were offered under the hammer, and were bid in by the plaintiffs.

If time has staled much of the tousle of "Lucia" and made the pauses between duets, concerted numbers and solos seem quaint and anachronistic to an ear attuned to the fluency of Verdi and the splendor of Wagner, it has also brightened the beauty of a few of its episodes.
Secret hearings in investigations of city departments are already under way, Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, revealed yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- A series of bills carrying out recommendations made by Governor Lehman in his message were introduced today in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The World Court issue was relegated to a remote point of Senatorial consideration this evening after President Roosevelt and Senator Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic leader, decided that the unsettled condition of Europe makes consideration of adherence by the United States inopportune for the time being.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 4. -- J.E. Smallman's Feudal Lord triumphed in the easiest sort of fashion in the featured five and a half furlong Ponce de Leon Purse at Tropical Park today. The favored Frederick of the B.B. Stable was second, beaten by five lengths, while H.C. Phipps's De Valera was a nose further back in third place.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Unless the Yale Club squash racquets team is able to down them in the final match on the schedule next Thursday night, the Harvard Club No. 1 team players will retain possession of the Dixon Trophy, emblematic of the Metropolitan Class A championship.

A wider use of silver in the monetary systems of the world was advocated yesterday by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin and by Raymond Moley, in articles in the current issue of Today, of which Mr. Moley is editor.

Maria Olszewska, Metropolitan Opera contralto, made her first appearance of the season in a Town Hall recital last night. Her program comprised an Italian group by Bononcini, Pergolesi, Gordigiani and Giordana; four songs by Schubert, four new songs by Clemens Franckenstein and a concluding group by Hugo Wolf and Richard Strauss.

Net asset value of the Lehman Corporation increased from $39,860,601 to $54,763,355, and the net asset value of outstanding shares increased from $58.27 to $80.51 a share in 1933, according to a report issued yesterday. This is a gain of 38.17 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- Two upsets featured the play today in the women's Pennsylvania State squash racquets championship tournament at the Merion Cricket Club. Two unseeded players, Miss Anne Townsend of the home club and Miss Virginia Vanderbeck of the Country Club, won their way into the semi-finals.
The United Hunts Racing Association plans to race later in the Spring and earlier in the Fall than for years past, it was disclosed at the annual meeting held at the Jockey Club yesterday.

More than 2,000 guests are expected tonight at the Peacock Motor Show Ball to be held in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor. Many of the subscribers will go to the ball from dinner parties that have been arranged to precede it.

Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena stepped off the Commodore Vanderbilt at the Grand Central Terminal yesterday, deposited his bags at the Hotel Vanderbilt and went across the street to the Seventy-first Regiment Armory with his tennis racquets.
t The Cunard liner Mauretania, [ sailing today for Plymouth, Cher-I ;bourg and Southampton, will haveI among her passengers:
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 4. -- Naval Academy athletic officials today announced the award of 222 letters and numerals for three Fall sports, football, soccer and cross-country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- President Roosevelt's budget estimates give $3,969,740,300 as the expenditures by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation if the loaning powers of that corporation are extended by Congress beyond Jan. 22.

When the District Attorney and the Commissioner of Accounts asked separately yesterday for transcripts of the testimony taken before License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine in the investigation of graft in the granting of newsstand licenses, which he has been conducting for the last two weeks, they were informed that the records were two weeks behind.

The second-degree arson case against Samuel J. Wurzberg, Brooklyn fire loss adjuster, was given to the jury before County Judge Franklin Taylor in Brooklyn at 6:45 last night. It had failed to reach a verdict at 11:30 o'clock and was locked up for the night.

PARIS, Jan. 4. -- Four interpellations on France's latest sensation, the Bayonne pawnshop scandal, which has cost French investors between 100,000,000 and 200,000,000 francs, were deposited in the Chamber of Deputies today, and it is expected more will follow.

A gift of $150,000 by Charles Hayden of Hayden, Stone Co., for the purchase of the "artificial heaven" in the planetarium to be constructed by the American Museum of Natural History's Planetarium Authority, was announced yesterday by F. Trubee Davison, president of the museum.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Frank T. Hines, veterans' administrator, asked today that judgment on the revamped veterans' relief policy be withheld.

The flight which Admiral Byrd has made from his ship to a point about 1,200 miles north of the South Pole in the unknown Pacific quadrant of the Antarctic was done under the difficulties which fliers have experienced along the edge of Antarctica in the late Summer season. Fog and snow and bad visibility are their portion.

During the week ended Dec. 30 deaths in New York City from all causes totaled 1,643, an increase of 76 over the preceding week, it was announced yesterday at the Department of Health. The average death rate was 11.67 for each 1,000 of population, as compared with 11.83, the average rate for the corresponding week during the six preceding years.

BASLE, Switzerland, Jan. 4. -- The Bank for International Settlements ended the year 1933 with the first increase in funds its monthly statements have registered since August. A statement issued tonight showing its position as of Dec. 31 balances roughly at $131,000,000 in gold, an increase over November of nearly $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Receipts of the Democratic National Committee totaling $728,536 during 1933 and expenditures of $710,640 were reported to the clerk of the House today by William F. Cronin, assistant treasurer, as required by the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.

A report criticizing the medical profession for a majority of the deaths of mothers in childbirth here between 1930 and 1932 has been unanimously approved by the Council of the Academy of Medicine, it was revealed last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- Judge Frank Cooper in Federal court today gave attorneys in the litigation involving the New York Title and Guarantee Company and others until Wednesday to file additional affidavits and briefs. Max D. Steuer is seeking to have George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, removed as trustee for the title companies now in process of rehabilitation.

About 150 persons were driven into the street from the seven-story apartment house at 22 Nathan Davis Place, facing Mount Morris Park at 122d Street, last evening when a Christmas tree fire in a sixth-floor apartment spread to the top floor and the roof.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Apprehension by his own party leaders lest the enormous cost of recovery become a political issue in the 1934 Congressional elections, and a feeling of encouragement among Republican leaders that they had found a weapon to aid opposition to the administration's expensive recovery machinery were the reaction here to the President's budget message.

The impression seems to have got about that Bill Terry and his world's champion New York Giants are a bit glum about the faster standard ball that will be adopted by the American and National League presidents in Philadelphia today.

O.E. BAKER of the U.S. Department of Agriculture draws a population picture of America one, two and three decades from now, beginning with the basic statement that we are approaching the time "when children will be "born, with few exceptions only, to "those parents who want them."
LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
