MONTREAL, Jan. 4. -- Eddie Shore, defense star of the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League, today was absolved of any deliberate intent to injure Irvin (Ace) Bailey of the Toronto Maple Leafs when he charged into him at Boston Dec. 12.
ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Jan. 4 (By Wireless). -- Nature draws her battlelines closely in these Antarctic regions, where an eternal warfare of wind, sea and ice rages.

Frederick Houk Law, president of the High School Teachers Association of New York City, appealed yesterday to Governor Lehman to recommend to the Legislature the granting of full statutory aid for the public schools of the State.

Nearly $208,000 has been pledged to the Citizens Family Welfare Committee by the gas and electric companies in the system of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York. Of this amount $157,872 represents pledges of employes. In addition, the company made a $50,000 contribution during the early part of the campaign, according to Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the public utilities division of the welfare committee, who made the announcement yesterday.

The subjoined table shows the highest and lowest points reached in 1933 and in a series of past years for the principal items of the account. The amount of Federal Reserve Bank notes outstanding is now included under the head Reserve Note Circulation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, delving today into records of the Guardian Detroit Union Group, Inc., disclosed "profits in the red" and apparently contradictory reports to stockholders and to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, from which the Group sought loans aggregating about $65,000,000.

Tributes to her character, experience and fitness for the post of city magistrate were paid to Mrs. Anna Moskowitz Kross by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Chief Magistrate James E. MacDonald and other speakers at her induction at Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning.

Turning back both the New York Athletic Club and the Salle d'Armes Vince in the final round robin, the Fencers Club gained a leg on the Cartier Trophy by finishing first in the team foils competition last night at the Saltus Fencing Club in the Twenty-third Street Y.M.C.A. The New York A.C. won last year.

Support for W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, in his fight to prevent the re-election of Fred W. Hammond of Syracuse as Clerk of the Assembly came yesterday from six up-State clergymen. Assurance of this support was received in letters to William Ziegler Jr., treasurer of the Republican State Committee, who sent these and other clergymen copies of Mr. Macy's Utica speech, charging domination of the Assembly by public utility interests, and editorial comments thereon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Counsel for the United States Steel Corporation today challenged the right of the National Labor Board to take up the dispute in the "captive" mine controversy on the ground that there was nothing in the relations of the corporation's coal subsidiary, the H.C. Frick Coal and Coke Company, to its employes that was referrable to the board.

Stanlislaw Patek, Polish Ambassador to the United States, returned on the Italian liner Rex yesterday from a trip to Poland. He said he came with the feeling that Poland "is at present strong, the people are working hard and the stability of work and of production is good."

What was regarded as the first step in a drive to oust John H. McCooey from the Democratic leadership of Kings County was temporarily stopped last night by the adroit use of parliamentary procedure at the annual meeting of the Madison Club, 922 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Quiet business conditions following the stimulation of Christmas trade were reported for various countries by the Department of Commerce today in its weekly survey of foreign business conditions based on advices from commercial attaches abroad.
The LaGuardia administration moved yesterday to cut expenses, the Mayor, Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch and Corporation Counsel Paul Windels all slashing the payrolls of their offices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- A "sensible" monetary policy and wise expenditure of budget funds asked of Congress by the Roosevelt administration will be necessary in the drive toward recovery, in the opinion of Dr. O.M.W. Sprague, Professor of Banking and Finance of the Harvard Business School, recently resigned from the Treasury Department.

VIENNA, Jan. 5. -- The Austrian situation is again approaching a critical stage. The Heimwehr Fascists have issued an ultimatum to Chancellor Dollfuss demanding a number of drastic changes, including more Cabinet seats for themselves, the appointment of Commerce Minister Stockinger as financial dictator of Vienna and expulsion of the Socialist majority from the municipal government.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- A remarkable collection of British art treasures -- one of the greatest ever assembled -- was exhibited at the Royal Academy in a private view today. The exhibition will be open to the public tomorrow.

Ratification by newspaper publishers of the ten-point proposal offered as a means of establishing an amicable policy on news broadcasting between radio and the press was urged yesterday in a statement by the chairman and vice chairman of the publishers national radio committee, according to The Associated Press.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- Republican factional lines held firm today and the Assembly, still unorganized and unable to do business, recessed for the week-end without a clerk.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP). -- Rumors of imminent White House action to increase the value of silver persisted in Senate circles tonight, and in the expectation of early Presidential action on the currency situation Senator Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, agreed to withdraw his plan to have a Senate subcommittee draw up a monetary program.

Philip H. Philbin Jr., young promoter who obtained control of the Atlas Tack Corporation and made a profit of more than $600,000 trading in the stock of the corporation, was arrested yesterday in the office of State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. in the State Building.

Confirming a report which went abroad during the major league meetings in Chicago last month, but which the club at the time felt necessary to deny, the New York Yankees yesterday announced that unconditional releases had been mailed to Herb Pennock, brilliant lefthander over a period of nearly two decades, and Joe Sewell, veteran third baseman.
The three women's squash racquets teams that will represent New York in the intercity matches next week were named yesterday by the selection committee of which Mrs. James P. Hendrick is chairman.

GENEVA, Jan. 5. -- Twenty countries had less unemployment during the last quarter of 1933 than for the corresponding period of 1932, according to the quarterly report of the International Labor Office, issued today. Allowance is made for seasonal variations.

A plan to safeguard industry against design "piracy" was presented for discussion last night to a group of business and trade representatives at a dinner in the Hotel Vanderbilt. If, and when, approved, the plan will be submitted for inclusion in manufacturers' and retail NRA codes and may be bolstered by Federal and State legislation.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

The earliest authentic manuscript in existence of "The Star-Spangled Banner," which Francis Scott Key penned in Baltimore nearly 120 years ago and which is said to have been sung first in a tavern there, is going back to Baltimore for permanent public enshrinement.

Dr. and Mrs. Oswald Swinney Lowsley of 20 East Ninety-third Street and New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Lowsley, to John Ellis of Philadelphia, formerly of Greenwich, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Pell Ellis of Philadelphia.

Isidore Prushansky, 33 years old, of 681 Howard Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested late yesterday afternoon in front of a bank at Broadway and Forty-first Street by Detectives Cordes and Broderick of District Attorney Dodge's new racketeering squad after, it is alleged, he had accepted $50 from another man.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 5 (AP). -- A proposed compromise agreement with the Chase National Bank, of New York was filed in Chancery Court today by United States Senator Daniel O. Hastings, receiver for General Theatres Equipment, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Recommendations for a reduction of the sale of machine guns and other firearms and other suggestions aimed at strengthening the government's arm against crime were made by Attorney General Cummings in his annual report today to Congress.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- Governor Lehman sent a letter today to Mayor LaGuardia of New York City informing him that he is unalterably opposed to the vesting in him of the broad powers provided for in his "emergency dictatorship" bill. He made public the text of his letter this evening.

Recommendations for the improvement of the Home Relief Bureau, which is distributing relief to more than 110,000 families in the city, were made yesterday by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration in a report submitted to Mayor LaGuardia and William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, under whose jurisdiction the Home Relief Bureau is operated.

The standard ball for the two major leagues for 1934 will follow the specifications used by the American League last season. The National League has accepted the speedier American League ball in toto.

HERE is a good book, "Brazilian Adventure," by Peter Fleming (Scribner, $2.75), the Book-of-the-Month Club choice for this month. It is very nearly an exciting discovery. There are short parts of it when the writing is for the blood rather than the brain, and the reader shivers in cold rain in a Brazilian forest and hungers for something with more fat in it than a little rice every day.

United States Government bonds again were the centre of attention yesterday in trading in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Prices of the government issues closed generally lower but slightly above the lows of the day. Final quotations on the long-term issues were 11-32 point lower to 1-32 point higher.

A dozen properties, including seven in Manhattan and five in the Bronx, were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. One scheduled Manhattan sale was adjourned. The results were as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- Widely divergent views on President Roosevelt's new budget, regarded on the one hand as "ruinous" and on the other as nothing to worry about, were presented by speakers before a special conference of the American Academy of Political and Social Science here today.

Motor cars differing radically in appearance and mechanical construction from any heretofore produced in this country will be shown to the public when the National Automobile Show opens at 2 P.M. today in Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets.

Three deals by Frederick Brown, operator, featured the realty trading in the metropolitan area reported yesterday. Mr. Brown acquired two Manhattan parcels and sold the Englewood Theatre in Englewood, N.J., to Walter Reade, theatre operator.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Allotments of Public Works funds for sixty-two additional non-Federal projects, including one in New York City, today brought the total of such grants up to an aggregate of $774,416,874 for 1,707 projects.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 5. -- James H. Bolitho, former prosecutor of Morris County, who in 1925 was sentenced to two years in State Prison for malfeasance in office, was arrested tonight with five others and charged with conspiracy to commit arson.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art opens tonight its sixteenth season of free orchestra concerts, as provided annually on four Saturdays in January by gift of John D. Rockefeller Jr. David Mannes's orchestra will play Beethoven's "Eroica" symphony and works of Tchaikovsky, Mendelssohn, Grainger, Liadov and Johann Strauss.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 5. -- The constitutionality of the Wolber Act, passed by the 1933 Legislature to aid reorganization of closed State banks, was challenged in a suit argued today before Federal Judge Forman. After hearing testimony the judge directed counsel for the American Surety Company of New York, the complainant, and the Asbury Park and Ocean Grove Bank, the defendant, to file briefs within a month.

BUDAPEST, Jan. 5. -- Count Bethlen, former Premier, made a speech last night at a private gathering of distinguished political and literary persons of Budapest which created a sensation in political circles today. For the first time the Hungarian statesman put Hungary's revisionist demands in concrete form.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The House passed today, by a vote of 388 to 5, the Ways and Means Committee's liquor tax bill, which is expected to produce $470,000,000 a year in revenues from spirits, beer and wine. The Senate is expected to take up the measure on Monday or Tuesday, at which time the liquor control bill for the District of Columbia will go before the House.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The James Monroe High School five, city P.S.A.L. champion, made a second-half rally to defeat New Utrecht, 27 -- 22, in an inter-borough contest yesterday on the latter's floor. When the first half was over the Bronx quintet trailed by 12 -- 6.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 5. -- The consistent gelding Charlie K., which now races under the colors of Haughton, Jones and George, triumphed easily in the featured Flagler Claiming Handicap at Tropical Park today.
Brooklyn Tech, defending champion in the P.S.A.L. hockey tournament, gained undisputed possession of first place by defeating Jamaica, 2 -- 1, last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.
Columbia and City College met last night in the Morningside Heights pool and the Lions were victorious, 40 -- 31. It was the opening meet of the year of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- Two more leading British banks, Midland and Lloyds, announced today excellent profits and substantial dividends for 1933. As was the case with Barclays and Martins banks, last year's dividends were maintained.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Action to improve the quality of liquor sold to the American public was taken today by Joseph Choate Jr., Director of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration. He asked Governors of wet States to report instances of the sale of impure beverages.

The German Government's sterilization program seems to be slowing-up. The first concession was made when Catholic patients were exempted from the proposed surgical treatment if placed under institutional care.
Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's statements in THE TIMES today bring back to me a humorous incident that occurred when Woodrow Wilson was nominated and later installed in the White House.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- London is skeptical of President Roosevelt's monetary and financial experiments, the financial editor of The London Times said today in commenting on the President's budgetary message.
If I were Mayor of New York I would strive to make this the most beautiful city on the face of the earth.

MONTEVIDEO, Saturday, Jan. 6. -- The Chaco armistice will not be renewed when it expires at midnight tonight, according to reliable information at an early hour this morning from sources close to the League of Nations Chaco Commission. It is understood the commission will not request another renewal, and it is not expected either Bolivia or Paraguay will offer it spontaneously.
" A Divine Moment," by Robert Hare Powell, will have its premiere this evening at the Vanderbilt Theatre.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 5. -- For the first time in 121 years the Connecticut State Medical Society tonight exercised its charter right to confer the honorary degree of Doctor of Medicine. The recipient of the honor was Russell H. Chittenden, authority in physiological chemistry, and professor emeritus in that subject and emeritus director of the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 5. -- The keel for the new America's Cup defense yacht is to be poured in the Herreshoff yards tomorrow morning. Eighty-odd tons of lead will go into, the forms as the base of a boat that is to defend the cup against the challenge of T.O.M. Sopwith's new Endeavour.

Debutantes of this season and a number of girls who made their debut last year gathered at the Ritz-Carlton last night for the second Junior Assembly of the Winter. Pink and green was the color scheme of the floral decorations. The walls of the ballroom were festooned with Southern smilax, while cybotium ferns and palms were grouped in the corners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Marshaling his forces to put his unprecedented financial program through Congress without substantial change, President Roosevelt in a harmonious conference with Democratic members of the House Appropriations Committee warned today that any considerable increases above the expenditures outlined in his budget message would endanger his objective of a balanced budget by 1936.

Plunging from the north-bound platform of the West Side elevated railway station on "Dead Man's Curve" at 110th Street and Eighth Avenue, one of the highest points of the city's railway system, John Bolger, 57 years old, fell to the street seventy-five feet below last night, yet escaped with an injured left leg.

Activity in the time money market featured. There was a good demand for ninety-day funds, which were loaned at 1 per cent, and some inquiry for four months' at 1 1/4, a fractional concession from the previous rate. Otherwise, the rates for Stock Exchange call loans at 1 and Street money at 3/4 7/8, were steady. Commercial paper was firm and moderately active.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Mrs. Katherine Phelan, housekeeper, who is being held for the killing of Douglas Sheridan, stock broker, of 800 Riverside Drive, received bequests of $8,000 and most of his household effects "in recognition of her kindness to my two aunts and my dear wife," according to his will filed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Legislation to guarantee Treasury payment on $4,000,000,000 worth of bonds whose issue by the Farm Credit Administration and the Home Owners Loan Corporation is proposed, will be asked of Congress by President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- Interest in grains on the Board of Trade was limited today, and while there was moderate strength early, the upturn was not maintained. Less was heard today than yesterday regarding probable inflation of the currency.

ABOARD THE STEAMSHIP GEORGE WASHINGTON, at Sea, Jan. 5. -- Unmindful of the distinction of having aboard two Ambassadors of the largest countries in the world, this ship in the last five days has been executing every radical and revolutionary movement known to transatlantic liners.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 5. -- Taking a well-earned rest after an uninterrupted period of official dinners and social gatherings, Secretary of State Cordell Hull spent most of the day quietly at the United States Embassy.

INVERNESS, Scotland, Jan. 5. -- The Loch Ness "sea monster" was reported to have been seen again this morning -- this time on land, on the north side of the loch near Abriachan, where the water is only a short distance from the roadway.

The schedule of heavy service charges on small checking accounts proposed in the "metered service" regulations put forward by the banks of Greater New York last week and now under scrutiny by General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, was adopted over the protests of several small banks, it was revealed yesterday.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 5. -- Mrs. L. Copenhaver's Chief Almgren led home a field of seven in the seven-furlong dash that featured today's program at the Agua Caliente track. Mrs. John A. Coburn's Centre Lane was second and W.A. Dutton's Manitobian third.

A movement to coordinate all the forty code authorities operating in the city under specific industrial codes was begun yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, as chairman of the Retail Code Authority, at a meeting at NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway.

After listening to the persiflage of "Oliver Oliver," which opened at the Playhouse last evening, it is difficult to forget "The Vinegar Tree," which was visible at the same theatrical caravansary two or three seasons ago. Paul Osborn, who has written "Oliver Oliver," wrote "The Vinegar Tree," in which Mary Boland gave one of her exhibitions of inspired dementia.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- The following is the text of the letter sent today by Governor Lehman to Mayor LaGuardia:
DENVER, Jan. 5. -- Enthused by a skyline automobile ride up Lookout Mountain to Buffalo Bill's grave, Coach Lou Little and his Columbia Lions resumed their homeward trip at 4:30 P.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Plans for the reorganization of the Munson Steamship Line and its merger with the International Mercantile Marine Company, which now has a controlling interest in its properties, were laid before government officials today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 5. -- Responses to the call of the Controller of the Currency for statements of the condition of banks Dec. 30 revealed an increase in deposits in national banks in Kansas City over Oct. 25 of $9,000,000, with the total of $250,000,000, down $21,000,000 from a year ago.

Henry E. Dixey, one of Broadway's oldest and best-known actors, famous as the matinee idol of gaslight days of the Eighties, will be 75 years old today. He will spend his birthday in bed at the Times Square Hotel, with a broken arm in a cast.

The 1,600-odd piece gilded silver service which, according to tradition, Napoleon gave to his sister Pauline and her husband Prince Camillo Borghese will decorate the dining tables of several wealthy New Yorkers and a few museum shelves as a result of the auction sale here yesterday at which its pieces were divided among many buyers.

Highly irregular price movements characterized trading on local commodity futures markets yesterday. Most staples showed small losses at the close, although the trading volume held up well. Cash prices also were lower.

The entire Board of Estimate has been invited to attend the transit unification conference to be held at City Hall this morning, according to Mayor LaGuardia. At a conference on the subject, held before the new administration took office, Borough Presidents Levy of Manhattan and Lyons of the Bronx, non-Fusion members of the board, were not invited to attend.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, Exploring off Antarctica, Jan. 4. -- Her operations off the Pacific quadrant being completed, the flagship of the Byrd Antarctic Expedition at 4 o'clock this afternoon commenced to extricate herself from the Antarctic pack and start on her journey to Little America.

The Perkin Medal of the Society of Chemical Industry, awarded annually for valuable work in applied chemistry, was presented last night at a meeting of the society at the Chemists Club, 52 East Forty-first Street, to Dr. Colin G. Fink off Columbia University for his inventions in the fields of metallurgy and electrochemistry.

Ten of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks operated last year at a net loss after payment of dividends and charges, it was disclosed yesterday in the detailed statements of the banks. The two that showed net profits transferred to surplus account at the year's end were the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, with $2,688,000, and the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, with $932,000.
After advancing early yesterday to the highest ground in the last three months, prices on the Cotton Exchange fell back 10 points and ended with losses of 6 to 12 points.

BERLIN, Jan. 5. -- Yesterday's upward swing continued at the opening of today's session of the Boerse, with increased buoyancy, a number of stocks opening substantially above yesterday's closing. I.G. Farben was 1 7/8 points up and Reichbahn preferred rose 3 points, with heavy industrials and public utilities otherwise in chief demand and generally higher.

Speaking before a group of textile manufacturers, merchants and bankers last night at the Princeton Club, Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana made a plea for the re-monetization of silver. He also criticized the administration's emergency measures calling for the reduction of cotton and wheat acreage.

A competition to select a sculptor or designer for the memorial to be erected to the Rev. Francis P. Duffy will be held by the Father Duffy Memorial Committee, sponsors of the movement to honor the wartime chaplain of the old Sixty-ninth Infantry.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- The stock market was cheerful today in spite of the end of the account tomorrow. British Government funds benefited from reinvestment of interest disbursements, also in expectation of an early government financial operation.

Experimental operation of a dummy ticker unit, to determine the practicability of the proposed "express-ticker" system, is likely to be started by the New York Stock Exchange in about a month, it was announced yesterday.

New York University's basketball team registered its third consecutive victory of the season in triumphing over Johns Hopkins, 48 to 24, at the University Heights gymnasium last night. The Violet came from behind to pile up a 26-to-11 lead at the end of the first half.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5. -- Mrs. Wanamaker Munn, who will leave tomorrow for New York with her house guests, Mrs. Cole Porter and Roger Davis, and her children, Miss Fernanda and Gurnee Munn Jr., entertained today with a luncheon at Louwana.

Garages pay the city millions of dollars annually in taxes and have paid many hundreds of thousands of dollars in street assessments. They endeavor to comply with the NRA by employing adequate help at fair wages, yet they get no cooperation from the city.

Back from Albany, where he urged quick passage of the LaGuardia administration's housing program, Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post expressed the hope yesterday that slum clearance work in the city could start by March 1.

These changing times offer the greatest opportunity to advocates of the decimal plan. Many people are apathetic when they hear the familiar arguments for the metric system -- for they admit it can be learned easily and would simplify all transactions; yet they dread the change in names.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Stabilization of steel prices under authority of the NRA code for the iron and steel industry, approved by President Roosevelt on Aug. 19 last, has produced so many identical bids on steel products that the Navy Department is awarding contracts with the aid of Lady Luck.

Charles S. McCain, chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank, will be elected next week president and chief executive officer of the United Light and Power Company to succeed William Chamberlain, who will become chairman of the board.

Crockett Buss. Inc., in an expansion move, has leased about 8,500 square feet in the Susquehanna Building at 149 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Thirty-second Street. The firm, a wholesaler of rugs and carpets, is to move from 15 West Twenty-eighth Street late this month.

The "forgotten section" of Amendment XIV, about which P.J. Eder wrote to THE TIMES, is forgotten for the very good reason that the issue it was intended to meet was disposed of well over half a century ago. The entire section reads as follows:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- Syracuse annexed its seventeenth consecutive basketball game by defeating Princeton tonight, 34 -- 26. Archbold Gym was packed to capacity with 3,500 fans who saw a game replete with thrills to the final whistle.
Contributions for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases held up well again yesterday and made another substantial inroad into the long list of families and individuals still unprovided for.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- President Roosevelt received today from Harvey Couch, a director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, a graph showing that from Nov. 9 to the first of January 3,391 banks not members of the Federal Reserve System had been helped to qualify for membership ill the Deposit Insurance Fund.

The upward trend in gross revenues was resumed in November by the Class I railroads, according to the Bureau of Railway Economics. The increase was 2.8 per cent and it brought gross revenues for the eleven months of 1933 to within 1.2 per cent of the total for the same period in 1932.

While it generally had been surmised that in the near future the Federal Government would take some step toward unifying conservation work in this country, the appointment this week of a committee which has power to develop and supervise such a program came as a surprise to most persons interested.

In the first Eastern Amateur Hockey League double-header, the Baltimore Orioles turned back the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, 2 to 0, and the Bronx H.C. vanquished the St. Nicholas sextet, 2 to 1, in the New York Coliseum last night.

For twelve years the Berkshire Industrial Farm has shared in the proceeds of the Nearly New Shop, which conducts a permanent rummage sale at 913 Eighth Avenue. Each year the Berkshire Farm's share of the profits from this shop has been sufficient to support eight or ten of the 150 destitute boys at the farm.

Over-night reflection upon the government's financial problems which the President described in his budget message of Thursday did not change the complexion of the markets greatly yesterday. If anything, the attitude of the financial community was even more reserved than on the day before.

HALLE, Germany, Jan. 5 (AP). -- A half dozen venerable State Bishops of the Lutheran Church, who had assembled here determined to unseat Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller, capitulated before the magic name of Hitler today and went home without taking action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Speculative attacks on bank stocks and switching of deposits from one bank to another preceded the Michigan banking collapse, according to evidence given the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack will hear arguments next Friday on a motion to compel the Interborough receivers to make known at once whether or not they intend to seek permission to abrogate the 999-year lease of the elevated lines of the Manhattan Railway Company.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- A strike, effective tomorrow, which will deprive Chicago of the milk usually, delivered by the 18,000 farmer members of the Pure Milk Association was voted this afternoon.

Except for a short time in the late forenoon, the share market was heavy and listless throughout yesterday's trading. Brokers said the general apathy of traders was mainly responsible. There was some profit-taking but never in any considerable volume.

PARIS, Jan. 5. -- Greater optimism prevailed among importers of American goods today after United States Embassy officials had received verbal assurances from the French Government that no tax would be applied upon import licenses, as had been reported.

ROME, Jan. 5. -- A complete plan for the reorganization of European peace was outlined in the two conversations Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, had with Premier Mussolini during his visit to Rome. The plan which was submitted by Signor Mussolini and received the full approval of Sir John would take effect in three stages:

A concerted effort to rid Jersey City piers, wharfs, factories, warehouses and private homes of rodents will begin next Friday with the combined aid of the Federal Government and the local health department. More than 100 Civil Works Administration employes will be recruited for the job.

Because six of its ten directors are also directors or officers of banks and because it has not yet been able to obtain an official ruling as to their eligibility to retain those positions under the Banking Act, the National Investors Corporation and its three affiliated investment trusts have elected three new members to their boards to insure the existence of a quorum.

Although the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had expressed willingness to lend money for a building in which a planetarium for the American Museum of Natural History was to be housed, no provision was made for the optical apparatus. Thanks to $150,000 donated by Mr. CHARLES HAYDEN, the Museum is now able to break ground, to purchase the equipment that it needs and thus to realize a long-cherished dream.

Asserting that the clergymen of the State were with Chairman Macy in his fight to prevent the re-election of Fred W. Hammond as clerk of the Assembly, William Ziegler Jr., treasurer of the Republican State Committee, made public yesterday a second lot of letters supporting Mr. Macy.

Even though retail buying lacked the stimulus of sub-zero temperatures, the weather was sufficiently cold to keep sales during the week nearly on a par with the level of the previous week, according to the weekly review of Dun Brad-street, Inc.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 5. -- Defeating all efforts to induce him to join the Cabinet George Tatarescu is trying to form, Nicholas Titulescu announced this evening he would not retain the post of Foreign Minister, but would soon go abroad again. He is expected to resume his old post as Minister to London.

The New York University girls' basketball team opened its season by triumphing over Brooklyn College, 41 to 10, at the Washington Square gymnasium of the N.Y.U. School of Education yesterday. The Violet girls were in the van, 17 to 6, at the half.

STUTTGART, Jan. 5. -- Two Catholic priests, Father Dangelmaier of Metzingen and Father Sturm of Waldheim, were arrested by the political police today for allegedly seditious conduct and were interned in the Kuhberg concentration camp.

There are no heroines in the sketches Edward F. Gardner has derived from Dorothy Parker's "After Such Pleasures." Rather, in all eight of the portraits is shown woman's most unreasonable side; if this be libel, blame the proprietors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Great confusion prevails among the twenty-four New York City Democratic members of the House. Heretofore accustomed to taking orders and voting as they were told by the leaders of Tammany and its affiliate organizations, each member at this session is "following my conscience" and looking to President Roosevelt for leadership.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 5. -- Thousands of commuters on the Erie Railroad in Bergen and Passaic Counties were heartened considerably today when word came to them through the Utility Users Protective League, formerly the Metropolitan League of Erie Commuters, that beginning Feb. 1 reduced rates would become effective to conform with the five-day week program under which many commuters are working.
Apartment houses in Jersey City and Hoboken were included in the New Jersey turnover reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP). -- With an assertion that the country "stands disgraced in the defeat of its greatest moral advance," the National Temperance and Prohibition Council today issued its declaration of purposes and called on all foes of liquor to fight the traffic.

Retail trade made an excellent showing during the week, retail executives here reported yesterday. The usual post-holiday lag in shopping was at a minimum and many stores achieved substantial increases over the same period a year ago.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 5. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ending Dec. 30 totaled 342,475,000 barrels, a decrease of 164,000 barrels from the total of 342,639,000 barrels reported for the preceding week, Harold L. Ickes announced today, as Administrator of the Petroleum Code.

In the annual report of the Attorney General for the fiscal year 1933 the faithful reader cannot turn with the old eagerness to the observations of the Director of Prohibition. Lugubrious thoughts crowd up. A once majestic officer inevitably takes on the look of a funeral director.

A program of Walt Disney animated cartoons will be presented for six showings today at the County Centre in White Plains by Mrs. Joseph Sonneborn, who sponsored the recent Disney program at Carnegie Hall.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 5. -- After wandering for more than four hours through rain and sleet at levels from 1,500 to 6,000 feet above a cloud-wrapped world, Dean Burford, air-mail pilot, landed at Newark Airport at 4:40 this morning. He had taken off from the same field for Pittsburgh and Columbus soon after midnight.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 5. -- Nine men were held here today in bail ranging from $2,000 to $7,500 as members of a gang alleged to have passed thousands of counterfeit $5, $10 and $20 bills in this vicinity in recent months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The proposal recently made to Great Britain to increase substantially the quota allotted to United States pork products from 6.3 per cent in return for an increase of the basic English liquor quota of 600,000 gallons brought today a tentative offer of 7.6 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- A plan of organic union of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America and the United Presbyterian Church of North America was made public today by a joint committee which is mailing copies to clergymen of the two denominations.

Action designed to force the Actors Equity Association to abandon its stand against Sunday closing of legitimate theatres was taken yesterday by members of the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802, of the American Federation of Musicians at a turbulent meeting in Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Bep van Klaveren, Holland's candidate for the world's welterweight boxing title, started the new year last night at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, with a stirring triumph over Tony Falco, Philadelphia, in the feature bout of ten rounds.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 5. -- A great reunion of revolutionary leaders will take place here tomorrow or Sunday, to confer on the political crisis created by the recent resignations of several Cabinet members.
The dollar rebounded sharply yesterday from the shock it had received by the publication of the President's budget message.

One of the largest entertainments for charity this season took place in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria last night when the annual Peacock Motor Show Ball was given in the interests of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

Mayor LaGuardia will lead the Columbia football squad from the Pennsylvania Station to Morningside Heights when it arrives at 8:30 o'clock tomorrow night, it was announced yesterday by Associate Dean Nicholas McD. McKnight, chairman of the reception committee.
Henri Cochet of France is ranked first by William Tilden among the players whom the Philadelphia master of the tennis courts has met during his career as amateur and professional.

Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, retired Health Commissioner, was elected president yesterday of the Greater New York-New Jersey Milk Institute, an organization of milk dealers in the metropolitan area. He succeeds Harry A. Cronk, who is the head of Borden's Farm Products Company, Inc., and who served as head of the institute without salary.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan 5 (AP). -- Slapped, a 4-year-old son of Pompey, representing L. Wilson, conquered a small field today in winning the one and one-sixteenth mile feature at Jefferson Park.

BERLIN, Jan. 5. -- The disarmament snarl as viewed in the Wilhelmstrasse this early in the new year is about as hopeless as when Germany bolted the Geneva conference on Oct. 14. Neither the French reply to Chancellor Hitler's proposals nor the conversations of Premier Mussolini and Sir John Simon, it was declared today, contribute toward a workable solution.

Members of various teachers' organizations, aroused over the LaGuardia bill providing a payless month's furlough for city employes, attacked the Mayor yesterday for breaking his campaign pledges against salary reductions.

When the city closed its books on Dec. 31 it had plenty to worry about in the months that lay ahead. But as it looked backward it had cause to feel some measure of relief. The agreement with the bankers had at least laid the groundwork for restored municipal credit.

Two attaches of the staff of Sheriff Frank J. Quayle of Kings County started out yesterday to serve a warrant for a writ of attachment on the North German Lloyd steamer Europa, which docked yesterday at the Army Pier at the foot of Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.

Legislation of the greatest importance to horse shows and participants in such exhibitions in the United States was adopted yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Morse Show Association, held in the Hotel Biltmore.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, is expected back in London tomorrow. Early next week there will be a meeting of the Cabinet subcommittee on disarmament followed by a full Cabinet session to hear what he accomplished on his latest mission to Paris and Rome, and to decide what the British Continental policy is to be from now on.

A copy of the third Shakespeare folio in contemporary binding brought $3,750 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction sale of rare books, autographs, manuscripts and drawings from a number of consignors.

Trading in United States Government bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday showed a lesser degree of nervousness than on the previous day, but closed irregularly lower with the losses ranging up to 11-32ds point. Total transactions were $5,544,000, compared with $7,320,000 on Thursday.

Democratic members of the Board of Aldermen spent half an hour yesterday replying to the New Year's Day address of Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch, in which he referred to the board as "an assemblage of district messenger boys."

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in 1933 totaled $241,454,844,300, a decline of 5.9 per cent from the turnover in 1932. While the shrinkage is a continuation of the recession that set in after the collapse in 1929, the comparison is more favorable when compared with loss of 37.4 per cent in 1932 from the aggregate in 1931.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., Jan. 5 (AP). -- Vincent Flannelly, 25, was killed, and Allen McCarthy, 23, was injured seriously when their motor car struck a bridge near Lakin, Kan., today. Both were students at Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The simple question, "Who carried the first bottle?" held the attention of the House for a time today.

Impressions at Washington, as everywhere else, differ about the effect of the President's budget message. The prevailing opinion seems to be that expressed by Senator WAGNER. He was quoted yesterday as saying: "It must "now be evident that the whole trend "is away from fiat or printing-press "money."

Ida Horowitz, a lawyer, applied to the Appellate Division yesterday for permission to appeal from a ruling of the Appellate Term upholding the dismissal in the City Court of a suit she brought against the Bank of United States and the estate of H. Louis Jacobson, counsel for the bank, for $1,500 for legal services in aiding in the collection of a judgment.

TRENTON, Jan. 5. -- Segregation of Negro pupils in swimming classes at the Trenton Central High School was held today to be unlawful discrimination by the Court of Errors and Appeals. A similar ruling by the Supreme Court was unanimously sustained.

In volume and in total sales value the best sellers of 1933 represented a 12 per cent increase over those of 1932, according to Baker Taylor Company, book wholesalers. The Christmas sales boom came late this year, the wholesalers say, but it was strong when it came, adding that the "important thing to remember is that the terrible downward plunge has been stopped and we are climbing back."

Sergei and Marie Radamsky, both of whom have traveled and given concerts extensively in Soviet Russia, gave their only New York recital of the season at the New School for Social Research last night. In an uncommonly interesting and searching program, they made known something of what the contemporary Soviet composer is writing in the song form as well as providing a perspective with two complete groups by Mussorgsky.

WARSAW, Jan. 5. -- A semi-official communique from the telegraphic agency A.T.E. confirms today the report that the Soviet Union and Poland have been negotiating a pact guaranteeing the independence of the four Baltic States -- Latvia, Estonia, Lithuania and Finland.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels and Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, who are jointly investigating the twenty-five-year bus franchises voted to five Manhattan companies during the closing days of the Tammany administration, received promises of complete cooperation yesterday from officials of the companies involved.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, announced in today's issue of the bulletin of his office that he is working on a plan of reorganization of the Westchester Trust Company of Yonkers, which he took over on Tuesday, and that the plan is being submitted to the Supreme Court in Westchester County.

The aim of the city's Purchase Department will be to get the best commodities and materials at the lowest prices so that the cost of government may be reduced Commissioner Russell Forbes said yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 5. -- After having combed Paris four days in search of Alexandre Stavisky, leader of the Bayonne Credit Municipal swindle, the police today found his wife and three children but not Stavisky.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 5. -- There were many close football games played last Fall and I think it was due to the fact that teams were more evenly matched than in some previous seasons. The Columbia victory over Stanford was a sensational climax to developments marking fresh enthusiasm for the game.

PARIS, Jan. 5. -- President Roosevelt's budget message and its astronomic figures have had, on the whole, a good reception in Paris. The President scores as many approvals as disapprovals among the financial pundits of France and the allied press.
The payment of $50,000,000 to Pennsylvania veterans was provided yesterday when Governor Gifford Pinchot, who is in St. Luke's Hospital here suffering from shingles, signed the necessary bills.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Presidential approval of a code of fair competition for the wholesale food and grocery trade was announced today by General Johnson. This is one of the more important codes transferred recently to the NRA from the AAA.
The return of policemen who were demoted or transferred through political influence during the Bolan regime was started yesterday by Chief Inspector Lewis J. Valentine.

CLEVELIND, Jan. 5 (AP). -- A petition asking that four railroads be enjoined from carrying on a "store- door" delivery service was filed in Federal Court here today by the Ohio Association of Commercial Haulers.

CALCUTTA, Jan. 5 (Canadian Press) . -- Despite introduction of the so-called bodyline bowling and aggressive fielding by the Indians, England compiled a total of 257 runs for only five wickets at the close of play today in the second test cracket match of the Indian tour.

NEVERS, France, Jan. 5 (AP). -- Miss Evelyn G. Frost, a prominent St. Louis society woman, was burned to death today in the flaming wreckage of her small tourist biplane after it had crashed into a high-tension wire and pole near here in a heavy fog.

George S. Van Schaick State Superintendent of Insurance will be the first witness in the Moreland investigation of his department's handling of the guaranteed mortgage situation, beginning at 10:30 A.M. Jan. 15.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 5. -- Equaling the course record set by last year's winner, with a dazzling 33 -- 33 -- 66, Charles McAllister, professional at the Queens Valley Country Club in Forest Hills, L.I., gained a two-stroke lead in a field of 161 starters in the first eighteen holes of the seventy-two-hole competition for the Miami open championship at the Miami Springs Golf Club today.

The Emergency Child Welfare Committee to carry out recommendations of the recent Washington conference on emergencies in the care of dependent and neglected children was formed yesterday at a meeting of conference representatives in the Russell Sage Building.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The Home Owners' Loan Corporation entered the new year with $103,257,858 of loans on 36,310 urban homes closed and paid out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- President Roosevelt today ordered full speed ahead on ratification of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence waterway treaty. He told Senate leaders he desired the treaty approved with a minimum of delay, after a conference at the White House with Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the New York Power Authority.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

PARIS, Jan. 5. -- The gravity of a threat to overthrow the French Cabinet because of the collapse of the Bayonne municipal pawnshop was revealed today in a half-hour talk between Premier Chautemps and President Albert Lebrun.

Richard Whitney, well known as the prime mover in the race meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds in New Jersey, has been elected a steward of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, according to an announcement yesterday from Frank Bryan, secretary of the association.

Sidney S. Levine, License Commissioner, made a second appearance before the grand jury yesterday to summarize the results of his three weeks' investigation of graft in the issuance of news-stand licenses.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 (AP). -- The New York State Conference of Mayors and other municipal officials through its officers and advisory committee presented a program to the Legislature today featuring two proposals for stricter control over utility rates through the Public Service Commission and a 2 per cent retail sales tax.

A jury in the Kings County Court, after being locked up all night, returned a verdict of guilty yesterday morning in the case of Samuel J. Wurzberg, Brooklyn fire loss adjuster, who was charged with second-degree arson. After returning at 6:25 P.M. on Thursday, the jury reported its verdict yesterday shortly after 11 A.M.

After conferring with State Senator John J. Dunnigan, majority leader, on the bill giving the Mayor wide economy powers, Mayor LaGuardia was reported convinced last night that some form of compromise would be necessary to get his bill through the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Democratic plans to push legislation to grant special powers to the President, particularly power to negotiate reciprocal tariffs, seem likely to start a sharp conflict in the Senate.

The University of Toronto hockey team will seek to make it two straight on its New York trip when it meets the Harvard sextet at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Queen City stick-wielders have to their credit a 4-to-2 victory over the Princeton team, scored in a brilliant overtime game at the Garden on Wednesday night.

Creation of a commission to conduct an inquiry into the policy of America in international economic relations carries into a world-field studies of national scope begun in 1921 under the chairmanship of HERBERT HOOVER, then Secretary of Commerce, and continued in the report on "Recent Social Trends" made late in Mr. HOOVER'S Presidency by a committee under the chairmanship of Dr. WESLEY C. MITCHELL.

A FEW hours earlier Mr. Ellsworth Vines had stepped from the train which had carried him from California to New York. Now, after a bit of tennis in the afternoon, he was enjoying himself, in company with Bill Tilden, in a local hotel at a dinner which was symbolizing his debut in professional tennis. His smooth, young face, tanned and healthy looking, wore a perpetual grin. He was feeling well, thank you.

Fred Coolemans, another of many foreign dancers to elect to appear in America this season, made his local debut last night at the Forrest Theatre. Half Dutch and half Javanese by birth, he has spent most of his professional career in Germany, where he is said to have enjoyed some success.
Despite the election of Mayor LaGuardia last November, New York City remains overwhelmingly Democratic, according to the enrolment figures made public yesterday by the Board of Elections.
Mrs. Eleanor Dwight Jones, in a letter to THE TIMES, makes the statement that British birth control has been endorsed as moral by the Lambeth Conference of Anglican Bishops.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- Aggregate deposits and cash resources of banks in this city expanded in the last quarter of 1933, while outstanding loans and discounts shrank, it appeared today when both State and national banks reported their condition as of Dec. 30 in response to calls from the State Auditor and the Controller of the Currency.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5. -- An old model single-passenger plane crashed in the heart of Shadyside this afternoon, after the 21-year-old pilot had jumped in his parachute to land in Centre Avenue, within 200 feet of a hospital. First examination indicated that he was only slightly injured.

In preliminary discussions of the possibility of merging telegraph companies in the United States, should Congress pass a law authorizing such a consolidation, based upon the recent report filed with President Roosevelt by the Interdepartmental Communications Committee, communications experts have recommended a transfer of the telephone-typewriter service of the Bell System to the combined telegraph companies.

As Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, opened a drive against speakeasies last night, it became known that restaurant and hotel proprietors and other holders of liquor licenses are to be questioned by the office of District Attorney Dodge in an investigation of charges of grafting by board employes.

BANGKOK, Siam, Jan. 5 (AP). -- A two months' stay in New York for cataract operation on His Majesty's eye is the most important feature of a visit the King and Queen of Siam will make to the United States, sailing Jan. 12. Both of King Prajadhipok's eyes are stricken, the right more seriously.
Manhattan's sophomores performed like veterans in the Jasper gymnasium last night and turned in a surprising victory over Georgetown's basketball team, 26 to 17.

President Roosevelt repeated to the joint session of Congress the assurance he had already given at the Woodrow Wilson memorial meeting, that our Latin-American neighbors need fear no aggression or intermeddling on the part of this country. Even earlier, Washington dispatches had announced that he was considering the abrogation of the Platt amendment.

One of the most unusual events of the musical season will take place on Wednesday evening, Jan. 17, when Professor Albert Einstein, world-famed scientist, assisted by outstanding artists, will give a musical program at the residence of Adolph Lewisohn, 881 Fifth Avenue.

With many Olympic, national, intercollegiate and A.A.U. association champions competing on the program, the Columbus Council, K. of C., meet will open the 1934 indoor track and field season at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn tonight, starting at 8 o'clock.

BERLIN, Jan. 5. -- The German press began today a counter-offensive against the protests by the United States and Great Britain regarding Germany's arbitrary cut in her interest payments on her foreign debt. Back of this offensive is fear of retaliation by the creditors.

The Most Rev. James DeWolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church and Bishop of Rhode Island, will observe the twenty-third anniversary of his consecration to the episcopate this morning at 9 o'clock at a special service of holy communion in the chapel of the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue.

New State and municipal obligations scheduled for award next week through competitive bidding total $9,844,200, compared with this week's revised total of $4,447,003. A year ago this week new issues in the amount of $19,198,750 came up for award.

Shippers of coal have noted this season a depreciation in the equipment furnished them by the railroads, according to reports by members of regional shippers' advisory boards. Other shippers did not register complaints.
CAIRO, Jan. 5. -- No sooner does one political controversy die down here than the Egyptian press always finds a new sensation to fill its columns.

THE MOON THROUGH GLASS" is a longish novel, plotted by Mr. Coningsby Dawson with great care and involution, in a very romantic vein. It describes the numerous and slightly confusing amorous adventures of Sally Vail, the carefully trained daughter of a London clergyman.
OXFORD, England, Jan. 6 (Canadian Press). -- The touring American hockey team defeated an English team, 2 -- 0, tonight.

Financial relief for parochial schools is asked in an open letter to Governor Lehman and the State Legislature printed in the current issue of The Tablet, official publication of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN the cinema edition of "Alice in Wonderland" was flashed at Christmas time upon the nation's screens, Edgar Norton's five-year crusade to foist the Lewis Carroll classic upon a reluctant Hollywood came to a triumphant conclusion.
THE trend in Chevrolet sales over the past several years as compared with our experience in the last half of 1930 gives us great encouragement about the automobile business in 1934.

A collection of 125 pieces of Islamic calligraphy, painting, bookbinding and other items, presented to the Columbia University Library by Dr. David Eugene Smith, Professor Emeritus of Mathematics, will be shown publicly for the first time tomorrow at Avery Hall, Columbia University.

Inspector Joseph W. O'Connor of the municipal Bureau of Licenses, who has been named during the last three weeks by news-stand operators as the official from whom they got their licenses after graft had been paid to unofficial "fixers," took the stand yesterday at Commissioner Sidney S. Levine's inquiry into his own department.

More than 100 friends and associates of the Most Rev. James De Wolf Perry, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church and Bishop of Rhode Island, gathered yesterday morning in the chapel of the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue, where he has his headquarters, to join with him in observing the twenty-third anniversary of his consecration to the Episcopate.

Threats made by a group of musicians, meeting on Friday, to go on strike unless the Actors Equity Association abandons its stand against Sunday performances in legitimate theatres were "wholly unauthorized" by the board of the musicians' union, Edward Canavan, head of the American Federation of Musicians Local 802, said yesterday.

Scoring its third victory in as many days and its twelfth of the season, the undefeated Long Island University quintet routed St. Peter's College, 60 -- 24, before 500 fans at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.

The sportsmen of America who shoot and fish are said to expend in the neighborhood of $1,000,000,000 every year. The question now before the 10,000,000 or more men and women involved is this: Will they be willing to pay more?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Post-holiday influences and reduced activity for the year-end inventory period characterized business conditions during the week ended on Dec. 30, but the seasonal slackening was moderate and most indexes were higher than at the close of 1932, according to the weekly survey of business activity made public today by the Department of Commerce.
A test case to force the city to pay $20,000,000 to property owners on condemnation awards will be heard in Special Term Part I of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- Aside from their curiosity about the stupendous figures in the United States budget and the prospective public debt, the British people are finding in President Roosevelt's fiscal message material for argument on both sides of the controversy which is just beginning over their own government's budget.
Fordham's basketball quintet scored its sixth victory in as many games by turning back Columbia, 37 to 21, in the Ram gymnasium last night.
BERLIN, Jan. 6. -- Indiscriminate or forced dismissals of Jewish employes were prohibited by an order issued by Franz Seldte, Reich Minister of Labor, on Nov. 24 but never made public.

MR. TALBOT'S novel is a pretty stiff dose of the Battle-of-Waterloo-won-on-the-playing-fields-of-Eton tradition. He has placed it remotely enough -- in the middle of the nineteenth century -- to make dispassionate appraisal possible.

When Claire Linden is found dead in the bathtub in her bungalow home on the university campus the evidence points strongly to her husband, Paul, as the murderer, but there are two persons who refuse to believe him guilty. One is his brother. Doctor Linden, and the other is Breezy West, a newspaper girl who has loved Paul since long before he was married and still loves him.

NEVER in the history of the industry have automobile manufacturers faced a more interesting year than that which lies before us in 1934. It is more than mere coincidence that, in the very year that we are definitely emerging from the depression period, an entirely new and superior type of automobile has been developed and placed on the market to add the final touch of the spur to an eager market.

A further sinking spell in United States Government issues unsettled the market for bonds on the Stock Exchange during the brief trading period yesterday. The government group fell 2-32 to 17-32 points, with the exceptions of the called Fourth Liberty 4 1/4s, which were unchanged and the First Liberty 4 1/4s, up 1-32 point.

MOBILIZED for the most determined drive for business expansion in the history of its existence, the automotive industry moves into its 1934 sales position prepared to take a leading role in the general program of business rehabilitation.

In THE TIMES recent interview with Ambassador Bingham I was interested in his remark that much misunderstanding was due to inadequate newspaper correspondence. Misunderstanding is of course unfortunate, especially between nations that have so much in common, and I have for some time felt that such correspondence needed attention.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 19. -- Among its other outstanding achievements, the Seventh Pan-American Conference made a notable contribution to the codification of international law by adopting a draft convention on the subject of the rights and duties of States.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 5. -- A depression industry -- the practice of trucking coal directly from small independent anthracite mines in Pennsylvania to consumers in New Jersey -- is one of the problems that have arisen to trouble the new authority administering the New Jersey retail coal code under the New Jersey Industrial Recovery Act.

A set of amendments to the Food and Drugs Act, described as designed to obtain protection for the public but "to safeguard against fantastic legislation" were proposed yesterday by the National Drug Trade Conference as a substitute for the so-called Tugwell bill, upon which action is to be sought in the present Congress.
How often do you bathe each week?

WASHINGTON. FIVE census projects, approved by the Civil Works Administration with an allotment of $5,415,120, will give emergency employment to 29,000 men and women, largely recruited from the "white collar" groups.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, arrived in London tonight from Rome. Tomorrow he will give an account of his discussions with Premier Mussolini to Prime Minister MacDonald, who is returning from a holiday in Scotland.

Because William J. Flynn, former Bronx Public Works Commissioner, awarded contracts for metal furniture and fixtures of the new Bronx County court house to other than the low bidders, James J. Lyons, new Bronx Borough President, is seeking to have the contracts set aside.

HERE, in a form as compressed as a yeast cake, can be found a compendium of about all that is definitely known about colds -- which isn't much, after all -- and about the medicines which people swallow or inhale or rub on to cure or prevent them -- which is a great deal more.

MANY discussions assume that Washington's efforts to bring farm and other prices near together are an unheard-of departure. Several countries are trying experiments not much unlike ours, though less comprehensive. Holland fixes a price for hogs and issues a limited number of license tags to farmers, who must attach one to each animal offered for sale, thus preventing an overwhelming of the market.

LAST year was a tempestuous one for automobile tire manufacturers. Gross sales in units increased about 10 per cent, and there was a corresponding advance in the number of pneumatic tires manufactured, but again the industry finished a twelve-month period with little, if any, operating profit for the major companies, and the smaller ones registered lower profits than was the case in 1932.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- Illuminating gas escaping from a water heater in the basement of the home of William C. Hubbard, stage technician, at 49 Lawrence Avenue, this afternoon killed Mrs. Hubbard and overcame two women visitors. Two persons who came to the aid of the three, one of them Dr. James C. Wilson of 305 Columbus Avenue, Tuckahoe, also were overcome.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- An innovation in NRA code procedure was announced today by Recovery Administrator Johnson, who approved the method by which "actual overhead" will be determined for inclusion in the retail selling price of lumber, lumber products, building materials and building specialties.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 6. -- Announcement of the acquisition by Harvard University of twenty fragments of the famous "ivory house" of Ahab, mentioned in Biblical history, was made today by Dr. Kirsopp Lake, Professor of History at Harvard.

FROM the standpoint of body-styling the year 1934 represents a marked step in advance. Car contours have been developing rapidly during the past few years, but the culmination of the trend in the direction to all curved lines comes this year.
FOLSOM PRISON, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP). -- A parole was denied today Warren K. Billings, who was convicted with Thomas J. Mooney for bombing the 1916 San Francisco Preparedness Day parade.

IMPORTANT forward steps for aeronautics may be expected from the fact that this year's conference of the Federation Aeronautique Internationale, the world-governing body for aviation as a sport and in competitive matters, will be held in Washington with the National Aeronautic Association, American representative, as host.

MADRID, Jan. 5. -- Several bombastic speeches were made this week by the Socialist Opposition leader, Francisco Largo Caballero, who warned the newly elected Right majority in the Cortes that anything suspected of being covert preparation for a restoration of monarchy would be violently resisted.

MORE efficient operation of vehicles has always been the major problem in any form of transport. The cave man discovered that his drag was easier for his pony to pull when the drag ended in a leafy branch that spread the weight, and, in this, he discovered the first principle of overcoming resistance.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Jan. 3. -- Kansas in the 1934 election will be a political prize and the strategists from the Democratic and Republican camps are calling in their field officers to get the lay of the land.

The Columbia University wrestling team met with its first setback in several years at the hands of a C.C.N.Y. combination when it was defeated yesterday in the Blue and White gymnasium by the score of 16 -- 14.

JOBLESS teachers are frequently criticized because by the thousands they stay on in the larger cities, clamoring hopelessly at the gates of the big brick schools. Going West, they are told, they might find the little red schoolhouses more receptive.

The United States Government sold 50,000 to 60,000 of cotton contracts in the last three trading sessions on the New York and the New Orleans Cotton Exchanges, it is estimated. Because the trade is unable to determine the reason for the selling, the operators are said to be unsettling market factors.

WHILE the official price for newly mined domestic gold changes from time to time, the price for old gold fluctuates but slightly. To be sure, the peddlers of old gold, and there have been thousands of them of late, often possess the gambler's faith in tomorrow's luck.

Coordination of home-study facilities is essential for the further advancement of adult education, Edward S. Richards, associate director of University extension in charge of home study at Columbia University, declares in his annual report, made public yesterday.

An accurate-hitting, smooth-functioning Pennsylvania Military College team defeated Squadron C's trio, 15 1/2 to 6. last night in their Metropolitan Indoor Polo League Class B game at Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn.

The Savage School girls' basketball team opened its season with an impressive 17-10 victory over its Alumnae yesterday on the school floor. The winners, led by Miss Dorothy Morris, forged into the lead at the start and then continued to set the pace until the finish.

LONDON'S foreign exchange market -- made up of 120 British and foreign banks and private bankers and some forty foreign exchange brokers -- has become, willy-nilly, the world's chief battleground of the dollar, the pound sterling and the French franc.
IN his budget message to the Seventy-third Congress last week President Roosevelt made three remarkable predictions:

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sunday, Jan. 7. -- At least four workmen are believed to have burned to death when four 25,000-gallon crude oil stills at the Atlantic Refining Company's plant in South Philadelph'a became ignited late last night after an explosion felt over a radius of twenty miles.

SINCE the automobile was first accepted as a means of transportation, some forty years ago, literally thousands of laws affecting its ownership and use have been placed on the statute books. They are designed to meet virtually every situation that may arise from the movement of more than 24,000,000 motor vehicles on our Streets and highways.
BERLIN, Jan. 5. -- The powers that rule the new-Germany are determined that it shall, first, last and all the time, be "race-minded."
Two liners crashed in the Hudson River at noon yesterday as they attempted to pass in the dense fog that had hampered harbor traffic for two days.

WHEN Robert Seymour Conway died on Sept. 28, the most effulgent light on Etruscan culture was extinguished. Fabretti was already dead, and with him had died his unpublished secrets of the dead and buried language which had preceded Latin in the Italian peninsula.
One of the most enthusiastic and thunderous receptions New York has ever giver a victorious sports team will take place tonight when the Columbia football squad arrives at 8:30.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 6. -- War will be resumed in the Chaco at midnight tonight. Whatever slight hope remained last night that the truce between Bolivia and Paraguay might be prolonged disappeared with the receipt of dispatches from Asuncion this morning saying that under no circumstances would the armistice be extended.

City College pitted its smoother passing against the St. John's long-range sharpshooters at the 102d Regiment Armory last night and the Lavender wrested a close battle from its traditional foe, 30 to 25, to run its winning streak to eight in a row.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- Most of the Winter homes in Bermuda are now occupied and the round of social activities is in full swing. Christmas and New Year's ships brought down about 2,000 visitors from New York and more are coming on each subsequent ship.

The emergency tax of 5 per cent imposed on the receipt of corporate dividends, enacted last June as a part of the National Industrial Recovery Act, terminated with the advent of the new year. By provision of the act, the President's proclamation of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment automatically rendered the tax inapplicable in respect of dividends declared "on and after the first day of the calendar year following the date of such proclamation."

More than 500 elementary school principals from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut attended the final session of a two-day conference on elementary education, held yesterday at Teachers College, Columbia University. Dr. J.R. McGaughy, Professor of Education at Teachers College, directed the conference.

INDUSTRIAL conditions for 1934 are difficult, if not impossible, to predict with any degree of accuracy, since they will naturally be governed to a large extent by the further progress made in national recovery. The automotive industry is working under the code and the Buick Motor Company is operating under the provisions of that code.

BERLIN, Jan. 6. -- Following yesterday's recession, the Boerse today renewed its upward swing, with shipping stocks the centre of interest. The primary incentive for the advance by this group was believed to be the ratification of the North German Lloyd's composition with American creditors.

IN the past four years it became rather fashionable to shrug condescendingly whenever our unsophisticated predepression habits were mentioned. The optimism of our more prosperous days was interpreted as mere ignorance. Our appreciation of, and our willingness to work for, the possession of certain civilized comforts were evaluated as materialism, and many professional prophets went so far as to predict that the future path of our people would lead toward a sober paradise of frugality.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4. -- These are "Jacksonian days" with a vengeance in Pittsburgh. Inaugurated on Jan. 1 as the city's first Democratic Mayor in a quarter of a century, William N. McNair is redeeming his pledge to meet the people freely in the lobby of the City-County Building as one of them.

A sale of collateral by the Railroad Credit Corporation is disclosed for the first time in the report of its condition on Dec. 31, filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. The report shows that the corporation realized $558,006 from collateral, but whether this represented called loans was not disclosed.
FORTY years' experience in manufacturing vehicles has convinced me that this country is a good, sound place in which to work and progress. It welcomes theory, but it is founded on hard facts.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 3. -- The New Deal will cost Puerto Rico $21,000,000 the first year. This is an estimate which includes approximately $3,000,000 in various processing taxes and $18,000,000 in increased costs of commodities imported from the United States, the source last year of 95 per cent of the island's purchases.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP). -- A 21-year-old Brooklyn youth, Harry C. Bull, awaiting execution in Boston Feb. 4 for the murder of a Greenfield (Mass.) policeman, has enlisted the sympathy of Senator Copeland, chairman of the special committee investigating crime, and of Colonel Franklin S. Hutchinson, its chief investigator.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- J.M. Nichols, president of the First National Bank of Englewood, a Chicago subdivision stood firm today in his refusal to pay his bank's $10,500 premium into the Federal deposit insurance fund until he is officially informed what action will be taken in case of a failure to pay.

BARCELONA, Dec. 22. -- The stringent measures just announced by the authorities of the Balearic Islands governing the residence of strangers are inspired, on their face, by certain difficulties that have arisen in dealing with these temporary guests, among whom Americans, English, German and French predominate, and probably in the order named.

AMERICA'S economic trend appears to he definitely and unmistakably upward. Viewed from almost any angle, the business outlook for 1934 affords promise. Statistical symptoms of recovery are legion. Naturally there have been expressions of disapproval from various groups which expected a miracle instead of a cure for their difficulties.

IN celebration of its tenth anniversary the publishing house of W.W. Norton Co. has just issued a catalogue, designed by T.M. Cleland and printed under his supervision, which, in addition to the announcements of forthcoming books, lists those already published that have best fulfilled the prediction implied in the firm's slogan: "Books That Live."

WHILE the percentage of women drivers is steadily increasing, more than 75 per cent of the women in the car-owning group are members of the "backseat club," according to information obtained by Oldsmobile from various State motor vehicle officials who made a check of the driving licenses which they have issued.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 6. -Army defeated Johns Hopkins, 46 to 28, at basketball today in the Cadets' opening game. Army tallied all its points on field goals, making a total of twenty-three and thereby establishing a freak record for the West Point court.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- R. George Harvey, special investigator for the Department of Justice, said tonight that Mrs. Samuel O. Hobart of Troy had been arrested on a charge of sending a box of poisoned candy to her brother, Harrington Fitzgerald Jr., a patient in the Veterans' Hospital at Coatesville.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 6. -- Greyflight and Sir Gilbert, two of the most famous show jumpers of the East, fought a notable duel over the jumps at the annual New Year indoor horse show of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club today.
THERE is increasing demand by motorists for safety glass all around in their cars, instead of only in the windshield and ventilators. Yet few are acquainted with the way this glass is made.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 6. -- R.H. Helsel broke 50 straight targets to win the high scratch cup at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Eight gunners tied for the handicap honors. In the first shoot-off, E. Kohler, T.B. Pettit Jr., T.C. Webb and R. Marino again deadlocked.
LONDON, Jan. 6. -- Sir Stafford Cripps today made a reference to the King which aroused widespread indignant protest, even from his Socialist colleagues.

CHICAGO. PUBLISHING of the final report and recommendations of Dr. Miller McClintock, director of the Albert Russel Erskine Bureau at Harvard University, was an outstanding event in the field of highway and traffic development in the Chicago area in 1933.

Norman H. Davis, Ambassador-at-Large of the United States, has been appointed head of an international committee to compromise the conflicting claims of the companies of the late Ivar Kreuger and to make recommendations for a readjustment in order to protect and conserve the assets of these companies.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- The conviction that the peace of Europe depends on the settlement of the Franco-German arms controversy was brought back tonight from conferences with Continental statesmen by Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary.
