WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Earle Bailie of New York, who joined the Treasury forces a short time ago as special assistant to Mr. Morgenthau, then Acting Secretary, has submitted his resignation to take effect some time this month, as shown in correspondence between himself and Secretary Morgenthau, made public this afternoon.

DURING the year which has just drawn to a close the Legislatures of the various States throughout the country have enacted few laws in connection with automobile insurance coverage. Taking it by and large, that has been a good thing for the companies writing this form of coverage and the motorists who protect themselves from the serious consequences of accidents by buying adequate insurance.

QUEBEC. -- With abandoned events such as the international dog derby and the ice canoe race brought back to life, Winter sports again promise to play a leading role in Quebec's social life this Winter, and already heavy bookings of Americans are reported by the hotels.

The household staffs of many fashionable residences in this city and on country estates will make merry Friday night at the Butlers' Ball, an event backed by a certain London tradition, which is to be held at the Commodore for the benefit of the family welfare social service of Bellevue Hospital.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 12. -- The beneficent educational activities of "Yali," or Yale-in-China, disrupted by the Nationalist anti-foreign campaign in 1927 and by the Commu- nists in 1930, are again gathering momentum, according to word received from Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province, where the work is centred.

PEIPING, Dec. 12. -- One of the largest religious groups in China, the Mohammedans, have for some years played a relatively unimportant role in Chinese affairs. Events of recent months indicate, however, that they are still to be reckoned with as a political and military factor and may regain some of their lost power.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 6. -- Tommy Armour, the veteran Scot from Chicago, contributed another sub-par round, a 67, today to take the lead at the half-way mark in the seventy-two-hole competition for the Miami open championship at the Miami Springs Golf Club.

The Rockaway Steeplechase Association, affiliated with the Rockaway Hunt Club, but which has not run a race meeting in more than thirty years, is to be revived, according to an announcement yesterday by John E. Cowdin, secretary of the Jockey Club, who will be president of the reorganized association.

MOTORISTS themselves are the limiting factor in the development of automotive design. We have come a long way, but the evolution of the automobile has required more than a quarter of a century, with engineering and inventive genius always restrained by the conservative buying habits of the motoring public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Still unable to fill demands for liquor, distillers were urged today by Dr. James M. Doran, supervisor of the Distilled Spirits Institute, to concentrate on the manufacture of cheap whisky.
Elimination of the impression that mail contracts are the basis of subsidies to American merchant shipping is recommended by the Shipping Board in its annual report on the fiscal year 1932-33.

Tales of the "sea monster" of Loch Ness, Scotland, reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES, so closely parallel accounts of a similar visitation along our own shores in 1851 that the comparison of descriptions of the beasts indicate how conscientiously history repeats itself.
SAN FRANCISCO. WITH a good portion of the State's 139,680 motor vehicles in operation in the Bay Region, traffic chiefs of San Francisco and Oakland have a good-sized problem on their hands.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP). -- Harry Hopkins separated Governor Talmadge, whom he has accused of "headline hunting" and "yapping," from all authority and association with the Civil Works and Relief Administrations in Georgia today.

A new rule governing the registration of kennel names with the American Kennel Club will be offered for the consideration of the delegates at their annual meeting in this city in February. If accepted it will become effective on March 1.

An encouraging subscription is reported for the performance of "Manon" Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Florence Crittenton League. The league was established as a refuge and shelter for underprivileged and unfortunate young women, runaway girls, young witnesses or first offenders awaiting trial.

THIS is indeed the story of a great and thrilling adventure, even if it was adventure chained to a wheel-chair; adventure glowing, dauntless, that asked and received no handicap, but finally achieved its goal. Many thousands of readers and movie-goers know the name of the author, J. Breckenridge Ellis, who here tells his life story.

THE most difficult thing the automotive engineer faces is the fact that everything he does has to be proven twice. Every new idea he has must go through the most searching tests to prove itself before it goes into a car.

DOES Congress represent the people? At this writing the answer undoubtedly is, Yes. It is probably the first time since the World War when such an answer could have been made without qualification; and as to the Seventy-third Congress, perhaps modification will yet have to be entered before this and another new year have run their course.

AT the New York zoo they tell of a farmer from Port Jervis who visited the place for the first time and spent two days seeing the animals. What amazed him most, he said, was "to think that an animal as large as an elephant could be interested in anything as small as a peanut."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP). -- Administration spokesmen explained today that a twofold purpose lay back of the plan of the government to guarantee both the principal and interest of $4,000,000,000 farm and home loan bonds.

Two letters in THE TIMES, although on subjects far apart, nevertheless provide an interesting contrast of citizens' views concerning the national honor. One expresses the hope that the United States Supreme Court will permit Monaco to bring suit to recover an ancient debt against the State of Mississippi which that State has repudiated.

Retail trade in most sections of the United States last week exceeded all expectations. The first week of the new year found stores filled with customers seeking post-holiday bargains, but most merchants have deferred special sales because of the depletion of stocks and pending the filling of heavy restocking orders.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP). -- The liner Washington sideswiped the Nantucket Shoals lightship today in a thick fog forty-two miles southeast of the Island of Nantucket. The Nantucket was damaged, but remained afloat. No one was injured.

Railroads have lost traffic to motor truck and air transport lines rather than to inland waterways, according to Donald T. Wright, editor of The Waterways Journal. In an article replying to charges that the Federal barge lines expend $7,900 to move a ton of freight and that this government-owned service is unfair competition with the rail lines, Mr. Wright says:
MIAMI. -- The sixth annual all-American air races, to be held at Miami's Municipal Airport on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, will include many striking events.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- More than 500 men and women, including specialists in medicine, sociology, religion and education, will attend the American Conference on Birth Control and National Recovery to be held here Jan. 15-17 under the auspices of the National Committee on Federal Legislation for Birth Control, of which Mrs. Margaret Sanger is president.

THE type of independent front springing available as optional equipment on Terraplanes and Hudsons for 1934, as described by company engineers, permits the wheels to rise and fall, and the front springs to act independently, in a vertical plane.

The market was fully steady in New York on Saturday, with extras and higher grades advancing 1/4c, extras reaching 18 1/2c. The scarcity of offerings of undergrades resulted in 3/4c advance on 90 score, one sale being made under the call at 18 1/2c, and extras 91 score and 90 score are today all quoted at 18 1/2c.

CALCUTTA, Jan. 6 (Canadian Press). -- England compiled a score of 403 for the first innings of the second test cricket match with India today and when stumps were drawn the Indians had lost four wickets for 90 runs.

THE story of "Salome's" single performance at the Metropolitan, of the sensational crowds that attended, of the Opera board's abrupt decision to bar any further appearances at the Metropolitan on the grounds of decency and shocked sensibilities, has now passed into operatic history, being elsewhere reviewed in these pages.
PAYING tribute to the newspapers for their share in the development of the automobile business, William A. James, advertising manager of the Hudson Motor Car Company, said:

PROVIDENCE, Jan. 6. -- After twenty-one years as director of the Government Bureau of Forestry Pathology at Brown University, Professor James F. Collins retired this week at the age of 70 with a long record of service to science.

WHILE I am not given to prophecy, I believe the facts amply justify looking to 1934 with renewed confidence, renewed hope and the conviction that the progressive individual or company has in prospect a considerably better year than either of the past two.

The committee which will name the outstanding college lacrosse players of the country for the All-America team to meet Canada this Spring in the annual series, was selected last night by the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association.

With the formal dispatch of official invitations to fifty-three countries, Germany has commenced preparations for the 1936 Olympic Games at Berlin and is ready' "to welcome the youth of the world with Olympic hospitality.

THIS novel is another of the "chronicle" narratives which have become so popular of late years. Not of the dimension of "The Forsyte Saga" or Hugh Walpole's canvas of the Herries family, a deal of family history is nevertheless conveyed by the nearly six hundred pages of this book, the scene of which is a section of England hitherto not greatly exploited by novelists, namely, the Suffolk coast.

Mrs. Malkus writes with increasing power. "Stone Knife Boy" is a tale of the present day, but into it she has managed to put the Indians' sense of the past, the feeling for tradition and the dignity that must be accepted as a part of Indian character, if Indians and white men are to understand one another.

THE swastika of the German Nazis has invaded many countries of Continental Europe. In some of them it may be considered a serious menace to the established government; in others it has only a nuisance value. In some the Nazis are allowed to propagate their ideas; in others they are suppressed and can work only underground.

However disquieting the ten-billion-dollar budget message of President Roosevelt may have been, no serious doubt seems to have been raised in Wall Street as to the capacity of the credit structure to meet the government's requirements. There may be grave misgivings as to the ultimate effect of the prodigious expenditures that are contemplated, but so far as the immediate problem of financing is concerned there is little apprehension.

Except for a flurry of activity in cotton, which was sensitive to special influences, the speculative markets failed yesterday to arouse any wide interest, and Wall Street counted it as rather a wasted day. Securities marked time and there were fractional gains in the principal breadstuffs.

The other night a group of musicians were discussing tours, concert managers and programs. One of them said the average concert manager greatly underestimated the public's capacity for enjoying solid programs of good music, especially when booking artists for the Middle West and West. The others agreed.
AFTER more than sixty busy years, Art Young is having his first one-man show, simultaneously vith the publication of his book, "Inferno." Both events are sponsored by the Delphic Studios.

Mrs. Richard Samuel Reynolds and members of the group of women aiding in the arrangements for the performance of "Die Meistersinger yon Nurnberg" on the afternoon of Jan. 18 in behalf of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance, will give a reception Tuesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Reynolds, 120 East End Avenue.

THE motorist who is still driving a car that dates back a few years can have no conception of what the 1934 cars have to offer him until he has actually driven or ridden in them. This is true of performance and convenience and most especially of comfort, which takes on a new meaning.

A sharp upturn in the trend toward electrification of the American home will open a $5,000,000,000 market for electrical appliances in the United States this year, according to the electrical merchandising joint committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which made public yesterday the results of a study just completed.
APPROXIMATELY 363,000 motor trucks were produced by American manufacturers last year, as compared with the 237,500 output of 1932. This marks the first increase for a twelve-month period since 1929.

The London dispatch announcing that the Sinaitic manuscript Bible had been purchased from the Soviet Government by Great Britain is most welcome news. The attitude of the Russian Communists toward religion and religious publications led many to believe that it had been destroyed.

Billy Hogan, promising welterweight from Orangeburge ,N.Y. added Frankie Petrolle. Fargo, N.D., to his list of vanquished rivals by gaining the decision last night in their six-round bout at the Ridgewood Grove.

The tonal splendors and the emotional abandon of the second act of "Tristan and Isolde," performed yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, have made this passage, for the great public, the essence, if not the climax, of the opera. But each of the three acts is a masterpiece of a specially, and of a magnificent inner power and symmetry.

BUENOS AIRES, Sunday, Jan. 7. -- The League of Nations Chaco commission remained in session until midnight last night and revealed that last-minute suggestions for prolongation of the truce had been sent to President Ayala of Paraguay and President Salamanca of Bolivia.

ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON, who dearly loved a romantic tale, and who defined romance as the poetry of circumstance, would have delighted in Harold Lamb's "Kirdy." In this swiftly moving story events and characters are seen against a background that has the glamour of the picturesque and the unfamiliar.
The University of Toronto's hockey team scored its second New York victory of the week by defeating the Harvard sextet at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Thirty-one officers and enlisted men have been designated to make the Navy's formation flight with Patrol Squadron 10-F from San Francisco to Honolulu scheduled for next Friday.

Among other allotments made last week by the Public Works Administration was one of $25,000,000 for the purpose of withdrawing "submarginal" farm land from cultivation. This marks a new policy by the Government. The Administration is said to have under consideration a plan calling ultimately for the retirement of some 50,000,000 acres, at a total cost of $350,000,000.

A unified public banking structure under the control of the Federal Government was urged last night by Professor A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain and a member of President Roosevelt's "brain trust," in a radio address over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

A NEW deal for New York's leisure and pleasure has been proposed by Mayor LaGuardia, who would have the city create artistic beer gardens on the banks of the Harlem River and on other sites in various boroughs. Recently he said that he had in mind beer gardens and cafes of the Viennese type, "based on a liberal, constructive and intelligent attitude."

ANOTHER year passes. The automotive industry is grateful for the increased patronage received during the year as measured by a relatively important increase in its volume. It is thankful to have been able, for that reason, to have increased its payrolls through added employment and to have made it possible for others to do likewise through its greater purchases of materials, thus in degree helping all.

THE automobile easily ranks first in the interest of the average man and woman. This is evidenced by the eager interest shown in the new features of the 1934 cars. Not within my memory has there been an automobile show comparing with the one now in progress at the Grand Central Palace.

LOS ANGELES. ONE of the major traffic problems confronting Los Angeles is better protection for pedestrians. This is being given serious consideration at the present time, according to E.B. Lefferts, head of the public safety department of the Automobile Club of Southern California.

F.M. Law, president of the American Bankers Association, declared in a statement here yesterday that a "misconception unfortunately has arisen" regarding the so-called service charges proposed to be enacted under the bankers' NRA code.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6 (AP). -- In a driving rainstorm, J.D. Rolland's Malimou got up in the final strides today to win the Martin Behrman Memorial Purse from nine other platers at Jefferson Park.

When the hammer fell on the final bid at the auction of the art collection, personal effects and house furnishings of the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., as large a crowd packed the auction room as heard the opening bid last Tuesday afternoon.

LONDON, Dec. 20. FRAULEIN ELISABETH BERGNER had high repute in her own country as a play actress, but in England she has until recently been known only as an actress for the screen. I saw her in a German film, "Traumonde Mund," and, though the film itself was of little consequence, I was greatly impressed by her performance.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Jan. 7. -- The headquarters of General Chiang Kai-shek announced today that the Nanking nationalist forces had captured Yenping and Kuitien in Fukien Province from the rebels. Thus, it was said, the way was opened for an advance on Foochow, the provincial capital, which is only eighty-five miles distant.
THE future of the automobile industry rests with the young men of America. The cars of tomorrow will be built by the young engineers of today.

WHEN Charlie Robinson and I set out to knit up our nautical ditty, "Sailor, Beware!" it seemed to us that the background for such a godless yarn should be the Canal Zone. There our navy men came into the most vivid and concentrated contact with their feminine relaxation.

WASHINGTON Jan. 6. -- Collective bargaining in industry through the employe representation or company union plan has demonstrated its value as an instrumentality for eliminating conflict in industry, according to a report by Walter C. Teagle, chairman of the industrial relations committee of the Business Advisory and Planning Council.

Although yesterday's contributions for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases were the smallest of any day's this Winter, they carried the total across another thousand dollar line to $228,014.02. The fund now is $37 385.51 short of last year's total, $265,399.53, which provided for 428 cases.

Still hesitant and reflecting an almost total lack of public interest, the share market yesterday ended an eventful week in low speed. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was only 461,920 shares, the smallest since Dec. 2. There was an irregular opening, followed by indolent backing and filling, with no net progress shown at the close.

Winter sports enthusiasts will journey lo Palisades Interstate Park this afternoon to see the annual in Interstate ski jumping tournament, which will be staged by the Bear Mountain Winter Sports Association at 2 o'clock.
W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, predicted yesterday a break in the ranks of those seeking to re-elect Fred W. Hammond Clerk of the Assembly when that body reconvenes tomorrow night.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5. -- For the past five years the Soviet Union has been struggling with its railroads in an attempt to "solve problems of trade and transportation." Only during the past two years have the Russians realized fully the importance of river transportation for long hauls of non-perishable goods, which make up the bulk of the freight within the country.

MONTREAL. -- It is confidently expected by Montrealers that there will be a continuation of the excellent conditions which this season have provided unusual facilities for the enjoyment of Winter sports here. Predictions are made that during this month and next there will be rounded out a record Winter, as Montreal so far has had the best weather in many years for outdoor Winter pastimes.

AS might be expected with one who takes the gramophone seriously, Joseph Szigeti's records are made and released with great care and consideration. He is not one of those who elect to adopt an offhand attitude toward their disks, pretending not to know exactly what they have done or where and why they have done it.

AN auspicious start for the new year featured retail trade both here and out-of-town. Increases ranging from 15 to 30 per cent were achieved by most leading stores here on every day of the week, with the exception of Friday when the rain restricted shopping.
PARIS, Jan. 4. -- Elegantes at St. Moritz change from ski costumes to wool pajamas during that hour of relaxation that comes between the mountain sports and dinner.

With the arrival here of many buyers representing stores all over the country, Spring buying operations will gain marked headway here this week. The view is steadily gaining ground in retail circles that pre-Easter trade will run some 15 per cent ahead of the same period in 1933, and this confidence is reflected in correspondingly increased buying budgets for the new season.

ALVA LEE'S book is very largely concerned with inflation -- that is, "inflation" as he sees it, and it looms before his eyes big, mistaken and menacing. There is little in current economic phenomena of which he disapproves that does not seem to him to have some connection with inflation, to be part and parcel of that process.

A definite note of optimism at the economic outlook for 1934 is struck by Canadian Government officials and leading business men in a commercial and financial review for 1933 published by The Montreal Gazette. Improvement along various lines in 1933 is noted by the officials and others, whose articles were written especially for The Gazette.

A.O. Christensen discussed "Balanced Costs and Wages" in a letter to THE TIMES. It might be of interest to note that this article involves the concept of the "labor dollar" -- in other words, a dollar which will always buy the same number of "mean labor hours."

Alexander Troyanovsky, the first Russian Ambassador to the United States since diplomatic relations between the two countries ceased sixteen years ago, will arrive this morning on the United States liner Washington.

PITTSBURGH, Jan 7. -- The weekly report of steel ingot production for last week was awaited with special interest and proved to be reassuring, production being forecast at 29.3 per cent of capacity, against 31.6 per cent forecast for the previous week.

The friends of communism in the United States are the reactionaries, said the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in the Riverside Church yesterday. While dreading the thought of collectivism, he felt that to turn back the clock and refuse the New Deal would be to force the adoption of fascism or communism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Senator Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan, in an interview tonight praised President Roosevelt's frankness in his budget message, but suggested that he carry that straightforwardness still further and give Congress in "intimate detail" the breakdown of all emergency expenditures.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, today criticized the administration program which would increase the public debt. Speaking before the Chicago Forum, he approved a vast public works program but would finance it through issuance of non-interest-bearing Treasury notes.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 7. -- In honor of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton, who are spending the season at Brazilian Court, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Kroger entertained today with a large tea at their home on Brazilian Avenue. Assisting were Mrs. Harry Oakes, Mrs. Gretchen Kroger Barnes, Mrs. John Eugene Dana and Mrs. Alfred D. Bell.

Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel for the Transit Commission, has served notice upon Mayor LaGuardia that he will oppose any plan for rapid transit unification which is not squarely predicated upon maintenance of the 5-cent fare.

With both a first appearance of Mr. Toscanini and the start of a Beethoven cycle impending at mid-season, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra played in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon a program heard on the air throughout the nation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7 (AP). -- A group of Yale faculty members and students issued a statement tonight criticizing City Court Judge Raymond J. Devlin and City Attorney Nelson Durant for their conduct during the trial of Yale students and others arrested in the molders' strike here recently.

The recurring commemorative exercises at Columbia University in tribute to those of her faculties who died during the year again bring us face to face with the mysteries of life and death. The address was made yesterday by HOWARD LEE MCBAIN, dean of the graduate faculties, who holds that it is not "intellectually disreputable" to contemplate the age-old subject of immortality.
Small housing properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported over the week-end.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 7. -- The League of Nations Chaco Commission abandoned its peace efforts today and began the preparation of a report to the League.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Only 448 national banks in the United States remained unlicensed at the close of business Dec. 30, the Controller of the Currency, J.F.T. O'Connor, reported today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 7. -- A new mechanical nose, named the osmoscope, made to smell impurities in drinking water, is announced at Harvard University. The osmoscope is a smell meter, attaching to the nose.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 7 (AP). -- A decision upholding an intrastate freight rate structure applying to shipments of bituminous coal, as set up by the Interstate Commerce Commission, was announced here today after it was found among the papers of a dead Federal jurist.

Contrary to the belief expressed by Willis J. Rutledge in a letter to THE TIMES, England is not "sedulously imitating the New Deal policy." Long before the present administration came into power at Washington the British Government had completed plans for the regulation of the milk industry.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Two high officials of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and a former Cleveland bank president will go on trial here tomorrow charged with misapplying $450,000 of the funds of the Standard Trust Bank and with making false entries in the bank's records.

There will be two openings in the Broadway playhouses this evening. "Days Without End" will have its premiere at Henry Miller's Theatre. and Vittorio Podrecca's company of life-sized puppets called "The Piccoli" will begin a return engagement at the Hudson Theatre.

Paul Whiteman and his jazz orchestra were the participating artists yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in a concert which established a precedent and marked an anniversary at the same time.

A lively controversy has been going on for some weeks as to the sources of Hervey Allen's "Anthony Adverse," the historical novel that was last year's best seller. Some critics have remarked that Mr. Allen drew from source books perhaps too much detail, which he used for the significant facts that make local color.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- The Bank of England's position is rapidly improving again, now that the year-end monetary pressure and currency demands are abated. Note circulation is falling sharply and the reserve is rising with an equal rapidity, but a few weeks must elapse before the position will return to normal.

Play in the women's national squash racquets championship tournament will get under way this morning on the courts of the Junior League and the Cosmopolitan Club. The intercity team matches also will start today.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP). -- A British government project for the sterilization of mental defectives is expected to be presented to Parliament within ten days. A government committee has completed a report on the subject after long study but its recommendations are being closely guarded.

Pity the sorrows of Tammany and its associated powers of righteousness. The Democrats in the Board of Aldermen utter their pain and wrath at President DEUTSCH'S New Year greeting to it as "an assemblage of district messenger boys." Messengers they are, in the sense that in the people's employ they bear the people's messages and commissions.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee announced yesterday through James G. Blaine, its chairman, the appropriation of $1,200,000 of its funds to carry on the extraordinary activities of the fourteen family welfare agencies for which the committee's relief fund was raised.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Temperance forces have sustained a serious defeat by repeal of prohibition, but have not been destroyed, Bishop Ernest G. Richardson of Philadelphia, president of the Anti-Saloon League of America, declared today in opening the league's twenty-seventh annual convention.

A requiem mass will be said this morning at 9 o'clock in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at Sixty-sixth Street, for Miss Evelyn Frost, who was killed in an airplane accident at Nevers, France, on Friday. The mass will be as nearly as possible coincident with the funeral at Nevers, allowing for the difference in time between the two countries.

Several years ago I became interested in philosophical studies and attended meetings of a local society of that character, listening patiently to many learned papers, but was unable to make out what the authors were talking about. Thereupon I plunged into a course of reading, wading out deeper and deeper into the mire of philosophic thought.
The lines of battle over the LaGuardia economy bill were clearly drawn yesterday when the Mayor sent to Albany a reply to Governor Lehman's criticism of the measure as "dictatorship."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 7. -- Roy Manny sailed his Tara to first place in the point standing among Class A dinghies in the special Frostbite regatta staged by the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Bill Inslee steered the Husky to first place among the Class B boats.

Maxim Gorky's latest play, "Yegor Bulevitch," was presented in a Yiddish version by L. Feinberg by the Artef Theatre at the Heckscher Auditorium, 104th Street and Fifth Avenue, on Saturday night. This is the first of a projected trilogy which aims to portray the changing social scene in Russia from pre- to post-revolutionary days.

Deliberate violators of the labor provisions of the retail code will henceforth be reported to Washington, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the local Retail Code Authority, announced yesterday. Several cases are being prepared for such official action.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1933, as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Securities issues totaling $35,000,000 are proposed in registration statements under the Securities Act made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

The United States liner Washington, docking a day late as the result of continuous storms at sea, reported a near accident on Saturday night off the Nantucket Shoals. It was said on the ship that the Washington, groping in the dense fog that extended along the coast, scraped the side of the Nantucket Lightship, narrowly avoiding a crash.

In a letter to Mayor LaGuardia, which was made public yesterday, Assemblyman Laurens M. Hamilton, Republican, of Rockland County, declared that the Mayor could count on his support in the Assembly for all measures the Fusion administration in New York City might deem "proper and necessary."

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- The rival Republican groups in the Assembly will renew their struggle tomorrow night to elect a Clerk of the lower house of the Legislature. Neither side today gave any indication of yielding.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Alexander A. Troyanovsky, first Ambassador to the United States of the new regime in Russia, arrived this afternoon from Moscow and is "in residence" at the home of Boris Skvirsky, former Charge d'Affaires and now Counselor of the reconstituted Russian Embassy.

Hidden away on the upper floor of a loft building at the shipyard of the Herreshoff Manufacturing Company in Bristol, R.I., is the 5-foot model of the America's Cup yacht to be built for the syndicate headed by Harold S. Vanderbilt and the international match next September.

DETROIT, Jan. 7 (AP). -- The Rev. Father Charles E. Coughlin said in a speech today that Congress must determine within the next 150 days whether the control of gold shall remain in the hands of private bankers or be returned to "120,000,000 inarticulate American taxpayers."

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- Bill Cook's goal early in the third period tonight gave the New York Rangers a 1 to 1 tie with the Chicago Black Hawks in a rough overtime National League hockey match before 16,000 fans.

BERLIN, Jan. 7. -- The police swooped down on 1,000 Sunday school boys here today, broke up their procession and arrested their leaders as the mailed fist of the State came to the defense of Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller and his Nazi church regime.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The text of the American Federation of Labor's report for the year on employment follows:

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- The victim of a "one-way ride" returned alive today to confront his kidnappers and relate to police an astounding tale of being shot three times and of escaping with his life only because he dived into the Little Calumet River and feigned death.

The primary purpose of the church in all religions since the beginning of history has been worship, the Rev. Dr. John J. Moment, pastor of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church of Plainfield, N.J., declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

Postmaster General FARLEY has dropped remarks, in the intervals of his arduous political duties, leading the public to suppose that the postal service was going to pay for itself. But in his annual report today he incidentally reveals the fact that the "gross deficiency of revenues" for the year was $112,374,892.

PARIS, Jan. 7. -- Premier Camille Chautemps may present the resignation of the Cabinet to President Albert Lebrun tomorrow following the revelation of imprudence on the part of Albert Dalimier, Minister of Colonies, in connection with the Bayonne municipal pawnshop scandal.
The International League, by a vote of 7 to 1, decided yesterday at its annual Winter meeting in the Hotel New Yorker, to retain for another year the play-off system which it adopted for last season.

Following the sale on the first day of the year of the old Hotel Grenoble site on the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street, representing more than $1,000,000 with the additional deal on the last day of the week of the sixteen-story apartment house at 440 West Thirty-fourth Street, also in the $1,000,000 class, the first week of 1934 showed an excellent demand for New York City real estate.
A brilliant scoring performance by Rabbit McVeigh enabled the New York Americans to defeat the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night.

New public financing in the United States in 1933, bonds, notes and stocks, excluding domestic and Canadian municipals, aggregated only $207,788,000, according to a compilation announced yesterday by Otto P. Schwarzchild, editor of American Underwriting Houses and Their Issues.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- Unfavorable weather, with snow and low temperatures throughout a large part of the leading livestock districts, checked the shipment of animals of market last week, while the buying of hogs and cattle by the government for its relief movements absorbed surplus offerings and the combination strengthened prices.

The Columbia football team, victors on New Year's Day over Stanford at the Pasadena Rose Bowl, returned to New York and Morningside Heights last night. They were met at the Pennsylvania Station by Mayor LaGuardia and committees representing both the city and the university.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 7.-- While trading in the cotton-contract market here revived last week and had active periods, the volume of business was restricted by the New Year holiday at the beginning of the week and a desire of operators to hold off until Congress got down to work.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 7. -- The City Commission at its conference tomorrow is expected to consider a plan for the appointment of an expert committee to revalue all property in the city for tax purposes. The plan will be submitted by Reginald Parnell, Director of Revenue and Finance, acting on a report to him in November by a committee of citizens which he appointed to study the tax situation here.
The resignation of Grover A. Whalen as local NRA Administrator and as general manager of John Wanamaker of New York became known yesterday.

MANILA, P.I., Jan. 7 (AP). -- A Filipino youth movement, complete with a Fascist salute, was launched here tonight under the sponsorship of Manuel Roxas, former Speaker of the House. The movement has the avowed aim of fostering clean government in preparation for independence.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- Business in virtually all lines in this district is regarded as having made a most favorable start for the new year. The activity that ended 1933 is being carried over, and there is a desire in both trade and industry to push ahead.

PUERTO RICO, Jan. 7. -- Benjamin J. Horton, Attorney General and Acting Governor, was endorsed today for Governor by the executive committee of the Democratic party in Puerto Rico in a message to President Roosevelt. This action was the result of a definite conviction that Governor Robert M. Gore, now in the United States for medical treatment, will not return.
Following is the text of Mayor LaGuardia's letter to Governor Lehman, replying to criticism of the powers sought to reorganize the city government:

With a determined pull at the brim of his gray fedora and a squaring of his massive shoulders and strong jaw, Lou Little set himself for the ordeal that awaited above in the crowd as the Columbia Special pulled into the Pennsylvania Station last night at the end of a 3,000-mile trip across the continent.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 7. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926 is 72, which compares with 71.8 a week before, 71.4 two weeks before, 72 three weeks before and 71.7 four weeks before. The average of Oct. 15, at 72.2, was the highest of 1933; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

BERLIN, Jan. 7. -- The first regular transatlantic air line in history will become a reality about Feb. 1 when the Lufthansa begins an air mail service from Germany to South America. It will be assured by a combination of land and seaplanes that will cover the distance in five days.

Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein scored police raids on card games that resulted only in the arrests of players in Night Court last night, berate freeing thirty-three Chinese seized in a raid during the afternoon on a game at 65 Mort Street.
" Before Midnight," with Ralph Bellamy and June Collyer, will open at the Mayfair this evening at 6 o'clock, succeeding "Smoky."

Members of the musicians union organized under an emergency council of seven will meet again this morning in Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street, "to force a show-down" with the officials of the Associated Musicians of Greater New York on what was characterized yesterday as "a reorganization of the entire amusement industry" in the city.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Jan. 3 at 63.9. This compares with 63.6 on Dec. 13 last and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before Great Britain's suspension of gold payments.

Political economy has long been known as the dismal science and this is doubtless the reason why our legislators avoided the study of that science in their college days. It is evident that they preferred the alluring pages of "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland," if we may judge by legislative methods and governmental edicts recently issued.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 7. -- The Turkish Cabinet definitely approved tonight the new Five-Year Plan to industrialize formerly agricultural Turkey.

The sharp and, in our opinion, needless controversy between Governor LEHMAN and Mayor LAGUARDIA is unfortunate for both of them and for the city. In his letter replying to the Governor, Mr. LAGUARDIA renews his suggestion of a "conference on the sub"ject at any time or place which suits "your convenience."

SHANGHAI, Jan. 7. -- Swift advance of the government army against the rebel forces in Fukien Province, announced yesterday from Nanking, is confirmed today by telegrams from private sources in Hongkong.

An increase of 6.5 per cent in freight car loadings in the first three months of 1934 compared with the same period in 1933 is forecast in estimates compiled by the thirteen Shippers Regional Advisory Boards. The increase for the Atlantic States was estimated at 11.5 per cent.

Establishment of a municipal consultant service by the National Municipal League to assist local governments in financial difficulties to restore their credit was announced last night by Howard P. Jones, secretary of the league. He said the service was being undertaken in response to many requests for assistance from local governments in distress.
ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- The New York and New Jersey Milk Control Boards have prepared a joint plan for stabilizing the New York milk shed, which will be presented at a public hearing here tomorrow.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7. -- Pick's disease, a brain malady that takes from the patient the ready use of his memory, rather than the memory itself, has been reported by two Yale professors.

LONDON, Jan. 7. -- In an editorial highly sympathetic toward President Roosevelt, The London Times points out that although critics of the United States budget hold it a gigantic gamble, it is "a gamble which a majority of the nation appears ready to undertake with equanimity, even confidence."

Passers-by hurled themselves into doorways or dropped to the sidewalk in Seventh Avenue between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday shortly morning as gunmen in a swiftly moving taxicab opened fire on two men standing near the Knickerbocker Bar.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 7. -- Sharp Thoughts, Alexander Pantages's speedy 5-year-old gelding, outfooted a smart field of eight other sprinters in the six-furlong feature today. Under a hustling ride by Johnny Maiben, the winner was timed in 1:12 4-5 despite the slow track.

Commodity prices moved irregularly in trading on local exchanges last week. Coffee, cocoa, copper and hides closed with gains, while silver, sugar and rubber showed small losses. Trading was slightly improved in volume.

Ben Kramer of the Long Island University basketball team displaced his team-mate, William Schwartz, as leader in the Metropolitan individual scoring race by scoring 36 points in the past week. The undefeated Long Island five has run its winning streak to twelve games.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Sir Stafford Cripps, aspirant to Labor party leadership, undertook today to reply to a storm of criticism raised against a speech he delivered at Nottingham yesterday, in which he referred to Buckingham Palace. Sir Stafford said he did not mean to refer to King George at all, but only those who advised His Majesty.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 7. -- Nicolas Titulescu, who for more than three years has been Rumania's Cabinet maker, has become the actual controller of Rumania's government. Despite his "final" farewell to the Foreign Office last Friday, it is announced tonight that he has resumed the Foreign portfolio.

Scientific discoveries in recent years "have unquestionably made vast inroads upon man's traditional beliefs in immortality," Dr. Howard Lee McBain, dean of the graduate faculties of Columbia University, declared yesterday morning at the annual university commemoration service at St. Paul's Chapel.

John O'Dwyer, a brother of Magistrate William F. O'Dwyer of Brooklyn, was shot in the abdomen and in the left thigh shortly before 7 A.M. yesterday when one of his breakfast companions in the Terminal Bar and Grill, 55 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, Detective William Donnell of Butler Street station, exchanged shots with three hold-up men.

BERLIN, Jan. 7. -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller's attempt to dragoon the Protestant churches of Germany was met with open defiance today by the 6,000 pastors embattled in the Pastors' Emergency Federation, which the Reich Bishop's dictatorial edict yesterday aimed to smother.

The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of a branch of the Girls Friendly Society at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church was celebrated yesterday afternoon with special services at the church, Stuyvesant Square and Sixteenth Street. The society is a social and welfare organization for girls and women under the auspices of the Episcopal Church.

The Sleepy Hollow Country Club and Apawamis Club teams yesterday won matches to finish first in Groups 1 and 2, respectively, in the Westchester division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League Class B competition. They finished their respective group schedules with three triumphs apiece.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 7. -- Two little girls lost their lives and two other persons were badly burned today when a small bungalow in Lawrence, a suburb of Trenton, was burned to the ground after the mother of the children, mistaking gasoline for kerosene, had used the liquid to revive a fire.

Brooklyn civic interests asked Mayor LaGuardia yesterday to prevent the transfer of the North German Lloyd Line's docking operations from the Army Basin pier in Brooklyn to the North River. In letters to the Mayor and to John McKenzie, Dock Commissioner, the Bay Ridge Civic Council charged that the transfer was possible only by false interpretation of the terms of a docking contract.

Soviet Russia's first Ambassador to the United States, Alexander Troyanovsky, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington, accompanied by William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, and members of his staff.

Z.G. Simmons carried off the high scratch honors for the second day in a row at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He prevailed by breaking 96 out of 100 targets. J.H. Forsman, who returned the only full card, took the high handicap trophy.

The controversy over the "ectoplasmic fingerprints" of "Walter," dead brother of "Margery," Boston medium, is again raging in the open between the American Society for Psychical Research, with headquarters in New York, and its rival organization, the Boston Society for Psychic Research.

BERLIN, Jan. 5. -- The 100 per cent interest transfer to Switzerland and the Netherlands is based on supplementary purchases of German goods by these countries. It is the Reichbank's view that, in granting exchange for the repurchasing of bonds, it benefits all creditors.
A demand for the immediate resignation of John F. Curry as leader of Tammany Hall was made yesterday by a group of about seventy-five Democrats, following a meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7. -- Olin Dutra of Santa Monica, Calif., and Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., were all square with 138s at the end of the first thirty-six holes of the Los Angeles open golf championship tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- While officials studied the $10,000,000,000 financing program required by administration plans for the next six months, the National Economy League today endorsed that phase of the President's budget message presaging a balanced budget in the fiscal year 1936.

It is not independently suspended front Wheels and similar engineering refinements that are significant in the cars exhibited in this year's automobile show, but the marked tendency toward streamlining. One could still see the ghost of Dobbin in front of the automobile of 1933, no longer ambling, to be sure, but galloping at eighty miles an hour.

CALCUTTA, Jan. 7 (Canadian Press.) -- India today scored 247 runs in its first innings against England in the second cricket test match, following on with 30 for no wickets before the close of play for the day. England's first innings score was 403.
Of the twenty-three contributions which added $235.50 to the fund for the Neediest Cases yesterday, one was the second from its giver this year and was accompanied by the following letter:

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has reduced the price of gasoline at service stations throughout its territory, except in Delaware, 1.2 cents a gallon, effective today. The Standard Oil Company of Louisiana, wholly owned by the New Jersey company, has made reductions in retail prices ranging from 0.4 cent a gallon to 1.6 cents throughout its territory.

The letter from Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler against the child labor amendment in your recent issue seems to me very unfair when it states that if the amendment were passed Congress might send inspectors into any home, family, school or church to see what any one under 18 years of age was doing.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 7. -- A group of Harvard students were routed by the police tonight after they attempted to break up a religious service at the Epworth Methodist Episcopal Church near Harvard Square when Baron Kurt von Tippelskirch, German consul at Boston, arose to speak.

To restore the dollar to its former gold value is impossible under present conditions. It would be strongly opposed by a majority in both houses of Congress and by a majority of the people in large sections of the country. Besides, it would cause serious disturbances in business and finance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- President Roosevelt today had his first real rest from the work that began mounting up weeks before Congress convened.

DUBLIN, Jan. 7. -- The tide of public feeling is rising in favor of General Owen O'Duffy and his United Ireland party, while the de Valera government's prestige is falling, in the opinion of political observers here, following the events of the past week.

Speculative buying of silver increased substantially last year because of the desire on the part of capital in this country to find a medium for investment that would afford protection against a depreciated currency, Handy Harman say, in their annual review of the silver market in 1933.

Many American cities have gone into the red since the depression began. Some have defaulted. Out of $18,000,000,000 municipal bond issues outstanding in the country, $1,000,000,000 went into default. More than half of these were in two cities -- $400,000,000 in Detroit and $150,000,000 in Chicago.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 7. -- A sixty-foot chip shot that just trickled into the cup on the final green of the seventy-two-hole tourney enabled Willie Dow, the 48-year-old local veteran, to finish in a tie for first place with Ralph Stonehouse of Indianapolis in the $2,000 Miami open golf championship at the Miami Springs Golf Club today.
A war on racketeers in which Federal, State and city law enforcement agencies will be enlisted, was announced yesterday by State Attorney General John J. Behnett Jr.

GENEVA, Jan. 7. -- The report from Rome that Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, and Premier Mussolini had agreed in their talks that disarmament should take precedence over revision of the League of Nations covenant was considered in League circles to amount to a practical if polite burial of the Mussolini agitation for reform of the League.

Doubts were expressed yesterday by persons familiar with the structure of the city government that Mayor LaGuardia's Economy Bill, even if enacted, would be upheld in the courts. It was said that the bill was in conflict with the constitutional provision against lessening the powers of an elected official during his term of office.
The Police Department will begin preparations today for its drive to close New York's thousands of speakeasies.

After the campus ceremonies last night marking the victory of the Columbia football team at the Rose Bowl game, about 500 students invaded the Nemo Theatre, a motion-picture house at 110th Street and Broadway, where newsreel pictures of the contest were being shown, and caused a panic among the 2,500 spectators there.

BERLIN, Jan. 7. -- The confidence with which the German Government expects American opinion to swing American officialdom to the German viewpoint in the matter of German debt manipulation and indeed in all matters of controversy between the two countries is somewhat puzzling to an outsider.

The wrestling program at Madison Square Garden tonight will be a championship match in which Jim Browning, Missourian who is recognized here as the world's heavyweight titleholder, will defend his laurels against Ray Steele of Glendale, Calif.

Glenn Presnell of the Portsmouth Spartans and Ken Strong of the New York Giants finished in a tie for the individual scoring honors in the National Football League, according to statistics released yesterday. Each registered a total of 64 points during the professional campaign which ended recently.

Certain quarters in Washington will receive with mixed feelings F. TRUBEE DAVISON'S remark about the planetarium of the Museum of Natural History, which will soon be under construction. Mr. DAVISON, who is president of the Museum, believes that the picture of the heavens in motion will turn people's thoughts to a "very much greater power than man which is responsible for wonderful things which are daily occurring in the universe."

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- Delegates from Jewish charitable groups in thirty cities from coast to coast, heard a five-year program of leadership in social planning proposed here today by Ira M. Younker, a trustee of the New York Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- Failure of bullish influences on the Board of Trade, especially with the shortest crop in years, to bring sufficient speculative buying to advance prices of oats last week was discouraging to many speculators who have believed that consumptive demands would increase enough to force prices higher.

A goal by Oscar Kinghorn in 6:31 of the overtime period enabled a rejuvenated Hershey team to triumph over the Bronx H.C., 2 to 1, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game at the Coliseum last night. The victory sent the winners into a tie for third place with the Bronx club.

The Railway Labor Executives Association protests against the plan of F.H. Prince for the consolidation of the railroads into about seven systems, in an article issued for publication today. The statement asserts that the plan is not put forward with any definite provisions for the public interest or for the needs of communities affected.

The instinct to express ourselves is divine, and can be a means to perfect freedom, the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland, the rector, declared yesterday morning at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Sixteenth Street, east of Third Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- A detailed study of the budget message presented to Congress last week by President Roosevelt has led some observers here to believe that it was so framed as to make possible the closing of the fiscal year next June 30 with a deficit possibly of $1,000,000,000 less than that estimated.

The cotton market was more active last week than for some time and prices moved over a wider range than for several weeks previous. The upward movement, begun a fortnight before, continued and at the close of the week active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 32 to 44 points from the close of the previous week.

The Whitney Museum is announcing today its purchases made from the First Biennial Exhibition of Contemporary American Sculpture, Water-colors and Prints, which opened on Dec. 5 and will close at 6 P.M. next Wednesday. The museum set aside a fund of $20,000 for this purpose, continuing the admirable practice established last season when the first biennial of oil paintings was held.

BERLIN, Jan. 5. -- The new year opened with a fluid money market, a decline in interest rates and an active demand for Reich treasury bills and bank discounts. These factors, together with optimistic official utterances concerning the future of industry and public finance, induced a pronounced bull market in bonds and stocks on the Boerse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Devaluation of the dollar by 50 per cent, with the government taking the profit on a like amount from the $3,600,000,000 of gold held by the Federal Reserve Banks, is expected soon by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma, who has submitted a measure to the President which would empower the government to absorb the profit.

Gladys Edgerly Bates of Mystic, Conn., has won the medal of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors for the best work of art entered in the association's forty-third annual exhibition, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- A decline for the third successive year in business done by the Postoffice Department, resulting in a net deficit of $50,683,000 despite the increase in first class postage rates and the drastic economies made after March 4, 1933, was shown today by James A. Farley, Postmaster General, in his report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1933.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 7. -- Governor Lehman will stand firm in his rejection of the request of Mayor LaGuardia for legislation to give him dictatorial powers for reform of city government, it was asserted here tonight by persons close to the Executive.

Gratification over the work done by the 1933 Mobilization for Human Needs was expressed by President Roosevelt in a letter to Newton D. Baker, the chairman, made public yesterday at the offices of the organization here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Labor's prospects for employment and earnings are "considerably brighter" for 1934, the American Federation of Labor reported today, but "the outlook is overshadowed by a danger which might destroy all progress made -- inflation by fiat money."

VIENNA, Jan. 7. -- At a meeting at Leesdorf the leader of the Lower Austrian Heimwehr, Herr Kubacek, violently attacked the policy of Chancellor Dollfuss's Patriotic Front, his Christian Social party and the party newspaper, Reichspost.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP). -- It was only with greatest difficulty that Bureau of Identification experts were able to decipher the fingerprints of the slain gangster, "Handsome Jack" Klutas.

Future generations will look back upon the events of these times as the second American revolution, the Rev. Norman Vincent Peale said yesterday in his sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, West Twenty-ninth Street. At the same time he deplored the fact that, although the country seems awakening to an appreciation of human values, religion and the churches have not been sought as the result of the depression.
BAY OF WHALES, Jan. 7 (by Wireless). -- We have arrived. After a 17,322-mile journey since leaving Bergen, Norway, the Wyatt Earp lies snug against the Ross Barrier.

With post-holiday retail trade spurred by cold weather, store stocks were reduced sharply and a heavy volume of mail and wire orders came into the local markets last week. Although wholesale inventories are thinning out, a fair amount of merchandise at attractive prices is still available.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 7. -- After two dull periods, the Baltimore Orioles hit their stride in the third period of an Eastern League hockey game tonight at Iceland and subdued the New York Athletic Club by 5 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- President Roosevelt's announcement in his budget message that he was issuing an executive order reposing "necessary control" of emergency expenditures in the Director of the Budget and the Controller General has caused discussion in official circles as to his exact purpose and intent, and the possible effects on his recovery program of such a change from the current procedure.

BOSTON, Jan. 7. -- Newton police were asked today to look for Robert Howley, 17 years old, son of Robert V. Howley, an executive of the United States Fruit Company, and two other members of Ship 13, Sea Scouts of America, who are believed to have shipped aboard a freighter.
The national automobile show, closed yesterday, will reopen today in Grand Central Palace and continue throughout the week.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- The New Year has opened with a general expression of optimism for the future business of this country. It is a tempered optimism, however, and the markets are not making the mistake of thinking that a boom is just around the corner.

NINILCHIK, Alaska, Jan. 7 (AP). -- To judge by the map this little village should be a land of almost perpetual snow and ice. Instead, the "Organized Citizens of Ninilchik" are planning a community garden that will enable them to raise their own products.

Trade union leaders and representatives of the NRA Labor Advisory Board agreed yesterday at a conference at the Russell Sage Foundation that enforcement of industrial codes depended primarily upon strong labor organizations rather than on the NRA Compliance Board, or any other governmental bureau.

When two artists like Ossip Gabrilowitsch and Albert Spalding join to make Beethoven's music in the comparatively intimate surroundings of the Town Hall, it is news, and good news. The recital last night was the first of a series of three, which will cover the great Ludwig's ten sonatas for piano and violin.

Improvement was registered in the dollar last week. Opening at a loss of 1/4 cent, at 62.78 cents, on Tuesday, the rate moved up steadily to 64.07, on Friday. There was a moderate reaction at the week-end to 63.62 cents, but this was still more than 9-16 cent gain over the preceding week. Range a year ago was 100.43@99.93 cents.

For a new year to be immediately ushered in with events which change at once the trend of financial discussion, is no uncommon experience. That happened in the first week of 1930, for example, when the downplunge of agricultural prices suddenly began.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- Chicago pulled itself part way out of the financial hole during 1933, despite delayed tax collections, according to the annual reports of the city controller and the city treasurer.

The annual exhibition of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors will open with a private view this evening in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, and to the public tomorrow.

THE HAGUE, Jan. 7. -- In an interview in the Dutch press Lieut. Gen. Gerth van Wyk, former commander-in-chief of Dutch Indian forces, declares that Holland has only one policy in the Far East, that of joining the United States and Great Britain against Japan.

The Christian home is the nearest approach to the kingdom of heaven that can be found upon this earth, Mgr. Michael S. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared in his sermon at high mass yesterday, the day upon which the Catholic Church celebrates the Feast of the Holy Family.
DETROIT, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Two goals off the stick of Frank Carson tonight gave the Detroit Red Wings a 2-0 victory over the Ottawa Senators in a National League hockey match.
The Atlantic City Sea Gulls defeated the St. Nicholas Hockey Club by 7 -- 2 in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game in Madison Square Garden yesterday.
ON BOARD THE WYATT EARP, Jan. 6 (By Wireless). -- In eight hours we should be at the Bay of Whales.

Inspector Joseph W. O'Connor of the Bureau of Licenses, who charged before Commissioner of Licenses Sidney S. Levine on Saturday that news-stand fees had been paid to the law firm of which Mr. Levine formerly was a member, is scheduled to appear this morning at a private investigation of news-stand graft, begun by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP). -- Eight seeded players advanced without loss of a set today in the opening matches of the second annual Miami Biltmore tennis tournament.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 7. -- Strenuous efforts are being made by financial officers of the city to limit the issue of scrip during the coming six months to not more than $13,900,000 end to thus arrive at the end of the fiscal year, June 30, several million dollars under the expected deficit of more than $18,000,000.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Smear, 6-year-old gelding owned by Mose Goldblatt, demonstrated his mud-running ability today by winning the feature race on the charity program at Jefferson Park. Betty Farrell finished second and Eisenberg third.

Saturday night's turkey shoot was held at the Vanderbilt Theatre where "A Divine Moment" stuck out its head to contemplate the vagaries of the drama. The evening was not good. For Miss Peggy Fears chose as the means of her actress-manager debut one of the grimmest bits of all time -- and then acted around it accordingly.
President Roosevelt and Mayor LaGuardia were defended against charges of dictatorship yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, rabbi of the Free Synagogue, worshiping in Carnegie Hall.

The Rev. Dr. William Ashley Sunday, better known as Billy Sunday, the one-time baseball player and for a generation the country's most famous evangelist, came back to New York yesterday for virtually the first time in seventeen years. He preached to two packed audiences, with overflow gatherings, in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, and in addition he delivered a radio sermon.

Continued strength in the position of the Federal Intermediate Credit Banks System is reflected in the consolidated statement of condition of the twelve regional banks of the system as of Nov. 30, to be made public today by Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent. The statement shows an increase in surplus, undivided profits and reserves for contingencies from $2,166,094 on Dec. 31, 1932, to $3,393,137 on Nov. 30, 1933.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $4,219,958,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The plan to merge the Coast Guard Service with the navy, which would include transfer of the naval post-graduate school from Annapolis to New London, Conn., has provoked a good deal of opposition, most of it in the Atlantic States. Would it be economical? Would the efficiency of the Coast Guard suffer?

Hunters in this State may calm their alarm over recent reports which seemed to indicate that deer in this State were suffering from an epidemic of tuberculosis. Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne yesterday issued the following announcement on this subject:
A policeman, who had entered a blazing apartment to aid the occupants, and a 9-year-old girl he was trying to rescue, were burned to death early yesterday morning at 6,015 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn.

A New York sermon reported in THE TIMES of Jan. 1 censured the festive mode of celebrating New Year's Eve and deplored the "discordant chorus" of "Prosits!" "Your health!" and "Here's how!" heard on these convivial occasions.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 7. -- A $19,000,000 investment by the Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen railroad holding structure, is at stake in an investigation by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation under hearing here before Marion C. Early, special master in Federal court.

RENO, Nev., Jan. 7 (AP'). -- Prince Alexis Mdivani left the private railroad car of his Princess, the former Barbara Hutton, here today and departed at 9:45 P.M. (Pacific time) by airplane for Salt Lake City.

Conservation officials in the United States are hastening to offer their services and their cooperation to the newly created Game Bird Restoration Committee, brought into being less than a week ago through the good offices of president Roosevelt and Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace.

The interest which thoughtful persons in the United States now take in world affairs prompts me to give you a brief picture of conditions in England. There are signs here of economic recovery. However, employment remains far below the normal level. The depression is still acute in the cotton, coal and shipping industries.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- For the first time since 1900 Westchester property values will show a decrease in the assessed valuations as determined for 1934 tax purposes, it was announced today by Pliny W. Williamson, chairman of the tax equalization committee of the Board of Supervisors.
ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's reply to Mayor LaGuardia:
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
Dominic W. Rich has been appointed a vice president and D. William O'Kolski, an assistant treasurer of the New York Hanseatic Corporation.

The first meeting of the National Automobile Dealers Association since the adoption of the retail code was held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The speakers who addressed 2,000 assembled dealers were enthusiastic in praising the operation of the code during the three months of its existence.

Darkest Africa is still largely unexplored, in the opinion of Commander GATTI, who was due to leave London on Dec. 29 to penetrate jungles unknown to white men and unoccupied by blacks, except pigmies who live only on fringes of the forest. The modern map of Africa is studded with names of towns, villages, posts and missions.

Reports that S.L. Rothafel, better known to the entertainment world as Roxy, had resigned as manager of the Radio City Music Hall were confirmed yesterday by J.R. McDonough, general manager of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation and president of Radio City Theatres, Inc., and also by Mr. Rothafel himself.

Close matches were in order in Class B of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League competition yesterday. All three encounters in Group 1 ended in scores of 3 to 2, with the Harvard Club, the Princeton Club and the Racquet and Tennis Club emerging victorious.

With the exception of coffee and cocoa, futures prices declined in yesterday's trading on local commodity Exchanges. The volume or trading continued at comparatively reduced levels. Cash prices were irregular.

It is possible that the current week will produce announcements dealing with the selection of coaches for two of the leading football teams of the East, Yale and Dartmouth. It is known that athletic officials of these institutions are busy considering their problems and that meetings of both groups are to take place before the end of the week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- There were indications today that Congress might soon be asked to extend the loaning powers of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation beyond Jan. 22, with the final decision as to when they shall be terminated and actual liquidation begun left to President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- In labor circles it was reported today that unless the procedure of the National Labor Board was expedited to reach decisions promptly there was danger that the board might break down.

Mrs. Charles G. Ayres gave a luncheon yesterday in the Egyptian Room of the St. Regis for Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of President Roosevelt. The other guests were the Hon. Audrey Pauncefote of London, Mrs. Charles A. Cartwright, Mrs. Robert Malcolm Littlejohn, Mrs. Theodore Schumacher, Mrs. R. Keith Kane, Mrs. Ayres Starr, Brig. Gen. J. William Kilbreth, U.S.A.; Albert Morris Bagby, John F. Daniell, Lawrence Smith Butler and Richard C. Plater.

Committees of shipping men assigned to the task of drafting a code of fair competition for the industry met yesterday afternoon in an attempt to bring into agreement the factions that have delayed their work. Progress was reported last night after sessions at the offices of the New York Shipping Association and the American Steamship Owners Association.

Judge Rosalsky in General Sessions ordered yesterday a jury to acquit Mrs. Margaret Bruno, 32 years old, mother of four children, and John Monzillo, 21, on a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of her husband, Anthony, in the Summer of 1932.

Spring buying got off to a good start in the ready-to-wear and accessory markets here yesterday, with activity during the week promising to be exceptionally brisk. The attendance of buyers at the dress and coat showings was large, with a marked tendency shown to actual placing of orders rather than the shopping around which featured past seasons.

Outdoor work camps for employable men and women now quartered in the Municipal Lodging House were suggested yesterday by Welfare Commissioner William Hodson as means of raising the morale of the unemployed and making them physically fit to resume industrial work.

A move to reorganize the Democratic party in Manhattan by dropping the historic name of Tammany and substituting for it legally constituted organizations, such as exist in the other boroughs of New York City, is being considered by supporters of President Roosevelt and Postmaster General James A. Farley, State and national chairman, it was learned last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- Governor Lehman made public late tonight a letter which he had sent to Mayor LaGuardia in reply to the communication which he received from the Mayor today. The Governor said that he held strongly to his earlier statement that the "dictatorial powers" asked for by Mayor LaGuardia should not be vested in him.

Testimony linking the Bay State Corporation of Boston with Harold B. Hale, personal secretary to Philip H. Philbin Jr., who made $600,000 profit trading in stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation, was offered yesterday at the inquiry of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. into the market activities of the stock.

" Champagne, Sec." current at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, will lend its engagement on Saturday evening, Jan. 20. The operetta opened here on Oct. 14 at the Morosco Theatre and has also been housed in the Shubert Theatre. A tour will follow the Broadway engagement.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8. -- Four members of last year's Pennsylvania varsity crew were among the candidates who reported to Coach Rusty Callow at the formal start of indoor rowing today. They were Charles M. Swift, Hackensack, N.J.; Willard S. Martin, Byfield, Mass.; Joe Burk, football tackle from Beverly, N.J., and Chester L. Duff Jr., Syracuse.

" Tannhauser" was performed last night for the second time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House as the third week of the fourteen-week season began. In the principal roles were Maria Mueller as Elisabeth, Margaret Halstead as Venus, Lauritz Melchior as Tannhauser, Friedrich Schorr as Wolfram and Emanuel List as the Landgraf Hermann.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 8. -- Major William W. Ocker, blind-flying expert who developed instruments enabling pilots to guide their planes through fog, was ordered court-martialed today for use of "improper language" to other Kelly Field officers after he had been "grounded" on account of imperfect vision.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- With the flotation of new securities for financing the emergency program imminent, it was made known today that in the last week the Treasury had bought $44,713,000 of government securities in the open market. Of the total, $34,713,000 was bought chiefly for the account of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and $10,000,000 for the debt-retirement sinking fund.
Determined that consumers are to pay the absolute minimum prices for foodstuffs, Mayor LaGuardia moved yesterday to drive racketeers from the city's markets.
BAY OF WHALES, Antarctica, Jan. 8. -- The Northrop all-metal airplane in which I hope to span Antarctica is on the bay ice in the Bay of Whales where I expect to make my base.

The youth of the nationally high-ranking players and the wide geographical distribution of such honors for 1934 was one of the outstanding features of the past year in tennis and an encouraging sign for the future or the game in America during the coming season.

One who had prolonged the lives of untold thousands deserved himself to live longer. But real Crusader that Dr. WILLIAMS was, when he died his feet were "on the quest." He had a record that added years could hardly have made more resplendent. His service, ended so abruptly, had a certain chivalry that will prolong its influence.

The first bill embodying President ROOSEVELT'S budget recommendations be introduced this week and is expected to be the measure appropriating funds for the "independent offices." This is a deviation from the usual order, but the change is apparently not accidental.

Domestic speculative markets continued yesterday to rely, for their feeble impulses, upon the half-hearted efforts of perplexed professional traders. Quotations at the close did not vary greatly from those of last week.

The forty-third annual exhibition of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors opened with a reception last evening in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building. Beginning today, and through Jan. 28, the work will be on public view.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- To prevent if possible the migration to Detroit and other automobile centres of large numbers of automobile workers who would lack jobs after the Spring period of production, General Johnson today approved a modification of the code permitting an average 40-hour week instead of the 35-hour week.

All of the favorites who saw action scored decisive victories in the initial round of the women's national squash racquets championship yesterday as a new chapter for the sport in New York City was started.
" Ha!" said Mr. Lou Little, "You're late for the parade, aren't you? And I notice you're not wearing any Stanford sweater these days!"

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- An invitation from Dr. Hjalmar Schacht for Germany's medium and long term creditors to meet in Berlin on Jan. 22 was received at the Bank of England tonight and accepted here as evidence of a possible change, not only in his manners and perceptive powers, but also in his willingness to be convinced, for otherwise, so The Financial News observes, the forthcoming meeting could serve no purpose.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Farmer pickets of the Pure Milk Association committed one train robbery, stopped and searched other trains and wrecked several milk plants in Southern Wisconsin tonight in their successful campaign to shut off Chicago's milk supply.
