While Mr. O'Neill was pulling his psychological strings a block to the south, Signor Podrecca and his out-and-out puppets took up their position at the Hudson Theatre. It will be remembered that they were here last season, calling forth the adulation of major and minor prophets.

The Association for the Aid of Crippled Children will get more than $10,000,000 of the wealth of the late Milo M. Belding, retired silk thread manufacturer, it was disclosed yesterday when his estate was appraised. The association will receive the gifts upon the death of Mrs. Annie Kirk Belding, the widow, who gets the income for life.

Edward S. Greenbaum, American trustee in bankruptcy of the Kreuger Toll Company, filed yesterday with the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York an intermediate report covering the administration of the estate from Feb. 20 to Dec. 31, 1933.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Robert H. Gore, whose brief tenure as Governor of Puerto Rico has been markd by constant political storms in that island, probably will apply soon for a leave of absence that is expected to presage his resignation, it became known here today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 8. -- Spokesmen declared today the government had sufficient evidence to link former President Carlos Ibanez and other prominent persons with the recently discovered plot against the Alessandri administration. The details, however, were withheld until completion of the investigation.

The New York Stock Exchange has received no official notice from the Bethlehem Steel Corporation of the latter's decision not to pay coupons on its bonds in guilders, when presented for payment at Amsterdam, except when the owner established proof of bona-fide residence in Holland, it was announced yesterday.

As the first step in carrying out his announced intention of enlisting the nation's best scientific brains, President Roosevelt is bringing about the formation of a committee of eminent scientists to advise the government departments on scientific policies and programs, it became known yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 8. -- The Paraguayan Minister of War announced the occupation yesterday of Bolivia's last four important positions in the Chaco, Forts Platanillos, Jayucubas, Bolivar and Loa, which were reported abandoned by the Bolivians.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (AP). -- A separate maintenance action charging Rudy Vallee with being "intimate on numerous occasions" with Alice Faye, movie actress, and two "Jane Does" was filed against the singer and orchestra leader today by Fay Webb Vallee.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP). -- Fresh from conversations in Paris and Rome, Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, plunged today into the task of formulating a British policy designed to revive the World Disarmament Conference, with Germany participating.
A statistical analysis of the trends of Manhattan real estate made by the Record and Guide indicates that in general the year 1933 was slightly, if any, better than the year 1932.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- A decision handed down today by the Supreme Court, sustaining the Minnesota law establishing a moratorium on foreclosures of mortgages, was interpreted here as tending to indicate the future upholding of the legality of the sweeping emergency powers conferred by Congress on the President for the establishment and operation of the National Recovery Act.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8. -- The University of Toronto tonight reversed the outcome of its first hockey game with Yale by winning, 2 to 1, before nearly 2,000 spectators in the New Haven Arena.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Efforts are being made, and will be made, to minimize the cause and effect of the President's substitution of a new Executive order today for that of Jan. 3, which gave to Budget Director Douglas the power to audit the emergency budget.

With orders for tickets coming in in heavy volume, William Tilden and Ellsworth Vines went through the first of two final practice tests at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn yesterday in preparation for their professional tennis match in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., yesterday announced that the store's administrative board will shortly cease to function as such and that the executive committee composed of Percy S. Straus, president; Edwin I. Marks, Jack I. Straus and Delos Walker, vice presidents; Beardsley Rumi, treasurer; Ralph I. Straus, secretary; Donald K. David and Oswald W. Knauth, directors, and Q.F. Walker, secretary of the committee, will take over its duties.

PARIS, Jan. 8. -- With the political situation extremely uncertain following revelations and accusations in connection with the Bayonne scandal, the Bourse today was hesitant and weak. There is no evidence, however, that this uneasiness is deep-rooted.

The steel industry produced 22,878,571 tons of ingots in 1933, compared with 13,322,833 in 1932, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Operations for the week beginning yesterday were estimated by the institute at 30.7 per cent of capacity, 1.4 points more than a week ago.

Henry F. Wolff, deputy administrator of the local NRA organization, accepted yesterday Grover A. Whalen's invitation to take over the duties of NRA administrator for New York following Mr. Whalen's resignation. Mr. Wolff's official appointment is contingent upon approval of General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator.

Bertillon Growing Obsolete? Some of the underworld's leading practitioners are now having their fingerprints done over by surgery, and science has once more shown that it is 100 per cent neutral in the war between the forces of crime and the agencies of law and order.

When Peter Kaminsky of 105-11 Thirty-second Avenue, Corona, indicted on a charge of hoarding $6,000 in gold, appeared before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday he offered to plead guilty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- A resolution requesting President Roosevelt to communicate to the Hitler government "an unequivocal statement of the profound feelings of surprise and pain experienced by the American people" at the oppressions of the Jews in Germany was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Tydings of Maryland.

TRENTON, Jan. 8. -- With several important matters pressing for attention the 1934 Legislature will convene at noon tomorrow for organization. Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County will succeed Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic as President of the Senate, and Joseph Altman of Atlantic will take the place of Herbert J. Pascoe of Union as Speaker of the House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- President Roosevelt will send a special message to the Senate Wednesday urging the immediate ratification of the St. Lawrence Waterway Treaty as a means of increasing employment and reducing electricity rates to people living within 200 miles of the dam to be constructed on the St. Lawrence.

Twelve men named as "officers and agents" of New York Investors, Inc., and its subsidiary, the Realty Associates Securities Corporation, in indictments charging use of the mails to defraud, concealment of assets in bankruptcy and conspiracy, pleaded not guilty in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

VIENNA, Jan. 8. -- An extraordinary Cabinet council was held this afternoon, and a long communique was issued tonight announcing that the severest measures would be taken against Austrian Nazis in reprisal for more than 140 bombings and many other terroristic acts since Jan. 1.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Interest in the Board of Trade's annual election of officers today was probably the smallest in the Exchange's history. The one ticket had no opposition.
Police Commissioner O'Ryan approved three transfers of high ranking police officials yesterday.

HAVANA, Jan. 8. -- The military authorities continued today ousting the Mayors of interior cities and towns in their preparation for the expected uprising by opponents of the Grau San Martin government. It is believed the army is strengthening its forces in places where municipal officials were suspected of siding with the opposition.

William J. (Big Bill) Duffy, American representative of Primo Carnera and former night club proprietor, pleaded guilty yesterday to an indictment returned last .March charging that he failed to report a net income of $34,170.50 earned in 1930.

Your obeisance to my esteemed friend Herbert Bayard Swope is gracious, as is your compliment to his diction. Nearly thirty years ago (I am confident he will remember the incident) I made opportunity to say to Mr. Swope, "Bide your time, watch your step and you will go far in this town."

In the midst of a conference with an attorney who was arranging a separation agreement in his office at 75-05 Sixty-seventh Road, Glendale, Queens, last night, George Neilson, 45 years old, a chemist, suddenly drew a knife and stabbed to death his wife, Margaret, 33.

The all-star major league ball game, inaugurated last year in Chicago with such signal success, will be held this year on July 10 in New York. This was announced yesterday by the joint schedule committee of the National and American circuits as Presidents John A. Heydler and William Harridge completed the task of drawing up the 1934 championship schedules.

Attracting a heavy attendance of buyers, many Spring lines of dresses, suits, coats and accessories were launched here yesterday. Merchandise managers and buyers representing stores all over the country displayed marked confidence in commenting on prospects for the new season.

A "vast increase" in business along Broadway, particularly in hotels and restaurants, has taken place in the last two months, directors of the Broadway Association reported at their annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel, Astor.

BUFFALO, Jan. 8. -- Owen B. Augspurger, president of the Merchants Mutual Insurance Company of Buffalo, leaped or fell to his death from a room on the sixteenth floor of the Statler Hotel today. He was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Bishop James Cannon Jr. of the Methodist Episcopal Church South and Miss Ada L. Burroughs, who was treasurer of the Bishop's anti-Smith campaign committee of 1928, must stand trial for conspiracy to violate the Corrupt Practices Act, the Supreme Court ruled today.

For the first time since 1929 the report of the Interstate Commerce Commission covers a year in which the position of the railways has shown improvement. Gains made after March raised the number of carloadings in 1933 above the figure for the preceding year.

PARIS, Tuesday, Jan. 9. -- Alexandre Stavisky, leading figure in the Bayonne pawnshop swindle, shot himself yesterday afternoon in a locked room in a lonely villa at Chamonix, a snow-covered town in the shadow of Mont Blanc, while police who had come to arrest him were hammering their way through the door.
Numerous leases in the midtown area by firms in the garment and allied trades were among the business rentals reported yesterday as follows:

Commissioner S.S. Goldwater of the Department of Hospitals notified every one of the 12,000 civil service employes in the department yesterday that none "who is performing a useful service in a conscientious manner is likely to be suspended during the lifetime of the existent administration except for urgent budgetary reasons."

Mary McCormic, opera and concert singer, was sued in the Supreme Court yesterday by Collet D. Huff, who operates the Hollywood Country Club, at Hollywood, Fla., to restrain her from leaving New York on Jan. 13 to sing in London, on the ground that she has contracted for the period from Jan. 20 to Feb. 2 at the Hollywood Country Club at $1,500.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- An Executive order of last week placing all relief and recovery expenditures under the direct authority of Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Budget, has been reversed by President Roosevelt following protests from his emergency bureau heads that it was contrary to the basic idea of speeding relief work.

One of the most amazing things about Mr. O'Neill is his capacity for seasoning his valiant career with bad plays. His "Days Without End," which the Guild mounted at Henry Miller's last evening, belongs in that doleful category. Mr. O'Neill has labeled it "a modern miracle play."

CALCUTTA, Jan. 8 (Canadian Press). -- The second test cricket match between England and India resulted in a draw when stumps were pulled today at the conclusion of four days' play. The scores were: England 403 and 7 for two wickets, India 247 and 237.

BASLE, Switzerland, Jan. 8. -- A definite change in the German policy on payment of long-term private debts is expected in international banking quarters here, following long conversations today on the margin of the monthly meeting of the World Bank board.

The money market was featureless. Turnover was silght and quotations for all classes unchanged from those which prevailed last week. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 1 per cent, while a little was done outside at 7/8. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were steady.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Stockholders of the Central Republic Trust Company, at the annual meeting today heard a report on the institution's financial position as of Dec. 30, 1933, ratified a reduction in the number of directors from twenty to seven and authorized a new contract with the City National Bank and Trust Company for the handling of the company's trust business.

A collection of thousands of pieces of carved jades, ivories and amber, presented last year to the American Museum of Natural History, was hailed yesterday by F. Trubee Davison, president, as the most outstanding gift made to the institution not only in 1933 but in any year.

Dr. William J. O'Shea, who will relinquish the office of Superintendent of Schools on Jan. 31, after nearly forty-seven years of public educational service, found much for reflection yesterday in a retirement interview.

In an application before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday Thomas Keogh, attorney for a group of certificate holders seeking appointment as trustees for a mortgage in which they had invested, charged that the New York Title and Mortgage Company had sold $2,015,487 worth of certificates without getting an assignment of the mortgage securing them.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney scored two firsts and a second at Tropical Park today when her Easy Come won the featured Metecumbe Handicap after Back Fence had run second in the curtain raiser and Black Harmony had captured the second event.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8 (Canadian Press). -- Charlie Conacher of the Maple Leafs, with 16 goals and 8 assists, enjoys a wide margin in the race for National Hockey League scoring honors. His 24 points are five better than any other player.

After three weeks of hearings at which more than a score of newsstand operators testified that they had been compelled to pay graft of $1,000 or more to obtain $5 licenses, Commissioner Sidney S. Levine of the Department of Licenses served formal charges yesterday on Inspector Joseph W. O'Connor of his own department.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Jan. 8. -- Thirty-two students were chosen today in eight districts of the country to enter Oxford University next October under the provisions of the Rhodes Trust.

Mayor LaGuardia announced last night that the city would begin operation of the Brooklyn Ash Removal Company's three plants at midnight last night following an agreement to abandon an injunction proceeding in Supreme Court which sought to restrain municipal operation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Speculation in the grain markets showed no increase today, although the turnover exceeded the 8,711,000 bushels in all grains on Saturday. Wheat held within a range of a cent and corn of around 5/8 cent, with most of the business in small lots.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, en route to Little America, Jan. 8. -- Still below the Antarctic Circle, the flagship of the Byrd Antarctic Expedition today was creeping at slow speed through heavy fog. The abominable weather of the past fortnight continues, and even this hard-bitten crew is beginning to talk like characters in a Cape Cod drama.
" International day" at the National Automobile Show brought yesterday more than 200 motor representatives from thirty-eight foreign countries to view the exhibits at Grand Central Palace.

A new investment trust organized to provide a medium for purchase into a cross-section of any one of seventeen industries is sponsored by Distributors Group, Inc. The trust will be known as Group Securities, Inc., and is capitalized at 50,000,000 shares of 1 cent par value. Of these, 27,200,000 have been authorized -- 1,600,00 shares in each of the seventeen classifications.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 8. -- Guests at the tea which Mr. and Mrs. A. Parker Bryant gave today at their lake front home included Judge and Mrs. Jerome D. Gedney, Mrs. A. Romeyn Pierson, Dr. John Adams, Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West, Mr. and Mrs. John B. O'Day, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred D. Bell, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bromfield, Hugh Dillmann and Nelson S. Odman.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 8. -- From the discouragement, the despair and the disasters of 1932 there developed in 1933 not only a new deal in government and a new hope in the people but a new standard of news values, Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia University School of Journalism, said at Yale this evening, in an address on the philosophy of journalism.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 8. -- Eugene Bisson of Whippany, N.J., alleged member of an arson ring with headquarters in New Jersey, has confessed setting fire to the Warner Park toiler coaster here Sept. 30, 1931, police say.
Ray Miller of Essex Prep defeated George Brothers of the Salem-Crescent A.C. in the 165-pound intercity special in the amateur boxing tournament at the New York A.C. last night.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- Temporary insanity was indicated as the defense to be offered for Mrs. Sarah R. Hobart, who was admitted to $10,000 bail by Commissioner Cibberly today on a Federal indictment charging her with sending poisoned candy through the mails to her brother in the veterans' hospital at Coatesville, Pa., on Nov. 17.

Travis Harvard Whitney, Civil Works Administrator, lawyer, former Public Service Commissioner and founder of the Albany "people's lobby," died last night at Post-Graduate Hospital. He had been unconscious since early morning and at his death his wife and three sons were beside him.

Rapid clearing of the city of professional pandhandlers was reported yesterday by Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein at the end of the first week of the Civil Works Administration's experimental campaign to rid the city of beggars and to direct deserving mendicants into channels where they may obtain jobs, food, clothing and medical attention.

BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- The German reply to the French aide-memoire on arms will request more particulars, according to the Deutsche Diplomatische Korrespondenz. This inspired news bulletin suggests the German Government may take more time pondering the French proposition, in a spirit of good-will for mutual understanding and desire to reach an early agreement.
Several changes and promotions were announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

S.S. SANTA BARBARA, Jan. 8. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull today started his formal report on the Pan-American conference for submission to President Roosevelt. He said he felt thoroughly rested after his journey of ten days through the Argentine and Chilean lake region and from Santiago to catch the steamer at Valparaiso.
ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- Republican factional lines held firm in the Assembly tonight and once more the lower house adjourned without electing a clerk.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 (AP). -- Their honeymoon tour interrupted, apparently by a District Attorney's investigator seeking either to question or subpoena the bridegroom, Prince Alexis Mdivani and the former Barbara Hutton, heiress to $40,000,000 were far apart today.

Senator Huey Long was condemned in prose, poetry, song and softly blurred Louisiana accents last night at the Hotel Brevoort, where 200 militant Louisiana women gave a dinner in honor of Mrs. Hilda Phelps Hammond, leader of the movement to unseat the Senator.

The fact that Joseph V. McKee was appointed special counsel here to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation last Thursday was made known yesterday when he attended a hearing before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler on an application for the sale of a block of stock of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company, which has borrowed $12,000,000 from the RFC.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Rexford G. Tugwell, assistant Secretary of Agriculture, and a leader of the "brain trust" group in the administration, will be promoted to Under-Secretary of Agriculture if Congress approves an appropriation of $10,000 as salary for the new post.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- A Republican attack upon the Roosevelt recovery program was a feature of the Senate session today, with Senator Robinson of Indiana criticizing the President's message and "mad expenditures." He was answered by Senator Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic leader, who characterized his speech as "an unjust and unfounded attack on the President.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Spokesmen for "captive" soft coal mines controlled by Pennsylvania steel corporations told the National Labor Board today that they did not accept President Roosevelt's statement of Oct. 30, which was to have settled the dispute between miners and employers, as binding on the companies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The new liquor tax bill, substantially in the same form as it was passed by the House Friday afternoon, was laid before the Senate this afternoon so it could be brought up the first thing when the upper body convenes again on Wednesday.

A conference between Governor Lehman and Mayor LaGuardia on the restoration of the city's credit seemed highly probable late last night as the result of the Governor's suggestion of two possible appointments for a meeting, in his letter made public at Albany.

The government of the United States may continue to hold $10,810,850, which the estate of Baron William Waldorf Astor paid as an inheritance tax, though under protest, in 1922, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

A sharp rise in German bonds, which carried many issues up fractionally to more than 6 points, with the consequent firming of other foreign loans, contrasted yesterday with heavy selling of United States Government issues and irregularly lower quotations on domestic corporation bonds on the Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration abandoned today its nationwide program to improve returns to dairy farmers by enforcing fixed prices to consumers through local marketing agreements with distributers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Henry Morgenthau Jr. was confirmed as Secretary of the Treasury by unanimous vote of the Senate today after Senator Robinson of Indiana had said that he was unfit for the office because he had employed Earle Bailie as a special assistant.

The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, pursuing the policy which it began a year ago, yesterday published a complete list of its investments as of Jan. 1. The Corn Exchange continues to be unique in giving complete publicity to its portfolio, although other banks have given an increasing amount of information to shareholders and the public in the last year.
Contributions from twenty-three donors added $1,118 to the fund for the Neediest Cases yesterday.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 8. -- J. Glenn Anderson of Newark, counsel for the strikers of the Ford Motor Company's plant at Edgewater, said the strikers at a meeting today declared the strike at an end.

The Amateur Athletic Union completed arrangements yesterday for the staging of a national interscholastic track and field meet at Madison Square Garden on the morning and afternoon of Feb. 24 as a preliminary to the national senior championships at the Garden that night.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8. -- This city's strike of taxicab drivers, which has been marked by recurrent episodes of violence since Nov. 25, was virtually settled today.

ATLANTA, Jan. 8 (AP). -- Robert Lassiter Jr. of Charlotte, N.C., who captained Yale's 1933 football team, wants to set things right about a remark attributed to him that he "played football for fun and not to win."

An offer to settle the suit brought by Mrs. Gertrude Devine Webster of Washington, D.C., against her former husband, William M. Ritter, retired lumberman of Welch, W.Va., to enforce an agreement made in 1922 to pay her $70,000 a year for life, was rejected yesterday when Mrs. Webster told Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer she would not accept $30,000 a year agreed upon by the attorneys.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Veterans' legislation was introduced in the Senate today, with Republican leaders in Senate and House declaring that it will be one of the points of issue in this session.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 8. -- Rumors persisted in Harvard circles today that the teaching services of Dr. Tugwell were being sought for the university.
The executive committee of the Citizens Union adopted a resolution yesterday endorsing Mayor LaGuardia's economy bill.

District Attorney Dodge's campaign against racketeers included the arrest yesterday afternoon of two "boss" scrubwomen in Madison Square Garden on an indictment charging they extorted $1 to $1.25 weekly from subordinate scrubwomen.

Oswald Spengler argues for a purely aristocratic society and against all forms of contemporary social legislation such as the Nazis are now proposing in his new book, "The Hour of Decision," which Alfred A. Knopf will publish in February.
Purchase of a Jersey City apartment house featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

Jack Dempsey hurried into town yesterday and hurried right out again, stirring the heavyweight stituation to an unusual degree. The former heavyweight champion's visit aroused these two developments locally:

Except for another slight dent in the automobile group, an irregular decline in some of the so-called "pool specialties" and a hesitant advance in the alcohol group and some of the stocks that are more difficult to classify, the share market's performance was extremely tame yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Supplies of hogs were in excess of expectations today, but the offerings were quickly absorbed, with prices 5 to 10 cents lower. Shippers were more active than for some time, and buying of 7,000 by the government helped to sustain the market in the face of the liberal run.
Columbia and Stanford may carry along their football rivalry to a game at Baker Field next Fall, it was learned yesterday at Columbia.

The City A.C. Class C squash tennis team last night maintained its Metropolitan League lead by shutting out the Short Hills players, 5 to 0, on the winner's courts. The leaders have won seven matches and lost only one.

In a solemn and affecting letter two members of "the Democratic party" of New York City, in behalf of themselves and seventy-three other citizens "who represent every Assembly District in Manhattan," tell the Hon. JOHN F. CURRY to resign the leadership of Tammany Hall.

Jim Browning, giant Missourian, last night retained his world's heavyweight wrestling title by throwing Ray Steele, Glendale (Calif.) challenger, in Madison Square Garden. The bout, which lasted 1 hour 4 minutes 56 seconds, provided much excitement for about 8,000 fans.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The Duchess of Sutherland, Viscount Adare and the Baron and Baroness de Baubigny are among the passengers due late today from the Channel ports on the Cunarder Aquitania. Others arriving on the ship from Southampton via Cherbourg are:

Another "revolution" -- the revolution of the internationalists -- has failed, and the "fight against nationalism has lost," Senator William E. Borah of Idaho said last night in advocating a foreign policy of political isolation for the United States.
In considering the fiscal tasks that confront Congress, and leaving to one side the monetary and industrial problems, we may ask:
A further expansion in buying on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried prices into new high ground for the moment and left the list 11 to 14 points better.

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- The McGill hockey squad continued its romp against the United States college teams by beating Harvard 12 to 2 at the Garden tonight. The play of Farquharson, Farmer, McGill and Crutchfield simply bewildered the Harvard players.

Charges that "studied efforts to exclude Negro workers from the New Deal" were made during 1933 were contained in the annual report of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, submitted yesterday at the annual meeting at offices of the organization, 69 Fifth Avenue.

MADRID, Jan. 8. -- With the announcement today that Minister of the Interior Rico Avello -- the only Leftist member of the Spanish Cabinet -- would resign at the end of this week, Premier Alejandro Lerroux is now free to form an entirely Rightist government.

United planning and a more equitable distribution of expenditures for home missions representing three-fourths of the Protestant churches in America are urged in the report under discussion at the annual meeting of the Home Missions Council, which opened yesterday at the headquarters of the organization, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel Russell, pastor of Rutgers Church, Seventy-third Street, just west of Broadway, was elected Moderator of the Presbytery of New York yesterday afternoon at a meeting in the Parish House of the Fifth Avenue Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Arthur M. Oberfelder, operator of the Oberfelder theatrical circuit in five Middle Western cities, said last night that he was closing the circuit in order to reorganize it and begin over again. Companies playing in Kansas City and St. Louis ended their runs on Saturday night; companies in Louisville and Indianapolis will terminate their tours this Saturday evening, and a fifth company will close in Cincinnati a week later.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8. -- A.J. Halliwell's consistent 5-year-old gelding Contribute came again after losing the lead to outgame A.G. Tarn's Blue Day by a nose in the six-furlong Frank H. Hayes Memorial Handicap which featured today's program at Jefferson Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Jan. 3 shows increases for the week of $86,000,000 in net demand deposits and $12,000,000 in time deposits, and decreases of $81,000,000 in loans and investments and $113,000,000 in government deposits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The nomination of Judge Frank H. Norcross of Nevada to the United States Circuit bench in the Ninth Circuit was referred to a subcommittee for investigation today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP). -- The Washington Senators today handed Sam Rice, veteran outfielder, his unconditional release.

The dangers of a narrow nationalism, toward which he saw trends in the current administration's policies at Washington, were cited yesterday by William R. Castle Jr., Under-Secretary of State in the Hoover administration, in addressing the school of politics of the Women's National Republican Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- In the government's intensive drive to punish fraudulent evasion of income and other tax laws 1,444 criminal cases were investigated and prosecutions started in the fiscal year ended June 30, the Internal Revenue Bureau disclosed in its annual report today.
BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- Seven meetings of protest against the effort of Reichsbishop Ludwig Mueller to force Protestantism into a Nazi dictatorship were held in Berlin tonight.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8. -- Macdonald Smith today won the Los Angeles open golf championship for the fourth time in the nine years of the event.
PARIS, Jan. 8. -- The quota for imports from the United States into France was increased three-fold today for the first quarter of 1934 by the allotment of a total equal to the 1933 figure.

A revolt of the Republican party from its "old reactionary leadership" to a new leadership under principles and in accord with a change in the social order was urged last night by Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney.
Investment purchases of housing in Manhattan and Westchester featured the realty trading reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Alexander Antonovich Troyanovsky, first Soviet Ambassador to the United States, presented his credentials to President Roosevelt today.
The New York County Grand Jury will begin consideration today of charges that graft has been collected in connection with the issuance of liquor licenses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Representative Britten of Illinois introduced a bill today authorizing the construction of 101 naval vessels of various classes at a total cost of $473,200,000, beginning in 1935 and running through 1939.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8. -- Ralph Stonehouse, 29-year-old Indianapolis professional, won from Willie Dow, Miami veteran, in the eighteen-hole play-off for first place in the Miami open championship on the course of the Miami Springs Golf Club today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 8. -- Speaking before the annual meeting today of the Long Island Nurserymen's Association, at the Hotel Huntington, Meade C. Dobson, secretary of the Long Island Chamber of Commerce, said nurserymen should receive a return for the large quantities of shrubs and trees which they have been supplying without cost for roadside planting throughout Long Island.

Preliminary talks with representatives of rapid transit companies were held yesterday by City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., in preparation for actual negotiations for unification of all rapid transit lines. The date for the beginning of the formal negotiations will be announced by Mayor LaGuardia in a few days.

The collection of writings by and about Abraham Lincoln formed by his lifelong friend and law partner, William H. Herndon, comprising nearly 2,500 items practically unexamined by historians, has been acquired by Gabriel Wells.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 8. -- Two white and lemon pointers handled by Dr. L.V. Benbow of Winston-Salem. N.C., annexed the first two places in the amateur all-age stake, opening event of the Pineburst Field Trial Club's seventeenth annual meet today.

Sir CHARLES LYELL, English scientist, once asked Colonel T.H. PERKINS, the philanthropist, what he thought of the sea serpent. "Unfortunately," replied the Bostonian, "I have seen it." But he would not talk about it, valuing his reputation for veracity. In his younger days he had been much at sea as a supercargo on trading ships, and had voyaged about the Pacific, calling at Batavia, Canton and other ports in Asia.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- On the eve of her seventy-fifth birthday, Carrie Chapman Catt, noted women's suffrage leader, expressed today her admiration for President Roosevelt, but declared she was sorry that prohibition had been repealed.
A notable exhibition of watercolor drawings by the English mystic, artist and poet, William Blake, was opened yesterday afternoon at the Pierpont Morgan Library 29 East Thirty-sixth Street.

Supporters and opponents of the use of radios in taxicabs presented arguments at police headquarters yesterday before Harold L. Fowler, First Deputy Commissioner. Mr. Fowler announced later that he would send his recommendations to Commissioner O'Ryan.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- The stock markets opened the new account today active and firm, profit-taking causing only slight reactions, fresh support following immediately. Woolworth's announcement of bigger profits and increased dividends was the signal for a sharp recovery in the shares of that company.

BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- The Boerse opened firm today, but the absence of public interest soon led to realization sales, many stocks closing below Saturday's levels. The range of prices was narrow, however, the losses not exceeding two points. I.G. Garben's decline of 1 3/4 points was the signal for the reverse in trend. Cables, automobiles and a few heavy industrials were able to maintain the early gains, but the rest of the list sagged.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Increased quotas for United States products have been obtained from France and Great Britain, the State Department announced today.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8. -- Frank Shields of New York, ranking No. 1 player in the United States, today won in love sets from Larry Larsen of Peoria, Ill., in Shields's first tournament game of the year, to gain the third round of the Miami Biltmore championship.

TRENTON, Jan. 8. -- In its annual report, submitted today to Governor Moore, the Public Utility Commission asks an appropriation for employment of special engineers and experts to make a study of rates. A similar request was denied by the Legislature last year.

Mrs. Josephine Culbertson and Albert H. Morehead led a field of thirty-eight pairs at the end of the first day's play early this morning in the contract bridge pair championship of the United States Bridge Association at the Hotel Pierre.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- An allotment of $5,000,000 for civil works projects in New York State was one of twelve unemployment relief grants totaling $11,003,863 made today to nine States, Alaska, Hawaii and the Virgin Islands by Harry L. Hopkins, Emergency Relief and Civil Works Administrator.

The Standard Oil Company of New York, Inc., today will reduce the price of gasoline in tank wagons and service stations throughout its territory 1 cent a gallon. The new price in New York City will be 17 cents a gallon, including all taxes.

Jens Nelson, 68 years old, of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., filed a claim yesterday in Surrogate's Court that he is a son of Edward Albert Ridley, eccentric real estate dealer who was found slain in his subcellar office in Allen Street last May, and that he is entitled to $4,000,000 left by Ridley.

The re-election of Richard Whitney as president of the New York Stock Exchange for a fifth term was forecast by brokers yesterday, following the election of the nominating committee for 1934. The latter committee consists of Raymond Chauncey of Chauncey Co., W. Allston Flagg of Post Flagg, Robert B. Flinn of Fenner Beane, Jacob C. Stone of Asiel Co. and Robert F. Whitmer Jr. of Edward B. Smith Co.

The woman's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies celebrated the success of its part in the present campaign yesterday with a rally and tea at the home of Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, 1,109 Fifth Avenue.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 8. -- Negotiations on upward of $500,000,000 in claims between the United States and Mexico which for several years have been treated by special and general claims commissions nominated by the two countries have reached a critical stage.

" Disraeli," George Arliss's first talking picture, which was first released four years ago, will begin a revival engagement at the Hollywood Theatre tomorrow night. The picture was directed by Alfred E. Green and is based on the stage play by Louis N. Parker

Criticism of Senator William E. Borah and the announcement of a renewed campaign for United States participation in the League of Nations marked the annual meeting last night of the Greater New York Branch of the League of Nations Association. The meeting was at the Fraternity Clubs Building, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

Judge Seabury's recommendation that the magistrates and Special Sessions courts be consolidated should meet with approval from the bar. By such consolidation the jurisdiction now in the Special Sessions judges could be vested in an Appellate or Special Term of the new magistrates court -- and magistrates particularly qualified for this work could be assigned to it.
Sylvia H. Ross, who has been employed by Harlem Savings Bank more than three years, has been elected assistant secretary by the trustees.

The Regional Labor Board moved yesterday to compel laundries here to abide by the provisions of the State Minimum Wage Law. It considered complaints against nine laundries in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx whose workers have been on strike.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The names of prominent Republicans, including Patrick J. Hurley, former Secretary of War; Mabel Walker Willebrandt, former Assistant Attorney General; W.P. McCracken, former Assistant Secretary of Commerce; Edward T. Clark, former secretary to President Coolidge, and even Herbert Hoover himself, were drawn into the evidence heard today by a Senate committee investigating air mail contracts.

BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- Stocks turned soft at today's session of the Boerse, some leaders losing up to 3 points. The average change, however, was only fractional, some specialties even able to register gains. Heavy industrials were reactionary from the start.
DENVER, Jan. 9.--Two persons were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of gold hoarding in violation of President Roosevelt's executive order.
BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- All bank and trust companies meeting here today reduced their boards of directors to the legal twenty-five members.

The First National Bank may have to choose between a change in its present name or participating in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Jackson E. Reynolds, president of the bank, told the stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- A bill providing for the construction of one 15,000-ton aircraft carrier, 99,200 aggregate tons of destroyers and 35,500 tons of submarines to replace over-age under-surface craft was introduced in the House today by Representative Vinson of Georgia, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee.

To Wall Street, particularly the commission houses, yesterday was just another day in one of the longest dull periods in recent months. There was no brokerage business, there was no market activity, so the professional traders simply dawdled. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 870,000 shares -- not half of what is required to keep the market machinery going profitably.

Frank A. Vanderlip, former president of the National City Bank, defended President Roosevelt's monetary policies as "intelligent and astute" in a debate last night between hard and soft money advocates at the Smith College Club of New York.
BERLIN, Jan. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 6 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- Personal opposition to the child labor amendment as tending to "weaken the rights of the States, and what is worse still, the rights of parents over their children" has been expressed by Cardinal O'Connell.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 9. -- In a radio broadcast this evening President Abelardo Rodriguez outlined and defended the governmental program for the establishment of minimum wages for Mexican workmen, which went into effect on Jan. 1.
Here's William Tatum Tilden 2d, racquet in hand, awaiting the onset of another young chap who plans -- or hopes -- to run the old gentleman (just in a manner of speaking) ragged on the tennis court.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 9. -- H. Douglas (Sonny) Johnson Jr., 14-year-old Syracuse schoolboy for whom police throughout the State had been searching for a week, walked in the front door of his home here tonight as suddenly and as unexpectedly as he had vanished.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 9. -- The Mercantile Commerce Bank and Trust Company today revamped its board of directors to conform to the Glass-Steagall Act, but retained as a director Albert M. Keller, senior partner of Paul Brown Co., despite the act's requirement for the elimination of investment bankers from the boards of commercial banks.

The Dowager Lady Roberts is among the passengers scheduled to leave today for Mediterranean ports on the Roma of the Italian Line. Others sailing include Mrs. Alvin T. Fuller; T. Leslie Shear, and Mrs. Shear; Mr. and Mrs. Goldwaite H. Dorr, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel R. Milbank, Mrs. John J. Bush, Lawrence Bunker, the Rev. and Mrs. B.D. Chambers and Mr. and Mrs. L.H.D. Sutherland.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 9. -- Theodore Wold, senior vice president since 1919, was elected today president of the Northwestern National Bank and Trust Company of Minneapolis. He succeeds Edward W. Decker, who declined re-election as president of the bank and as chairman of the board of the Northwest Bancorporation.

A court-house superstition was revived in the Bronx yesterday, when four little starlings flew into the third-floor corridor of the Supreme Court Building and chattered merrily outside a room where Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo was hearing a case.
Without departing from the measured process of the last few days, the share market managed yesterday to edge forward for an average gain of about a point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Federal, State and municipal purchasing agents, buyers for colleges and universities and spokesmen for the farmers and for the largest mail-order houses in the United States protested at an NRA hearing today against price rises under codes of fair competition.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Action to separate two banks from security affiliates was taken at stockholders' meeting today, while in others there were withdrawals of directors because of their security business connections.
MONTREAL, Jan. 9. -- The international collegiate hockey games are over for another season, with McGill University again the outstanding sextet.
" Re-Echo," a play by I.J. Golden, opens this evening at the Forrest Theatre.

Al Barabas, Columbia University's sophomore halfback who scored the touchdown which enabled the Lions to defeat Stanford in the Rose Bowl, Pasadena, Calif., New Year's Day, returned to Jersey City, his home town, last night and received a noisy reception from a crowd of 8,000 persons.

DALLAS, Texas, Jan. 9. -- Election of R.H. Stewart, vice chairman, as chairman of the board of the First National Bank in Dallas and reduction of the boards of the First and Republic National Bank and Trust Company were the principal changes at the annual meetings today of bank stockholders and directors.

Educational programs for world peace and to meet the problems of legalized liquor were endorsed in resolutions adopted yesterday at the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the Home Missions Council and the Council of Women for Home Missions.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- In his annual report, submitted to the Legislature today, State Controller John McCutcheon showed an anticipated cash surplus for the end of the current fiscal year of $153,877, with a prospect of considerably more due to liquor taxes.

Plans for the New York observance of President Roosevelt's birthday on Jan. 30 with the object of arranging a number of balls and dinners for the benefit of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation were discussed yesterday at a luncheon given by Frank W. Smith, president of the New York Edison Company and chairman of the local committee for the celebration.

Armed with detailed reports showing a grave condition in the city's finances, Mayor LaGuardia will meet Governor Lehman in Albany at noon today in an effort to obtain either power to cut the city's expenses or a larger share of State taxes to replenish its empty coffers.

If the pending Federal loan and grant of $23,160,000 for completion of the city's new subway system should fall through, more than $152,000,000 already spent on the unfinished lines will lie idle indefinitely while interest on the city's investment keeps piling up, according to a report submitted to Mayor LaGuardia yesterday by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Three emergency Banking bills were passed by the 1934 Legislature at its organization session today and adjournment was taken until next Monday evening.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9 (32).--Johnny Risko, the Cleveland baker boy, pounded out an easy ten-round decision tonight over Jimmy Maloney, Boston heavyweight, in the first major light of the Winter season here.

Two magazines devoted to graphic art are at hand: The Print Collector's Quarterly (English) and Prints, an American bi-monthly. The latter contains these articles: "John W. Winkler, Master of Line," by John Taylor Arms; "Fine Prints of the Year 1933," by Fritz K. Ruprecht; "The Society of American Etchers Eighteenth Annual," by Dorothy Noyes Arms;

Definite indications that the new year is bringing with it an early upward surge in business activity were given yesterday by figures which show that the number of retail buyers arriving in the local wholesale markets for the week ended yesterday was the largest for any similar period in four years.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 9. -- In the first battle of the new phase of the Chaco war, the Paraguayans today captured Fort Camacho after a short but intensive assault, according to a communique issued at Asuncion tonight. The capture of Fort Esteros, said to have been abandoned by the Bolivians, was announced earlier.
TOKYO, Jan. 9. -- The proposals to make Henry Pu Yi hereditary monarch of Manchukuo are now approaching maturity in Hsinkiang.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,165,950 barrels, compared with 2,139,850 in the previous week, an increase of 26,100 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Rises of 15,200 and 14,700 barrels, respectively, in California and Texas and a decline of 17,700 in Oklahoma were the most important changes.

Two movements from the String Quartet in F, Op. 135, arranged for string orchestra will be added to the all-Beethoven program with which Arturo Toscanini will make his return as Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra conductor at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night.
The last ten minutes were the hardest for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last might.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Organized opposition to the St. Lawrence waterways treaty developed today as President Roosevelt was preparing a message on the treaty to be sent to the Senate tomorrow.

Leading corporation printers yesterday advanced prices on percales 1/2 cent a yard above the levels named a few weeks ago. The 80 squares were put at 13 1/2 cents for the jobbing trade, the 68-72s at 12 cents and the 64-60s at 11 cents. Prices to manufacturers were 1/4 of a cent below these levels.

A further sinking of prices of United States Government bonds contrasted with generally higher quotations for domestic corporation issues and leading foreign loans in yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Long-term Treasury issues were driven down 2-32 to 23-32 point on transactions of $5,765,200, compared with the turnover of $16,213,200 for the market as a whole.

Fritz Kreisler, noted Austrian violinist, who retains his residence in Berlin and makes concert tours in the United States, returned yesterday on the Aquitania after spending the holidays in Austria and Germany. For the first time in thirty years, he said, Mrs. Kreisler did not accompany him. She remained in Berlin on account of her health.
ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, en route to Little America, Jan. 9. -- The flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition was crawling this afternoon through the Devil's Graveyard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- American Federation of Labor officials are watching with a critical eye the assumption by Alexander Troyanovsky of his duties as Ambassador, in particular in relation to the Soviet pledge against encouragement by Moscow of Communist activities in this country.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- Orders of the Public Service Commission directed against the Staten Island Edison Corporation's issue of $7,500,000 bonds were affirmed by the Court of Appeals today. By a divided court last June the Appellate Division affirmed the orders, and the corporation appealed.

Republican organization leaders have grown restive in the last week over what they consider the failure of Mayor LaGuardia to give to their organizations patronage commensurate with the part they played in electing the Fusion ticket.

By this time it is evident that Nazi doctrine enjoys a more solid support in the German concentration camps than in the German churches. In the recent plebiscite on HITLER'S policy the vote in the prison camps showed a higher percentage for the Government than in the country at large.

Price movements were highly irregular yesterday in the commodity markets. In most items the trading volume shrank substantially. While contract prices were generally lower, cash quotations were higher.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9. -- Macdonald Smith, winner of the Los Angeles open golf championship for the fourth time yesterday, received $1,375 as his share of the $5,500 prize money, tournament officials announced today. Smith scored 280 for the seventy-two holes.
Harpo Marx, who has three brothers but has no relation to Karl Marx, returned on the French liner Ile de France yesterday after a visit to Soviet Russia.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP). -- Giuseppe Zangara, the assassin who killed Mayor Anton Cermak of Chicago when he fired upon President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt in Bayfront Park at Miami last Feb. 15, had "a normal brain," according to Dr. Adolph Meyer of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.

Four indictments have been voted by the additional New York County grand jury which is investigating charges of graft in the issuance of liquor licenses, it was reported yesterday. The indictments, naming four persons whose identity was kept secret, are the first of the inquiry.

Massachusetts awarded yesterday $1,500,000 of notes. The Lee Higginson Corporation and Whiting, Weeks Knowles obtained the block of $1,000,000 due on Nov. 22 next at their joint bid of a 1.80 per cent basis. Ten other bids were entered, the second highest being a 1.97 per cent basis, by the Shawmut Corporation of Boston, and the third 2.12 per cent by the Guaranty Company of New York.

Commissioner Sidney S. Levine of the Bureau of Licenses called Herman B. Sarno to the witness stand yesterday to explain the "thousands of dollars" which Mr. Levine's law firm has been accused of accepting privately to procure city licenses for news stand operators.

The money market continued dull, and except for a little sixty-day money at 1 per cent and some outside funds against call loans at 3/4@ 7/8 there was little else of interest in the day's trading. All sections maintained their rates on small turnover.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9.--Retail food prices continued to recede during the two weeks ending Dec. 19. 1933, showing a decrease of one and one-half per cent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department announced today.
ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- The Republicans in the Assembly were still in a deadlock today over the election of a Clerk.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- The stock market was quieter today, but there were good features. Outstanding was a sharp rise in British Government funds, the result of a steady investment demand. Most foreign bonds were better, particularly Germans, on the better attitude toward creditors.

Lincoln Ellsworth's Monday dispatch, telling of conditions in the Bay of Whales, on which Little America is situated, emphasized the problem which will confront Admiral Byrd when he gets through the Ross Sea pack ice and turns toward his old base.

With the formal casting of one ballot, William A. Dalton was inducted into office last night for his first full term as president of the New York Athletic Club. He moved into the office with the pledge that there never would be any curtailment of the athletic activities of the club while he held his position.

BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- The flames of the Protestant rebellion against Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller continued to burn fiercely today as the 6,000 insurgent ministers of the Pastors Emergency Federation consolidated their ranks.

President Roosevelt sent a message yesterday to leaders of the automobile industry congratulating them on their contribution to national recovery and wishing the industry "still greater progress" in 1934.
MOSCOW, Jan. 9. -- "Our country never knew such a harvest as that of 1933," reads a banner headline in Izvestia, which publishes figures for the total grain collections for the year.

Sometimes an insignificant litigant with a trifling case brings about a judicial decision of the most far-reaching importance. As HOOKER said of the law, its care extends to "the least" as well as the greatest. JOHN and ROSALA BLAISDELL, his wife, of Minnesota, could not pay the interest on a mortgage which they had given.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Many New York sportsmen doubtless will be interested in the views of George W. McKenzie, president of the Brooklyn Chapter, Izaak Walton League of America. Mr. McKenzie has a theory that the efforts of sportsmen in New York State to codify game laws are likely to meet with great opposition.

Wholesale prices of the four leading brands of cigarettes were established at $6.10 a thousand yesterday, less the usual discounts of 10 per cent and 2 per cent. The new price represents an advance of 60 cents a thousand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Security issues totaling $8,000,000, of which $7,000,000 represents new capital, are contemplated in registration statements filed with the Federal Trade Commission under the Securities Act and made public today. Beverage industries account for $5,000,000 of the total.

In his letter to Mr. LAGUARDIA, Governor LEHMAN said that in "certain specific instances" the Mayor might need more authority than he could exercise under existing law. In such cases he urged him to make his wishes known in the form of a bill to accomplish a definite and particular purpose.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Two bills awaiting quick action and seeking to extend the life of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and to increase its funds for additional loans, were before the Senate and House Banking and Currency Committees today.

When the Irish steward in the story was asked by his landlord to render a detailed account of expenditures, he regarded it as a deadly personal insult and challenged the owner of the estate to fight a duel. Something akin to this resentment was displayed by several of the spending commissions at the President's proposal to have their expenses controlled by the Director of the Budget and audited by the Controller General.

Mrs. Lois Spreckels, former wife of John L. de Ruyter, won yesterday her application to Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins for the custody of her infant sons, Jack and Michael de Ruyter, when the court ruled that, although the custody of the children was given to their father under a separation agreement, "children are not chattels subject to bargain and sale."

The Senate has adopted a resolution asking several questions which have already been answered. It wishes to know how much was collected up to Dec. 31 in processing taxes on farm products, under the Agricultural Adjustment Act, and how much was disbursed from the fund thus collected.

After three months of study and conference, the committee of the American Steamship Owners Association in charge of the drafting of a code for the industry completed its work yesterday. The original draft, finished about a month ago, was modified and the new proposal will be submitted to W.H. Davis, deputy administrator of the National Industrial Recovery Administration, tomorrow in Washington.

In your editorial "Silver and the Orient" you make a statement likely to puzzle many. You say that India and China buy silver with goods and not goods with silver, implying that any increase in the value of their silver due to the President's silver proclamation will not increase their buying power.

In your issue of Jan. 6 there appeared a story regarding the Musicians Union's meeting, at which Walter Reid, president of a theatre owners' organization, informed this gathering that I, among others, was against Sunday night performances in the legitimate theatre.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9. -- Hirsch Jacobs, who saddled more winners than any other trainer in 1933, scored a double at Tropical Park here today when he sent out Fredrick and Waterway to win in the B.B. Stable colors. Both racers were piloted by Jockey Earl Porter, leading rider here, who brought his string of triumphs for the meeting to twenty.

Fifty couples, all of whom were married more than forty years ago and all of whom marched down the church aisles to Mendelssohn's wedding march, will be guests of Dr. Walter Damrosch at the Mendelssohn celebration at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 17.

Ellsworth Vines makes his professional debut tonight against William Tilden, and the indications are that Madison Square Garden will be filled to capacity, except possibly in the lowest priced section in the gallery.

A special committee of directors of the Chase National Bank, with Elihu Root Jr. as counsel, has been formed to investigate the disclosures concerning the bank made before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee with a view to establishing claims against former officials of the institution, it was announced yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, executive head of the bank, at the annual meeting of shareholders.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- Guarded by a triple cordon of policemen on foot and by Republican Guards on horseback the French Parliament began a new session today. The public was not permitted to approach the Chamber of Deputies as it was feared there would be manifestations because of the scandal surrounding the collapse of the Bayonne municipal pawn shop.

ISTANBUL, Jan. 9. -- The Council of Ministers made public today a five-year ecoonmic plan that has been under examination for some weeks and has thereby officially asserted the government's determination to enter whole-heartedly into industry.
LONDON, Jan. 9. -- A gigantic Anglo-American recovery program on Rooseveltian lines was urged by H.G. Wells tonight in an address to millions of radio listeners on both sides of the Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Emma Goldman, famous anarchist deported by the United States fifteen years ago, has received permission to enter the country for ninety days to visit relatives.

The management of individual enterprise in industry must look forward to many new conditions of existence and management in the near future and expect regimenting authority either by industry itself or by the State, it was said last night by Dr. Harlow S. Person, director of the Taylor Society.

The Metropolitan debuts of Cyrena Van Gordon, American mezzo-soprano, and Carlo Del Corso, Italian dramatic tenor; the return of Elisabeth Rethberg, the revivals of Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" and Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" and the season's first performances of "Madama Butterfly" and "Il Trovatore" will be among the leading events of the opera's fourth week next week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- While Senate leaders prepared today to call up the Liquor Tax Bill tomorrow, the House adopted without record vote a beverage control plan for the District of Columbia that would change the national capital from a bone-dry city to one of the most "liberal" spots in the country.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Stockholders of the First National Bank of Chicago ratified today the sale of $25,000,000 of preferred stock to the RFC and reduced the board of directors from forty-three to twenty-five members.

Thunders from the Bronx and Washington have rolled harmlessly over Mr. CURRY'S head so far. He can be dislodged from his fortress only by his own chieftains; and a change in leadership wouldn't imply change in Tammany Hall. Mr. FARLEY and Mr. FLYNN did their best to prevent the success of the Fusion ticket.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Discovery of what was described by officials as a new form of "chiseling" on the farm recovery program resulted today in a warning by the AAA against the practice.

VIENNA, Jan. 9. -- That only deeds and not words will check Nazi terrorism in Austria was indicated today as several bomb outrages answered the government's proclamation last night warning that the severest measures would be taken against the authors of political outrages and calling on loyal Austrians for assistance.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 9. -- At the annual meeting of the Commerce Trust Company today, F.C. Marqua, an assistant vice president, became a vice president. George W. Dillon, a vice president and secretary to the board of directors, no longer will be listed as a director, having resigned from the board, which was reduced.

Senator William E. Borah of Idaho, in his address before the Council on Foreign Relations here Monday night, described -- without specific mention of either Chancellor Hitler or Germany -- the situation "in one of the leading countries of Europe."
Assured of full police cooperation, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., new Commissioner of Markets, began yesterday to lay the groundwork for his campaign to drive racketeers from the markets of the city.

An attempt to provide an international match for the world's welterweight boxing championship was launched yesterday when Charles J. Harvey, acting as manager of Jack Hood, English boxer who holds the European title, filed with the State Athletic Commission, a challenge to Jimmy McLarnin, world's champion.

Restoration of Bryant Park and conversion of the expensive Central Park Casino into a moderate-price restaurant within reach of all were among the proposals discussed yesterday by the Park Association of New York City, Inc., at its annual meeting.

Yesterday was "stage, screen and radio day" at the automobile show in Grand Central Palace. A number of celebrities in these and allied fields viewed the hundreds of car models and accessory displays on exhibit.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 9 (AP). -- The Algiers observatory announced today the discovery of two previously unreported small planets in a group of asteroids circulating between Mars and Jupiter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Burning of official and personal files of Walter F. Brown while he was Postmaster General was alleged today at a hearing before the Senate committee which is investigating air mail contracts. Testimony was also given that Mr. Brown, as Postmaster General, set up more than 5,000 miles of air mail line extensions without competitive bidding.

ROSELLE PARK, N.J., Jan. 9. -Edward F. Smith, 61 years old, a retired business man of Altadena, Calif., shot and killed his wife, Nellie, 57, and then killed himself this morning at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Wells of 24 Grand Avenue, where the couple had been guests since November. Mrs. Wells is a sister of the dead woman.

Continuance of investment purchases marked the urban realty trading reported yesterday. Daniel Brener, operator, bought a four-story business building at 229 West Fifty-eighth Street, near Broadway, assessed at $94,000 and subject to a $27,000 mortgage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- President Roosevelt ended today any hopes of restoration of Federal pay cuts by issuing an executive order continuing until June 30 the 15 per cent reduction of the Economy Act. The order was interpreted as additional evidence of the President's determination to hold regular budget expenditures to a minimum.
Setting a fast pace from start to finish, the Manhattan basketball team defeated the Seventh Regiment quintet, 38 -- 18, in the winners gymnasium last night.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 9. -- That the President's birthday ball for the benefit of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation will be the largest and most brilliant event held here in many seasons is evinced by the list of patrons and patronesses, released today by Hugh Dillman, Palm Beach chairman, and numbering about 200.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- The greatly improved New York Americans, aided by the sensational defensive play of their goalie, Roy Worters, and Bill Brydge, tonight topped the Boston Bruins, 2 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game. It was the home club's fourth straight defeat.

More than 500 stockholders attended the annual meeting of the National City Bank yesterday, the largest gathering in the bank's history, and approved the capital changes, including the sale of $50,000,000 of preferred stock to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the reduction of the present common capital stock by $46,500,000 to $77,500,000.

Ely Culbertson and Theodore A. Lightner had gone into the lead in the first annual contract bridge pair championship of the United States Bridge Association when play closed early this morning at the Hotel Pierre. Twenty teams are still left in the pair event, which will come to a close this evening.

A decision upholding the rights of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum as sole owner of the property at the northwest corner of Seventy-seventh Street and Third Avenue was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller in a suit by the orphanage against the city of New York for a ruling that the city has no interest that would be-cloud the title.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9. -The annual slate of nominations for vacancies which will come this Spring in the Harvard board of overseers and Harvard alumni offices was mailed today to more than 50,000 alumni.
I doubt whether I have ever read anything more interesting than the letter from Henry Wollman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The alphabetical excrescences of our al ready swollen Federal bureaucracy should not take too much encouragement from the Supreme Court decision in the recent Minnesota case.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 9. -- Finding two coveys and handling them perfectly, Last Word, white-and-liver pointer owned and handled by L.M. Bobbitt of Winston-Salem, N.C., captured the amateur all-age stake in the Pinehurst Field Trial Club's meet today. Eight dogs competed.

Plans for the formation of a Democratic organization in Manhattan opposed to and designed to replace Tammany were disclosed yesterday by local supporters of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman. It is expected that a start will be made this week by the selection of a chairman of a general committee.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, noted woman suffrage leader and peace advocate, was honored yesterday on her seventy-fifth birthday by 200 women at a luncheon at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East Sixty-sixth Street. The luncheon was given by the Leslie Woman Suffrage Commission's continuing committee, of which Mrs. F. Louis Slade is chairman.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 9. -The assets of the Huguenot Trust Company of New Rochelle, taken over last week by the Superintendent of Banks, amount to $3,937,426, it developed here today when George A. Porter, Deputy Superintendent of Banks, filed an inventory.

A.G. Spalding Bros. report for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, a net loss of $1,962,002, after all charges and reserves, including a reserve of $245,706, against loss through future declines in foreign exchange rates. The report, however, included in the income account an trend of $377,544 to cover "appreciation in asset values account of foreign exchange.

BERLIN, Jan. 9 -- An optimistic view of the trade opportunities between the United States and Russia -- "that land of unlimited possibilities and great achievements" -- was voiced today by Leo Chintchuk, Soviet Ambassador to Berlin, in a luncheon speech before the American Chamber of Commerce of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The attitude of the national administration toward the reorganization of Tammany Hall was defined today by one close to the President as hopeful that it would be brought about naturally without forcing the Democrats of New York City into an unseemly party fight.

John P. O'Brien, former Mayor, returned yesterday to active practice of the law. As special counsel to a committee of the National Association of Retail Tailors, Dyers and Cleaners, he visited District Attorney Dodge and urged him to start a drive on more than 100 employers for violating the NRA code.

The State Civil Works Administration yesterday took what was regarded as the first step toward decentralization of the vast CWA machinery when Alfred H. Schoellkopf, chairman of the administration, announced the creation of two new civil works administrations within the State organization to facilitate the operation of park projects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- An end of the decline in industrial production for several months following the July peak is chronicled today by the Commerce Department in its monthly survey of the business situation. In some lines a moderate improvement was noted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Once again the Supreme Court of the United States has dealt with the Constitution as a flexible instrument in a national emergency, deliberately couched in general terms by its framers so that it may be interpreted in the light of existing conditions.
Walter F. Brown, former Postmaster General, said here yesterday that he merely removed his personal files from the office of the Postmaster General.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Supreme Court's decision yesterday upholding the Minnesota Moratorium Law and thus giving evident support to emergency powers incident to the New Deal program was widely discussed today, both among exponents of the program and its opponents.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 9. -- It was learned today that the Dutch Government managed to obtain full German interest payments for Dutch bondholders for the second half of 1933 in recent negotiations by threatening to deduct the amount of interest due from the money Holland has to pay for the delivery of German goods, as the British Government is threatening to do.

Magistrate Brodsky in the Tombs Court yesterday reserved until Friday his decision on the charge that Philip H. Philbin Jr. had violated the General Business Law by refusing to answer questions in the Attorney General's office on his activities in transactions of the Atlas Tack Corporation.

Unemployed artists demonstrated yesterday in front of the offices of Mrs. Juliana R. Force, chairman of the New York regional committee of the Public Works of Art Project, in the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street. The demonstrators, members of the Unemployed Artists Association, charged discrimination in the placing of artists in jobs.

The National Orchestral Association marked the half-way point of its season yesterday in Carnegie Hall by presenting before a full house of subscribing members, as well as many other hearers by radio, a program of sharply awakening interest in New York's crowded calendar.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Princeton scored its second straight victory in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight, easily defeating Columbia in the Lions' first league contest, 42 -- 21. The triumph gave the Tigers undisputed possession of first place.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Miss Margaret Trumbull Corwin of New Haven, Conn., executive secretary of the Yale University Graduate School, has been named dean of the New Jersey College for Women to succeed the late Mrs. Mabel Smith Douglass. The announcement was made today by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University. Dean Corwin will take charge of her new work shortly after the beginning of the second semester in February.

Operation by the city of the three incinerating plants of the Brooklyn Ash Removal Company will result in a saving to the citizens of upward of $1,000,000 a year, Acting Sanitation Commissioner E.P. Goodrich estimated yesterday. The plants were taken over by the city at midnight on Monday.
In another instalment of his final report yesterday Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, urged the restoration of teachers' salaries to the level of 1932.

A legacy of the bank-merging days of 1929 and 1930 turned up yesterday at the annual meetings of the Chase National Bank and the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company. It was disclosed that the Chase Corporation, affiliate of the Chase National, owned 77,010 shares, or more than 10 per cent of the stock of the Corn Exchange.

Harry F. Wolf, Ne:v York A. C. ace and holder of the national championship, gave a masterful exhibition of his skill to advance to the third round as play was resumed in the annual Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 9. -Joseph Cerardi, 34 years old, of Ridgefield Park, a former boxer, who was questioned about the Lindbergh kidnapping, was arrested here tonight charged with having held his wife a prisoner in a locked room for almost two years.

The Lilienfeld-Van Diemen Galleries, which have not taken an active part in the exhibition world for some time, opened yesterday an old-master show called "Six Centuries and Six Countries." Most of the paintings have just been brought over from Europe.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels ruled yesterday that three contracts totaling $326,213, awarded by William J. Flynn in the closing days of his administration as Bronx Commissioner of Public Works, were not made in the public interest and therefore were illegal.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9. -- H.G. Knott's Happy Lad, piloted by Jack Westrope, scored a driving halflength victory over A.G. Tarn's Abstain in the mile and a sixteenth race which held the feature position on today's card at Jefferson Park. George Collins's Thistle Fyrn was third.

Satisfaction at the defeat of the proposed bill to repeal the existing legislation prohibiting the attendance of unaccompanied children under the age of 16 at moving picture theatres was expressed yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, held at the organization's headquarters, 2 East 105th Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9. -- The Hitler regime cannot last in Germany more than ten years in the opinion of Professor Albert Einstein, who came here today to receive a silver loving cup from Northeast High School and was cheered by 1,500 pupils.

MONTREAL, Jan. 9 (AP). -- The little veteran Aurel Joliat and young Jack Riley teamed tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 3 -- 2 victory over the Montreal Maroons. The victors thus protected their hold on second place in the National Hockey League's international section.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

A decision in a test case to determine the right of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company to withhold payment of the semiannual interest on bonds due on Nov. 1 last on the ground of the German moratorium was handed down yesterday by Municipal Court Justice James S. Watson, who rejected the steamship company's defense to a suit for $30 and directed summary judgment for the bondholder.

A new Reformation which may save the world from war and social chaos was reported last night by speakers at a meeting of the Oxford Group which filled the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel. Philip Marshall Brown, Professor of International Law at Princeton University, declared that this new Reformation was sweeping England and presented a challenge to this country.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 9. -- Stockholders of the First and Merchants National Bank at their annual meetings today did not act on the directors' recommendation that $300,000 in preferred stock be issued. The annual meeting was adjourned until Jan. 23.
