CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- The limited movement of cash grain to terminal markets throughout the country is commencing to affect futures, and removal of hedges against shipping sales helped today to advance prices on the Board of Trade. Kansas City reported sales of 500,000 bushels of cash wheat to mills overnight and some hedges against the business were removed here.

SEATTLE, Jan. 9 (AP). -- A 5,000-mile honeymoon voyage to the Orient, with the bride and bridegroom on separate ships and a great stretch of the Pacific Ocean between them, was arranged here today by the subpoena-dodging Prince Alexis Mdivani for himself and the former Barbara Hutton, American heiress.

With their knowledge of hockey and playing experience increased, members of the Morristown School hockey squad arrived home yesterday in the Cunard liner Aquitania after their invasion of Switzerland, during which they had won three of eight games played.
Small housing properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- The Suez Company announced today a long-awaited reduction in Suez Canal transit tolls. Beginning April 1 the charge to ships carrying freight through the canal will be reduced from 6 francs a ton to 5 3/4 francs per ton, while for ships carrying ballast the rate will be 3 francs.
Four Manhattan properties and eight parcels in the Bronx were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. One scheduled sale in each borough was adjourned.
ABANY, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- Paul Orsell, New York City construction engineer, won a reversal of a manslaughter conviction and a new trial in a decision today by the Court of Appeals.

The rehabilitation of the German refugees may require the expenditure of from $25,000,000 to $50,000,000, James G. McDonald, League of Nations High Commissioner for German Refugees and honorary chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, estimated last night at a dinner in his honor at the Town Hall Club.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Declaring that the people of New Jersey "must have help to keep their homes and a substantial part of that help must be real relief from burdensome taxation," Governor Moore today, in his annual message to the Legislature, proposed that a general sales tax be imposed for a period of three years.

Police Commissioner O'Ryan reduced one inspector and transferred him, and shifted the assignments of five other inspectors and deputy inspectors yesterday. The orders, made public by Chief Inspector Lewis J. Valentine, went into effect at 4 P.M.

PEIPING, Jan. 9. -- Official Chinese circles in Henry Pu Yi's old capital are buzzing with anticipation. Peiping newspapers, Chinese official quarters, Manchu princes and other retainers of the fallen dynasty are chiefly concerned over whether Pu Yi's elevation to Emperor of Manchukuo, if realized, will lead to the eventual extension of Japan's influence over North China and Mongolia.

Contributions for the Neediest Cases were increased by $813.50 yesterday, as a result of gifts received from forty-six donors. This brought the current fund to $230,281.02, or $38,218.81 less than the total received last year.
George Blumenthal, retired banker, philanthropist and art patron, was elected president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday to succeed William Sloane Coffin, who died on Dec. 16.

The Herman Ridder soccer team of the Bronx, defending titleholder, battled to a 1-all deadlock with East New York of Brooklyn in the city Junior High P.S.A.L. championship final at the Wingate Athletic Field in Brooklyn yesterday. Six overtime periods, two of three minutes each, three of four minutes and finally one of five minutes, were held, with no winning tally forthcoming from either team.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The tremendous scope of the activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was pictured in a review of activities from its establishment on Feb. 2, 1932, to Dec. 31, 1933, sent to Congress today. It places at about $6,000,000,000 the total of disbursements and of authorizations made but not yet disbursed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- With the American people generally more optimistic, the new year promises that the racing associations of the nation will have a successful season and that the losses of 1933 will be recouped.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- By unanimous agreement, according to the RFC, Walter J. Cummings, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, was selected today to become chairman of the board of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 9. -Changes in the directorates and readjustments of capital structures marked the annual elections in four Buffalo commercial banks. Changes in directorates, officials said, were in compliance with requirements of the National Banking Act, which ordered elimination of joint bank and investment affiliate directorships.
WASHINGTON, Pa., Jan. 9.Henry Ford is interested in perpetuating the memory of the birthplace of William Holmes McGuffey, author of the McGuffey Readers of public school fame.

One of the largest commercial rentals in recent weeks was reported yesterday in 10 East Fortieth Street, where the Chase Brass and Copper Company, a Kennecott subsidiary, leased the four upper floors in the tower of the forty-eight story structure.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- The first liquor-control bill of the present legislative session will appear in the Senate tomorrow under the sponsorship of Senator Desmond of Orange County. It will put the State into the liquor business, eliminating to a large extent private profits from the traffic and bringing substantial new revenues to the State.
Reports of annual meetings of banks, held yesterday here and in other places, at which important changes were made, follow:
Dr. Harold G. Campbell will succeed Dr. William J. O'Shea as Superintendent of Schools on Feb. 1, according to authoritative information at the Board of Education.

Bringing an exciting day of squash racquets to an end, New York's Class A team turned back Philadelphia yesterday to win th% women's intercity series and thus complete a clean sweep for the metropolitan teams at the Junior League clubhouse.

Charles M. Kinsolving, national vice commander in charge of the Northeastern section of the American Veterans Association, issued a statement yesterday opposing United States Senator D.A. Reed's stand on veterans' legislation and quoting a letter from the Senator from which the association had concluded that he supported it in its opposition to compensation for non-service-connected disabilities.

ALBANY, Jan. 9.--Federal cooperation to prevent a crisis in the New York milk shed was declared essential by Governor Lehman today in an address to several thousand farmers who stormed the capital city.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- The Westminster Bank, last of the "big six" to report, issued its statement for 1933 today. Profits were 1,464,955, against 1,495,172 in 1932. The dividend on the 4 shares was maintained at 18 per cent, with the final payment 9 per cent.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- Royalists rioted near the Chamber of Deputies this evening against what they alleged to be the part of high-placed officials in the collapse of the Bayonne pawnshop and in the death of its founder, Alexandre Stavisky.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 9 (AP). -- It was announced tonight that Equipoise, champion handicap horse, will return to the races this year with the purpose of breaking the money-winning record of Willis Sharpe Kilmer's Sun Beau.

Carl Friedberg gave a piano recital at the Town Hall last night that was distinguished by an authenticity and rectitude of style, brilliance of technic and breadth and profundity of insight that must be the despair of younger and ambitious artists.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 9. -Mrs. M. Ella Ackerman, 51 years old, of Mahwah, wife of Warren A. Ackerman who resigned Jan. 1 as tax collector of Hohokus township, was arrested today charged with embezzlement of municipal funds. She was released in $2,500 bail.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- Enlarged powers for the Board of Estimate, according to a view expressed at the Capitol today, may be the basis on which an agreement will be sought when Governor Lehman and Mayor LaGuardia of New York City meet here tomorrow.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- A letter from President Roosevelt, pointing out that the recovery program is a common task, was incorporated in Governor Moore's message to the Legislature today.

David J. Rosen, 43 years old, an attorney with offices at 1,767 Broadway, was sentenced in the Third District Municipal Court yesterday by Justice Thomas E. Murray to pay a fine of $250 and to serve thirty days in jail for contempt of court.

Business on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was much heavier than the narrow range of fluctuations indicated, and prices rose again, reaching highest marks since September and closing at gains of 4 to 5 points.

Mr. and Mrs. Morton Dean Joyce gave a dinner last night at their home, 1,165 Fifth Avenue, to celebrate the forty-fifth anniversary of the marriage of Mr. Joyce's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William B. Joyce of 975 Park Avenue. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Alanson P. Lathrop, Mr. and Mrs. Edgar S. Bloom, Mrs. Hugh Lord and Edward A. St. John.

OTTAWA, Jan. 9 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons, Toronto Maple Leafs and Ottawa Senators have joined in requesting a special meeting of the National Hockey League governors to review the suspension and reinstatement of Eddie Shore of the Boston Bruins, President Frank Ahearn of the Ottawa club said today.

Your Topics of The Times is right about slang. When slang sinks roots into the sod and becomes a hardy perennial, it has supplied, as the ductless glanders say, a thyroid deficiency in our workaday speech. But your piece has a deficiency of its own when you quote "corned beef and cabbage" to point your argument against the "recherche phrase."

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- After negotiations lasting more than a year the new Franco-Russian commercial treaty was completed today, was initialed by the negotiators and soon will be formally signed. The importance of this step reaches far beyond the mere achievement of a trade agreement between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a dinner tonight, entertaining more than 200 additional guests afterward in the East Room of the White House, where a musical program was given by Miss Ellen Ballon, Canadian pianist, and John Goss and his London Singers.

In the face of persistently strong rumors to the contrary, Harry Kipke, head football coach at the University of Michigan, issued a flat denial last night that he is to go to Yale to serve in the same capacity.

Elam Ward Olney, socially prominent and a former stock broker, was rebuked yesterday by Federal Judge Robert D. Patterson, who not only declined to discharge him from bankruptcy, but ruled that his testimony before Referee Harold P. Coffin had been "evasive, flippant and false in so many particulars that no credence could be given to anything he said."

CHICAGO, Jan. 9.--Farmer milk blockaders held up the United States mails tonight in a wave of violence which swept Lake and Cook Countries while leaders of the Pure Milk I Association were negotiating to end the milk strike of its 18,000 farmermembers.

The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company has filed applications with the Federal Reserve System for authority to retain Robert Lehman and Philip Lehman of the firm of Lehman Brothers as directors of the institution, but has submitted only general information with respect to three members of the New York Stock Exchange who are members of its board.
The Supreme Court decision in the matter of emergency legislation is to be hailed with the greatest delight by students of the Constitution everywhere.

TRENTON, Jan. 10. -- Declaring that "immediate action is not only justified, but demanded in public interest," Senator Dryden Kuser of Bernardsville today indicated that the Legislature will be urged to authorize drastic changes in the method of handling State investments.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Prices of grains on the Board of Trade were on the upgrade today and despite profit-taking the close was within a fraction of the top. The feeling toward the buying side was much more friendly than recently and many traders joined those who yesterday had expressed the belief that prices were to work irregularly higher.

Recent restrictions on Jewish immigration into Palestine were protested in a resolution adopted at a joint conference of the American representatives of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, the Zionist Organization of America and twenty other Jewish organizations last night at the Hotel Astor.

A wide change in rate-making policies is to be incorporated in a program of legislation for the present Congress to be discussed at a meeting in Washington for tomorrow of the advisory committee of the Association of Railway Executives.

TOKYO, Jan. 10. -- Ambassador Hiroshi Saito expects to reach Washington toward the end of February and will return to Japan, according to the newspapers here, in May after he has sized up the situation in the United States and discussed Japanese-American relations with American leaders.

When daylight began to penetrate the skylights of the West Fourteenth Street Armory yesterday morning, the 3,000 prize roosters of the fiftieth annual Poultry Show did not begin to crow, for the good reason that they had not stopped.

The Yale Club suffered its first defeat in Group 1 and the Squash Club remained unbeaten in Group 2 as play was resumed in the New York Class C Division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League yesterday after a respite of three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The British Embassy and the Canadian Legation were numerously represented in the audience which attended Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's seventy-first musicale morning at the Mayflower today to welcome and applaud Miss Ellen Ballon, Canadian pianist, and John Goss and his London Singers.
Several store structures were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The final draft of the nation-wide conservation plan which is being made by the Federal Game Bird Restoration Committee will be submitted shortly for Executive approval, according to an announcement from the committee yesterday.

With the volume of trading continuing to dry up, commodity futures turned moderately strong in yesterday's dealings on local markets. Gains were recorded in almost all departments. Cash prices also were higher.
" The Dark Tower" will close its engagement at the Morosco Theatre on Saturday evening. Another departure on that night will be "The First Apple," which will be withdrawn from the Booth Theatre.

Mrs. Stephen Baker was hostess yesterday at the first of a series of six "Debutante Discussions," planned to take place in her home at 993 Fifth Avenue on successive Wednesday afternoons at 3 o'clock. The series is of a religious nature.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Jan. 10. -- Colonel William H. Kelly, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, was appointed tonight trustee for the Fidelity Union Mortgage and Title Guaranty Company of Newark. The company, which is reported to have assets in excess of $96,000,000, has been on a restricted basis since the banking holiday last March.

Controlling at least twelve of the sixteen votes in the Board of Estimate, Mayor LaGuardia can drive through his proposed administrative reforms in accordance with the agreement reached last night in Albany, whereby these changes are entrusted to the board rather than to the Mayor alone.

PARIS, Jan. 10. -- Russia's new commercial treaty with France, initialed yesterday after three years of difficult negotiations, will be signed formally at the Quai d'Orsay tomorrow. It opens to the Soviet Government a huge new avenue of trade barred hitherto by the weird system of special licenses which only the most approved transactions could pass, and its political implications are of the most far-reaching character.
Governor Lehman was asked yesterday by the Consolidated Home Owners Mortgage Committee to recommend enactment of legislation protecting home owners against foreclosures.

So great has been the demand among household staffs for tickets to the Butlers' Ball tomorrow night at the Commodore that members of society face the prospect of homes and apartments devoid of servants for the evening. In view of this situation, Mrs. Marshall Field and members of her committee arranging the party have appealed to headquarters for additional police protection for the properties to be left servantless.

HANKOW, Thursday, Jan. 11. -- While the Szechuan anti-Communist campaign north of the Yangtse from the city of Wanhsien is temporarily pausing, General Liu Hsiang is making desperate efforts to raise money after notification he must assume sole responsibility for coping with the Szechuan Reds. Chiang Kai-shek telegraphed him that Nanking's financial and other resources were entirely absorbed in dealing with the Communist menace in Kiangsi and the Fukien rebellion.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Although purchases of 5,900 hogs were credited to the government today, the offerings were in excess of the demand and prices dropped 5 to 20 cents, with the kinds most favored for relief purposes showing the greatest recession.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Scattered in every section of the United States, 54,000,000 individual bank accounts in 13,431 banks are now protected up to $2,500 by the temporary insurance fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Chairman Walter J. Cummings said today.
THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 5 published a statement from London concerning the expulsion of Jews from certain Afghan cities that to my personal knowledge does not conform to fact.

The Kleemann-Thorman Galleries, formerly at 575 Madison Avenue, reopened this week in spacious new quarters on the second floor at 38 East Fifty-seventh Street with an exhibition representing various nineteenth and twentieth century artists and including work in several mediums.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 10. -- Morton L. Schwartz's Clarify made it two in a row at Tropical Park when he captured the Sarasota Purse, main event on today's card, after being made a 9-to-10 favorite. Scoring easily at the end of the mile the son of Chatterton and Maharanee was timed in 1:38, smart time in view of the drying out condition of the track.

News of a definitely encouraging character supplied a greatly needed stimulus to all the markets yesterday. Stocks, bonds and commodities advanced sharply. Trading was more active on the various exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The entire United States fleet in active commission, more than 100 vessels strong, will be reviewed at New York City by President Roosevelt in June, according to tentative plans announced today by Colonel Henry L. Roosevelt, Acting Secretary of the Navy.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell was elected Superintendent of Schools for a term of six years by unanimous vote of the Board of Education yesterday. He will succeed Dr. William J. O'Shea, the retiring superintendent, on Feb. 1.

The International Longshoremen's Association will ask that the code of ethics for the shipping industry, drafted by the American Steamship Owners Association as a master code and basis of agreements for subdivisions of the industry, be altered with respect to labor provisions when it is submitted to open hearing in Washington.

Real estate sales and rentals in the Scarsdale area showed an approximate gain of 25 per cent during the past year over the records of the previous year, John F. Lucey, executive secretary of the Scarsdale Chapter of the Westchester County Realty Board, announced yesterday.

The New York Police and Fire Departments joined in an impressive tribute yesterday at the funeral services of Patrolman Ernest F. McCarron of Brooklyn, who lost his life early last Sunday morning in a vain attempt to rescue a 9-year-old girl from a burning apartment.

There are at least seven different ways of setting about the task of simplifying the structure of local government in this city. In the light of the controversy that has arisen between the Governor and the Mayor, resulting in their conference yesterday, it may be worth while to set them forth:

Hatters all over the country were interested yesterday when Stephen L. Stetson, who is the grandnephew of John B. Stetson and the grandson of Napoleon Stetson, "the first hatter in the Stetson family," came to legal blows with the John B. Stetson Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, told newspaper men today that although Russia had not yet discussed a political or commercial non-aggression pact with the United States she would be glad to do so if it proved necessary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Senator Wagner's report, opposing ratification of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty, held that the treaty would impose costs upon the public which would be two to three times as great as the savings conferred.

Stockholders of the Marine Midland Trust Company at their annual meeting yesterday approved the proposal of directors for re-capitalization, involving the reduction of capital from $10,000,000 to $5,000,000 and the transfer of the difference to surplus account.

Hervey Allen's novel, "Anthony Adverse," had not long been off the presses when letters and telephone calls drawing attention to Mr. Allen's indebtedness to certain old books as sources for many incidents in his novel began coming in to the offices of literary and news editors, to the publishers, Farrar Rinehart, and to Mr. Allen.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Sixty-nine per cent of the 1,446 national banks unlicensed on March 16, 1933, had been licensed, chartered, absorbed or placed in receivership by Dec. 31, the Controller of the Currency, J.F.T. O'Connor, announced today.

Jack Sherry, 220, Ohio, threw Ivan Vakturoff, 220, Russia, with an airplane spin and body slam after 25:36 of the feature finish wrestling match before 1,500 persons last night at the St. Nicholas Arena. Vakturoff substituted for Vanka Zelezniak.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company reports, for 1933 a net income of $21,153,721 after all charges, taxes and depreciation. This is equal to $2.11 a share on the combined 10,000,000 shares of common and Class B stocks outstanding. For the preceding year, the company reported a net income of $33,674,800 or $3.36 a share on the outstanding stock.

Samuel Seabury, moving spirit of the fusion organization that elected Mayor LaGuardia, appealed yesterday for public support of the Mayor's program in a speech at the weekly luncheon of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAlpin. It was Mr. Seabury's first address commenting on the new administration in action.

Janet Penserosa, who is now approaching her seventh birthday, has recovered her health. Yesterday, in the chilly air of the Bronx, she hoisted her 106 pounds 8 ounces to the flying trapeze in a manner that belied her name. In New York this is not usually a matter of public interest, but the recovery of Janet is regarded as important not only in the Bronx but all over the scientific world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh received an outright gift of 25,000 shares of Transcontinental Air Transport stock, then valued at $250,000, in addition to his salary of $10,000 a year for associating himself with that company, according to letters introduced today as evidence before the Senate committee investigating air mail contracts.

Indictments accusing three detectives of the East Fifty-first Street Station of having aided Eric St. John, a Negro, filing clerk in the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, in obtaining graft in connection with the issuance of liquor licenses were handed up yesterday to General Sessions Judge Koenig.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today a message strongly urging ratification of the St. Lawrence Canal treaty as a means of increasing navigation facilities for the Middle Western farmers and producing cheaper electrical power for the Northeastern section of the country.

Gifts to Columbia University aggregating $14,268.32 were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president. Dr. and Mrs. Reginald Auchincloss gave $3,000 for special research in the Department of Chemistry under the direction of Professor Hal T. Beans. Other contributors were as follows:

The annual meeting of the Catholic Big Sisters was held yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Kimball G. Colby, 722 Park Avenue. More than sixty Big Sisters -- several from Jewish and Protestant organizations of the same nature -- assembled to hear reports and addresses by those interested in the Childrens Court.

DETROIT, Jan. 10. -- Henry Ford, the outstanding hold-out against signing an industrial code, broke his long silence today and discussed the efforts of the Washington administration to bring about recovery.
A young woman, apparently refined, was hunted by the police yesterday as the kidnapper of Patricia Luciano, 23 days old, of 251 Seventh Street.
The Columbia swimming team won its second meet of the season last night by defeating Fordham, 50 -- 21, in the Morningside pool. The Lions won six of the eight events.

Two ticket brokerage firms -- the Warfield Ticket Library and the Newman Theatre Ticket Office -- were suspended from doing business for one week because of violations of the legitimate theatre code regulations applying to the sale of tickets, at the regular meeting of the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority held yesterday.

The recital of Caroline Thomas, violinist, which took place in the Town Hall last night, demonstrated the dangers involved in judging an artist's work from a portion of her program. The first half of the recital brought forth Vitali's "Chaconne" and Jules Conus's rather uninteresting concerto.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10. -- The Yale Daily News said today in its Sportocracy column that students of the university want a winning team only legitimately, that they oppose any go-getting policy by the coaches and any special privileges to athletes after they become registered students.

Three of the most significant ballets in the entire history of the dance were given by the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe at the St. James Theatre last night, when "Les Sylphides." "Stravinsky's 'Petrushka" and the Polovitsian dances from Borodin's "Prince Igor," all by Michel Fokine, were added to the repertoire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Henry H. Heimann of Michigan will be director of the Shipping Board Bureau of the Commerce Department, which succeeds the Shipping Board, under an appointment made today by Secretary Roper.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Following is the text of President Rosevelt's message on the St. Lawrence Waterway Treaty:

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 10. -- Reed Smoot, 72 years old today, believes firmly that "America will never fail," and in a birthday statement he expresses "the hope that the year 1934 will be the beginning of the return to normal conditions."

Chief Inspector Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday that "drones and political parasites" were to be weeded out of the Detective Division and transferred to uniform duty, and that Assistant Chief Inspector John J. Sullivan would be held "personally responsible for the efficiency, morale and everything that goes to make up a good detective division."

Increased buying power continued yesterday to absorb contracts released by government agencies and prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced to the highest marks since Sept. 19. The May rose above 11 cents a pound under the most active mill demand in several months and the list closed with gains of 6 to 9 points.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- The removal of Frank J. Clancy, a disabled war veteran, as former inspector of grading and paving in the Queens Department of Public Works, has been upheld in the Court of Appeals. The court reversed the courts below and denied Clancy's petition for reinstatement.

A net loss of somewhat more than $5,000,000 was recorded by the New York Central Railroad in 1933, according to actual figures for the first eleven months and an estimate that in December the company about met interest charges. This would compare with a net loss of $18,256,000 in 1932.

In his speech before the Council on Foreign Relations on Monday evening, Senator BORAH made a moving protest against the frequent assertion, or, as he called it, "solemn pronouncement," that "popular government has "failed and constitutional democracy "is dead."

An application of the Mengel Company for listing 240,000 additional shares of $1 par value stock, which was approved yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange, was the first to contain the agreements recently adopted by the Exchange requiring full publicity on stock options and restricting trading by a company in its own stock.

Field goals by Mike De Angelis and Ernie Morris in the closing-minutes gave the Textile basketball team a 22-to-18 triumph over James Monroe High yesterday in the Textile gymnasium in a non-league game.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking last night at the Women's City Club, made one of her rare excursions into political discussion by referring to the Federal budget deficit.

VIENNA, Jan. 10. -- Nazi violence in Austria continues to increase despite the government's proclamation two days ago that severe measures would be taken. The Nazis are apparently daring Chancellor Dollfuss to fulfill his threats, so that they may obtain martyrs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10. -- Six great naval seaplanes winged over the Golden Gate this afternoon on the start of a 2,400-mile flight from this city to Honolulu.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 10. -- The fast-skating Clarkson hockey team defeated Princeton, 5 -- 3, in a hard-fought overtime game at Baker Rink tonight. Paul Marion starred for the visitors, scoring three goals and being credited with an assist on a fourth.

Dr. Jose Manuel Puig Casauranc Foreign Minister of Mexico, who was president of the Mexican delegation to the Pan-American Conference at Montevideo, arrived yesterday on the Prince liner Eastern Prince from South America. There were seventeen in his party, including other delegates and experts.

Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen declared yesterday that he was prepared to make recommendations to the Board of Estimate for the wholesale abolition of city jobs which he considers unnecessary to the proper administration of the city.

With attendance at the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace declared yesterday to be running far ahead of last year, directors of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, under whose auspices the exhibit is held, expressed themselves as being "optimistic" about the public's reception of the industry's new products.

Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong, former British Consul General in New York, and Lady Armstrong, who will return to England tomorrow on the Britannic, gave a farewell dinner last night at the Weylin. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Edward Watson, Captain and Mrs. Thaddeus Armstrong and Miss Constance Armstrong.

The Catholic Mission Exposition, in memory of the Most Rev. John J. Dunn, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, who died last August, was solemnly inaugurated yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore. The luncheon was attended by more than 300 priests and missionaries.

Stocks engaged yesterday in the widest advance since Dec. 28 and the speculative enthusiasm which was felt first in this market spread later to commodities and even bonds. The unexpected aid which the President gave in the form of a discussion of railway and utility debt problems was welcomed by all the markets.

The United States Steel Corporation shipped 600,639 tons of finished steel in December, 170,281 more than the 430,358 in November, according to figures given out yesterday. This compares with 227,576 tons in the same month last year and constitutes not only the largest December business since 1929 but the first time in many years that the trend has been upward in the final month of the year.

LEIPZIG, Jan. 10. -- Germany exacted retribution this morning for the burning of the Reichstag building when Marinus van der Lubbe, the Dutch political pyromaniac whom the Supreme Court convicted of revolutionary arson and high treason in connection with that fateful fire, was executed here at 7:30 o'clock by means of the guillotine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Senate and House leaders today paved the way for early action on President Roosevelt's proposal to extend the life of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. They agreed upon additional authorization of $850,000,000 and approved a plan to extend its activities until Feb. 1, 1935.

TRENTON, Jan. 10. -- In a report submitted to Governor Moore today, the South Jersey Transit Commission recommended increased speed of trains, the construction of two new bridges and rapid service from Camden to Woodbury. One of the bridges proposed would span the Maurice River at Bivalve and the other would cross Townsends Inlet.

VINELAND, N.J., Jan. 10. -- A two-year feud between Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Y. Smart of Brewster Road, here, and the Board of Education, was settled tonight when a committee from the board, after an investigation, agreed to permit two of the Smart children who are of school age, to continue their studies at home.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 10. -- The Rumanian political crisis, which had continued since the assassination of Premier Ion G. Duca, ended tonight when Nicolas Titulescu, veteran Foreign Minister, took an oath of loyalty to King Carol on his return to Bucharest.
HAVANA, Jan. 10. -- A decree throwing government lands and the confiscated estates of former Machado officials open to settlement by the poor was signed today by President Ramon Grau San Martin.

United States Government long-term issues struck the only discordant note in the listed bond market yesterday, declining sharply on the Stock Exchange under pressure of heavy offerings as domestic corporation bonds and foreign loans were bid up rapidly. Federal bonds dropped 1-32 to 26-32 point, with the exception of Liberty 3 1/2s, which were up 1-32 point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Dissatisfaction at finding Republicans getting jobs in a Democratic administration led a group of Democratic Representatives today to force a caucus for discussion of patronage.

The large subscription for the special performance of "Manon" this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over in behalf of the Florence Crittenton League, indicates that the funds for carrying on the league's work will be augmented greatly.

Charging unfair competition and coercion in obtaining tenants for Rockefeller Center, a suit for $10,000,000 against John D. Rockefeller Jr., the Rockefeller Center Corporation, its officers and other defendants was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court by August Heckscher, as president of two realty corporations.

Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson, author of many books of verse, director of the Hall of Fame and former Ambassador to Italy, will celebrate his eighty-first birthday tomorrow. With mind alert and twinkling eyes that belied his age, Dr. Johnson spoke yesterday with almost boyish enthusiasm about the many projects in which he is still actively interested.
Vice Chancellor John J. Fallon of the New Jersey Chancery Court, who was appointed to the bench in 1927, submitted his-resignation yesterday to take effect next Monday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 10. -- "The possibility that the decision in the Blaisdell case rests on the doctrine of emergency does not mean that the court will refuse to sustain the New Deal except as a temporary device," asserted Professor Edward S. Corwin, authority on constitutional law and chairman of the politics department at Princeton University, in a statement today regarding the decision in the Minnesota mortgage moratorium case.

" Tristan und Isolde," sung and broadcast at last Saturday's Metropolitan matinee, will be repeated at the company's second visit to Brooklyn next Tuesday. The cast at the Academy of Music in that borough will include Mmes. Kappel and Branzell, Messrs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Testimony that Walter F. Brown, as Postmaster General, asked an air-line official not to bid on a mail route was heard by the Senate committee.

An important deal in the fur district was reported yesterday by which Frederick Brown, operator, became the owner of the twelve-story business building at 135-39 West Twenty-sixth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues. The building was sold by a client of Coon, Saxe Co., Inc.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10. -- The goal of the American fliers is but a pin point on the map of the Pacific, and any slight miscalculation would send them wide of their mark. However, navy ships, stationed 300 miles apart along the course, stood by ready to speed to the aid of any plane coming to distress.

Close cooperation between the City Market Department and the State Department of Agriculture and Markets has been arranged better to protect the interests of consumers and the farmers, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., city Market Commissioner, announced yesterday.

Physical examinations of National Guard officers have been conducted in a perfunctory and dishonest manner and, generally speaking, "are not worth the paper they are written on," Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commanding the New York National Guard, writes in the current issue of The New York State National Guardsman.

Ruth Sire and her maid, Francine Granat, were bound and gagged by two holdup men who invaded their apartment at 57 East Seventy-third Street, two doors west of Park Avenue, shortly before 1 o'clock this morning. The intruders escaped with jewelry valued at between $15,000 and $20,000.

LEIPZIG, Jan. 10. -- The guillotine that decapitated Marinus van der Lubbe this morning was hastily erected during the night by the official executioner and his attendants in the prison yard of the Leipzig district court.

Fourteen institutions in New York and New England will share the bulk of the estate of Mrs. Eliza W. Valentine, widow of Samuel H. Valentine, who died on Jan. 4, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Governor Lehman and Mayor LaGuardia of New York City after a conference held in the executive chamber today are in full accord on a bill which will enable the Mayor to put through measures of economy and efficiency in the New York City administration.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- The stock markets were more cheerful today. Demand for British funds was stimulated by good revenue returns and foreign bonds were firm, the German group recovering. Home rails declined sharply, however, following publication of traffic reports. General improvement appeared in the international list, although the best prices were not maintained fully.

Confidence that 1934 will be a better year as a result of planned expenditures by the Federal Government and optimism for a general business recovery were expressed yesterday by Richard H. Grant of Detroit, vice president of the General Motors Corporation, at a luncheon at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Jan. 10. -- An order to Police Chief Andrew H. Coleman to clear Irvington of all slot machines of a gambling nature was issued by the town commission at the conclusion today of a special session.

Praise for the policies of President Roosevelt's administration, not only those directed toward business recovery but also those designed to bring about "certain fundamental readjustments in our social structure," was voiced yesterday by Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, at the annual meeting of the bank's shareholders.
Staging a rally in the last three minutes, St. John's University conquered a fighting George Washington University five, 32 to 30, before a large crowd in the DeGray gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night.

BERLIN, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller was reported to have been scolded by President von Hindenburg for starting the controversy that for more than three months has rent the German Evangelical Church. The President expressed grave concern over Bishop Mueller's dictatorial actions, especially in attempting to dissolve Protestant youth groups and subordinating them to the non-sectarian Hitler youth organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Passage of legislation to give an unconditional Treasury guarantee for the principal as well as the interest of $2,000,000,000 of Federal Land Bank bonds authorized for the refinancing of farm mortgages was urged upon Congress today by President Roosevelt in a special message.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- The estimated cost and most desirable route for the proposed ship canal across New Jersey, the final link in a projected inland waterway from Boston to Key West, was reported to the House of Representatives today by Secretary Dern.

Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., disclosed yesterday his attention of asking the city administration to scrap the so-called Lay than for developing Marine Park in Brooklyn.

A papier-mache dinosaur reposed on a truck in front of the County Court House all day yesterday awaiting a call as an exhibit in a suit before Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck brought by Messmore Damon, Inc., against Earl Carroll, owner of the exhibit, for $7,500 damages and an injunction on the ground that it was made from plans designed by the plaintiffs.

William Tilden extended the official hand of welcome to Ellswort Vines of Pasadena at Madison Square Garden last night -- a welcome to the same fate that the Philadelphia tennis marvel visited upon Henri Cochet on the occasion of the French Davis Cup ace's professional debut last Fall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Farm stocks of wheat on Jan. 1 were reported today by the Department of Agriculture as 194,136,000 bushels, the smallest amount since 1927, when the department began collecting such data.

MIAMI, Jan. 10. -- As a curtain-raiser to the sixth annual all-American air races which open here tomorrow, Lawrence P. Sharples, 41-year-old sportsman pilot, of Philadelphia, won the Henry L. Doherty trophy and first prize of $500 from fifty-eight other private fliers in a cruising race from Orlando today. He flew a Travelair.

MADRID, Jan. 10. -- Spain's republican regime produced another paradox today when Gil Robles, leader of the ultra-conservative Catholic party, which profited in the recent elections by the popular reaction against socialism, introduced a bill in the Cortes for a "dole" for all of the country's able-bodied unemployed workers between the ages of 16 and 60 years whose yearly incomes formerly did not exceed 6,000 pesetas.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10. -- Amateur and professional golf stars, 200 strong, will tee off tomorrow in the eighteen-hole qualifying round of the fourth annual $4,000 national match play open championship.
Twenty-seven contributors added $752.50 yesterday to the Neediest Cases Fund, bringing the total of the current fund to $230,933.52.

THE Toronto Maple Leaf hockey team, skating at full speed, is due to appear on the Garden ice this evening, and that recalls the judicial decision in the celebrated case of Bailey vs. Shore (Mass. 1933-34, Patrick, J.), the aforesaid decision being now on the calendar of hockey's appellate division.

The report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, published yesterday, shows in detail its total disbursements to the end of 1933, the amounts repaid and the commitments for the future. The data included cover the entire period since the RFC was organized on Feb. 2, 1932, under the auspices of the Hoover Administration.
A financial deadlock will prevent a meeting of Primo Carnera world's heavyweight champion, and Max Baer, California challenger, this year unless concessions are granted on both sides.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Unrestricted imports of American-type whisky for thirty days and unlimited manufacture of ethyl alcohol from sources other than grain for forty-five days were authorized today by the Federal Alcohol Control Administration. The action was taken to cut the price of liquor and drive the bootlegger out of business.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 10 (AP). -- James Bolitho, described by officers as a former District Attorney of Morris County, N.Y., and Larry and Michael Donofrio were indicted by the grand jury here today on charges of arson in connection with the burning of the Warner Park roller coaster in 1931.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 10. -- Brazil's Cabinet crisis has been solved, it was announced today, by the decision of Osvaldo Aranha and Dr. Afranio de Mello Franco to return as Ministers of Finance and Foreign Affairs, respectively. It was further stated President Getulio Vargas would name General Goes Monteiro as Minister of War.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The Senate on the first record roll-call of the session voted today 40 to 39 that governments which have defaulted in their debt payments to the United States shall pay a penalty tax on liquor imports into this country.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- An exhaustive inquiry into the Insull receivership litigation, to determine if actions involved in it were collusively brought and fraud practiced upon the court, was ordered today by Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley.

The youthful citizens of the Boys Brotherhood Republic opened their new clubhouse at 290 East Third Street for inspection yesterday. The brotherhood is the largest self-governing organization of boys in the city and has a membership of 195.
In a series of prolonged matches four of the eight seeded players were eliminated in the third round of the women's national squash racquets championship yesterday at the Junior League clubhouse.

Steel operations are estimated by The Iron Age to be at the rate of about 31 per cent of ingot capacity. This is the same rate that was reported by this publication a week ago. It is noted, however, that the demand has shrunk since the end of the year, production of raw steel in December having shown a contra-seasonal gain of 23 per cent over November.

Determined to purge his department of grafters, Austin H. MacCormick, Correction Commissioner, yesterday ordered his deputy, David Marcus, a former Assistant Federal Attorney, to "go right down the line" and clean up the department.

The City Athletic Club Class A squash tennis team, which had been running a neck-and-neck race with the Columbia University Club and New York A.C. for the lead in the Metropolitan League, dropped to third place as a result of last night's setback.

The challenge presented to the church to keep pace with the social changes affecting the nation and to provide "a spiritual setting" for the economic struggle, was stressed yesterday in a discussion of a six-year survey of church organization and life in the United States, Alaska and the West Indies.

Simon N. Whitney, a former member of the department of economics at Yale University and attorney with the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, has written a book-length discussion of the NRA in operation. It is published by Central Book Company, 245 Broadway.
LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Dimitri Maximos, the Greek Foreign Minister, said today that Samuel Insull must leave Greece by Jan. 31, despite an appeal to the High Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Federal protection for small industries through the Guilds of American Foundation, modernizing under NRA rules the old guild system of the Middle Ages, was advocated tonight by Senator Nye, William A. Julian, treasurer of the United States, and Dr. M.L. Wilson, director of the Subsistence Homesteads Division of the Interior Department.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- A truce ending the milk strike and embargo which has tied up milk deliveries in Chicago since Saturday was signed today in Mayor Kelly's office.
All the flag officers of the American Yacht Club have been renominated and only one change will be made in the board of directors at the annual meeting and dinner on Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Laird Bell of Chicago and Pierre Jay of New York, members of the executive committee of the Foreign Bondholders' Protective Council; George Rublee of Washington, its counsel, and John Foster Dulles, representing financial houses which issued German bonds, conferred this morning with Acting Secretary of State Phillips in anticipation of the conference of Germany's long-term creditors in Berlin Jan. 22.

The Jewish Conciliation Court of America handled during 1933 more domestic relations cases than in any previous year in its ten-year history, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the institution, held at the Federation Building, 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Establishment of a Federal communications commission with authority to regulate wire and radio companies just as railroads are regulated by the Interstate Commerce Commission will soon be urged in Congress with the support of the administration.

BOSTON. Jan. 10. -- Stanley (Bucky) Harris, new manager of the rebuilt Boston Red Sox, hastened here from his Washington home today to spread the alarm that his charges must beat the Senators to gain the American League pennant.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- William Murphy Walker, one of the firebrands in the old Federal League baseball war, ascended the Cub baseball throne today.

Acquisition of the Codex Sinaiticus by the British Museum is declared by The Observer of London to be the greatest event in the history of the Museum since it became possessed of the Parthenon frieze. Widely different questions have been raised by these two transactions.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 10. -- The League of Nations Chaco Commission began exploring with Argentine authorities today the possibility of renewing efforts to terminate the war between Bolivia and Paraguay. Juan Alvarez del Vayo and General Freydenberg of the commission spent an hour conferring with President Augustin P. Justo and another two hours with Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Luis Podesta Costa and Horacio Carrillo of Argentina.
GENEVA, Jan. 10. -- League of Nations quarters believe the meeting of the bureau (steering committee) of the disarmament conference set for Jan. 22 probably will be postponed two or three weeks.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- Employment dropped 1 per cent and payrolls fell 1.7 per cent in New York State factories in December, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported today. These decreases lowered the Labor Department's index numbers based on the three years 1925-27 as 100, to 66.2 for employment and 51.3 for payrolls.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Jan. 11. -- With Nanking armies battling the Fukien rebels only eight miles from Foochow, the Japanese Minister to China again warns Nanking that Japanese rights in Fukien and Japanese citizens resident there must not be jeopardized and voices hope Nanking will not extend hostilities without considering the danger to Japanese lives and property.

Fred C. Lemmerman, one of the three commissioners of the Triborough Bridge Authority and former president of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce, resigned yesterday after charges had been filed against him by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

BAY OF WHALES, Antarctica, Jan. 10 (By Wireless). -- Our Northrop all-metal plane has been completely assembled and is ready for flight. We are now waiting on the weather to permit us to make our first flying test.

BERLIN, Jan. 10. -- The Boerse was dull and generally weaker today. Most changes were fractional, but some specialties lost more than 2 points. Shipping company stocks, which recently spurted upward, suffered a sharp reaction, and Hapag and North German Lloyd lost approximately 3 points, or 10 per cent of the quotation value, the decline being attributed to pessimistic views of shipping prospects. Banks alone were able to improve prices.

Business in the money market remained stagnant. Turnover was extremely light, and quotations for all classifications unchanged from Tuesday. Stock Exchange day loans continued at 1 per cent, and Street funds at 3/4 @ 7/8.

BOSTON, Jan. 10. -- The Harvard hockey team, with Benny Beale in the starring role, scored a 4-3 victory over Boston University in a hard-fought game tonight at the Boston Garden. Beale scored three of the Crimson's goals. Sam Callaway tallied the other Harvard marker.

The hearing of formal graft charges against License Inspector Joseph W. O'Connor with a view to his dismissal opened yesterday before Commissioner Sidney S. Levine in the Bureau of Licenses with a declaration by Mrs. Lena Feldman, a witness, that within the last few days she had been told to keep quiet by messages from the Commissioner's predecessor, James F. Geraghty, a Democratic district leader in the Bronx.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Amateur athletics give prospect of booming in the United States in 1934.

HAVANA, Jan. 10. -- A man dressed in the uniform of a naval lieutenant distributed handbills in suburban Marianao today asking the people to help enforce the new law requiring that 50 per cent of the employes in all commerce and industry be natives.

Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, said yesterday that the bill to establish the Municipal Housing Authority would be introduced in the Legislature late this week or early next week. He expressed hope that it would pass both houses without opposition.
ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- A resolution for a constitutional amendment to permit pari-mutuel betting at the New York tracks was introduced today by Senator George Blumberg, Brooklyn Republican.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Drastic reductions in municipal expenditures, elimination of overlapping departments and the immediate appointment of a budget director were recommended today in a financial and administrative survey of the city of Yonkers, issued by Mayor Joseph F. Loehr.

When I.J. Golden was writing "Precedent" a season or two ago, the raw facts of the Mooney-Billings case were stirring enough to compensate for his unpracticed craftsmanship. But when he discusses the nuances of human character, as he does in "Re-Echo," which was staged at the Forrest last evening, his clumsy style betrays him into writing Bowery melodrama.

PARIS, Jan. 10. -- Withdrawal of the parliamentary immunity of Deputy Gaston Bonnaure and the arrest of two prominent Parisian editors, Camille Aymard of La Liberte and Albert Dubarry of La Volonte were requested today by the magistrate who is investigating the issuing of fraudulent securities of the Bayonne municipal pawnshop by Alexandre Stavisky.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- A new form of money order which would be known as a postal note, and be negotiable, has been proposed before the House Postoffice and Post Roads Committee by Chairman Mead of Buffalo, and will be taken up for detailed study.

The Supreme Court decision sustaining the Minnesota law establishing a moratorium on foreclosures has been hailed widely as indicating that this court will uphold the legality of the special emergency powers conferred by Congress on the President for the establishment of the National Recovery Act.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 10. -- The dinner dance formally opening the Colony Club for its sixth season, held tonight, proved a brilliant affair, with several hundred colonists attending. Innovations there include a Cafe de la Paix for the serving of aperatifs and a rolling stage.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 10. -- Alexander Pantages's Vermont Rose accounted for her second straight triumph at Agua Caliente today when she scored a surprising victory in the featured fifth race. The Pasadena Stable's Notify was second, and the Oak Tree Stable's Thoughtful saved the show.

The New Jersey Legislature met on Tuesday with the Republicans in absolute control and in no mood to allow Governor MOORE to obtain any political advantage. It is assumed that he will be a candidate for United States Senator at the November election. Lay Judge W.L. DILL of the Court of Errors and Appeals announced at the convention of the Atlantic County Democratic clubs on Jackson Day that he would be a candidate for Governor.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The bill designed to give Robert Moses unified control over the parks of the entire City of New York was restored today to the form in which it was originally presented to the Legislature by the new city administration.

The vast herds of buffalo exterminated in the winning of the West will be memorialized on their old stamping grounds, according to plans made yesterday by the American Bison Society at its annual meeting in the New York Zoological Park in the Bronx.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 10. -- In a bitterly contested match Marcel Rainville, Canadian Davis Cup ace, was defeated, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 1, 8 -- 6, today by Hudson Hamm of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for the first upset of the Miami Biltmore tennis tournament.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (AP). -- The Continental Life Insurance Company declared it is not "in danger of becoming impaired or insolvent," in an answer filed in Circuit Court today to a dissolution suit brought by the State Insurance Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- That utilities corporations must file data concerning rate and valuation cases pending before Public Service Commissions or in the courts in registration statements, under the Federal Securities Act, has been established by action of the Federal Trade Commission in connection with the recent application of the Laclede Gas Light Company of St. Louis to issue $3,000,000 of refunding bonds.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10. -- M.E. Costello's fast mare Betty Farrell, which has been in the money in ten of her last twelve starts, led home a field of ten high-class platers in the feature race at Jefferson Park today. It was her sixth victory of the current meeting.

Demand for men's clothing and furnishings for Spring spurted sharply this week, as buyers came into the local markets in large numbers. Merchants expressed confidence in the outlook for the Spring season and backed their opinions with substantial orders on all types of goods.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- President Roosevelt feels that railroads and other public utilities should plan for the systematic retirement of bonded indebtedness out of earnings and that, where necessary, official regulatory bodies should take this factor into consideration in establishing rates to be charged.

Because of the depreciation of the American dollar, Surrogate James A. Foley granted an increase yesterday of $2,500 a year in the allowances for the education and support of Arthur G.M.D.H. de La P. Beresford, 18 years old, and his sister, Catherine Moya Beresford, 20, children of Lord and Lady Decies. Lady Decies was the former Vivien Helen Gould.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 10. -- Foreign Minister Alberto Mane has asked Colombia to recall her new Minister to Uruguay, Jose Camacho Carreno, saying he is no longer persona grata. Senor Camacho Carreno today addressed a note to Dr. Mane, requesting him to state in writing the reasons which make him no longer acceptable as Minister.
Fifteen properties, including twelve in Manhattan and three in the Bronx, were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure tions yesterday. One scheduled sale in each borough was adjourned.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (AP). -- The Continental Life Insurance Company declared it is not "in danger of becoming impaired or insolvent," in an answer filed in Circuit Court today to a dissolution suit brought by the State Insurance Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- That utilities corporations must file data concerning rate and valuation cases pending before Public Service Commissions or in the courts in registration statements, under the Federal Securities Act, has been established by action of the Federal Trade Commission in connection with the recent application of the Laclede Gas Light Company of St. Louis to issue $3,000,000 of refunding bonds.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10. -- M.E. Costello's fast mare Betty Farrell, which has been in the money in ten of her last twelve starts, led home a field of ten high-class platers in the feature race at Jefferson Park today. It was her sixth victory of the current meeting.

Demand for men's clothing and furnishings for Spring spurted sharply this week, as buyers came into the local markets in large numbers. Merchants expressed confidence in the outlook for the Spring season and backed their opinions with substantial orders on all types of goods.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- President Roosevelt feels that railroads and other public utilities should plan for the systematic retirement of bonded indebtedness out of earnings and that, where necessary, official regulatory bodies should take this factor into consideration in establishing rates to be charged.

Because of the depreciation of the American dollar, Surrogate James A. Foley granted an increase yesterday of $2,500 a year in the allowances for the education and support of Arthur G.M.D.H. de La P. Beresford, 18 years old, and his sister, Catherine Moya Beresford, 20, children of Lord and Lady Decies. Lady Decies was the former Vivien Helen Gould.

TRENTON, Jan. 10. -- A bill authorizing municipalities to compromise their bonded indebtedness will be introduced by Senator Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic County when the Legislature reconvenes next Monday night.
Would that Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's letter in opposition to the so-called Child Labor Amendment could be mailed to every home in our land!

H. Donald Campbell, vice president of the Chase National Bank since June, 1930, was elected president yesterday at the organization meeting of the board of directors, and Winthrop W. Aldrich, who had been president, was elected chairman of the board of directors. Mr. Aldrich previously was also chairman of the governing board, but that office was eliminated.

Howard Schenken and Michael Gottlieb won the first annual contract bridge pair championship of the United States Bridge Association when the three-day struggle came to a close at the Hotel Pierre early this morning. They completely spreadeagled the field in the final session of play last night.
Miss Marion Lloyd of the Salle d'Armes Vince, former women's national fencing champion, captured first place in the competition for the Mrs. Alice West Voorhees medals last night at the Fencers Club.

American specialists have helped to draft the new five-year industrialization plan just announced by the Turkish Government. The program calls for the expenditure of $32,000,000 on fifteen big factories. It is good to see the Kemalist regime working for a higher standard of living for its people, and American experts lending a hand.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Ordinarily people in the rest of the country have a good, hearty laugh over the sorrows of inhabitants of the District of Columbia. They have no vote. Too bad. Their local government, supervised by Congress, is remote from them. How regrettable! They can't turn their motors right on a red light except at one or two corners. Well, that's pretty tough.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The first appropriation bill for the fiscal year 1935, the independent offices supply measure, was introduced in the House today by Representative Woodrum, chairman of the subcommittee that prepared it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Nearly half of the veterans receiving pensions last March have been dropped as the result of economy legislation passed last Spring.

HEAVEN, said Emerson, always bears some proportion to earth. And so, for that matter, does Hell. Art Young tells us just how the proportions work out in his "Inferno" (Delphic Studios), which is by way of being "a journey through Hell 600 years after Dante." This "Inferno," illustrated and written by one and the same Art Young, is a diabolically clever book in more ways than one.
The slot-machine racket in Manhattan will feel the heavy hand of Deputy Chief Inspector David J. McAuliffe, new borough commander, within the next few days, he revealed yesterday.
" Man of Two Worlds," featuring Francis Lederer in his American film debut, will open at the Radio City Music Hall today. Elissa Landi plays the feminine lead.
ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- Still divided by sharp factional lines, Republican members remained deadlocked today over the election of the Assembly clerk.

Mayor LaGuardia, in a letter to Nathan Burkan, chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority, made public yesterday, said he was opposed to letting contracts for work in New York City to concerns from out of town. The letter indicated that his opinion on the subject had been requested.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Data on employment hours under the codes will be scrutinized next month to ascertain whether these hours should be shortened and how far such a change may be feasible at this time, General Johnson stated today.
Formation of a standing committee to supervise dealings in bonds was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
Walter F. Brown, former Postmaster General, said here yesterday that he was perfectly willing to testify "concerning facts" before the Black committee should he be called upon to do so.

Meetings of the Yale football committee with Malcolm Farmer, director of athletics, continued in New York yesterday, with no indication of the approach of any agreement or of any definite action in the near future regarding a football coach.

Gruenberg's "Emperor Jones," preceded by the season's first "Cavalleria Rusticana," drew a large audience at the Metropolitan last evening. The relative honors implied by the opera house's generous quota of standees, doubtless, could be credited about equally to the American production and to Mascagni's once thrilling "shocker" of an earlier generation.

The Joint Board of the Dressmakers Union figured in one of the largest commercial leases reported yesterday. The group rented three floors, consisting of 37,500 square feet in 218 West Fortieth Street, for a long term for executive offices, council rooms and library. The contract was negotiated by Schuster, Fine Mayleas, Inc., for the Guzy Realty Company.

The address on "the Consumer in the National Recovery Program," by Frederick J. Schlink, president of Consumers Research, Inc., which was barred from the Columbia system last Saturday when Mr. Schlink spoke at Philadelphia before the Academy of Political and Social Science, has been reinstated by the radio organization and the address will be broadcast from 3:30 to 4 P.M. on Jan. 13 "without censorship and without comment," it became known yesterday.

Gruenberg's "Emperor Jones," preceded by the season's first "Cavalleria Rusticana," drew a large audience at the Metropolitan last evening. The relative honors implied by the opera house's generous quota of standees, doubtless, could be credited about equally to the American production and to Mascagni's once thrilling "shocker" of an earlier generation.

The Joint Board of the Dressmakers Union figured in one of the largest commercial leases reported yesterday. The group rented three floors, consisting of 37,500 square feet in 218 West Fortieth Street, for a long term for executive offices, council rooms and library. The contract was negotiated by Schuster, Fine Mayleas, Inc., for the Guzy Realty Company.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, urged that only students who felt they were the best qualified should go on with pre-medical studies, at a meeting of the Biology Club of the college yesterday. The group was made up of students who hope to make medicine their profession.

Colonel Lindbergh revealed yesterday that he had sent to a Senate investigating committee a complete record of his financial transactions in aviation. At the same time he offered to clarify any misunderstanding about these transactions, and indicated that he would be available for questioning if the committee wanted him.

Samuel Untermyer, former transit and financial adviser of the city, in a telegram to Mayor LaGuardia made public yesterday, asked the Mayor to make a survey of the possibilities of recapturing the company lines for unification with the city's Eight Avenue subway, before entering into an agreement for the purchase of the B.M.T. and Interborough systems.

With Captain Alex Goldberg showing the way, East New York of Brooklyn annexed the city P.S.A.L. Junior High soccer crown by topping Herman Ridder of the Bronx, defending champion, 1 to 0, at Macomb's Dam Park in the Bronx yesterday.

Within eight days of a fiftieth anniversary of its original Paris premiere, Massenet's ever youthful "Manon" was sung at the Metropolitan yesterday afternoon for the first time this season. There was a brilliant matinee audience assembled for the annual benefit of the Florence Crittenton League.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The compliance machinery of the NRA was invoked today in an effort to compel a signer of the automobile code to live up to the labor provision of the code and of the Recovery Act.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 11. -- Governor Murray authorized two attorneys today to sue the United States for $100,000,000, allegedly due the State from taxes on Indian lands which were declared tax-exempt in the Congressional act admitting Oklahoma to Statehood.

HONOLULU, Jan. 11. -- Six United States Navy planes successfully completed a record formation flight from San Francisco to Pearl Harbor today. The first plane alighted on the water off the concrete ramp of the fleet air base at 12:29 P.M. [5:59 Eastern Standard Time] and the last plane splashed into the water at 12:37 P.M. [6:07 Eastern Standard Time], 24 hours and 56 minutes after the 2,400-mile flight had begun.

Two big detectives acted as interference for Bernard A. Appleton yesterday as he left West Side Court surrounded by a menacing group of frustrated crooners, sopranos and whistlers, their fathers and their mothers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- America's stock of monetary gold at the end of December was $4,322,865,873, as compared with $4,507,522,361 a year earlier, the Treasury reported today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 11. -- Reduction to $30,000 in the added value of the Kentucky Derby was announced tonight by Colonel Matt J. Winn, president of the American Turf Association and executive director of Churchill Downs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins pushed the Chicago Black Hawks out of sole possession of the leadership in the National Hockey League's American division by earning a scoreless tie tonight in a bruising overtime battle.
TEANECK, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Robert Ellsworth Lowe left Teaneck on Jan. 19, 1933, to go on a vacation in Florida. His wife, Gladys, remained at her home, 131 Fort Lee Road, Bogota.

Arnold Schonberg as guest of the Boston Symphony Orchestra is conducting a program of his own works in Boston today and tomorrow, presenting the "Verklarte Nacht," the symphonic poem of "Pelleas und Melisande" and Schonberg's arrangement of the E-flat organ prelude and fugue of Bach.

WASHINGTON, Jan. ll. -- Fourteen bills designed to make virtually impossible the illegal possession of firearms by gangsters were introduced today by Senator Copeland as the result of exhaustive studies conducted by a special Senate committee of which he was chairman.

Trading in commodities was highly irregular yesterday. Prices moved upward in the early trading and sold off moderately through the remainder of the day. As a rule, prices were unchanged or slightly firmer at the close. In the cash markets, rubber, antimony, tin, cotton, printcloths and silk advanced, while wheat, corn, oats, sugar and rubber eased.

Two robbers last night forced Walter Kowalewski, proprietor of a delicatessen store at 109-72 Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, to give them the key of his cash register by burning his bare feet with half a dozen matches. They escaped after taking all the money in the register, $12.81, only to be captured an hour later by the crew of a police radio car.

MIAMI, Jan. ll. -- Under a blue-and-white sky and in an air un-usually brisk and cool for Florida, Miami's sixth annual All-American air races got under way this afternoon. The racing itself produced no startling speeds but the army and the marines put on a splendid show of precision flying.

TRENTON, Jan. 11. -- Chancellor Luther A. Campbell today appointed Judge Charles M. Egan of the Hudson County Common Pleas Court to succeed John J. Fallon as Vice Chancellor. Chancellor's resignation, announced yesterday, is effective next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 10. as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $2,665,000,000, a decrease of $21,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $519,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

Briefs and affidavits were filed with Federal Judge Frank Cooper in Albany yesterday by Joseph Nemerov, as attorney for mortgage certificate holders, in connection with his application to have George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, ousted from control of the mortgages and the underlying securities behind the certificate issues of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company and the Lawyers Title and Mortgage Company.

The Playhouse has been booked for the presentation of the John D. Haggart play, "Mackerel Skies." It will open at that house on Tuesday night, Jan. 23. "Mackerel Skies" deals with an opera singer and is being produced by George Bushar, said to be a pseudonym, in association with John Tuerk.

BAY OF WHALES, Antarctica, Jan. 11 (By Wireless). -- I have made my first flight in the Antarc tic. Fifty-six hours after the motor ship Wyatt Earp drew alongside the Ross Barrier our Northrop all-metal airplane, which I have named the Polar Star, was in the air.
PARIS, Jan. 11 (AP). -The weekly statement of the ]Bank of France shows, the. following changes in francs:

French Cochran. Inc., and North Iritish Mercantile insurance Co.. in 90 John St.; Clothing },erchants Association, Inc., in 72 5th Av.; Rogers Flynn Co., in 79 Wall St.; Metro Woolen Co.. inc., renewal. store and basement in 11 Washington Pl.; Irving Brause. renewal, store and basement in 404 Broadway; Bleyco Paper Corp.. renewal, store, basement and part of first loft in 215-17 Greene St.; Brown, Wheelock, Harris Co., brokers.

Conference between Governor LEHMAN and Mayor LAGUARDIA could hardly have failed to result in an agreement reasonably satisfactory to both of them. When two frank and public-spirited men, both of them pledged to do all in their power to bring about economies in State and city, and neither of them manoeuvring for political advantage, sit down to study and adjust their differences, the outcome is not in doubt.

The failure to ratify the World Court protocol is the "most discreditable thing" in the recent history of the United States, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the Students International Union, at the home of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, 2 East Ninety-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Nearly 4,000 cases of canned Japanese tuna fish, each case bearing the NRA Blue Eagle insignia and landed at San Pedro, Calif., were ordered held pending a joint investigation by customs and National Recovery Administration authorities, it was announced at NRA headquarters today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- With the debt-default penalty eliminated, the liquor tax bill was passed today by the Senate, approved by the House with respect to other Senate amendments and sent to the White House. President Roosevelt postponed signing it until the Treasury makes a routine examination of its contents tomorrow.

Stricken with an attack of gallstones while singing the role of Fricka in "Die Walkure" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, Karin Branzell fainted as she left the stage. She was attended by the house physician, Dr. Walter H. McNiell Jr., and sent home.

President ROOSEVELT has recommended that Congress guarantee the principal of Federal farm-loan bonds to the amount of $2,000,000,000. Provision for the issuance of these securities was made last year in the same omnibus measure which created the AAA and authorized currency inflation.

The constitutionality of the alcoholic beverage control legislation enacted last Spring and Summer was challenged yesterday before Magistrate Hughes in Downtown Court, Brooklyn, on the ground that during the life of the Eighteenth Amendment no State Legislature had power to regulate the sale of hard liquor.

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- After the last remaining member of Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller's Protestant Church Cabinet had resigned today, news came tonight that the Prussian secret police were raiding the homes of local secretaries of the Pastors Emergency Federation, the organization opposing the Nazi Reich Bishop's dictatorial rule, in many places throughout the State.

The trend in scientific thinking, as exemplified by Dr. Compton's viewpoint quoted in THE TIMES, is demonstrably away from a materialistic interpretation of the universe. Yet, salutary as is this attitude, there exists, it seems to me, a quite definite danger that a number of our scientists are on the verge of tipping over backward in their flight from materialism.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 11. -- Asserting that New York and Wisconsin were mutually interested in the building of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence waterway, Delos M. Cosgrove, vice chairman of the New York State Power Authority, urged a joint meeting of the two bodies of the Legislature today to expand efforts to bring it about.
A collection of American historical portraits from the estate of Hiram Burlingham of this city brought $27,770 last night at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

A proposed AAA code of fair competition for the live poultry industry of the metropolitan area, which aims, among other things, to clean up unsavory conditions of long standing in the industry, was outlined yesterday at the meeting of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council at the Hotel Wellington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP). -- Wholesale commodity prices showed a slight rise during the first week of January.

A Congressional investigation of Fascist propaganda in this country and of the activities here of Piero Parini, director general of Italians abroad and of Italian schools abroad, was requested yesterday. Parini's expulsion from the country also was asked.

All that the commission house brokers could say yesterday, on the basis of the further expansion in business, was that they expected to see the market pick up. They said that with evident conviction. Yesterday's market, in which the turnover on the Stock Exchange was about 1,700,000 shares, did seem promising.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Sentiment on the Board of Trade was bullish on grains today, but the buying was not sufficient to lift prices much despite the government report of reduced farm reserves. Many buyers of yesterday became sellers today when outside trade failed to broaden to the extent expected, and this selling was largely responsible for a late recession.
