By defeating the Yale Club in the concluding match of the season last night, the Harvard Club No. 1 team gained the Dixon Trophy and the title in the Class A division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League for the second successive year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The argument of a few weeks ago over whether the government should after devaluation take the dollar profit on the gold holdings of the Federal Reserve Board has changed into a discussion of how the profit should be taken. It is worthy of record that, except for Senator Glass and a few others, no protest is heard in official circles, and from the country have come many messages endorsing the proposal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The administration machine today successfully crushed the first insurgent uprising in the House, but by the narrow margin of five votes.
A particularly rewarding group of American figure paintings, by nineteenth and twentieth century artists, has opened at the Milch Galleries, where it will remain through this month.

Temporary financing by the Federal Government of capital goods industries and of allied service industries, pending revival of the securities market, was urged yesterday as an important next step in the recovery program by Malcolm Muir, president of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, upon his return from Washington following his resignation as divisional NRA administrator.

Negotiations for a return heavyweight battle between Max Baer, outstanding contender for the world's heavyweight title, and Max Schmeling of Germany, who formerly held the championship, actively got under way yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- The stock market was active and buoyant in all sections today. There was continued investment demand for British Government funds. German bonds improved in anticipation of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's meeting with creditors.

MESA, Ariz., Jan. 11 (AP). -- A motor-car accident caused by a tire blowout tonight brought death to Charles E. Mack of the famous "Two Black Crows," vaudeville team of Moran and Mack, partners for many years, and injured Mack Sennett, former producer of "Bathing Beauty" film comedies.

When the United States St. Lawrence Commission made its report to President COOLIDGE in January, 1927, recommending construction of the deeper waterway, business was improving in this country. International trade was expanding. The railroads were carrying more freight.

A hard-hitting, five-game match that ended in a victory for Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia featured the quarter-final round of the women's national squash racquets championship yesterday at the Junior League clubhouse.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- A strike of anthracite miners in the Wilkes-Barre and Scranton areas is likely to be called on Saturday, according to word that came to the National Labor Board today.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- With Mayor LaGuardia bringing pressure in an effort to break the Assembly deadlock over the election of a clerk, Speaker McGinnies and W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, assured the Mayor in messages tonight they would do all in their power to make prompt organization of the lower house possible.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- James H. Moran, oldest active public official in Westchester County, was 90 years old today. His colleagues on the County Board of Supervisors, of which he has been a member for twelve years, often refer to him as 'the youngest man on the board."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. ll. -- G.M. Odom's Irene's Bob barely managed to maintain a nose advantage over Mrs. J.H. Whitney's Crowning Glory in the featured six-furlong Daytona Purse at Tropical Park today. Mrs. M. Colford's My Purchase was third in a field of twelve.

Some of the reasons for establishing the Fund for Needy Vocal Students, for which Luella Melius has sung and spoken in public, were told by the singer yesterday at her home at 152 West Fifty-seventh Street. Mme. Melius appeared for the fund recently at the home of Mrs. John Henry Hammond, she said, and will appear again at the Plaza on Feb. 10 for the same cause.

The listed bond market advanced briskly yesterday in a turnover of $20,094,500 on the Stock Exchange, compared with $24,305,000 on the previous day. Few domestic corporation bonds failed to improve and the major gains in this group ranged from 1 to 8 points.

Under the auspices of the Welfare Council's Coordinating Committee, former Governor Alfred E. Smith began yesterday a series of ten radio broadcasts over station WOR designed to inform the people of the city, particularly those in need, where to go to obtain relief.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 11. -- Shore's Frosty Mist, lemon-and-white pointer owned by Dr. O.A. Foard of Winston-Salem and handled by Marvin Yount of Newton, captured the $350 first prize in the open all-age stake of the Pinehurst Field Trial Club today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 11. -- On a wall in Indiana State Police Headquarters is a "box score" of the fight to round up members of the "dangerous Dillinger gang," led by John Dillinger, a bank robber, and composed largely of convicts who escaped last September from the State prison.

Buying by consumers from all parts of the world established new high quotations for the movement on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and despite an afternoon reaction prices closed with gains of 4 to 8 points.

Records of attendance at the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace have been toppling ever since the exhibition opened last Saturday, and there is a good chance that the show this year will set a new high mark for number of visitors, according to the committee in charge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Almost simultaneously with the landing of Squadron 10-F at Pearl Harbor, congratulatory messages were sent by Colonel Henry L. Roosevelt, Acting Secretary of the Navy, congratulating the officers and men on their record-breaking mass non-stop flight.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 11. -- President Oscar Benavides welcomed Secretary of State Cordell Hull to Peru with a State dinner tonight at which he called upon the United States to understand the difficulty of Latin American debtors in meeting their obligations in the midst of a world depression.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- December department store sales, including the holiday trade, showed gains for all Federal Reserve districts except Boston, where there was no change. For the country as a whole the sales were 7 per cent greater than in December, 1932, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The text of the remarks by Secretary of State Hull at a dinner given by the President of Peru in Lima tonight was given out by the State Department as follows:

Thirty-five members of the 1933 Manhattan College football and cross-country squads were honored by 350 supporters at the first annual Block M dinner, held under the joint sponsorship of the Manhattan Alumni Association and the Jasper Club at the Knights of Columbus Hotel last night.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 (AP). -- Disapproval of any increase in real estate tax exemptions was expressed today by the State Tax Revision Commission.

TRENTON, Jan. 11. -- Governor Moore was told today by the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards that the tax base must be broadened to bring about a 50 per cent reduction in taxes on real estate.
The massed flight of six United States Navy patrol seaplanes from San Francisco to Pearl Harbor -- 2,408 statute miles -- set a new record for over-water formation flying.

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -Today's session of the Boerse, on the whole, was weaker, with a shrinkage in the volume of business. Public buying virtually was concentrated on fixed-interest securities. The Reich revaiorization, first series; rose 2 points and the second series gained point on brisk buying.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Walter F. Brown, Postmaster General in the Hoover Administration, gave air-mail operators a free hand in drawing up an "air-mail map," but became dictator of mergers and consolidations when the operators failed to come to terms with one another, Daniel Sheaffer indicated in testimony today before a Senate inquiry.

Nothing that was "not moral" was done with its invested funds by the Board of Ministerial Pensions and Relief of the United Lutheran Church in America, according to a verdict reached by the executive board of the communion last evening at a meeting in the Lutheran Church House, 39 East Thirty-fifth Street.

Under Commissioner O'RYAN changes and reorganization in the Police Department are going steadily forward. There has been no bluster about it, no wholesale "shake-up," but General O'RYAN, who has been openly acting upon the advice of his new Chief Inspector, LEWIS J. VALENTINE, especially in the matter of transfers, has been moving quietly but firmly toward stiffening up discipline in the police force.

Nathan R. Margold, chairman of the Petroleum Administrative Board, in response to a telegram sent recently to him and to Secretary Ickes, Oil Administrator, telegraphed yesterday to Frank C. Hart, president of the Hartol Products Corporation, that charges brought by Mr. Hart are being investigated and that selling of oil products below cost must be stopped.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Support for the purpose of the National Recovery Administration expressed by the long silent Henry Ford had quickened interest in the capital tonight in the permanent form the organization may assume.

The Federal Reserve Banks set aside this week $129,360,000 for subscription to the stock of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, it is disclosed in the weekly report of the Reserve System, published yesterday. Of this amount, one-half, or $64,680,000, has been paid over to the corporation, the report shows, and stock of the corporation has been received for it.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- No further intervention in major banks in Chicago or New York by the RFC as owner of preferred stock was pledged today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, according to a dispatch from Washington to The Chicago Tribune.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Edsel B. Ford, president of the Ford Motor Company, testifying today before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, admitted that as a director of the Guardian Detroit Union group, parent unit of the Michigan banking chain, he had scant knowledge of the situation which ended in the banking collapse.
Patricia Luciano, the 24-day-old baby who was kidnapped Tuesday from the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Luciano, at 251 Seventh Street, was back in her mother's arms last night.

YONKERS, Jan. 11. -- Following announcement of a list of seven new directors, including Dr. Albert N. Benedict, son-in-law of John E. Andrus, to manage the proposed Citizens Trust Company, which is to replace the restricted Westchester Trust Company bank here, it was said today that the presidency of the bank was to be offered to Dr. Benedict.

With contributions totaling $472.50, twenty-seven additional donors brought this year's fund for the Neediest Cases up to $231,406.02 yesterday. This is $33,993.51 short of the total last year, when $265,399.53 was contributed.

MADRID, Jan. 11. -- The seven judges of the military section of Spain's Supreme Court listened today to a Spanish lawyer's explanation that the five accused Americans did not understand for a moment the gravity of their offense when they became involved in a fight with a Civil Guard at Palma, Island of Majorca.

Plans for a new campaign by property owners against the 50 per cent increase in water rates recently voted by the city were made yesterday at the annual meeting of the First Avenue Association in the Hotel Barclay.

During 1933 the New York Community Trust at 111 Broadway -- one of the twenty largest foundations in the country -- distributed a record total of $198,918 in charitable funds, according to the annual report of Ralph Hayes, the director, made public yesterday.

In electing HAROLD G. CAMPBELL as City Superintendent of Schools the Board of Education made a commendable choice. It cannot be said that it was dictated by either political or other than educational qualifications. He has won his way to the top by merit. For several years he was deputy to the Superintendent whom he now succeeds.

Representative John J. Boylan was seen last night as the probable new Tammany leader of the middle part of the Fifth Assembly District to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Owen W. Bohan, elected Judge of the Court of General Sessions at the last election.

A program for a more united Protestantism to cope with community needs and to cooperate with government rehabilitation projects was formulated yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the Home Mission Council and the Council of Women for Home Missions.
The New Deal is here. If public expressions mean anything it is the desire and the will of the people.

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- The Pastors' Emergency Federation, comprising more than 7,000 Protestant clergymen, has gained formidable support in its fight against Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller by the organization of laymen's leagues.

The government policy of meeting large emergency expenditures for public and civil works programs and for all kinds of relief by borrowing is the best and perhaps the only way out of the crisis. This method may achieve what the automatic marketing process failed to accomplish.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 (AP). -- Beginning their divided honeymoon voyage across the Pacific, Prince Alexis and Princess Barbara Mdivani boarded ocean liners in widely separated ports today, bound for a reunion in Yokohama.

The undefeated Long Island University basketball team recorded its thirteenth successive victory last night, beating George Washington University, 41-25, before 1,200 at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

Ab Jenkins, race and test driver, received yesterday from the contest board of the American Automobile Association, governing body of automobile racing, a trophy "for the most outstanding accomplishment in 1933." The presentation was made by Captain Eddie l%ickenbacker, chairman of the hoard, in the Hotel Commodore.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels said yesterday that the appeal by the city from the court decision holding invalid the five-cent tax on taxicab rides was awaiting a decision by the Board of Estimate on the policy to be followed with relation to the tax.

Hiding Erickson, 44 years old, of 1,457 Wilkins Avenue, the Bronx, who was butler for former Mayor James J. Walker, surrendered yesterday to District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx as a material witness in the killing of Lillian Schwartz, 19, of 1,175 Wheeler Avenue, last June 21.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Wider use of Central Park and other parks in the city for athletics, especially baseball, was urged by several speakers at the annual dinner of the New York City Baseball Federation last night at the Hotel McAlpin. Forty members attended the dinner, at which a drive for $10,000 to promote the federation's sandlot baseball program also was launched.

Amid a roar of airplane engines and the cheers and laughter of crowds that had gathered to welcome them, members of the United States Navy air squadron were gathered before microphones yesterday at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, to recount their thrilling experiences.

OTTAWA, Jan. 11. -- Lester Patrick's New York Rangers collected two valuable points tonight when they took a 5-3 victory from the Ottawa Senators. It was the Senators' third straight defeat and kept them well down the ladder in the international group of the National Hockey League.

Early indication by the government in Washington as to its plans for possible extension of the civil works program beyond Feb. 15, the date originally set for its completion, was declared essential to the complete success of the program by Civil Works Administration officials yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 11. -- A wall of water seventy-five feet deep was thundering down deep gorges of the Andes Mountains tonight, wiping out whole villages in Mendoza Province. Some estimates of the dead tonight were as high as seventy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP). -- The campaign of bimetalists in the House to obtain support for silver remonetization legislation spread today with the decision of a group of Wheat-Belt Representatives to name a cooperating committee.

License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine declared yesterday at a hearing on news stand graft that "there are a lot of records missing, and somebody is hiding records that we need. We have had police trying to find out who is doing it."

PARIS, Jan. 11. -- Royalists plotted today to restore a monarchy in France while the Chamber of Deputies debated the many scandals unearthed after the suicide of Alexandre Stavisky. He shot himself Monday at Chamonix when the police ware about to arrest him for issuing fraudulent securities of the Bayonne municipal pawnshop.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- William C. Bullitt was confirmed by the Senate late this afternoon without a roll-call as the first Ambassador to the Soviet Union, the only open opponent of his nomination being Senator Robinson of Indiana.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was the most active yesterday of any day for the last two weeks and there was some slight enhancement in quoted values. The other markets were firm with the exception of wheat, which had a setback.

The charge that James J. Joyce, secretary to former Borough President John A. Lynch of Richmond Borough, removed a voters' registration book from a polling place in New Brighton last October in violation of the State election law, was dismissed yesterday by City Magistrate Henry W. Bridges in the West New Brighton Police Court on motion of Assistant District Attorney William R. McDermott.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Recapture by the Treasury of the profits on about $3,600,000,000 of gold held by the Federal Reserve banks in the event that President Roosevelt devalues the dollar was discussed today by the President at conferences with fiscal advisers and Attorney General Cummings. That devaluation will come when Mr. Roosevelt believes the opportune moment has arrived for stabilization is generally accepted here as a foregone conclusion.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11. -- Robert Ellsworth Lowe, 38, former cashier of the Teaneck (N.J.) National Bank, and his bride of a few months, the former Mrs. Elfrieda Ecklelmann Renner, 29, were arrested here today by local police and two Department of Justice agents.

Friends, near-friends and casual acquaintances who expect Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan to help them when they get summonses for traffic violations merely will be wasting time, he announced yesterday.

The directors of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation declared yesterday a dividend on the common stock of 1/800 share of convertible 5 per cent preference stock, equal to 12 1/2 cents in par value of the preference stock. Regular preferred and preference dividends were voted.

The New Republic dwells on the woes of the Progressives. These Thunder Birds have lost their thunder. Mr. ROOSEVELT has snatched it from them. Where are they to go? What are they to do? At a lodge of sorrow in Chicago they made an effort to pull themselves out of the hole by making it deeper.
" I Was a Spy," with Herbert Marshall, Conrad Veidt and Madeleine Carroll, will open at the Roxy today.

A concerted movement to stamp out racketeering was launched by State, county and Federal prosecutors with the promise of cooperation from the police yesterday. Plans for the campaign were laid at a conference, the first of its kind ever held in this city, in the offices of State Attorney General John J. Bennett, in the State Office Building.

SEA BRIGHT, N.J., Jan. 11. -- The Coast Guard and Monmouth County police began a search tonight, for W. Wilfred Dupont, 34 years old, of 71 Elm Place, Nutley, N.J., insurance salesman, whose automobile, business papers, hat and overcoat were found this afternoon on the sea wall of the J.L. Galef estate here.

Operating earnings of the Bankers Trust Company in 1933 were $10,938,329, against dividend requirements of $7,500,000 at the rate of $3 a share, S. Sloan Colt, president of the company, told stockholders yesterday in a detailed report at their annual meeting.

A chaotic situation with respect to the honoring by American corporations of bond coupons payable in one of several currencies at the option of the owner has been disclosed in the divergent policies of the Southern Pacific Company and the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 (AP). -- Kinrey Matsuyama, champion billiard player of Japan, but now a resident of New York, won the opening game in the national three-cushion tournament tonight by defeating Robert B. Harper, Southern sectional winner from Denver, 50 to 36, in fifty-seven innings.
Park Commissioner Browne of Brooklyn declared yesterday the proposal to scrap the Lay plan for Marine Park was "the most nonsensical thing I have ever heard of."
CINCINNATI, Jan. 11. -- The Cincinnati Reds tonight announced the signing of Bob O'Farrell of the Cardinals as a player-manager for the coming baseball season.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11. -- Four seasoned tennis campaigners today defeated the best opposition Florida and Cuba could offer and swept into the semi-final round in the Miami Biltmore championship.

Anticipating early passage of legislation setting up a Municipal Housing Authority, a steering committee of housing experts was brought together yesterday at the request of Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post to assemble data to be turned over to the new agency upon its creation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11. -- John Rogers, Denver professional, won the medal over the Lake Merced course in today's 18-hole qualifying round of the fourth annual San Francisco open golf championship with a fine 70, two under par.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11. -- Appointment of two committees for President Roosevelt's birthday ball to be held Jan. 30 at the Everglades Club were reported today by Hugh Dillman, Palm Beach chairman.

There is one fact in connection with the post-prohibition liquor situation that the manufacturers and dispensers have apparently failed to grasp, and this is that to several millions of us their products are no longer a mystery. We know what they are made of, how they are made, and what they cost to make.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11. -- James A. Moffett of New York, whose failure to agree with Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, is understood to have been the underlying cause of his resignation as vice president of the company last July, has been elected vice president of the Standard Oil Company of California.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11. -- Johnny Skillman, 26-year-old defending titleholder of the Apawamis Club, Rye, N.Y., got away to an auspicious start in the national professional squash racquets championship tournament at the Penn A.C. today, winning two matches to advance to the third round.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 11. -- The cost of living for families of wage-earners and lower-salaried workers increased 5.2 per cent during the six months period ending last month, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, reported today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11. -- The first break in the tense football coaching situation at Yale came today with the appointment of Ivan Williamson, captain and star end of the 1932 Michigan Wolverines, as freshman end coach.
" Come of Age," a play by Clemence Dane, with music by Richard Addinsell, will open tonight at Maxine Elliott's Theatre.

The Rev. Cornelius Greenway, pastor of All Souls Universalist Church, Brooklyn, has been expelled from the Alpha Kappa Club, an organization of ministers, for an alleged breach of ethics in referring to several of his associates as "nominal, hyphenated Christians," it was disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP). -- A 43-year-old unemployed engineer boldly stepped up to the solicitor's table in historic Old Bailey Court today, told the judge he had proof he was the nephew of King George, and won the right to subpoena witnesses in his fight against a charge of attempting to blackmail his Majesty.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 11. -- President Roosevelt enjoyed an hour's drive through Washington without a motorcycle escort this afternoon when he slipped away from official duties to look over some work being done in this city as part of the Civil Works program.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York expressed to Senator Robert F. Wagner yesterday the appreciation of its members for his fight against the ratification of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty in opposition to President Roosevelt's recommendation.

CHICAGO, -- Jan. 11 (AP). -- Dr. Alice L. Wynekoop went on trial for murder today while 2,000 persons rioted in the corridors seeking-entrance to the court room. Four tentative jurors were chosen before adjournment.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 11. -- Seven Ohio State University students who revolted against compulsory military training were suspended from the school today by President George W. Rightmire.

Jeremiah D. Maguire, president of the Federation Bank and Trust Company, the largest labor bank in the world, with resources of $7,818,917 at the end of 1933, says in his annual report that loans of various descriptions have materially increased, "all indication of the progress of your bank and an expansion of its business."

The national junior team saber championship was won by the Fencers Club last night in a tournament held under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America. So close was the competition in the final round-robin that the number of opponents' touches had to be computed to decide the victor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Representatives of several New York State banks, headed by the Manufacturers Trust Company, including Joseph V. McKee of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, have discussed with the RFC the prospects of obtaining from it loans for new mortgage loan companies to be set up to aid distressed guaranteed mortgage and certificate holders.

When the America's Cup races are held next September, probably off Newport, the successor to the late Sir Thomas Lipton's famous steam yacht Erin will be a twin Diesel-motored yacht, the Argosy, which has been purchased by T.O. M. Sopwith, who is having the yacht Endeavour built to race for the cup.

Deputy Chief Inspector Thomas F. Cummings who has commanded the uniformed force in Brooklyn for five years was demoted yesterday to the rank of captain and was sent to take charge of the Grand Avenue Precinct, Brooklyn.

Records filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office of Hudson County, N.J., show that the Port of New York Authority paid $50,000 for real estate in Weehawken which was valued for taxation purposes at $13,800.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- Five thousand tons of rock sent roaring down the face of Short Cove Mountain by a dynamite blast which had exploded prematurely crushed two men to death here this afternoon at the quarry of the New York Trap Rock Company.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11. -- Revision of the constitution and by-laws governing athletics at Yale has been completed, it was announced today. Changes in awards of both major and minor sport insignia will go into effect.

All sections of the money market continued quiet. Rates for all classes remained firm. Business was at a minimum and chiefly of a routine character. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent and street loans 3/4. Demand was light in both places.

The New York Americans fought the Toronto Maple Leafs to a standstill in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Simpson skaters, after gaining a one-goal advantage in the first period, yielded a point in the second, and through the remainder of the battle, including the overtime period, neither team was able to break the 1-1 deadlock.

Tammany politicians were accused in the Supreme Court yesterday of ordering reprisals against the American LaFrance and Foamire Corporation, which has furnished most of the city's fire-fighting apparatus in recent years, because of the Seabury inquiry testimony of its president, Charles B. Rose, involving former Mayor James J. Walker.

Zeek, the Rouen young duck adjudged the best duck in the United States at the annual exhibition of the New York Poultry Show, Inc., now in progress at the 244th Coast Artillery Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street, should have been in fine fettle yesterday afternoon after winning the championship.
LONDON, Jan. 11. -- Britain last year imported 262,039,000 worth of bullion and specie, which was an increase of 102,036,000 over 1932, figures published today by the Board of Trade show.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 11. -- A new plan for the election of alumni representatives to the board of trustees of Princeton University was approved today at the Winter meeting of the board.

Coordinated surveys of all city departments were begun yesterday so that as soon as the Legislature adopts the city's revised economy bill the Board of Estimate will have the necessary data upon which to base its projected reforms.

Mayor LaGuardia administered the oath of office to Dr. Harold G. Campbell, newly elected Superintendent of Schools, at City Hall yesterday The oath also was administered to Dr. John S. Roberts and Stephen F. Bayne, new associate superintendents.

William Woodward was continued in office by the Jockey Club yesterday when the stewards re-elected the master of the Belair Stud as chairman. Joseph E. Widener was returned as vice chairman and John E. Cowdin as secretary.

The charge of undue assistance by the government to the development of inland waterways, made by the railroads in the last year, was answered by J.W. Muller, general manager of the Transmarine Transportation Corporation. In a letter to Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, Mr. Muller invited a government survey to determine the actual degree to which the waterway operators benefit.

Two rivals for a bout with Barney Ross, holder of the world's lightweight title, head the boxing card tonight in Madison Square Garden. Cleto Locatelli, Italian, who wears the European 135-pound crown, and Jack (Kid) Berg of England are the principals, and they are scheduled to box ten rounds.

The first Toscanini concert of the season by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra took place yesterday evening in Carnegie Hall. This meant an auditorium again crowded to capacity with the most impressive audience of the season -- an occasion when music lovers in all walks of life assembled to hear Mr. Toscanini's interpretations and do homage with him to the genius of Beethoven.

Federal funds are to be used to carry out the wild-life conservation program which is being prepared by the recently appointed Federal Game Bird Restoration Committee, according to a letter which the committee mailed yesterday to all State game and conservation officials and to interested organizations.

Plans were made yesterday in this city and suburban communities for balls to be held Jan. 30 in honor of President Roosevelt's fifty-second birthday, the proceeds of which will be used for the benefit of the Warm Springs Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Eight teams-of-four survived the first knockout round of the national championship play at the end of the first two sessions early this morning at the Hotel Pierre. Sponsored by the United States Bridge Association, the tournament originally included seventeen teams-of-four, eleven of which were victors of intersectional tournaments held throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The taxes carried in the Liquor Tax Bill, passed by Congress today and expected to bring in $500,000,000 annually in revenue, are as follows:

The electrical equipment at Camp Upton, L.I., constructed during the war for the United States Government by the Long Island Lighting Company on a cost-plus-profit basis, was repurchased by the utility company after the war at a greatly reduced price, but this price was carried on the books of the company at the original cost-plus-profit figure, it was brought out yesterday at the Public Service Commission's investigation into the utility's rates.
VIENNA, Jan. 11. -- The Fascist Heimwehr leaders' conference concluded tonight after obtaining another concession from the government.

VIENNA, Jan. 11. -- Austria, which since the establishment of the republic had not known capital punishment, hanged a man this afternoon. The execution was carried out in the courtyard of the Graz Assize Court three hours after the sentence had been pronounced by the lightning court established by Chancellor Dollfuss's martial law proclamation.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 11 (AP). -- When the Baltimore Mail Line steamer City of Norfolk left the Army Base for Havre this afternoon it had cradled on its deck the yacht Marcon, formerly owned by Colonel Charles H. Consolvo and sold through W.M. Eldridge, yacht broker of New York, to George Levy of Paris.

Frederic G. Melcher yesterday was elected president of the R.R. Bowker Company, which publishes The Publishers' Weekly and The American Library Journal. He succeeds Richard Rogers Bowker, who died on Nov. 12. Albert R. Crone succeeds Mr. Melcher as vice president.

Why is the United States Supreme Court like circumstances? Because both alter cases. Why is the United States Supreme Court unlike circumstances? Because the United States Supreme Court cannot alter circumstances, but circumstances can alter the United States Supreme Court.

At the invitation of Mayor LaGuardia, it was learned yesterday, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, acting chairman of the Regional Labor Board, will act as labor adviser to the city administration. Mrs. Herrick will cooperate with the Mayor particularly on enforcement of the State Minimum Wage Law.

Mme. Lotte Lehmann, who made her Metropolitan debut as Sieglinde in "Die Walkeure" last evening, has long been known to New York audiences as a recitalist of rare artistry, particularly in her treatment of German lieder. She had not been on the stage ten minutes when it was apparent beyond doubt that she was also a Wagnerian singer of first rank.

The Triborough Bridge Authority announced yesterday that it had repudiated its lease at 141 Broadway, which led to the resignation of one of its members, Fred C. Lemmerman, after charges had been filed against him by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

While the pace of trade was not as active as was the case last week, reports on retail volume thus far this week showed increases over a year ago. Consumer response to offerings of domestics, home-furnishing items, clearance apparel and men's and boys' wear was good.

PARIS, Jan. 11. -- Foreign Minister Paul-Boncour and Ambassador Dovgalevsky of Soviet Russia expressed satisfaction today upon the signing of the Franco-Soviet trade treaty at the Quai d'Orsay. Both said that the long period of negotiations during which political relationships between the two countries gradually improved had finally made possible the commercial understanding.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey, after hearing testimony yesterday that the appearance in court of Joseph W. Harriman, indicted banker, might prove fatal, ruled nevertheless that Harriman must come to court to attend hearings concerning his mental condition.

As delegates from all over the country met yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club in the annual convention of the United States Polo Association, the probability loomed of international polo with an Argentine team here during the coming Summer.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP). -- James R. Chapman, noted civil and electrical engineer who constructed the London tubes, died at his home here today at the age of 82.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained tonight in honor of the diplomatic corps, giving for them the state dinner included annually in the White House social program, with a musicale afterward to which additional guests were invited.

Fresh impetus appeared generated yesterday for the proposals to make national as well as world open championships a definite part of the tennis tournament program, following Big Bill Tilden's decisive victory over Ellsworth Vines before a record American tennis gallery in the first of their series of professional matches.

The Board of Estimate is prepared to adopt a resolution at today's meeting asking the Legislature for power to reorganize the city government and cut salaries in accordance with the agreement reached between Mayor LaGuardia and Governor Lehman.
Several housing deals were included in the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 11. -- The French Government is supporting the protests of the British and American Governments against what amounts to a partial default of payments upon the German private debt.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's proposal for the substitution of "symmetalism" for gold as a monetary standard and for the redemption of government bonds in currency would not work, because there is not enough gold and silver in the world to make it work, even if both metals were revalued at any conceivable rate, James P. Warburg, vice chairman of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, said yesterday.

Deputy Chief Inspector David J. McAuliffe, who was called to command Manhattan police on Monday because of the success of his previous onslaughts against gambling, made a spectacular raid last midnight at 182 Third Avenue, near Seventeenth Street.

Phay Ray Oh II of Pequosette, Dunrovin Troubadour of Abingdon and Twin Light Tumblebrooks Robin Hood moved into the crystal room of the Hotel Taft yesterday at the head of a fantastically named contingent of cats.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 11 . -- Substantial measures of cooperation between the Canadian National and the Canadian Pacific Railways are to be undertaken soon as the sequel to the appointment of Justice Fullerton as chairman of the Canadian National.

For the eight months of its operations, the National Surety Corporation had a total volume of business of $5,714,802, according to the report issued yesterday by Vincent Cullen, president. Gross income, including $214,877 received from invested assets, amounted to $5,929,680.

Plans for the development and manufacture of a small airplane to sell for about $700 are being studied here and in Detroit by engineers of General Aviation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Having shown himself in control of the House with the adoption of the rule to prevent hostile amendments to regular and emergency appropriation bills during this session, President Roosevelt today turned his attention to the Senate, with the purpose, according to party leaders, of forcing through the St. Lawrence Canal Treaty by exercising his power to the fullest extent.

A slight recession in bank clearings in the last week is reported by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. For twenty-one leading cities the total was $4,366,917,000, against $4,369,471,000 in the same week last year, a drop of 0.7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Restrictions on the importation of liquor by travelers were imposed by Secretary Morgenthau today after he had received an appeal from John McNamara, executive secretary of the Retail Liquor Stores Association of Erie County, N.Y.

NOTING a recent paragraph to the effect that France has Just admitted American apples and pears in return for a doubled liquor quota, and also has excepted the country from her new restrictive quotas on trade in general, the thought occurs that the New Dealers in Washington, who are shuffling the quotas on this side of the water, may be called upon to go into the matter of the Italian quota in pugilistic titles.

With every department of his game functioning perfectly, Harry F. Wolf of the New York Athletic Club, the national champion, routed John B. Quincy of the Yale Club in the third round of the Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP). -- The crowning of a new champion Dachshund, the classy little Red Madchen of the Dachshaven Kennels of Rye, N.Y., marked the opening today of the Miami Biltmore National Dog Show.

Members of the board of directors of the Sportsmanship Brotherhood, holding their annual meeting in the Hotel McAlpin yesterday, re-elected Matthew Woll, president; Devereux Milburn, Preston Davie and Marshall Field, vice presidents; James G. Blaine, treasurer, and Daniel Chase, executive director.

Trade in the wholesale markets here during the week easily got off to the best seasonal start since 1930, according to reports in most lines. It was noteworthy, however, that while the sentiment of the increased number of buyers here was greatly improved, there was no splurge to purchasing.

The advance that had sent up prices more than $3 a bale within a week ran the market into a larger supply of contracts yesterday, and quotations on the Cotton Exchange ended 10 to 12 points lower than on Thursday.

Reichsbishop MUELLER is finding it harder and harder every day to be dictator of the Protestant Churches in Germany. His authority is rejected by a great association of pastors and by leagues of laymen which have been joined already by some 1,500,000 persons, all active workers in the Church.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- General Johnson, gravely concerned over the price-cutting war now raging in five of the major bituminous coal, producing States, has sent out a summons by telegraph to members of the National Bituminous Coal Industrial Board to meet here Tuesday.

Cultural relations with the U.S.S.R. were formally resumed last night when two dancers from the Marinsky Theatre, Leningrad, made their American debut at Carnegie Hall by official permission of their government. They are Tatiana Vecheslova and Vachtang Chabukiani, and their performance was one of the most hilarious events which has graced the dance platform in many a season.

United States Government bonds continued their recovery and domestic corporation bonds their general advance on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Total dealings of $18,229,000 for the listed bond market, although heavy, compared with $20,094,000 on the previous day and with the unusual total of $24,305,000 on Wednesday.

Cross currents in the markets indicated yesterday some confusion of judgment. The bond market continued to advance confidently under the leadership of the United States Government group, but stocks pointed downward after two or three hours of hesitancy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Lightweight hogs were in active demand today and 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight higher in price than yesterday, while other kinds were steady. However, the advance in the former was largely lost at the close. Packers bought about 4,700 hogs weighing 170 to 210 pounds for the Relief Administration, paying $3.50 to $3.55.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- A definite step toward the reformation of Westchester County's government was taken this afternoon when the special committee of the Board of Supervisors on reorganization of county government voted to name a citizens' committee under the laws of 1922 to draft a new form of government for Westchester.

The tactical flight of six United States Navy planes from San Francisco to Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, was a satisfactory demonstration of the efficiency of the air service and the soundness of its equipment. It was a long turn of duty and, as Commander McGINNIS says, "a tough trip," with poor visibility and a night of fog.
By unanimous vote the Board of Estimate adopted a resolution yesterday asking the Legislature to invest it with power to cut salaries and reorganize the city government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- By signing the new Liquor Tax Bill ten minutes before midnight last night, President Roosevelt made the new taxes operative on spirits sold today.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Proposed dissolution by the State of the Continental Life Insurance Company, a Missouri company, was opposed in a hearing here today on the ground that no company is insolvent until it is unable to pay current liabilities.

As former extension director of the White House Conference on Child Health and Protection, I have been interested in the letters of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler and William D. Guthrie about the proposed child labor amendment.

By the margin of a single point, Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia captured the fifth and deciding game of her match yesterday with Miss Eleonora Sears of Boston to gain the final round of the women's national squash racquets championship.

The Bayside Tennis Club suffered its first defeat of the season in the Class B competition of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League in bowing to the Harvard Club players last night, 3 to 2, on the winning team's court. The losers retained first place by half a game.

The estate of Jordan L. Mott, former president of the J.L. Mort Iron Works, who died near the Bahamas on Jan. 7, 1932, while he was on a cruise, was appraised yesterday at $652,928 gross and $519,417 net. Of the gross amount, $553,994, consisting of cash and securities, had been inherited from his wife, Mrs. Katherine J. Mott, who died May 14, 1927.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Members of the Senate committee investigating air mail contracts disclosed tonight that they were checking the income tax reports of Colonel Lindbergh, former Postmaster General Walter F. Brown, and Herbert Hoover Jr., who were among the 200 persons asked to fill out committee questionnaires.

Professor Raymond Moley, formerly Assistant Secretary of State, characterized as "fantastic" last night some of John Maynard Keynes's recent criticisms of the New Deal. Dr. Moley spoke before a large audience in the Town Hall under the auspices of the League for Political Education.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has announced several gifts and a bequest of rare works of art, some of which are to be placed on exhibition this morning in the museum's room of recent accessions.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- Members of the New York State Publishers Association, convening at the Lake Placid Club today for their fourteenth annual meeting, adjourned their business discussions this afternoon to visit the bob run on Mount Van Hoevenberg, where they were guests of the State Conservation Department.

The current discussion of the child labor amendment is interesting, but of all that I have read not one touches the crux of the situation. A school teacher sees this problem and solution as no one else can.

John P. O'Brien, in his first court argument since the end of his term as Mayor, Jan. 1, was interrupted several times in Special Sessions yesterday by the rapping of Presiding Justice McInerney's gavel.

Modern art developments in Paris are receiving considerable attention in local galleries this season. Two recently opened exhibitions carry forward this program. These are a retrospective group of oils by Jacques Villon at the Marie Harriman Gallery and a series of "Compositions,'' also in oil, by Jean Helion, at the John Becker.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- Governor Lehman has received assurances from Washington that the Federal authorities will give prompt cooperation to efforts to stabilize conditions in the New York milk shed and would speed up a marketing agreement.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 12(AP) -- Two claimants to the Kingston Mayoralty were battling for the possession of the office tonight, both contending it is rightfully theirs and determined to fight to a finish.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 12. -- Arthur Crock, Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, spoke tonight on "The National Recovery Act -- An Appraisal," in the Stafford Little series of lectures at Princeton University.

William J. Flynn, former Public Works Commissioner of the Bronx and for years a centre of political controversy in that borough, has filed an application for a $240 a month or $2,880 a year city pension, it was disclosed yesterday.

Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson, poet, editor and diplomat, celebrated his eighty-first birthday yesterday. Still actively interested in many projects, including his directorship of the Hall of Fame, he did not allow the observance of the anniversary to interfere with his day's work.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- Substantial agreement on the terms of the bill to give Mayor LaGuardia and the Board of Estimate broad powers for reform of city government has been reached between the offices of Governor Lehman and Mayor LaGuardia, it was learned tonight.

TRENTON, Jan. 12. -- Subcommittees of the State commission appointed by the Legislature to study possible consolidation of local governments were instructed today to conduct surveys and report back with recommendations by April 1. The chairman of the commission is Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Public Service Corporation.

Fred I. Kent, who has been in charge of the special division of the Federal Reserve Bank controlling transactions in foreign exchange since March, resigned yesterday from the bank, effective on next Monday. The division was established by the bank to perform the duties placed upon it by the President's executive order of March 10 in respect to transactions in foreign exchange.
Nine properties, eight in Manhattan and one in the Bronx, were sold at auction yesterday, and in all cases were bid in by the plaintiffs. Two Manhattan sales were postponed.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12. -- Another A.G. Tarn racer scored at Jefferson Park when Altena led home a field of 3-year-old platers today in the six-furlong third race on an all-claiming program. Mint Memories was second, with Fair Duchess third.

DETROIT, Jan. 12. -- A statement by Edsel Ford in Washington that business conditions at present "look very, very good" is shared by other leaders of the automobile industry, who think the combination of increased purchasing power, improved conditions and accumulated replacement demand is beginning to be felt in growing degree.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The heavy administration machine rolled successfully over another House uprising today and passed the controversial Independent Offices Appropriation Bill without a record vote.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- In accordance with the President's executive order approving the Motion Picture Code, Sol A. Rosenblatt, NRA Division Administrator in charge of amusements, today transmitted to the industry three-point questionnaires intended to develop its financial structure.

Mrs. Ernest Frederick Eidlitz gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 920 Fifth Avenue, for Mrs. Kensuke Horinouchi, wife of the Japanese Consul General in New York, and Mrs. Riochiro Arai, president of the Japanese Women's Club in New York.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 12. -- F.H. Carpenter's Scream, 21 to 1 shot, scored handily in the mile of the featured Lantana Purse at Tropical Park today after a ragged start had spoiled the chances of several of the leading contenders. Ridgeview, second, was beaten by a length, but was two lengths before Moane Keala.

Justice Pette in the Queens Municipal Court yesterday ordered the city to refund part of the $15 fee paid to the Board of Health for a permit to sell light wines and beer, because the permit became void when the State beer law went into effect June 1.

A pledge of cooperation by manufacturers with the government's recovery program was voiced yesterday by Clinton L. Bardo, president of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, following his election as president of the National Association of Manufacturers. Mr. Bardo succeeds Robert L. Lund, who headed the association for two years. Mr. Lund was elected chairman of the board of organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Forty-four State emergency council directors were appointed by Frank C. Walker, chairman of the national council. They will have the responsibility within their territories of directing compliance with NRA codes and AAA marketing agreements and for adequate representation of consumers.

Charters were granted yesterday by the Associated Actors and Artists of America, which is the branch of the American Federation of Labor having jurisdiction over employes in the entertainment fields, to the Actors Betterment Association and to the Burlesque Artists Association, making each the official representative for artists in their particular fields.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Edsel Ford said in an interview today that business conditions "look very, very good" and that the Ford Motor Company expects a "75 per cent pick-up" over 1933.

Despite the brilliant performance of George Sheinberg of City College, New York University's swimming team turned back the Lavender, 38-33, in a meet at the C.C.N.Y. pool last night. Sheinberg won the 220 and 440-yard races, swam anchor on the winning relay team and shattered the college record in the 440.

A suit for $53,322 was filed in Supreme Court yesterday against Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins for alleged thefts by employes from the funds of his office while he was County Clerk. The suit is brought by the City of New York and the County of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- In an effort to avert a threatened strike of anthracite miners tomorrow, the National Labor Board decided today to ask the Anthracite Board of Conciliation to take up the report of the national body's fact-finding committee for immediate investigation.

A new educational policy that will exclude many of the conventional college entrance and curriculum requirements that are believed to hamper the progress of many students has been developed at St. Stephen's College, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., it was announced yesterday by Acting Dean Donald G. Tewksbury.

In her radio debut last night, Maude Adams brought to a nationwide audience a revival of Sir James Barrie's "The Little Minister," her early starring vehicle which captivated playgoers of another generation when it was presented at the Empire Theatre in 1897.

Several important pieces of new State and municipal financing are included in the total of $24,258,875 which will come up for award next week. The total compares with this week's aggregate of $12,343,200 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $8,395,101.

Baldwin B. Bane of the Federal Trade Commission was reported as stating that the Federal Securities Act was "good and workable." He argues that it is not the Securities Act which is obstructing financing, because there are few issues being made even of the exempted securities, such as "municipal issues, bank stocks or building and loan association stocks, and railroads, and so forth."

Unnecessary units of the English system of Weights and measures have been discarded, just as there has been a good deal of discarding of unnecessary metric measures. With the English system many of our odd units are confined to the industries in which they are peculiar.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

In view of the evident determination of the administration in Washington to float further huge issues of bonds and certificates, it occurs to me that the principles of good banking laid down in a recent article in the Yale Review by Dr. H. Parker Willis should be kept in mind.

PARIS, Jan. 12. -- In so far as the political effect is concerned the Stavisky scandal is over. Late this evening after more than twelve hours of stormy debate the Chamber of Deputies by 360 to 229 rejected the Opposition's proposal for a parliamentary commission to investigate the collapse of the Bayonne municipal pawnshop operated by Alexandre Stavisky.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Debate on the St. Lawrence seaway treaty was opened in the Senate today by Senator Pittman, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, as spokesman for the administration, who championed ratification and denounced the "selfish interests" of the railroads and the port cities in fighting the treaty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Jan. 6 totaled 343,284,000 barrels, an increase of 809,000 barrels from the total of 342,475,000 barrels reported for the preceding week, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and administrator of the code of fair competition for the petroleum industry, announced today.

To clear up misunderstandings between banks and their depositors over the proposed bankers' code regulations governing service charges, the New York State Bankers Association sent yesterday to its member banks a letter declaring that no attempt had been made to "put over" these regulations on the public or on General Hugh S. Johnson, and that they had been taken up and approved by one of General Johnson's deputies.
For the first time in the history of the sport in this country, polo has ten-goal players from west of the Hudson River.

The thirty-fourth National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace will come to a close at 11 o'clock tonight. According to the committee in charge of the exhibition, attendance at the show already has broken last year's record "by an enormous margin," and the number of visitors on some days has set new marks in the exhibition's history.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 12. -- Forcing their opponents to defeat themselves by their masterful strategy, George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago, defending champion, and Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta today battled to the final in the Miami-Biltmore tennis tournament.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 12. -- Following a long session of the executive committee of the Yale Athletic Board of Control, it was announced today that no action had been taken on the football coaching situation.

More than 2,000 unemployed musicians who met yesterday in Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street, elected a committee to ask Governor Lehman to aid in obtaining legislation to permit Sunday performances in the so-called legitimate theatres.
The largest dinner ever tendered to a Columbia athletic team will be held tonight in the Morningside gymnasium at 6:30 o'clock in honor of the Blue and White's football team.

Reports from all sections of the country showed retail sales had steady increases during the week, according to the trade review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Day-to-day sales totals are rising uninterruptedly above the showing for last year.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Jan. 13. -- The precarious position of the rebel Nineteenth Route Army is reported to have been made more dangerous because a large volunteer force in Southern Fukien, hitherto neutral, now proclaims its loyalty to Nanking.

The report of the Discount Corporation of New York as of Dec 31, published yesterday, shows that the corporation greatly increased its portfolio of acceptances and United States Government securities during the last quarter of the year Holdings of acceptances rose from $36,639,873 on Sept. 30 to $112.125, 345 at the end of the year, and holdings of government securities increased from $47,936,999 to $78,801,926.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 12. -- Delegates from twenty-five business, professional and civic groups started a campaign today against the State charter which grants tax exemption to the Society for Useful Manufacture, known locally as the S.U.M.

Every one associated with "Come of Age," which was acted at Maxine Elliott's last evening, has aspired so earnestly that it would be gratifying to say that they had succeeded. Working in collaboration, Clemence Dane and Richard Addinsell have improvised a musical fantasy on the tragic legend of Thomas Chatterton.

St. Ann's Academy registered a 17-to-11 basketball victory over Manhattan Prep yesterday in the Manhattan College gymnasium in a New York division C.H.S.A.A. game. At half time St. Ann's was ahead, 6 to 4.
The attack on John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, was pressed from two directions yesterday.

The Brooklyn Technical High School hockey team virtually won the P.S.A.L. championship by defeating the Erasmus Hall sextet at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night, 6 to 0. The Tech skaters, who won the title last year, have only one game left to play, and a victory or a tie in that struggle will give them their second championship in a row.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 12. -- No reply has yet been received by the State Department to its inquiry of the German Government as to why German bonds are being bought in while Germany insists that insufficient foreign exchange is available for debt service. Through Ambassador Dodd the Reich government was asked specifically to what extent funds had been granted for such bond repurchases.

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- Within an hour after the first news of Governor Gore's resignation and General Winship's nomination reached La Fortaleza this afternoon, El Mundo had a single sheet, 1-cent extra on the street, giving the text of Mr. Gore's letter and the President's note of acceptance.

When Tito Schipa, Metropolitan Opera tenor, retires from the operatic stage "some years hence," he will devote his time to raising chickens at his huge chicken farm near Capannelle, Italy, eighteen miles from Rome.

BERLIN, Jan. 12. -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Prussian Premier, Minister of the Interior and head of the regular and secret State police, Reich Aviation Minister and Speaker of the Reichstag, celebrated the first birthday he has had in the Third Reich today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Opposition to the NRA code proposed by the electric light and power industry was offered by the Federal Power Commission, the Department of Interior and the Edison Employes Equity Association, a labor organization, at a hearing today.

Karin Branzell, contralto of the Metropolitan, who fainted on leaving the opera stage after singing her role of Fricka in "Die Walkure" on Thursday evening while suffering from a recurrent attack of gallstones, underwent a second examination by X-ray yesterday to determine if an operation were necessary.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- A conviction of Charles Smith, charged with preaching atheism in New York City streets, has been upheld by the Court of Appeals, which also ruled that an ordinance requiring of exhorters permits for street speaking was constitutional.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. -- Johnny Skillman of the Apawamis Club, Rye, N.Y., the defending titleholder, survived a day of upsets in the quarter-final round of the national professional squash racquets championship at the Penn A.C. today.

Efforts of sportsmen to obtain restrictive legislation covering saltwater fishing will meet with vigorous resistance at Albany this Winter, according to Captain Frank J. Tuthill of East Marion, L.I., president of the Eastern Long Island Fishermen's Association. Captain Tuthill has led many such fights in the last thirty years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Five securities issues totaling $3,000,000 are proposed in registration statements filed with the Federal Trade Commission under the Securities Act and made public today.
Chief Inspector Lewis J. Valentine served notice yesterday on gamblers and racketeers that their stay in this city would be short.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Governor Lehman's Debt Conciliation Commission will meet here tomorrow to consider ways of helping farmers and their creditors make adjustments for their mutual benefit.

VIENNA, Jan. 12. -- The insecurity of Chancellor Dollfusa's Patriotic Front was clearly shown by the surprising results of a police raid this morning on the home of Alfred Frauenfeld, Vienna leader of the outlawed Nazi party, in connection with renewed terroristic activities by the Nazis since Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- After Mr. Leyburn, the bank examiner, testified today that the Controller of the Currency did not act on his reports of bad conditions in the Guardian Banks of Michigan "because he was told by the higher command not to do anything to rock the boat and not to have any more bank failures," he explained that he meant the Secretary of the Treasury and the White House by "higher command."

Miss Elsie Hydon's champion Lavender Chu Chu won the top honors as the thirty-second annual show of the Atlantic Cat Club ended last night in the Hotel Taft. Chu Chu, a handsome blue Persian, was judged best male and best cat in the show.
A crowd of about 6,000 in Madison Square Garden last night saw the passing of an old Garden ring favorite.

Arthur A. Ballantine, who was Under-Secretary of the Treasury in the former Republican administration, attacked the financial program of the Roosevelt administration yesterday on the ground of its great contemplated expenditures.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 12. -- The mystery of how large the universe is or whether it is boundless may not be solved soon, but Dr. Edwin Hubble gives a hint of what may lie beyond the range of the 100-inch telescope.

The Triborough Bridge Authority is a separate body not directly under the supervision of the Mayor. He has the right to remove a member on charges, however, and to fill vacancies. The board is composed of three-commissioners, who serve for overlapping terms. From the time the Authority was created a year ago it has been in Democratic hands.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP). -- A jury of craftsmen and clerks, salesmen and CWA workers was selected today to decide whether Dr. Alice L. Wynekoop killed her daughter-in-law, Rheta, and, if so, what the penalty shall be.
" Tobacco Road," which has been playing at the Masque Theatre since Dec. 4, will move on Monday to the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 12. -- Orders were issued today for the appearance of former President Carlos Ibanez and other alleged revolutionary leaders before the special court which is investigationg the plot unearthed by the police several days ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12. -- While the medalist, Johnny Rogers of Denver, still set the pace, though other favorites toppled, survivors worked through first and second rounds today in the San Francisco national match play open golf championship.

Cardinal Hayes issued a pastoral yesterday which will be read tomorrow at all the masses in Catholic churches in the city, asking his priests to exhort their parishioners to visit the Bishop Dunn Memorial Mission Exposition which will open in the Hotel Commodore Monday and continue through Jan. 21.

WARSAW, Jan. 12. -- Nearly 30,000,000 dollar notes, it is calculated, left Poland in the last half of 1933 and not more than another 30,000,000 remain in circulation in this country. The dollar has ceased to be Poland's auxiliary currency, which it has been for more than ten years.

TRENTON, Jan. 12. -- Six years of litigation ended today with an opinion by the Court of Errors and Appeals that the Elizabeth School Board had not violated a State law enacted in 1925 prohibiting salary discrimination because of teachers' sex.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP). -- The veteran Alfredo De Oro of New York, former national three-cushion and pocket billiard champion, tonight defeated Arthur Woods, 50 to 39, in sixty-five innings in the United States three-cushion billiard tournament.

The money market was listless. Although the Street rate for call loans was easier at 3/4, compared with 7/8 previously, there was little doing even at that figure. The rate on the Exchange remained at 1 per cent. Time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were all quiet.

Four hundred guests, subscribing collectively some $10,000 in addition to further individual gifts, attended a benefit concert held under distinguished auspices last evening for the fund for destitute German professionals here and abroad. Lawrence Tibbett, the American baritone, and Jose Iturbi, the Spanish pianist, joined with Jascha Heifetz in volunteering the concert, which was held in the large music room of Mr. Heifetz's penthouse atop a twenty-story building at 247 Park Avenue.

HONOLULU, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Showers of praise, including a congratulatory message from President Roosevelt, poured today upon Flight Squadron 10 of the United States Navy for its precision flight over 2,400 miles of the Pacific from San Francisco to Honolulu.

Hardman, Peck Co., after more than fifty years on Fifth Avenue, will move their piano business to 33 West Fifty-seventh Street, it was announced yesterday. The six-story building at that address has been leased for fifteen years by the firm through R.B. Wattley Co., Inc.

Carl H. Pforzheimer, New York broker and chairman of the Westchester County Relief Committee, was the host last night to sixty bankers, financiers and insurance officials at a dinner at the Hotel St. Regis. The dinner, which was private, was arranged for an informal discussion of current problems in American municipal administrations.

New York's first butlers' ball was pronounced "successful beyond all expectation" by Robert Hider, butler for Mrs. Marshall Field, as he cast a benign eye on 2,000 other butlers, gardeners, tradesmen and valets fox-trotting with their ladies in the ballroom of the Hotel Commodore, at 1 o'clock this morning.

When an Irish judge ruled the other day that General O'DUFFY is entitled to wear a blue shirt he may have precipitated a situation that bodes good or ill for DE VALERA. But, so far as an outsider can tell, it has been a good thing for Ireland.

Nearly every one of the 300 passengers who arrived from Bermuda yesterday on the Furness liner Monarch of Bermuda returned to a great disappointment in the form of a new liquor ruling imposed while they were away. On Thursday night the Treasury Department announced that passengers, who had previously been able to bring home $100 worth of liquor duty free, could bring only one quart.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, State Public Works Superintendent, today announced that his department is developing plans for four 44-foot highways to be constructed "when the financial condition of the State warrants."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley was asked today to nullify all the orders issued by Justice George H. Taylor Jr. in the rehabilitation of the Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company.

CAMBRIDGE, Jan. 12. -- A prediction that high school education would ultimately become compulsory as a result of changing economic conditions, and a plea that it be revised to serve the highest purposes of democracy, were made tonight by Professor Isaac L. Kandel of Columbia University, giving the annual Inglis lecture at the Harvard School of Education.

The city administration's housing bill, now in the process of final redrafting, will make possible the setting up of housing authorities in cities throughout the State, as well as in New York City, it was disclosed yesterday.

Transfer to the Finance Department of full responsibility for inspection of commodities bought by the city is being considered as a part of the general plan of the LaGuardia administration to reform the structure of'the city governmerit for efficiency and economy.

Miss Millicent Baum, New York's "ideal school teacher," so called because of her personality which has inspired thousands of associates, students and former students during her fifty years' service as a public school teacher, was honored yesterday such as few other persons in the city's history.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 12. -- Preliminary estimates of the Mendoza River catastrophe list twenty-three persons dead, $5,000,000 property loss and 190,000 acres of vineyards facing destruction by the shutting off of irrigation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Attorney General Cummings today gave President Roosevelt a ruling on the legality of the government's taking over the $3,600,000,000 in gold held by the Federal Reserve Banks.

For the first time in many years the Association for the Advancement of Science has chosen as its president a man who is widely known as a teacher and a teacher of teachers -- Professor EDWARD L. THORNDIKE. He has had an important part in developing Teachers College in Columbia University.

Although more alert than usual to trading opportunities, speculative leaders interested mainly in the share market seemed to find little in yesterday's news upon which to base what they like to speak of as "constructive developments." The news was not unfavorable, however, even if it could not be called exciting.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- Increased outside interest in wheat was apparent today on the Board of Trade, and with commission houses and the professional element buying actively the price for the May delivery advanced 1 3/4 cents a bushel from yesterday's closing quotation to the highest level since Dec. 12.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. -- At its concert this afternoon in the Academy of Music the Philadelphia Orchestra under Leopold Stokowski gave a first Philadelphia performance of William Walton's "Belshazzar's Feast," assisted by Dudley Marwick, baritone; the Philadelphia Orchestra chorus, composed largely of students from local colleges and universities, and the Mendelssohn Club of Philadelphia.

Two publishing houses are celebrating their tenth anniversaries this month, Simon Schuster and W.W. Norton. Norton's tell of having three Nobel Prize winners on their list, Thomas Hunt Morgan, leading authority in experimental biology; Max Planck, originator of the quantum theory in physics, and Edwin H. Schroedinger.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Within an hour after announcing the resignation of Robert H. Gore as Governor of Puerto Rico, President Roosevelt today sent to the Senate the nomination of Major Gen. Blanton Winship, retired, for that post.

A bill imposing new Federal liquor taxes has been approved by both houses of Congress and signed by the President. The rates are necessarily experimental.Within a year Congress will in all probability be reconsidering them, questioning whether a tax of $2 a gallon on spirits is too high or too low, and whether the distinctions made between wines of different alcoholic content are rightly drawn.

John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, pledged his support yesterday to the nationwide movement to honor President Roosevelt with benefit dances on Jan. 30, the Chief Executive's fifty-second birthday. The proceeds will go to the Warm Springs (Ga.) Foundation for infantile Paralysis.

It would be difficult to measure the energy devoted by local governments and volunteer associations to the lessening of motor vehicle accidents and the reduction of fatalities. The number of people killed on streets and highways in the last four years exceeds by more than 10,000 the total of dead on the Union side in the Civil War.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Distilled spirits, wine and beer of more than 3.2 per cent alcoholic content yielded taxes of $19,045,279.89 in December.

Allen L. Lindley, vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, a witness yesterday at the public inquiry of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. in the State Building into the recent market activities of the Atlas Tack Corporation's stock, said he would recommend more frequent and detailed reports by brokerage firms where any suspicions arose regarding the stocks they handled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- A measure was put before the House today which would subject buses and trucks to the same degree of Federal regulation under the interstate Commerce Commission as is now applied to the railroads.

Paul Boesch, Brooklyn lifeguard, defeated Sid Nabors of Memphis in the feature wrestling match at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night. A crowd of 1,500 persons saw Boesch pin his rival in 35 minute and 9 seconds with a body slam.

A committee representing the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council visited Mayor LaGuardia and his Commissioner of Markets, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., yesterday and pledged the organization's cooperation in the drive against racketeers, particularly in the live poultry industry.

Lily Pons, who will return to the opera in Patti's role at the Metropolitan's revival of Donizetti's "Linda di Chamounix" in February, took a brief leave of Broadway last evening for a mid-season holiday and concert tour. It was the French prima donna's fifth appearance of the current series, in addition to three others on the Metropolitan's visits afield.

HAVANA, Jan. 12. -- President Ramon Grau San Martin today signed a decree removing Thomas L. Chadbourne as president of the national Sugar Exporting Corporation, ofifcial organization functioning under the Chadbourne sugar restriction plan adopted by Cuba in 1930, and reorganizing this body.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 12 (AP). -- Although Governor Pinchot is ill in a New York hospital, the Pinchots of Pennsylvania have delivered their first attack against United States Senator David A. Reed, whom the Governor is expected to oppose for re-election.

MIAMI, Jan. 12. -- One young flier from Miami, W.H. Grevemeyer, had a brush with death today as the second afternoon of the All-American air races at the Municipal Airport drew to a close. He won, but it was by a margin so narrow that many minutes elapsed before the tension in the crowd of 5,000 spectators relaxed.
Jesse I. Straus, United States Ambassador to France, is returning today to his post in Paris on the French liner Ile de France, accompanied by Mrs. Straus.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 12. -- Lines for a determined fight on administration policies in the Senate next week were drawn today when Senator Johnson and Senator Robinson, Democratic leader, arrayed their forces on the Johnson bill forbidding flotation in the United States of the securities of any country in default of debt payments to this nation.

An objection of the International Longshoremen's Association to the inclusion of a minimum wage of 30 cents an hour for pier employes in the master code for the shipping industry resulted yesterday in the elimination of the clause and the substitution of a new basic rate.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 12. -- Children of the country to the number of 5,500,000, 35 per cent of whom are of preschool age, have been the principal victims of hardships caused by the depression, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal emergency relief administrator, said today.
Since he was 12 years old Howard Boyle, 19, an evening high school student of 657 MacDonough Street, Brooklyn, has been consumed with ambition to become a chemist.

Irregularity again featured movements of futures prices on local commodity exchanges yesterday, as each commodity moved in accordance with its own conditions in the absence of any general trend. The volume of trading showed slight improvement in some markets.

Four teams of New York contract bridge experts reached the semi-finals of the United States Bridge Association's first annual championship at the Hotel Pierre early this morning. They eliminated the last out-of-town representatives from among the winners of sectional championship events brought here for the tournament.
The Bronx Hockey Club was held to a 1-to-1 tie by the Baltimore Orioles in an Eastern Amateur League game at the Coliseum last night. Neither team was able to score in the extra period.
