ABOARD S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, Jan. 12. -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd has driven his third wedge of aerial exploration into the Pacific quadrant of Antarctica. On the flight he had three companions -- Chief Pilot June, Assistant Pilot Bowlin and Cameraman Peterson, who also acted as radio operator.

Mrs. Margaret Stackhouse, 35 years old, and Angus Stackhouse, her Negro husband, were held in $10,000 bail each in Bay Ridge Court, Brooklyn, yesterday on an affidavit accusing them of having kidnapped Patricia Luciano, 23 days old, from her parents' East Side home at 251 Seventh Street.

The first gain in dollar volume of business since September, 1930, as shown by comparison of sales for a month with those of the same month of the preceding year, appeared in the report of estimated sales for December issued yesterday by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Continued improvement in industrial and commercial activities in Great Britain and Northern Ireland was reported by the Commerce Department today in its weekly survey of foreign business conditions.

Taxes to be raised this year in Jersey City under the tentative budget presented yesterday at a special meeting of the City Commissioners will be more than $1,000,000 over 1933. If the budget is adopted the tax rate will be increased $3 a $1,000, Mayor Frank Hague indicated.
Leaders in the city's musical life joined yesterday in paying tribute to Paul Kochanski. Some of the comments on his death follow:
" Myrt and Marge," in which the radio team make their film debut, will open at the Mayfair on Monday evening. Ted Healy and his stooges, Eddie Foy Jr. and Trixie Friganza, are also in the cast.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

David Mannes's orchestra, at its free concert in the Metropolitan Museum of Art tonight, is to play Lalo's "Roi d'Ys" overture, Mozart's symphony No. 39 in E-flat, Smetana's "The River Moldau," the Gluck-Mottl ballet suite, Emanuel Moor's "Barcarole" and Wagner's fire music from "Die Walktire."

PORTSMOUTH, England, Jan. 12. -- The battleship Nelson, 7,500,000 "wonder flagship" of the home fleet, went aground in the harbor entrance in An early morning fog today when she was starting on the fleet's Spring cruise, and for nine hours the 33,500-ton vessel defied a series of ingenious efforts to move her.

The emergency act passed by the State Legislature during the bank moratorium last March, under which the State Banking Board had the right to suspend the operation of the banking laws until the emergency was declared terminated, was called unconstitutional yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- Walter J. Cummings, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, was elected director, then chairman of the board of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company today, and seven other new members were chosen.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- The prolonged deadlock over the election of a Clerk, which has kept the legislative machinery in the Assembly at a standstill since the beginning of the 1934 session, was broken this afternoon through the appointment by Speaker McGinnies of Fred W. Hammond of Syracuse to the position he has held for twenty-one years.

Commissioner Sidney S. Levine of the Department of Licenses, who has been conducting a graft investigation in his own department for the last four weeks, offered protection yesterday to any news-stand dealers who would tell what they knew.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan, 12. -- Confronted with the refusal of holders of defaulted obligations to accept a lower interest rate until North Bergen Township has made every effort to collect outstanding taxes aggregating $4,316,800, the Municipal Finance Commission ordered today that a tax sale be held immediately.

BERLIN, Jan. 12. -- The eyes of German Protestants are on the meeting tomorrow in Berlin between Reichsbishop Mueller and the State Bishops who were summoned to discuss reorganization of the United Evangelical Church cabinet.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. -- Although Ellsworth Vines, young Californian, managed to take his first set from Big Bill Tilden in their present professional tennis tour, the former Philadelphian carried off the match at the Arena tonight, 6 -- 4, 8 -- 10, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3.

Mayor LaGuardia and Police Commissioner O'Ryan made known yesterday that the Crime Prevention Bureau, established in the Police Department by former Commissioner Whalen, is being scrutinized to determine whether the results it has obtained justify the expense of its budget.

BERLIN, Jan. 12. -- Trading at today's session of the Boerse decreased in volume to near the stagnation point, especially the stock market, and yesterday's weakening tendency increased. Bonds retained more firmness, the revalorization, first series, for instance, actually rising one point, but the market lacked animation.

Another notable baseball event which in recent years had become something of an institution -- the annual Spring salary squabble between Babe Ruth and Colonel Jacob Ruppert -- went into the discard yesterday when Ed Barrow, business manager of the Yankees, announced that the noted home-run slugger and his employer had quietly and amicably come to terms for the 1934 season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- On the eve of the Michigan bank collapse last February Henry Ford turned a deaf ear to pleas emanating from the Treasury Department that he "freeze" his deposits in Detroit units of the Guardian Detroit Union Group of banks, the Senate banking inquiry developed today.
Several minor changes designed to make the old Tombs prison more humane and more nearly escape proof were announced yesterday by Austin H. MacCormick, Commissioner of Correction.

Although the output of the steel industry declined 27 per cent in November, employment dropped only 4.19 per cent, according to a report covering employment and wages in the four weeks on Dec. 2, issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

William C. Potter, president of the Guaranty Trust Company, is expected to become chairman of the company to succeed the late Charles H. Sabin, while W. Palen Conway, a vice president, will probably be chosen president when the bank's directors hold their organization meeting after the annual gathering of stockholders next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- As a result of the hearings held this week to determine the fairness of prices under some of the NRA codes, a preliminary report was made to General Johnson today by A.D. Whiteside, Division Administrator, who recommends further hearings "to investigate the implications involved in regard to price provisions in some codes."

Just after Mr. HAMMOND was made clerk of the Assembly at Albany yesterday, indomitable Chairman MACY exclaimed: "The fight has been won. "The election of HAMMOND was "defeated." This was after all his little band of Republican Assemblymen except four had voted for the appointment of the clerk by the Speaker.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to advertise for public hearing on Feb. 9 a one-year franchise to the Green Bus Lines, Inc., covering four Manhattan crosstown routes. They are the lines on Delancey, Seventy-ninth, Eighty-sixth and Ninety-sixth Streets, which were included in the twenty-five-year grant voted to the New York City Omnibus Corporation in the closing days of the O'Brien administration.
The annual ball Of the First Reserve Aero-Squadron Association was held last night at the Ambassador for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.
BERLIN, Jan. 12. -- The worker's status in the new Germany, uncertain since the Nazi government suppressed the trade unions and collective wage scales, was reordered by the Cabinet today.
Leases in the midtown area for expansion were among the business rentals reported yesterday. Among other new tenancies listed were various garment firms and liquor dealers.

New business written by the New York State Fund for Workmen's Compensation in 1933 exceeded all previous records, according to a report by Charles G. Smith, manager. The total was $2,780,000, or $800,000 more than in the preceding record year of 1929, and more than $900,000 above the amount in 1932.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The Congressional leaders who sponsored the Philippine Independence Act one year ago will make no attempt to extend the offer beyond Wednesday, when it will expire, barring unexpected action by the Philippine Legislature, Senator Cutting said today after reporting on the situation to President Roosevelt.

The New York University's girls' basketball team defeated the St. John's University girls yesterday, 44 to 5, at the N.Y.U. School of Education's Washington Square court. The game marked the second triumph by the Violets in as many starts.

Mayor LaGuardia will be one of three speakers at a mass meeting in behalf of the unemployed to be held in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine Sunday evening, Jan. 21, at 8 o'clock. The others will be Bishop William T. Manning, who has arranged the service, and the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, junior Suffragan Bishop of the Diocese, who is chairman of Dr. Manning's committee for unemployment relief.
MINUTES of a special meeting of the Board of Trustees of Omega University held in the Council Chamber on the Greek Kalends; Mr. Alpha in the chair.

One of the greatest upsets in the Clyde Martin memorial squash tennis tournament was furnished at the Yale Club last night when Philip T. Moore of the Columbia University Club fell before Robert C. Hynson of the Princeton Club.

Eva Le Gallienne will abandon her current tour of "Romeo and Juliet" and her version of "Alice in Wonderland" after two more weeks and then will make a tour to the Coast with three Ibsen plays. They are "Hedda Gabler," in which she will play the leading role; "The Doll's House," with Josephine Hutchinson, and "The Master Builder," in which Miss Le Gallienne will take the part of Hilda.

MANY may ask why Stephen Leacock, whose professorial interest is another field than literature, should be moved to write a fairly extensive book on a novelist and his novels. Mr. Leacock, anticipating the question, answers it himself, and in no uncertain terms.
An old man who had made and squandered millions was found dead yesterday from a heart attack in his $17.50 a week room in the Hotel Wellington.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13. -- Len Kenney, Chicago, went out in front in the national 3-cushion billiard tournament today, aided by the upset victory of Charles McCourt, northern sectional champion from Cleveland, over Kinrey Matsuyama, Japanese star.

HOLLYWOOD. PRODUCTION of one of the year's more interesting and, certainly, most fantastic films was announced this week when it was revealed that Stacy Woodard, creator of the microscopic "Battle for Life" series, is to make "The Land That Time Forgot," which will picture a struggle between man and insects of elephantine proportions.

FASHIONS OF 1934,' which features William Powell as well as gowns and dances, is scheduled to enter the Hollywood on Thursday. In any case it will follow the revival of "Disraeli" at that house. The Warners like this film, and they plan to road show it in Cleveland, Pittsburgh, Washington, Philadelphia and Boston before casting it out for general release.

At a meeting last week of the directors of Christodora House, Ninth Street and Avenue B, it was voted attempt to raise a budget estimated at $94,700 for 1934. Rentals from the nine-story club residence and annual contributions are expected to bring in $54,700, leaving $40,000 which must be raised from new sources if the program of the settlement is not to be severely curtailed, according to John Cabot Jr., treasurer.
Returning a visit of the English players that inagurated the international squash racquets series a year ago, the women's United States team will sail on the Red Star liner Olympic on Saturday.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S statement to Congress that the Federal Government must borrow $10,000,000,000 in the next six months emphasizes the scope of the task that confronts Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, and his advisers in the matter of Uncle Sam's borrowing operations.

THERE is a new spirit in City Hall. The old corridors which for years have re-echoed to the leisurely tread of late-coming or slow-going Mayors are now filled with new sounds. Speed is the order of the day. Dead and gone Mayors, whose portraits in more or less stilted poses line the walls, would gasp in amazement -- if their oleaginous eyes could see -- at the present occupant of the office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Although the first uprising against administration economy measures has been crushed by House leaders, two elements facing them early next week may lead to a serious defection in party ranks.

MR. BRUCE'S familiarity with the life and character of Franklin peculiarly fits him for the writing of such an imaginary but realistic series of scenes as he offers in this volume. For his first book, "Benjamin Franklin Self-Revealed," it will be remembered, won the Pulitzer Prize as the best biography of the year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- When English colonists came to Westchester about 250 years ago, they brought to the New World the forms of local government then known in the old. To be sure, ox carts have given way to streamlined automobiles and log cabins to elaborate homes, but many of the told forms of local government remain.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 13. -- Better passing and accurate long-range shooting were the chief factors in the victory of Duke over the Naval Academy by 29 to 23 in a basketball game today. The visitors took the lead early in the first half and held it despite desperate efforts on the part of Navy.

The intimations from Washington that, presumably in connection with some "dollar-stabilization" plan, the Government might consider "taking over" the gold in the Federal Reserve, have been extremely vague. The matter cannot be discussed in detail until the full particulars of any specific proposal are made known.

PARIS. A SARTORIAL sex war is being waged on Southern beaches. Bathing dresses are turning a cold shoulder on shorts, and pajamas are being extremely superior about beach pinafores. Each side has ardent partisans among leading Paris couturiers, hence the sun seekers may relax in the knowledge that whatever they choose will be smart so long as it is becoming and practical.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- The widely celebrated Loch Ness "sea monster" is neither a prehistoric plesiosaurus nor a sea serpent of the ancients, but only a large gray seal which has strayed from its natural habitat, according to Nature, an authoritative scientific journal.

The writers would like to express their thanks to Hans Lange for his recent programs with the Philharmonic. Considering the history of this orchestra, Mr. Lange seems to have accomplished a minor miracle. On his three Thursday nights he presented music that was varied, stimulating and decidedly worth while -- and he let the panting, overdriven war-horses rent in their stalls.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 13. -- The formal opening tonight of the restaurant at the Beach Club was marked by several dinners.

CORAL GABLES, Fla. -- Left-handed golfers, a cat show and bridge tournaments are component parts of this week of activity at the Miami-Biltmore Hotel, where the echoes of last night's aviation ball still linger.

The duralumin masts for the new America's Cup defense yacht and for her trial horse, Weetamoe, will be 154 feet above deck, or one foot and six inches taller than that of the defender Enterprise in 1930. The heights of the cloud-tearing sticks were made known yesterday.

IN New York State a new law became effective with the dawn of the new year requiring safety glass in all vehicles manufactured or assembled after Jan 1, used for carrying passengers for hire, or as a public conveyance to transport school children or others.

FROM Boston comes the report that the Boston Opera Association has informed its public that the response of former guarantors has been so far "good" to its proposal for a visit of the Metropolitan Opera in the first week of April, immediately after the close of the season in New York.

The Deane plan for eliminating unemployment and sustaining mass purchasing power was explained yesterday by its author, Albert L. Deane, president of the General Motors Holding Corporation, at a luncheon of the League for Political Education in Town Hall.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S new Secretary of the Treasury takes up a task as arduous and exacting as any in Washington, after the task of the President himself. Most men might hesitate at the assignment, but Henry Morgenthau Jr. sets his firm chin a little more firmly and goes to work.

It has been frequently charged that the propaganda of the American Birth Control League is replete with unfairness. My comments on the last letter of Eleanor Dwight Jones will enable the truth-seeking readers of THE TIMES to form their own conclusions on a question of such grave import to the American people.

Hold-up men who only fifteen minutes earlier had robbed a dentist a mile away were routed last night by Dr. Pleamon M. Rountree, also a dentist, from his office at 946 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Dr. Rountree's battle with three of the five thugs was heard by a patrolman, who engaged in a pistol duel with the gunmen as they escaped.

SYRACUSE. N.Y., is the city, and Dr. Winslow, who is Professor of Public Health in Yale University's School of Medicine, has in this book set it on high that the light of its example may shine far and wide upon men. For Syracuse has done a wise, important, inspiring thing that deserves the attention of all other cities and of readers everywhere.
LONDON, Jan. 13. -- A week of abnormally large gold purchases ended today with American buyers taking 500,000 to 555,000 available in the open market.

HOW to levy a fee on millions of unseen listeners is a riddle that has caused more than one economist hours of concentration during the past decade. Recently, several of the calculators have reached what they consider to be practical conclusions, and they have presented their suggestions to Uncle Sam for possible use in the "New Deal."

TORONTO, Jan. 13. -- Led by the veterans Roy Worters, Rabbit McVeigh and Normie Himes, the New York Americans more than held their own with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight and earned a 2-2 tie, the second National Hockey League deadlock the same teams have played this week.

The newly formed Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, which has the approval if not the actual direct backing of the Roosevelt administration, will be represented at the long-term German debt conference in Berlin called by the Reichsbank for Jan. 22.

SEBRING, Fla., Jan. 13. -- Basing my prediction upon the trend of professional golf during the year 1933 and the program and plans mapped out by the tournament bureau and other branches of the Professional Golfers' Association of America, I feel safe in saying that the year 1934 should be as great as 1929 as to prize money, , for professional tournament golf.

Young women in the rural districts of various Southern States will be aided by a special performance of "Die Meistersinger" on Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over by the New York branch of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance in behalf of the organization.

THIS little book with its dignified and unusual title is from the pen of a Japanese born in Hawaii and now a resident of New York. There is no profusion here, for it is not the way of Nippon's art to be profuse, and Miss Gengo is faithful to native tradition.

The review of "Martin Luther" by Mr. P.W. Wilson, was on the whole so flattering that it may seem ungracious to object to anything he said. I feel, however, that I owe it to, let us say, the Record, or Truth, to correct certain misstatements of fact that may easily be verified.

THE Automobile Show which closed last night at the Grand Central Palace is said to have broken all, or nearly all, records for attendance. The cars exhibited embodied more changes and novelties than have been seen at an automobile show for years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 13. -- After getting off to a slow start, the University of Pennsylvania rallied in the final half to defeat the Harvard varsity basketball team, 38 to 22, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game in the Harvard indoor athletic building tonight.
Mrs. William F. Howe Jr. of Boston gained further distinction yesterday as the leading women's squash racquets player of the country by winning the national championship for the third time.

The indoor track season for senior public high school and private school athletes will get under way in New York City on Saturday night when the twenty-ninth annual Stuyvesant High School inter-scholastic meet will be held at the 102d Engineers Armory, starting at 7:30 o'clock.

Dr. H.M. van Haersma de With, the new Minister of the Netherlands to the United States, arrived yesterday on the Holland-America liner Volendam en route to Washington. He was in this country last in 1921-1922, when he came as a member of the Holland delegation to the naval disarmament conference

FIFTEEN years ago this week -- on Jan. 18, 1919 -- the Peace Conference opened at Paris. Its purpose was to clear away the wreckage wrought by the World War and to lay a new basis for the public law of Europe. Looking at the world scene today the authors of the peace settlement must be dismayed at the result of their handiwork.

PINEHURST. -- With the conclusion of the Pinehurst field trial clubs' seventeenth annual meet yesterday this resort faces a week without tournament sports activity. This, however, is only the calm before the storm, for one week from tomorrow the thirtieth annual St. Valentine's golf championship will usher in a solid four weeks of competition.

THE CROSS OF PEACE" is less a novel, in the ordinary sense, than an impassioned argument for the cause of world peace, and a bitter lament for the apparent hopelessness of that cause at the present time. It is true that Sir Philip Gibbs has constructed a romance from Captain Armand Gatieres's relationships with two women who represent the emotional side of his life.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 13. -- The Greenwich Society of Artists will hold an exhibition in the Art Gallery of the Greenwich Library commencing Monday, Jan. 15, and continuing up to and including Tuesday, Jan. 30. It will be entitled "A Brief Survey of Modern Painting in Color Reproduction," and will include more than fifty-seven reproductions, the collection having been made by the Museum of Modern Art of New York.

WHEN Edgar Allan Poe wrote a novel of the Antarctic he described a curtain of mist veiling an unknown land from which came the sound of rushing water; into the mist his small boatload of people disappeared, not to return.

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- A stream-lined train which will make the Boston-Providence run in forty-four or forty minutes, instead of one hour, de luxe equipment for the New York service, reconditioned cars on all divisions and revolutionary improvements in train service, were announced today by John J. Pelley, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford, as part of a $5,500,000 program.

FEES amounting in all to more than $27,500 are reported to have been paid to the London surgeon Dr. H.S. Souttar, his anesthetist, Dr. J.H. Challis, and the nurse, Miss A.M. Bradford, who recently flew from London to Bombay to carry out an operation on the daughter-in-law of the Maharajah of Nepal, and have now arrived back in England.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Continued improvement in business activity, after allowance for seasonal influences, was reported today by the Department of Commerce in its weekly survey of business and industrial conditions. Evidence of an upward trend was seen by the department in the resistance of productive operations and primary distribution, as measured by freight car loadings, to the usual seasonal declines in December.

Expressing his dissatisfaction with the usual methods of filling vacancies in the city's educational system, Mayor LaGuardia urged the Board of Higher Education yesterday to consult a committee of eminent musicians before naming a head of the music department at Hunter College.

PEIPING, Dec. 20. -- One of the minor problems facing the American Government as a result of the recognition of Soviet Russia is to find qualified men to assume charge of the consulates soon to be established in the important cities of the U.S.S.R. The American consular service has long had men stationed in European centres for the purpose of learning the Russian language, and it is expected that some of these will be assigned.

A SCHOOL of music whose avowed and foremost aim is the teaching of composition not as "theory" but as a living language of expression will open its doors Feb. 5, with a preliminary lecture, free to the public, on Jan. 29, at the Dalcroze School.

There were thirty-eight banks in the country with deposits of more than $100,000,000 each at the end of 1933, compared with forty-two banks of this size a year before, according to the annual compilation of the largest banks of the country prepared by The Financial Age.

PALM BEACH. -- With little preliminary manoeuvring and an enthusiasm seldom displayed until later in the season, Palm Beach has already settled down to the enjoyment of many events of diversified interest.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- The calendar of events at Sea Island Beach this week will be headed by a golf tournament to be played on Saturday at the Sea Island Golf Club. There also will be a trap-shooting tournament, dinner dances at the Yacht Club and the Cloister.

Last night's performance of Richard Strauss's "Salome" at the Metropolitan Opera House recalled the furor which the single public performance of that work in the same auditorium evoked in 1907, when, on the night of Jan. 22, it was put on under the regime of Heinrich Conried as a benefit that drew $22,000.

PARIS, Jan. 5. -- Friends of the late Ambassador Jules Jusserand, who represented France in the United States for nearly a quarter of a century, have decided to erect a monument to him in France. The monument will be in the little French town of Saint-Haon-le-Chatel where he used to pass his vacation days in France and where he was buried in accordance with his desire.
TOKYO, Jan. 13. -- The coming coronation in Manchukuo is now referred to with a transparency which makes the censorship look farcical.

In 1929, a year that now seems as unreal as a fantastic dream, the average annual income of a representative group of wage-earning families in the United States was $1,700. In 1932 these same families averaged only $900. In 1929 only a third of the families had incomes of less than $1,200; in 1932 three-fourths of them had less than this amount.

And surely he is, Vincent Burns, in love with life. We fear that his love, as not infrequently happens when high enthusiasms are involved, somewhat interferes with his career as a poet; art is a jealous mistress, permitting not too much interference even by life itself.

Northport and the 105th Field Artillery polo teams were the victors in the Class C games played last night in the 105th Field Artillery Armory. The first named trio defeated the Governors Island combination, 12 to 10, and the Squadron A players went down before the artillery outfit, 15 to 9.
GENEVA, Jan. 13. -- There was much talk last Autumn of the failure of the Geneva, or multilateral, type of diplomacy and of the world's return to the old-fashioned bilateral diplomatic channels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- In terms as strong as those used previously on the opposite side of the argument, Donald R. Richberg, general counsel of the NRA, replied today to the objections raised against the proposed code for the electric light and power industry.

The Scripps Motor Company of Detroit will enter eight models of representative engines in its exhibit at the Motor Boat Show. Restricting the display to eight is necessary because of the physical impossibility of showing all of its thirty-two standard models.
Walter Spence, Rutgers ace, put on a brilliant performance last night in the Morningside Heights pool to enable his team to defeat Columbia, 41 -- 30, in an Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet.

The Federal Bar Association New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, through its president, Henry Ward Beer, disclosed yesterday it had renewed its appeal to Governor Lehman to send a special message to the Legislature recommending emergency legislation to end the congestion of court calendars throughout the State.

THE Bahai movement has spread from Persia into every other land and into nearly every State in this country. Devoted to universal peace, universal brotherhood and universal religion, its venerable leader, Abdul Baha, still issues clarion calls to which people are increasingly responding, notably the youth.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- New light is thrown on Charles Dickens's married life by a collection of 136 letters from the great novelist to his wife, which will soon be made available to students in the British Museum.

Marco Polo and his cohorts of some centuries ago will be revivified Friday night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria, where the annual Beaux-Arts Ball will be given under the auspices of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange that interest on two of its bond issues, which previously was payable in any one of several currencies at the option of the bondholder, would be paid in dollars only to residents of the United States.
a stage coach and breaking into a bank.

The poems which go to make up the collection "Black" are by a man whose parents were born slaves. Mr. Gardner, however, does not permit himself to be bowed under the burdens of his race; on the other hand, if his work is less distinctly Negro than perhaps many of his own race might wish -- there is no going back to plantation tradition and there is a welcome absence of "blues."

CLEVELAND, Jan. 11. -- Industrial plants in many sections of this district advanced schedules the past week, partly on prospects of greater activity in the near future, but more generally as a result of actually increased orders.

Fordham College, the Downtown College, and the Graduate School and Teachers College of Fordham University will conclude the work of the Fall semester this week. The School of Sociology and Social Science ended the work of the semester last Friday and the School of Law will not suspend until Jan. 31.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- The thesis that the new rulers of Germany may spare themselves the trouble of devising measures for eliminating Jews from the national life, as the German Jews are eliminating themselves by reducing propagation, is propounded in The Jewish Review, organ of the German Zionists, by Dr Felix A. Theilhaber.

BOSTON, Jan. 12. THERE is a new play in Boston on the way to New York, by title "No More Ladies." A.E. Thomas, neither unknown nor unpracticed playwright, wrote it lightly, wittily. It has received the blessing of the American Theatre Society as well as of Messrs. Shubert.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The State Department today replied favorably to an invitation from the fourteen nations bound by the Chadbourne sugar agreement to participate in a preliminary discussion of the possibility of concluding a world sugar convention.

An aggressive, hard-hitting Pennsylvania Military College trio defeated Allenhurst, 6 1/2 to 3 1/2, in their Metropolitan Indoor Polo League Class B game at the Squadron C armory in Brooklyn last night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- The Princeton swimming team opened its season in Brokaw Pool today by overwhelming Lehigh, 61 to 10. The Tigers took all eight first places and all except one of the seconds.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 12. -- Two recent events which attracted wide attention in the Commonwealth are bound to have important sequels. One is the election of the reformed Legislative Council of New South Wales. Previously the members of the Legislative Council, which is the upper house, were nominated by the Governor on the advice of the Ministers.

VIENNA, Jan. 2. -- Dr. Kraul, head of the Vienna University women's clinic, has sent to the press an account of an interesting patient, Frau Marie Urmann, who recently gave birth in the clinic to the twenty-ninth child she has had in thirty years.
Mayor LaGuardia announced yesterday that he had appointed Vincent C. Peppe and Bernard A. Savage as Commissioners of the Board of Standards and Appeals.

THE never-ending war against the rat goes on along widely separated fronts. Paris is intensifying its campaign, using poison gas and other means which science has developed. In China the superstitious peasants of Anhul are employing more legendary methods -- giving charades and gay theatrical performances -- a reminder that magic similar to that of the Pied Piper of Hamelin is still relied upon.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13. -- Mrs. James Chesney's Our Justice came from behind in the late stages of the featured Louisiana Purse at Jefferson Park today to win by three lengths from Mrs. R.T. Flippen's War Plane, with John J. Robinson's Little Lad in third place.

A variation of the "Murder at the Vanities" idea provides the complications for a fantastic and frivolous day at a cinema star's estate in Ensenada. In this comic-opera setting the Don Juan hero finds on page 34 a note announcing that he will be killed at 3 o'clock in the morning unless he asks its anonymous writer marry him before then.

TOKYO, Dec. 30. -- A proposal to place Henry Pu Yi on the throne of Manchukuo is now being spoken of sub rosa among officials in Tokyo, but correspondents are forbidden to cable the news or the local press to publish it on the ground that the matter is still being studied.

With the piping of a bo'sun's whistle the doors of Grand Central Palace will be swung open at 7 o'clock on Friday evening, and from then on through Jan. 27 the annual National Motor Boat Show will hold forth.

The poems which Adelaide Love has grouped under this highly engaging title are written with skill against a background of deep thought. And when one comes to think about it, this is not such a usual combination -- skill one may have, and yet lack the mental background; or, if there be ethical sincerity, there may be a lack of poetic excellence.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- Pursuant to his promise of reforms which won the Chamber of Deputies' vote of confidence, Premier Camille Chautemps today announced a bill amending the civil code to facilitate the repression of corruption in government and blackmailing and libel in the press.

Regarding the letters of Wally Benke and A.L. Fenton, it looks paradoxical that certain banking institutions receiving Federal aid look with a fishy eye and a hard-boiled stare at the new Home Owners Loan Corporation 4s.

Laurence B. Mason, whose collection of early United States stamps won commendation in many exhibits, has been elected president of the Collectors' Club and Charles Curie has been re-elected secretary. Plans for the annual dinner in February are in charge of a special committee.

In the week just closed the various primary textile markets enjoyed a spurt of business which was beyond their earlier expectations and which was the largest volume received since the Summer activity. In most cases, sales exceeded production, stocks started to diminish and prices continued their upward movement, initiated in the previous week.

LAKELAND, Fla., Jan. 11. -- Although Florida's citrus season inspired unusual optimism among growers as it got under way three months ago, it has fallen far short of bringing in the money expected, and there is considerable concern as to possible returns during the next two months.

AMONG those who are taking a prominent part in the discussions over the German debt service charges owed to foreign bondholders is Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank. Not many of those who read about Dr. Schacht's activities know that his full name is Hjalmar Horace Greeley Schacht.

This sheaf of poems, chosen in a local book competition out of 207 entries for publication, is more than local to Texas, since Miss Hay, having appeared in considerably more than one New York periodical, is not unknown to metropolitan read ers. This, we take it, however, is her first volume.

The small American college of the right type now fills a definite place in cultural training and development of character, a place that it has not filled since the days of the covered wagon, Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, Easton, Pa., declared at the annual dinner of the Knox College Club last night. Dr. Lewis was formerly a student at Knox.
Attaining supreme heights, the veteran Milton Baron of the Fraternity Club yesterday did something that no other squash tennis star in the district has been able to do in recent years.

ONE of the outstanding trends in gardening today is toward the use of the single flower. Many professionals and amateurs alike have discarded the huge double blossoms that only a few years ago excited admiration. Instead, they are growing the simpler, more effective single type of bloom.

It is evident that the League of Nations is today facing a crisis involving its very existence, it was declared by Frederic R. Coudert, authority on international affairs, at the recent dinner of the Greater New York Branch of the League of Nations Association at the Fraternity Clubs Building, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

Andrei Salama and his Caravan Jongleurs, who dispense folk music carols, selections from medieval mystery plays and humorous peasant vignettes, will appear this afternoon at 3 o'clock in the Barbizon-Plaza. The company includes Ellenor Cook, interpreter of folksongs; Hudson Carmody, bass-baritone; Arcady Stoyanovsky, formerly of the Chauve-Souris; Gene Fontaine, soprano, and Maryann Shelley, pianist.

The Spanish-American War is characterized as a disaster to American political traditions, and its two war heroes, Theodore Roosevelt and Admiral George Dewey, are called "fortunate beneficiaries of groundless cults" in a book by the late Professor John W. Burgess of Columbia University, entitled "Reminiscences of an American Scholar," soon to be published by the Columbia University Press.

Six American colleges in the Near East will be the beneficiaries of a special performance of "La Boheme," in which Lucrezia Bori, Nino Martini and Lawrence Tibbett will have the leading roles, to be given on the afternoon of Jan. 26 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Several young women are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "The Lake" Tuesday night at the Martin Beck Theatre which has been taken over by members of the board of directors of the Children's Village to raise funds for that project.

ONE week from tomorrow night they'll be chanting Civil War songs in West Forty-seventh Street and the body of John (Pottawatomy) Brown, which all these many years has been quietly a-mouldering in the grave, will rise up to reinvest that gentleman's more hardy soul and go marching on to the stage of the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.

MILAN, Dec. 18, 1933. AFTER the partita of Dallapiccola, the next novelty heard at the Augusteo was "Impressioni di Spagna" (first time in Rome), by the Milanese composer-patron, G. Ascanio Cicogna (pupil of Ferroni), president since 1923 of Milan's symphonic society.

Some means of providing for the realignment which has taken place in international commerce since the World War must be found in any changed tariff policy which this country may adopt, Captain F.X.A. Eble, general manager of the Match Institute and former Commissioner of Customs, told THE TIMES here yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11. -- Ten million bushels of grain can be replaced by 75,000,000 gallons of blackstrap molasses under the order of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration allowing alcohol for beverage purposes to be made from other substances than cereal grains, it is estimated here.

A SPECIAL value of timeliness heralds this latest addition to the always valuable series of the Home University Library of Modern Knowledge, now grown to goodly proportions. As with its predecessors, it is a product of modern scholarship and specialized knowledge and therefore speaks with the voice of authority, its author being Professor of Civic Design in the University of Liverpool.

BERMUDA. -- Yachting, favorite sport here, will be as accessible to visitors this season as to Bermuda's own experts. There will be weekly races of Bermuda one-design-class dinghies, to be sailed by visitors only, every Thursday from now until March.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- Sir Frederic Leith-Ross, economic adviser to the government, together with the officials of the Treasury and the Board of Trade, is engaged in drafting a set of new regulations, which Parliament, when it meets again in February, may be asked to pass as a matter of urgency.

The New York Junior League Players this week will begin casting for their second production of the season -- "The Silver Thread," by Constance D'Arcy Mackay, a dramatization of George MacDonald's story for children entitled "The Princess and the Goblins."

Onlookers in Wall Street found little of interest yesterday except an unusually active cotton market and a further display of firmness in the bond market. Trading in stocks was slow and colorless, although the turnover was about 290,000 shares greater than on the previous Saturday.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Jan. 13. -- The Lapham Trophy returned into the possession of the United States today when the visiting Canadian team was beaten by an overwhelming margin in the annual international squash racquets match at the Rockaway Hunting Club.

A geographic theatre has been organized by a group of outstanding geographers, explorers and scientists under a distinguished patronage. Members of the new theatre have formed the Geographic Players, Inc., and will present programs combining motion pictures, lantern slides, lectures and native music and dancing.

Swimmers of Henry P. O'Neil School, interborough junior high team champions of the Public Schools Athletic League, gave an amazing display of group strength in the individual title tests decided in the 75-foot pool of Seward Park High yesterday.

SOFIA, Dec. 30. -- A stork exhibited in the window of a pet shop escaped from its cage while the shopkeeper was absent and proceeded to feast upon its fellow-exhibits. A large crowd watched the unique entertainment through the window.

MUKDEN, Manchukuo, Jan. 13. -- A high Manchukuoan official, who "is desirous that THE NEW YORK TIMES readers have a full understanding of Henry Pu Yi's reasons" for planning to accept the throne of Manchukuo and resume his imperial rank, states:

With an average sales increase of 3.77 per cent on a combined sales volume of $477,484,931, the two leading mail-order companies made the best comparative showing in retail trade last year, according to analyses made here during the week. For twenty-three chain merchandising companies, excluding the two mail-order houses, the total sales last year were $2,147,447,088.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- C1d Z was produced in the volume of 2,435,091 ounces, valued at $50,337,{800, in the United States last year, {the Treasury announced today. I The production of si]ver was 22,141,130 ounces, valued at $7,638,690.

Mrs. Ida Harris, who operates the news stand on the northeast corner of Wall and William Streets, testified yesterday at the graft inquiry in the license department that her license last year was renewed only after she had told James F. Geraghty, who then headed the department, that she would hold meetings and tell the newspapers that her license had been "sold from under her" for $2,700.

Contracts held by steamship lines for the transportation of mails in the fiscal year 1933 cost the Post-office Department $23,054,223 more than payments for the service would have been had the cost been based on poundage carried, according to Postmaster General James A. Farley.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13. -- Johnny Skillman, instructor at the Apawamis Club, Rye, N.Y., and Jack Summers, coach at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, today reached the final round of the National professional squash racquets title tournament at the Penn A.C.

PORTRAITS and figure subjects in several mediums -- the varied assortment yielding dates that, if you please, involve no less than seven centuries -- have played a conspicuous part in this caballero's art exploits for the week just concluded.

FOR the first time in years and by a happy, combination of circumstances, Colonel Jacob Ruppert can gaze around his office in early January and say cheerfully: "No trouble brewing." Prohibition went out lately and Babe Ruth came in early. Prosit!

London reports of active American buying of gold in that market could not be confirmed in Wall Street yesterday, according to The Associated Press, but some banking quarters regarded the reports as plausible. They pointed out that such action might well have been necessary to prevent a sharp rise in the dollar.
DUBLIN, Jan. 13. -- A drive to increase the Free State's export and import trade with the United States has been initiated by the de Valera government.

FOR what trades should the public schools give training? Should they meet the eager interest of present-day youngsters in aviation, for instance, in radio or in motion-picture technique, or should they limit their teaching to those subjects in which jobs seem most probable?

THE plan of the German Government's subsidized air transport system, Lufthansa, to open its airplane transatlantic service to South America next month is vastly more important than it appears to be on the surface.

The Metropolitan Opera Company's much anticipated revival of Richard Strauss's "Salome," opera after the drama of Oscar Wilde, took place last night, before an audience that packed the theatre and that waited breathlessly for the effect of the music and the shocking revelations that rumor imputed to the work.
BOGOTA, Jan. 9. -- Colombia had a favorable balance of trade of $9,321,963 in the first nine months of 1933, according to a report of the controller general published in the local press.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley predicted today that President Roosevelt would not "spread his sails before the inflation gale, with all the perils that beset such a course."

BERLIN, Jan. 2. -- Surgery has its possibilities, but also its limits, and the limits have been more clearly comprehended tn the last few years than ever before, or at least so declared Dr. Ferdinand Sauerbruch, noted German surgeon, in a recent address.

LAKE PLACID. -- While novice bobsledders have been polishing their runners on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run this week, in preparation for the four-man races this morning, champion drivers are anticipating the National A.A.U. junior four-man championship races, sanctioned by the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, scheduled for Jan. 21.

Inaction was the rule on most of the markets yesterday, but cotton was a notable exception. This staple held speculative attention to such an extent that price movements elsewhere, even where there was any net change of consequence, such as that in wheat, were more or less obscured.

What little activity there was last week in the calling of bonds for redemption before their maturity dates was centred in foreign loans announced for payment in months starting with February. An almost negligible amount of municipal bonds and warrants was added to those which are to be paid this month.

GENEVA, Jan. 2. -- The petition signed by 250,000 Croatians in the United States setting forth the Croatian complaints against the Yugoslav Government has been judged "non-receivable" by the League Secretariat to which it was delivered by special messenger in October.

Kentucky sends out the news that 200,000 bushels of inferior blue grass seed are to be given to the flames by arrangement between the growers and the Farm Credit Administration in Washington. The purpose is to raise the price of the higher grades of seed.

LOOKING forward to the duties of Superintendent of Schools, one cannot help but feel most deeply the great responsibility that goes with the office, especially in view of the many changes that have taken place both in educational concepts and in the structure of society itself.
UNIVERSITY, Va., Jan. 13. -- Virginia's boxing team opened its season tonight by scoring a 6 to 2 victory over the Harvard ring men. A capacity crowd of 4,000 saw the Virginians gain their triumph.

That 42 per cent of all persons (estimated to be 12,500,000) receiving relief last October when the survey figures were gathered were children under 16 years of age gives us, as Mr. HOPKINS of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration says, "something to think about."

IN 1909 Charles Chadenat, a bookseller on the left bank of the Seine, made an interesting find of two four-page leaflets published anonymously in New Orleans in 1777. They contained what, for want of a better designation, passes for poetry, each of them being an extravagant eulogy of Don Bernard de Galvez, Spanish Governor of Louisiana.

A collection of Americana, comprising the library of Edmund A. Funke of this city, the Revolutionary library of Dr. William Sturgis Thomas, president of the New York State Society of Cincinnati, and other properties will be offered at auction on Wednesday afternoon and evening and Thursday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

Five thousand eggs, a parting gift of the blue-ribbon birds of the poultry show that ended yesterday, went to the public hospitals of the city with the compliments of the show committee. The show, which opened Jan. 9 and ended yesterday was the fiftieth annual exhibition and was held in the West Fourteenth Street Armory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- A larger volume of private and public construction during December than in any month since October, 1931, is shown in a survey by the F.W. Dodge Corporation, as announced today by the Public Works Administration.

HERE are some accounts of wanderings in the Far Northern wilderness by a man whose emotional reactions to the solitude of mountains and forests are fine and keen and deep, who observes closely and who can not only think interestingly about what he sees and about what all these things mean to him, but who has also a notable gift for expression and can write about them with charm and beguilement and realistic portrayal.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12. -- Business and industry are proceeding at a moderate pace in the Eighth Federal Reserve District, with confi dence expressed by leaders in most lines of activity in the Spring.

BOSTON, Jan. 10. -- Only five State Legislatures meet every year and two of these belong to New England. Both the General Assembly of Rhode Island and the Great and General Court of Massachusetts are now well under way. The fireworks to date have been furnished by the legislative body of the smallest of the States.
MAYOR LAGUARDIA, quoting the Athenian oath in a radio address on the day of his inaugural, invoked the ideals which enabled the capital of ancient Greece to meet a great crisis.

ON the maritime map of the world there are many canals that have been cut by the processes of nature, and others that we owe to the genius of man. The engineer has driven his Wedge through the isthmuses of Kiel and Corinth.

PARIS. Jan. 1. MOST of the new productions can hardly be compared in artistic interest with the two recent Guitry plays and those of Bernstein and Marcel Achard, but each of them presents an attraction of some kind which deserves a passing notice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The first permit period for the importation of alcoholic beverages was closed by the Federal Alcohol Control Administration today. Applicants for permits have been notified that no further original or supplemental permits will be issued to import specific amounts of alcoholic beverages until after Feb. 28.

GENEVA, Jan. 13 (AP). -- The League of Nations commission which seeks to effect peace in the Chaco warfare between Bolivia and Paraguay sent a message to the League Council today, asking advice about handling the dispute and suggesting a three-point plan for a settlement.

A CENTURY ago the London of Peel and Palmerston and Brougham was kept guessing. At frequent intervals the printshops in her ill-paved streets displayed large cartoons reproduced on rough drawing paper.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 11. -- Representative women from twelve out of thirteen Southern States attended the meeting here this week of the Association of Southern Women for the Prevention of Lynching and went on record as preferring coordinate action between Federal and State governments, but regarding "with favor any legal measure which promises sure and permanent eradication of lynching."

IN "Old Lady Esteroy" Edith Everett Taylor has written a psychological novel of an unusual order. Its theme is essentially a familiar one, but Miss Taylor has handled it so deftly, and has given it so impressive a setting, that it achieves an effect of remarkable originality and freshness.

PRIVATE business offices and reception rooms now offer rich opportunities for the art of the interior decorator and the mural painter. Their atmosphere may, if desired, subtly interpret the character of the business or the whims of its executive.

New York and Brooklyn department store advertising showed a gain for the fifth consecutive month in December, the total of 3,502,393 lines representing an increase of 14.5 per cent over the 3,058,223 lines for the same month of 1932, according to Media Records.

HERBERT MARSHALL, who is getting to be a familiar figure along the arms of the triangle represented by London, Broadway and Hollywood, is walking the screen of the Roxy this week. This time the picture is British; its title, "I Was a Spy." He was not born with a mission to become an actor; that came later.

A luncheon bridge in behalf of the Prosperity Shop has been planned by officers and directors for Feb. 13 at the Dorset. Mrs. George D. All is president and Mrs. Max Milikan heads the luncheon committee.

Additional contributions to the department and retail stores division of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee were announced yesterday by John S. Burke, the division chairman. He reported that the division has now reached a total of $107,261. Its goal was $100,000.

Jesse I. Straus, United States Ambassador to France, sailed yesterday on the Ile de France of the French Line for Paris accompanied by Mrs. Straus, after being absent from his post for four months. He underwent a minor operation while here and said that his health now was excellent.

MISS MARION BAUER is the complete modernist. In her book she tells more thoroughly and completely than has often been done before how the modern music developed and also -- a more difficult task -- how to listen to it; and a good deal about the creators or perpetrators of it.

Using its first five as a unit for only eight minutes, City College's undefeated varsity basketball team was extended at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium last night to register its ninth victory at the expense of a hard-fighting Manhattan College squad, 32 to 15.

The Cotton Exchange ended yesterday the most active week in several months, with prices advancing into new high ground. Although the market failed to respond early to a sharp rise in Liverpool, buying orders steadily increased as the session progressed. The list closed at the top at gains of 16 to 24 points.

" Big Flight" is an adventure story brimming with a keen zest for flying. Its authors have a practical knowledge of flying and a contagious enthusiasm in writing about it. The reader who has never been in a plane, even on the ground, is likely to find himself caught up by the breathless pace of the story, and to lay it down feeling considerably more air-minded.

AFTER four years of itinerant traffic with the ogres and dragons of Hollywood, S.N. Behrman has decided that the blood-curdling accounts of atrocities practiced by the cinema barons on virtuous playwrights and novelists are composed largely of a chemical known as hot air.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- The most important matter to come before the Council of the League of Nations when it meets at Geneva next week is that of fixing the date and arranging the machinery for the plebiscite which, before the end of 1935, must be held in the Saar Territory to determine its future government.

THROUGH the Surplus Relief Corporation there has been lately appropriated a fund of $25,000,000 for the selective retirement of marginal land, not piecemeal, patch by patch, but by whole farms, tracts and areas.

Hollywood in the raw is not mild, as Mr. James sees it. Any one eager for an inside view of the private lives of cinema stars, pretty girls keen on movie careers, scenario writers, men-about-Hollywood, and others rated high in scandal columns, will find just what he is looking for in "Ladies in Waiting."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Two spectacular field goals by Captain Earl Nikkel and another field goal by Jim De Angelis in an extra period of play gave the Yale University quintet a hard-fought 37-36 victory over the Montclair A.C., Eastern Athletic Club League champions, tonight.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Colgate defeated Army at hockey tonight, 2 to 1, in a fast and exciting game played in the West Point arena. The game was featured by the play of Bob Billings, the up-State goalie, whose work in the net was outstanding.

Academies of science are supposed to be bodies of professors, walking in a haze of absent-mindedness, musing about the square root of minus one, helpless when brought face to face with the realities of a hard business world. Yet in the World War it was to these dreamers that all governments turned.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Paterson, still the "Silk City of America" despite the challenge of districts in Pennsylvania and New England, today looks back upon a fourteen weeks' silk strike which has spurred the city to a new endeavor to retrieve its former prestige as a manufacturing centre.

" Tristan und Isolde" will be presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday evening, the second of the borough series by the Metropolitan Opera. The east will be headed by Gertrude Kappel, Karin Branzell, Lauritz Melchoir, Gustav Schutzendorf and Emanuel List in his Brooklyn debut.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- The usual January vacuum in British politics is being filled by statistics of calories and proteins which the government's medical experts and the British Medical Association are throwing at each other in the controversy over what the minimum diet for a poor man should be.

Evidence that the payrolls of manufacturing plants in New York City have been increased by $126,000,000 annually as a result of the industrial codes and the President's re-employment agreement was contained in a report submitted yesterday to Henry F. Wolff, local NRA administrator.

WHEN former President Hoover was Secretary of Commerce he instituted a commercial foreign service which proved a boon to American business. That system of commercial attaches is still bearing fruit and is likely to continue to do so for many years.

Trading in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday during the two-hour session was chiefly of an evening-up character. The net changes in the averages for the various groups were slight. Dealings amounted to $8,333,000, compared with $8,145,000 the previous Saturday.

ONE basic secret of success in politics is knowing the public mind. There are some very practical politicians who say all there is to good leadership is finding out where the people are going and taking them there. They are exaggerating, as is their custom, but there is more truth in what they say than those outside politics will ever be able to appreciate.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13. -- Clinging to his pace-setting role with the same consistent golf that won him medal honors, Johnny Rogers, Denver professional, led survivors today into the semi-finals of the San Francisco national match-play open tournament.

THIS novel is not so much a mystery story as a study of motives for murder. The motive that might one already say, compelling. One man, an artist named Whitestone, is married to a woman who is a millstone round his neck so far as development of his artistic talent is concerned.

JACK ROBINSON" is a boy's adventure into the sinister life of beggary, an adventure that is later seen to be the strange prelude to maturity. The story takes no more than six months of the boy's sixteenth year while he lives in doss houses or hedgerows with tramps, pickpockets, prostitutes and the like.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Retention of not more than four $2.50 gold pieces is permitted under an amendment issued by Secretary Morgenthau today to his order of Dec. 28, which stipulated that all gold coin, bullion and certificates be returned to the Treasury.

A one-design decked sailing canoe, measuring seventeen feet by forty inches and carrying a standard ketch rig, has been adopted by the general sailing committee of the American Canoe Association, it was announced yesterday.
NANKING, Sunday, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Prison officials announced today that the hunger strike of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Noulens, "the couple without a country," had ended. They declined to give particulars.

The Nassau Trapshooting Club of Mineola captured the Annual invitation shoot of the New York A.C. over the Travers Island traps of the Winged Foot organization yesterday. The Long Island team compiled a total of 433 out of 500 targets.

Outboards have almost endless uses. Those who see small craft moving about bays, lakes and rivers, propelled by motors slung over their sterns, may not realize the utility of them. There are the out-and-out racing ones, but there are others used for short transportation purposes and even fishing.

GENEVA, Jan. 13. -- The recovery prospects in the United States for 1934 are "incomparably brighter" than in 1933, according to Harold F. Butler, director of the League of Nations International Labor Office, in a report appearing in its monthly review.

MIAMIM, Fla., Jan. 13. -- Overpowered by his opponent's great stamina and variety of shots, Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant Jr. of Atlanta today went down to defeat before the defending champion, George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago, in the final of the Miami Biltmore singles tennis championship. The score was 9 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 11 -- 9.

The plan to have a Federal game administrator, which is to be proposed by the Federal Bird Restoration Committee, has aroused a great deal of interest among conservationists and sportsmen in the country. There appears no question that an administrator with wide enough powers could do a great deal in the work of saving and propagating game in the United States.

PASADENA dispatches report that the astrophysicists of Mount Wilson Observatory are still busy measuring the heat of the stars. Professor Alfred H. Joy of the observatory's staff is quoted to the effect that the measurement of star heat is one of the most pressing questions in astrophysics at the present time.

LAST Monday afternoon Mr. Laurence Binyon in the Pierpont Morgan Library talked of William Blake to an invited audience, most of whom were initiated in Blake's art and its literature. Superb examples of that art were hanging on the walls of the room and supported with their quality the illuminating statements embodied in the lecture.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 13. -- Al Bonniwell, slim Dartmouth junior, almost single handedly defeated the Princeton quintet in the Alumni gymnasium tonight by a score of 31 -- 30 in one of the most thrilling games to be played on the Dartmouth court in a decade.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- The program of activities at Southern Pines for the remaining days of January will include many sport events, of which golf will take the lead, with a number of women's tournaments to be played on the links at Southern Pines Country Club.
The trend of futures prices in local commodity markets yesterday was toward higher levels, although the volume of trading was small in most instances. Cash prices also were strong.

APPOINTMENT of three subcommittees to act immediately in the various phases of the development of a volume-production airplane for private flying has been the immediate outgrowth of the meeting in the Commerce Department last week of a special committee of leaders in American aeronautics who assembled to study plans for the development of such an airplane.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- The Tottenham Hotspurs defeated Everton, the cup holder, by 3 -- 0 today in the feature battle of the third round of the struggle for the English Association soccer cup. The Spurs are well up in the league race and the result was not unexpected.

SINCE tours of Radio City were instituted in November thousands of visitors from many parts of the world have paraded through the radio realm. On Dec. 1 a record was established when 1,884 persons viewed the broadcasting scene; Dec. 27 was another good day with 1,505 visitors anxious "to see the wheels go round."

Prominent members of the New York Women's League for Animals will have charge of the tea room at the annual show of the Pekingese Club of America, which will be held tomorrow in the main ballroom of the Roosevelt for the benefit of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Gamblers of Essex County, alleged to be linked with certain policemen, ran for cover today as Prosecutor William Wachenfeld opened an investigation, using all the forces at his command. The centre of the prosecutor's first attack was Irvington, where fifteen of his detectives started investigating an alleged slot machine ring that some residents of Irvington say is controlled by a Newark gang.

ADMIRAL BYRD in his recent voyage along the hidden front of the Antarctic Continent east of King Edward VII Land reported what was apparently the greatest number of icebergs ever seen in one day, but other Antarctic expeditions have also recorded vast groups of bergs at one time.

HALLOWED by heredity, perfected by environment and adorned by affluence, a great lady is a work of art, and among great ladies of that Victorian era, Mary, Marchioness of Salisbury, was admirable as a masterpiece.

Discussions which took place at annual meetings of banks last week made it evident that Congress will face in the next few months a wide-spread demand, led by thousands of holders of bank stocks, for modification of the Federal deposit insurance plan so as to maintain in force the present guarantee of small deposits and to abandon the permanent deposit insurance plan.

The open tournament in lawn tennis, which many judged to be just around the corner after the record-breaking turnout for the match between Willian Tilden and Ellsworth Vines at the Garden, is likely to round that corner at the meeting of the International Federation on March 16.

The Grand Street Settlement, which maintains an extensive educational and recreational program for the underprivileged in a crowded district of the city, will be the beneficiary of a midwinter festival and dance Tuesday night at the Commodore.

An important change in investment policies took place among the leading investment trust companies in 1933, it has been revealed in the first annual reports made public. In all cases, the trusts appear to have improved their positions substantially during the year.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 10. -- The three Alabamians who have been most conspicuous in the conduct of the Scottsboro trials at Decatur will be among the candidates for office in the State Democratic primaries next May. While each has a general record to offer or to be examined, the part each has played in this famous case is sure to bear importantly upon his fate at the polls.

ALL Norah Hoult's novels are novels without a hero; she sees her people humanely enough, but with complete detachment, and none of them is look at in a special light. This present study of a family group plays no favorities; each member, in himself and in his relation to others, is serutinized for what he is worth.

Lieut. Gen. Robert Lee Bullard, U.S.A., retired, will be 73 years old tomorrow. He retired from the army on his sixty-fourth birthday. The same year he was elected president of the National Security League, in which capacity he has served ever since.

Southerners in New York who long have taken an active interest in the Blue Ridge Industrial School have arranged the annual Blue Ridge Ball in behalf of that institution for the night of Jan. 26 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. A feature of the evening will be an entertainment in which theatrical, musical and radio stars will take part.

Both retail and wholesale trade here forged ahead last week. Continuing the surprising gains which have featured distribution since the close of last year, leading local stores again had substantial increases in the dollar volume of sales over the corresponding week of a year ago.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller obtained another respite for his tottering church regime today when a delegation of Lutheran Bishops with whom he had been in conference the greater part of the afternoon voted to grant him a truce until next Wednesday.

HAVANA, Jan. 13. -- A strike which would throw Cuba into darkness, cutting off all electric power and the water supply, loomed tonight when the company failed to accept the union's demands at 6 P.M., the time set in the workers' ultimatum.

COMPLICATIONS begin early in this ingenuous romance, a four-cornered love story enacted by a quartet of Hollywood folk, one of them, Rex Brandon, a famous screen player and idol of America's feminine movie public. He is interviewed for the press by Starr Thayle, temperamental redhead who, though she has never hitherto met him, unfairly regards Rex with contempt.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 13. -- S.W. Labrot's home-bred mare, Monel, was a driving winner of the featured Miami Shores Handicap run before one of the largest crowds of the meeting at Tropical Park today. It was estimated that 12,000 persons saw the 5-year-old daughter of Sir Greysteel and La Muiron last to triumph by a neck at the end of a mile and a sixteenth.

THE cabled trivia from London mostly concerns itself with the flood of American plays expected over there. Tomorrow, Marius Underwood's "Hemlock" opens at the Fortune Theatre, and next week Maxwell Anderson's "Saturday's Children" is due at the Westminster Theatre.

BERLI, Jan. 13. -- The Boerse closed the week in a waiting mood. Business was dull and quotations irregular, but most changes were merely fractional, the widest fluctuations not exceeding two points. On the whole, both stocks and bonds showed good reslstance, turning even stronger toward the close.

THE spirit of burlesque was the tutelary deity of this Brazilian jungle expedition, or so Mr. Fleming decided, when the unwearyingly flippant voyagers approached their three-thousandth mile or so. The end was then in sight.

As paradoxical as it may seem, when business conditions were good and the taxpayer was affluent in the things that make for wealth, he was invited to take advantage of the government's offer whereby he could legally reduce his income taxes, whereas, now that a depression has come upon him, it is sought to deprive him even of the benefits that are availing under present law.

Many of prominence in society, civic and official life have accepted invitations for the thirty-fifth annual dinner of the Society of the Genessee, which will be held on Feb. 5 at the Hotel Commodore. The society for years has chosen as its guest of honor a man of distinction in the business or professional world.

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- The Boston Red Sox today started sowing on their baseball farms. They released Urban Pickering, an infielder, and Curtis Fullerton, veteran right-handed pitcher, outright to the Kansas City club of the American Association and sent three promising youngsters to Roger Peckinpaugh's team.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 10. -- Many thoughtful Puerto Ricans appear to be shocked by events which occurred during the recent gasoline boycott, when for a time they found that the island had only mob government. Fortunately, the period lasted only two days, but occurrences during the forty-eight hours are accepted as indications of a condition which may occur again.

OMAHA, Jan. 11. -- When the Kansas bond scandal broke upon the nation last Summer it was the signal for no little ironical comment. Kansas was in the position of the preacher with a wayward son. It was an ugly mess which involved the forgery of public securities and dealings with public officials to such an extent that the fair name of the State itself was involved.

A plea for training in manual trades and farm work is being made in Germany by 69,000 Jewish young people between the ages of 14 and 29, according to a report by Joseph C. Hyman, secretary of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, made public yesterday.

ONCE more savage attacks are being made against the League of Nations, and not only by such "hereditary" enemies as Chancellor Hitler, Premier Mussolini and our irreconcilables. In unexpected quarters one finds such comments as this on Germany's withdrawal:

The title of this book does not signify that there are no murders in it; there are enough and to spare, but there is one man who seems to bear a charmed life. Three separate attempts are made to kill Robin Foster, but the end of the story finds him still alive and with every prospect of future happiness.

Building has been at almost a standstill for several years and millions of architects, engineers, skilled mechanics and unskilled laborers have been harder hit than in almost any other line of business.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that he had instructed District Superintendent Frederic Ernst to investigate tomorrow morning reports that pupils at New Utrecht High School, Brooklyn, had begun a boycott on the school lunchroom.

Members of the Vassar Club have taken over a special performance of "La Traviata" on the afternoon of Feb. 2 at the Metropolitan Opera House to augment the scholarship fund of that organization. The scholarship fund of the Vassar Club aids needy young women in New York City and its vicinity to continue their attendance at Vassar College.

The very unusual situation of a tie at the end of a sixty-four board contract bridge match developed early this morning in one of the semi-finals of the United States Bridge Association's first annual team-of-four championship at the Hotel Pierre.

WANDERING out on the back porch of the Palace, saloon and gambling hall, whose dark length was spotted with the glow of pipes and the "pulsing red points of cigarettes," Walt Devon suddenly saw flashed from one end a startling signal in dots and dashes. "Death" was the word spelled out in the Morse code.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- The Army basketball team defeated the University of Vermont by a score of 47 to 23 today in a hard-fought game. Army started the scoring immediately after the tap-off when Hillis caged a long goal and then proceeded to take a lead of nine points before the visitors counted.

COUPLED with the heavy arrivals of buyers here, reports on retail trade during the week were of a highly encouraging tenor. Here and elsewhere a continuance was noted of the up-trend in sales volume noticed since the close of the Christmas shopping period.
Columbia University's wrestling team gained its first victory in two matches by crushing Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute yesterday in the Blue and White gymnasium. The score was 24 -- 8.

City officials, Judges, Aldermen and members of Congress were among those who helped pile up a total of 318,579 unpaid rides on the city-owned ferry lines in the eight years through 1933, Frederick J.H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, revealed yesterday.

The new supply of crude oil in the United States during November amounted to 2,400,000 barrels daily, the largest for that month since 1931 and an increase of 9.8 per cent over the 2,186,000 barrels daily in November, 1932, according to a compilation by William J. Kamnitzer from data of the United States Bureau of Mines.

Charges of "gross waste" in the collection of the estate transfer tax in this State were made yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York, in a report that made recommendations for reducing the State budget.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- With its nine-day deadlock broken, the Assembly was a quiet place today as the members scattered to their homes to receive repercussions of the long factional strife among the Republicans over the election of a clerk.

BUFFALO, Jan. 11. -- Four years of difficulties in municipal affairs face the New Deal administration of Democrats which has taken over the reins of government in Buffalo. On New Year's Day George J. Zimmermann was inaugurated Mayor, the first Democrat to hold that office in seventeen years.

THIS pamphlet will interest students of anthropology and, even more particularly, those: readers who would like to learn something of the Hopi life and literature. Mrs. Lockett has lived among these people some twenty years and her purpose is to show that the present-day social organization of the Hopi is the outgrowth of their unwritten literature.

A SHORT time ago the Prince of Wales paid a visit to a huge brick-and-glass block of model flats which had been newly completed in the midst of a London slum. Passing an old tenement building which was about to be demolished to make room for more model flats, he turned aside unexpectedly to enter it.

Steamship lines submitted 630 agreements to the Shipping Board in 1933, designed to regulate competition in various trades under the supervision of the government. This culminates a steady increase in agreements filed during the last four years, says the annual report of the board.

After violent protests, and the revolt of eighty-four Democratic members of the House, the Administration forces were able to adopt, though only by a majority of five votes, a rule governing the passage of appropriation bills. Its immediate application was to the Independent Offices Bill then before the House, but one clause made it also applicable to "any section of any "general appropriation bill of the Sev-"enty-third Congress."
DODGE CITY, Kan., Jan. 11. -- Dodge City folk believe they have discovered why Henry L. Mencken enjoys writing pungent paragraphs at the expense of Kansas.

SHERRY and Jimmy Maxwell are an average married couple, young, attractive, very much in love with each other, and proper meat for a typical Faith Baldwin story. Sherry has money, and Jimmy hasn't. But he is a star insurance salesman and able to hold up his end of the budget.

Peremptory writs of mandamus were issued yesterday by Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the New Jersey Supreme Court against eleven of the twelve municipalities in Hudson County for payment, at least in part, of delinquent taxes. The order was obtained by J. Emil Walscheid, county counsel.
