Reports on January retail sales reflect an excellent improvement in consumer demand, as compared with a year ago, according to the market survey prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. While the sales at retail are not spectacular, they do show a steady day-by-day increase, the report points out.
SHANGHAI, Sunday, Jan. 14. -- Foochow, the capital of rebellious Fukien Province, was surrendered by the insurgents Saturday afternoon.

MR. LANGDON-DAVIES. who has made some excellent attempts in the past to popularize the new physics, gives us here a book addressed primarily to young readers, in which he essays the difficult task of reducing the discoveries and theories of the atom-splitters to words of two syl lables and to mental pictures.

Richard Li Brandi, Politan A.C. boxer, and the Metropolitan District's amateur flyweight titleholder, last night advanced through his second trial in his bid for the New York State 112-pound championship.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Southern California football fans who believe their local intercollegiate heroes are the acme of perfection will gather at Wrigley Field tomorrow to see the Chicago Bears In action against an all-star combination.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- It is the opinion of persons who have watched impartially the development of the milk situation in the Chicago area, that the underlying cause of the recent fiercely waged strike of producers which ended in a truce and the appointment of an arbitration committee was the growth of the independent milk dealers' movement.

BELGRADE. MEMBERS of the younger generation in Southern Serbie are in revolt against the old custom of buying and selling brides, but their efforts are making little headway against the peasant conservatism of their elders. Nor have efforts Of the authorities to abolish the practice met with greater success, for such transactions are carried on secretly and no one but the strojnik, or marriage broker, and the families interested need be the wiser.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- A suit to collect $8,140,514 taxes on 1,271,955 proof gallons of denatured alcohol, alleged to have been diverted for beverage purposes, was begun today by the government in the Federal court in Baltimore against the United States Industrial Alcohol Company and the United States Industrial Chemical Company.

THIS is the first completely documented and scholarly book on the part the Indian has played in American literature. And since the Indian made his first appearance in American literature at the very beginning of the first English settlement in the New World, and has continued to interest writers down to modern times, the history of his characterization is a sociological study as well as a literary one.

Scoring twenty points before the opposition tallied, Long Island University's undefeated basketball team triumphed over Wagner College, 49 to 21, for its fourteenth triumph of the campaign, last night at the Wagner gymnasium, Grymes Hill, S.I.
Every commanding officer in the Police Department, no matter how small a unit he supervises, was ordered yesterday to submit plans for retrenchment and economies.

In THE TIMES of Dec. 20 appeared an article, "Newspapers of '65 on Exhibition Here," in which is reprinted from the issue of THE TIMES of May 15, 1865, a paragraph regarding the capture of President Davis. No one acquainted with the history of Jefferson Davis could believe that so high-minded, courageous a man as he would stoop to attempt to escape in women's clothes.

A CONCERT commemorative of the composer Mendelssohn is in these days an exceptional event. On the program that he gives next Wednesday for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund, Walter Damrosch will present in spectacular fashion a number of Mendelssohn's most representative works.

Mary McCormic, opera and concert singer, sailed for London on the Ile de France at noon yesterday after successfully evading process servers with an order restraining her from breaking a contract i to begin a two weeks' engagement next Saturday at the Hollywood Country Club, Hollywood, Fla.

JACQUES VILLON'S last previous one-man show was held at Brummer's in 1930. It is a retrospective group that has been assembled at the Marie Harriman Gallery, there to remain until Jan. 27. This French artist has responded sympathetically to divers phases of the modern movement in Paris.

FOR twelve years the man in the street has been in two minds over a religious movement which upsets his usual calculations. It is grave yet gay. It is fervent. Yet it seems sometimes to be frivolous. It tells what it holds to be the truth. Yet it adds the trivial. It is applauded. It is denounced. He does not know what to make of it.

CONSIDER for a moment the case of a party pianist. An obliging and sometimes neglected fellow, he graciously provides music for his friends' social occasions, formal and otherwise. He is occasionally cursed as a menace, but is almost never praised.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11. -- No Missouri Legislature within the last two decades has been under such a fire of criticism as the present extraordinary session, now in its fourth month of futile argument and bickering, with prospects that such agreements as it may reach within the next few days on liquor control and revenue measures will be mere compromises.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 12. -- Adthough it was generally believed that the Palestine Government would not allow the proposed Arab demonstration in protest against Jewish immigration and the sales of land to Jews, the writer can now state on most reliable authority that the demonstrations planned for next Wednesday have been definitely sanctioned by the government.

On three several occasions Mr. P. W. Wilson has made the statement that Wellington never fought a battle he did not win, nor besiege a fortress he did not take. This is true with regard to the battles, but not with regard to the fortresses. After the Battle of Salamanca Wellington laid siege to the strong fortress of Burgos.

THAT popular hero of previous Orczy novels, Sir Percy, known to his enemies as The Scarlet Pimpernel, here continues his chivairous task of salvaging French loyalists from the clutches of the Terror and smuggling them to safety into his native England.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Chairman Black of the special Senate committee investigating air mail contracts, said today the inquiry was "just beginning."

IN primitive religion, the fear of the dead is a potent force, more potent even that that of dreams, little if at all inferior to that of the more noticeable and alarming manifestations of nature. Among primitive peoples there are few who do not believe in one form or another of survival, even though the idea of immortality is too abstract for their comprehension.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, En Route to Little America, Jan. 12. -- Seeking a favorable southern passage to Little America, the flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition this afternoon was steering a westerly course along the northern edge of the Antarctic ice pack.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Rallying in the last half, Cornell defeated Columbia, 30 to 28 in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight. It was Cornell's first league test, and the second defeat for the Lions in the current campaign.

DICKINSON COLLEGE, Carlisle, Pa., was chartered on Sept. 9, 1783, by the General Assembly of Pennsylvania, and named for John Dickinson, president of the Supreme Executive Council of the State. In the 150 years of its ex istence it has clung to the belief that education means culture, and has never yielded to the demands of opportunistic materialism.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 13. -- It now seems definitely established that the Mendoza River catastrophe was caused by the seven-hour damming of the Tupungato River by an enormous block of ice which broke off a glacier a few miles above its confluence with the Mendoza River.
PARIS, Jan. 13. -- The French are beginning to dread the dollar stabilization for which they have clamored.

THE French cinema has not had much good luck during 1933 with its most important productions. Since there has been no lack of talent, money and skillful publicity, one must suppose the trouble lies in the material used for scenarios.

That moral life lost its position of leadership in world affairs during the prosperous years of mechanical advancement was asserted yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise, Rabbi of Central Synagogue. He spoke at a luncheon of the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Young Folks Jewish Temple Leagues at the Community House of the Central Synagogue, 35 East Sixty-second Street.

A GOOD many of us are now likely to look back with a kind of smugness on the fat years before 1929 -- condemning and wondering at other people for ridiculous extravagance, even though there may be no flavor of sour grapes in this condemnation.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 13 (AP). -- Robert H. Wiles, South Carolina's first kidnapper-killer in recent years, was sentenced today to die in the electric chair on March 12. Sentence came just three weeks after he beat to death a 15-year-old schoolboy.

Establishment of minimum selling prices in industrial codes, together with provision for a systematic filing of quotations, was suggested yesterday as a more reliable method of preventing price-cutting than sales-below-cost clauses by Eric A. Camman, partner of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co., in a report prepared for the National Association of Cost Accountants.

BEFORE attempting to review the work in this exhibition done for the theatre during three centuries by painters and architects, it is well to remind ourselves that even in their own day they were not what Mayor Hylan described as art-artists, but artists, content to be necessary craftsmen, and rarely needed as an incentive the conviction that they were producing a work of art or contributing to the development of art history.

LONDON, Dec. 22. IT is an amusing chance of a dramatic critic's life that he should write in one week of Elisabeth Bergner, who is new to our stage, and, in the next, of Marie Tempest, who first appeared upon it in 1885, being then in her twenty-first year.

Claude M. Leigh, managing director of the Metropolitan Housing Corporation, Ltd., and fifteen other similar companies in London that house approximately 10,000 families, is in New York for a biennial visit. He is accompanied by T.P. Bennett, apartment house and theatre architect.

DUBLIN, Jan. 12. -- Already the business and farming communities of the Irish Free State are looking forward with anxiety to the de Valera government's next budget, to be introduced at the end of March. With the country's trade falling, the need of some relief from taxation is urgently felt by these classes, but on the showing of Exchequer trade returns for last year the prospects for any remissions are not roseate.
Fordham's basketball team wilted in the face of terrific pressure applied by New York University last night and was toppled from the ranks of the unbeaten.

NOT novelty hunters alone but every gardener who takes pride and pleasure in having an ever-improving garden will be delighted with the unusual number of new things in this Spring's cataloques. A remarkably large proportion of these introductions are valuable not merely because they are new but also because they represent genuine advancements.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- The Germans look ahead and prepare for what is coming. Having dropped their proposal that the Saar Basin Territory should be returned to the Reich by private arrangement with France -- the French having declined to consider it -- they now accept the plebiscite next year and are getting ready for it.

ROME, Jan. 13. -- One of the most important pieces of railroad work in Italy will be inaugurated on April 21 when the first passenger train runs over the new line between Florence and Bologna, which has just been completed after about twenty years of effort.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11. -- Hard-bitten sailors on oil tankers in Los Angeles Harbor rubbed their eyes when the Standard Oil tanker El Segundo put to sea with her decks filled with strange gear and her crew equipped as though she were bound on some trading expedition to the Sahara Desert.

CAMDEN, S.C. -- The Camden hunting set and the Winter colony are here in almost full force; in particular, more owners of race horses and amateur riders are here than usual at this time. Camden and Aiken have just arranged a joint program.
FOUR poets have presented four new poems in the dolightfully printed Borzoi Chap Books. The books have been illustrated by George Plank, W.A. Dwiggins and Marguerite Jones Drewry.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 13. -- Black Minnie finished strongly to win the five and one-half furlong fourth race at the Agua Callente track today. With Jockey Williams up, Black Minnie was rated along in fourth place at the quarter and gradually moved up to gain a position a half-length behind Pretty Nellie entering the stretch.

The sensational bank scandal in France, which threatened to upset the Ministry not at all responsible for it, should attract thoughtful readers to the recent book of LUCIEN ROMIER, "If Capitalism Should Disappear." His general theme is that capitalism must adopt new and better moral principles, on pain of death.

Singing the "Marseillaise" in French to all the children of France who may have been listening in across the Atlantic, a duty thrilled audience at the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's concert for children in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning had the further excitement of joining their shrill treble voices with that of the Metropolitan's French prima don Lily Pons.

THIS book, which has an unusual history, narrates an eerie story of one of those dark mysteries of the human brain for which none has yet been able to find a fully adequate solution. It tells how an architect was able, by means of automatic writing, to render valuable assistance in the locating of lost chapels in the magnificent ruins of the famous Glastonbury Abbey.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Unaware that her twin sister has died, Mrs. Henriette Dannenbaum will observe her 100th birthday on Tuesday in her suite at the Hotel President here.

NEW YORK has been examining its weather records in the light of recent experience with unusually low temperatures. Until Dec. 29, when the mercury registered 3 below, the city had not had zero weather since Jan. 27, 1927. On only forty-nine days in the past sixty-three years has the thermometer in New York City registered zero, or below, the coldest day in that period being Dec. 30, 1917, with 13 below.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 13. -- Yale's swimmers defeated New York University, 39 to 32, in the Payne Whitney pool tonight. Dick Hower, Violet star, secured two firsts, winning the fifty and 100-yard free-style events.

Bep Van Klaveren, welterweight from Holland, knocked out Benny Levine of Newark in 2:06 of the third round of the scheduled ten-round feature bout last night at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn before 2,500 persons. The winner weighed 145 1/2 pounds and Levine three pounds more.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Opening their indoor polo season today, the Army riders defeated Squadron A of New York by a score of 17 to 6. Army took a commanding lead of 8 -- 1 in the first two periods and never was in danger.

Chris-Craft engineers have been busy during the past year and the results of their efforts will be on display during the show. With a fleet comprising twenty-four models, embodying the latest refinements in design and introducing new sizes, the Chris-Craft exhibit is expected to attract wide attention from motor boat enthusiasts.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- "Fear," the most successful present-day drama in Russia, had its American premiere here tonight in the Experimental Theatre of Vassar College. Banned at first by the Soviet authorities as counter-revolutionary, it was later accepted as part of the U.S.S.R.'s self-criticism program, and for the last two years has been playing to packed houses in a number of theatres throughout Russia.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- The Princeton hockey team outplayed Harvard in Baker Rink tonight to win the opening game of the quadrangular hockey league, 3 -- 0. With the rival goalies and captains, Henry Thouron and Paul De Give, playing star roles, the game was fast and rough all the way.

" New Yorkitis," an ailment peculiar to inhabitants of this city, is especially common among college students, according to Dr. William J. Fordrung, head of the physiology and hygiene department of Hunter College. It is caused by a continuous combination of mental and physical shocks, augmented by improper eating, irregular and insufficient sleep and insufficient drinking water.

ONE hesitates to say flatly that "The Mother" is Mrs. Buck's best book up to this time, though there is much to be said in support of such a contention. Grounds for hesitation there unquestionably are, because, for one thing, "The Mother" is built upon a more restricted canvas than "The Good Earth" and the trilogy to which that novel belongs.
IT is your chance to score while being an onlooker at sports events in the South this year. You may as well make a hit yourself and be done with it. Be sure to pick your colors to win.

WHEN the House adopted week a beverage control plan for the District of Columbia it was acting in its capacity as part of the Legislature of the District. The measure then went to the Senate, which is the District's Upper House.

The following new contributions to the Citizens Family Welfare Committee were announced Thursday by James G. Blaine, chairman. Although the committee has concluded the intensive period of its campaign, contributions may still be sent to Thomas Cochran, treasurer, 120 Broadway.

Three clergymen, representing the Jewish, Catholic and Protestant faiths, who have been touring the country on behalf of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, will be welcomed Jan. 22 at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Invitations to the meeting have been extended by Newton D. Baker, Professor Carlton W. Hayes and Roger W. Straus, co-chairman of the conference, and more than eighty sponsors.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Ready to "go home and face the music," they said, Robert Ellsworth Lowe and his bride of a few months, Mrs. Alfreda Ecklemann. Renner Lowe, waived removal hearing before a United States Commissioner here today and their return to Teaneck, N.J., was ordered.

Mrs. Lorillard Spencer has enlisted the aid of several younger members of society in the sale of women's wearing apparel now being held at the Chat-Souris Shop in Madison Avenue for the benefit of Manhattan Council of Camp Fire Girls.

ONE thing is undeniable: Miss Steen has definite beliefs, and is not afraid to voice them. In her eyes Hugh Walpole is the outstanding figure in present-day English literature; she hails him as one of the Immortals, the Great Romantic whose story of Rogue Herries "blazed the trail for the renaissance of the romantic interest."

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- Malcolm Farmer, director of athletics at Yale University, says the demand "for more and more victories" is forcing the coaches of some institutions to resort to proselyting of athletes to obtain strong football teams.

NO factor contributing to the economical upkeep of an automobile is more important than a good lubricant in the crankcase, yet it is the rare and unusual driver who gives the matter particular consideration. The car-owner casually reasons that, as all oil comes from the ground, it is all the same.

AMONG the attempts that have been made thus far, whether in English or in any other language, to describe that unique phenomenon of international significance, the Russian Dispersion throughout the world, W. Chapin Huntington's book unquestionably stands out as the most interesting, most comprehensive and most important.

Nearly 1,500 Columbia alumni and students assembled last night in the Morningside Heights gymnasium to tender a testimonial dinner to the Blue and White football team, victorious over Stanford in the Rose Bowl encounter on New Year's Day.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 13. -- In defiance of the National Labor Board, the United Anthracite Miners of Pennsylvania, formed in opposition to the United Mine Workers of America, voted a general strike this afternoon in District 1, comprising the Wilkes-Barre-Scranton area, or northern field.

A primary fight for control of the Republican State organization and delegates to the next State Convention was forecast yesterday by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, in a statement commenting upon the appointment of Fred W. Hammond as clerk of the Assembly by what he called the "back door" route.

The Bowery has lost its bread lines. In the early stages of the depression, the lines began to appear and multiplied rapidly. Nightly, regiments of hungry, homeless men waited impatiently for food and steaming coffee.

BY CANDLELIGHT," the pictorial offering which was at the Roxy last week, is a genuinely pleasing though light entertainment which is thankfully free from bromidic ideas, and its well-turned comedy gave the audience many a good chuckle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Stroking and smashing in the style that carried him to the amateur heights in 1932, Ellsworth Vines tonight won his first professional victory by downing an erratic William T. Tilden in four sets.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- President Roosevelt has summoned the Banking and Currency Committees of the Senate and House for a White House conference at 8:45 P.M. tomorrow.
This is the third book of poems by Mary Owens Lewis, her earlier works being "The Phantom Bow" and "Tower Window." Hence she does not come to the reader as one unknown.

LONDON. ERNEST NEWMAN'S metier is that of a music critic, but when he has occasion to deal with publications within his own field he displays an insight and a sanity of judgment that would be creditable to any professional literary critic. In reviewing in The Sunday Times recent lives of Bach. Beethoven and Chopin he makes some shrewd comments which apply to biography in general.
Comparisons of Great Britain's foreign trade in December are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- On the eve of adjudication of the wartime sabotage claims of the United States against Germany, growing out of the Black Tom and Kingsland explosions and fires, financial support of the American section of the German-American Mixed Claims Commission, which has been handling the negotiations, has been discontinued.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 13. -- Skeet shooting made up the program at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Two silver trophies were offered by P.G. Gossler Jr., for the best handicap scores. Thirteen gunners tied, each with a full card of fifty targets.

A glazed terra-cotta altarpiece, portraying "The Agony in the Garden," from the atelier of Giovanni Della Robbia, was bought for $7,600 yesterday afternoon by the trustees of the Walters Art Gallery in Baltimore, at an auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

A new attendance record, with approximately 5,000 retailers present from all over the country, is expected to be set at the twenty-third annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which begins here tomorrow night.

THE purpose of Mr. Reynolds in writing this book has been to provide, in effect, a biography of Jesus that would be a record as nearly complete as possible of His life and teachings compiled of what can be learned of Him from the first four books of the New Testament, Matthew, Mark, Luke and John.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Publishers of the State were told today by Mark Graves, head of the State Tax Commission, that the State budget this year would be greatly reduced.

THE Waiter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation will begin in March its tenth annual series of auditions for pianists, violinists, 'cellists and singers who are "of mature talent and ready for professional careers" but who have not already had a New York recital reviewed by critics.

PARIS. THE American public and critics have received very warmly the first volumes of Jules Romains's great novel, "Les Hommes de bonne volonte" ("Men of Good Will"). Flammarion, publisher. It will be recalled that he intends to write a work in fifteen or twenty volumes in which he will deal, through about ten years, with groups of characters belonging to all classes of society.

RECENT events have focused interesanew on Soviet Russia. The government of that country has adopted a second Five-Year Plan of Industrial progress; it has received the recognition of the United States. Dismission has been widespread. But through it all we have had scarcely a glimpse of the land and the people who are most concerned.

LONDON has a large number of "official" cats attached to the various authorities. Most of them are to be found in the neighborhood of the docks, where they live unmolested so long as they keep the warehouses and dockyards clear of rats and mice.

THE introduction in 1934 models of independent front wheel springing will raise in many minds the question of whether the new construction entails changes in wheel servicing, such as adjust ments for toe-in, camber, caster and so forth.

THIS depression is like the World War People who have not been on the firing line really know very little about it. Far too many of us are in the habit of saying that "there must be something wrong with the person who can't get a job."

The New York Athletic Club team rallied in the final period to defeat Squadron A in a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League game at Squadron A Armory last night, 10 1/2 to 6. In another league match the First Division trio defeated the New York Riding Club, 12 to 7 1/2.

WHEN you meet the Baron, you are at once impressed with his serious mien, his fine diction and his keen intellect. Jack Pearl might be anything but a comedian. His views on life are philosophic; his outlook on life serious and thoughtful; his opinions decisive.

BAY OF WHALES, Antarctica, Jan. 13 (By Wireless). -- We have had a narrow escape from complete disaster. The shelf ice broke up suddenly and cast our ship, the Wyatt Earp, adrift, and the skis of our plane, the Polar Star, slipped through a crack in the ice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- A House Banking Committee report said today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation planned to lend $590,000,000 to release frozen deposits in banks shortly after its life is extended by Congress.

In the Feature Section of THE TIMES today the Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, Mr. TUGWELL, discusses some of the larger problems of "land adjustment" which are the concern of his department. In the foreground is the necessity of reducing surpluses of farm commodities which have accumulated in consequence of the loss of foreign markets.
PARIS, Jan. 12. -- Like a storm the Stavisky affair has passed over France, testing the strength and weakness of men and institutions and stirring up almost unknown forces.

District Attorney Dodge revealed yesterday that he intended to communicate with the justices of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Manhattan and Brooklyn this week and request that in every instance of bail applications in felony cases, the jurists in those courts first communicate with the General Sessions judge who fixed the amount and his own office.

One hundred and twenty-two Pekingese dogs will greet visitors to the Hotel Roosevelt tomorrow. They will make up an entry of more than a hundred and fifty for the twenty-third specialty show of the Pekingese Club of America.

Another selection of United States silver and copper coins from the collection of Brig. Gen. Walter D. McCaw, retired, will be sold with other collections by Thomas L. Elder on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.

THERE is a great deal of sensible, unbiased discussion in this novel of the efficacy of psychoanalysis as a cure for the ills suffered by men and women in mismated, unhappy marriages. But it is unfortunate that the various patients offered in evidence are of a class so trivial and self-absorbed.

Members of the Neighborhood Playhouse Associates have taken over a preview performance of "Richard of Bordeaux" at a theatre yet to be announced the night of Feb. 13 to augment the scholarship fund of the Neighborhood Playhouse Studios.

FROM all along the line, as the new year starts, comes evidence of ever-increasing interest in gardening. New organizations, plans for new lecture courses and additional flower shows, increased demands for seed catalogues -- all point to the fact that the depression has had no curtailing effect upon our love of things that grow.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 13. -- Yale's wrestling team opened its season today by scoring a 15-to-9 victory over the New Britain Y.M.C.A. While each squad won three bouts, Yale's were through three falls and the visitors on three time-advantage decisions.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- The pledge of Premier Camille Chautemps to clean up financial scandals had its first effect today when the banker Albert Oustric was jailed for one day. M. Oustric has been mentioned frequently during the bitter debate of the past week regarding the collapse of the Bayonne municipal pawnshop.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop's confession that she killed her daughter-in-law, Rheta Wynekoop, will not be referred to Monday in the State's opening outline of its case to the murder-trial jury, according to Charles Dougherty, Assistant State's Attorney.

MEMBERS' annual exhibitions are current at two venerable New York strongholds -- the National Arts Club and the Pen and Brush. The former includes more than a hundred canvases by some of the most widely known American painters and a score of small sculptures.

FROM the moment of its adoption and proclamation in 1920 until Adolf Hitler took power, the program of the National Socialist German Workers party was drummed into the German masses with a demagogic energy unprecedented in the nation's history.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 13. -- Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas explains that Argentina's present activity in the Chaco peace negotiations is largely the result of cablegrams from several other governments, urging President Augustin P. Justo to attempt to find a solution for the conflict.

IF Henry Jones of Windfall, Ga., had not pilfered from his mother her famous recipe for cornpone-and-potlikker, the young man would never have gone to Paris to write a cook book; consequently he would not have been incarcerated in the Sante Prison, there to languish under the stigma of espionage charges while headlines of Paris dailies screamed the latest news of L'Affaire Jones.

MR. SEYMOUR wrote this book for the best reasons the world -- because he wanted to, because it gave him very great pleasure, and because he had something to say, a great deal to say, indeed, that he thought of enough consequence to be preserved in print.

Two orders requiring George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, to show cause next Friday why he should not render an accounting of two certificate issues totaling $51,000,000 of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, of which he is rehabilitator, were issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

MADRID, Jan. 13. -- Ever since the recent general elections swept them from power in the Spanish Cortes a few disgruntled Socialists have been proclaiming from the rostrum and in their press that only a united front of all the Left forces would save the republic from sinister plans for its overthrow and a monarchical restoration.

THE experience of many years as Conservator of Forest in India has given to Sir Sainthill Eardley-Wilmot the intimate knowledge and familiarity with jungle life that appear in these classic stories, now republished as the latest addition to the Kingfisher Library.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Senator Borah gave his support today to the Johnson bill to prohibit financial transactions with debt-defaulting nations. The measure comes up for reconsideration in the Senate next week.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 12. -- Four years of depression and search for its causes have impressed upon the public mind in this State that the machine is a Frankenstein of social destruction if it is abused. An intellectual background of statistics confirms the public in this opinion, but to some extent men and women have learned their lesson in emotional ways which are real and dramatic.

George Spitz, New York University's brilliant high jumper, proved to the complete satisfaction of 3,000 spectators last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory that he is ready for any competition the current indoor season may offer.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN'S immediate concern, after he had installed himself at the Waldorf, was the commercial problems connected with issuing his treasured Anna Sten film "Nana" to the nation's booking offices. But he abandoned the project and deserted his sales manager long enough to discuss this and that, not excluding his impending European trip, his plans for next year and his faith in the box-office lure of the blonde and handsome Miss Sten.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Drastic revision of the Cotton Futures Act to bring transactions on the New York Cotton Exchange and other contract markets for cotton under direct government supervision and limit the amount of futures permitted to be held by any individual, directly or indirectly, is contemplated by Chairman Smith of the Senate Agricultural Committee.

M. LUCIEN FARNOUX-REYNAUD tells the readers of Figaro that the Americans are "shaking a leg" over the fall of prohibition. How did it happen that the instinct to forbid and persecute was long so strong in a country to which so many persons fled in its earlier days to escape persecution?

A change in the character of railroad directorates is seen by some railroad officials as a possible result of the Securities Act of 1933. Meanwhile, railroad managements are analyzing the situation in respect to financing in which they are placed by the law.

Magistrate Anna Moscowitz Kross, completing her first week on the bench at the Women s Court at Jefferson Market, said in an address yesterday that she was more than ever convinced that the only hope of getting at the roots of the problem of prostitution was to take it out of the courts, out of the category of crime, and "devise some system of handling it socially, on a high plane."
With an eye toward the comfort and convenience of those aboard, Elco designers have been working on refinements in design in sea-worthiness and safety.

Because "onlookers see most of the game," if it be a game which they are accustomed critically to observe, the writer, a Virginian who for more than forty years has lived abroad, developing gas processes and plants for the use of foreign utilities, is moved to express his views regarding an appalling situation which now faces privately financed utilities in the United States.

Many official gatherings of the various organizations interested in motor boating have been scheduled for the National Motor Boat Show. There will be the roups of manufacturers, dealers, associated clubs and racing officials, with one or more meetings every day.

MONTREAL. -- Competition for the Royal Victoria Jubilee trophy will begin at the curling clubs on Friday and will extend through next week until the final on Saturday, Jan. 27. This is one of the most popular of annual competitions here, participants comprising clubs throughout the Province of Quebec and the Ottawa Valley.

PADUCAH, Ky., Jan. 11. -- Eggnog, wine-flavored fruit cake and boiled custard "spiked" with liquor, enjoyed during the holidays, have served to create turmoil and back-fence quarrels in Hickman, a town of 2,000 near here.

ONE wonders after reading this book just what Herr Hausleiter's standing is in Germany. A publisher's note or foreword says "The Machine Unchained" defies description. Its author presents the same problem.

THE National Automobile Show of 1934, which brought to Grand Central Palace more than 200 models of the new automobiles, became history last night. This thirty-fourth annual exhibition of the industry's products was declared to have been one of the most successful from the standpoint both of attendance and actual and prospective sales.

CARL and Valerie were boy and girl sweethearts. They became so closely attuned to one another from their early childhood that they found themselves sending mental messages to each other over telepathic waves. They read each other's thoughts.

CARL and Valerie were boy and girl sweethearts. They became so closely attuned to one another from their early childhood that they found themselves sending mental messages to each other over telepathic waves. They read each other's thoughts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Five securities issues, covering $5,500,000 of new capital in mining, liquor and pharmaceutical projects, are proposed in registration statements filed under the Securities Act and made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

At the hearings to begin tomorrow in Washington before the House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures, the question of how much additional silver should be injected into the monetary base of the country to help in the recovery program is expected to be among the principal subjects of discussion.

In a suit to foreclose a second mortgage for $2,050,000 on the twenty-one-story office building at 42 Broadway, Supreme Court Justice Leary appointed Casimir C. Patrick receiver yesterday. The suit was brought by Harry Hoffman, assignee of a mortgage given to Supreme Court Justice Irwin Untermyer and Alvin Untermyer by the Fifth National Realty Company in 1929.

New York Stock Exchange firms, on March 1, will be faced with the problem of renewing expiring contracts of more than 7,000 customers' men, a group constituting approximately one-fifth of their employes. These men are the business-producing forces of brokerage firms.

VIENNA, Dec. 22, 1933. AT the general meeting of the Salzburg Festival, the financial manager, Director Sadleder, showed that the 1933 festivals ended with a deficit of 22,345 schillings. This will have to be covered from the reserve funds, or carried forward as a debt against 1934.

I just read with the greatest Interest Mr. Downes's article about "Salome" and thought you might like to have for your readers a short description of the premiere of this opera in Paris at the Chatelet.

Hailed by leaders of the industry as one of the most successful ever held, the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace close last night. Attendance broke last year's mark by 71 per cent and come close to equaling the all-time record of 1928, the committee in charge announced.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 13. -- Osvaldo Aranha will return Monday to the post of Finance Minister, which he vacated two weeks ago. Dr. Afranio de Mello Franco is considering the pleas of President Getulio Vargas and others that he resume the portfolio of Foreign Minister, which he resigned at the same time.

VIENNA, Jan. 13. -- The Austrian capital, which was greatly surprised yesterday by the disclosure of secret negotiations between the Heimwehr and the Nazis and the forced resignation of Count Johann Alberti, commander of the Lower Austrian Heimwehr, had another sensation today.

THE most startling bit of news for this gentle January morning is that New York won't see the new Kern-Hammerstein show right away. London seems to have taken "The Three Sisters" out of Metropolitan hands, and the musical will go on at Drury Lane some time about the middle of April.

IT is simple enough to come to New York with the full backing and authority of the Theatre Guild behind one, as I did three years ago, when I had the pleasure of lecturing for that redoubtable institution in its subscription cities across the country.
LONDON, Jan. 13. -- An armada of the most powerful ships of the British Navy is now assembled at Arosa Bay, Spain, ready to sail next week on a cruise to the West Indies.

Capacity business at leading hotels here last week was due in large measure to the exceptionally large number of merchandise buyers visiting the market to fill requirements for their stores, according to managers of several leading hotels in the midtown section.

NOW that the ban has been removed from "Ulysses," it may be expected that James Joyce's best-known book will have many new readers in this country. It may be expected, too, that some of those readers will find difficulty in understanding what the book is about.

NEGAUNEE, Mich., Jan. 11. -- On the corporate seal of the city of Negaunee is a representation of a pine tree lying on the ground with roots exposed. The wind which blew down that tree started something which has gone around the world. For the tree once grew in what is now the heart of Negaunee, and many tiny points glittered on its roots.

IT is prudent to read carefully books by professors on economic problems, since there is a good chance that almost any professor will turn up in Washington at almost any moment and start to run something. The thought need not be a disquieting one, especially if the professor in question is as full of logic as is Professor Adams.

Following the refusal of Commissioner John Stratton O'Leary of the Triborough Bridge Authority to resign last Thursday under charges of incompetence and neglect of duty, Mayor LaGuardia yesterday informed him that a hearing on the charges would be held at City Hall at 1 o'clock on Jan. 25.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- The whirling microscope invented by Professor A. Newton Harvey of the department of biology of Princeton University, and by Alfred Loomis of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., has recently made possible the discovery of a new type of genesis in nature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The popular belief that brain-workers require food rich in phosphorous, like fish, is exploded in a report on energy consumption by Dr. and Mrs. Francis B. Benedict, made public today by the Carnegie Institution.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- "The Pelham Purities of 1934" will be presented on Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings at the Manor Club, under the auspices of the junior section.

IT was no will-o'-the-wisp fancy but rather very definite theories on how drama could be presented effectively on the air that lured Maude Adams from retirement to re-create for the radio audience the whimsical heroines of Barrie's plays that made her name a by-word a generation ago.

The Bronx County Medical Society charged yesterday that the city was defrauded of $600,000 in the Bronx alone last year by patients at city hospitals in that borough who received free treatment without being entitled to it.

THE 125th anniversary of the birth of Edgar Allan Poe will be commemorated next Friday at a dinner dedicating to his memory the recently restored "rose-covered cottage" in Philadelphia, where the poet, his child-wife, Virginia; her mother, Mrs. Maria Clemm, and their cat, Catterina, lived from 1842 to 1844.

ROME, Jan. 13. -- The Senate by an overwhelming majority approved today the new corporative measure proposed by Premier Mussolini, which is to usher in the "corporative State" toward which the Fascist regime has been moving in the last few years.
The value of the do[laD on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

VIENNA, Jan. 12. -- The announcement in yesterday's proclamation by the government that between Jan. 1 and 8 there were 140 Nazi bomb outrages, besides hundreds of less serious political offenses, in Austria, startled the average Austrian as well as the outside world.

IF Mr. O'Neill were not by common consent our foremost dramatist the moribund artistry of "Days Without End" would not greatly matter. Dramas no better than this "modern miracle play" come and go in the theatre without creating much disturbance.

With a declaration by Chief Inspector Valentine that "gambling is being suppressed," the police made a widespread series of raids yesterday that resulted in wholesale arrests of alleged gamblers, including residents of Chinatown and members of the city's Spanish colony.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- The German Government's methods in supplying authorized reading matter for the public, following the banning of the French newspaper Petit Parisien because of the publication of secret documents purporting to reveal Germany's propaganda system, were disclosed here today when the newspaper Koelnische Illustrierte Zeitung reached France.

A collection of prehistoric objects, excavated by the late Duchess Paul Friedrich of Mecklenburg, believed to be the largest such archaeological collection in private hands, will be sold at auction next Friday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

THE entrance of dancers from the recital field into the less sedate arena of the Broadway musical show continues to have its effect upon that branch of theatrical activity which Europe generally considers to be America's greatest contribution to the arts of the stage.

The United States has no surplus population viewed from a territorial and natural-resource basis, like Japan and other countries, but we have a surplus population of unemployed people. The government has done and is doing much to relieve the situation, temporarily. It occurs to me that this period of temporary relief should be utilized by the government to wean the people from reliance on government support and inaugurate an epoch of self-support.

Colonel Leonard J. Harmon, Past New York County Commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, attacked President Roosevelt last week in connection with the President's economy program as it affects veterans. On March 11, 1933, Colonel Harmon had called upon all members of his organization to support the President in his economy drive.

AMONG the features of the fourth week of the Metropolitan Opera season are the debuts of the American mezzo-soprano, Cyrena Van Gordon, and Carlo Del Corso, Italian tenor; first performances this season of "Die Meistersinger" and "Madama Butterfly," the second of "Salome" and the revival of "Gianni Schicchi."

Although he believes that some governmental regulations have been unwise and injurious, Victor Morawetz, a local corporation attorney, said in a statement issued yesterday that a large measure of regulation of the railway was absolutely necessary.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 13. -- Headed by Peter Myer and Studdiford Pitt, former Olympic stars, the New Haven Fencers Club scored a 9-to-8 victory over Yale today.

LIMA, Jan. 12. -- The present Peruvian Cabinet crisis may prove a turning point in the history of the Aprista party, headed by Victor Haya de la Torre. With a Cabinet reorganization decided and resignation expected hourly, observers today were speculating on the influence exercised in the situation by the youthful Apra leader.

Presentation to the Museum of the City of New York of a portrait of Isaac Moses, Revolutionary patriot and financier, will take place next Tuesday at 3 P.M. at a ceremony in the museum's auditorium. The portrait, the work of John Wesley Jarvis, 1780-1839, was purchased through the efforts of Mrs. Solomon de Sola and Mrs. Annie Nathan Meyer, by a group of individuals and the Manhattan Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution.

Howard Boyle, 19 years old, of 657 MacDonough Street, Brooklyn, stood with bowed bead in Gates Avenue Court yesterday. Magistrate Jeanette Brill told him she felt sorry for his predicament but that she had no alternative but to send him to jail on a burglary charge until he could raise $500 bail.

AN unconventional, rather formless and quite unclassifiable sort of book is this by Edwin C. Washburn, whose previous books, mostly fiction mingled with much fact and truth, have been warmly praised. But it gains rather than loses by its lack of conventional form and its refusal to run in any of the usual literary ruts.

A decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, announced yesterday, upholds an order for a trial in a suit by civil service engineers, draftsmen and laborers to compel their reinstatement in city employ on the ground that their places have been taken by favored relief workers.

WINSTED, Conn., Jan. 14. -- Despite a steady snowfall that hindered their vision and militated against still better performances, twelve courageous fliers competed today in the first professional ski-jumping tournament ever held in the East.
With a fast-moving attack which functioned at its best in the final period, the Hershey six scored a 4-to-0 triumph over the New York A.C. team in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

LINCOLN, Mass., Jan. 14. -- A colt's toss of its head cost the life of Miss Elizabeth P. Bigelow, aged 26, of Boston and Concord, daughter of Professor Henry B. Bigelow, on the estate of Charles Francis Adams today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Coincident with the departure of Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinov from Moscow on Oct. 26 on the trip to Washington that resulted in United States recognition of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, The Chicago Tribune's Baltic bureau received a copy of the Journal of the Red International Trade Unions.

BUTLER, N.J., Jan. 14. -- Ernest Fenner, 20 yeas old, and his fiancee, Kathleen Weaver, 18, who were to have been married on Feb. 3, were killed today when they were run down by a hit-and-run motorist on State Highway 23 on the out-skirts of Butler.
The President is much concerned over water power in the St. Lawrence. This would be a very serious expense, which should not be saddled upon the taxpayer without careful study as to its usefulness.

Arturo Toscanini led the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in his first Sunday afternoon concert of the season, presenting a program that must certainly have been devised with an eye on the box office. It included Rossini's overture to "La Scala di Seta," Brahm's Fourth-Symphony, Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" and Ravel's "Bolero."

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Going into faction after having played a hard tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs last night, the New York Americans were unable to stop the Chicago Black Hawks tonight and took a 4-to-0 setback.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Purchases of hogs for the government seem to be likely to continue indefinitely. Supplies exceed the demand, and the government and the packers have no trouble in obtaining all that they require. The government has changed its regulations so that farmers are allowed certain amounts of hog meat as a processing return for their own use or disposal.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- In nearly all directions the financial markets are experiencing good going. Tax collections are beginning to press heavily, but the reactionary tendency usually noticeable in the stock markets at this time of year is conspicuous by its absence.

The middle of January is somewhat early for discovery of the real trend in a new year's finance and industry. In past years, excepting when some unexpected influence, outside of the business field, came suddenly into view, January has been apt merely to continue December's general trend.

Featured by marked strength in coffee futures, commodities on local exchanges moved irregularly higher last week. In most instances trading was dull, although there was some improvement late in the week. Cash prices were irregular.

TOKYO, Jan. 14. -- Manchukuoan legal authorities, the newspaper Asahi reports, have decided to liberate the six Russian railroad officials whose release was Russia's condition for resuming the Chinese Eastern Railway negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Of the $3,300,000,000 appropriated by Congress to finance the Public Works Administration, more than half has been allotted for non-Federal projects, going to States, municipalities, highway construction in all States, the civil works program, low-cost housing projects and the railroads.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14. -- A new "spy case," which may rival in sensations the celebrated British Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company affair, has arisen in Russia with the arrest of the general manager and five other foreign representatives of the Controll Company branch of the Societe Generale des Surveillances, Ltd., of Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- In keeping with its policy of recognizing Progressive Republicans in Cabinet places, the administration is ready, to take under its wing in this year's elections Senators who supported President Roosevelt in 1932. As the titular head of the party, the President is represented as favoring such a course.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- President Roosevelt pressed Senatorial leaders today for action on the St. Lawrence waterway treaty during a White House conference which preceded the larger meeting with Congressional committees tonight. Attending the treaty conference were Senators Pittman, Byrnes and Harrison, Democrats, and Senators Borah and Norris.

For the first time in the history of the American stage, the government will aid the unemployed actor, having granted an appropriation of $28,000 through the Civil Works Administration to put 150 actors to work immediately.

The bankers' agreement, embodying the four-year plan of emergency municipal financing, is in constant danger of misconstruction. This is perhaps only natural, since it is at once a novel and a rather complicated arrangement, establishing a relationship between the city and its creditors which has unfamiliar elements of duration and rigidity.
ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Speedy passage of the measure to give Mayor LaGuardia and the Board of Estimate broad powers to effect economies and changes in the city government was anticipated here tonight.

The funeral service held yesterday afternoon at the Juilliard School of Music, 130 Claremont Avenue, for Paul Kochanski, the violinist, demonstrated the esteem in which he was held by his associates in the world of music, and formed a fitting farewell to the artist.
The Census Bureau's report on American stocks of cotton at the end of December, in bales, exclusive of linters, compares as follows with that of a month and a year ago:

GENEVA, Jan. 14. -- The seventy-eighth session of the League of Nations Council opens here tomorrow under the presidency of Joseph Bock, Polish Foreign Minister, and it promises to get under way rather slowly.

VATICAN CITY, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Six Swiss Guards, high on a balcony of St. Peter's Cathedral, sounded their trumpets today as Mother Thouret, heroic healer and educator of the French revolutionary period, was joined to the ranks of Catholic saints by Pope Pius.

It used to be a tradition in England that a special meeting of the Cabinet was cause for anxiety if not alarm. News of its being summoned sent a tremor through the press and the financial markets. But a wise and experienced public man protested that this interpretation was all wrong.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Reports from the country indicate that corn held on farms by the government loans of 45 cents a bushel is around 125,000,000 bushels, indicating an outlay of about $56,250,000 and a small movement to primary markets for some time.

With the receipt of a $5,000 gift from the Altman Foundation, contributions to the United Hospital Fund, which is seeking to raise $500,000 to help its fifty-six member hospitals to provide free care to the sick poor, now total $375,300, it was announced yesterday.

The Park Association scroll, awarded annually to the person who has rendered the most outstanding service to the parks of New York City, will be given this year to William Henry Williams, it was announced yesterday. Mayor LaGuardia will make the presentation on behalf of the Park Association tomorrow at 11 A.M. in his office at City Hall.

Transit Commissioner Leon G. Godley and Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood, former Transit Commissioner, explained yesterday that neither one ever had a personal ferry pass, as might have been inferred from publication of data from the Department of Plant and Structures showing a total of 318,579 unpaid ferry rides in the last eight years.
BERLIN, Jan. 14 (AP). -- The fate of Bishop Ludwig Mueller as Reich Bishop of Germany rested today in the hands of Chancellor Hitler.

Dartmouth's 31-30 victory over a favored Princeton quintet at Hanover on Saturday featured the week in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race. With Al Bonniwell, forward, tossing in a basket in the last few seconds of play, the Hanoverians came from behind to give the Tigers their initial league defeat and place themselves in a tie for first place with Penn.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 14. -- Nelson Macy Sr. entertained a group of friends at his home, the Boulders, Glenville Road, Greenwich, tonight at a concert by the Perolle String Quartet of New York, whose members are Joseph Coleman, first violin; Max Hollander, second violin; Lillian Fuchs, viola, and Julian Kahn, 'cello.

Mayor LaGuardia and Governor Lehman will confer soon on revision of the city charter, it was learned yesterday. Their meeting will precede the introduction by the city administration of any legislation for wholesale charter revision.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- For the first time in four weeks a full program of dinghy racing was held today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. A west wind was stronger than really desired. One boat capsized, another was swamped, a third lost its rudder, and bits of rigging snapped like popping corks.

Barely recovered from an accident in which his arm had been broken three weeks ago, Henry Dixey, matinee idol of the Eighties, fractured his skull last night in a fall against a stairway. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where his condition was reported to be critical.

To be successful the industrial codes of the NRA must be coupled with spiritual codes, and to stir up these spiritual reinforcements is now one of the main objectives of the church, declared the Rev. Dr. Minor Simons in his sermon yesterday in All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

The Roosevelt Administration has won the first round of the controversy over reform of the veterans' pension system. It scored this victory when the House of Representatives approved a bill embodying the President's budget estimates. This measure proposes to appropriate for veterans' relief during the fiscal year beginning next July the sum of $546,000,000 -- compared with $884,000,000 actually spent for the same purpose in the year which ended last June 30.

PARIS, Jan. 14. -- The prospects for a peaceful plebiscite settling the troublesome problem of the Saar, for which the Council of the League of Nations will set a date in 1935 at its meeting in Geneva this week, are not encouraging.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- The United States budget has been little commented on in the press. It is remarked that the ordinary expenditures seem reasonably low in view of the expected increased cost of public administration arising from dollar depreciation and the rise of prices.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1933, as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Formation of a triumvirate to govern Tammany Hall has been suggested by some of those within the organization who favor removing John F. Curry as leader, it was revealed yesterday. As an alternative, it has been suggested that the governing committee have five to seven members, in which event some of them would be women or persons other than the present Assembly district leaders.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday the completion of a survey of the potential effects of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty, based entirely on testimony given before the subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and intended to show that American interests in transportation, industry, labor and agriculture would be adversely affected by the proposed development.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP). -- Cliff Sutter of New Orleans and Eugene McCauliff of New York, the national indoor champions, won the Miami Biltmore doubles title today, defeating Frank Shields of New York and Ricardo Morales of Cuba, 2 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0, in a sharply played final.

Immediate enactment of legislation creating municipal housing authorities was recommended yesterday, in a summary of its annual report, by the State Board of Housing. At the same time the board announced that a bill designed to carry out this recommendation would be placed before the Legislature tonight by Senator Samuel Mandelbaum.

THE next war, so the authorities of the symposia tell us, will be a war of civilian populations as well as a conflict of troops. Women and children, old men and cripples -- all will be subjected to mass pressure, to propaganda, to the fumes of gasses, the bombardments from the skies, the starvation superinduced by submarines watching the sea lanes.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14. -- Three winners returned more than $50 straight in the $2 mutuels on an eight-race charity program at Jefferson Park today. In three other events the pay-off exceeded $10 as favorites failed consistently despite racing conditions that were ideal with a fast track underfoot and clear skies overhead.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- The American and British protests against the reduction of German bond interest transfer apparently have had no effect on the Reichsbank authorities. The press prints the identical inspired paragraph that the protests played no role in the decision to hold a new conference in Berlin on Jan. 22 and that the real motive was to negotiate new transfer agreements with Holland and with Switzerland.

In a letter to THE TIMES E.T. Scott states with admirable lucidity the reasons why the Supreme Court of the United States might net sanction, even on the ground of "emergency," the assumption by the Federal Government of State authority not granted to it by the Federal Constitution either explicitly or by necessary implication.
Rose Bampton sings at the Beethoven Association concert tonight in the Town Hall, accompanied by Wilfred Pelletier, in lyrics of Brahms, Strauss, Wolf-Ferrari and Rossini.

The cancellation of a speech on the NRA which he was to have made here this afternoon at the Advertising Club before the Advertising Post of the American Legion was attributed yesterday by Colonel Robert Harvey White, a former City Auditor of Louisville, Ky., to the "underhanded work of some of General Johnson's subordinates."

The heaviest attendance of buyers in several years brought a sharp spurt in trade volume to practically all wholesale apparel markets here last week. The prospect of an early Easter and the reduced condition of retailers' stocks combined to give the Spring buying season an early start.

The police continued their drive against the city's gambling coterie yesterday, harassing occupants of suspected places with a series of raids. In many cases large groups of alleged gamblers were taken to police stations, but in others the raiders found the quarters deserted when they smashed their way in.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- With both houses of the Legislature fully organized at last, Governor Lehman will submit his annual budget message to the members when they return for a new week of sessions tomorrow night.

The French Line announced yesterday the retirement, effective Jan. 31, of Oscar R. Cauchois, advisory director of the line and dean of New York shipping men. Mr. Cauchois is 78 years old and has been with the French Line more than fifty-eight years.
Gangsters interrupted the last hand of an all-night card game yesterday morning and carefully and deliberately killed Angelo Pezzulo, 29 years old, of 1,223 White Plains Road, the Bronx.

In the plans for the improvement of the public school system there is one practical step of which no mention has been made. That is the importance of cooperation between the teachers of English and the public libraries.

" A Christian purpose is no guarantee of the intellectual ability to solve problems," said the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin yesterday morning in his sermon at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Seventy-third Street and Madison Avenue.
The Bronx Hockey Club's sextet defeated the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club at the Coliseum last night in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game, 6 -- 0.

Morton's Bantam Carry On, owned by Edward Morton of New York City and handled in the ring by Harry N. Clasen, won the highest award last night in the fifth annual specialty show of the Brooklyn Boston Terrier Club.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14. -- Harold (Red) Grange may not be the agile athlete of old, but he galloped like a ghost out of the past today, scoring two of the touchdowns which gave Chicago's Bears a 26-to-7 victory over a Southern California all-star football team before a near-capacity crowd of 20,000 at Wrigley Field.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 14. -- Gaillardia, a 10-1 shot bearing the silks of John D. Mikel, dashed to victory in the Hollywood Handicap, six-furlong feature here today. Alexander Pantages's Sharp Thoughts and the Meadowbrook Stable's Marceita, which ran as an entry, finished second and third, respectively.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- The week's trade reports were satisfactory. Railroad corporations' freight-car loadings for November were 7.6 per cent above the same month in 1932. November receipts were 259,000,000 marks, which was 28,000,000 marks above the total in November, 1932.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 14. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 72, which compares with 72 a week before, 71.8 two weeks before, 71.4 three weeks before and 72 four weeks before.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14. -- A unique honor to a living educator was paid by the Semitic Museum of Harvard yesterday when a portrait of Dr. David Gordon Lyon, honorary curator of the museum, was hung among those of the founders of the institution.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 14. -- A rise in production in the second week of the new year has given the steel trade further assurance. Production of ingots last week was reported at 30.7 per cent of capacity, against 29.3 per cent in the first week of the year.

More than a year of dissension among the members of the congregation of St. George's Greek Church, 420 West Forty-first Street, came to a climax last night when 300 infuriated men and women rioted for twenty minutes before a score of policemen were able to restore order.

HAVANA, Monday, Jan. 15. -- A high government official told The Associated Press early today that President Ramon Grau San Martin had presented his resignation to the original revolutionary junta of nineteen at Camp Columbia a few minutes after midnight.

The Tugwell Food, Drug and Cosmetic Bill, if enacted into law, could never accomplish the purposes of its author. It contains the same basic defects as those which have made its predecessor incapable of functioning according to plan.

The hope of the world is not the younger generation but the older, declared the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers in a sermon yesterday on "The Power of a Disillusioned Idealist" at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Better conditions for the grain trade are looked for by the majority of interests in all markets, with the trend of prices irregularly higher. Purchases are being made on the Board of Trade on all weak spots, and while upward responses of prices are not large, the market held unusually well last week, and there is more disposition to place a bullish construction on everything that comes from Washington.

The adoption at the Horace Mann School, Teachers College, Columbia University, of a new plan of teaching, beginning in the kindergarten and continuing through the high school, is disclosed in the annual report of the principal, Dr. Rollo G. Reynolds, made public yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- According to reports received by responsible financiers from Washington, it would appear that President Roosevelt is beginning to realize the dangers of the existing monetary situation and is inclined now to stabilize the dollar.

In the nomination of Major Gen. BLANTON WINSHP, retired, to be Governor of Puerto Rico there is much to commend. In a Governor the Puerto Ricans like dignity, courtesy, sympathy with their needs and comprehension of their problems, economic and political. It is essential that the Governor shall be able to keep on good terms with the island politicians, whatever he may think of their demands for Statehood and independence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP). -- William I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, announced today a continuation this year of a marketing plan for the wool and mohair clip similar to the one employed in 1933.

BARCELONA, Jan. 14. -- Left Wing republicanism in all Spain obtained a new lease of life today, when the Esquerra, Catalonia's Extreme Left party, won a decisive victory over the Monarchists and Conservative Catalonian League candidates for municipal offices in elections in 1,069 towns and cities.

The second performance of the season of the New York Chamber Music Society, Carolyn Beebe, founder and director, took place last night in the ball room of the Hotel Plaza before a large subscription audience.

The dollar was irregularly higher last week, measured by the quotation for the French franc. It had a strong start, at 64.44 cents on Monday, and held around the 64-cent level until Saturday, when it slumped to 63.60, closing at 63.76, which was a net gain over the previous week of .14. Range a year ago was 100.39@100.23 cents.

Appraisals of the current status of various phases of American life and forecasts, generally hopeful, of the outlook for the near future, were voiced last night by speakers familiar with a wide range of endeavor in a symposium over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

With the publication this month of Pearl S. Buck's "The Mother," that author's earlier best seller, "The Good Earth," has been "entrusted" by John Day Company, the original publishers, to two reprint houses for simultaneous publication.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop will be in court tomorrow morning to face a jury which is ready to begin hearing evidence in her trial for the murder of her daughter-in-law, Rheta Gardner Wynekoop. This was indicated tonight as the 62-year-old physician, rallied from a heart attack which she suffered last night.

The carcass of a two-toothed whale, believed to be similar to the one found off the Rockaways several weeks ago and of a species seldom seen on the Atlantic Coast, was washed up at the foot of Beach Fifty-fifth Street, Edgemere, Queens, yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The trucking industry through its national association today asked that Congress forego all plans for regulation of this business pending a trial of the trucking code.
HAVANA, Jan. 14. -- The properties of the Compania Cubana de Electricitad, an affiliate of the

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- President Roosevelt tomorrow will disclose his monetary policy in a message to Congress in which it was indicated tonight that he will ask for affirmative legislation to take over the $3,600,000,000 gold in the Federal Reserve banks and revalue the dollar.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- The Reichsbank authorities do not admit that German dollar bonds are being purchased abroad except in accordance with its regulations. It is asserted that it would indeed be impossible to market in Germany surreptitiously repurchased bonds.

Defending his belief in immortality, Bishop William T. Manning replied yesterday to the assertion made last week by Dr. Howard Lee McBain that man's belief in an after-life has been greatly weakened by the progress of science.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Extension of the Railway Emergency Transportation Act, so as to improve working conditions of Pullman porters was urged today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who pointed out that porters, as employes of a common carrier, could not come under the NRA.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 14. -- State Troopers and Bergen County Police arrested five men today believed to be members of a gang that had robbed homes in this and Rockland County, N.Y., in the last few months. More than $4,000 of the loot has been recovered.

The Rev. Dr. William A. Sunday, better known as Billy Sunday, preached to two overflow congregations yesterday in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street. The 70-year-old evangelist entered the second week of a fortnight's revival campaign, which closes next Sunday night.

The disclosure that assessments totaling $28,750,000 for local improvements had been "practically stuffed away in pigeonholes" during Tammany control of the city government was made last night by W. Arthur Cunningham, the new City Controller.

Albert H. Wiggin, Percy A. Rockefeller and two other directors have resigned or signified their desire to retire from the board of the American International Corporation, according to the annual report made public yesterday. The other two are Beekman Winthrop of Robert Winthrop Co. and Robert K. Cassatt of Cassatt Co.

WILKES-BARRE, Jan. 14 (AP). -- With the police units of two counties prepared to suppress the first semblance of disorder, the northern anthracite region tensely awaited developments tonight in the impending struggle for mine union supremacy.

However baffling the lay visitor may find the eleven paintings by Mrs. Irving T. Bush that go on exhibition this morning at the galleries of Wildenstein Co., Inc., 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, their inspiration is not to be attributed to spiritualism.

BERLIN, Jan. 14. -- Two hundred thousand German workers "of the fist and brow," headed by 2,000 banners and a score of bands, were assembled in the Lustgarten in front of the former royal palace in Berlin this afternoon to celebrate a new labor law that actually re-establishes the former relation in which the employer was "master in his house."

A statement of the position of the United States Industrial Alcohol Company and the United States Industrial Chemical Company, sued by the government at Baltimore for $8,140,514 taxes on denatured alcohol allegedly diverted for beverage purposes, was issued last night by Charles S. Munson, president of the former concern.

The plane and equipment used by Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh in their recent exploration of ocean air routes will be put on public exhibition at 9 o'clock this morning at the American Museum of Natural History.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the recital by Ruth Slenczynski, 8-year-old pianist, on the afternoon of Jan. 27 at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of St. Mary's Hospital for Children. Proceeds of the benefit will be devoted to the needs of the hospital which has had unusual demands made upon it recently in caring for the children of unemployed parents and those who cannot afford to meet the fees.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14. -- Flower-adorned tables surrounding the dance floor were filled with members and their guests tonight at the colorful dinner dance with which the Everglades Club celebrated its formal opening for the season, and initiated a series of similar events to be held there Thursday and Sunday nights throughout the Winter.
Jesus Christ established the true commune, said the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, preaching yesterday morning in the Little Church Around the Corner, Twenty-ninth Street east of Fifth Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14. -- Suffering from an injured foot, Johnny Skillman, defending titleholder from the Apawamis Club at Rye, N.Y., was forced to default today to Jack Summers of Boston in the final round of the national professional squash racquets championship at the Penn A.C.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $4,244,988,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
The New York Americans defeated Brookhattan, 4 to 2, in a first-round National Challenge Soccer Cup contest at Starlight Park yesterday before 1,500 spectators.

A letter to Governor Lehman, suggesting that New York State might increase its taxes on gasoline, motor vehicles, amusements, insurance companies, incomes, chain stores, tobacco, inheritances and banks without raising the level of such imposts beyond that of other States, was made public yesterday by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations of 130 West Forty-second Street.

Oswald Jacoby, David Burnstine, Michael T. Gottlieb and Howard Schenken broke the deadlock last night in a play off at the Crockford Club of the semi-final round of the contract bridge national championship held at the Hotel Pierre. Jacoby and his partners defeated Mrs. Ely Culbertson, Waldemar von Zedtwitz, Edward Hymes Jr. and Louis H. Watson, and emerged after thirty-two gruelling hands with a lead of 2,740 points.

The cotton market was more active last week than in any similar period since Dec. 1. Prices again moved upward, recording the highest quotations since September. Active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the week 35 to 45 points net higher.

The name of W.S. Barstow Co. has been changed to the E.M. Gilbert Engineering Corporation, according to an announcement made yesterday. The new name has been voted by the board of directors to identify the organization with its president, E.M. Gilbert.

" Salome" represents a striking reversal in public temper between the two Roosevelt administrations. The Strauss opera was received with horrified disapproval in 1907 and banned after a single performance. No public protests have been heard against its revival today.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- Steel production in Great Britain during December was 668,900 tons, against 695,000 in November and 430,400 in December, 1932. The total for the year was 7,002,800 tons, comparing with 5,261,400 in 1932.

Two important museum exhibitions are scheduled for this week. Tonight, with a reception and preview at 10:30, the Museum of Modern Art will open its international exhibition of theatre art, assembled by Lee Simonson. Beginning tomorrow, the work will be on public view until Feb. 26.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14. -- Factional strife within the Armenian Apostolic Church, which caused the recent assassination of Archbishop Tourian in New York, called thirty detectives today to St. Gregory's Church here, after its seizure by one faction of the congregation.

HSINKING (Changchun), Jan. 14 (AP). -- A gorgeous robe of yellow silk, traditional Chinese imperial color, will cloak Henry Pu Yi when he is enthroned as Emperor of Manchukuo March 1. He used the robe when at the age of 3 he mounted the throne of China.

DETROIT, Jan. 14. -- By revaluing and nationalizing gold and restoring silver we would have enough precious metal upon which to base 25,000,000,000 currency dollars, Father Charles E. Coughlin declared today, urging his audience to write their Congressmen and demand support of such a program.

If the people of the United States are trying to secure prosperity by raising prices, it certainly should be made clear to them that sudden increases in the amount of money without due regard for other influences will not accomplish their purposes.
