Coughlin, "radio priest" of Detroit, told the House Coinage, Weights and Measures Committee today. He added that "President Roosevelt has leadership; he has followers and he is the answer to the many prayers that were sent up last year."

WITH Primo Carnera duo to land on United States soil today, it is interesting to note that Jack Dempsey is swinging toward Gene Tunney. There is nothing belligerent in this swing. The old Manassa Mauler is not taking down his padded gloves for a third battle with the retired Student Prince of pugilism. This is a peaceful swing as far as the famous principals are concerned.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16. -- Excelling in all departments of the game, Tommy Goodwin, 20-year-old Monroe (N.Y.) star, registered an easy victory in the first round of match play in defense of his midwinter amateur golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today.

Inspector Joseph W. O'Connor of the Department of Licenses took the witness stand yesterday as the last witness in a dismissal hearing before Commissioner Sidney S. Levine on charges that he conspired with others to extort thousands of dollars in graft from news-stand operators whose license fees are fixed at $5 each.

Supreme Court Justice McGeehan, who heard yesterday an application by substitute high school teachers for full-time salaries while holding positions not filled by regular appointments, reserved decision after commenting on the fact that some teachers conduct playground and recreation classes in addition to their regular jobs.

ROME, Jan. 16 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's proposals for revaluing the dollar were cited before the Italian Senate today by Finance Minister Jung as proof of the wisdom of Premier Mussolini's firm stand against inflation.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- Prussian Premier Hermann Goering has decreed that of the tens of thousands of Germans who have fled abroad since the Nazi victory, only those will be received back into the Fatherland who can show they were innocent victims of propaganda or fled because of unreasoning fright.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- Schkewa Dimitroff, aged mother of Georgi Dimitroff, called at the Reich Ministry of the Interior today in an effort to obtain the release of her son who is still held in a Leipzig jail together with his two Bulgarian comrades, despite their acquittal at the Reichstag fire trial.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 16. -- The Legislative conference committee will meet next Monday to consider the recommendations made last night by D. Frederick Burnett, State Beverage Commissioner, for changing the State Liquor Control Law.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- Mute evidence -- a chloroform mask, red-stained clothing, towels, handkerchiefs, a glistening revolver -- stirred Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop out of apathy today in Judge David's court where she is on trial for the murder of Rheta Wynekoop, her daughter-in-law.

A resolution praising Governor Lehman for his recommendation that the 1 per cent sales tax be abandoned after June 30 was adopted yesterday at the closing session of the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Secretaries at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

S.S. SANTA BARBARA, at sea, Jan. 16. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull will transfer tomorrow at Cristobal, C.Z., to the cruiser Richmond, which will hand him at Key West, Fla., in time to reach Washington Saturday night instead of the following Wednesday.

The Police Department began a new search yesterday for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, notorious beer racketeer, by shifting two detectives with a reputation for vigor in harrying members of Schultz's "mob."
MOSCOW, Jan. 16. -- Reorganization of the machine tractor stations -- the most important single unit in Soviet agriculture -- is forecast in an article appearing in today's Pravda.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 16. -- The Riverhead Production Credit Association, a farmers' cooperative organization, with resources for lending $1,000,000, has been organized to assist farmers throughout Long Island and Staten Island to finance the planting and harvesting of their crops.

House Democrats have a long-standing grudge against Postmaster General FARLEY. Several times remonstrances and supplications have been addressed to him. None the less the regular patronage has been ladled out with provoking slowness. Distribution of jobs in the emergency agencies has filled faithful hearts with amazement and anger.

The most intensive round of play and entertainment that has probably ever been planned in honor of a visiting women's sports team awaits the American women's squash racquets combination which will sail for England Friday evening at midnight on board the White Star liner Olympic.

Despite Mayor LaGuardia's letter to Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, urging him to consult a committee of eminent musicians before naming a head of the music department at Hunter College, the Board, without such action ratified last night by a vote of 17 to 4, the selection of Louis Lucien Lambert for that post.

KEARNY, N.J., Jan. 16. -- Five Japanese, who had been photographing the Pulaski Skyway and other points from Jersey City to the Newark Airport, were questioned by police here today for more than nine hours and then released in the custody of Takeo Nimiys, vice consul of Japan in New York City.

A few survivors of the Jefferson Brick school of finance echo the old cry that in all questions of money and standards of value America should proudly go it alone. This now seems like a leftover from 1896, when WILLIAM J. BRYAN was demanding remonetization of silver at the ratio of 16 to 1, "without waiting for the consent of any nation on earth."

The New York City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board submitted yesterday to the State ABC Board recommendations for changing the State regulations for liquor sale, including a provision that was interpreted as a move for permitting drinking of liquor at bars.

Notice of appeal from the decision of former Vice Chancellor John J. Fallon of New Jersey handed down on Monday in the case of the Fidelity Title and Mortgage Company of Ridgewood was filed yesterday in the Court of Errors and Appeals, Jersey City, by Mahlon Pitney, counsel for a joint committee of security holders.

S.S. SANTA BARBARA, at Sea, Jan. 16. -- Cordell Hull, Secretary of State of the United States, disclosed today that the formula for the long-pending and disturbing situation in Haiti included the withdrawal of United States treaty officials as soon as Haiti paid debts amounting to $11,000,000 or $12,000,000 due to the United States.

Seventy-seven prisoners taken in gambling raids were arraigned in Night Court last night but all except one of them were freed for lack of evidence. The lone exception was John Daly, arrested with fifty-nine others in a raid at 2,182 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Twenty of the thirty-five Republican Senators, with only two of the insurgents present, adopted a legislative program today. While not taking a definite stand on the President's monetary proposals, they demanded full hearings by the Banking and Currency Committee, with opportunities for the presentation of opposing arguments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The President's monetary policy is intended to bring about "a more steady purchasing power for your dollar," Secretary Morgenthau said in an address before sound cameras at the Treasury Department today.

The nicely calculated manoeuvre of the New York Yankees in signing Babe Ruth early and at a greatly reduced salary paves the way for major league club owners to effect further retrenchment in their 1934 payrolls.

Former Mayor John P. O'Brien has been withdrawn as a candidate for appointment by Governor Lehman as Supreme Court justice to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Curtis A. Peters, it was learned yesterday. Mr. O'Brien, who quit the office of Surrogate of New York County in 1932 to run for Mayor, was recommended for the appointment by John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall.
The organization of a new polo club was announced at a dinner in the St. Moritz Hotel last night. It was named the St. Moritz Polo Club and plans were made for a season of play.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Five hundred physicians of Washington, New York, Philadelphia and other cities today joined in endorsing the bills introduced by Senator Hastings and Representative Pierce of Oregon to authorize the dissemination of contraceptive information and advice by recognized medical authorities.

Defending his administration of the State Insurance Department, and particularly his program for the mortgage guarantee companies, Superintendent George S. Van Schaick testified yesterday in the Moreland Act investigation of his department that he had taken over the companies as a last resort.

From a radius of sixty miles this evening will come fifty elderly couples whom Walter Damrosch has invited as guests of honor tonight at the Mendelssohn Festival in Madison Square Garden. The couples were married to Mendelssohn's wedding march forty to sixty years ago.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 16 (AP). -- Carl G. Snavely, head football coach at Bucknell University for the last seven years, was tonight elected by the University of North Carolina athletic council as head coach to succeed Charles (Chuck) Collins, whose contract expired the first of the year.

A plan of operation designed to permit the company to waive certain requirements in its indenture has been sent to holders of 5 per cent sinking fund gold debentures of the United States Radiator Corporation.

George V. McLaughlin, banker and independent Democrat, was appointed and sworn in yesterday by Mayor LaGuardia as a member of the Triborough Bridge Authority. He fills the vacancy caused by the recent resignation of Fred C. Lemmerman.
Plaintiffs in foreclosure actions bid in yesterday's auction offerings, including seven Manhattan parcels and two in the Bronx, as follows:

The year 1933 was abnormally warm, rainy and windy in New York City, according to the sixty-fifth annual report of the New York Meteorological Observatory of the United States Weather Bureau. The report was made public yesterday by David R. Morris, meteorologist of the observatory, which is in Central Park.

News was received yesterday from London by the Cunard Line that Captain George Gibbons, master of the Franconia, which sailed on Jan. 9 for a southern cruise around the world, has been appointed aide de camp to King George V. This carries with it the promotion to the rank of captain in the Royal Naval Reserve and is the highest honor paid to officers in the British merchant marine.

In an exhibition that opens to the public today, the Whitney Museum of American Art reports its acquisitions for the year 1933. Many of the new possessions made their first Whitney appearance in the recent biennial of sculpture, water-colors, drawings and prints. These purchases were announced in the art column of Jan. 8.

In an open letter of rebuttal, James P. Warburg, vice chairman of the Bank of Manhattan Company, renewed yesterday his criticism of the monetary proposals of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin and defended himself against the charge of being a "spokesman for Wall Street."

LEIPZIG, Jan. 16. -- Ludwig Renn, noted writer, was sentenced by the German Supreme Court today to two and one-half years' imprisonment for high treason, his eleven-month detention in a concentration camp without trial to be deducted from the sentence.

Philip H. Philbin Jr., promoter who made more than $600,000 trading in stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation, was examined again yesterday before Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall, but was unable to recall details of large loans he received or of checks for $404,400 which passed through his hands.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- Sharp criticism of the attempt by the Public Service Commission to reduce light rates in New York City, on the ground that the commission had attempted to use methods "not sanctioned by law," was contained today in a decision handed down by Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck.

Republican Senators meeting in caucus at Washington yesterday decided not to oppose the President's monetary policy in anything like a general line of battle. They did demand, as is their right, full and free hearings before the Banking Committee when the President's bills are under consideration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- A challenge of the President's authority to delegate the powers granted him by recovery legislation confronted the administration today as the result of an opinion given to Secretary Ickes by Controller General McCarl, holding that expenditures by the Federal Housing Corporation without his own approval would be unconstitutional.
Cardinal Hayes was guest of honor at a reception tendered him last night by the Catholic Club of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. About 200 invited guests attended.
WARSAW, Jan. 16. -- Archbishop Dionitius, head of the autonomous Orthodox Church of Poland, was indicted today together with five other Orthodox bishops for granting illegal divorces.

Upon agreement to pay $5,000, Isidor J. Kresel, counsel and director of the Bank of United States, who was convicted of aiding and abetting the misapplication of funds of one of the bank's affiliates, was eliminated yesterday as a defendant in the $60,000,000 suit by the Superintendent of Banks against the officers and directors of the Bank of United States and in the $50,000,000 action against the directors of the Bankus Corporation, an affiliate.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 16. -- Argentina's efforts to arrange a Chaco peace ended in failure today. The Foreign Office presented a memorandum of its effort to the League of Nations Chaco commission and terminated its mediation without giving out details.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Babe Ruth's radio contest with baseball prizes for children was the subject of a suit brought by the government today against the sponsor, the Standard Oil Company of Hew Jersey.

BOSTON, Jan. 16 -- The Boston sloop Yankee, holder of the best time on record for the thirty-mile ocean course over which America's Cup contests are sailed, today re-entered the lists as a prospective defender of that most prized of all yachting trophies in the international contest scheduled next Summer.

The shipyards of the world, exclusive of Russia, were engaged in the construction of 727,277 tons at the close of the year, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, published yesterday. This is an increase of 525 tons over the total reported on Sept. 30 and marks the second successive improvement after two years of reduced activity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The Special Committee on the Investigation of Campaign Expenditures, in a report made to the Senate today, stated that the situation with regard to the elections in Louisiana "cannot be defended," but did not question the right of Senator Overton to be seated.

The net operating deficit of the Young Men's Christian Association of the City of New York last year was $79,198, according to a summary of the association's reports, made public yesterday. The total operating income was $2,371,943, compared with total operating expenses of $2,451,141.

Fred Ostermueller of Rochester was the most effective pitcher in the International League for the 1933 season, turning in an average of 2.44 earned runs per nine-inning game, according to the official figures released for publication today.

NUTLEY, N.J., Jan. 16. -- James Percival Terry of 12 Myrtle Avenue, who was born in the Tower of London and has recollections of the coronation of Queen Victoria, will celebrate his 100th birthday Friday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Following is the text of the statement on the administration's monetary policy issued today by Governor E.R. Black of the Federal Reserve Board:

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Jan. 16. -- The four children of Mrs. Charles Laverty, ranging from 7 to 13 years of age, could not suppress a desire to see their father, who was separated from Mrs. Laverty three years ago, so they started out on foot this morning for the Pennsylvania Station in New York, where Mr. Laverty works as a track walker.

Charles H. Brown, 68 years old, who in 1931 impoverished three elderly sisters, one now dead, through the theft of $38,116, after two other swindlers had defrauded them of $12,500 in bogus real estate transactions, was sent to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions for a term of from three to six years.

This morning, while walking across the George Washington Bridge, I noticed that the surface of the Hudson was almost completely covered with a film of oil, which in many places thickened into long ribbons or patches that moved steadily with the ebbing tide.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Yesterday the only Democratic voice raised in public against the President's plan to take title to the Federal Reserve Banks' gold was that of Senator Carter Glass. Only a few Republicans spoke out critically, and today that party's Senate conference deferred the expression of an opinion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Canada would not have one right of navigation under the proposed St. Lawrence Waterway treaty that she does not possess today, Senator Vandenberg, a supporter of the treaty, asserted in the Senate today.

The thirty-odd members of Class 8 B-4 of Public School 7, the Bronx, were "kept in" yesterday afternoon. They had whispered and been inattentive; the punishment was neither unexpected nor unprecedented.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 16 (AP). -- Exhibiting a steady brand of tennis, William T. Tilden defeated Ellsworth Vines, youthful California pro, in straight sets, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, 8 -- 6, before a crowd of 3,000 fans tonight. The victory gave Tilden a 3-2 lead in the current series with Vines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The battle opened on Capitol Hill today over legislation to carry forward President Roosevelt's monetary program, with all signs pointing to early adoption without substantial change of the bill drafted by the Treasury and submitted to Congress yesterday.
Dr. William Beebe, deep sea scientist, threw in his lot last night with the disbelievers in the sea serpent of Loch Ness, Scotland.

Attorneys for the clearing house banks and the bankers sued by the government to compel payment in full of the depositors of the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company served answers yesterday on counsel for the Controller of the Currency.

Believing that plays should be about something that matters, Leopold Atlas has set down the tragedy of a boy whose parents are divorced, "Wednesday's Child," which was put on at the Longacre last evening. It is a sensitively imagined play, told with unusual reticence and played, especially by young Frank M. Thomas Jr., with heartbreaking sincerity. According to the author's version of the old nursery rhyme, "Wednesday's child is full of woe.

Brooklyn College succumbed to Yeshiva College in a match under the auspices of the newly organized New York City Intercollegiate Chess Association at the rooms of the New York University Chess Club yesterday. The contest was staged on four boards, Yeshiva winning by 2 1/2 to 1 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Approval of the President's monetary policies was termed an integral part of the program of the National Agricultural Conference, composed of leaders of farm organizations, by a delegation from the conference which called on President Roosevelt at his invitation today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Rum Row, which has existed off the northeastern coast of the United States since 1925 endeavoring to land intoxicating liquor, tonight, as a result of an official hint, is being shifted toward British Honduras and other foreign ports to prepare for legal shipment of about 2,000,000 gallons of whisky into the United States.

A truck loaded with woolens and other merchandise valued at about $5,000 was hijacked from its driver and his helper yesterday morning when they had parked to make several deliveries along Tenth Avenue and the upper Fifties. The empty van later was recovered by the police of the Fifth Street station following a teletype alarm.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16. -- Jacques Dupuy, publisher of the Le Petit Parisien, was in a "serious but not critical" condition in St. Francis Hospital at Miami Beach tonight from head wounds suffered when a small seaplane which he was flying crashed into Biscayne Bay this afternoon.

An order for a new sailing canoe to compete against the British for the International Challenge Cup has been placed by W.A. Bartholomae Jr. of Los Angeles with the firm of Sparkman Stephens, it was announced yesterday.

At last we know where we stand in this whole monetary business. We, the people of the United States, stand to make $2,666,666,666 when we have taken over all the gold in the country and the dollar has been devalued to 60 cents.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 16. -- Holding that it would be unwise now to appoint an outside football coach, the Yale Daily News in an editorial today strongly recommended the reappointment of Reginald Root, football mentor last year, for the coming campaign.

A permanent organization of the Recovery party in New York County, with former State Senator Thomas Sheridan as chairman, was formed last night at a meeting in the Hotel Astor. The organization will seek to reorganize the Democratic party in the county and oust John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, from the party leadership.

The cost of living for industrial wage earners declined .6 of 1 per cent in December, according to the regular monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board, which was made public yesterday. This followed a decline of .3 of 1 per cent in November, which had terminated six months of steady advance.
" Massacre," with Richard Barthelmess and Ann Dvorak, will open at the Strand today.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

A tract published by the Community Trust is entertaining reading. One chapter recites the difficulties an interstate traveler would have in obeying the laws. In Maine it is a misdemeanor for a pedestrian to solicit a ride from a passing motor vehicle. In Massachusetts he may not "while in disguise" pull up a mayflower.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 16. -- Scoring twice in the first five minutes and holding the upper hand throughout, the Princeton freshman hockey team scored its second victory of the season in the Baker rink tonight, downing the Morristown sextet, 7 -- 0.

GENEVA, Jan. 16. -- Talk of the Saar Territory Governing Commission's asking the League of Nations Council to reinforce immediately with a neutral police force its means of maintaining order grew here today, while the council delegates of France, Britain and Italy held several bilateral conversations on the problem of arranging for the 1935 plebiscite.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- The Daily Herald has given a new turn to the controversy over the purchase of the Codex Sinaiticus asserting that the full purchase price of 100,000 was paid to the Soviet authorities on Dec. 24, the very day the manuscript arrived in London.
Members of the freshman class at Barnard College were advised yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gilder-sleeve to take their examinations "like scores in golf."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a dinner at the White House tonight. Afterward there was a musicale in the East room to which additional guests had been invited. The program was given by Miss Jessica Lee, diseuse, and Ruggiero Ricci, violinist.

The Museum of the City of New York received yesterday for its diversified collection of material illustrating the history of the city a portrait of Isaac Moses, Revolutionary patriot and financier. This painting by John Wesley Jarvis was bought recently, through the efforts of Mrs. Solomon de Sola and Mrs. Annie. Nathan Meyer, by a group of public-spirited citizens.

As a result of the reduced appropriation for the Dock Department in the 1934 budget which the O'Brien administration adopted, Dock Commissioner John McKenzie has been forced, he said yesterday, to drop seventy-two members of his engineering staff.
A radio facsimile inter-city service is planned by the Radio Corporation of America, David Sarnoff, its president, announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club.
Sale of a large apartment building in the lower Washington Heights section of Manhattan and several deals in the Bronx enlivened the real estate market yesterday.
Heywood Broun, the columnist, disclosed yesterday that he and his wife, Ruth Hale, head of the Lucy Stone League, were divorced last November at Nogales, Mexico.

DENVER, Jan. 16 (AP). -- Former Senator Charles S. Thomas, 84, expressed the hope from a sick bed today that his daughter, Edith Thomas, 45, recently indicted on a charge of hoarding $3,000 in gold, "accepts life imprisonment rather than relinquish her fight to establish her property rights."

HAVANA, Jan. 16. -- Fearing the outbreak of civil war between the followers of Antonio Guiteras and the forces backing Carlos Hevia, the new President, residents of Havana remained in their homes throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Upon the records of the Senate committee investigating air mail contracts was spread today the story of a young man who ran an investment of $40 in aviation stock to paper profits of more than $5,000,000 in less than four years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Approval of a loan of $77,000,000 from the Public Works Administration to the Pennsylvania Railroad was announced today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. Half of the proceeds of the loan will be used for completion of electrified facilities from New York to Washington and the other half for the purchase of rolling stock equipment.
BOSTON, Jan. 16 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins ended one of the longest longest streaks in their history tonight by overwhelming the Canadiens 4 -- 0 before 9,000 in the Boston Garden.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange continued its vigorous advance yesterday with the exception of foreign loans, which moved lower as the leading foreign exchange rates declined in relation to the dollar. The market was extremely active, the turnover of $25,253,200 being the largest since July 7.

Leading medical and social organizations of the city have been asked to aid in a reorganization of the Advisory Council of the Hospital Department, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- The first session of the unrestricted public sale in Chicago of the furnishings of the town mansion of the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick this afternoon almost amounted to a private sale. Muriel McCormick Hubbard, the wife of Major Elisha Dyer Hubbard and the elder daughter of the late Mrs. McCormick and Harold F. McCormick, was the principal buyer.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Jan. 16. -- The Choate basketball team routed Kent today, 36 to 17. Shirk of Choate led the scoring, tallying eleven points. Jackson was high man for Kent with seven. At the end of the first half the score stood 14 to 3 in favor of Choate.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- The new German labor code, already celebrated at mass meetings Sunday and hailed as Chancellor Hitler's greatest revolutionary deed, was published today. It will become effective May 1.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- The Westchester Title and Trust Company, to avoid any complications from a question raised as to the qualifications of Supreme Court Justice George H. Taylor Jr. to sign orders in the rehabilitation of title companies in which he held certificates, obtained today from Justice William F. Bleakley an order turning its assets over to the Superintendent of Insurance for rehabilitation.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 16. -- Lady Daphne F. Hatton has arrived from Philadelphia, joining the house party of Charles A. Munn at Amado.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- A significant fact not generally known and never before published is that not one shilling of England's exchange equalization fund of 350,000,000 has ever been used to buy dollars since the United States went off gold last April.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- A bid to heal the breach which developed among Republicans in the Assembly over the election of a clerk was made today by Speaker McGinnies when he announced the committee assignments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Two former Secretaries of the Treasury under President Wilson, Senators McAdoo and Glass, led the opposition today to President Roosevelt's taking over the gold held by the Federal Reserve Banks.

Upon being informed yesterday that the State Senate had set Jan. 30 for a hearing on the city economy bill, Mayor LaGuardia acted immediately to have the date advanced. In telegrams to Senator John J. Dunnigan, majority leader, and Senator George R. Fearon, minority leader of the Senate, the Mayor pointed out that Jan. 30 was just two days before the time limit set by the Federal Government for balancing the city budget.

Irving Bitz, racketeer, whose release from the Tombs on a $30,000 bail bond by Justice May of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn was without the knowledge of District Attorney Dodge, was ordered yesterday to appear for trial today in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions.

J. Howard Shoemaker of New York and Abraham Kaiser of the Brooklyn Elks won their initial matches in the national amateur three-cushion billiard championship tournament at the Capitol Billiard Academy yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- A brutal attack on an American citizen in Berlin by a uniformed Nazi storm trooper yesterday was reported to the Prussian police authorities today by Raymond Geist, acting United States Consul General.

VIENNA, Jan. 16. -- The intrigues of the faction of the Heimwehr led until recently by Count Johann Alberti are still going on despite his recent forced resignation as leader of the Lower Austrian section of the movement.

CALCUTTA, Jan. 16. -- Two airmen who flew over the earthquake-stricken district of Northern Bihar today estimated 1,000 lay dead in the streets of Muzzafarpur, a city of about 44,000, where scarcely a house was left standing.

Reporting on the recent real estate code hearings in Washington to the Management Division of the Real Estate Board of New York at the dinner meeting last night at the Hotel Astor, Lawrence B. Cummings, vice president of the Real Estate Board and chairman of the code committee, stated that none of the realty codes is definitely settled and further conferences must take place before final decisions are reached.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Jan. 17. -- The Cantonese armies are now engaged in a race to occupy the cities of Southern Fukien, deserted by the rebels, and two divisions already are reported to have taken Chuanchow and Chengchow.

CALCUTTA, Jan. 16. -- Two airmen who flew over the earthquake-stricken district of Northern Bihar today estimated 1,000 lay dead in the streets of Muzzafarpur, a city of about 44,000, where scarcely a house was left standing.

Reporting on the recent real estate code hearings in Washington to the Management Division of the Real Estate Board of New York at the dinner meeting last night at the Hotel Astor, Lawrence B. Cummings, vice president of the Real Estate Board and chairman of the code committee, stated that none of the realty codes is definitely settled and further conferences must take place before final decisions are reached.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Jan. 17. -- The Cantonese armies are now engaged in a race to occupy the cities of Southern Fukien, deserted by the rebels, and two divisions already are reported to have taken Chuanchow and Chengchow.

Mrs. Francis Hennessy gave a luncheon yesterday in the Tapestry Room of the Ritz Tower for her sister, Miss May Leslie, who is leaving today for Fresno, Calif. Other guests were Mrs. Julien St. Charles Chaqueneau, the Misses Barbara Shields, Louisine Munn and Alice Schumacher; Lawrence Sprague, Berkeley Jackson, Ward Fox and Joseph Ryle.

Irving Bitz, racketeer, whose release from the Tombs on a $30,000 bail bond by Justice May of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn was without the knowledge of District Attorney Dodge, was ordered yesterday to appear for trial today in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions.

J. Howard Shoemaker of New York and Abraham Kaiser of the Brooklyn Elks won their initial matches in the national amateur three-cushion billiard championship tournament at the Capitol Billiard Academy yesterday.

Considering the extremely active stock markets of Monday and the violence of the advance, Wall Street seemed agreeably surprised that business held up so well yesterday and that the gains in the general market were extended. The board rooms of the commission houses were crowded for the first time in many weeks, and the more enthusiastic brokers began to lay plans for continued expansion in market operations.

The seasons first performance of Richard Wagner's "Siegfried" will take place next Wednesday evening during the fifth week of the Metropolitan Opera season. In the cast will be Mmes. Kappel, Branzell and Fleischer and Messrs. Melchior, Schorr, List, Schutzendorf and Windheim, Mr. Bodanzky conducting.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- Rose Marie Brancato, 21-year-old Kansas City girl, made her debut in "Rigoletto" at the Civic Opera House tonight. She sang the role of Gilda which Marion Talley, another Kansas City singer, declined when the Chicago Grand Opera Company failed to meet salary terms.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 17. -- Bill Terry expects his New York Giants to encounter brisk opposition this year from Chicago, St. Louis and Pittsburgh, but he is not afraid of any one of them.
Steel operations are running at about 33 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 31 per cent a week ago, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- President Roosevelt's next message to Congress he indicated today will, as forecast by his budget message, request the immediate appropriation of $1,166,000,000 to carry on the relief and recovery programs until June 30, the end of the fiscal year.

VIENNA, Jan. 17. -- Emil Fey, Minister of the Interior, broadcast tonight a warning to Austrian Nazis and threatened to act mercilessly against those who exploded bombs or committed other acts of terrorism.
BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- An inspired statement issued today denied reports from abroad, attributed to emigres, that there are still 215,000 political prisoners in Germany.

Having covered 22,000 miles on foot and bicycle since June 28, 1930, and planning to cover several thousand more before returning to Shanghai, Poon Tuck Ming, youthful Chinese, is resting for a week or so at the International House, 500 Riverside Drive.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 17. -Tables the North Lounge placed in were decorated with pink gladioli for the luncheon with which Mrs. Robert Dun Douglass entertained today at the Breakers, where, with Mr. Douglass, she is spending the season.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- The stock market were quieter today and most industrial shares were weaker on fears that devaluation of the dollar may affect British exports. Gold-mining shares also were quieter, but after early profit-taking the strength of the franc revived interest on Paris buying.

Appointment of leaders of American and Japanese commerce and industry to the executive committee of the American-Japanese Trade Council, which is fostered by the National Foreign Trade Council, was announced yesterday. Problems affecting the trade relations of the two countries will be dealt with by the body.
The trustees for Mobile Ohio general mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1938, received tenders at around par for $167,000 in response to a purchase offer that expired on Tuesday.

The payment of graft to obtain news-stand licenses has been such a well-established practice in this city for years that it has developed into a business under the name of "news-stand brokerage," according to William Heinemann, chairman of the Welfare Committee of Disabled Veterans.
Miss Catherine Paul-Boncour, daughter of Joseph Paul-Boncour, French Minister of Foreign Affairs, is arriving today from Havre via Plymouth on the French liner Champlain.
Mayor LaGuardia announced yesterday a change in the policy of the Department of Hospitals which will make it possible for expectant mothers to obtain pre-natal care in the city hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Secretary Morgenthau tonight extended the deadline for the surrender of gold coin, bullion and certificates, issuing instructions for the receipt of gold and payment at face value until further notice. A previous order had set midnight tonight as the deadline.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, issued a statement today condemning the new German labor code as meaning "enslavement and autocratic control" for the German working masses.

MANILA, Jan. 17. -- The Hawes Law expired in the Philippines amid the same apathy as greeted its passage. Despite attempts to work up a big funeral demonstration, including the serving of free lunch in the public plaza, proponents of the act were able to muster only 3,000 persons out of a city of half a million to hear eulogies at its death.
PARIS, Jan. 17. -- The real nature of France's offer to Germany in her disarmament memorandum is outlined in an extensive summary of that document published in Le Petit Parisien.

PANAMA CITY, Jan. 17. -- Hailed by the local press as "the standard-bearer of peace," Secretary of State Cordell Hull of the United States, who arrived here this morning on the Grace liner Santa Barbara, justified that designation.

Purchase of several residences on the East Side featured the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday. Among the buyers was William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting Company, who acquired a four-story dwelling at 29 Beekman Place from the Gustav J. Staats estate.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- The hog market was somewhat unsettled today. Offerings of light weights were liberal and sales generally were at 5 cents decline, while heavier weights and packing sows were steady to strong, with some sales that looked 10 cents higher.

The provisions of the National Recovery Act through the codification of industry are to be applied to the insular possessions of the United States, it was learned yesterday with the announcement that Rose Schneiderman, member of the Labor Advisory Board of the National Recovery Administration, would leave this morning for Puerto Rico to help in the writing of codes for industries of the island.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- The Boerse continued to weaken today under a growing wave of liquidation. A trade conflict with France and the American currency plans were elements of uncertainty, while the new labor code, in the words of one financial commentator, "made a strong impression but was unable to counteract the decline."

LONDON, Jan. 17, -- Despite further official sales of the dollar against purchases of gold in London -- effected at the London, not the higher American, price of the metal -- the dollar has not yet been reduced to the maximum future value of 60 per cent which President Roosevelt prescribed.

The plan for readjustment of debt and capitalization of Rudolph Karstadt, Inc., has been declared operative, according to announcement by the bondholders' protective committee headed by Robert O. Hayward of Dillon, Read Co. More than $10,600,000 of the $13,793,000 outstanding first-mortgage collateral 6 per cent bonds originally sold here have been deposited under the plan.
Chafing under the prospect of delay in the passage of his economy bill by the Legislature, Mayor LaGuardia declared yesterday that the city's transit unification program was being seriously impaired.

Activity in the business leasing field continued yesterday, with reports of rentals by liquor merchants and garment firms in the midtown area and by various companies in the downtown financial district. The lessees included the following:

The stroke of a pen in a local hotel yesterday solved Dartmouth's football coaching problem, created new ones at West Point and Pittsburgh and struck one of the most prominent names from the list of men said to have been under consideration for the gridiron portfolio at Yale.

Except for a little activity in the time money market in which small amounts were done in 60 days' at 1 per cent, and 90 days at 1 1/4, there was very little doing in other sections of the market. Quotations in all instances were unchanged from Tuesday.

With speculators impatiently realizing profits, the share market had somewhat difficult sledding yesterday, but it managed to show slight progress. The composite index of averages recorded a net gain of about 10 cents after the market had lost part of an early advance.

Great South Bay boat captains yesterday placed themselves on record as, favoring regulation of salt water fishing. Their move promises to precipitate a three-cornered struggle among commercial fishermen, sportsmen-anglers and party boat captains.

In the Wynekoop murder trial at Chicago, our special correspondent stated yesterday, the first policeman to view the body was testifying. The prosecutor asked the witness where he had seen the pistol:

A luncheon was given at the Weylin yesterday by Miss Lillian !I-Iart to celebrate the birthday of Srs. Samuel Greer. The other guests were Mrs. Edwin Du Bots, Mrs. Dwight-Austin, ]srs. Abbott iI-Iutchinson, lSrs. Edward Koem;peI, Mrs. Graham IcDougall, Mrs. Charles Cutterill and Miss Dolly de Rulhac.

The fourth Festival Carnival for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund took place last night in Madison Square Garden before a large and apparently much-pleased audience, who applauded soloists, chorus, orchestra, conductor and the especially invited guests.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- The Straus West African Expedition of the Field Museum left Chicago this morning for New York whence it will sail on Jan. 25 for a seven months' tour, covering 4,000 miles by automobile and motor truck.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Attorney General Cummings laid before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today an opinion holding constitutional in every respect the President's plan for the Treasury to impound gold held by the Federal Reserve Banks.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17. -- The elimination of Celeste A. Durand of Garden City, L.I., provided the major upset of the second round of match play for the midwinter amateur golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- While the administration was seeking today to compose its differences with Controller General McCarl over the question of the legality of Federal Housing Corporation expenditures, Mr. McCarl made public his letter to Secretary Ickes disclosing disagreement with the government as to the corporation method of carrying out the recovery program.
" I Am Suzanne," with Lilian Harvey, Gene Raymond and Leslie Banks, will open at the Radio City Music Hall today.
Walter Spence of the New York A.C. won the 100-yard senior Metropolitan A.A.U. free style championship swim, feature event of the aquatic carnival held last night in the New York A.C. pool.

Speculative operations for the advance were conducted yesterday with almost as much aggressiveness as on the two preceding days, but possibly with a little less confidence. Stocks advanced hesitantly, bonds were heavy at the outset and then strong, while several of he agricultural commodities declined.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The Johnson bill to bar future flotation in the United States of securities of any nation now in default to this country received support today from Senator Robinson, Democratic leader. He said he favored its general purpose, but with amendments intended to protect holders of bonds issued before the bill's passage in cases where scrip or other new obligations are issued.
The Princeton Club No. 1 team in Group 1 and the Squash Club players in Group 2 again emerged victorious yesterday in the New York Class C Division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 17. -- Letters of administration on the estate of William K. Vanderbilt Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., who was killed last Nov. 15 in an automobile accident at Ridgeland, S.C., were issued by Surrogate Leone D. Howell here today to the father, William K. Vanderbilt of Northport, L.I. Vanderbilt Jr. was killed when the automobile in which he was riding crashed into a parked truck on the State road.

David Lamar, the "Wolf of Wall Street," who made and squandered millions, was buried yesterday. Three men, who twenty years ago as headwaiters of famous cafes were tipped handsomely for giving Mr. Lamar the best service, paid for the funeral.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 17. -- Arab demonstrations throughout Palestine in protest against Jewish immigration and the sale of land to Jews passed off peacefully today. All the processions followed the routes and procedure previously prescribed by the government.

Stockholders of the Irving Trust Company, at their annual meeting yesterday, received from Harry E. Ward, president, the most comprehensive report of the earnings, operations and policies of the bank ever made. The report was supplemented by Mr. Ward and Lewis E. Pierson, chairman, in answers to questions by shareholders. The meeting was enlivened by a debate among shareholders and the management upon deposit insurance, the Irving's receivership department and the Better Business Bureau.

BOSTON, Jan. 17. -- Two Harvard hockey teams triumphed in the Boston Garden today. The Crimson freshmen conquered Exeter, 3 to 1, on two last-minute goals, and the junior varsity overpowered Andover, 7 to 1.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- An early dip of about 3/4 cent in the May delivery of wheat today on the Board of Trade was followed by a rally of 2 cents, which carried the near-by position to within 1/4 cent of Monday's best level. Trading, however, was not large and the market was rather easily influenced at times.
BERLIN, Jan. 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Having established himself along Broadway as the co-author of "Sailor, Beware!" Charles Robinson is formally completing his admission requirements. "Mahogany Hall," which had a stately production at the Bijou last evening, should admit him to the freshman class, though not without a few conditions.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- A bill, approved by Governor Lehman, creating a commission to prepare a new charter for the City of New York, will have its first reading in both branches of the Legislature tomorrow.

Edward Lee, defending champion, and J. Howard Shoemaker scored their second victories yesterday in the national amateur three-cushion billiard championship tournament at the Capitol Academy and are tied for the lead in the competition.

Miss Henrietta Additon, head of the Crime Prevention Bureau, asserted yesterday at a luncheon in behalf of the New York Council of the Girls Service League at its clubhouse, 138 East Nineteenth Street, that the bureau was becoming more effective each year and "will more than repay the city for any expenditure it may make."

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for this afternoon's special performance of "Die Meistersinger von Nurnberg" at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over by members of the New York chapter of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance to raise funds for its philanthropies.

The development of Muscle Shoals, Boulder Canyon, the Columbia and St. Lawrence Rivers as "primary sources of power in a nationally interconnected power system," of which one of the large customers would be a "nationally unified, noncompetitive railroad system, electrically operated" and giving "the lowest transportation cost in history," was pictured yesterday before the eighty-first annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 17. -- Overnight 21-year-old Rose Marie Brancato has stepped to the threshold of her fondest dreams. The prayer of her father, Marion Brancato, who died with the words "Rose Marie, my little singer" on his lips, has been answered. Her widowed mother, who fought the singing "because it takes my baby away from me," is overjoyed at her success.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUSDON, N.Y., Jan. 17. -- The Philadelphia contingent in the sixth annual invitation women's squash racquets tournament, which got under way on the courts of the Racquet and Swimming Club, gained three places in the quarter-final round at the completion of today's play.
A pamphlet issued by the joint committee of teachers' organizations reached me the other day. The campaign outlined for 1934 for the protection of teachers' salaries is interesting.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17. -Yale ran roughshod over Williams at basketball in the Yale gymnasium tonight, winning by 46 -- 23. The score at half-time stood 21 -- 7 in Yale's favor.

The New York Banks Glee Club, an organization of sixty "singing bankers," opened a fifty-fifth season at Carnegie Hall last evening. There was a friendly audience, as always there has been, to greet the infrequent public performance of the excellent male chorus and its conductor, Bruno Huhn.

The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board is expected to begin next week drawing up recommendations for permanent legislation for liquor control, Chairman Edward P. Mulrooney said yesterday on his return from a trip to confer with boards at Buffalo and Albany.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- The favorable turn in the negotiations for sale of the Chinese Eastern Railway by Russia to Manchukuo has aroused keen interest in Paris, for it is still maintained that French interests hold the legal right to that Manchurian railroad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Mrs. Roosevelt attended Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's musicale at the Mayflower this morning, entertaining with a box party for wives of Cabinet members, including Mrs. Swanson, Mrs. Farley and Mrs. Wallace, to hear Miss Eide Norena, Norwegian soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association; Rene LeRoy, flutist, who has been a guest at the White House for several days; Sheridan Russel, violinist, and Pierre Jamet, harpist.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler sat in a round-table conference yesterday with twenty-five attorneys holding various views on the method of solving the guaranteed mortgage problem to aid the holders of certificates sold by fourteen companies now in the hands of George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, for rehabilitation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP). -Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight denounced war as "utter futility" and "deadly stupidity" in an address at the conference on the cause and cure of war.

Herbert Meyer, whose exhibition of paintings will remain at the Macbeth Galleries until Jan. 29, has developed notable skill in the handling of complex landscape patterns. A canvas called "The Hunters" illustrates both Mr. Meyer's interest in such patterns and his capacity to bring them to a successful conclusion.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17. -- Adam Walsh was urged upon the Yale athletic board of control for head football coach in a communication to The Yale Daily News from a senior today. The writer said that results will be painful if either Reggie Root or Harry Kipke of Michigan is appointed. He added:

The withdrawal of homeless men from municipal lodging houses and their transfer to work camp, the elimination of categorical divisions in welfare work and the establishment of an information service for the needy and unemployed were three of the reforms that William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, said last night he would attempt to effect during his administration.

For the benefit of the eighty-six rookie firemen of the Fire College of the department, in East Sixty-eighth Street and also for news and movie photographers Rescue Squad No. 1 staged a demonstration yesterday of the use of smoke masks, the rescue of a supposedly overcome man and methods of artificial respiration.

LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP). -- Eight of the nine ties in the third round of the competition for the English Association soccer cup were decided in replays today. The victors were Aston Villa, Bury, Derby County, Liverpool, Huddersfield, Sunderland, Portsmouth and Chelsea.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- Marc Catton of Oakland, Calif., upset one of the two leaders in the national three-cushion billiard championship tournament tonight by handing Len Kenney of Chicago his first defeat of the tournament, 50 to 32, in sixty-three innings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Doubts whether France would fulfill her promise to import 200,000 quintals of American apples and pears in return for a doubled liquor quota were ended today by a communication sent to the State Department by the French Embassy.

The gambling clean-up campaign of the new police administration received a setback yesterday when Magistrate Frank Giorgio ruled in Ridgewood court, Queens, that one of the types of machines which is engaging police attention is not a gambling device but a game of skill.

While the program of "dollar devaluation" by arbitrary action is hard to defend, it is necessary to dispel certain erroneous ideas, more or less widely entertained, regarding the concrete effects of a devaluation law. Two statements published yesterday, both from responsible quarters, were so worded as apparently to justify alarming inferences.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 17. -The Princeton hockey team defeated Williams by 6 -- 1 in the Baker Rink tonight. The Tigers outplayed the Purple team, which has been hampered by lack of practice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- President Roosevelt's decision on codes for the construction industry will have a direct bearing upon the wages of several million skilled mechanics, it was understood today when building trade circles learned of an important White House conference last night at which the codes were discussed.

At the age of 76, with an outlook as "blackly pessimistic" as ever, Clarence Darrow, noted trial lawyer and agnostic, nevertheless finds it "rather interesting" to be alive, he told interviewers yesterday. Mr. Darrow, who is here to meet John Haynes Holmes tomorrow night at Mecca Temple, in a debate on the subject, "Can Civilization Be Saved," is visiting at the home of a friend.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- Austrians residing or traveling in Germany were summarily ordered today to report to the German police by Saturday for identification and renewed registration. The order was issued by the chief of the secret political police.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The widespread activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in November called for advances and authorizations totaling $515,813,582.41, according to the monthly report submitted to Congress today.

Protesting the interest payments recently authorized by the courts on Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway general mortgage bonds of 1988, Evans, Stillman Co., dealers in equipment trust certificates, announced yesterday that they were investigating the road's accounts to determine whether sums were not available for payments on certificates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Ralph Pulitzer of New York, former president of the Press Publishing Company, publisher of The New York World, has been appointed deputy administrator in charge of the newspaper and graphic arts codes, it was announced today by General Johnson.

In search of giant lizards, wild dogs, hairy-eared rhinoceroses and other strange creatures of the South Seas, the 500-ton steam yacht Southwind will sail on a 30,000-mile cruise next week, Commander George M. Dyott, explorer and traveler, announced yesterday.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 17. -- Arthur F. Mullen, Democratic committee-man for Nebraska and a practicing attorney in Washington, said tonight at his home here that he had no intention of resigning from the committee because of his law practice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Speedy action by Congress on President Roosevelt's proposal that $1,116,000,000 be allowed for emergency activities appeared necessary today to maintain the administration's announced policy of seeing that no one goes cold or hungry this Winter.

The approbation given by legitimate business interests and the general public to the NRA policies for eliminating unfair competition due to child labor, sweatshop and price-cutting tactics which all acted so powerfully to destroy legitimate business, evidences the fact that great reforms can take place rapidly where sentiment is united for the purpose.

The bankers' code of fair competition, recently proposed, was denounced yesterday by Percy H. Johnston, president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, at the annual meeting of shareholders of the bank.

MONACO, Jan. 17. -- The failure of Prince Louis and the royal family of Monaco to return to the principality for the celebration of the national festival today has given rise to rumors that the ruler intends to resign.

Hatless and smiling, Primo Carnera returned on the Conte Di Savoia of the Italian Line from his native Italy yesterday for what he hopes will be two battles in defense of his world's heavyweight championship in America. One of these battles is almost at hand.

At its first meeting yesterday the new Fusion Sinking Fund Commission ordered an investigation of the franchise and lease for the operation of the ferry between Sixty-ninth Street, Bay Ridge, and Staten Island. The Brooklyn and Richmond Ferry Company, Inc., of 17 Battery Place, received the award from the Sinking Fund Commission on Dec. 27, just before the O'Brien administration left office.

Federal Judge William Bondy, ] after hearing charges of prejudice] made by attorneys for three groups] of creditors and stockholders, with-I drew yesterday from considerationI of requests for allowances made by1 tl.e receivers for the Paramount/ Publix Corporation.

The President's new monetary policies will bring no important rise in prices nor increase in industrial activity, according to Dr. O.M.W. Sprague, who resigned several weeks ago as financial adviser to the Treasury. He spoke yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor by Fiduciary Counsel, Inc., at the Bankers Club and attended by many bankers and other financial authorities.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 17. -Army defeated Providence College at basketball today, 35 to 29. The cadets took an early lead which they never relinquished, the first half ending 14 to 8 in Army's favor.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 17. -Dartmouth responded enthusiastically tonight to news of the "new deal," which brings Red Blaik from the Army to guide the sagging football destinies of the Green for the next two years at least.

Cuban exiles in New York were delighted with last night's news that Colonel Carlos Mendieta would succeed to the Presidency today. It was considered probable that he would receive support from all factions except the extreme radicals. This would make it likely that his government would win prompt recognition from the United States, which is needed to solve the Cuban economic crisis, especially in the sugar industry.

Both the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and its largest subsidiary, the Alton, improved their position in 1933, statements issued yesterday show. The B. O., which reported a net income of $525,608 for the first eleven months, will show a comparable result for the full year, according to Daniel Willard, president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission and State regulatory bodies today threw the weight of their influence behind the Rayburn Bill to bring interstate bus and truck operations under Federal control. Hearings on the measure were begun before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

Bond brokers and investors have shown a marked tendency recently to place more of their bond business on the New York Stock Exchange rather than on the over-the-counter bond market, F. Kingsley Rodewald, president of the Bond Brokers Association, said yesterday.

President ROOSEVELT was asked by the correspondents yesterday to comment upon what many think is getting to be a party scandal in Washington. It seems that a number of prominent Democratic politicians have suddenly discovered that they possess great legal ability and have opened offices at the capital for the practice of the law there.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 17. -- A pure white flawless diamond, weighing 726 carats, the fourth largest ever discovered, has been found by J.J. Jonker, a poor prospector, at Elandsfontein, three miles from where the Cullinan diamond was discovered in 1905.

A gain of about 24 per cent in net assets was made by the Tri-Continental Corporation in 1933, while two of its principal subsidiaries, Selected Industries, Inc., and the Capital Administration Company, gained 20 and 9 per cent respectively, according to the annual reports mailed yesterday.

As an indication that the New York Giants are not likely to experience any more trouble this Spring in bringing their athletes into the fold than they did a year ago, even though their estate rose in the interval from the second division to the world's championship, Secretary Jim Tierney announced yesterday that the first signed contract to be received for 1934 was from their No. 1 per former.

GENEVA, Jan. 17. -- The serious situation in the Saar Basin Territory, where next year the people must vote under the auspices of the League of Nations whether they will return to German jurisdiction, accept the sovereignty of France or remain under the jurisdiction of the League, has been brought before the League Council, now meeting here, in terms which may well provide a prelude to strong action to insure fair dealing in the plebiscite.
ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- Following is the text of the bill creating g commission to prepare a new charter for New York City:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17. -Yale and the Boston Olympic Club battled to a 5-to-5 hockey tie tonight after two overtime periods in the New Haven Arena before 800 spectators.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan reserved decision and promised a prompt ruling yesterday in the suit by the Triborough Bridge Authority for an injunction restraining the city of New York from interfering with the Authority in conducting its affairs.

The regulations in effect postponing indefinitely the deadline for the return of gold brought relief to many confused persons here who had apparently realized only at the last minute yesterday that they faced the prospect of losing the value of their gold and possible additional penalties under the midnight limit.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan, 17. -The Massachusetts Institute of Technology defeated the Harvard basketball team at the new Harvard gymnasium tonight, 32 to 28. The game was an interesting and closely contested encounter from start to finish.

GENEVA, Jan. 17. -- In a note to the League of Nations published today the Dutch Government "sees no necessity of modifying the covenant, which, in its opinion, offers ample possibility of achieving the League's objects, provided its members are actuated by a spirit of collaboration."

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- A minimum of testimony was spread between heated words of argument today as Judge David and defense counsel differed on court ethics and on the admissibility of bits of evidence at the trial of Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop for the murder of Rheta G. Wynekoop, her daughter-in-law.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (AP). -- How Princes David and Serge Mdivani built a small oil empire, voting themselves salaries and bonuses, only to see it collapse, was recounted in Superior Court here today by Miss Rose K. Adler.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Fred B. Rentschler, brother of Gordon S. Rentschler, president of the National City Bank of New York, made a paper profit in 1929 of $35,575,848 out of a $253 investment in airline stocks, and actually sold 159,604 shares at $9,514,000, he testified at the Senate hearing on air mail contracts today.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- The drive to end the virtual monopoly of the Irving Trust Company as Federal receiver in bankruptcy cases was renewed today in the Legislature. Three bills were introduced by Senator McNaboe of New York, which if enacted into law would prohibit the Irving Trust from acting as receiver or trustee in bankruptcy either in Federal or State courts.

Fabrics and colors were featured at the Spring fashion show given last night by the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania. More than 1,000 persons, including retailers, many from out of town, wholesalers and stylists viewed the selection of Spring styles for every occasion.

Earnings of the Empire Trust Company in 1933 amounted to $510,650, Leroy W. Baldwin, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday. This equaled $1.70 a share on the capital stock, on which dividend requirements are $1 a year.
HAVANA, Thursday, Jan. 18. -- President Carlos Hevia, who took office Monday, resigned at 1:20 A.M. today, delivering the Presidency to the revolutionary junta.

Mayor LaGuardia indicated yesterday that his policy in reference to the construction of the new Triborough Bridge, whereby he will attempt to have as many contracts as possible awarded to New York City concerns, would be applied in a like manner to all city contracts and purchases of supplies.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens dismissed yesterday two CWA labor supervisors attached to the Queens Highway Bureau on charges of payroll padding and other irregularities. Two laborers were suspended in connection with the matter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The rivalry between two House committees over the privilege of introducing President Roosevelt's gold program developed late today into open warfare.

The defeat of the Curry forces in the Board of Aldermen on Tuesday lent encouragement yesterday to the leaders of the movement for a new deal in the Democratic party in this city. Members of the anti-Curry faction expressed the belief that Mr. Curry's influence was now limited to Manhattan, and that the next step in reorganizing the party was to end his influence there.

Still ignorant of the precise nature of the neutron, physicists already see its possibilities both in battering the atom to pieces and in competing with the X-rays as a therapeutic agent. Unlike the positron, the electron and the proton, the neutron is electrically dead. For this reason it has penetrating powers possessed by no other material particle.

The city, which was named as a defendant in the suit brought by the Citizens Budget Commission to restrain the payment of a pension to former Magistrate Francis X. McQuade, who resigned under fire, will join forces with the plaintiff when the case is argued before the Appellate Division this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Million-dollar net personal incomes, which numbered 513 in 1929, dropped to twenty in 1932, the Internal Revenue Bureau reported today.

The people of the City and State of New York should not let this year pass without special recognition of one to whom they owe what came to be known as the "Charter of Liberties" -- Governor THOMAS DONGAN. He was born 300 years ago, though the month and day of his birth are not precisely known.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP). -- The question of how liquid the stock market should be was disclosed tonight to be the basic point in the report of the Commerce Department stock market committee in considering how extensively and rigidly the market should be regulated.

KEARNY, N.J., Jan. 17. -- Five Japanese, detained yesterday when they were discovered taking pictures from the Pulaski Skyway, were freed this afternoon by the police of this town. The men had seven cameras.

The suggestion that the New York Stock Exchange make public the data that it receives at noon each Friday, concerning pool operations in which its members are involved or of which they have knowledge, is being made by partners in several Stock Exchange firms.

The growing tendency among American artists to cooperate more with their fellow artists was described as a hopeful sign in the profession last night by John Robert Gregg, president of the National Arts Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Tokyo alms to set up a political and economic bloc composed of China, Japan and Manchukuo, constituting "a far-reaching bid for complete Japanese hegemony in the Far East," according to a report on "The New Status in the Pacific," published today by the Foreign Policy Association and written by T.A. Bisson.

To say that Walter Gieseking, pianist, playing last night in Town Hall, displayed his wonted mastery and individuality of style is not to say a new thing. But Mr. Gieseking's performances are such a blend of style and feeling, intellectuality and emotion, that they have the effect of a fresh experience of beauty.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 17. -- John D. Mikel's Gaillardia, a recent arrival from Texas, scored his second victory within a week when he won the featured Happy Hollow Purse at the Agua Caliente track today. The 6-year-old gelding clipped two-fifths of a second off the track record for the seven furlongs.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 17. -- The primary fight which Republican county chairmen hoped to avert by inviting former Ambassador Walter E. Edge to become the Gubernatorial candidate is apparently assured, according to developments throughout the State today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17. -- Reversing a previous ultimatum that the 1933-34 athletic budget must balance, President J.B. Conant has authorized the committee on the regulation of athletic sports to operate under a miximum deficit of about $30,000 for the fiscal year ending June, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The administration moved today to force recalcitrant farmers into the production-control program of the AAA ruling that government crop by loans would be made only to growers who agree not to expand production.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Tammany politicians are deeply involved in the policy and slot-machine rackets, which have taken a yearly toll of millions from the poor and from the children of New York City, according to the annual report of the Society for the Prevention of Crime.
Professor Albert Einstein dropped his mantle of world scientist for a few hours last night to become simply a gentleman musician, playing to entertain his friends.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Resolutions urging President Roosevelt to "advise Congress of the importance" of amending the criminal code to permit dissemination of birth control information were adopted today by the Conference on Birth Control and National Recovery and taken to the White House by a group of delegates.
ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- Creation of a State Planning Board to formulate a wide program for social and economic betterment in the State was announced tonight by Governor Lehman.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 17. -- The Yale swimming team defeated Wesleyan by 45 to 32 tonight. The winners scored six firsts in the meet besides setting two new national intercollegiate records.

The production management of "The Lake," current attraction at the Martin Beck Theatre, was found guilty yesterday of violating the regulations of the legitimate theatre code pertaining to the sale and distribution of tickets by the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority, meeting in the Paramount Building.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 17 (AP). -- Asserting that it is the evident intention of the Federal Government to compel all State banks to liquidate or become national institutions, State Senator Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic City today said that he considered the creation of a State central reserve bank to be a necessity.

Accessories are beginning to figure more prominently in the Spring buying by retailers here. Blouses are outstanding, and one of the best seasons in years is predicted in this merchandise. The call for handbags has also increased steadily, with the indications being that leather types featuring monogram ornaments will be notably active.

Futures prices sagged yesterday all along the line on local commodity markets. The volume of trading in several of the markets, however, showed a distinct improvement, and at the close, in most cases, the losses had been reduced to relatively small ones. Cash prices were irregular.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Door-to-door pressure to force payment of Federal income taxes was suggested by Secretary Morgenthau today in setting a $200,000,000 goal for back-tax collections this year.

After negotiations lasting for two years the merger between the White Star and Cunard steamship lines is now in effect. Since Jan. 1 the accounts of the two companies, afloat and ashore, have been one.

ONE by one the American rich -- Rockefeller, Morgan, Carnegie -- sit to John K. Winkler for their portraits. This time it is the elder James Stillman of the National City Bank. Mr. Winkler quite frankly doesn't like him, and the portrait stares out at us with cold eyes from "The First Billion: The Stillmans ant the National City Bank" (Vanguard, $2.50).

The Constitution of the United States, Article I, Section 8, Paragraph 5, reads: "[The Congress shall have power] To coin money, regulate the value thereof, and of foreign coin, and fix the standard of weights and measures." Under this provision the President, by delegation of power from the Congress, is attempting a comprehensive scheme.

A central clearing house for local enforcement of permanent codes to promote fairness and efficiency in the operation of the code system was advocated yesterday by Harry Van Horn, president of the National Association of Better Business Bureaus, at the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP). -- The question of Philippine independence, presumably disposed of a year ago today with passage of the Hawes-Cutting Bill granting the islands independence within twelve to fifteen years, was returned to Washington tonight.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- The British pound continued its downward flight in the exchange market today, while the dollar resisted, gaining 7 centimes to close at 15.73 francs. The pound, at 80 francs against 80.45 yesterday, touched the lowest level since Nov. 4.

A collection of original papers of the American Revolution, including two letters signed by General Israel Putnam, letters by General Silliman and others, muster rolls, , brought $725 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of historical Americana from the libraries of Edmund A. Funke, Dr. William Sturgis Thomas and others.
The permanent administration of the NRA in New York was started yesterday with Nathan Straus Jr. assuming control as State director of the National Emergency Council.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx announced yesterday acceptance of a $47,000 bid to supply the wooden equipment for the new Bronx County Building, 161st Street and Mott Avenue. This includes chairs, desks, tables and settees for judges' chambers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- President Roosevelt joined Philadelphia today in observing the 228th anniversary of Benjamin Franklin's birth. In a letter to H.H. Kynett, president of the Poor Richard Club, the President sent a message which was read at services held in old Christ Church, where both Franklin and George Washington once worshiped.

The permanent plan of Federal insurance of bank deposits is unsound and "charged with grave possibilities of injury to the entire American banking system," William C. Potter, head of the Guaranty Trust Company told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting.

An appreciation of about 62 per cent in the net value of assets, the largest so far reported by a major investment trust company, is disclosed in the annual report of the Adams Express Company for 1933. The value of net assets on Dec. 31 was equivalent to $2,744 for each $1,000 of collateral-trust bonds, and, after deducting these and preferred stock at par values, to $6.40 a share for common stock.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17. -- Aunt Flor, owned by the Middleburg stable of Mrs. William Ziegler Jr., was a 19-to-1-shot winner of the featured Fort Lauderdale Purse at Tropical Park today. The daughter of Our General and Quick Batter scored by half a length and paid $40.90 for $2.

The relative merits of the five-day and six-day weeks in the operation of department stores and other retail establishments under the retail code had a prominent part in discussions at the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at he Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Immediately after President Roosevelt had vigorously expressed the opinion today that no holder of a high political office should practice law here, Robert Jackson announced his resignation as secretary of the Democratic National Committee.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 17. -- Shooting one of his greatest competitive rounds, Harold McSpaden of the Quivera Lake Golf Club, Kansas City, Kan., turned in an individual card of 62 in the Santa Monica amateur-pro championship today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The St. Lawrence Waterway treaty received attention today for a time in both Congressional chambers.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17. -- W. Black's 5-year-old daughter of Epinard, Ep, scored by two lengths in the featured fifth race at Jefferson Park today. Mrs. Lawrence A. Daly's By Product was second and J. Burks's Flying Cadet third.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, continuing its investigation of the Michigan bank collapse, disclosed today records of loans and other liabilities of directors and officers of the Union Guardian Trust Company totaling more than $2,477,000, most of them long standing and a very substantial part of them still carried on the books of the company.

The New York Athletic Club Class A squash tennis team last night took sole possession of first place in the Metropolitan League by defeating the Princeton Club, 4 to 1, on the latter's courts. The Winged Foot players now have won 7 and lost 1. Their victory dropped Columbia, which drew a bye, into second place.

The pamphlet report of the American Superpower Corporation for 1933 shows a liquidating value of $26.31 a share for 235,207 shares of $6 no-par preference stock after allowing $100 a share for 312,819 shares of first preferred $6 dividend stock of no-par value.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- Responding to the Keynote sounded by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, Sunday for a campaign to popularize the new Nazi labor code, which puts German labor in the keeping of the employers and the State, the Nazi press and Nazi speakers continue to train their guns on "brazen reaction."

J. Seward Johnson is considering taking his new 6-meter racing sloop to Sweden to race for the Scandinavian Gold Cup, it was learned yesterday. The cup has been challenged for by the North American Yacht Racing Union.

ABOARD THE OIL TANKER GULFLAND, Jan. 17, 8:02 P.M. -- At 12 noon, we sighted the yacht Alamyth showing distress signals. Went alongside and found the yacht in a sinking condition. This was in Latitude 39:12 N., Longitude 72:26 W.

Net income of the National Biscuit Company for the year ended Dec. 31 amounted to $14,995,304 after depreciation, Federal taxes and all other charges.
