This was equivalent, after the deduction of preferred dividend requirements, to $2.11 a share on the 6,289,263 shares of common stock, and compares with a net profit of $17,104,124, or $2.44 a common share in the preceding year.
Arthur Krock's article in THE TIMES of Jan. 6 closes with the sentiment, "The moral of these citations and reflections is: Cheer up." May I contribute an additional reflection?

In one of the biggest upsets of the basketball season the Columbia quintet vanquished the highly favored Princeton team by 36 to 29 in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game in the Lion gymnasium last night.

THERE was some mention of a 400 Set in hockey and, with that recent picture of the Toronto Maple Leaf regulars in high hats and swallowtail coats, the fear in this corner was that the rough-and-ready, slam-bang game might be softening up. A visit to M'sieu Lestairre Patrick, the old trapper of the frozen ponds, brought relief from that fear.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Jan. 18. -- Eugene Chen, former Foreign Minister, and nearly all the other leaders of the Fukien rebellion arrived today in Hongkong on a steamer with several military officers and many other refugees.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- A secret mission to London made recently by a member of President Roosevelt's "brain trust" was reported here today as the basis of an informal currency agreement which may hold the British pound around a 5-to-1 ratio with the dollar.

Ridicule on stage and screen and in the press of lawyers and magistrates is conducive to public disrespect for the law and its administrators, The New York Law Journal asserts in a leading editorial in its issue of yesterday.

The commercial relations of the United States and Colombia were declared last night to have been greatly improved by the recent commercial treaty signed by representatives of the two countries, in an address by Roberto Escobar, Acting Consul General of Colombia, before the Foreign Commerce Club of New York.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, en Route to Little America, Jan. 16. -- The flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition was 150 miles north of Little America at 4 o'clock this afternoon. Under a fine metallic sky she was making seven knots against a smart southerly breeze.

Devised by the Nazi regime in Berlin, the new German code for labor is naturally wrapped up in many fine phrases. It is to embody the new sense of "social honor" as well as national solidarity. Both workers and employers are to consider themselves merely parts of the grand Hitlerite State.
The police were called out yesterday to disperse a resentful crowd of CWA workers at 139th Street and Convent Avenue as they swarmed about an entrance of City College.

Frances Renard, whose real name is Frances Fox, and who is the sister of Fontaine Fox, has written a novel about Kentucky which Stokes will publish next month. Miss Fox was born and brought up in Gap-in-the-Nobs, Ky., the scene of the book.

Tammany's opposition to the City Economy Act is easy to understand. For sixteen years the organization has ignored the maxims of frugality. A liberal spending policy gilds the lily of prosperity for the boys on the payroll, while in times of adversity the crude edifice of local government affords many a hidden refuge for the victims of the storm.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved yesterday over a wider range than usual, and after frequent irregular fluctuations ended with losses of 7 to 12 points.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The Garment Manufacturers Association, Inc., of 521 Fifth Avenue, New York City, and several independent garment manufacturers appealed today to the District of Columbia Supreme Court for an injunction to restrain enforcement of the provisions of the Coat and Suit Code against them and challenged the constitutionality of the National Recovery Act.

David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, was elected a director of the Metropolitan Opera Association, Inc., and the Metropolitan Opera Company at a directors' meeting held yesterday at the Broad Street Club', 15 Broad Street.

Following early irregularity, the bond market on the Stock Exchange rallied and closed strong, particularly the domestic corporation issues. Most of the long-term United States Government closed with gains, the group closing 6-32 point higher to 2-32 lower, while leading foreign loans moved irregularly lower.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Prime Minister MacDonald held his own in addressing his constituents at Seaham Harbour tonight in vigorous defense of the National Government's record for the past two years. He claimed it had carried out its promise to devote all its energies to a concerted effort to lay the foundations for financial security and industrial improvement.

The city of Reading, Pa., awarded yesterday $1,850,000 of water bonds dated Jan. 15, 1934, and due serially from 1940 to 1954. Award of $1,335,000 of the bonds, due from 1944 to 1954, was made to a syndicate comprising Graham, Parsons Co., Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc; Yarnall Co., of Philadelphia; Singer, Deane Scribner, Inc., of Pittsburgh; Dougherty, Corcoran Co., and E.H. Rollins Sons.

Less than 25 per cent of the liquor dealers in the First Internal Revenue District of New York comprising all of Long Island and Staten Island who have been licensed by the State have complied with the United States Internal Revenue laws which require the payment of a Federal liquor tax.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Attorney General Cummings's opinion on the constitutionality of the President's proposed gold legislation, as made public by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today, was as follows:

The establishment of a Federal Mortgage Bank of Discount as an important factor in the rehabilitation of real estate throughout the country will be urged at the annual business meeting of the National Association of Real Estate Boards now in session at Coral Gables, Fla.

The tendency of local law enforcement and prosecuting agencies to allow Federal detection agencies and Federal District Attorneys to shoulder the responsibilities of States and municipalities was deplored yesterday by Federal Judge Frank J. Coleman, United States Attorney Martin Conboy and George Z. Medalie, former United States Attorney.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- Voluntary sterilization of the unfit, subject to certain safeguards, is recommended for legalization in Great Britain by the report of a departmental committee on sterilization issued tonight. The committee, whose report is unanimous, rejects any suggestion of a compulsory measure.

Under the joint auspices of the Masters of Foxhounds Association and the National Beagle Club, the annual hound show will be held today at the Riding Club, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street. It is for the benefit of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

Gross irregularities and defects in the construction of the city's new $12,000,000 prison on Rikers Island, such as cracked walls, sinking foundations and improper plumbing, as reported by Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard, caused Controller W. Arthur Cunningham to hold up last night all payments to contractors.

The twentieth American Game Conference will start at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Monday morning. Delegates already are assembling here and before the first session is called at 9:30 o'clock there will be many informal conferences among conservation leaders of the country who will attend the convention.

Cyrena Van Gordon, mezzo-soprano, and Carlo Del Corso, tenor, made their first appearance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Miss Van Gordon was the Amneris in a performance of "Aida" and Mr. Del Corso the Radames.

In Harrisburg yesterday Senator REED made the first speech of his campaign for a third term. He said that he "admired President ROOSEVELT'S bravery," though he has assailed many of his policies. In the circumstances, Mr. REED'S bravery may be admired even by those, including a great number of Republicans, who are disgusted with his mustering of some twenty Republican Senators to overthrow Mr. ROOSEVELT'S wise and just economies in the matter of veterans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Following is the text of the statement made today by Secretary Morgenthau before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The question of veterans' compensation, which has been a major issue in every Congressional session since the World War and reached proportions last Spring that threatened to wreck the recovery program, arose today as a problem for this session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- A story of the travels back and forth between Detroit and New York of 30,000 shares of Union Commerce Investment Company (Detroit) stock was told to the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP). -- Formally reporting approval of the administration's money measure, the House Coinage Committee said today that Great Britain forced the United States off the gold standard and the proposed $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund was intended to "prevent a repetition of this experience."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Amendment of the penal laws to permit medically supervised dissemination of birth control information and advice to overburdened parents of "unwarrantably" large families in their own interest and those of the taxpayers who are staggering under the "greatest relief load in history," was urged today on moral, economic and scientific grounds at a crowded hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Foremost in the series of legislative proposals which will be pressed at the present session by the American Federation of Labor are amendments to "vitalize" Section 7-A, the collective bargaining provision, of the Recovery Act and the inauguration of a shorter work-day and work-week. If the shorter work-day and work-week is not obtained by legislation, efforts will be made to have it provided for in the NRA codes.

Colonel MENDIETA'S accession to the Presidency of Cuba is taken both in Havana and in Washington as a marked turn for the better. He had steadily resisted the factions that urged him to become Provisional President. It was his preference to wait until the Constitutional Convention is held in the Spring, and until he might be elected President by a popular vote.

Governor Gifford Pinchot of Pennsylvania, who is at St. Luke's Hospital, ended the long fight of his State to establish a system of old-age pensions yesterday afternoon by signing a bell for that purpose passed by the Pennsylvania Legislature.

MR. TAY PAY GORMAN of Chicago, Ottawa, Agua Caliente and way stations was herding his Chicago Black Hawks toward Madison Square Garden for their hockey date with the Rangers, but he paused to deliver an oration on an agricultural problem.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- With its $400,000,000 fund for emergency re-employment rapidly nearing exhaustion, the Civil Works Administration today placed the 4,000,000 workers now carried on its rolls to a twenty-four-hour week in cities of more than 2,500 population, and fifteen hours a week for smaller communities and rural districts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Figures showing large profits in service fees collected by the Electric Bond and Share Company from associated and affiliated concerns were read into the record of the Federal Trade Commission today by its examiner, Walter Meelen, as the company finally agreed to an examination of its books after a long legal contest.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18. -- An attempt to solve the mysteries of Sargasso Sea is among the objects of an expedition to the Caribbean Sea, sponsored jointly by Yale University and Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, which will depart from Woods Hole next Saturday on the research ship Atlantis.

Moving contrary to the trend a year ago, bank clearings at leading cities throughout the country again made a disappointing showing in the last week, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. For twenty-one cities, clearings aggregated $4,162,182,000, against $4,431,588,000 a year ago, a decline of 6.1 per cent.

Thirty prizes were awarded yesterday by Uncle Robert to winners of his "S.O.S. -- Stay on Sidewalk Safety Essay Contest" in Public School 18 at 501 Courtlandt Avenue, the Bronx. The prize winners, together with principals and teachers of the school, will be the guests of Loew's National Theatre at Bergen Avenue and 119th Street, the Bronx, on Jan. 31.

Dr. Panofsky's appointment was made possible by a group of patrons consisting of Paul Baerwald, George Blumenthal, Leonard A. Cohn, Alfred A. Cook, Mrs. W. Murray Crance, Henry Goldman, William Goldman, Henry Ittleson, Arthur Lehman, Emanuel Libman, Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Mack, Walter W. Naumburg, William C. Osborne, the Rev. W.S. Prunty, Ernst Rosenfeld, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, Lionel F. Straus, Mrs. Lillian Wadsworth, Felix M. Warburg and an anonymous donor.

Joseph E. Sheedy, former executive vice president of the United States Lines, unexpectedly upset a meeting of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York yesterday with an attack on the government's policy of allotting ship lines to private companies and granting contracts for transportation of mails at sea.

NASHVILLE, Jan. 18 (AP). -- Early establishment of ten banks in Tennessee to make loans directly to farmers under the newly organized Production Credit Corporation has been announced by Ernst L. Rice, president of the Federal Lank Bank of Louisville.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 18. -- Two upsets marked the second day's play in the sixth annual invitation women's squash racquets tournament at the Racquet and Swimming Club as the semifinal brackets were filled today.

Increased activity in the commercial paper market, without, however, any alteration in the prevailing discounts, and a few short-term loans arranged at 1@1 1/4 per cent, in the time-money section, represented about all that was done in the day's money market.

So far as this column is able to see, "And Be My Love," which was staged at the Ritz last evening, is a flawless comedy, though dull, Lewis Galantiere and John Houseman have written it according to the convention of drawing-room philandering.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Following is the text of the statement made today by E.R. Black, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, to the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency:

Business rentals reported yesterday were centred in Manhattan's midtown area. Among the lessees was the Manufacturers Aircraft Association, Inc., F.H. Russell, president, which took quarters in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. The association is now in 300 Madison Avenue.

A painting by the French artist Jean Francois Millet, called "The Knitting Lesson," brought $16,000 last night at an auction of paintings of various schools at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

Nathan Straus Jr., because of the pressure of his new duties as State head of the National Emergency Council, has arranged for a leave of absence as president of the Park Association, it was learned yesterday.

With the dollar working higher in terms of all foreign currencies, both gold and non-gold, the domestic security and commodity markets were in some confusion yesterday. Stocks and agricultural products were marked down a little, domestic corporation bonds added to their recent gains and United States Government issues were a trifle easier at times but never seriously unsettled.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 18. -- A temporary restraining order preventing the State from continuing its investigation of the financial affairs and stock sales of the Northwest Bancorporation was issued today by the Federal court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The National Bituminous Coal Industrial Board adopted a tentative draft of plans today for better enforcement of the soft coal code.

Robert Graves, editor and writer, has rewritten one of Charles Dickens's best books, "David Copperfield." With the title of "The Real David Copperfield," this rewrite job, which was received with no great kindness in England, will be published this Spring by Harcourt, Brace.

C. Stanley Mitchell, chairman of the board of the defunct Bank of United States, was accused yesterday of making a secret profit of $170,000 for assisting in the merger of the Central Mercantile Bank, of which he was chairman, with the Bank of United States.

Sales of life insurance have shown a substantial improvement as a result of the NRA and the various farm-relief measures of the government, according to a report by the American Service Bureau, the inspection organization of the American Life Convention. The surveys cover a group of 10,164 buyers of new life insurance.

Two trucks loaded with 627 cases of bonded liquor valued at about $40,000 were hijacked by a gang of at least nine men operating in three automobiles. The truck drivers were held up within a block of each other, blindfolded, driven away in automobiles and released an hour later in the Bronx.

Dr. Joaquin Martinez Saenz and Dr. Juan A. Lliteras, members of the directing cell of the ABC, strongest of the anti-Machado revolutionary societies, announced last night that the ABC was giving approval to the new Mendieta government in Cuba and might actively participate in it.
A business building in Thirtieth Street near Fifth Avenue, and two apartment houses in the Bronx, were among the properties involved in realty transactions reported yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- Promising there would be no reduction in France's armaments while other countries were rearming, Premier Camille Chautemps obtained an almost unanimous vote of confidence this afternoon in the Senate on the government's foreign policy as outlined by Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour on Tuesday and by himself today.

The New York University girls' swimming team had to come from behind to triumph over Savage's mermaids, 30 to 23, in the American Woman's Association clubhouse pool yesterday. Miss Lisa Lindstrom, N.Y.U. captain, was the individual star of the opening meet of the season for the winners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The Roosevelt Administration is watching with particular interest the efforts of Mayor LaGuardia to give New York City a thorough "house-cleaning" and would not approve any action at Albany that would handicap this work.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York bought $4,319,000 of gold abroad on Tuesday and Wednesday under the new regulations which transferred the gold-buying functions to the Reserve Bank instead of the RFC, it was disclosed in the bank's weekly report, issued yesterday.

The annual report of the United Corporation shows total investments with an estimated market value of $188,249,626 on Dec. 31, 1933, based on year-end market prices, comparing with $272,256,212 a year before. The asset value of the 2,489,065 preferred shares was $73.96, against $104.96 a year before, and the asset value of the 14,531,197 common shares, after deducting $50 a share for the preferred stock, was $4.13, against $9.41 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Leaders in the overwhelmingly Democratic House today set the stage for adoption of President Roosevelt's money bill before adjournment Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Informed persons here who have been concerned over the method by which the Treasury will attempt to raise ten billions for the emergency budget are very much interested in a plan that has been proposed.

BERLIN, Jan. 18. -- The Boerse today suffered an almost complete stagnation of business, but there was only a slightly sagging trend and this was considered an indication of fairly good resistance. Most losses were merely fractional, only some of the lignite and potash shares dropping around 2 points.

TULSA, Okla., Jan. 18. -- Harry F. Sinclair, oil operator, and twenty-four other directors and officers of the defunct Exchange Trust Company were charged today with embezzlement of $23,869.93 from the institution.

A plan designed by three Brooklyn civic workers for immediate partial elimination of elevated structures in the Brooklyn Bridge Plaza area in Brooklyn, preparatory to the comprehensive plaza improvement project contemplated for later on, was sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Raymond V. Ingersoll, Borough President of Brooklyn.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18 (AP). -- The cogs in the machinery of the Yale Athletic Association moved more swiftly tonight as the appointment of a football head coach was imminent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the third of the four annual State receptions, entertaining in honor of the Senate and the members of the House of Representatives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Wholesale commodity prices rose 1 percent in the week ended Jan. 13, marking the third consecutive weekly rise, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- A proposed agreement between the American and Canadian newsprint manufacturers, and a code provision that paper shall not be sold for delivery during 1934 at less than a base price of $41 a ton, are among the recommendations made by the code authority of the newsprint industry. A public hearing will he held Feb. 1 before Deputy Administrator W.W. Pickard.

The proposal of a commission of notables to revise the city charter is interesting, and something can no doubt be worked out along the lines indicated by Senator MANDELBAUM and Assemblyman STEIT. Mayor LAGUARDIA agrees with them in principle and is sanguine of the outcome of their efforts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18. -- Hogs were in active demand and 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight higher early today, but part of the upturn on medium weights was lost later after urgent orders had been filled. The top was 10 cents higher at $3.65, while the day's average was 10 cents higher at $3.45.

The far-reaching influence of the housing program which the government has launched and which is now being systematically developed will make itself felt in the very near future. Briefly, the thought underlying the social justice which government today feels itself called upon to stress demands not only a recognition by the great public of a higher interpretation of its own responsibilities and opportunities, but also a call upon industry to serve these aims of society.

MONTREAL, Jan, 18 (AP). -- Three players from the United States marched into the semi-final round of the Canadian covered court tennis championship today with only one Canadian, young Laird Watt of Montreal, left to dispute their way to the title.

Dwight Deere Wiman, in association with Forrest C. Haring, his general manager, and J.H. Del Bondio, company manager for "Champagne, Sec," and "She Loves Me Not," has announced preparations for a production during the Spring of a musical version of "Apron Strings," the comedy by Dorrance Davis which was presented here four seasons ago by Mr. Haring.

The pound sterling broke sharply yesterday to the lowest price since Nov. 8, as the flight of foreign capital from London, set in motion by the announcement of President Roosevelt's stabilization program, gathered momentum.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- The French denunciation of the Franco-German commercial treaty, which will take place tomorrow and did not, as reported from Berlin, occur yesterday, will not close the door definitely to agreement between the two countries, it was stated in official circles here today.

The Eastern Railroad presidents conference decided yesterday to wait until March before considering further action on the proposal to reduce passenger fares in this region from the present basic rate of 3.6 cents a mile. Rates of 2 cents a mile for coaches and 3 cents for Pullmans are universal in the West and quite general in the Southeast.

The name of Alfred E. Smith, one-time idol of Tammany Hall, was booed last night at the annual dinner of the Tammany Hall Speakers Bureau, held in the Hotel Commodore. The dinner, in past years called the party's "victory dinner," turned out to be an occasion for expressions of party loyalty in the face of defeat.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 18. -- Martha Bussing Norris of Hatch Terrace, Dobbs Ferry, who died Aug. 3, 1932, left $22,000 outright to eight charities, and $32,000 additional to charities contingent upon the death of her sister, Sarah A. Bussing of 205 West Fifty-seventh Street, New York, who is to receive the income of the residuary estate for life.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- Pennsylvania's rowing squad -- almost200 strong -- has voiced its preference to forego the intercollegiate regatta at Poughkeepsie this year, if the necessity arose, rather than drop some of the scheduled races of its regular season, it was announced today.

As the ship's bell clangs two bells of the second dog watch today, or at 7 P.M. to those who only are accustomed to salt in their food, the twenty-ninth annual National Motor Boat Show will open in Grand Central Palace for an eight-day run, Sunday excepted.

Thomas W. Mullarkey, a retired police inspector, who disappeared shortly before he was indicted nearly two years ago on a charge of conspiracy to violate the prohibition and internal revenue laws, surrendered yesterday morning to United States Attorney Howard W. Ameli in Brooklyn. Mullarkey was accompanied by his attorney, Sydney Rosenthal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 17, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,658,000,000, a decrease of $7,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $554,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18. -- American universities are taking the financing of athletic sports out of the hands of committees, are soft-pedaling athletic scholarships and are resisting the "commercialization of athletics," the Association of American Colleges was told today.
ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Two bills designed to aid the national drive against unemployment were introduced in the upper house of the Legislature today by Senator Desmond, Republican, of Orange.

HAVANA, Jan. 18. -- Colonel Carlos Mendieta, leader of the rebellion against former President Gerardo Machado in 1931 and head of the Nationalist party, was sworn in as Cuba's new President at 12:30 P.M. today while a wave of joy and enthusiasm swept the island.

The Durieux Chamber Music Ensemble will give its second Twilight Musicale this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock at the Grand Central Art Galleries. The proceeds go to needy artists. Antonia Brico and William Durieux will play works of Brahms and Rachmaninoff.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Senators Glass, Borah and Nye joined in an attack today in the Senate on the NRA codes, declaring that small business men were being driven out of business, while the consumer was mulcted by price-raising and price-fixing provisions.

TORONTO, Jan. 18 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs routed the Boston Bruins tonight, 6 -- 2. The victory stretched Toronto's lead over the Montreal Canadiens in the international section of the National Hockey League to 15 points and left Boston still deep in the American division cellar.
Purchase of a West New York factory by an expanding leather goods firm featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- The dollar again resisted downward pressure today, gaining twenty-four centimes to close at 15.97. The French are saying "it refuses to go down." The pound, however, lost fifty centimes, closing at 70.50 which is near its record low of 78.575 on Oct. 3.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- John Leydon, secretary of the Department of Industrial Commerce for Southern Ireland, will arrive in Washington soon to discuss the placing of large orders in the United States for coal, petroleum, timber, automobiles and other manufactured articles in return for favorable tariff treatment for Irish hides, homespuns, poplin, linen, lace and knitted goods.

The "absurd" values placed upon slum area lands constitute the most serious difficulty in the way of housing developments by the Public Works Administration, according to Carey. H. Brown, acting chairman of the technical board of review of the PWA.

The American principle of asylum for refugees from political and religious persecution must be restored, Raymond Moley, editor of Today, declares in an editorial written for the current issue on the subject of refugees from Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Administration plans for the introduction into the present session of Congress of an omnibus bill establishing Federal regulation over stock and commodity exchanges were disclosed today in connection with testimony of Secretary Wallace before the Senate Agricultural Committee.
New York is to have an opportunity soon to see a collection of some ninety bronzes by the noted sculptor Malvina Hoffman, depicting "The Races of Man."

The fourteen survivors of the little pleasure schooner Alamyth, who were rescued in a storm on Wednesday off the coast of New Jersey, gratefully came back to land on Staten Island yesterday when the Coast Guard cutter Thetis docked at Base 2, Clifton.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, Bay of Whales, Antarctica, Jan. 17. -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd and the vanguard of his second Antarctic expedition tonight were at his old base at Little America, and his flagship lay within the white, shining barrier walls of the Bay of Whales, scarcely two miles away.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Passage of President Roosevelt's gold program was urged, with reservations, before a House committee today by James P. Warburg, monetary adviser to the American delegation to the recent World Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- William Sacks, Republican State Committeeman in Missouri at the time the Robertson brothers, original backers of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, were trying to get an air-mail contract for a line between St. Louis and New Orleans, denied emphatically today that he had tried to "cut in" on the deal or threatened to smash it unless he received 5 per cent of any subsidy they might obtain.

District Attorney Dodge announced last night he was about to write a letter of protest to Commissioner O'Ryan. He complains of the, failure of the police to provide a detective escort last Wednesday night, at the prosecutor's request, for six detained witnesses who wanted to attend a meeting of a union in which they had charged there was racketeering.

The Beaux-Arts Ball, one of New York's most famous annual entertainments, will take place tonight in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. After months of preparation, all arrangements have been completed and the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects, sponsors of the ball, are certain that the event will be the most elaborate they have produced in two decades.
DUBLIN, Jan. 18. -- A sudden strike of the Dublin street car and bus employes left the city practically without transport today. Commuters from the suburbs were obliged to walk to work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Member banks of the United States were in a position to meet their holiday demands for the usual increase in currency without increasing their indebtedness to the Federal Reserve Banks, the Federal Reserve Board said in its monthly bulletin today.
" Miss Fane's Baby Is Stolen," with Dorothea Wieck, Alice Brady and Baby LeRoy, will open at the Paramount today. Eddie Cantor will head the stage show.
HARBIN, Manchuria, Jan. 18. -- Bandits in Manchuria today wrecked two trains, one of them armored, causing the deaths of at least four persons and the injury of thirty-nine others.

A copy of the first issue of the first edition of one of the most famous early histories of America, Captain John Smith's quaintly titled "The Generall Historie of Virginia, New-England, and the Summer Isles," published in London in 1624, brought $800 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. The auction of historical Americana was from the libraries of Edmund A. Funke, Dr. William Sturgis Thomas and others.
LONDON, Jan. 18. -- Amid active dealings the dollar rose on the foreign exchange today to less than $5 to the pound, and closed at $4.95, a gain of 12 1/4 cents over yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- At the annual meeting of the shareholders of Barclay's Bank today the chairman, F.E. Goodenough, devoted a good part of his speech to recent developments in the financial policy of the United States.

Lionel Conacher furnished plenty of excitement for the 12,000 hockey fans in Madison Square Garden last night as the New York Rangers swamped the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 to 0, and went into exclusive possession of first place in the American group of the National League.

Luigi Beccali of Italy, the Olympic 1,500-meter champion and one of the greatest runners in the world at the mile or kindred distances, will not compete in the United States during the present indoor season. Daniel J. Ferris, secretary treasurer of the A.A.U., yesterday admitted that he had given up all hope that the black-haired European ace would be over this year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 18. -- Out of the humanity of every size, type, race, creed and color imaginable that swarmed through Chicago's Century of Progress Exposition comes the first vague evidence that through succeeding generations of its native-born, America may be producing a race of its own.

Lou Brouillard, former holder of the world's welterweight and middleweight boxing championships, will make a bid for his third title tonight. The rugged Worcester French-Canadian will oppose Bon Olin of Brooklyn in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden, and if he wins will issue a challenge to Maxie Rosenbloom, holder of the light-heavyweight championship.

Owners of entire guaranteed mortgages now in default who are able to prove that they were induced to sign releases of the guarantees in order to get possession of the mortgages under circumstances amounting to duress are entitled to have the releases vacated and returned to them, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler ruled yesterday.

Sugar and rubber were the features in futures trading yesterday on local commodity exchanges. Both were influenced heavily by developments in their peculiar interests and both gained sharply. Prices in other markets were irregularly lower in fairly active trading. Cash prices also were mostly lower.

Bearing in mind that in the national election of 1932 the New Jersey Republicans elected a United States Senator and ten of fourteen Representatives, and also a majority in the Assembly, it would seem that the party's prospect of regaining the Governorship this year was at least fair.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- Strengthening his hold on the lead in the race for the national three-cushion billiard title, Alfredo De Oro Sr., the 71-year-old Cuban veteran from New York, already wearing the crown of Eastern sectional champion, today conquered his fourth consecutive opponent.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18. -- Blue Day continued his consistent Jefferson Park record by winning the six-furlong Bulletin Handicap which featured today's racing. The A.G. Tarn racer crossed the finish line a length in front of Arthur J. Halliwell's Contribute, with Mrs. Floyd West's Don Vern third.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 18 (AP). -- Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr. declared here tonight that a "study of the reactions of human beings in their relations to money leads to the conclusion that it is impossible, by artificial manipulation of the gold content of the dollar, to maintain a fixed level of commodity prices."

The task of the New York County Republican Committee will be to restore the advantages of the two-party system of government to the people of the city, Chase Mellen Jr. declared last night. Mr. Mellen spoke at a meeting of the committee at the Julia Richman High School, Second Avenue and East Sixty-seventh Street.

Plans for a world's heavyweight championship bout in New York next Summer, with Max Baer as one of the contestants, struck a snag yesterday. Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, and Ancil Hoffman, Baer's manager, held a long conference but were unable to come to terms.

Police Commissioner O'Ryan, reversing the stand taken by his predecessor in office, ruled yesterday that taxicabs in the city would be permitted to carry radios under regulations to be drafted by the Police Department.
Alfredo De Oro Jr. and Charles Gill yesterday scored their first victories in the national amateur three-cushion billiard championship tourney in progress at the Capitol Academy.

For thirty-five years Alfred Marzorati has sat at the information desk at Teachers College, Columbia University, and courteously answered all questions concerning that educational institution. However, at a luncheon held yesterday in his honor and attended by more than 200 of the staff of Teachers College educators, Marzorati was, for the first time in his life, at a complete loss for words.

Mayor LaGuardia appointed yesterday Robert Moses as Park Commissioner, Fire Chief John J. McElligott as Fire Commissioner and Paul Moss as License Commissioner, while three other administrative posts were filled by members of his cabinet.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated over a range of only 15 points yesterday and ended at losses of 1 to 11 points. An unusually large quantity of contracts changed hands.

Counsel for the city and the Transit Commission will appear before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack today to oppose a direct move to make them parties to the Interborough receivership now pending in the Federal courts. Since the beginning of the receivership they have refrained from submitting to the Federal jurisdiction.
LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

VIENNA, Jan. 18. -- Fulvio Suvich, Italian Under-Secretary of State, arrived here this morning. The Austrian Nazis had made extensive preparations to impress Premier Mussolini's envoy with their numerical strength and vigor, but the Vienna police, anxious to prevent even the smallest demonstration, had been held in readiness for twelve hours and had worked out a complicated scheme to assure his undisturbed entry.

Buying of domestic corporation bonds, notably the lower-priced issues, was heavy again yesterday in the bond market of the Stock Exchange. United States Government issues gave ground slightly and leading foreign loans were irregularly lower.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- With far more vehemence than had been evidenced last week the Stavisky scandal suddenly broke into the debate in the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon and became far more serious both for the government and for all those involved.

A letter in THE TIMES signed Roland Petrie accuses the Federal Securities Act of 1933 of discriminating against those who do "decent, responsible, conservative financing" in favor of irresponsible persons putting out "a most miscellaneous batch of fourth-rate issues of the most speculative nature," those who have little to lose assuming the obligations required by the act, while the rich are turned away by fear of future litigation.

SOUTHAMPTON, Jan. 18. -- Lord Essendon, chairman of the White Star Line, said at the formal opening of the George V graving dock today that the Cunard-White Star merger awaits only a few formalities before coming into operation.

The Manhattan bus franchises awarded during the last days of the O'Brien administration were defended by Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan and denounced by Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, in speeches at the annual luncheon of the First Avenue Association yesterday in the Pan-Hellenic, 3 Mitchell Place.
PARIS, Jan. 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
The text of the address of General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, last night before the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Pennsylvania Hotel, follows:

The Savings Bank Trust Company and the Institutional Securities Corporation, the bank and mortgage company, respectively, formed cooperatively last year by the savings banks of this State for mutual help in times of need, rendered reports yesterday to the mutual savings banks that hold their stock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- President Roosevelt's move against the politico-lawyer system was put before the Senate today.

Speaking in his characteristic vigorous and picturesque style, General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, last night delivered a defense of the NRA which was also a challenge to its critics. He spoke at the annual dinner of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Four of the larger guaranteed mortgage and title companies now in rehabilitation paid dividends aggregating $13,150,000 in 1931 and 1932.

Mayor LaGuardia expressed his general approval yesterday of the Charter Revision Bill introduced in the Legislature, but said he thought the proposed revision commission should include added members representing a wider cross-section of public opinion.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 18. -- With deposits of approximately $3,900,000, the Elizabeth Trust Company today began operating under the Altman Act, a State measure authorizing restrictions on withdrawals. Decision to take advantage of the act was reached by the directors this morning.

The 2 per cent sales tax proposed at Albany by George R. Fearon, Republican Senate leader, and John J. Merrill, State Tax Commissioner, as a means of raising $120,000,000 annually for the relief of municipalities, will be opposed by the Merchants Association, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The index of employment in manufacturing industries declined 1.8 per cent in December as compared with November and payrolls fell 1 per cent in the month, Secretary Perkins announced today. Based on 1926 levels as 100, the December index was 70.1 and on payrolls was 49.8.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 18. -- An aged father, personal friend of President Roosevelt and Governor Floyd B. Olson, tonight begged law enforcement agencies to cease their efforts to free his 37-year-old son from a kidnap gang which held Edward G. Bremer for $200,000 ransom.
Rainbow is to be the name of the new America's Cup yacht being built for defense of the historic trophy against T.O.M. Sopwith's English challenger Endeavour.

Birth control implies not only "protection against children whose coming would be detrimental" but also "provision of expert advice to the considerable number of persons who desire more children than they have," Dr. C.E.A. Winslow, Professor of Public Health at Yale, declared last night at a dinner of the American Birth Control League, at the Park Lane Hotel.

BERLIN, Jan. 18. -- It appeared probable today that Germany would delay her reply to the American and British notes of protest against the arbitrary reduction of the interest payments on her foreign debt until Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, had discussed the situation with the creditors' committee at a conference starting Jan. 22.

Two resolutions, one approving pending legislation to consolidate the Court of Special Sessions and the Magistrates' Courts and the other proposing reforms in the unwieldy Civil Practice Act, were adopted in principle last night by the Bar Association of the City of New York at its building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

The Parmelee System, operators of 14 per cent of all the taxicabs in the city, informed Mayor LaGuardia yesterday that it was willing to give its drivers 40 per cent of the city tax of five cents a ride when the invalidity of the tax was finally established.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 18. -- Jacobus Jonker, owner of the world's fourth largest diamond, which a native assistant found yesterday on Jonker's claim in the Elandsfontein diggings, brought the gem to Johannesburg today. Sir Ernest Oppenheimer bought it for 63,000 on behalf of the Diamond Corporation, Ltd., of which he is chairman.

DETROIT. Jan. 18 (AP). -- The Detroit Red Wings and Montreal Maroons battled to a 1-1 overtime tie tonight in a rough game in which eighteen penalties were imposed, five of them being majors. The tie gave Detroit a tie for second place with Chicago in the American Division of the National Hockey League.

The Columbia swimming team defeated New York University, 43 -- 28, last night in the Morningside pool. The 400-yard relay race, final event on the program, was the deciding contest. The Lions led by 35 -- 28 at the start of the relay. Had the Violet won, it would have scored eight points and captured the meet.

For every passenger who lost his life last year on the street railways and buses of the larger transit companies of the United States and Canada, 310,000,000 rode in safety. This record was revealed yesterday at a luncheon of members of the American Transit Association and representatives of the American Museum of Safety at the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- President Roosevelt received a first-hand report on slum-clearance problems and low-cost housing construction in New York City today from Langdon Post, Tenement House Commissioner of New York.

GENEVA, Jan. 18. -- Into the meeting of the Council of the League of Nations dealing with such routine matters as the cooperation of the press and the reorganization of peace, Argentina's non-aggression compact and kindred subjects there crept again today, with Germany absent from the Council table, the vital question of the Nazis' disregard of any other rights than their own and what is to be done about it.

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- The Court of Appeals ruled today in unanimous decision that former Magistrate Francis X. McQuade of New York City, former treasurer of the National Exhibition Company, was not entitled to a $42,827.38 judgment against Charles A. Stoneham and John J. McGraw of the New York Giants.

Richard H. Brown, former president of the Manhattan Electrical Supply Company, and Charles H. McCarthy, stock pool operator, were convicted last night of mail fraud. It took a jury of eleven men only one and a half hours to reach a decision. One juror had been excused.

In thanking the "courteous reader" at the beginning of the year 1734, Poor Richard expressed his gratitude that his circumstances were "much more easy in the world," due to the increased sale of his Almanacks. His wife had been able to get a new pair of shoes and certain garments and he had himself bought a second-hand coat so good that he was no longer ashamed to go to town or to be seen there.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 18. -- With a dinner tonight at which the speakers were Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank of New York; E.C. Stokes, president of the First Mechanics National Bank of this city and first president of the State body, and Dr. J. Duncan Spaeth of Princeton University, the midwinter conference of the New Jersey Bankers Association was opened here today. Sessions will be held tomorrow.

Easily the best news of the day is the report that we are no longer a people with the average mental age of a 12-year child; our true mental age is nearly 18 years. That is the finding of an expert who writes in School Life, the official publication of the Federal Office of Education in Washington.

The old Hotel Brevoort, at Eighth Street and Fifth Avenue, formally rang out the lean years of the dry era last night by tendering a repeal dinner to a "gathering of moderns," many of whom had glowing memories of hours spent in the hostelry l before prohibition.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18. -- Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop gasped under the strain of a severe heart attack this afternoon after listening in cold-eyed anger as two witnesses, one a fellow physician, told a tense jury that she had admitted in their presence that she killed Rheta Wynekoop, her daughter-in-law.

Both houses of Congress have now passed the bill extending for another year the power of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to make loans, and increasing by $850,000,000 the notes which it may issue. The corporation, created by act of Jan. 22, 1932, dates back to the days of President HOOVER.

The year 1933 closed with The Annalist index of business activity showing a slight upturn, following four months of recession from its July peak of 89.4. The preliminary index for December is 69.2, as against 68.4 for November and 72.4 for October.
Range of important items in 1933 compared with preceding years. All figures except ratio of reserve are in thousands of dollars:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Security issues totaling close to $4,500,000, of which almost $3,000,000 relate to new capital, were proposed in registration statements filed under the Securities Act with the Federal Trade Commission and made public today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18. -- The long-awaited stabilization in livestock prices appears at hand, G.F. Swift, president of Swift Co., told shareholders today at the annual meeting in the company's offices in the Union Stock Yards.

Former Magistrate and Mrs. George F. Ewald and their two sons left their apartment at 404 Riverside Drive yesterday because an eviction order was obtained against Mrs. Ewald, who is suffering from a nervous breakdown, it was made known yesterday by their attorney, Bernard H. Sandier.

The claim of Pola Negri, actress, for $4,000 allegedly owed her by the Shuberts for her appearances in the try-out engagement of "A Trip to Pressburg" and the counter-claim of the Shuberts for $25,000 for breach of contract when she left the cast because of illness, will be arbitrated this afternoon in the offices of the American Arbitration Association.

For many weeks the public has been told that the West is dead set for inflation. Newspaper reporters and persons whose business or pleasure has led them to travel through the Farm Belt have informed us that the demand there for currency inflation is overwhelming.

Retail collections registered an increase of 3.32 per cent during December, according to the index based on twenty local Key stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. This gain compares with a decline of .91 per cent in December, 1932, and an increase of 1.90 in November. 1933.

Administration proposals for increasing foreign trades are inconsistent with the industrial recovery program to which American industry has subscribed, William L. Monro of Pittsburgh, president of the American Tariff League, said yesterday in an address before the annual meeting of the organization.

HURST PARK, England, Jan. 18 (AP). -- George H. (Pete) Bostwick's Blue Mirage was ridden to victory today in the Mortlake Handicap hurdle race by Louis E. Stoddard Jr., a young American sportsman almost as well known in turf circles as the horse's owner.

Tribute to Robert Moses as founder of the State park system and developer of the Long Island parks and parkways was paid by more than 400 persons at a luncheon yesterday just before his appointment as Park Commissioner of New York City.

GENEVA, Jan. 18. -- Disarmament talks were resumed here today informally with the arrival of Arthur Henderson, Sir John Simon, Joseph Paul-Boncour and others. A dinner given for members of the League of Nations Council brought them together.

Wagner's "Die Meistersinger," which has been absent from the Metropolitan Opera Association's repertory since Dec. 12, 1931, was again interpreted in that abode of art yesterday afternoon. The occasion was a very welcome one.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railway incurred a net loss of about $5,000,000 after all charges in 1933, compared with a net loss of $23,269,678 in 1932, according to St. Paul advices quoting H.A. Scandrett, president. He said that traffic was running about 18 per cent ahead of last year's, but that washouts cost the company between $75,000 and $100,000 in December and January.

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Eminent leader of the Democratic party in Washington are taking a lively interes in developments here in the situation affecting the LaGuardia legislative program and the factional division of the lew York State Democrats.

With all of the markets showing more caution, the speculative performances yesterday were much less entertaining to onlookers. The gyrations in foreign exchange evidently served as a restraining force in the domestic markets. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 2,125,000 shares, compared with 2,849,000 shares on Wednesday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18. -- The 6-year-old campaigner General A. closed with a good burst of speed in the featured six furlong Osceola Purse at Tropical Park today to win by a nose from J.E. Smallman's Fancy Flight. Mrs. C.M. Henderson's Flying Sailor was third in a field of eleven.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18. -- Tommy Goodwin, 20-year-old Monroe (N.Y.) star, continued his victorious march in defense of his laurels when he defeated Curtis Bryan of Jacksonville, 1 up, in the semi-final round of the midwinter amateur golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today.

As successor to Commissioner Sidney S. Levine in the Department of Licenses, Commissioner Paul Moss inherited and at Mayor LaGuardia's direction promptly turned over to Commissioner Paul Blanshard of the Department of Accounts yesterday the license graft investigation which has gone on four weeks.

Statements of the leading insurance companies in the America Fore group as of Dec. 31, issued yesterday, showed in most instances an increase in surplus accounts, although total assets continued to decline. In all cases, securities are carried at the latest "convention valuations" as permitted by the New York State Insurance Department, but contingency reserves, representing the differences between the convention and the market values on Dec. 31, have been set up.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 18. -- Mrs. Elden C. DeWitt gave the first in a series of dinners followed by contract tonight at Casa Cora, her villa on Via Del Mar. Guests were Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr., Mr. and Mrs. William R. Sweatt, Dr. and Mrs. Edmund Le Roy Dew, Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne and Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff.

Suggestions for reducing the maternity mortality in New York City were presented by the leaders of ten round-table discussion groups at the annual meeting and luncheon of the Maternity Center Association at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- President Roosevelt's sociological ideals are twenty years ahead of current thought, Father Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit declared today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The advisability of setting up a sinking fund for retirement of future railroad bond issues was discussed recently at a conference here between officials of the New York Central and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the corporation, revealed today. This principle has received the backing of President Roosevelt.
Corralling their second successive world's series hero in as many days, the New York Giants yesterday announced the signing of their little right fielder, Melvin T. Ott, for the 1934 campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- At the request of President Roosevelt, the Federal Trade Commission has prepared a twenty-five-page memorandum criticizing the multiple basing point system embodied in the steel code as permitting price-fixing and monopolistic practices.

It develops that the accomplished Edy Legrand has been paying a visit to Morocco. Although, in his present exhibition at the Marie Sterner Galleries, you occasionally come upon a "Bank of the Seine" or a "Bridge in Provence," such home-abiding records are greatly outnumbered by ladies and gentlemen in gay North African finery.
ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- Need of better water facilities in the New York City reformatory at New Hampton is stressed in a report just submitted to the Commission of Correction.

With the development of an expanded trade with Russia expected as a result of recognition of the Soviet Governments and an eventual agreement on a credit arrangement, we must consider entry ports for our products into Russia and shipping points for Russian exports.

A majority of business men expect a gradual improvement in trade in the first six months of this year, according to a mail survey just completed by C.W. Young Co., investment managers. A questionnaire was sent to representative business men in approximately 200 important industrial and agricultural communities of the country.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, Bay of Whales, Antarctica, Jan. 19. -- The twenty-eight sleepless hours that followed the arrival of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition in the Ross ice barrier have seen it transported in a series of rapidly succeeding crises from jubilation to the verge of despair.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Liberalization of the penal laws to permit transmission and possession by medical authorities of contraceptive devices, and to give birth control advice, was attacked and defended at the closing session today of the hearing before the House Judiciary Committee on the Pierce bill.

Net premiums written by the New Amsterdam Casualty Company increased from $12,546,781 in 1932 to $13,186,348 in 1933, according to the annual report made yesterday. Losses and claim expenses paid declined to $9,168,677 from $9,488,797, so that the excess of debits over credits dropped to $268,883 from $1,052,093.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Despite administration strength which promises to push President Roosevelt's money bill through the House by tomorrow night, the Governors of two Federal Reserve Banks protested today against certain provisions as reducing the Federal Reserve System to a mere "machine" in a new centralized banking order.
Edward Lee, defending champion, yesterday scored his third straight victory in the national amateur three-cushion title tourney at the Capitol Academy and took sole possession of first place.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Many local operators went out of their lines of long wheat at the close of the market yesterday on the Board of Trade, not liking the prospects or the decline in sterling. Today sterling rallied sharply and they found it hard to reinstate their lines without advancing prices.

The special license numbers for 1934 for the automobiles of prominent officials, business men and others, which do everything to identify the owner but spell out his name, were disclosed yesterday at the office of Charles A. Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
Richard A. Glendon, popularly known throughout the rowing world as "Old Dick," will shortly join the coaching staff at Columbia, it was learned yesterday.

Echoes of the gayety in Havana that had greeted the installation of Colonel Carlos Mendieta as President of Cuba stirred the three-story residential hotel at 10 Fort Washington Avenue yesterday. It was there Colonel Mendieta and his wife had lived for several months prior to their departure for Cuba last August.

The listed bond market showed unusual buying enthusiasm yesterday. Many issues of the domestic corporation group, industrials, rails and utilities were bid up 1 to more than 6 points, and several foreign loans gained 1 or more points on the day.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 19. - Transandine railroad construction engineers doubt whether the section of the railroad destroyed by a flood in the Andes can be rebuilt. They say the damage to the road, which connects Argentine and Chile, cannot be merely repaired; the line must be reconstructed and they do not think the traffic justifies the cost of rebuilding.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- President Roosevelt is ready to approve action which would prohibit government officials from using the prestige of their positions in legal practice where the government has a stake.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- A movement for the large-scale construction of new homes of moderate cost, as a spur to the general recovery program, was discussed today at a conference of officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the Home Owners Loan Corporation, insurance companies, savings banks and other institutions in the mortgage field.

A committee of harbor and shipping authorities will be appointed by the New York Board of Trade to consider the establishment of a free port here, according to a decision reached at the organization's board of directors meeting held yesterday at the Broad Street Club.

Brokers were in high glee yesterday as the business on the Stock Exchange picked up. Their trading customers applauded the advance in prices. Stocks displayed what was called exceptional strength in the afternoon, largely as a result of the wide advance in railway shares.

LANSING, Kan., Jan. 19. -- Seven desperate convicts, including Bob Brady and Jim Clark, who joined in the big Memorial Day prison break here escaped from the State prison today, and are still at large tonight.
We hear a lot nowadays about civil service, and of the alleged outrages which Executives of the State and city contemplate in order to spend public funds wisely and justly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Following are the texts of Executive orders issued by President Roosevelt today liberalizing veterans' compensation regulations:
Mayor LaGuardia plans to exercise regularly to keep himself in good physical condition, it appeared yesterday when the private gymnasium underneath his office in City Hall was made ready for his use.

Manhattan realty trading yesterday was centred on the East Side. Two Lexington Avenue properties changed ownership, a Murray Hill parcel was acquired by an operator and a large commercial building in East Sixty-first Street was taken under a long lease.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP). -- A 23 per cent increase in the acreage of Winter wheat plantings in the eleven principal wheat-growing States over the figures expected was reported today by the Farm Administration.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 19. -- At the concluding session today of the mid-Winter conference of the New Jersey Bankers' Association, resolutions were adopted favoring enactment of a retail sales tax to relieve the burden on real estate and calling upon the Legislature to hear the State Banking Commissioner and spokesmen for the association before passing any banking bills.
Carol Margot gave a costume recital at the meeting of the Theatre Assembly yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor.

The estate of Miss Elisabeth Marbury, civic leader and writer, who died Jan. 22, 1933, was appraised yesterday at $109,173 gross and $73,504 net, which included securities worth $50,033 and her home at 13 Sutton Place, valued at $35,000 and mortgaged for $17.874.
Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan continued his gradual shake-up of the Police Department yesterday by transferring an inspector and four other officers in Brooklyn.
Postmaster General James A. Farley will resign as chairman of the Democratic National Committee and as chairman of the Democratic State Committee.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- In a surprising, straight-game victory over the favored Miss Elizabeth Pearson of Philadelphia, Miss Eileen Beresford of Short Hills gained the final round of the sixth annual invitation squash racquets tournament at the Racquet and Swimming Club today.

BERLIN, Jan. 19.-- The Boerse I continued in the doldrums today, but the tone was slightly firmer, due to repurchases by professionals. Changes remained fractional. Heavy industrials, constructions and textiles improved slightly, machineries, electricals and shippings sagged, while automobiles, cables and chemicals were irregular.
Meat trade condition and wholesale prices at New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19. -- Charles McCourt of Cleveland, Northern sectional winner, sent the national three-cushion billiard championship tournament into a three-way tie tonight by defeating the veteran Alfredo De Oro of New York, 50 to 45, in seventy innings

Complaints by members of the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802, against union officials were referred to the Regional Labor Board yesterday after a hearing before James F. Hodgson, district compliance director of the NRA. Another hearing will be held Monday before Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, acting chairman of the NRA Labor Board.

Copies of newspapers of a mellow age are hard to come by. The American Antiquarian Society, itself an ancient of almost 125, is an assiduous collector of these in single copies and in files. Librarian VAIL points a reproachful finger at our careless ancestors. Butchers did their meat up in newspapers.

The effect of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment on the sales of department stores in the metropolitan area of New York is indicated in a report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which for the first time has undertaken, in its periodical statements, to segregate the liquor business.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- The portals of organized baseball are closed forever to Shoeless Joe Jackson and his confessed cronies, who staggered the national game in 1919 by throwing the world's series to the Cincinnati Reds.
Brooklyn Tech's hockey team retained its championship and finished the P.S.A.L. season undefeated by downing the Textile sextet, 4 to 0, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 19 (AP). -- A mother prostrated by grief in her Newfield (N.J.) home, spurred the search today for Jack V. Baker, 18-year-old junior in the Cornell College of Mechanical Engineering.

Speculative operations were resumed yesterday on several of the markets and the result was a broad advance in stocks and agricultural products. Dollar exchange declined, in terms of all the currencies that figure in the calculation of our currency's actual value.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 19. -- Anxiety for the welfare of Edward G. Bremer, prisoner of kidnappers demanding $200,000, grew today as blood stains were found on the seats of his abandoned automobile.

The second "Salome" of the season, last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, was prefaced by a return to the repertory of Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi." This double bill attracted the largest and most financially profitable audience of the season with the exception of that of the opening night.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 19. -- Indictments on four counts against James H. Bolitho, former Morris County Prosecutor, and Eugene Bisson, alleged leaders of an arson ring, were returned today by the grand jury. True bills also were found against James Applin of Morristown, Mrs. Elizabeth Kingdon of Hurdtown and Mr. and Mrs. John Cochran of Dover, all of whom are charged with having conspired with Bolitho and Bisson to set fire to their homes.

Home owners whose properties are sold in foreclosure for a fraction of their value may be entitled to relief if the mortgagee seeks to execute a deficiency judgment, Supreme Court Justice Paul Bonynge held in Brooklyn yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19. -- William C. Bullitt, Ambassador to Soviet Russia, told the Chamber of Commerce at a dinner given in his honor in his native city tonight that the United States should not grant "excessive" credits to foster trade with Russia.

A firmer tone prevailed yesterday afternoon in the local commodity futures markets, with the result that prices reached the best levels of the day at the close. In most cases gains were reported. Trading was more active. Cash prices were higher.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. - Former Postmaster General Walter F. Brown personally delivered to Postmaster General Farley here today two packets said to contain all of the official records of air and ocean mail contracts which post-office clerks had told the special Senate inquiry committee had been burned by order of Mr. Brown in the last days of the Hoover administration.

The late N.E. Montross, although his principal aim was the promotion of American art, used from time to time to show the work of outstanding foreign painters. Pursuant of this policy, the Montross Gallery opened this week a group exhibition of canvases by some Austro-German moderns.

HAVANA, Jan. 19. -- President Carlos Mendieta strove today to form a Cabinet that would meet with the approval of the people and laid plans for solving the many grave problems that confront his administration.

General JOHNSON ended his long address on Thursday to the National Retail Dry Goods Association with a vehement exhortation. He declared that if he had to state the whole object and hope of the Recovery Act, it would be in the nine words: "Keep prices down -- for GOD'S sake, keep prices down!"

The various private interests concerned in the Federal receiverships of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company are about to launch a drive to make the city a party to the litigation, either in the Federal or the State courts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop was so weak this morning when she was wheeled into court that Judge Joseph B. David adjourned until Monday resumption of her trial for the murder of Rheta Gardner Wynekoop, her daughter-in-law.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- President Roosevelt ordered increases in veterans' allowances totaling $21,000,000 annually.

Judge Corrigan in Genera Sessions yesterday, at the request of District Attorney Dodge, increased the bail of Irving Bitz. racketeer, from $30.000 to $50.000.He also ordered that Bitz be produced for trial before him Thursday on indictments for carrying a pistol and jumping $25,000 bail last October.
LANSING, Kan., Jan. 19. -- After Deer had surrendered his cell keys today, he and several trusties were locked in a solitary-confinement cell.

An announcement that they are "going in for Pulitzer Prize brothers and sisters" comes from Coward-McCann. On their Spring list they have a second novel by Isabel Wilder, the younger sister of Thornton Wilder, "Heart, Be Still," and "Hoxie Sells His Acres," a first novel by Christopher La Farge, brother of Oliver La Farge.

PATERSON, N J., Jan. 19. -- After five hours deliberation, a jury before Judge Joseph A. Delaney in Quarter Sessions Court, returned verdicts of guilty tonight against five men charged with conspiracy to commit embracery in connection with the Passaic County "jury fixing" investigation.

Architects and contractors accused by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, in connection with the construction of the city's new Rikers Island prison made emphatic denial of the charges yesterday.

The work of the Crime Prevention Bureau in the Police Department was commended and its continuation and expansion were urged last night by speakers at a conference on crime prevention methods held under the auspices of the American Institute at its headquarters in the Lincoln Building, 60 East Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- War veterans will receive an additional $21,000,000 annually under the terms of four executive orders liberalizing cuts in benefits under the Economy Act, which were issued today by President Roosevelt. The increases affect 228,000 veterans.
BERLIN, Jan. 19. -- The German Government's reply to the French memorandum on armaments is said to cover fourteen typewritten pages.

GENEVA, Jan. 19. -- The Saar plebiscite next year was on the agenda of today's meeting of the Council of the League of Nations, but after the preliminary conferences that usually precede a Council meeting to insure that the agenda raises no unforeseen difficulties it quickly came off.

" As one Mayor to another," said 16-year-old Sidney Orenstein, Mayor of the Boys' Brotherhood Republic, as he clasped the hand of Mayor LaGuardia at the formal opening last evening of the republic's new "city hall" and clubhouse at 290 East Third Street.

Severe sentences were imposed yesterday by Federal Judge John M. Woolsey as a result of the first trial and first conviction in this district of defendants accused of violating the mail-fraud statute in the operation of a stock pool.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Regulations prohibiting the payment of interest on demand deposits by non-Federal Reserve Banks as well as member banks which have joined the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation insurance fund were issued by the corporation today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Prospects for a harmonious meeting of share-holders of Armour Co. on next Friday to elect directors were dimmed today when it appeared that Chase Ulman of St. Louis had refused a place on the board, formed a committee and issued to stockholders an appeal for proxies to elect a board.

Far Rockaway High School upset predictions last night by winning the P.S.A.L. swimming championship in the Columbia University pool before nearly 1,000 spectators. The brilliant performances of the victors, who won four of the eight events, left such stalwarts as Erasmus and Clinton in second and third place, respectively.

For the first time in the history of the Manhattan Building Bureau, alteration work during the past year involved a larger expenditure than new construction, according to a review yesterday by Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings, of plans filed in the borough during 1933.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Judge James H. Wilkerson, in Federal Court, today adjudicated the Trustees System service Corporation bankrupt, following a recommendation of Garfield Charles, referee. Clyde L. Day, equity receiver, was named receiver in bankruptcy and his bond was set at $25,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Fear of possible effects of the President's monetary bill upon the future of the Federal Reserve System was a thread that ran through testimony of Roy A. Young and George W. Norris, governors respectively of the Boston and Philadelphia Reserve Banks, at Congressional hearings today.

A patrolman, James J. Carney of the East Twenty-second Street station, was one of seven men arrested yesterday after a fight attributed by detectives to gang rivalry over the profitable Harlem "numbers" racket. Associates of Dutch Schultz, fugitive racketeer, were connected with the fight, the police believe.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Following is the text of the White House statement concerning two War Department reports on the St. Lawrence Deeper Waterway, sent to the Senate today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- As the Senate today resumed consideration of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty its advocates declared that the President already had won over three Democratic Senators to the pact and was determined to exert his influence fully to obtain ratification.
ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- Enlargement of the proposed charter revision commission for New York City as set forth in the Streit-Mandelbaum bill would be "agreeable" to Governor Lehman, he made known today.

The North German Lloyd Liner Bremen, commanded by Commodore Leopold Ziegenbein, steamed up the Hudson River last night for the first time and was made fast on the north side of Pier 86, at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street.

The four-story restaurant building at 79 Pearl Street and 46 Stone Street was bid in at a foreclosure auction sale yesterday by Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of President Theodore Roosevelt, and her sister, Miss Emily T. Carow of Genoa, Italy. The structure was taken on a $10,000 bid.

The convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association adjourned yesterday after a morning session at the Hotel Pennsylvania devoted to a discussion of sales problems. Lew Hahn, retiring president and temporary chairman of the national Retail Code Authority, presided.

Clarence Darrow, noted lawyer, declared his conviction to an audience of about 2,000 last night at Mecca Temple that "civilization has been destroyed by those who own it, by the people who have the vast wealth, the masters of the world who will not permit a fair distribution of its products."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Protests arose today in Congressional and State political circles against the retrenchment in relief and civil works expenditures ordered yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, the Federal administrator, but were met with the declaration that it was "purely a matter of money" and must stand unless or until the funds requested by President Roosevelt were appropriated by Congress.

VIENNA, Jan. 19. -- This city today appeared to be beleaguered. Its boulevards were filled with large forces of police. Several cordons barred all entrances to the inner city from the suburbs, breaking up small parties of Nazis who persistently strove to work their way through.

Entries in the annual collaborative competition sponsored by the Association of the Alumni of the American Academy in Rome for students of architecture, painting and sculpture in the colleges and art schools of the United States were judged yesterday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

All records of the news stand graft inquiry conducted by Sidney S. Levine during the closing four weeks of his administration of the License Department were transferred yesterday to the Department of Accounts, to be coordinated with the evidence uncovered in the separate inquiry conducted privately since the inauguration of Mayor La-Guardia by Irving Ben Cooper, special counsel for the Department of Accounts.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 19. -- R.H. Martin's 4-year-old filly, Fairystreet, led home a field of nine in the featured Steamer California Purse at the Agua Caliente track today. Leroy and Curtis King's Flower Day was second and the Lone Trail Stable's Gerard third.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19. -- Jonathan F. Clark Jr.'s Clang made his first start a winning one when he captured the quarter-mile race for juveniles at Jefferson Park today. E.K. Bryson's Moraine was second and John J. Robinson's Mr. Bill third in a field of nine.

The city's proposed housing plan is important both as a means of improving existing conditions and as an impetus to similar projects throughout the country, Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post said yesterday in an address before the Woman's Forum at the Hotel Roosevelt.

BERLIN, Jan. 19. -- Leo Gallagher, Los Angeles attorney and legal representative of Georgi Dimitroff, who has been trying to obtain the Bulgarian Communist's release from continued imprisonment since his acquittal in the Reichstag fire trial, was ordered by the police president of Berlin today to leave Prussia within three days.

The rally in the dollar caused by the repatriation of funds from London was flattened yesterday when the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, acting for the Treasury, purchased the bulk of 900,000 (about $4,500,000) of bar gold available in the London market.

The annual review and forecast number of The Annalist, published yesterday, contains not only a business record of the past year but an appraisal of the situation at the beginning of 1934. There will be general agreement with the observation that seldom if ever before has rise ordinary business man been forced to give so much consideration to "external economic and political influences" in planning for a new year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- A ruling delivered by Attorney General Cummings on Dec. 26, that the Department of Labor has the right to accept "public charge bonds" for immigrants, seems likely to have important effects for German refugees seeking admission to the United States.
