That the New York State Conservation Commission has framed a bill which will meet the demands of salt water anglers for the protection of fishing in the State's waters was made known yesterday by Commissioner Lithgow Osborne, who, with Bill Adams, Superintendent of Fish and Game for the Conservation Department, is here for the twentieth American Game Conference, which opens on Monday.

Closing after tonight's performances are "The School for Husbands" at the Empire, "Champagne, Sec," at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre and "Double Door" at the Shubert. The first and third will go on tour. The return engagement of the Piccoli puppets at the Hudson closes after Sunday night's showing.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered sharply yesterday as other markets rose and ended with gains of 13 to 19 points.

The rule of the New York Stock Exchange requiring its member firms to notify it of any pool operation in which they participate, or of which they have knowledge, has been interpreted by many members of the Exchange as virtually prohibiting them from indulging in pool activities, it was revealed yesterday in a survey of member firms.

" An American Adventure" will be the general topic at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania Monday evening under the auspices of the National Conference of Jews and Christians. Clergymen representing the three major faiths in this country who have just returned from a transcontinental journey "in the interest of amity, understanding and cooperation between Americans of all faiths," will speak.

The money market was at a standstill so far as business was concerned, very little new funds being taken in any section. What went on was chiefly routine requirements. Quotations, too, were steady and without variation from Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Wholesale prices dropped one-half of 1 per cent during December, but for the seventh consecutive month prices averaged higher than in the corresponding month of the previous year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Thanks to the joint efforts of the Mayor, the Governor and the Legislature, responsibility for the development of almost the entire metropolitan park system has been lodged in the hands of one man, made a full-time job, and given to ROBERT MOSES. Only those who have observed the results of uncoordinated, half-time, unskilled and misguided efforts in the past can appreciate what this new dispensation may mean for the parks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Robert H. Jackson, who resigned some weeks ago as secretary of Democratic National Committee and as its member from New Hampshire, has issued the following statement about a paragraph in a Washington dispatch yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES on the President's attitude toward the practice of law here by national committee members and others important in party politics:
PARIS, Jan. 19. -- Ambassador Jesse I. Straus arrived in Paris tonight from the United States after an absence since Sept. 6 on account of illness.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 19 (AP). -- A proposed New York-Bermuda air service came under debate in the House of Assembly today when a message was received from the Governor outlining operation terms.
PARIS, Jan. 19. -- Germany's reply to the French memorandum of Jan. 1 on armament, received tonight, makes no definite commitments, but leaves the way open for further discussion.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- A long-standing controversy between Dr. George C. Stevens, superintendent of the Albion Training School for Girls, and the school's board of visitors was disposed of today by Governor Lehman, who recommended that Dr. Stevens be displaced.

The State Title and Mortgage Company was permitted by the State Department of Insurance to continue in business for two years after the department's examiners had submitted reports showing an alarming condition, it was disclosed yesterday by the Moreland Act investigation of the Insurance Department and its handling of the guaranteed mortgage situation.

Two more CWA laborers assigned to the Queens Highway Bureau were suspended yesterday by Superintendent Andrew J. Kenny of the bureau in connection with the investigation by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens into charges of payroll padding and other irregularities among the emergency forces.

ATHENS, Jan. 19. -- The State Council appeared today to be impressed by counsel for Samuel Insull, former Chicago utilities magnate, in their arguments that he should not be deported as ordered by the Ministry of the Interior. Insull is scheduled to be expelled from Greece Jan. 31.

Of next week's new State and municipal financing to be done through competitive bidding, aggregating $13,523,231, interest centres largely in the offering of $8,453,000 of water and unemployment relief bonds by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

Please don't -- unless you want to break all our hearts -- print any more of Thomas McMorrow's piteous plaints about his inability to buy good booze at reasonable prices, how aged liquor disagrees with his digestion, and so on. (And here I have been supposing all my life that old liquor was the only kind fit to drink!)

THE chap in the brown overcoat turned out to be Frank Frisch, the second baseman and manager of the St. Louis Cardinals. The Fordham Flash has had steady work as a second baseman, but he knows baseball history and the chances are that he harbors no illusions about his job as manager of the Cardinals. That office is just about as permanent as a position in a revolving door.

Parents came in for a general drubbing yesterday at the hands of psychiatrists, educators and social workers who spoke at the opening sessions of the two-day conference of the Child Study Association of America. The conference, marking the organization's forty-fifth anniversary, will be continued today in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The application by the Triborough Bridge Authority to restrain Mayor LaGuardia from trying John Stnatton O'Leary, one of its three members, on charges preferred by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan.

Seemingly undisturbed by the various movements to displace him, John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, left yesterday for Miami. It was said at Tammany Hall that he probably would be gone for about four weeks.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP). -- Clarence Guy Gordon Haddon pleaded guilty to a charge of menacing King George, whose nephew he claims to be, and then went his way today, promising to forget his alleged grievances.

The pending treaty for the construction of the St. Lawrence waterway was attacked yesterday morning by Elon H. Hooker, president of the Hooker Electrical Company. He addressed the opening session of a two-day meeting of the New York State Secretaries Conference at the Lincoln Hotel, attended by about thirty-five secretaries of Chambers of Commerce in various parts of the State.

This was the name given to the ordinance of SOLON, meaning "a shaking off of burdens." Specifically, it referred to the burdens of debt. PLUTARCH'S comment is that this term meant both the lessening of the interest on obligations ("which sufficiently pleased the people") and enlarging the "measures," and "raising the value" of money as follows:

Deposits in mutual savings banks in New York State amounted on Jan. 1 to $5,064,000,000, according to the Savings Banks Association of the State. This was a net decline of $252,775,000 from the total on Jan. 1, 1932, which was $5,316,775,000.

Henry W. Pollock, who was vice president and counsel of the defunct Bank of United States, was eliminated yesterday as a defendant in the $60,000,000 suit by Banking Superintendent Broderick against the directors and from liability in other actions arising from his status with the bank, when Supreme Court Justice Valente, who is hearing the action, signed an order permitting a settlement with him for $4,700.

Twenty children, most of them crippled, narrowly escaped serious injury yesterday morning when a bus in which they were being taken to school overturned and caught fire after a collision with an automobile at Sixteenth Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, Brooklyn.

Followers of the hounds from all sections of the East and from a number of the hunting sections of Maryland, Delaware and Virginia gathered at the Riding Club yesterday for the ninth annual hound show under the auspices of the Masters of Foxhounds Association and the National Beagle Club.

ABOARD THE WYATT EARP, En Route to Dunedin, N.Z., Jan. 19 (By Wireless). -- We are at Lat. 69 degrees 28 minutes South and Long. 178 degrees 24 minutes East. We are forty-three miles north of where we left the pack ice on our southbound journey, but there is now no ice in sight.

MADRID, Jan. 19. -- The Spanish Supreme Court, reversing the decision of a court-martial at Palma, Majorca, last Oct. 17, ordered four of five Americans to serve six months and one day in jail for assault on a Civil Guard at an hotel in Palma.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19. -- The wisdom of wealthy Irishmen in setting aside rare books for rainy days, not for reading, but with which to pay the rent, was remarked yesterday by Shane Leslie, Irish poet and biographer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Consolidation of all Southern Pacific lines in Louisiana and Texas but one, through the acquisition by the Texas New Orleans, the system's principal subsidiary, of thirteen affiliated roads embracing 4,513 miles of trackage, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The order of Civil Works Administrator Harry L. Hopkins reducing the work week of CWA workers and forbidding further hiring of men and purchases of supplies and materials was termed yesterday a "monumental piece of stupidity" and "a gross injustice to the men" by Robert Moses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Recognition of Cuba by the United States became a distinct possibility today as tentative plans were made known involving the opening of action looking toward recognition within a week or ten days.

Declaring that the recovery movement is considerably well advanced, a survey of the textile industry for 1933 by the National Credit Office revealed yesterday that the industry was showing reasonable profits on invested capital, that stocks were in line with demand, that bankruptcy figures were the most favorable in a decade and that collections were generally good.

PARIS, Jan. 19. -- Threats of two duels between French Deputies arose today as a result of the Stavisky scandal in which French investors lost heavily through the collapse of the Bayonne municipal pawnshop.

MONTREAL, Jan. 19 (AP). -- Two high-ranking stars from the United States, Frank Shields of New York and George M. Lott of Chicago reached the singles final of the Canadian covered courts tennis championships today.
Max Schmeling, former heavyweight champion of the world, arrived last night on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to make a bid for the title he lost to Jack Sharkey in 1932.

Bowed over a counsel table, his head resting on one hand, Joseph W. Harriman, indicted banker, sat yesterday in a court room in the Woolworth Building, while Dr. Menas S. Gregory, head of the psychiatric ward of Bellevue Hospital, testified that he was sane.

Because of the absence from the State of necessary witnesses and in order to invoke a wider jurisdiction, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. turned over yesterday to Martin Conboy, United States Attorney, the data obtained in his inquiry into the "extraordinary action, of the common stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation on the New York Stock Exchange."

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- Governor Lehman's $81,000,000 tax reduction budget was subjected to attacks from two sides today as a drive began for realignment of the executive tax program and imposition of a 2 per cent retail sales tax.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 19. -- It is "a crime against civilization that we fail to let any brain pass unexamined when it has done its life work," said Dr. Adolf Meyer, psychiatrist-in-chief of the Johns Hopkins Hospital, today.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- An order of the State Milk Control Board revoking the license of the Grandview Dairy, Inc., of Brooklyn was nullified by the Appellate Division, Third Department, today, Justice Christopher J. Heffernan writing the opinion.

Ending a long and bitter jurisdictional dispute of long standing, the United Hatters of North America and the Cloth Hat, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union held a joint convention at Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, yesterday and ratified the recent agreement between the two organizations to become one union.

Mayor LaGuardia was asked yesterday to move toward repeal of the 50 per cent increase in water rates by Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley of the Bronx, sponsor of the first resolution to repeal the increase in the Board of Aldermen.

Retail trade in men's clothing and furnishings continued fairly active during the week and held to the levels of the first half of the month. Results in this district were somewhat spotty, depending upon the location of stores, but on' the whole, volume is running somewhat ahead of last year, probably about 5 per cent, according to estimates yesterday.

The New York A.C. and St. Nicholas hockey teams battled to a 5 -- 5 deadlock in a nerve-tingling overtime Eastern Amateur League encounter at the Coliseum last night. The score was tied at 4 -- 4 at the end of the regulation time.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19. -- Earl Porter, leading rider of the meeting, added another triple at Tropical Park today when he was first with Bickering, Happy Scot and Just Buck. It was Porter's fifth triple of the session and brings his total to thirty-one winners.

Secretary MORGENTHAU'S proposals for amendment of the Federal bond-issue statutes are mostly of routine character, necessitated by the immensely enlarged plans for future borrowing. This is why he asks that the present statutory limit of $7,000,000,000 be extended on the total permissible issue of the one-year to five-year obligations known as "Treasury notes."
Without fanfare, the twenty-ninth annual National Motor Boat Show last night began logging its run of eight days in Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Individual Federal income tax payers in New York State filed 634,057 returns in the calendar year 1931 and showed net income of $3,108,633,729, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today in "Final Statistics of Income" for that year.

Keeping up the fast pace set by the LaGuardia administration, the Board of Estimate disposed of a calendar of 124 items yesterday at the rate of about one a minute, including the retirements of a number of Tammany officeholders.

The expected announcement that the American ship lines operating in the foreign trade and foreign flag lines operating to American ports would adhere to the terms of the master shipping code accepted Wednesday by the NRA failed to materialize yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 19. -- J.M. Keynes, in an article in The New Statesman concerning President Roosevelt's gold policy, says that unless prices in the United States rise far more than seems likely France's position will be very difficult and probably untenable.
The dental office of Dr. Julius Lunenfeld at 80 Delancey Street was looted of $5,000 in gold yesterday by four dapper young gunmen.

KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 19. -- Jefferson Caffery, President Roosevelt's personal representative in Cuba, is much encouraged with conditions existing in Cuba and believes that President Carlos Mendieta will shortly have the island republic back to normal.

The directors of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad have not yet taken action toward the payment of interest due on Feb. 1 on the company's $29,808,000 of general mortgage 5 per cent bonds due in 1955. It was said the company had sufficient cash to meet the obligation, but that the outlay would impair working capital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Investigation by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee of the affairs of the Guardian-Detroit Union chain of banks, the collapse of which last February almost wrecked the Michigan bank structure, practically ended today.
MONTREAL, Jan. 19. -- Four New York players filled the semi-final brackets in the Canadian amateur racquets championships today as rivals from Philadelphia, Boston and Montreal were eliminated.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19. -- Miss Leila Hathaway Swift of Wellesley Hills, Mass., entertained a large number of colonists today at a tea in the garden adjoining La Solano on Sea Breeze Avenue, where she is spending the Winter.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., reported yesterday that in the thirteen weeks ended on Nov. 25, 1933, it had made its first profit for any quarter since 1930. The net profit for the period was $105,752, equivalent to $1.02 a share on 103,107 no par shares of preferred stock, on which dividends have not been paid since March 1, 1932.

Bob Olin's quest of the world's light-heavyweight championship received a setback last night in Madison Square Garden. Without being disgraced, Olin was beaten in ten rounds by Lou Brouillard of Worcester. Mass., who formerly held the world's welterweight and middleweight titles.

QUINCY, Ill., Jan. 19. -- Five bandits from Chicago robbed the State Bank of Girard of $5,000 early today. Late this afternoon they were surrounded near Basco, Ill., by a posse of 250 men and after a spirited exchange of shots were compelled to surrender.
The Horace Mann School basketball team defeated the Montclair Academy five on the former's court yesterday, 34 -- 11.
The first women's squash racquets team ever to sail from this country on an international expedition departed on the White Star liner Olympic last night for England.

Beneficiaries of 270 estates that were looted by James W. Hennessy, former Public Administrator of Richmond County, will receive only about 33 per cent of their legacies, Frank H. Innes, referee, reported yesterday to the Surrogate's Court at St. George.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Lines were being drawn sharply today in the controversy between the Federal Trade Commission and Senators Nye, Borah and Glass on one side, and General Johnson on the other, over price-fixing in the NRA codes.

Mrs. Henry S. Downe of Paris gave a luncheon yesterday at the Pierre. Her guests were Princess Henry XXXIII of Reuss, Countess Costantini, Mrs. Herbert Shipman, Mrs. Charles A. Cartwright, Mrs. John North Willys, Mrs. Edward Gwynne, Mrs. Tarn McGrew, Mrs. Clarence M. Woolley, Mrs. William Hayward, Mrs. Herbert Stuart Stone, Mrs. Marjorie Turnbull Oelrichs, Miss Virginia Latrone and Miss May Birkhead.

Professor I. Maurice Wormser, in his admirable letter to the Governor on the congestion in the courts, suggests, according to the Sunday TIMES, the appointment of emergency judges or referees "to handle non-jury if not jury cases." His survey shows, however, that the non-jury calendar is up to date, thus the imperative emergency relates only to jury cases.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Irwin Steingut, minority leader of the New York State Assembly, today pledged himself to work for "any program that Governor Lehman wants" as he left the White House after a conference with President Roosevelt.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19. -- Tommy Goodwin, 20-year-old star from Monroe, N.Y., rallied to retain his laurels in the midwinter amateur golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today. He defeated Brooks Glenn of Miami, 3 and 2, in the thirty-six-hole final.

The New York Giants brought another of their topliners into the fold yesterday with the announcement by Secretary Jim Tierney that the signed contract of Freddy Fitzsimmons, the chicken farmer of Arcadia, Calif., and skilled manipulator of the knuckleball, had just been received.

War and other public calamities are indeed close upon us if there is anything in the traditional portents, omens and signs. Scotland has a prehistoric monster of the most horrendous shape and size. A woman has given birth to a baby weighing 18 1/2 pounds.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 20. -- Ontario's gold mines produced bullion to the value of $43,728,144 last year, against $46,773,154 in 1932. The figures are based on gold at $20.67 an ounce. With adjustments for exchange, the production for 1933 amounted to $58,127,144, against $52,938,343 for 1932.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- An interesting sign of the times is the formation of the Wine and Food Society, which had its first meeting with an Alsatian luncheon at the Cafe Royal. The society, of which Andre Simon, author of "The Art of Living," is president, has been organized by bon vivants to raise the standard of eating and drinking in England.

The League of Composers presented a program of uncommon interest and value last night in Town Hall. The works performed were four. Two were by Hindemith and two by Stravinsky. The Stravinsky pieces -- the "Concertino" for string quartet; and concert excerpts from the "L'Histoire d'un Soldat" -- are in their kind established masterpieces.

Drug and food executives are looking for definite progress on revision of the laws governing their industry this week with the expected introduction of the so-called Beall amendment in the Senate and of a new bill by Representative Sirovich in the House, it was indicated here yesterday.

Professor Samuel B. Heckman, organizer and director of the educational clinic in the School of Education at City College, was guest of honor at a dinner last night in the Hotel Roosevelt in commemoration of the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the clinic.

BUSBY BERKELEY, who spends his tortured midnights wondering how he can make his new dance formation just a bit more intricate and fabulous than the last, is currently represented with the mass fan dance in "Fashions of 1934," at the Hollywood.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 18. -- As a few citizens had suspected, the late Henry Walters bequeathed the City of Baltimore not only a monument, but a monumental task in the internationally famous art gallery that bears his name.

The heavy trading in bonds on the Stock Exchange continued unabated during the two-hour trading period yesterday. Transactions reached $11,663,000, the biggest Saturday's business since Jan. 10, 1925. Prices of domestic corporation bonds were moderately higher, on the average, and those of leading foreign loans were irregularly higher.
Like the perfect hostess that she was, Alice worked hard to keep the conversation going, but the Mock Turtle and the Gryphon continued to look sadder and sadder.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 20. -- Professor Leo S. Rowe, director general of the Pan American Union, has left for Valparaiso to embark on the S.S. Santa Clara for the United States.

THE New Deal involves more than emergency organization. If it is to accomplish permanent results, its administrators must be guided in their planning by facts. Resources, methods, possibilities and limitations must be known before effects can be engineered; and such information comes not by guess, nor by hunch, nor by invocation, but by the passionless methods of research.

THE continuance of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's Beethoven cycle, the visit of the Philadelphia Orchestra with prize-winning Dalies Frantz as soloist, the season's first performance of "Siegfried" and Ludwig Hofmann's assumption of the role of Hans Sachs at the Metropolitan are among important musical events of the week.
Unemployed teachers seeking jobs and needle-trades workers protesting against "police brutality" besieged City Hall for three hours yesterday in a vain attempt to see Mayor LaGuardia.

RUSSIA'S repertory of national operas, principally by the group of "The Five," will again be drawn upon to enrich and vary an artistic season in New York. The Russian Opera Company, whose singing actors have before been heard here, are back from a tour afield and have announced "an extended season of popular priced Russian opera" to open Feb. 1 at the former Earl Carroll Theatre, now known as the Casino.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Stocks of foreign and domestic crude petroleum increased 582,000 barrels in the week ending Jan. 20, totaling 342,894,000 barrels, as compared with 342,312,000 in the preceding week, Secretary Ickes, Oil Administrator, announced today.

PARIS, Jan. 6. -- Sponsored by the Minister of Beaux Arts, the annual Barter Salon, in which artists of Paris exchange their landscapes and portraits for any goods or services that may be offered, has been especially successful this year.

PARIS, Jan. 20. -- A report in the American House of Representatives today of Nazi anti-French activities in the United grates was considered in official quarters here as a "confirmation of long-standing suspicions."

Applause greeted a speaker at the thirteenth annual luncheon of the Women's National Republican Club yesterday when she urged the women to rally to the defense of the Constitution against any "emasculating amendment or specious attack."
LONDON, Jan. 20. -- The British Government told timber importers here yesterday that they must not import more than 350,000 standards, or 5,775,000 cubic feet, of woods from Russia this year.
May I correct a misconception on the part of the average American with reference to Scotch whisky, I refer to the use and common understanding on this side of the water of the term "blend."

The American Car and Foundry Company brings out a new 36-foot twin screw cruiser in its exhibit at the motor-boat show. It also presents a 30-foot day cruiser, likewise a recent model, to bring the a.c.f. fleet to twenty stock boats of various sizes. The entire fleet, of course, is not included in the show because of space limitations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- A plea that the church advocate temperance to meet the new liquor situation resulting from repeal was made by the National Lutheran Council, which has just closed a two-day session here.

ALTHOUGH diplomatic relations between the United States and Soviet Russia were interrupted for sixteen years, it has required only three months since President Roosevelt took the first step toward recognition last October for the basis of an understanding to be created and for Ambassadors to take up their posts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18. -- There are many intriguing features in the strange tragedy which brought Dr. Alice Wynekoop, elderly and respected physician, before a jury on the charge of murdering her daughter-in-law. Devotees of detective fiction have abandoned their favorite devisers of mystery to follow the trial now in progress.

Engineers from the Finance Department and from the staff of Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, are cooperating in a thorough survey of the partly completed $12,000,000 city prison on Rikers Island, it was revealed yesterday.

THE remarkable development in certain annuals in the last few years is one of the promising things in horticulture in America. Annuals are coming more and more to be valued as flowers for cutting. The substantial petalage, the longer and stronger stems and the artistic colors of many of these newer varieties make them ideal for vases, bouquets and flower arrangements.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The historic slopes of Lookout Mountain, rising above Chattanooga, are to become a part of the National Parks system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- A "tentative plan" for public ownership and operation of the railroads was transmitted to President Roosevelt by the Interstate Commerce Commission today in a voluminous report by Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Transportation, on the progress made under the Emergency Railroad Transportation Act.

THIS beautifully bound and printed anthology will interest and delight students of Elizabethan literature and interest those writers who are concerned with the subject of patronage and its effect upon the creative artist. The sources are first editions, either in original or in photostat or in facsimile form.

Your editorial "Conservative Soviet Pedagogy" undoubtedly pleased many of our conservative pedagogues (believe it or not, there are many of them still extant). I myself, whom Professor Tugwell would, no doubt, term a reactionary, was very much interested to learn that Soviet Russia has abandoned revolutionary methods of education and has returned to conservative methods.

FROM up Nyack way comes a rumor that Charles MacArthur and Ben Hecht are spending the Winter months jotting down acts and scenes on a typewriter. One who has watched them at it prepares to take oath that the pair are writing another play.

A VERY useful and wholesome book is this by James Hayden Tufts, who, after many years of service in the chair of philosophy in the University of Michigan, is using the rich and mellowed wisdom of an emeritus in the study of the origin, moral quality and significance of the manners and customs, the social habits and group ideas and impulses, of Americans as a nation.

The library of Mrs. Henry D. Hughes of Philadelphia, comprising fine bindings, books illustrated by Cruikshank, Rowlandson, Alken, and other English artists, literature relating to the fine arts, French illustrated books, and first editions and other volumes, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries on Thursday afternoon and evening and Friday afternoon.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20. -- A decree signed by Joseph Stalin and Premier Molotoff and published today opens up a new channel through which collectivized and individual peasants may sell their grain surpluses. The decree states in part:

The sudden and unheralded appearance before Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan yesterday of former Inspector Thomas W. Mullarkey, who demanded back pension checks of more than $6,600 while he was listed as missing since 1931, forecast drastic changes in departmental regulations.

PANAMA, R.P., Jan. 17. -- A survey of the activities of the government-owned Panama Railroad Company has been started here by Marshall E. Dimock, Associate Professor of Public Administration of the University of Chicago. The final report will be made available to Secretary of War Bern, although the survey is being made independently of the government, according to Professor Dimock.

A novel little exhibition of drawings is on in the lobby of the Rivoli Theatre. Six artists -- Diego Rivera, Howard Chandler Christy,: McClelland Barclay, James Montgomery Flagg, Hayden Hayden and Bradshaw Crandall -- were asked to preview "Gallant Lady," the moving picture starring Ann Harding, and to draw his own impression. The result reveals interesting differences both in viewpoint and method.

THE lack of comprehensive treatment of the history of New York State as a whole has been evident for many years. No spasm of Babbittry is needed to call attention to this deficiency, which nine historians of importance emphasized in a fifty-six-page pamphlet published in 1915 on "The Need of a History of New York."

Price movements on local commodity excanges yesterday were irregular, as sugar and rubber again took the spotlight with vigorous rallies. Changes in the other staples were of relatively small proportions. Trading was in fair volume.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Walter E. Edge, former Governor of New Jersey and Senator from that State, as well as Ambassador to France under President Hoover, today declined to accept the Republican nomination for Governor of his State.

IT'S a pretty far cry and something more than a stone's throw from the dank shadows of Shubert Alley or the stuffy quarters of a Forty-fifth Street theatrical producer to the large, airy offices in the new Department of Commerce building here in Washington which are inhabited by Sol A. Rosenblatt, division administrator for the NRA in the entertainment field.

LAKE PLACID. -- This resort is knee-deep in the heaviest snow blanket of the season. Winter sports conditions are at their best, calling the skier to the trails and ski jumps and the bobsledders to the run, now available for its full mile-and-a-half length.

Thomas H. Beck, chairman of the President's Wild Life Conservation Committee, will attend the twentieth conference of the American Game Association which is to open in this city tomorrow. It is likely that on Tuesday Commissioner Beck will reveal the entire wild water-fowl program of his committee.

Myra Hess, pianist, gave what was announced as her only New York recital of the season yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall before an audience that packed the auditorium and overflowed a hundred strong onto the stage.

A LOAN exhibition of oils, watercolors and drawings from the collection of Robert Laurent is hung in the gallery of the Art Students League. Maufra, Van Dongen, Vlaminck, Redon, Despiau, Utrillo and many of the leading contemporary American artists are represented in the half-hundred works on view.

The expression "stabilization of the currency" is used to express different ideas. Stabilization of the gold value of the dollar is one thing and to attain this it is necessary to make the paper currency definitely and permanently exchangeable for a fixed amount of gold.

PARIS, Jan. 20. -- Additional quota allotments on American meat and dairy products were announced by the Foreign Ministry to the United States Embassy today. The principal articles covered are frozen and salted meats, hams, sausages and condensed milk.

BERLIN. THE German poet Stefan George died at Locarno in the night between Dec. 3 and 4, 1933. With him we lost a remarkable and powerful personality hardly known to the general masses, who had heard of him little except some oddities and who did not comprehend the proud isolation of his lonely life.

PARIS, Jan. 20. -- Former Premier Andre Tardieu lashed out at all and sundry in a lecture yesterday on the moral and material position of France. He spoke before the Geographical Society. Even his mordant pessimism never found fuller expression than in his concluding phrases:

A substantial increase in sales of machinery and machine tools during the current year was predicted here yesterday by Hermann H. Lind, managing director of the National Machine Tool Builders' Association. Since last March, when the industry came to an absolute standstill, both foreign and domestic orders have picked up steadily, Mr. Lind said, and a relatively sharp improvement can be depended upon for this year.

OTTAWA, Jan. 20 (AP). -- The Ottawa Senators won a sensationally played National Hockey League 5 to 4, tonight and displaced the idle New York Americans in fourth place in the International division standing.

THERE are less arduous ways of exploring the wonderworld of ice than those chosen by Byrd and Ellsworth. In Winter you can conduct an Antarctic expedition in your own garden Take a microscope along and you will perhaps make a greater variety of discoveries than you could hope to make from an airplane flying over the South Polar Continent.

Los ANGELES, Jan. 19. TWO New York hits -- one current and one from last season -- are at present on view for the edification of local playgoers. The former is "Sailor, Beware!" in its third week at the Mayan, and the latter is "Autumn Crocus," which opened last Sunday at Mr. Duffy's El Capitan with the whole film colony turning out to see the famous Francis Lederer in his original role.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 20 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt stood bareheaded in the rain for half an hour today to watch a rehearsal of a birthday party which patients at the Warm Springs Foundation plan in honor of the President, their part-time neighbor.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Barry Ryan, seeded sixth, was eliminated in his first match in the New Jersey squash tennis championship at the Short Hills Club today. He was defeated in the only upset of the opening day by Frank Brodil of the Columbia U.C., 15 -- 10, 8 -- 15, 15 -- 12.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Jan. 18. -- The Civil Works Administration is in the dog house so far as its operation in Southern California is concerned. The task of providing 60,000 jobs on short notice proved too much for the sketchy organization to bear up under, and charges of political favoritism and malfeasant handling of the machinery have led to an investigation which promises startling revelations.
In a keenly fought match, Charles Gill vanquished Alfred De Oro Jr., 50 to 44, in the national amateur three-cushion title play at the Capitol academy yesterday.

As the Italian liner Conte di Savoia was backing out of her slip, Pier 59, at 1 P.M. yesterday, a tardy passenger, accompanied by a group of friends, strolled down the pier and casually watched the liner being sent out into midstream. Without any apparent anxiety, she walked up to a passenger representative and said:

Largest of all the boats on display in the Motor Boat Show is a fifty-four-foot twin-screw motor yacht which heads the display of the Wheeler Shipyard of Brooklyn. Eight craft are in the display, ranging down to a twenty-six-foot semi-shelter sea skiff.

Several small lots of municipal bonds and warrants to be redeemed this month and later, together with one entire industrial issue and parts of two industrial and realty loans for payment in February, composed most of the securities called last week for retirement before their dates of maturity.

Mayor LaGuardia applied yesterday to the State Advisory Board of the Federal Public Works Administration for Federal loans of $2,139,900 to complete two dock improvements on the Hudson and to provide a new electrical system at City College.

This is another of the Merle Armitage monographs. It contains, besides reproduced examples of the artist's work and Mr. Armitage's comment, contributions by Reginald Poland and Edward Weston; also a brief biographical sketch. Mr. Poland, in his appraisal, thus quotes Arthur Millier, art editor of The Los Angeles Times:

Marmaduke M. Mizzle, the energetic and adventurous Mincing Lane caraway seed merchant, has just been heard from again by his friends, the spice merchants of Water Street, but his position is very precarious. The chances that he will succeed in extricating himself from the dangers by which he is surrounded are remote.

THE question "How many jobs have been created in the administration of the New Deal?" was raised in Washington recently. The answer is somewhat involved. But the Civil Service Commission in a survey made public early this month revealed that between June 30 and Nov. 30 last the number of officers and employes in the Federal executive civil service had increased by 22,603.

THE Metropolitan Opera Company announces that its annual Wagner matinee cycle outside the regular subscription will begin this year with "Tannhauser," Friday afternoon Feb. 9, and conclude with "Die Meistersinger," Thursday afternoon, March 15.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 20. -- The Columbia wrestling team defeated Princeton in the Tigers' gymnasium today, 19 -- 11. The visitors were credited with one fall, a default and three time advantages.

THERE may be a limited number of plots, but new ways of telling a story are forever bobbing up, sometimes setting a fashion, oftener arousing a momentary, interest. For "First Love and Last" Mr. Coxe has found a new way or at least has carried a recognized method to such an extreme that it must count as new.

Preliminary plans are being made for the sixth annual Russian Students Ball, which will be held on Feb. 9 in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. As in past years, many prominent Russians residing in New York are sponsoring the event in the interests of unemployed students of the Russian Alumni and Students Association.

The auction sale of the "Treasures of Carniola," the collection of prehistoric antiquities excavated by the late Duchess Paul Friedrich of Mecklenburg, which was scheduled to take place at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday, has been postponed until next Friday afternoon. The collection will be on view until the time of sale.

BOSTON, Jan. 20. -- Plans for establishing a $10,000 book fund in memory of President Calvin Coolidge were announced today by the New England Historic Genealogical Society. The fund, which is being raised by a private subscription sponsored by eight prominent members of the society, is to be known as the Calvin Coolidge Book Fund and will be used in acquiring additions to the society's library at 9 Ashburton Place.
Dr. Lewis Freeman Mort, head of the English department at City College since 1897, will retire at the end of the present semester, it was announced yesterday by President Frederick B. Robinson.

FROM a little town in South Serbia, Klinovo, comes a strange tale of an unusual record of longevity. Stoyan and Yelka Dimitriyevitch a few months ago celebrated their 100th wedding anniversary. Stoyan is 123 years old and Yelka is 119.

Read this story fast enough and it's a rousing mystery thriller. The writing is in a pseudo-sophisticated, cosmopolitan style, a bit tinny round the edges. But the story simply bristles with plot and counter-plot. It's rather dizzying to follow, but you'll probably have the will to hang on.

WILLIAM POWELL, who was a villain before he became a hero, has emerged with his customary eclat as the star of "Fashions of 1934" at the Hollywood. It was back in 1907 that Mr. Powell, a native of Pittsburgh, became interested in dramatics, and he is prepared to prove that his entrance on the amateur stage had no connection with the panic of that year.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 19. -- Under the auspices of the government of Chile the second Pan-American Conference on Education will be held here in September.

Ill and needy children at St. Mary's Hospital will be the beneficiaries of a recital to be given by Ruth Slenczynski, 8-year-old pianist, next Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Already many boxes and seats for the benefit have been purchased.

Mayor LaGuardia's pre-election promises to develop municipal markets began to take shape yesterday with a surprise visit to the Bronx Terminal market. In addition, he disclosed he would start a farmers' market, to which farmers could bring produce for direct sale to consumers, at 150th Street and Cromwell Avenue, the Bronx.

THERE is, as a matter of course, but one main objective for the actor -- his audience. His fame, his welfare, his artistic achievement rest, not on the favor of friends, the verdict of critics, the estimation of his director nor the satisfaction he may give himself by his exploit, but on the attitude of a group of spectators who have paid box-office, cutrate or speculator's prices to see him act.

ONE word led to another and from thence to such strange topics as the mysterious disappearance of the distinguished Lieut. Col. P.H. Fawcett, D.S.O., in Central Brazil in 1925 and the astonishing discovery that there are yoicks in Matto Grosso.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20. -- Coming from behind four times during the game, the Canadiens tonight defeated the Rangers for the first time this season, 5 -- 4, before a crowd of 10,000. By winning, the Canadiens tightened their hold on second position in the international group of the National Hockey League. The Rangers lead in the American group.

While motoring homeward after a vacation in Canada, Peter Clancy and his incomparable valet, Wiggar, happen upon a murder mystery in the mountains of Northern New Jersey. The local police have no idea that it is either a murder or a mystery, but Clancy is almost instantly aware that Dr. Lacasse could not possibly have shot himself.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- In his report Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, presents his conclusions as follows:
After prices had risen to within 15 points of the week's high mark, realizing brought a setback and a net loss of 8 to 12 points in active trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

NEXT week looks, from this not too remote distance, like a rather hectic time. On Monday, Jan. 29, "The Joyous Season" is listed to open at the Plymouth and "Hotel Alimony" at the Royale. On Wednesday "A Hat, a Coat, a Glove" is to enter the Selwyn and "Theodora, the Quean" is to have its premiere at the Forrest.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Big Bill Tilden went 1 up on Ellsworth Vines in their tennis tour tonight by defeating the Californian in a gruelling five-set match, 9 -- 7, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, before a capacity throng of 5,200 spectators at the Broadway Armory.

THE traditional marketing system is to be abolished by the elementary and junior high schools of Newton. In the senior high school the problem is still being studied, although on account of college entrance requirements the difficulties are more perplexing there than in the lower grades.
To those who have had a part in the earlier revisions of the Federal income and estate tax loans, the recent news from Washington sounds very familiar.

BANFF. -- The eighteenth annual Winter carnival of the Banff Winter Sports Association will be held from Jan. 31 to Feb. 4, inclusive, when all outdoor snow and ice games will be featured. Visitors from all parts of the continent attend this annual event at Alberta's mountain resort.

BOSTON, Jan. 20. -- Princeton defeated Harvard at hockey, 5 to 2, tonight to score its second victory of the season over the Crimson and capture the series with its Cambridge rival for the first time in twenty years.

DAFFODIL fanciers, whose number is legion in this part of the world, look forward to the Spring of 1934 with unusual interest. They expect the old familiar forms of their flower as a matter of course, and they will not be disappointed, for the Daffodil is always faithful, and more than faithful, rewarding its friends with a wealth of bloom that grows richer with every new year.

LEOPOLD ATLAS -- who is the literary father of "Wednesday's Child," at the Long-acre -- was born in Brooklyn in 1907. He attended Boys High School, where he made something of a name for himself as an athlete, playing varsity football and lacrosse.

PUPILS in the first, second and third grades of Horace Mann School at Teachers College are now taking a comprehensive course in typewriting, complete with drills suited to their age. These drills are included in a typewriter textbook just introduced in the classes, which is believed to be the first book of its kind ever published for elementary school children.

The annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers will open Tuesday morning at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, and will continue for four days. From 1,500 to 2,000 electrical engineers from many parts of the country are expected to attend.

Staging an uphill fight in the second half, a fighting St. Francis College five scored an upset victory over St. John's University, 27 to 26, before a capacity crowd in the DeGray gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- Princeton's hard-hitting indoor polo team rode to an 11-6 victory over the Army trio in the feature event of a busy day of sports at the United States Military Academy today.

ONCE upon a time I read some statistics about play production in New York, which ran about like this: One hundred and fifty to two hundred plays are produced each season, twelve or fourteen of these make a small profit, and only four or five actually earn big money for all concerned.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Jan. 20. -- Junius A. Richards and Danforth Miller of the Rockaway Hunting Club, runners-up a year ago in the Piping Rock Invitation Handicap squash racquets doubles tournament, gained the semi-final round of the second annual competition tonight on the Piping Rock courts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Secretary Ickes as Oil Administrator today approved in modified form the oil purchase and marketing agreements submitted to him by the industry as a plan to stabilization. The agreements become effective immediately, the Secretary having been advised that refiners representing 85 per cent of the industry had signed, and that a total acquiescence of 95 per cent was expected.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 20. -- Cornell's basketball team scored a last-minute victory over the Dartmouth quintet, 40 to 35, before a crowd of 2,500 in the alumni gymnasium tonight. The victory was the Ithacans' second in two starts in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Encouraged by the favorable reaction accorded their proposals in Washington last week, a committee of foreign trade leaders here yesterday began laying the groundwork for a "National Foreign Trade Bank" to be capitalized at $30,000,000 and with resources of around $300,000,000, for use in financing export and import transactions.

IT has always seemed to this department remarkable that low comedy is so rare in the theatre. Here it is the middle of the season when the show shops are supposed to be bustling, and yet Fannie Brice and Willie Howard are the only proper clowns on view.

WITH its Latin and Greek and archaic English, its multitudinous array of footnotes and its elaborate index, this simple volume has the value of an oyster which, submerged in the depths and hard to open, yet yields pearls of great price.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Colgate's undefeated basketball team ended the nineteen-game winning streak of Syracuse tonight by downing the visitors, 21 -- 16, in a game that was so closely fought that much of the time minutes would pass before a player had a free shot at the basket.

The forward surge of business activity in the metropolitan area since the beginning of the year was continued last week, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the New York Credit Men's Association, which found that two-thirds of the companies surveyed had increased their sales.
TRENTON, Jan. 19. -- There is evidence that the New Deal is taking root in New Jersey, a bit of the civilized world which is not so very new, and yet not so old that it cannot lear a few new tricks.

A monopoly that New Utrecht had held for nine years in the Stuyvesant interscholastic indoor track and field meet came to a sudden and surprising termination at the 102d Engineers Armory last night when the completely unheralded Abraham Lincoln combination upset the perennial P.S.A.L. champions to win the team trophy with 30 points.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18. -- Sidney Summerfield, clerk of the Cook County Marriage License Bureau, had just finished reading an editorial in his favorite newspaper setting forth its none too illuminating views on the currency question. The currency question interests Mr. Summerfield because pay checks have been distressingly irregular in the county service of late.

Leading throughout by a good margin and aided by a six-goal handicap, the Riding Club defeated Squadron C by 16 1/2 to 11 1/2, in a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League class B game last night at the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn.

THE dramatic events of the last week have shaped a new monetary program for the United States. It is embodied in a bill drawn under the President's direction and now pending before Congress. At five important points this measure proposes to change the existing situation:

There has been an encouraging subscription for the preview performance of "A Hat, a Coat, a Glove," Friday night at the Selwyn Theatre, which has been taken over by the directors of St. Timothy's League to raise funds for the East Harlem Nursing and Health Service.

An ex-convict and the widow of a beer-garden owner, who was murdered last September, were arrested yesterday in Brooklyn charged with homicide after the police had learned that the woman was at one time the beneficiary of $22,000 in insurance policies on the life of her husband.

Children engaged in professional work who attend the Children's Professional School will be aided by a forthcoming revival of George M. Cohan's "Forty-five Minutes From Broadway." There will be two performances of the production, which will be personally supervised by the author, on the afternoon of Feb. 2 and the other the night of Feb. 4, both at the Empire Theatre.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekcop, whose trial for the murder of her daughter-in-law was interrupted yesterday because her lawyers feared she might die, was feeling better early tonight in her private room in the Cook County jail.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- Mayor Leslie V. Bateman studied today recommendations of the National Municipal League with respect to this city's financial situation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The House passed the administration Gold Bill, 360 to 40, and recessed at 7 P.M. until noon Monday. The Senate Banking and Currency Committee held a hearing on the measure, the Senate itself being in recess until Monday.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 18. -- The past year has witnessed the repeal of much puritanical legislation in various sections of the South, and the Virginia General Assembly, which convened a week ago, apparently is in step with the procession.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 26. -- On Nov. 2, 1917, Arthur (later Earl) Balfour, on behalf of the British Government, issued a declaration to world Jewry stating:

TORONTO. EVERY four years there is held a gathering of mathematicians, known as the International Congress of Mathematicians. At the next meeting and each one thereafter two gold medals will be awarded to mathematicians selected for their outstanding contributions to mathematics by an international committee appointed for the purpose.

THE admission of the Fulton Fish Market merchants that they have paid racketeers for protection because, they said, they could not get protection from the police, and the coordinated efforts for the first time of prosecutors and the police to reduce this form of extortion on business, again serve to focus public attention on an evil which has festered under the surface of New York life for many years.

THREATENED with Federal regulation, the New York Stock Exchange is making a desperate fight for continued existence as an independent, self-governing institution. The focal point of the clamor for government control or supervision, it finds itself carrying the banner for the other security and commodity exchanges which are equally involved.

Prominent graduates of Vassar Collage are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "La Traviata" the afternoon of Feb. 2 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over by members of the Vassar Club to augment their scholarship fund. Many boxes and seats have already been subscribed for.

In a letter yesterday to President Roosevelt, Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, called the reduction in CWTA work "most alarming," and urged the "overwhelming necessity of an adequate plan and an appropriation for it."

The increased number of buyers in town and the placing of heavier orders than were expected point to an excellent Spring season, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. If the volume of business continues large, out-of-town retailers will make trips to the local markets more frequently during this year, the group said.

LONDON, Jan. 19. -- A bill labeled "anti-dumping" has been placed on the docket of Parliament by a group of private members who will endeavor to have it considered early in the approaching session of the House of Commons.

Even without the gold sovereigns scattered about the scene the murder of Lord Wallace would be mysterious enough. The body is found lying on the sand, far above high-water mark, and there is not a single footprint, or any other mark, to indicate how he or his slayer reached the spot or how the latter went away.
Joseph W. Harriman, former chairman of the board of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, must stand trial on the charge that he misapplied more than $1,000,000 of the funds of the bank.
