The text has been sent to the United States, Germany, Italy and France, and Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, made a brief announcement to that effect to the House of Commons today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29. -- Miss Virginia Vanderbeck, fourth seeded player, was eliminated in the second round of the women's Philadelphia and district squash racquets championship tournament at the Cynwyd Club today.
FORTALEZA, Brazil, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Italy's first attempt to span the South Atlantic with a regular airmail plane ended in a smash-up on the jungle coast of Brazil before dawn today.

Recognition of the Mendieta Government in Cuba inevitably involved the relief of a people who had been living for a long time in a state of hand-to-mouth existence. The disturbances, the strikes, the rioting and looting since the fall of MACHADO, in fact, conditions verging on chaos, were economic as well as political in their origin.
Your editorial of Jan. 1, relative to Grace Adams on "The Rise and Fall of Psychology," strikes me as somewhat less than fair in evaluating the work being done by our psychologists.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Jan. 29. -- The Los Angeles bridegroom, who was shot dead in his automobile here on Saturday morning while he and his bride were en route to New York, supposedly to collect $110,000 cash, was a native of Turkey, who was once held in Chicago for deportation, it was revealed today.

The best sale in three years for the Metropolitan Opera's annual Wagner matinee cycle has been recorded thus far, it was announced last night by Earle Lewis, box-office treasurer. The subscription male closes tonight and single tickets will be available beginning on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Threats of a strike of 75,000 steel workers and serious disaffection among 450,000 steel employes all over the United States were brought here today by a union delegation which will meet President Roosevelt tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The entire Civil Works Administration staff in Colorado was dismissed tonight by Harry L. Hopkins, CWA Administrator, on a charge of "irregular if not illegal proceedings."

The Harvard Club No. 1 team and the Squash Club team were winners respectively in Groups I and II in the metropolitan Class B squash racquets competition yesterday. Both teams have perfect records, Harvard No. 1 having won six in a row and the Squash Club five in a row.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- The British Museum authorities tonight announced they had received a cablegram from Archbishop Porphyrios of Sinai saying the Monastery of Sinai claimed ownership of the Codex Sinaiticus, fourth century Bible manuscript which the British have just purchased from the Soviet for 100,000.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 29. -- A call for the United States to modify its tariffs and abandon its "intense nationalism," was sounded here tonight in a speech by Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury.
" All the King's Horses," a musical show, opens tonight at the Shubert Theatre, and "American, Very Early" opens at the Vanderbilt.

The first plan under which holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates contemplate taking over the property securing their holdings was submitted for approval yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler. The proposal, involving an apartment house, was taken under consideration by Justice Frankenthaler.

The second of the concerts of modern chamber music that the Roth String Quartet is giving in Steinway Hall took place last night in that intimate auditorium. The program, the contents, of which had been changed since the initial announcements, consisted of Darius Milhaud's Seventh Quartet, Roy Harris's "Variations in Three Movements" and Erno Dohnanyi's Quartet in D-flat major. No. 2.
" Frontier Marshal," with George O'Brien and Irene Bentley, opened at the Mayfair last night.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 29. -- The coffee market here is excited and exporters are filing protests with the government on the "insidious" rumor from the United States that Brazil intends to consign 1,000,000 bags of coffee to the United States market.

The New Music School, which will begin its initial term next week, opened officially last night at the American Dalcroze Institute with a lecture by Roger Sessions, one of the heads of the school, on "The Composer and Musical Education.''

In a letter sent to the stockholders of the General Baking Company, the management has replied to criticisms directed against it by a group of shareholders headed by William Deininger and Louis J. Kolb, which is soliciting proxies for the annual meeting on Feb. 15.

Malvina Hoffman's large exhibition, composed chiefly of the "Races of Mankind" material prepared for the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, will open with a reception and preview from 3 to 6 o'clock this afternoon at the Grand Central Galleries in the Grand Central Terminal.
A majority of the members of the Tammany executive committee are in agreement that John F. Curry must go as leader of Tammany Hall, it was asserted yesterday by persons opposed to his leadership.
For the first time in the history of New York City a complete survey of its dwellings, from tenements to private homes, is to be made. Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The text of the Currency and Monetary Bill follows:

Reports received here yesterday that the difficulties met by the international rubber conference in Amsterdam in regulating production had been ironed out caused a rally to the highest prices in nearly four years in the markets here and in London.
DUNEDIN, N.Z., Jan. 29. -- The Wyatt Earp is tied up to the wharf at Dunedin, where her polar supplies are being unloaded and stored until my future plans are definitely decided.
PARIS, Jan. 29. -- The British Government's memorandum on disarmament is not likely to satisfy French opinion.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 29. -- Striving for outright possession of the Walter J. Travis Memorial Trophy, Carl M. Dann Jr. of the Dubsdread Country Club at Orlando, Fla., won the qualifying medal in the seventh annual National Championship of Club Champions on the St. Augustine links today.
In a letter relating to the St. Lawrence Waterway Treaty published by THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan 15, and bearing the signature D.H. Primrose, there appears the following paragraph:

Two reports prepared by the Executive Committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, of which Laurence B. Elliman is chairman, will be referred to the chamber for action at its regular meeting on Thursday at 65 Liberty Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- A recommendation by Admiral William H. Standley, Chief of Naval Operations, that 1,184 naval aircraft be bought over a five-year period coincident with the naval building and replacement program already advanced by the administration was approved today by the House Naval Affairs Committee.

The Physicians' Wives' League of Greater New York, a non-sectarian organization of 500 members, has severed its connection with the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs on the ground that a resolution backed by the league endorsing the boycott of German goods had been rejected on a technicality by the federation.

The appointment of Joseph Johnson as general manager of the Triborough Bridge Authority was made after Tammany Leader John F. Curry had said that he "thought well" of Mr. Johnson, it was testified yesterday at the trial of John Stratton O'Leary, member of the Authority, on charges of incompetence, and neglect of duty.

Samuel Seabury announced yesterday his acceptance of the post of special counsel for the Board of Estimate in negotiations with the rapid transit companies looking to their unification with the city's own subway system. He declared that he would not accept compensation for his services.

All classifications of bonds averaged higher on the Stock Exchange yesterday in trading approximating $15,000,000. United States Government bonds jumped 1-32 to 11-32 point in a turnover of $1,747,000, the largest in several days. Many domestic corporation issues were up a point or more and leading foreign loans finished irregularly higher.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Arbitrary establishment of an international price for wheat below which the principal producing nations would refuse to export their grain on the world market is likely to result from negotiations now under way at London, Chester Davis, head of the Farm Administration, said today.

Frills in education! Just what is a "frill"? As a woman, a picture comes to my mind of those dainty little ruffles, of the pleatings and ruchings and pipy frills that go into the making of a charming costume. Strictly speaking, they are not necessary for warmth or decency, but how I should hate to see a dress stripped of all its frills. Any wool-sack would do just as well.

Rebuilding of the Republican party on a national scale as an extension of the activities of the Republican Builders, a body organized to reform the party in this State, was urged yesterday by Mrs. Ruth Pratt, member of the Republican National Committee.

Colonel Russel C. Martin of Los Angeles, commander-in-chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, who served under Generals Custer and Sheridan, visited this city yesterday for the first time since the Civil War and made his first visit to Grant's Tomb.

Title to the Codex Sinaiticus, the Greek Bible text acquired by the British Museum from the Soviet Government, is now claimed by St. Catherine's Monastery on Sinai Peninsula, whence the manuscript was carried off about the middle of the last century.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 29 (AP). -- A new attitude of optimism pervaded members of his family today as they remained alert for word from the kidnappers of Edward G. Bremer, 37-year-old banker seized Jan. 17 for $200,000 ransom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- In the War and Navy Departments here there is a division of opinion among our high command as to the imminence of a military crisis between Japan and Soviet Russia. But it may be of interest to report that their disagreement is only as to time; most of them expect a war.
George A. Saxton has been elected vice president and a director of Howard Robbins, Inc. Jules A. Schwertz has been appointed manager of the investment service department.
BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Take it from Eddie Shore, a man who knows, cheers sound much sweeter than jeers.

As one of his last official acts before retiring tomorrow, Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, will award the Rebecca Elsberg Memorial Prizes today to two pupils for "honorable character and scholarship." The ceremony will take place at 11 A.M. in Dr. O'Shea's office at 500 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Jan. 24 shows increases for the week of $44,000,000 in net demand deposits, $20,000,000 in time deposits and $73,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and decreases of $51,000,000 in loans and investments and $93,000,000 in government deposits.

PARIS, Jan. 29. -- Edouard Daladier has been chosen by President Lebrun as the man most likely to prove capable of putting order into the chaos of France's party-ridden Parliament and bring authority in the administration of justice and sound economy in the direction of finance.
The news columns of Jan. 22 carry an account of the report of the City Superintendent of Schools, Dr. O'Shea, in which is featured his prescription for the treatment of radicals in the school system.
Exports and imports into the United States by classifications during the calendar year 1933, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with 1932 and 1931 (000 omitted):

The City Athletic Club squash tennis team won the metropolitan Class C team championship for the second successive year yesterday when it defeated the Bayside Tennis Club team in the final match of the season.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- The LaGuardia Emergency Economy Bill, which would give the Board of Estimate broad powers to cut salaries, consolidate departments and effect economies by other means was reported in the Assembly at the session tonight without amendments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- It is the expectation of administration advisers conversant with the situation in New York that Frank Sinnott, acting postmaster in Brooklyn, will be appointed to succeed the late John H. McCooey on the Democratic National Committee.

JULES ROMAINS is an exciting writer. His "Men of Good Will," a "novel" that will, when it is completed, be as long or longer than Proust's "Remembrance of Things Past," may be exasperating in its labyrinthine form, its serpentine progression. But this sort of "novel" has its own quiet satisfactions. Strangely enough, these satisfactions are not particularly "modern."

Two raging fires, whipped to fury by a bitter northwest wind, swept large parts of the Canarsie and Flatbush districts of Brooklyn yesterday morning, causing property damage estimated at $160,000 and giving a small army of firemen a stiff battle for several hours.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Removal of any danger of Russian dumping appeared assured today at the close of the opening session of the third meeting of the International Advisory Wheat Commission.

Walter Marty of Fresno Junior College and the Olympic Club of San Francisco, the holder of the world's high jump record, arrived in New York yesterday for the Millrose games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. The 22-year-old youth, who has leaped 6 feet 8 3/8 inches, higher than any one ever went before, was ready to practice outdoors on a board floor at N.Y.U., but found it too cold.

Under the eyes of two armed thugs guarding her and three office associates as four accomplices of the thugs were looting the wholesale confectionery and tobacco store of Abraham Oriel at 111 East 113th Street, Miss Juliet Coffino, a book-keeper, presses a secreted alarm button last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Senator Long of Louisiana came back to the capital to rest today from lost election battles and to joke about being "challenged to a duel" by Ulic Burke, political ward leader in New Orleans.

Joseph Abrams, who won the tourney a year ago, led the Clinton tennis stars yesterday as he gained the third round of the De Witt Clinton High interscholastic indoor tournament at the 369th Regiment Armory.

MONTREAL, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press). -- Despite a comparatively poor week by his club, Charlie Conacher, right wing of the Maple Leafs, compiled seven points in four games to increase his lead in the race for National Hockey League scoring honors.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 29. -- The address of Ogden L. Mills here this evening before the Kansas Day Club was as follows:

Harry Van Arsdale Jr., business agent of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, and Max Rosenberg, a member, were convicted by a jury in General Sessions last night of assault in the first degree in connection with the shooting of a mem ber of an opposing faction in the union.

The second, or afterthought, notation this morning can but conclude that the world is a very cold place, indeed. Last evening there were winds on Forty-fifth Street, and grim spectres attacking the drama on the stage of the Royale Theatre.

Leaders of women's organizations, experts on international law and others paid tribute last night to Doris Stevens, chairman of the Inter-American Commission of Women, at a testimonial dinner at the Park Lane, honoring her success in obtaining international legislation for women at the recently concluded seventh Pan-American Conference in Montevideo.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 29. -- Following a decision of the Republican Joint Conference Committee, the Assembly adopted tonight a resolution forbidding passage of the Sales Tax Bill until adequate legislation can be enacted requiring every municipality to decrease its budget during the period in which any additional tax shall be effective.

Jens Nelson, Poughkeepsie inventor and farmer, who contends he is the son of Edward Albert Ridley and heir to the $3,000,000 estate of the murdered real estate operator, heard testimony for and against his claim before Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- Prices of hogs advanced today 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight to a new high mark since Nov. 29, the top being up 10 cents to $3.85, showing 35 cents above the peak of four days ago. The general average rose 5 cents to $3.60.
BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- The process of putting all Germans -- men, women and children -- into uniforms is making rapid progress.

The fleeting sea serpent of Loch Ness leaves at least one eminent reptile student unmoved. Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars, curator of mammals and reptiles at the Bronx Zoo, had just shown motion pictures yesterday of some animals almost as startling as sea serpents before the annual meeting of the School Nature League when he was asked his opinion of the Scottish monster.

CAMBRIDGE, Jan. 29. -- This has been the most memorable day in my life because in our small ten-horse-power car my husband and I gave a lift to the Queen of England when we found her stranded on the road.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- The stock markets were quiet today. The French Government crisis and uncertainty over the next step in the United States monetary policy were restricting factors. British funds continue to be sold. German bonds hardened in the foreign market.

New York is planning to mark today the fifty-second anniversary of the birth of President Roosevelt with a series of dinners, dances and pageants. They have been planned not only as a tribute to the President but, in at least forty of the events, as a contribution to a cause close to his heart, the Warm Springs Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

A general wave of buying came into the local commodity markets yesterday and carried nearly all prices to substantially higher levels. Silver and rubber were the features of the day. Trading was active. Cash prices also were higher.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 29. -- Devaluation of the dollar by 40 to 50 per cent is "altogether too great." Professor E.W. Kemmerer, Princeton University monetary expert, told more than 100 farm leaders, editors, rural bankers and business men at the forum of the Rutgers Institute of Rural Economics here today.

LIMA, Jan. 29. -- Transportation in this city was tied up when tram, bus and taxicab drivers unexpectedly began a twenty-four-hour strike at 6 o'clock this morning. A few tramcars operated under police guard. The textile workers adhered to their promise not to walk out, made last night to the Department Prefect.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29. -- Coming through the stretch with a fine burst of speed, J.J. Bauer's Chance Flight courageously overcame an early handicap to win by half a length in the six furlongs of the featured Granada Purse at Hialeah Park today.

Eleven of the twelve stage directors of the CWA plays held a protest meeting yesterday at the Hotel Lincoln, objecting to the cut of 23 per cent in salary affecting them and 150 players who are to participate in the twelve presentations. Also attending the meeting was Paul N. Turner, counsel of the Actors Equity Association.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- The wheat market broke today out of the narrow range it had held for two weeks on the Board of Trade and soared to the highest mark since Nov. 21 and closed at the top at gains of 2 1/8 to 3 1/8 cents a bushel.

Walter Damrosch, orchestra conductor, who observes his seventy-second birthday today, discussed the current musical situation yesterday afternoon at his home. He expressed the opinion that one of the most important musical issues of 1934 was the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's campaign for funds.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 29. -- The initial flight of Italy's bid for a transatlantic air mail service from Rome to Buenos Aires ended in a crash on the north coast of Brazil early this morning. The first plane, which left Rome on Saturday, and Dakar, Africa, yesterday, crashed on a remote beach near Fortaleza.

As a result of the delay by thousands of automobile owners, a last-minute rush to obtain new registration plates is "certain." Deputy Commissioner I. James Brody said yesterday at the Bureau of Motor Vehicles headquarters, 155 Worth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- President Roosevelt, as the absent guest tomorrow night at more than 5,000 birthday parties held in his honor, will broadcast from the White House his thanks "in behalf of the crippled children of the nation."

Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan ordered the department yesterday to "take all necessary steps to break the back of the policy racket within two weeks and to substantially eliminate it within thirty days."

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP). -- Two desperadoes who escaped Oklahoma State prison last August after they got permits to go fishing were wounded and captured here today by officers who beat their quarry to the draw.
DOUGLAS, Ariz., Jan. 29. -- John Dillinger, Indiana gang chieftain, was put in the city jail here tonight, after an airplane flight from Tucson, en route to Indiana.

The Lafontaine Blues of Montreal battled to a 3-to-3 tie with the Atlantic City Sea Gulls at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 8,000 persons saw the Jersey sextet, which trailed for the greater part of the game, knot the count late in the third session.

A further improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried May contracts within 3 points of recent high records, at which level the market met cotton and a setback causing net losses of 2 to 5 points.
A hockey triple-header, featured by an Eastern Amateur League game between the St. Nicholas sextet and the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club of Brooklyn will be held at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- President Roosevelt today signed the epoch-making Money Bill. The act, passed exactly as approved by the President, sequesters for the United States Treasury all gold held by the Federal Reserve Banks, grants authority to reduce the gold content of the dollar within a range of 40 to 50 per cent, and authorizes the establishment, with $2,000,000,000, of a stabilization fund for operations in foreign exchange.
" Hi, Nellie," featuring Paul Muni, will be presented at the Strand tonight at 8 o'clock.

The much examined and discussed football rules will be combed by the football coaches' rules committee in an all-day session at the New York Athletic Club on Saturday. Lou Little, Columbia coach and chairman of the committee, will preside.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The regulations issued today by the Treasury to implement the Monetary Bill signed by President Roosevelt follow in full:

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- In a speech charged with confidence as well as with defiance Chancellor Hitler tonight spread before the Reichstag the balance sheet of National Socialism's first year in office. It was the anniversary of his elevation to the Chancellorship and he spoke as the tribune and leader of the German people.

Net assets of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation on Dec. 31 were $26,028,000, according to a statement issued yesterday by the company in connection with the preparation of its annual report. This compares with $23,300,000 a year earlier.

After strongly assailing Hitlerism and endorsing the boycott of German goods before more than 2,000 members of Jewish women's organizations at the Hotel Astor yesterday, Mayor LaGuardia even more outspokenly condemned a school "machine or ring" which he said was blocking his administration and which he would fight when the time came.

Sales by department stores in December in this Reserve district were 4 1/2 per cent higher than in December, 1932, including liquor departments, and 1 1/2 per cent higher, excluding liquor sales, according to reports to the Federal Reserve Bank.

The Messrs. Cort and Abramson last evening gently waved a tattered emblem from the stage of the Shubert Theatre. The occasion was the first showing, to Forty-fourth Street and vicinity, of a musical show named "All the King's Horses."

For weeks England has been all het up about the latest list of Words and How Announcers Shall Say Them, put together and forth by the B.B.C. Committee on English Pronunciation, headed by the inevitable Mr. G.B. SHAW. The resulting letter-fall has been enormous.

Thomas I. Parkinson, William Roberts and Bertram Cutler, members of the board of directors of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, are charged with fraudulent misconduct toward policyholders in an equity suit filed in the Supreme Court yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- The Boerse observed the first anniversary of the Hitler rgime with an improvement in tone which led to minor advances. Business remafned quiet, but heavy industrials, machineries, automobiles, chemicals anc electrics were able to score gains exceeding 1 point, and some specialties gained above 2 points.

The performance of "By Your Leave" on the night of Feb. 19 at the Morosco Theatre has been taken over by the Menorah Writers and Artists Committee, which is made up of women members of the Menorah Association. The proceeds will be used for the cultural and education work of the association and for the publication of The Menorah Journal, a quarterly magazine featuring the work of American and European writers, scholars and artists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Eight of the Democratic California delegation of eleven in the House today endorsed Senator Johnson for the Democratic Senatorial nomination. They are Representatives McGrath, Church, Burke, Ford, Golden, Kremer, Lea and Buck.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Foreign nations owe the United States $12,710,451,610.40, of which all except about $2,000,000,000 is due from Great Britain, France and Italy, Secretary Morgenthau reported to the Senate today. He acted in response to a resolution recently adopted on motion of Senator Borah, and made no comment in transmitting the data.

The movement of ships in and out of the harbor will be of minor interest to William Larkin of Rosebank, S.I., after 4 o'clock this afternoon. For fifty-four years it has been his task to observe and report to land stations their arrivals and departures from the observation tower of the Western Union Telegraph Company at the Quarantine station down the bay.

A bridge tea will be given on Feb. 5 at the Plaza under the auspices of the women's auxiliary of Congregation Emanu-El for the benefit of the organization's philanthropic activities, which include a workroom for unemployed women.

The F.W. Woolworth Company reports for 1933 a net income of $28,690,884 after depreciation, amortization and Federal taxes, equal to $2.94 a share on the 9,750,000 shares of $10 par value capital stock outstanding. This is exclusive of a profit of $1,970,561 from the sale of stock of F.W. Woolworth Co., Ltd., of England.

Attempts to "synthetize prosperity" were attacked yesterday by Lammot du Pont, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., in issuing the company's annual pamphlet report. In recent months, he said, improvement in business and finance had been less certain than from March to July last year.
" A Hat, A Coat, A Glove" will have its premiere this evening at the Selwyn Theatre and "Theodora, the Quean," will open at the Forrest Theatre.
Jimmy McLarnin, world's welter- weight champion, will defend his title against Barney Ross, holder of the lightweight championship, in this city on May 23 if present plans materialize.

With a great many stocks rising into new high ground for the movement, and some of them improving their best figures for 1933, Wall Street seemed yesterday to be specially proud of the share market. In turnover and in the number of stocks traded, the market was the largest since the third week of last July.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, BAY OF WHALES, Antarctica, Jan. 29. -- In the broken and pitted pressure ridge and crevasses west of Little America forty-four marooned men of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition tonight were struggling with dog teams and the strength of their backs to save the stores of Winter provisions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The greatest peace-time navy in the country's history was voted today by the House in passing the Vinson Naval Replacement Bill, providing a program to cost $475,000,000 to $570,000,000. The measure went through without a record vote after six hours of debate.

The estate of Benjamin Griffen, father-in-law of Bernard M. Baruch, was appraised yesterday at $270,716 gross and $252,689 net, of which $256,928 was in securities, including 4,500 shares of Chesapeake Ohio Railroad common, worth $180,000. Mr. Griffen, who died Sept. 25 last, gave half the residuary estate to his daughter, Anne G. Baruch, and the other half to his son. Cecil Griffen.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Sports-page heroes, fans and press-box toilers gathered tonight in Philadelphia sportdom's big round-up -- the annual dinner of the Sporting Writers Association -- and the presence of a Cabinet member set a new record for prestige among the honored guests.
Play-off hopes burn more brightly for the New York Americans as the result of a victory over the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

KINGS PARK, L.I., Jan. 30. -Dr. Charles S. Parker, superintendent of the Kings Park Hospital here, reported this afternoon that the charges recently made by John Cummings, Federal veteran investigator attached to the United States Veterans Hospital at Northport, that attendants of the local institution were selling and "swapping" cigarettes intended for World War veteran patients, have been found to be wholly without foundation.

At the 1932 annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association, and after the report of its committee on public defenders had been presented and discussed, a resolution was adopted that the association approve the principle of public defenders, and that it refer that subject to the Commission on Administration of Justice of New York State, with the request that it receive most serious consideration.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30. -- An earthquake described by University of California seismologists as "very sharp" was felt in widely separated parts of the West today.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- Premier Edouard Daladier has put his reputation as France's strong man to the severest test. He has formed a Cabinet which is weak in personalities and even weaker in parliamentary support.
May one who has had first-hand opportunity of comparing living costs in New York with those in other cities commend you for bringing up the subject in your editorial "New York a Liberal Employer"?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- President Roosevelt will issue an executive order, probably tomorrow, for a poll of the employes of the National Steel Company on the proposal of the steel men's union for an independent election.

WITH the runners warming up for the Wanamaker mile and other events on the Millrose program, the merits of the loose-lap system of conducting track meets once again come to the fore. An official in Boston a few nights ago wrenched a lap out of a mile race and was about to make off with it when he was discovered.

Affidavits by two former Welfare Island prisoners, charging that "trusties" had told other inmates that paroles could be arranged by seeing James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, were made public in part yesterday by the Society for the Prevention of Crime.

The first large industrial election ever to be held in this city under the NRA to determine the right of workers to affiliate with a union of their own choice will take place here this week, when the regional labor board will supervise a vote to be taken in nineteen of forty-five shoe factories in various parts of the city.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Completely disregarding a special message in which Governor Lehman strongly urged passage of Mayor LaGuardia's Emergency Economy Bill, New York City members of the Governor's own party brought about the defeat in the Assembly of that measure today.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 30. -- The Yale quintet tonight defeated Georgetown, 34 -- 26, in a game in which the score was four times tied. Yale took an early lead, the visitors surged to a slight advantage just before half time and were overtaken early in the second half. From then on the Blue was never headed.

Daily average gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,222,750 barrels, compared with 2,294,600 barrels in the precedin week, a decline of 71,850 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 67,400 barrels in Oklahoma's daily output and a gain of 9,700 in that of Texas were the principal changes.

A doughty handful of centenarians, with a few score nonagenarians, octogenarians and septuagenarians in the supporting ranks, held a party yesterday afternoon at the Home of Old Israel, 70 Jefferson Street, in honor of the birthday anniversary of a mere stripling of 52, Franklin D. Roosevelt.

TOKYO, Jan. 30. -- Japan's wish to cultivate American good-will, which Foreign Minister Koki Hirota expressed recently in the Diet, was amplified tonight by Katsuji Debuchi, until recently Ambassador to the United States. In addressing the Japan-America Society he invited American business to extend its trade in Eastern Asia by cooperation with Japan.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The text of Governor Lehman's special message follows:
WASHINGTON, Jan 30. -- Ogden L. Mills's Topeka speech was regarded today by many Democratic leaders as the keynote of his platform as a candidate for the Republican nomination for President in 1936.

Refusing to recognize defeat of his economy measure by the Legislature, Mayor LaGuardia made plans last night to appeal to the people of the city and the State to support him in his fight for the powers he deems necessary to balance the city budget.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30. -- The President Roosevelt's birthday ball for the benefit of Georgia Warm Springs Foundation, held tonight at the Everglades Club, set a new high mark here for social activities. Guests, numbering more than 500, overflowed the orange gardens, the ballroom, the patios and great lounge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Overwhelmed by an amazing outpouring of testimonials to the affection and admiration in which he is held, President Roosevelt thanked the nation over the radio tonight for "the happiest birthday I have ever known."

In its preliminary statement for 1933 the United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of $36,519,000 after all charges but before dividends, compared with $71,175,704 in 1932. After preferred dividends of $7,205,620 the deficit last year was $43,724,901, or less than half the 1932 deficit of $91,891,867.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- The Huguenot Trust Company, taken over on Jan. 2 by Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, will open for business tomorrow morning, it was announced tonight. The State Superintendent filed with the Westchester County Clerk today a copy of his order permitting the bank to resume business.

The American Olympic Committee announced through Secretary Frederick W. Rubien yesterday the personnel of five of its sports sub-committees for the 1936 Olympic Games. They are the track and field, women's swimming, weight lifting, fencing and rifle-shooting committees.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- Fear of an eventual Nazi triumph in Austria was expressed today when the League of Nations governing body for German refugees held a public session here to organize assistance for the 60,000 Jews and others who have fled from the Hitler regime.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Bills to create a State Liquor Control Authority to conduct a State monopoly of the entire wholesale distribution of liquor and fortified wines were introduced in the Legislature today.

The nation, in honoring its President yesterday, did not forget to pay its tribute to his mother, Mrs. James Roosevelt, now in her eightieth year, who was a radiant figure in the city's life yesterday. The outpouring of public affection for her son compelled her to abandon for the day her usual quiet routine and go forth publicly to accept her share of the nation's congratulations.

The shipyards of the world launched 489,016 tons of commercial ships last year, setting a new low mark for the century, according to the annual report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, which was published yesterday. This total represents a reduction of 237,575 tons from that of 1932 and is less than 15 per cent of the pre-war output in 1913.

VJASHINGT01N, Jan. 30 o.P),-;President Roosevelt today nomi!nated Joseph B. Poindexter of Hawaii to be Governor of Hawaii. He thus abandoned a previous in[tention to appoint an outsider to thispost. The bill making it possi- I ble to name a non-resident of Ha-[ waii as Governor passed the House but never reached a vote ih theI I Senate. [

The Horace Mann School for Boys and Cathedral Boys High quintets yesterday extended their unbeaten records in the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League and New York division C.H.S.A.A. competitions, respectively.

Two fires started simultaneously in the cellars of downtown loft buildings last night, causing considerable damage to merchandise in storage and giving the fire crews of forty-two pieces of apparatus a stiff battle for about two hours.
PARIS, Jan. 30. -- The first Summer fashion shows reveal no sensational silhouette changes. Simplified shoulders choose a golden mean between sloping champagne-bottle and straight, square lines.
ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Governor Lehman broadcast tonight a birthday message to President Roosevelt, praising him for giving renewed confidence "to a sorely tried people."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Two balls were held in Washington tonight and one in Alexandria, Va., in honor of President Roosevelt's birthday and for the benefit of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation.

Further improvement in the banking situation is reported by Mr. O'CONNOR, Controller of the Currency. He has had the responsibility of supervising reorganization of national banks not permitted to reopen after the crisis of last February-March. There were then 1,446 such institutions, with total deposits amounting to about S2,000,000,000.

Returns to date indicate that the trend of railway earnings in December reversed the one usual to the season by showing an increase over the preceding month. It has been several years since a result of this kind has been shown.
ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The State Milk Control Board withdrew its schedule of prices on sales of milk and cream to stores and restaurants today.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Jan. 31. -- The Soviet civil stratosphere balloon Osoaviakhim 1 greatly exceeded the world's official altitude record yesterday morning by reaching a height of 67,585 feet at 11:15 o'clock Moscow time [4:15 A.M. Eastern standard time].

The people believe in President Roosevelt because he has lifted them out of the state of fear in which they existed before his inauguration, according to Martin Conboy, United States Attorney. Speaking at a luncheon in the Engineers Club in celebration of the President's birthday, Mr. Conboy said:
Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, will retire today as the Fall term ends with the graduation of more than 54,600 pupils in senior and junior high and elementary schools.

Joseph Murphy, $2,400-a-year clerk in the Department of Markets, who was absent from duty 1,625 days and received pay for all of the time off, appeared yesterday before Market Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. and his deputy, Michael Fiaschetti, to answer charges of neglect of duty.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- With the American monetary bill enacted, the dollar began bowing to the inevitable today and lost 20 centimes in the exchange market, closing at 15.82 francs. It still is 51 centimes above the parity of a 60-cent dollar, however, and French authorities predict a struggle before the rate is brought down and held at 15.31 francs.

KALGOORLIE, Western Australia, Jan. 30. -- Long-standing grievances against foreigners who work in local gold mines at low wages flared into violence today after the death of an Australian in a barroom and arrest of the foreign bartender on a charge of manslaughter.

Confession being good for the soul, Florence Johns and Wilton Lackaye Jr. probably feel a good deal more cheerful this morning. Their three-act confession about the cupidity of the antiques business, "American, Very Early," was acted at the Vanderbilt last evening, and Miss Johns, who has been rusticating out there where the pavement ends, had the satisfaction of playing the leading role.

Tito Schipa is to supervise a rehearsal of the Teatro Piccoli this morning, when two of Podrecca's puppets costumed by Mme. Pangoni of the Metropolitan will "impersonate" the opera tenor as Nemorino in "Elisir d'Amore" and in full dress in a Neapolitan song.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Legislation providing Federal regulation of stock exchanges will be sought much earlier than was expected, it was disclosed today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

Mrs. Philip Rhinelander 2d gave a luncheon yesterday at the Pierre. Her guests were Mrs. Moses Taylor Campbell, Mrs. Herman D. Kountze, Mrs. Adolf Ladenburg. Mrs. James Stewart Cushman and Miss Anne W. Stuyvesant.

More than thirty architects and draftsmen working under the Civil Works Administration have started preparing scale drawings of historic buildings in the metropolitan district. The sketches, which will be made a part of the records of the Library of Congress, are intended to preserve for posterity accurate representations of some of the edifices linked with New York's history.
Hughie Critz, the slender, will o' the wisp second baseman of the world's baseball champions, is the latest performer to gladden the hearts of the New York Giants' official family.
ATHENS, Jan. 30 (AP). -- On his plea that he is too ill to travel, the Greek Government decided today that Samuel Insull may stay here ten days longer before seeking another haven.

It is hard sledding for romance when an eminent Egyptologist refuses to believe in Egyptian curses and a distinguished snake expert fakes no stock in sea-serpents. First Mr. WINLOCK of the Metropolitan Museum of Art squelches the curse of Tut-ankh-Amen business and now Mr. DITMARS of the Zoo scoffs, at the Loch Ness monster.

Two of six State witnesses who have been in the House of Detention since last October were called yesterday at the start of the trial of eighteen officers and members of the Delicatessen and Restaurant Countermen and Cafeteria Workers Union, Local 302, on racketeering charges.

ATLANTA, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The Interracial Commission said in a statement today that Negroes in Jefferson County at Barrow "are living in a state of fear," following recent killings and beatings of members of their race in that section.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Amendment of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation Act so that loans of a maturity up to ten years could be made to railroad and possibly to some other borrowers was suggested today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the corporation, at an executive meeting of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.
Radical changes in the handling of the national championships were announced yesterday by the Indoor Polo Association of America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The Hubbard Gold Medal for outstanding geographic achievement was awarded by the National Geographic Society today to Mrs. Anne Morrow Lindbergh for her achievements as radio operator, aerial navigator and co-pilot on the flight of the Lindberghs last Summer.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30. -- Stockholders of the Baldwin Locomotive Works at the annual meeting on March 1 will vote on a reduction of the stated capital from $42,134,000 to $30,548,000, according to a message sent to them by George I. Houston, president.

The Treasury Department's complete monthly report of the stock of all kinds of money in the United States as of Jan. 1 shows the following principal changes in December. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted; gold released from earmark is added:

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- The conference on the German transfer moratorium will face its crisis tomorrow when the creditors' representatives are expected to call for a showdown on the points at issue, namely, the cut in Germany's cash payments to 30 per cent and the discriminatory treaties with Switzerland and Holland granting payment in full to those countries in return for supplementary imports from Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull indicated today that the United States Government was persisting in friendly efforts to end the Chaco war between Bolivia and Paraguay. He said that representations were being made constantly through the United States Ministers in Asuncion and La Paz to the governments of the warring nations.

In an opinion fortified by rulings of the United States Supreme Court and the appeals courts of New York State, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler declared unconstitutional yesterday the Shackno Law under which fourteen mortgage guarantee companies are being rehabilitated by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, and properties on which guaranteed mortgages have defaulted are in process of reorganization.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30. -- Miss Anne Townsend, all-around Merion athlete, led the way into the fourth round of the women's Philadelphia and district squash racquets championship at the Cynwyd Club today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- A young man in this city graduated yesterday from one of the most difficult courses in the world. Neither he nor his instructors made any particular ceremony of the affair; it passed practically unnoticed by them and by him. But an examination was held, the answer to a question was given; and everything about a graduation exercise was there except the diploma.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30. -- Argentina's favorable trade balance declined 50 per cent in 1933, as compared with the previous year, total-ling only 223,344,000 paper pesos, as compared with 451,518,000 pesos in 1932, according to the National Statistical Bureau's annual report, published today.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The Assembly today passed the Mandelbaum Bill sought by the city administration to open a large-scale housing and slum clearance program with the aid of $25,000,000 allocated by the Federal Government. The Senate had already given its approval to the measure.

The St. John's quintet was too experienced for Manhattan's sophomore contingent in their traditional basketball battle last night and the Brooklyn Redmen routed the Jaspers, 38 to 23, in the De Gray gymnasium before a capacity crowd of 1,000.

President Roosevelt was eulogized for his part in the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and the re-establishment of the wine and liquor industry at a Roosevelt birthday and Warm Springs Foundation benefit dinner dance given at the Hotel Roosevelt last night by the Spirits Club, trade organization of the wine and liquor industry.
DUBLIN, Jan. 30. -- Disquieting incidents have increased rapidly in the South of Ireland in the last few days.

The State of Illinois awarded yesterday a new issue of $10,000,000 of 6 per cent tax-anticipation warrants to a syndicate of Chicago banks headed by the First National Bank of Chicago. The warrants, dated Feb. 1 and due Dec. 1, 1934, were purchased by the banks at par.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30. -- Booing of advocates of the proposed 2 per cent retail sales tax, cat-calls and shouted threats, with a sharp interchange between Senator Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic County and Samuel S. Kenworthy of Belleville, secretary of the State League of Municipalities, marked a public hearing by the Joint Judiciary Committee of the Legislature here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- President Roosevelt signed the Gold Revaluation Bill, conferred with steel workers about their troubles under the code, and broadcast a brief birthday speech to the nation.

For the first time this year the total number of buyers registered in the past week failed to reach the 1,000 mark. However, the total remained well ahead of the number listed in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
The following table shows the ten i most active stocks traded on the i New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne of New York State, William C. Adams, his chief assistant; Captain H.J. Burlington, secretary of the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission, and J.H. Mathews, president of the Middle Atlantic Fisheries Association, held a conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan tightened a loose corner of the net in which he hopes to catch the kingpins of the policy or "numbers'' racket when he wrote yesterday to Chief Magistrate James E. McDonald, asking the cooperation of the courts.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP). -- A band of men lynched Robert Johnson, a Negro, held for investigation for an alleged attack on a white woman, about 3:15 A.M. today in an isolated place fifteen miles from here.

It's an old American custom to reply to an important public speech by alleging that the man who made it is a candidate for office and that therefore what he says doesn't count. This is illustrated again in the reception at Washington of the address just made in Kansas by Mr. OGDEN MILLS.

Prices of bonds surged upward again yesterday on the Stock Exchange in heavy trading, the gains for all groups surpassing those on Monday. United States Government bonds were bid up 1-32 to 10-32 point to new high marks on the recovery.
New York, in common with most of the Atlantic seaboard, was in the grip of the cold wave yesterday, with slight prospect for relief today.
Fifty-two young girls, all in white, were living symbols of a nation's love and admiration for its President at the Birthday Ball for President Roosevelt at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

Although television transmission is "ready to come out," receiving apparatus still is too expensive for mass distribution, according to Charles A. Wall of the National Broadcasting Company treasurer's office. Mr. Wall reviewed the progress of radio broadcasting yesterday at a luncheon of the Manlius Old Boys Association held at the Columbia University Club.

" Broomsticks, Amen!", the Elmer Greensfelder play, dealing with the folk ways of the Pennsylvania Dutch, will come to the Little Theatre some time next week. It will succeed "False Dreams, Farewell," which is expected to move to a larger playhouse.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 30. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Act was declared unconstitutional by Federal Judge Alexander Akerman here today. He made the ruling orally at the conclusion of a two-day hearing on injunction proceedings brought by a group of Florida citrus growers.

A large and highly diversified exhibition of the work of Brooklyn and Long Island artists opened to the public yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum. It contains work by more than a hundred painters and sculptors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The text of President Roosevelt's radio speech tonight to the groups celebrating his birth anniversary follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The completion of Adolf Hitler's first year as Chancellor of Germany finds official relations between the United States Government and the Reich less tense than they have been for several months.

The choice of appraisers in condemnation proceedings by the Triborough Bridge Authority was attacked yesterday by Irving Ben Cooper, acting as prosecutor, in the trial of John Stratton O'Leary, member of the authority, before Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch.

HARTFORD Conn., Jan. 30. -- Attorneys representing the Gray Telephone Pay Station Company and the stockholders' proxy committee reached today an agreement to enlarge the board of directors to nine members from seven. Both the management and the stockholders' committee will inform all shareholders that the following board "should receive the support of all stockholders":

VIENNA, Jan. 30. -- What was expected to be for Austria a fatal Jan. 30, when the Austrian Nazis, with a little help from Berlin and Munich, would present to Chancellor Hitler the accomplished fact of the seizure of power in his native country as a souvenir of his first anniversary as Chancellor, has passed as this dispatch is written at midnight.

CROWN POINT, Ind., Jan. 30. -- John Dillinger, the outlaw whose gang depredations impelled Indiana to mobilize its National Guard several months ago, tonight was safely locked behind the bars of the jail here to await trial on a charge of murder.

H.F. (Pink) Baker of the Princeton Club, member of the celebrated Tiger football "team of destiny" of 1922, furnished the first major reversal in the Metropolitan Class A squash racquets championship yesterday at the University Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The special Senate Committee investigating ocean and air-mail contracts was told today that Walter F. Brown, when Postmaster General, operated a secret joint stock market account involving more than $1,000,000, with G.M.P. Murphy Co. of New York and Washington, part of the collateral for which was 3,000 shares of International Mercantile Marine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Completion of arrangements to sell $2,000,000 worth of food products to the Cuban Government for emergency relief work may be expected within the next few days. The contract of sale, under which the Surplus Relief Corporation acts as vendor, was sent to Havana last night and should be received there tomorrow.

The amazingly rapid disintegration of the ice shelf in the Bay of Whales is again emphasized by the foregoing dispatch. It is much more extensive than anything which took place on Admiral Byrd's other journey south.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 30. -- The elimination of the medal winner and defending titleholder, Carl M. Dann Jr. of Orlando, Fla., by Morton McCarthy, Norfolk, Va., was the highlight of the first match round in the seventh annual national championship of club champions today.

Eugene S. Daniell Jr., 29 years old, lawyer, Harvard graduate and Presidential candidate of the Commoners party in 1932, went on trial yesterday before Judge Corrigan and a jury in General Sessions. He is charged in two indictments with second-degree assault and malicious damage to the New York Stock Exchange Building on last Aug. 4.

The pamphlet report of the Hartford Electric Light Company for 1933 shows a net income of $2,427,645, equal to $2.89 a share on 840,000 shares of $25 par value common stock, comparing with $2,399,834, or $2.86 a share, earned in 1932. The surplus after common dividends and adjustments was $145,063, against $103,744.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Permanent establishment of the present temporary Federal guarantee for bank deposits up to $2,500 was proposed in a bill introduced in the Senate by Senator Vandenberg today. The Senator, who was outstanding in starting the Deposit Guarantee Law, would eliminate that part expanding the insurance on July 1 to cover deposits in full up to $10,000 and on a scaled proportion above that sum.
In his letter to THE TIMES Elihu Cooper has much to say in criticism of Joseph M. Levy's article regarding the Arab-Jewish question in Palestine, published Jan. 21.

John W. Lacey, former president of the Sunrise National Bank and Trust Company of Baldwin, L.I., and Amos V. Pearsall, a former director of the same institution, were named in an indictment handed to Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Brooklyn yesterday by the Federal grand jury.

The treaty of 1911 between the United States and Japan, containing a clause granting to Japanese subjects in this country the same trade rights as citizens here, has helped two restaurant owners to obtain licenses to sell liquor, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, revealed yesterday.

In a move to separate its security distributing business from its investment operations and to simplify further the intercorporate relations between itself and its subsidiaries and affiliates, the Equity Corporation has sold its 44 per cent interest in Distributors Group, Inc., to interests identified with David M. Milton, president of Equity.

Robert Grossman, 51 years old, a patrolman attached to the West Twentieth Street Station, shot and killed himself yesterday in a garage on his beat at 146 Thirteenth Avenue. He had been in poor health for more than two years and that combined with injuries he had suffered a month ago in quelling a Communist disturbance, police said, probably caused him to end his life.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 30. -- The United Mine Workers of America in convention here refused today to make any concessions to communism, despite recognition of the Sovient Union by the Unted States.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30. -- Complimenting Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d and Joseph E. Widener, whom they have visited at Il Palmetto, Mr. and Mrs. Austen Gray gave a luncheon today at their Brazilian Avenue residence. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington, Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas, Grand Duke Dmitri, Princess Anna Ilynski, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Moore of New York, Frank Carter and Captain Cecil Boyd Rochfort.

There was a slight hardening in the Street rate for call loans at 7/8, compared with 3/4 previously, but otherwise there was little else of significance in the day's market. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 1 per cent, while time money, commercial paper and acceptances were quiet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The House Banking and Currency Committee revolted today against what it termed "one-man rule" and after a heated executive session voted to override Representative Steagall, the chairman, and appointed three subcommittees to conduct hearings on separate measures now before the committee.

More than 6,000 hotel strikers and sympathizers filled the exposition hall in Madison Square Garden last night at a strike meeting called by the Amalgamated Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union, the strike organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The bitter controversy for six months lover the code for the construction industry has been ended, and this code, one of the most important negotiated by the NRA, will soon be placed before President Roosevelt.

All but three of the fifteen canvases constituting Walt Kuhn's new one-man show at the Marie Harriman Gallery were painted in 1933. The exceptions are "Young Clown," "Rose Clown" and "Miss X," which were done in 1932. All of the work shown is in oil. This exhibition opened to the public yesterday and is scheduled to remain until Feb. 24.
Today is the last day on which automobile owners may operate their cars with the 1933 registration plates. The 1934 licenses must be on all motor vehicles driven in this State after midnight tonight.

Eugene O'Neill, who has spent most of the late Fall and early Winter here, returned Monday to his island off the Georgia Coast. With two plays presented in the last four months, his immediate plan is to rest for a while.

Stimulated again by the prospect of an early stabilization of dollar exchange, the speculative markets attracted business of large proportions yesterday. Stocks advanced sharply, wheat was fractionally higher, bonds were firm and most of the foreign currencies had a slight sinking spell.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Lower prices for alcoholic beverages within the next month were foreseen today by Joseph H. Choate Jr., chairman of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 30. -- Death in the electric chair at Sing Sing during the week of March 12 was the sentence today on Alphonse Brengard, 32 years old, a former New York State trooper who was convicted of killing Patrolman John Kennedy of the Nassau County Police in 1928.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 30 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's Georgia home held two birthday parties in his honor tonight -- townspeople danced in the casino and patients at the Warm Springs Foundation cut a seven-foot cake and square-danced in their wheel chairs.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30. -- Supreme Court Justice Parker today dismissed a suit filed by Joseph A. Broderick, New York State Superintendent of Banks, against 560 residents of New Jersey who were shareholders in the Bank of United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Criminal prosecutions in six cases involving complaints of graft in the Civil Works Administration were ordered tonight by the Division of Investigation of the Public Works Administration.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30. -- Three internationally known members of the amateur tennis ranks spoke their minds today on an "open tournament" idea to give a striking cross-section view of what leaders in the sport think of the agitation to let simon-pures match strokes with professionals.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30. -- Joseph E. Widener's The Pelican, never much as a 2 or 3 year old, ran one of his best races at Hialeah Park today to win the featured Franklin D. Roosevelt Purse. The Pelican, now a 4-year-old, is a gelding by Haste -- Catalpa, and was clocked in the smart time of 1:11 3-5 for the six furlongs.

OTTAWA, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Backed by the sensational goal-tending of Chuck Gardiner, the Chicago Blank Hawks blanked the Ottawa Senators, 2 -- 0, in a National Hockey League battle tonight and went into a tie with the New York Rangers for first place in the American section.

The Pennsylvania Railroad is to begin immediately the expenditure of a $77,000,000 Public Works Administration loan on projects which will provide the equivalent of one year's work for 25,000 men, W.W. Atterbury, president, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The United States team of women squash racquets players, which lost its first match yesterday to the Queen's Club, today defeated an International Sportsmen's Club team of women, five matches to two.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Increased speculative buying on the Board of Trade advanced wheat prices today to the highest point since Nov. 17, and for the fourth straight day the finish was above the close of the previous session, although net gains were only 1/8 to 1/4 cent a bushel.

Birthday greetings for the President were expressed last night by representative clergy of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths, by public officials, educators, judges and other prominent citizens of this city at a dinner and dance in the Hotel Astor organized by a special committee representing the insurance business in this State.

The fact that more than three times as many aliens left the United States in 1933 as entered may give the impression that immigration is no longer a serious problem. But by the latest census there were 6,000,000 aliens in this country. It is estimated that of approximately 13,615,000 individuals on unemployment relief last November, nearly a million were aliens.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Although the act under which the State is administering emergency relief expires tomorrow, Governor Moore today deferred signing the bill for reorganization. Until he does so, John Colt, State Finance Commissioner, will continue as administrator.

Losing only a single game for the second consecutive day, Joseph Abrams, Clinton captain, gained the quarter-final round of the De Witt Clinton interscholastic indoor tennis tourney yesterday at the 369th Regiment Armory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Mrs. Roosevelt was the honor guest today at a luncheon given by Mrs. Daniel C. Roper, will of the Secretary of Commerce, who entertained in her home on Woodland Drive. Other guests included Mme. de Laboulaye, wife of the French Ambassador; Representative Isabella Greenway, Mrs. William Phillips and Mrs. Woodrow Wilson.

A bequest of $20,000 was added yesterday to the fund for the Neediest Cases, making possible relief and a modicum of happiness for 114 persons who previously had faced the prospect of going without help this year because the necessary money was not available.

Vladimir Horowitz's recital at Carnegie Hall last night was productive of something richer and deeper than virtuoso playing. Bach, Beethoven, Schumann, Chopin and even Liszt were treated with understanding and a warm, poetic glow.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- After attorneys for Henry L. Doherty, financier, had argued for another adjournment of trial on the ground that their client was suffering from arthritis in Florida, counsel for the plaintiff presented an affidavit purporting to show that Mr. Doherty had broadcast an appeal in behalf of President Roosevelt's birthday observance over a New York radio station Sunday.

Strength was the rule yesterday on the commodity markets, although profit-taking cut into some of the gains of silver and rubber futures. Silk, cocoa, coffee and copper were higher. Cash prices were firm, and new high marks for the year were reached by wheat, cocoa, butter, lard and silk.

Two more athletes were added yesterday to the staff of Martin Conboy, new United States Attorney, who last week named two of intercollegiate note to serve with his group of young assistants, who already had, from the previous administration, an All-American back as a colleague.
Fidgety husbands who wring their hands, mop their brows and pace outside of the maternity ward in Flower Hospital have always amused Eugene Joseph Caton, the hospital's chief clerk.

The Board of Aldermen stood on its dignity as a legislative body yesterday. The result was a rebuke to Mayor LaGuardia, in which the Republican and Fusion members joined, and a demonstration by the board that the days of steam-roller tactics in that body were at an end.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30. -- Mrs. Clyde Van Dusen's Ted Clark finally got back to winning form at Fair Grounds today as he barely lasted to score by a head over Mrs. R.T. Flippen's Malimou in the sixth race at a mile and a sixteenth. Euryalus was third.
LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The Royal Aero Club issued today revised rules for the air races from England to Melbourne, Australia, next October.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 30. -- Governor Theodore Francis Green came here this evening to open the ball marking President Roosevelt's birthday. The party was given at State Armory with a large attendance of the Winter and army and navy colonies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- For the second time bids on the construction of the New York City postoffice annex, adjacent to the Pennsylvania Railway Station, were rejected today by the Treasury Department, which called for new ones on Feb. 21. It was found that under the estimates submitted the total cost of the project would be greater than the $5,370,000 allocated by the Public Works Administration.

A change in the personnel of the field for the Millrose 600, one of the features of the Millrose games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night, was made yesterday when Director Fred Schmertz received a telegram withdrawing Glenn Hardin of Louisiana State from the meet.

BOSTON, Jan. 30. -- A packed house of 16,000 fans gave Eddie Shore a hero's welcome and then cheered the Boston Bruins to a spectacular 2-1 victory over the New York Rangers tonight at the Boston Garden.

The United States has returned to a gold standard, according to the interpretation of the President's proclamation by leading monetary authorities in Wall Street. It will not be like the old gold standard and, at present, at any rate, can only be looked upon as temporary -- but it has the essential feature of a monetary gold basis, the purchase and sale of gold at a fixed price.

Eugene S. Daniell Jr. of Boston, lawyer, Harvard graduate and a founder of the National Independent party, testified in his defense yesterday at his General Sessions trial on two indictments. He is accused of felonious assault and malicious damage in having placed two tear-gas bombs in the Stock Exchange building last Aug. 4.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 31 (AP). -- Acceptance of the Arkansas Bond Refunding Bill was voted unanimously in New York today by the protective committee representing the holders of $91,500,000 of highway and toll bridge bonds, and State officials said the success of the refunding plan thus was virtually assured.

ROME, Jan. 31. -- A full and final statement of the Italian viewpoint on disarmament, made with the avowed intention of inducing other governments to make similar statements and of forcing each to assume full responsibility for its actions before public opinion of the world, was made public today.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- Governor Lehman today signed the Mandelbaum Bill authorizing the creation of municipal housing authorities. The measure provides for setting up authorities of five members in cities, and as it became law the LaGuardia administration began plans for immediate creation of such an authority in New York City to start a program for large-scale slum clearance and low-cost housing, with the aid of $25,000,000 to be allocated by the Federal Government.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- President Roosevelt's decision on the dollar value is taken here to mean that temporary stabilization of the United States currency at 59.06 cents gold is now an established fact, but, according to several authorities, there must be some heavy selling by the Washington exchange stabilization fund to bring it down on the international exchange market to the level decreed by the President.

A testimonial dinner in honor of A. Ralph Steinberg, national chairman of the foreign-language division of the Department of Public Relations of the National Recovery Administration, was given last night at the Hotel Astor by the for eign-language press. Bernard H. Ridder presided.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31. -- Preceding the round-robin tennis matches held today on the club courts, Edward M, Mcllvain Jr. entertained a group of those participating with a luncheon at the Everglades Club. Included were Mr. and Mrs. Jay F. Carlisle, Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Hassler, the Misses Edna Brokaw, Anna Coxe Newbold and Dorothy J. Richards; Edward F. Hutton, Maurice Fatio, George G. Bourne and Milton W. Holden.

The trial of John Stratton O'Leary on charges of incompetence and inefficiency as a member of the Triborough Bridge Authority came to an end yesterday at a session replete with caustic remarks exchanged between the prosecution and the defense.

TOKYO, Jan. 31 (AP). -- The Japanese Diet was informed today that new Japanese auxiliary vessels will outrank those of the United States by 1937 and that if the naval men of the two nations dictated on programs in the 1935 naval conference "a rupture would be inevitable."

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the heaviest since last July. Sales last month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 54,567,209 shares, compared with 34,877,616 in December, and 18,719,502 shares in January a year ago.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- Good wishes for President Roosevelt's policies in general, but misgivings over the new stabilization fund were expressed today by Rupert Beckett in his annual speech as chairman to shareholders of the Westminister Bank, one of Great Britain's "big five."

Leases of office and showroom space to firms engaged in the garment trades were a feature of realty activity in Manhattan yesterday. Manufacturing furriers and coat and dress manufacturers figured prominently in the renting of new quarters in buildings along Seventh and Eighth Avenues and in the West Thirties.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Jan. 31. -- Gloria McMahon, 9 years old, daughter of Oliver R. McMahon, controller of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, of 11 Lakeside Drive, was drowned today when she attempted to save her brother James, 8, who had fallen through the ice at the Hempstead State Park Reservoir.

Limitation of free storage of freight on piers in the port district was urged by steamship and warehouse operators and spokesmen of trade groups yesterday morning at a hearing at the Port of New York Authority building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

Figures from forty-one States and the District of Columbia showed yesterday that the nation's "birthday party" to President Roosevelt and to the Warm Springs Foundation for Sufferers from Infantile Paralysis was a social and financial success.

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet and irregular today. Increased sales of potash created an interest in the potash shares, some of which gained up to 4 3/4 points. Heavy industrials were dull and changes stayed within fractions except for Silesian issues which rose beyond 2 points.
It is encouraging to read J. Pryse Goodwin's letter to THE TIMES suggesting remedies to relieve congestion at the Forty-second Street station of the Lexington Avenue subway.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 31. -- By the score of 26 to 24, the Naval Academy today gave North Carolina the second defeat it has experienced in thirteen starts this season. The last half was exciting as the visitors staged a great rally which just failed.

Two Shavian prefaces will he contained in the new volume of Bernard Shaw's plays which Dodd, Mead will publish this Spring. One is concerned with the right to exterminate incompatibles and undesirables claimed and practiced by some post-war governments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- At 3:10 o'clock today the President, acting under powers conferred on him by Congress in the Thomas amendment of 1933 and the Monetary Bill passed this week, put his signature to a proclamation and, by so doing, automatically effected these momentous changes:

Only two weeks ago, on Jan. 15, to be exact, the President said in his message to Congress, referring to "the gold value of the American dollar," that "because of world uncertainties, "I do not believe it desirable in the "public interest that an exact value "be now fixed."

Harry Harkness Flagler, president of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, made public yesterday letters from both Governor Lehman and Mayor LaGuardia in support of the society's appeal to the public for $500,000 to guarantee the continuance of concerts for the next three years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee, with administration forces in control, voted today to restore one-third of the 15 per cent Federal pay cut on Feb. 1 and another third on July 1.

According to reports which are drifting in, more than twenty States have been able to do a great deal of needed conservation work because of the availability of Federal work funds. Programs which have been delayed for years at last have been started and in many cases completed.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company is depositary in connection with the mortgage reorganization plans for $2,565,500 of 666 West End Avenue first mortgage 6 per cent sinking fund coupon bonds and for $930,000 of 898 West End Avenue Apartment Building first mortgage 6 per cent serial coupon gold bonds.

PARIS, Jan. 31. -- Mirande's attractive youthful collection of Summer garb contains many interesting details, such as huge linen handbags, fabric-trimmed gloves, organdie ruffs and string or leather leash collars. Boyish pinch-waisted jacket suits, often having contrasting skirts, and girlish hip-length cape suits divide daytime honors, accompanied by real shirtwaists of printed linen, tie silk or flowered chiffon.

In voting almost unanimously against the LaGuardia Economy Bill, the Democratic members of the Assembly broke their own promises and went against their own party leaders. They disregarded both the appeal of Governor LEHMAN and the well-understood wishes of President ROOSEVELT.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Mayor Moore of Philadelphia, president of the Atlantic Deeper Waterways Association, today urged Congressional approval of the $12,500,000 Chesapeake and Delaware Canal project.

There will be no race the coming Summer for the North American Yacht Racing Union's International 12-Meter Cup. It was stated yesterday that the proposed challenge of C.R. Fairey, rear commodore of the Royal London Yacht Club, was regretfully declined two weeks ago. Announcement was withheld until the word should reach England.

The whole world from Angmagsalik to Natal will applaud the recognition of Mrs. LINDBERGH'S part in the circumnavigation of the North Atlantic and the earlier flight from Washington to the further shores of the Pacific. The distance traveled is considerably greater than a line of lowest latitude around the globe.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The Jesters Club team of men squash racquets players today gave the visiting United States women's team liberal handicaps and defeated them, 7 matches to 0. It was the second defeat in three starts for the invaders.
LONDON, Jan. 31. -- The Foreign Office issued today the following official summary of its disarmament proposals:

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- Republicans in the Legislature are strangely unsympathetic and aloof in the face of the defeat yesterday in the Assembly of the New York City Economy Bill, which has been pronounced by Mayor LaGuardia the only measure that can help to restore the credit of the city.

Complete reorganization of the custodial staff in the Welfare Island penitentiary was indicated yesterday by Austin H. MacCormick, Correction Commissioner. Fully half of the personnel will be involved in impending transfers, demotions, promotions and suspensions, it was declared.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31. -- Mrs. Gifford Pinchot sewed an NRA label on a dress at a Philadelphia factory today and received a membership card in the Waist and Dressmakers' Union, a local of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31. -- In the most spectacular advance in many a day, security prices on the exchanges went into new high ground on a great wave of late buying today. Turnover on the Stock Exchange reached the highest peak since July, 1933, as 80,694 shares changed hands.

An exhibition of paintings and drawings by E. Barnard Lintott is current at the Macbeth Galleries, where it will remain until Feb. 19. In a catalogue foreword Marie Sterner, reminding us that "variety is charming, repetition dull," goes on to observe: "It is because of this fact that the artist with an active, analytical and exploring mind will paint still-life, landscape, genre; in fact everything, rather than be pigeon-holed and placed in a category."

From the newspapers and various other semi-official sources I learn that plans are fairly well matured whereby funds from the CWA are being made available for the purpose of giving employment to large groups of unemployed teachers by establishing nursery schools and schools for adult education.

Public offering of new securities here in January was little changed from the small volume of December and consisted almost entirely of State and municipal bond issues. By comparison with a year ago, however, it showed a marked shrinkage.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 31. -- Georgetown's fast and clever basketball team downed Army today in a hard-fought game, 27 to 24, before a large crowd.

Two more seeded players were eliminated yesterday in the third round of the metropolitan Class A squash racquets singles championship in progress at the University Club. Ralph A. Powers of the Harvard Club, seeded No. 3, went to defeat at the hands of his clubmate, G.J. Leness, and B.H. Whitbeck Jr., also of Harvard, defeated Howell Van Gerbig, No. 7, of the University Club.
