May I suggest that Congress would confer a boon on investors generally if, when amending last year's Securities Act, it added measures that would enforce the use of the following methods:

Supreme Court Justice Lydon fixed yesterday the details of the trial to open before him on Monday of the suit by Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks, against 15,000 stockholders of the Bank of United States owning less than 100 shares, to recover an assesment of $25 a share.

Emmett Toppino, winner of the Millrose sprints for the past two years, arrived here yesterday and immediately began putting the finishing touches on his preparations for the Millrose meet Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stock from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rafts and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

The last was a banner year for deer hunting in New York State, according to the latest reports from the Conservation Department. In all 8,444 deer were shot, nearly 1,600 more than in 1932. Among the kill were 449 large bucks having from eleven to twenty points.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Following is the text of the statement issued to the press by President Roosevelt today on his gold policy:
NEW HAVEV, Conn., Jan. 31. -- Yale's long debate over its football coaching staff for 1934 ended tonight with the announcement of the appointment of Raymond W. (Ducky) Pond as head coach.

After an ownership of a week Frederick Brown has resold the nine-story elevator apartment house at 17 East Eighty-fourth Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues. The building stands on a plot 50 by 100 feet and has been acquired by an investing client of Brown, Wheelock, Harris Co., brokers, in the resale.

Mayor LaGuardia shattered another precedent last night -- this time in the field of commencement ceremony -- at the graduation exercises of the James Monroe High School, 172d Street and Boynton Avenue, the Bronx. About 2,000 parents and 750 boys and girls of the graduating class were present.

The Domestic Relations Court, comprising the Children's Court and Family Court, needs increases in personnel and in the number of justices if it is to serve the city properly, Presiding Justice Edward F. Boyle asserted in his first annual report submitted yesterday to Mayor LaGuardia and the Secretary of State of New York.

The recital given by Sigrid Onegin last night in Town Hall provided the audience with one of the most interesting song programs that has been offered for some time in this city. It may be admitted that an unconventional program of any kind is sufficiently of a rarity in our concert world for any exception to the rule to be conspicuous.

The recent improvement by months noted in declarations of dividends was emphasized in January, when, for the first time since the curtailment of payments to shareholders began, the declarations for a month were in excess of those for the corresponding month the year previous.

It was with a feeling of disappointment and chagrin, bordering on despair, that I read in Owen D. Young's otherwise sensible testimony before the Senate committee on the Money Bill his endorsement of Professor Rogers's astounding assertion that the gold profit resulting from the devaluation of the dollar is "a thing taken out of thin air by legislation."
Steel mill operations have risen this week to 35 per cent of ingot capacity, according to the review of The Iron Age. This compares with a rate of 32 per cent a week ago.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Announcement of the new price to be paid by the government for gold and the official devaluation of the dollar to 59.06 cents came too late yesterday for general comment by the grain trade. Brokers, however, who received the report were of the opinion that the plans would remove much uncertainty and might result in a sharp upturn in grain prices on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- A sweeping investigation of costs and profits of aviation manufacturing companies which have contracts with the United States Navy will be started Friday, Representative Vinson, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Construction of seven new revenue cutters, to be used in the suppression of rum running and for other purposes, was authorized by the Treasury Department today. They will cost $11,520,000 and will be built by the Navy Department in government navy yards with funds allocated by the Public Works Administration.
A mild reaction overtook the stock market yesterday and Wall Street saw, in the reversal of the price movement, the inevitable profit-taking sequel to a sustained advance.

Mayor LaGuardia announced last night that A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain and fiscal adviser to the administration, would represent him today in Albany before the Senate Cities Committee, which earlier yesterday had asked him to give the committee detailed information on the size of the city's budgetary deficit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Ratification of the St. Lawrence Seaway is within five of the necessary two-thirds vote. President Roosevelt told Democratic leaders today. He assured them that opposition would vanish, with indications that the treaty would be adopted by the Senate Within three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Mrs. Roosevelt attended Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's musicale at the Mayflower this morning, entertaining a party including Mrs. Henry Morgenthau Jr., Mrs. Vincent Astor, Mrs. Tracy Dows, Mrs. Walter Bruce Howe and Miss Nancy Cook, to hear Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, British pianists, in joint recital, and Alexander Gray, baritone, of Pennsylvania, who made his debut as a concert singer in New York last month.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Early passage of the "Vanderlip plan" for a Federal monetary authority was urged today before a House Banking and Currency subcommittee.
LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Predictions of intense activity in the foreign exchange market followed President Roosevelt's gold announcement today in London newspapers.

A hard shot from the stick of Leo Schroeder in 7:02 of a 10-minute overtime period gave the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club hockey team a 1-to-0 triumph over a fighting St. Nicholas sextet last night in an Eastern Amateur League game.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Following is the text of the gold proclamation issued today by President Roosevelt:

Reports from out-of-town men's wear stores yesterday indicated that sales during January showed a substantial rise over the corresponding month of last year. Gains of 10 to 50 per cent were mentioned in several localities. Payments to CWA workers played a prominent part in the increased sales, and many stores were able to measure their effect as they cashed such checks.

The Board of Education, at a special meeting last night, approved leaves of absence of one month without pay for forty-five employes of its building bureaus because of an expected curtailment tomorrow by the Board of Estimate in the issuance of only $10,000 in corporate stock to pay salaries of seventy-four persons in the bureaus.

The Metropolitan Club, founded in 1891 by the elder J.P. Morgan and a group of associates, is considering "a union with some club of similar standing" because of hard times, it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Buyers of hogs moved slowly today as the processing tax will be increased to $1.50 a 100 pounds tomorrow. With a liberal supply, prices dropped 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight, with the close at the inside figure. Packers bought around 6,600 head for relief purposes.

PARIS, Jan. 31. -- Premier Daladier's Ministry has had an exceptionally bad reception in the press and among party politicians in the Chamber of Deputies and Senate. It is being attacked from all sides.

The seven blocks of land acquired several years ago by the city for the Chrystie-Forsyth Street housing project, which have lain idle and vacant since then, are to be turned into a park and playground area, Mayor LaGuardia announced yesterday.
After the third successive day of near-zero weather, the wind shifted to the Southwest yesterday and routed the cold wave.
HAVANA, Jan. 31. -- Increasing agitation among labor groups now in the hands of radicals brought a walk-out today of some 30,000 tobacco workers as well as the omnibus employes of Havana Province.
The committee appointed by the National Motion Picture Code Authority to hear recommendations on revision of the code affecting vaudeville actors held a public hearing yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

WHILE waiting for the Toronto Maple Leafs to take the ice against the Rangers this evening, there is a chance to give honorable mention to a blushing hero who has left town. On the occasion of the recent clash between the Americans and the Montreal Maroons, Irving Frew of the Maroons proved himself to be a regular Sir Philip Sidney on skates, a poke-checker of chivalrous instincts.

The private telephones installed in the magistrate's chambers in the thirty-five courts of the city within the last ten years, will be taken out by the telephone company as soon as possible under a new contract effective today.

Last week I went to the reference room of the Forty-second Street Public Library with the intention of looking up some data on a historical character. I had recently finished a biography concerning this subject and was interested in discovering something more about it.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31. -- The 6-year-old gelding Kai-Finn led home a field of nine older platers in the best race on a featureless program at the Fair Grounds today. The veteran mud-runner finished two lengths before Judge Primrose in the six-furlong dash, third on the program, with Preferred next.

The President's announcement stabilizing the dollar on a modified gold bullion standard at 59.06 per cent of its former parity brought a swift decline in the dollar in foreign exchange late yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- President Roosevelt, accepting the credentials of Dr. Manuel Marquez Sterling as Cuban Ambassador today, invited Cuba to open negotiations for revising treaty relations with this country. The President's invitation mentioned "modification of the permanent treaty between the United States and Cuba and for revision of the commercial convention between the two countries."

The North German Lloyd Company has notified holders of its twenty-year 6 per cent bonds, outstanding in the amount of $16,926,500, that the time for depositing the bonds under its interest-reduction plan has been extended to March 1. It states that more than $8,000,000 of the bonds have been deposited with the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- General Hermann Goering today ordered the secret State police, of whom he is the head, to make immediately a list of all German emigres who fled under the Nazi regime, giving the emigres' present whereabouts if possible.

With the City Home on Welfare Island as the first point of attack, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, began yesterday his promised drive to rid the city's hospitals of political influence and to have them run solely for the benefit of the patients.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Preliminary approval of a definition of service charges and a standard formula to be used in the analysis of checking accounts, submitted by the Banking Code Committee, has been given by General Johnson. This is with the understanding that the fair trade practice provisions of the various schedules are to be returned for revision to the city and regional clearing house associations or other groups submitting them.

" THE NATIVE'S RETURN," by Louis Adamic (Harper's, $2.75), which the Book of the Month Club is sending out to its lucky subscribers this morning, is one of those rare, unclassifiable "originals" which turn up once in every blue moon. We cannot conceive of a person living who won't like at least portions of "The Native's Return."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Secretary Roper made a spirited defense today of the New Deal and the administration's emergency policies from the attack of Ogden L. Mills, delivered Monday in Topeka.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- With the gradual speeding up of the recovery program, calling for gigantic expenditures from the Treasury, the government's deficit on Jan. 29, for the first time since July 1, 1933, exceeded that of a year before.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, Bay of Whales, Antarctica, Jan. 30. -- The Jacob Ruppert, flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition, is desperately struggling to finish the job of discharging the balance of the stores for the Winter party.
Several flats and business buildings were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Victor J. Dowling and Thomas E. Murray, receivers for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, will notify Federal Judge Julian W. Mack today of their intention to seek disaffirmance of the company's 999-year lease of the elevated lines of the Manhattan Railway Company.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- The field for the Grand National Steeplechase, to be run at Aintree on March 23, was reduced to fifty-four following the first acceptances today. Twelve horses, including F. Ambrose Clark's American-owned Jack O'Day, were declared out.

Magistrate Jeanette G. Brill was chided yesterday by Mrs. Herbert Shipman, head of the new Clean City Committee, for rebuking policemen who brought in Flatbush housewives on charges of leaving the covers off refuse cans.

The automobile financing business of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation totaled approximately twice as much on Dec. 31 as it did a year earlier, according to the annual report. The volume of notes at the end of 1933 exceeded the total at the end of 1932 by $48,473,717.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 31. -- The United Mine Workers of America voted today at the closing session of their international convention to press for the thirty-hour week and increased wages.

A clean-up of CWA projects employing nearly 60,000 men in the city's parks was launched yesterday by Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, in cooperation with the local Civil Works Administration, with a view to weeding out loafers and straightening irregularities.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31. -- The Texas campaigner Coequel, a gray daughter of Cotlogomor and Sequel, established a new track record of 1:10 1-5 for six furlongs at Hialeah Park today to win the Clearwater Purse, one of two features. In the other main event Clarify made it four in a row when he dashed six furlongs in 1:10 4-5 to take the Tamiami Handicap.

Exports of gold from here in January were less than in December and were more than offset by a gain in the amount of gold released from earmarked holdings. The shipments aggregated $3,386,000, compared with $9,086,000 in December and with only $20,000 in January, 1933, when imports totaled $116,078,000, the high figure for an incoming movement, which ended last February.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 31. -- An 18-year-old student, Morton McCarthy, tackle on the Norfolk (Va.) High School football team, is proving the sensation of the seventh annual national championship of golf club champions. In the second match round today young McCarthy contributed another upset by defeating Tommy Aycock of Jacksonville, former intercollegiate titleholder, by 2 and 1.
Four fencers earned the right to compete for the women's national junior foils championship in the preliminary round held at the Fencers Club last night.
By registering a clean sweep in yesterday's match against the Harvard Club, the New York Athletic Club squash tennis team continued to hold its grip on first place in the Metropolitan Class A League.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- John Gielgud, the young star of "Richard of Bordeaux," which marks its first anniversary on Friday, made his managerial debut tonight, sponsoring and directing another actor, Emlyn Williams, in a romantic comedy of Shakespeare's time, "Spring, 1600."

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- A news agency report from Washington that Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury had intimated that early Anglo-American exchange stabilization negotiations were likely awakens no immediate British response.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Applications for approval of $6,274,000 in equipment loans from the Public Works Administration were filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the New York, Chicago St. Louis and the Lehigh New England Railroads.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Verne Sankey, a suspect in the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby and long hunted for crimes in the Middle West, was arrested here today by Federal agents as he sat in a barber's chair.

Thomas Jefferson High School's unbeaten team defeated Erasmus Hall, 27 to 21, in the Jefferson gymnasium as play opened yesterday in the Brooklyn division of the city P.S.A.L. championship basketball competition.

Several days ago President ROOSEVELT asked Congress for funds with which to supplement the salaries of American diplomatic officers resident abroad. Depreciation of the dollar by approximately 40 per cent has meant for them a corresponding cut in pay. Assistant Secretary of State CARR reports much hardship in the foreign service.

The rate of government expenditures in excess of receipts rose to nearly $30,000,000 a day in January, resulting in heavy withdrawals of funds from depository banks by the Treasury and larger offerings of new government securities, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its monthly review, published yesterday.

Money market was quiet and except for routine requirements little new money was taken in any section. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 1 per cent, and counter trades, 3/4@7/8. Time money ranged from 3/4 to 1 1/2 per cent. Business money was unchanged in discount.
BERLIN, Jan. 31 (AP). -- A longstanding Protestant church controversy took an unexpected turn tonight when Chancellor Hitler ordered the police not to interfere in the strife.

Reactionary tendencies prevailed yesterday in futures price movements on local commodity exchanges, following the trend in the securities markets. Trading, although somewhat reduced, was still in fairly good volume. The trend was downward in cash prices.

Be not deceived by the intimation of gents' furnishings in the title of the play that appeared at the Selwyn last evening. "A Hat, A Coat, A Glove" is a crime play adapted by William A. Drake from the German of Wilhelm Speyer. It is not the most brilliant of crime plays, but A.E. Matthews is to be discovered in the central role, and he can give a mediocre play a piquant look of distinction.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Following is the text of the Treasury Department regulation issued today after President Roosevelt had make his gold proclamation:
LONDON, Jan. 31. -- Great Britain and Italy issued new disarmament suggestions today, but Rome apparently stole a march on London by getting its memorandum before the world first.

Hope that the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad would be in a position to pay another dividend in June was expressed by officials of the company in correspondence with the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed yesterday. The company objected to the commission's suggestion that it create a sinking fund for its general-mortgage 4 per cent bonds.
Christie Hans, 33 years old and six feet tall, told other drivers for the Dominion Forwarding Company whenever they talked about hold-ups: "I'll never hand my truck over to anybody, guns or no guns."

Members of seven additional committees for the 1936 Olympic Games were announced yesterday by the American Olympic Committee through its secretary, Frederick W. Rubien. Twelve groups have now been named. Within a few days the remaining eleven will be made known.

More bonds were called for payment in January before their dates of maturity than in December, but the total was only about half that of a year earlier. The redemptions aggregated $24,582,000, the smallest amount for a January in six years, compared with $17,326,000 in December, and $44,725,700 in January, 1932.

The New York Quotation Company, the subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange that provides the Wall Street district with stock ticker service, notified its subscribers yesterday that it was considering offering an express ticker service to supplement the present ticker in busy markets.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- The issuance of so-called international passports to German exiles will be sought by the League of Nations High Commission for German refugees following a two-day meeting here of its governing body and spokesmen of the private organizations concerned.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 31. -- The coaching situation at two Ohio universities was changed completely today when Sam Willaman resigned as director of football at Ohio State and Western Reserve announced he had signed a three-year contract to replace Tom Keady.

Robert E. Christie Jr., president of the Investment Bankers Association, announced yesterday that the governors of the organization will meet in Chicago on Feb. 10 and 11 to consider the fair-practice rules for the investment banking code, which have been in process of formation the last two months.

Hack Wilson, right fielder of the Dodgers, who at one time ranked as the National League's leading homerun hitter, will have to accept what the Brooklyn club deems a fair wage for his services in 1934 or place his demands elsewhere.

VIENNA, Jan. 31. -- An Austrian trade commission will leave Vienna for the United States next Tuesday. On it are pinned high hopes for closer relations between the two countries for the benefit of both.

A shake-up that will affect between 150 and 200 detectives, particularly those who have gained preferred positions through Tammany influence, was strongly rumored at police headquarters yesterday in the face of official denials.

Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, revealed yesterday that Mayor LaGuardia had asked the Board of Education to start a "high school of art." He made the statement on explaining the Mayor's views on education, in a speech before the Women's City Club, 22 Park Avenue.

As often happens, to the chagrin of the stock market, the most important news was withheld yesterday until long after the close of business on the Stock Exchange. The President's gold proclamation had been widely discussed, and in some quarters predicted with surprising accuracy, but nobody seemed willing to speculate extensively on what might come out.

President ROOSEVELT signed the Gold Bill twice and it was again demonstrated that future historians who go to the news reels for evidence are in for a lot of trouble. The President really signed the bill in the presence of Secretary and Mrs. MORGENTHAU and two members of the White House secretarial staff.
" The Wind and the Rain," a comedy by Dr. Merton Hodge, will have its premiere this evening at the Ritz Theatre.

Despite heavy Investments in public utility securities, which adversely affected the value of assets, the Niagara Share Corporation paid all of its $1,500,000 notes due last year and acquired $862,000 more of its debentures at a net discount of $320,756, said the annual report, issued yesterday.

The authors of "Theodora, the Quean," take nothing so easy as love in a metropolitan pent-house, or in East Orange. Tiring of the present day, at least, they have sought out the sixth century, and Byzantium. The costumes are there, the slaves, the emperors; but otherwise the play which last night was put upon the stage of the Forrest Theatre is the drama of the Park Avenue boy and the girl from the house uptown.

The estate of Alfred P. Sloan, father of the president of the General Motors Corporation, was appraised yesterday at $2,297,220 gross and $2,103,379 net, of which $2,147,709 was in securities. He owned 14,770 shares of General Motors preferred worth $236,720, and had 6,950 shares of the Irving Trust Company valued at $183,306.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Twenty-two persons in the office of Robert G. Estill, Prosecutor, in Crown Point, Ind., today pointed accusing fingers at John Dillinger and unanimously agreed that he was the gunman who shot and killed Policeman Patrick O'Malley during the hold-up of the First National Bank of East Chicago, Ind., on Jan. 15.

The State of West Virginia announced yesterday that on Feb. 6 it would offer a new issue of $2,500,000 of refunding bonds dated June 1, 1933, and maturing serially from 1934 to 1953. Bidders are asked to name the rate of interest in multiples of one-quarter of 1 per cent at not to exceed 4 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Oscar W. Underwood Jr., chairman of the convention committee of the American Veterans Association, has issued a call to all chapters to have their delegates attend the second national convention in Washington at the Hotel Powhatan on Feb. 10, 11 and 12, under the auspices of the Washington Chapter.
Champagne foamed over the steel bow plates of the U.S.S. Hull yesterday as the first ship of the nation's new destroyer fleet was launched at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
A Staten Island woman, accused of having killed her 8-month-old son, is to be hynotized in an attempt to explore what psychiatrists have declared to be a blank period in her memory.
Plaintiffs bid in thirteen parcels at foreclosure sales in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. The results follow:

DUBLIN, Jan. 31. -- The Dail Eireann had scarcely reassembled today when the house was thrown into uproar. The trouble was precipitated by a question by the United Ireland party Deputy, John Burke, addressed to Minister of Justice Patrick Ruttledge, inquiring if the murderers of Cornelius Daly of Dummanway, the first Blue Shirt martyr, had been apprehended.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31. -- The three Soviet airmen who ascended in a balloon to the record height of 67,585 feet were killed instantly when the balloon crashed between 3:30 and 5 P.M. yesterday near Potisky Ostrog, about 150 miles due east of Moscow.
Warren Bachelis, who at 13 knows more about Ambrosius Theodosius Macrobius than he does about William Harold Terry, became last night one of the youngest high-school graduates in the city's history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- General Johnson threw a bombshell into the meeting of the State directors of the National Emergency Council today by announcing that Secretary of Labor Perkins already had appointed many of the labor advisers in the offices of the State directors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- New York theatre musicians sometimes are forced under a system of racketeering known as the "kick-back" to return part of' their salaries to theatre managers or contractors for theatre orchestras, members of the New York local of musicians informed the Copeland crime subcommittee this afternoon.

Melvin Lapman of Evander, who reached the final of the recent national boys' championship, fought his way into the semi-finals of the De Witt Clinton indoor tennis tourney yesterday in the most spectacular match that has thus far marked the schoolboy tournament.
VIENNA, Jan. 31. -- A very grave picture of the danger threatening the Dollfuss government was painted in the Lower Austrian Diet this afternoon by the Socialist Deputy Schneidmadl.

The grand prize of $25 in Sanitation Commissioner Ernest P. Goodrich's trash can slogan contest was awarded yesterday to Miss Florence Kehoe of 822 East 163d Street, the Bronx, whose slogan, picked as the best of 10,000 submitted, was "By the Law Abide -- Put Trash Inside."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Two series of Treasury bills aggregating $175,000,000 were advertised today by Secretary Morgenthau. The bids are to be received at the Federal Reserve Banks and branches up to 2 P.M., Eastern standard time, next Monday. The bills will be dated Feb. 7.

United States Government bonds were the strongest yesterday of the list on the Stock Exchange, the heavy buying being attributed to Federal sources. Long-term obligations of the government rose 2-32 to 23-32 point, with the exception of the comparatively inactive First Liberty 4 1/4s, which held unchanged.

An agreement for the broadcasting of news twice a day, for five minutes in the morning and five minutes in the evening, has been reached at a series of conferences between representatives of newspapers, press associations and radio groups, it was announced yesterday.

The Mandelbaum bill, which has been signed by Governor LEHMAN, may turn out to be one of the State's chief contributions to the realization of an ancient ideal: slum clearance and better housing for the poor of the great cities. It declares rehabilitation of areas in which "unsanitary or substandard" housing conditions exist a public purpose, and authorizes setting up municipal housing authorities to do the job.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 1. -- Japan is evidently preparing to take the position that the system of allocation of naval strength by ratios is inherently defective and has failed to reduce costs, lessen competition or diminish international tension after ten years' trial.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The possibility of a conference with Japan within the next few months to try to avert the threatened deadlock at the scheduled naval conference of 1935 is receiving consideration at th State Department, it was learned today.

The Dollar liner President Pierce, leaving today for Havana, the Panama Canal and San Francisco, will have among her passengers Mr. and Mrs. Clinton B. Allsopp, George Haas, Jimmy Dykes, Professor George D. Birkhoff, Mrs. A. Feist, Miss M. Feist, Mrs. Newton Kuttner, Martin B. Keenahan, Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Templeton, Miss Mabel Helene White and Prince and Princess J. Capece Zurlo.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan 31. -- John D. Griffin, formerly president of the Croton-on-Hudson Democratic Club, an attorney and real estate developer, testified before Supreme Court Justice Raymond Aldrich and a jury this afternoon that he and Milton J. Gordon, attorney on trial on charges of setting fire to the Hessian Hills Golf Club, of which Gordon was president, had conspired to burn the club buildings at Croton-on-Hudson "to make some money."

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 31. -- Craig Wood from Deal, N.J., shattered the course record today to lead the field in the first eighteen holes of the fifth annual $7,500 Agua Caliente open golf championship by scoring a sparkling 67.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Any probability of the sales tax becoming an issue at this session of Congress was seemingly dispelled today when the Ways and Means Committee referred to a subcommittee a proposal of Representative Crowther of New York for a 2 1/2 per cent manufacturers' excise levy.

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- The conference between Germany and her long-term creditors ended today with a compromise agreement, which, as far as the holders of German bonds are concerned, not only wipes out Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's recent cut in Germany's interest payments, but even increases them above what they were before Jan. 1.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
The New York Stock Exchange distributed yesterday to members copies of its year-book for 1932-33, containing statistics and historical data for the last year.

For the fifty-eighth annual bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club to be held in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 12, 13 and 14, an entry of 2,461 individual dogs has been received. This is the second largest entry in the history of the organization, the record of 2,673 having been established in 1930.

Assets of the Equity Corporation increased from $311,925 to $5,068,468 last year, and assets of controlled and associated companies, including the United Founders Corporation, now amount to approximately $50,000,000, against $6,225,234 a year earlier, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- Two grizzled fighters of four score years and more, both veterans of many wars, swapped battle yarns in the private study of the Reich's President today. 'One was President Paul von Hindenburg and the other Sir Ian Hamilton, British general, only four years the President's junior.

The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company reports net income of $7,764,977 for 1933, equal to $5.82 a share on 1,333,458 shares of capital stock, comparing with $8,999,876, or $6.75 a share, earned in 1932. There was a deficit of $233,771 after dividends of $6 a share, comparing with a deficit of $1,667,786 after dividends of $8 a share in 1932.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Gounod's "Faust," which was presented at the new Metropolitan Opera House at its opening night on Oct. 22, 1883, came back to that theatre last night a little more than half a century later, still appealing and popular, for its first performance of the season.

Call loan rates, following the fractional increases made in December, remained fixed throughout January at 1 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange and 1 1/2 per cent on the New York Curb Exchange; the same charges as prevailed a year before.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31. -- Stepping through light calisthenics, Maxie Rosenbloom, wearer of the light-heavyweight crown, and Challenger Joe Knight of Cairo, Ga., today tapered off training for their fifteen-round title bout here tomorrow night, the-first championship battle in Florida in forty years.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 31. -- Secretary Wallace, speaking today to farmers at the Wisconsin College of Agriculture, admitted the failure of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to do as much for the dairy industry as it had done for the wheat and cotton farmers, and outlined the government's new plans for helping the dairy farmers.

Anent the ruling, of Secretary Morgenthau in the matter of importations of Soviet Government lumber and pulpwood, he did not touch upon the one phase of this subject that should control the entire situation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Operation for practically a month of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has been attended by a very substantial increase in bank deposits, officials of the organization declared today.

Leaders in many fields of science and engineering allied with aviation gathered at Columbia University yesterday for the annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences. Informal discussions in the physics building revealed great progress during the past year in speed, safety, engine efficiency, radio communication and weather forecasting.

Marc Connelly, Alexander Woollcott and Heywood Broun shouted and hammered as auctioneers yesterday for the benefit of the Artists and Writers Dinner Club. The scene was Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue, and the occasion was a party given by a committee headed by Mrs. William Averell Harriman.
Creation of a State agency operating independently of the Insurance Department to act for mortgage investors was recommended yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

The world's operatic premiere of "Merry Mount," the music of which is by Howard Hanson and the libretto by Richard L. Stokes, and the first performance in the annual matinee Wagner cycle will be among the leading events at the Metropolitan Opera House next week, in the seventh week of the season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Drastic reductions in four executive departments under the 1934 appropriations and also in the budget estimates submitted by President Roosevelt were recommended to the House today when the 1935 fiscal year combination supply measure for the State, Justice, Commerce and Labor Departments was introduced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Cancellation of leases of terminals under Jurisdiction of the Shipping Board was approved today by Secretary Roper "where such leases have been entered into without due advertising and competitive bidding." The Secretary acted on a recommendation by Henry H. Heimann, director of the Shipping Board Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- As the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency neared completion of its inquiry into the affairs of the Detroit Trust Company, McPherson Browning, president of the reorganized trust company, was questioned today about a $2,500,000 deposit of the Ford Motor Company.

After most of yesterday's trading on the Cotton Exchange had been transacted at a slightly lower range of prices, rumors from Washington of the monetary developments that were announced later caused an advance which left gains of 4 to 5 points on the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Benjamin T. Batch, trust officer of the Toledo Trust Company, which holds a trust for Walter F. Brown, former Postmaster General, today told the Senate Committee investigating ocean and airmail contracts that Mr. Brown had told him yesterday in New York that of the 4,300 shares of International Mercantile Marine stock held in the trust, some 2,500 were acquired before Mr. Brown took office.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway began yesterday to pay $3,950,000 of 6 per cent notes which it sold to defray the purchase of stock in the Erie, New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) and Pere Marquette from the Alleghany Corporation.
The expected shake-up in the Police Department began yesterday with the transfer of sixty men ranging in rank from inspector to sergeant. Additional transfers are expected later.
PARIS, Feb 1. -- The taxi drivers of Paris have gone out on a strike which threatens to be prolonged land probably will excite sympathy strikes in the provinces.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1. -- Captain and Mrs. R. Amcotts Wilson gave a luncheon today at their villa, having Mrs. William Randolph Hearst, Mr. and Mrs. Otto H. Kahn, Mrs. John C.O. Marriott, Lady Abingdon, Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Phipps, Mrs. Marshall Field, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio, Wadsworth R. Lewis and Milton W. Holden as guests.

Three areas involving five census or sanitary districts in the Bronx were listed as worthy of consideration for slum clearance in a report yesterday by the Regional Plan Association giving the results of a re-housing survey in that borough.

Holder of the national team saber championship for more than a decade, the New York A.C. relinquished the crown as its team finished second to the Fencers Club in the titular meet last night at the Saltus Fencing Club. Third place went to the University Fencers Club.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- The market for hogs was extremely erratic today, with an early advance of 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight on kinds suitable for relief purposes, but at the close prices were little changed from those of the previous day.

On your editorial page of Jan. 30 there is this remark: "Perhaps New York's musical population, which Mr. Damrosch estimates at 1 per cent, will grow as the composers succeed in turning popular music to higher uses."

Not since the third week of last July, when the market was burgeoning, has there been such active trading on the Stock Exchange as was witnessed yesterday. The turnover was 4,713,000 shares, compared with 3,105,000 on the preceding day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- One government investigation has been started and grounds for another are being studied as the result of widespread complaints of the existence of a liquor trust.

Charles M. Andress, secretary of the Saratoga Springs Chamber of Commerce, visited the offices of the Saratoga Association here yesterday and announced that the petition in support of the Crawford-Herman bill for the relief of racing already had been signed by 10,000.

If "The Wind and the Rain," which was acted at the Ritz last evening, is not perfectly intelligible in this impetuous city it is possible that we do not understand British playwrighting perfectly. Although the language in the English and American theatres is technically the same, the minor plays that exchange homes across the Atlantic do not say the same things in London and New York.

ROME, Feb. 1. -- The British memorandum on disarmament has been read with considerable satisfaction in Italy, especially because of its similarity to Premier Mussolini's. It is felt that with Britain and Italy fighting for the same objectives the problem of disarmament has taken a decided step toward solution.
Mayor LaGuardia presented by radio last night to the people of the city and the State his case for the passage of the Economy Bill by the Legislature in Albany.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- The Boerse was livelier today. Heavy industrials had a somewhat soft beginning but were steadier later. Gains ranged beyond 5 points, although the day's best prices were not maintained. The firmness was attributed to the publication of the British-Italian memorandums calling for a certain amount of German rearmament, while the agreement on the debt transfer problem and stabilization of the dollar also helped sentiment.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reduced its rediscount rate yesterday from 2 per cent to 1 1/2, seeking, by this conventional central banking step in the face of an impending heavy influx of gold, to reassure foreign banks of issue against a fear that this country was seeking to "corner" the world's gold supply.
P, nnr nf important items in 19B3 cnnlpa;ed with preceding years. \]} figuro except ratio of reserve are m thousands of dollars:

Unless certain trades, for which the Dodgers are understood to be earnestly negotiating, materialize and thus alter present plans, a squad of thirty-four players will report to Manager Max Carey at Orlando this Spring. This was revealed yesterday with the distribution of the Brooklyn club's official roster for the 1934 campaign by Business Manager Bob Quinn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1. -- Official Yale and, apparently, the entire university was satisfied today with the ending of the discussion of football coaching plans. This came last night with the announcement of the appointment of Ray Pond and a new staff of assistants.

In two ways American holders of German bonds will benefit by the agreement concluded in Berlin. It promises cancellation of the special arrangement by which creditors in two countries -- Switzerland and the Netherlands -- have received full payment on their bonds, while all others have been asked to be content with less.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Charges of "wholesale" violations of the Recovery Act by the automobile industry will be placed before General Johnson shortly by President Green of the American Federation of Labor.

A group of independent steamship lines, operating from Gulf ports without membership in the established ship-line conferences, filed objection yesterday to the proposed steamship code which has been submitted by the American Steamship Owners Association to the National Industrial Recovery Administration.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 1. -- Airport officials here spent an anxious couple of hours yesterday when Miss Alice F. du Pont and her brother, Richard, who are flying from Miami to Rio de Janeiro in stages, did not arrive at the time they were expected, it became known today.

If a decision given yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Dore is upheld by the higher courts the Investors Syndicate of Minneapolis is liable for the return to New York residents of about $3,000,000 paid by them between 1927 and 1930 in the purchase of ten-year instalment certificates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- A Federal monetary authority as proposed by Frank A. Vanderlip would be far superior, Professor Irving Fisher today told a House Banking and Currency Subcommittee, "to permanently vesting the control of the dollar in the hands of the President or Secretary of the Treasury."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Security issues totaling nearly $6,500,000 are proposed in filed statements made public today by the Federal Trade Commission. The proposed certificates of deposit for reorganization or readjustment represent $2,500, 000, while about $3,500,000 is for investment companies.

The M.A.M. Holding Corporation, a syndicate represented by Goodman Mabel, attorneys, has bought the six four-story houses at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 139th Street for remodeling and modernizing. The buildings cover a plot 100 by 100 feet and were sold subject to a first mortgage of $70,000 held by the Dry Dock Savings Bank.

In the correspondence from Jerusalem in THE TIMES of Jan. 21 the division of Palestine into Jewish and Arab cantons, with each of these peoples living as a separate entity, was suggested as a solution of the Arab-Jewish problem. Carrying out the canton plan would result in crystalizing the status of Jews in Palestine and creating a political situation which would prevent the Jewish national home from further development.

THERE is an old joke about the longevity of the "condition of England" question, which, like the poor, is always with our cousins across the sea. Back in the Sixties the "condition of England" was grist for the mill of Karl Marx, who analyzed English capitalism. Today it is grist for the mill of Phyllis Bentley in the West Riding of Yorkshire, who makes novels of it.
" You Can't Buy Everything," with May Robson, Jean Parker and Lewis Stone, opens at the Capitol today. Miss Robson is making a personal appearance on the stage in conjunction with the film.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Conforming to the country's new gold status today, the Treasury's daily statement as of Jan. 30 lumped all gold in the sum of $4,029,092,988 instead of carrying it separately as gold coin and bullion.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- Governor Lehman's Agricultural Advisory Commission approved in principle the proposed Federal licensing plan for stabilizing the milk market, at a meeting in the executive chamber today.

Mrs. Walter Ewing Hope had a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 43 East Seventieth Street, for many of those interested in the special performance of "La Traviata" to be given this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Vassar Club.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

The Millrose A.A. is taking no chances on any errors by officials in the counting of laps. A lap-counting machine, designed and built by Gustavus Town Kirby, will be among the "officials" at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, it was revealed yesterday.

At first sight one would have said that the photograph in yesterday's paper showed a modern version of the return of the Prodigal Son. There on the right is the sturdy and winsome youth with his arm around the shoulder of the man with the paternal smile in the middle.

Additional dismissals of undesirable and rowdy workers employed on CWA park projects were made yesterday and Paul Blanshard. Commissioner of Accounts, was preparing to begin an Investigation into the disappearance of large quantities of materials and equipment supplied by the city for work in the parks.

A warning that the sales tax has once more come to the fore both in national and State Legislatures as "an inevitable factor in the attempt to raise funds" was sounded yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at a meeting in the association's headquarters here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The United States has notified all countries signatory to the International Wheat Agreement that it will not consider suggestions for pegging world wheat prices or other "palliatives" unless they take definite steps toward carrying out both the spirit and the letter of the agreement.

That the markets would give a more or less turbulent reception to Wednesday's White House announcement was foregone. The President's proclamation went a step beyond previous periodical changes in the Treasury's official price for gold and therefore in its theoretical valuation of the dollar.

Siberian weather raised the curtain of the Casino, the former Earl Carroll Theatre, punctually at 8:30 last night, on mighty "Boris Godunoff" as the first presentation of The Art of Russia, Inc., in a modern home of stagecraft on Broadway. An interior of Pompeiian red, black and silver reflected the brilliantly lighted Russian motley of scene and costume on the stage.

The veteran team of Clarence C. PelI and Stanley G. Mortimer, the dominating players in American racquets since 1915, hurdled their first obstacle in quest of another] title yesterday as the nationall racquets doubles got under way atI the Racquet and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- A partisan debate started in the House today, with Representative Snell, Republican leader, denouncing the Democrats for their failure to support the recovery plans advocated by President Hoover.

Although under suspension and facing a departmental trial on charges of neglect of duty and incompetency, Warden Joseph A. McCann, of the Welfare Island Penitentiary, applied yesterday for retirement on a pension. In his application to the Board of Estimate he gave physical disability "incurred in line of duty" as his reason for wishing to retire.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 1. -- Chileans are becoming alarmed over reports that Argentina is trying to settle the Chaco war between Paraguay and Bolivia by arranging for Bolivia to gain access to the sea through Argentine territory. It has occurred to Chileans that such a settlement would take a great deal of business away from Northern Chilean ports since Bolivia has been virtually limited to Chilean ports as outlets since the Nitrate War of 1870.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Plans for the formation of an agency within the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to finance exports to Russia and other countries became known today following a White House conference participated in by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC; William C. Bullitt, Ambassador to Russia, and John Wiley, counselor of the embassy at Moscow.

Joseph Johnson, general manager of the Triborough Bridge Authority, resigned his $13,500 job last night. He gave as his reason the fact that the State Civil Service Commission had refused to grant his application for exemption from the civil service lists.

Although outwardly rallying to the support of the new football coaching staff, headed by Ducky Pond, Yale alumni yesterday displayed a lack of enthusiasm over the compromise solution of this problem and clearly indicated that the Eli athletic house is still sharply divided against itself.

In the House on Monday the ancient question, to pad or not to pad the misnamed Congressional Record, was again discussed. Majority Leader BYRNS threw the first ball by asking unanimous consent to insert "a very excellent and eloquent address" on Georgia delivered by Representative PARKER of that State at Valley Forge, and "a tribute to Georgia" by the Cedartown High School.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 1. -- Wilfred Hiram (Wiffy) Cox, 36-year-old Brooklyn professional, added a smart 70 today to a fine 69 yesterday for a total of 139 to lead the field in the Agua Caliente open golf championship by two strokes.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- Overt Nazi propaganda in the Sear Basin territory by citizens of the Reich has been called off by the German Government. In a statement issued tonight it disavows any intention of influencing, next year's plebiscite there.

The Book-of-the-Month Club selection for March will be Matthew Josephson's composite biography of the American capitalist, "The Robber Barons," in which the great financial figures of the last half of the last century are interpreted as no more "wicked" than their contemporaries, but rather as tools of the economic forces of their time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 31, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,640,000,000, a decrease of $8,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $561,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.
VIENNA, Feb. 1. -- The Austrian trade mission that will leave for the United States Tuesday hopes to effect the removal of various handicaps to which Austro-American commerce is now subjected.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 1. -- The League of Nations commission's efforts to arrange peace between Bolivia and Paraguay in the Chaco are deadlocked on the question of the President Hayes arbitral award. Bolivia insists that the area which President Hayes of the United States awarded to Paraguay a half-century ago must be included in any new arbitration of the Chaco dispute.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- The German Government, in a voluminous reply to the Austrian note of Jan. 17 protesting against German Nazi interference in Austria's affairs, retorted, in effect, today that National Socialism would not stop at the frontier of Austria, which was as German as Bavaria.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1. -- Jockey Earl Porter, leading rider at the recent Tropical Park session, scored with four mounts at Hialeah Park today to bring his total winners for the current meeting to eleven and his 1934 total to forty-seven.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- The sale of 6,447 American motor trucks in overseas markets during December, an export business double that in November, is hailed by trade observers as indicating a continued pick-up in business prospects abroad. Exports of commercial vehicles were nearly three times larger than the shipments in December, 1932.

The Mortgage Conference of New York, composed of the lending institutions of this city, held its first convention yesterday at the Hotel Commodore to discuss the protection of investments in real estate.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- The late Tammany administration, in addition to leaving a $31,000,000 deficit in the budget, also left obligations of approximately $82,000,000, due and payable during the present year, as a legacy of trouble to the Fusion administration that succeeded it, according to testimony given today before the Senate Cities Committee by City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr.

A retrospective group of paintings by Georgia O'Keeffe has opened at An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue. In arranging it Alfred Stieglitz selected work from as far back as 1915, the year of O'Keeffe's first appearance at the pioneer Stieglitz gallery on Fifth Avenue called "291."

The State Education Department presented free concerts yesterday by the New York State Symphonic Band at the Bronx Continuation School, the Knickerbocker Little Symphony at Textile High School, the University Dance Orchestra at Greenwich House, the Capitol String Quartet at St. Gabriel's Park public library, the Empire Quartet at St. Agnes library and the Harlem Trio at Abyssinian Baptist Church.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, Bay of Whales, Antarctica, Jan. 31. -- The Bear of Oakland, supply ship of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition, is berthed alongside the flagship Jacob Ruppert, and since midnight the two ships have been simultaneously discharging Winter stores to the bay ice, six miles from Little America.

The charitable and philanthropic institutions that are residuary legatees of the estate of Miss Ella V. von E. Wendel, once valued at $100,000,000, have decided to form a foundation under special act of the Legislature to avoid liquidation of the estate's large real estate holdings, it became known yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1. -- There will be 50,000 persons in Red Square tomorrow to witness the placing of the ashes of the three stratosphere balloon victims in the Kremlin wall, and a million more Russians will march afterward through the square to pay their last tribute to the men.

The listed bond market kept pace with the share market yesterday, all classifications of bonds advancing briskly. Transactions on the Stock Exchange, which reached $26,616,000, were the heaviest since March 20, 1930. Domestic railroad, utility and industrial bonds averaged higher in the order named, with the combined average just under the best mark for 1933.
Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff gave a dinner last night at the Riding Club for Mrs. Frederic Ashton de Peyster, who is sailing tomorrow on the Rex.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- No replies have been received by the British Government from Paris, Berlin and Rome to its latest disarmament proposals, but unofficial reports concerning the reaction of France and Germany are unfavorable. The first reactions reported from Paris were so hostile that fears for the fate of the British memorandum are increasing among members of the Cabinet which sponsored it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Despite heavy costs of unemployment relief, annual expenditures by States and local government have been cut $1,000,000,000 below the peak, according to a report made today by the committee on State and local expenditures of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

The development of greatest significance in the day's money market came after the close of trading when the Reserve Bank announced a cut in the rediscount rate to 19 per cent from-, which had been in effect since last October.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the fourth State reception on their social program, entertaining in honor of the officials of the Treasury, Postoffice, Interior, Agriculture, Commerce and Labor Departments, and of other Federal agencies, including many emergency organizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- While the public was holding United Aircraft and Transport stock valued on the market at $168,000,000, the National City Company of New York made a profit of $5,895,311 on a cash investment of about $14,800,000 and issued stock at $30 a share to a preferential list, the same stock opening on the Exchanges at $97, the Senate committee investigating ocean and air mail contracts was told today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The attempt of the Code Authority of the Newsprint Industry to obtain NRA approval for basing prices upon zones rather than f.o.b. mill was attacked today as an attempt to "set up a monopoly in the manufacture and sale of newsprint paper for use in the United States and to obtain for the monopoly absolute power over the price to be extracted from the consumers of newsprint."

MOSCOW, Friday, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Fully authenticated records said to show that the three young Russian balloonists who were killed Tuesday had reached a height of 72,178 feet [13.67 miles], instead of 67,585 feet, as previously reported, were made public early today.

The payment of interest on a bond on the basis of the former value of the gold dollar is demanded in a suit filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Norman C. Norman of 40 West Forty-eighth Street against the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company.

The Code Authority of the Motion Picture Industry will move about Feb. 15 to the R.K.O. Building, Rockefeller Center, it was announced yesterday. Other business leases reported included the following:

At the end of this week the collection of twenty sculptures of British champion animals by the American sculptor Herbert Haseltine, will be packed up at the galleries of M. Knoedler Co., 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, where they have been on view since Jan. 15, for shipment to the Field Museum in Chicago, to which they will go as a gift of Marshall Field.

Herbert Singer, lawyer, and son of Saul Singer, executive vice president of the Bank of United States, was cross-examined yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente in the $60,000,000 suit brought by Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, against the directors of the bank.

Under conditions giving the city a month in which to work out its subway policy, the Interborough Rapid Transit Company sued yesterday for permission to disaffirm its lease of the Manhattan Railway Company elevated lines.

TOKYO, Feb. ! (z). -- There will be no Russo-Japanese war "unless the war is carried to us by the other side," General Senjuro Hayashi lold The Associated Press today in the firs', intervie-v since his appointment as War ]YIinister, succeeding General Sado Araki.

The first shuffling of the new deal for the parks of New York City and its suburbs is already under way. Commissioner MOSES has ordered a clean-up of CWA works and workers. "Loafers must go" is the slogan. The more elaborate features of Mr. CHARLES DOWNING LAY'S plan for the development of Marine Park in Brooklyn, at an ultimate cost of some $40,000,000, are to be abandoned.

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- Mlle. Louise Weiss, who founded and has directed the important political weekly L'Europe Nouvelle for the last sixteen years, has announced that she is going to retire from the direction of her paper.

Joseph Abrams of Clinton gained an opportunity to repeat his success of a year ago by reaching the final round of the De Witt Clinton High School interscholastic indoor tennis tourney yesterday. No player has ever succeeded in carrying off the honors two years in a row.

Candlemas Day, when, according to homely legend, the groundhog comes from the earth looking for shadows to jump at, will be observed today by virtually every one in the nation but the groundhog itself. Far from being afraid of shadows, the sluggish rodent would not dream of leaving home till the earth has been comfortably warmed by the sun and a shadow virtually is guaranteed in advance.

There is much interest in fishing at this period of the year because of legislation which concerns both fresh and salt water angling. Even though the average fisherman is not indulging in his favorite sport, he is not without thought for the future. In New Jersey, for instance, a bill now before the Legislature would alter the present trout-fishing season.

Pending action by the Board of Estimate to turn over to the Park Department the Chrystie-Forsyth area, Park Commissioner Moses announced yesterday that detailed plans for improvement of the land as a park would wait.

WASHINGTON, Feb 1 (AP). -- Senate administration forces lost the first struggle today to block new veterans' legislation, and then gave out strong hints they would not object to enacting into law portions of the new Presidential regulations adding $21,000,000 to the former soldiers' compensation.

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- France rejected Germany's offer of non-aggression pacts and charged Chancellor Hitler's program "would lead directly to an armaments race" in a note, published tonight, which was sent the German Government on Jan. 1.

A snowstorm that caused many street accidents, hampered traffic and disrupted airplane communications struck the city yesterday morning, lasted all day and for several hours last night. Cloudy and colder weather was forecast for today, with rain or snow.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- Governor Lehman announced today that he had selected Kenneth O'Brien, his campaign manager in 1932, to fill the place on the Supreme Court bench left vacant by the death of Justice Curtis A. Peters.
Mady Christians, whose last appearance here was in "A Divine Drudge," has been engaged for a leading role in the Theatre Guild's forthcoming play, "Races."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- A slight increase of average wholesale commodity prices last week marked the fifth consecutive week in which prices have advanced and brought them approximately to the level of May, 1931, Isador Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, reported today.

The $1,000 bail bond of John Sheehan Jr. was ordered forfeited yesterday and a warrant issued for his arrest when he failed to appear before Magistrate Burke in Morrisania court to answer a charge of suspicion of larceny.

The United Fruit Company may pay its entire indebtedness of $13,802,375 to the United States Government in the coming year, according to the annual report issued yesterday. The debt is the balance of a loan obtained under the Merchant Marine Act of 1928 for the construction of mail ships.
YALE finally announced its selections for the football coaching staff and the effect on trade should be immediate. Ever so many persons can now go back to minding their own businesses.

Indicating possible intervention by the Regional Labor Board in the hotel strike situation in this city, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, acting chairman of the board, requested yesterday the Amalgamated Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union, the strike organization, to report to the board the number of strikers and hotels involved.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 2. -- Suggestions that the politicians, having had their innings against the army, should now turn to tamer topics have not yet registered. Public interest in the present session of Parliament continues to be focused on charges the politicians continue to bring in language which is becoming plainer against military meddling in politics.

Edward Corsi, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization at Ellis Island for two and a half years, announced yesterday that he had sent his resignation to Colonel Daniel W. McCormack, Commissioner General of Immigration, at Washington. It became effective immediately.

Miss Harriet Cohen did some missionary work for the British composer in her concert at the Town Hall last night. Her first group was devoted to representatives of several centuries back; Orlando Gibbons, a brief suite; Henry Purcell, Movements of the Suite, and Thomas Arne, Sonata No. 2.

VIENNA, Feb. 1 (AP). -- The German answer to the Austrian note threatening to appeal to the League of Nations if Nazi terrorism was not stopped in Austria was rejected as "unsatisfactory" tonight by the Cabinet.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1. -- Wood F. Axton's 3-year-old gelding Two Sons accounted for his second triumph within a week when he was able to hold a slim lead long enough to score by a nose over Mrs. Floyd West's Cursor in the mile of the St. James Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- Virtually eliminated from the Lindbergh kidnapping, Verne Sankey, the chunky little South Dakota farmer, who turned kidnapper, was arraigned this evening before Federal Judge John B. Barnes, who ordered his immediate removal to Pierre, S.D., to stand trial for the abduction of Charles Boettcher 2d, a wealthy broker of Denver.

Of the $20,263,876.35 in water charges due the city on Jan. 31 only $7,486,225.70 has been paid, Controller W. Arthur Cunningham announced yesterday. All those who failed to make the payments face a penalty of 7 per cent interest on the sum due from Jan. 1 until their account is paid.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Revaluation of the dollar will be "very helpful to business" and will be reflected soon in longer payrolls, Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, economist and vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, said today.

The Bankers NRA Committee for Greater New York announced following a meeting held yesterday that it would resume its work on a set of banking rules for the metropolitan area, based on the standard formula provided by the NRA.

CHICAGO. Feb. 1. -- Official devaluation of the dollar and the advance in the price of gold fell almost flat today as a direct market influence on grains on the Board of Trade. Wheat advanced around 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish at the extreme, but this was due largely to sympathy with stocks and to short covering, which followed a moderate amount of buying by the East.

E. Roland Harriman, president of the investment banking concern of Brown Brothers. Harriman Co., was elected president of the Boys Club of New York at the annual meeting of the trustees last night in the University Club, 1 West Fifty-fourth Street. Mr. Harriman succeeds the late Charles H. Sabin.

SOUTH BEND, Feb. 1. -- Elmer Layden sat down at Knute Rockne's famous old desk under the golden dome today and began his active campaign to bring Notre Dame back to its former glory in the football world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The army general staff air expansion program, providing for gradual acquisition of new airplanes over a five-year period, was introduced today by Chairman McSwain of the House Military Affairs Committee.

Although the share market, in the scope of its recovery, was somewhat disappointing yesterday to Wall Street, the volume of business on the Stock Exchange indicated that the promulgation of the President's monetary program had aroused widespread speculative and investment interest.

OTTAWA, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Observers here expressed the opinion today that the most important immediate effect upon Canada of President Roosevelt's new monetary policy would be that Canadian gold would probably now go to the United States, whereas for nearly a year it has been shipped principally to London.

Settlement of the controversy between the Peerless Corporation and Redmond Co. over the latter's refusal to accept delivery of 92,071 shares of Peerless stock under an underwriting agreement was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 1. -- A trolley car carrying eight passengers, but no motorman, ran away in the centre of town here today, rolling at forty miles an hour down a mile-long hill, crashing into an automobile and causing injuries to four persons.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra continued its Beethoven Cycle under Toscanini last night in Carnegie Hall with the Sixth or "Pastoral" symphony in F major and the Seventh symphony in A major. While snow whirled and winds howled outside the auditorium, Spring blossomed within.
LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The proposal to amend the State Insurance Law in relation to fraternal benefit societies was opposed yesterday by delegates of the New York Fraternal Congress, comprising fraternal insurance societies of the United States and Canada, at its annual meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.

The appointment of Dr. John A. Hartwell as director of the New York Academy of Medicine to fill the vacancy left by Dr. Linsly R. Williams, who died on Jan. 8, was announced last night by Dr. Bernard Sachs, president, at a meeting of the academy.

Commodity futures prices were irregular yesterday and for the most part indicated little enthusiasm for the overnight developments respecting the dollar. Trading was heavy in most markets, but, with a few exceptions, little progress was made in either direction.

William V. (Big Bill) Dwyer, who was known as "king of the bootleggers" seven years ago when Federal Judge Julian W. Mack sent him to Atlanta for two years, is defendant in an action begun yesterday by the Federal Government to recover more than $4,256,002.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York voted yesterday in favor of "seven vital changes" in the laws governing New York municipal pensions. Jacob H. Haffner, chairman of the Committee on Public Service in the Metropolitan District, estimated "that these amendments will save the city from $5,000,000 to $6,000,000 a year and will place the pension system on a sound actuarial basis."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Federal regulation of highway transportation agencies to the same extent as applied to railroads was approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission today in a report to the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce on the Rayburn bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- President Roosevelt issued an Executive order today putting "teeth" into the election machinery designed by the National Labor Board to ascertain the will of the employes for collective bargaining.

William E. Coyle Jr., the 17-year-old representative of the Montclair Athletic Club, yesterday scored an impressive triumph over H.F. (Pink) Baker of the Princeton Club in the quarter-final round of the metropolitan Class A squash racquets championship at the University Club.

Democratic Assembly district leaders opposed to the continuance of John F. Curry as leader of Tammany Hall were surprised and puzzled yesterday by the discovery that an amendment to the rules of the Democratic County Committee of New York County, filed with the Board of Elections, had established sixteen ex officio members of the executive committee.

A reduction of $12,655,223 in the contingency reserve representing the difference between market and convention valuation of investments on Dec. 31, last, is shown in the annual report of the Home Insurance Company for 1933. Total as sets were $89,679,382, comparing with $98,030,337 a year earlier.
LONDON, Feb. 1. -- The pound followed the dollar downhill in terms of gold currencies today as closely as if the British authorities were deliberately pushing it down.

Because of the ultra-conservatism of bankers in Europe, the financial dawn must come from the United States, Sir Henri W. A. Deterding, general managing director of the Royal Dutch Company and chairman of the Shell Union Oil Corporation, said in a letter just received by a banker here.

A syndicate headed by the Guaranty Company of New York won yesterday the award of a new issue of $6,000,000 State of California unemployment relief bonds at an auction sale held by the State. The bonds, due $2,000,000 on July 1, 1941 to 1943, brought a price of 104.008 as 4 1/2s. Four other groups competed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Armed with its $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund, the Treasury Department today began operations to maintain the dollar at its new level of 59.06 cents in relationship to foreign currencies, in the hope that other governments will cooperate with the United States and that a currency war will be averted.

Net income of Standard Brands, Inc., and subsidiary companies in 1933 was $15,048,795 after charges, depreciation, Federal taxes and minority interest. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.15 a share on 12,645,374 no par common shares.

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- In a case deriving special importance from the present situation in Europe, the public prosecutor of the Seine Tribunal yesterday asked for a court decree dissolving the League of Conscientious Objectors in France.

Benny Friedman, former all-America quarterback at Michigan and a professional football star, may become head football coach at City College if and when a group of alumni raise sufficient funds to pay his salary, President Frederick B. Robinson stated yesterday to The Associated Press.

Continuing their drive to end racketeering in the city's markets, Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. and Michael Fiaschetti, his deputy, revoked the permits yesterday of thirteen push-cart proprietors who have been doing business in the Peck Slip fish market.

Stimulated by the dollar stabilization program as announced by President Roosevelt after the close of the market Wednesday, a swift upward movement took place in most security prices yesterday and many issues sold at the highest levels in several years.

Reduction in the gold content of the dollar, which many operators had been expecting since last Spring, had less effect yesterday on commodity than on security markets, and after an early rise of 15 points prices on the Cotton Exchange fell back and ended 2 to 6 points higher than on Wednesday.

More than 300 representatives of employes of institutions and agencies supported by the Federation for the support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies voted unanimously last night to hold a two-hour strike or "stoppage" unless wage demands were granted.

Making an unusually large gain from the preceding week, bank clearings in twenty-one leading cities throughout the country showed for the week ended on Wednesday a wide gain over the same week in 1933, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- News of the revaluation of the dollar was received here with general admiration for President Roosevelt's prompt action but considerable uncertainty concerning its exact bearing.

Thousands of automobile owners stood in line yesterday at offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles to obtain the 1934 plates for their cars; while others, thanks to a Police Department order, continued to drive their vehicles with the 1933 licenses, which had expired officially at midnight Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Loans to forty-three Judges totaling $639,631 were on the books of the Wayne First National Bank, major unit of the Detroit Bankers Company, on Dec. 11, 1933, the date of the most recent check-up, according to a receiver's statement supplied to the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency today.

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- If the Daladier Cabinet survives its first meeting with the Chamber of Deputies next Tuesday, which will depend on the energy it shows in the Stavisky scandal inquiry, it is expected to oppose the suggestions in the British and Italian armaments memoranda published yesterday.
The first of the monthly index numbers of commodity prices, that of Dun's Review, was published yesterday. It figures out an advance in the general average prices during January of 1 3/8 per cent.

By far the most eloquent "Tristan und Isolde" of the season thus far was presented last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. It is fair to assume that a large measure of the uncommon vitality and eloquence of the performance were due to the first appearance this season of Frida Leider as Isolde.

A "substantial" increase in the city's appropriation for home relief for February to enable the Home Relief Bureau to provide for 15,000 families who are not now receiving help, will be requested by the Welfare Department, Commissioner William Hodson announced in a radio address last night.

A controversy between the Van Sweringen interests and the Arthur Curtiss James group over the fiscal policies of the Denver Rio Grande Western has halted negotiations to merge that line with the Western Pacific. Both sides were reported yesterday to be mustering support with the intention of bringing the matter to an issue at a meeting of the Rio Grande board in the week of Feb. 12.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- Bills to carry out recommendations of the Commission on Administration of Justice for revision of the statutes governing perjury were introduced today by Senator John L. Buckley, chairman of the commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- In quantity, if not in percentage also, the President is the most popular man in public office today. The Germans swear by Chancellor Hitler, and the Italians by Premier Mussolini, but the combined population of those countries is less than that of the United States.

Difficulties experienced in convincing retailers that facts they furnish in the census of American business for 1933, launched here and in other cities this week by the Bureau of the Census of the United States Department of Commerce, will be treated in confidence, threaten to slow up the work in Manhattan and Richmond, H. Wayne Pierson, supervisor for the two boroughs, said here yesterday.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 1. -- Tommy Goodwin of the Monroe (N.Y.) Country Club, holder of the Empire State junior title, brought an abrupt halt to the onward rush of Morton McCarthy, Norfolk (Va.) high school football star, in the quarter-finals of the national championship of golf club champions today.
PANAMA CITY, Feb. 1. -- The life of President Arias was probably saved by the timely discovery of a plot to assassinate him last Saturday, according to an extra issued by the Star and Herald today.

A struggle loomed yesterday between the large automobile companies and the important steel units over the method of quoting prices established by the steel code, according to leaders of both industries.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents.

The resignation of Howard G. (Jake) Cann as New York University football coach was announced by the N.Y.U. Board of Athletic Control last night. This news came as a complete surprise, since there had not been even the slightest hint that such a move had been contemplated.
