WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Administration spokesmen in Congress are expecting to receive definite word any day from President Roosevelt to proceed with legislation for Federal regulation of stock exchanges.

The resignation of Howard G. (Jake) Cann as New York University football coach was announced by the N.Y.U. Board of Athletic Control last night. This news came as a complete surprise, since there had not been even the slightest hint that such a move had been contemplated.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- The United States women's squash racquets team easily triumphed over the Ladies Carlton Club, 6 to 1, today. Before the match the club gave a luncheon in honor of the American players.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 (AP). -- An organized movement was started today by the New York State Conference of Mayors to mobilize support for Governor Lehman's twelve-point public utilities program.

A rise of $109,000,000 in brokers' loans, carrying the total to $888,000,000, was reported yesterday in the condition statement of member banks in New York City issued by the Federal Reserve Bank. The rise was due in part to the increasing activity in the stock market, but it also reflected the larger borrowing of dealers in government securities in connection with the recent Treasury financing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Administration spokesmen in Congress are expecting to receive definite word any day from President Roosevelt to proceed with legislation for Federal regulation of stock exchanges.

Ever since the Armistice British policy on the Continent has been in a strait betwixt two. This does not mean the old question -- or curse -- of European alliances nor yet a return to the theory of the Balance of Power. What has taxed the brains of the British Foreign Office is the difficulty of maintaining good relations with both France and Germany.

The differences between "normal tax and surtax rates" were explained in an announcement made public yesterday by the Bureau of Internal Revenue. The normal tax rate is 4 per cent on the first $4,000 of net income and 8 per cent on the remainder.

Supreme Court Justice Curtis A. Peters, who died on Dec. 17, left almost all of his estate to his widow and children in his will, filed yesterday. The estate is formally valued at "more than $20,000."
The text of Mayor LaGuardia's radio address last night follows:

In a voice so indistinct that his answers several times had to be repeated by the stenographer, Joseph Rao, Welfare Island penitentiary racketeer, testified as a "character witness" in General Sessions yesterday at the trial of another inmate for murder.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's credit-expansion policies might be followed by actual inflation of the currency, Walter E. Edge, former Ambassador to France, said today in an address before the Philadelphia Board of Trade and the Manufacturers and Bankers Club.

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- The Paris exchange market today had one of its most exciting and confusing sessions since the franc was stabilized. The dollar proved wildly erratic because no one in Paris knew, even well after the markets and banks had closed, whether New York would buy gold freely at $35.
GENEVA, Feb. 1. -- The British and Italian disarmament plans impress observers here as attempts to solve the problem by a much greater degree of rearmament than any powers had openly approved before.
The dollar rose to a premium of 4.7 cents above its new parity in the foreign exchange market yesterday and closed higher on the day at a premium of 3.4 cents, measured against the franc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Tobacco tax collections last year amounted to $409,308,921, as compared with $387,271,269 the year before, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins, with Eddie Shore playing with old-time abandon, fought to a 2-2 overtime tie tonight with the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League match in which most of the thrills and action came in the first period.

After deliberating about an hour, a General Sessions jury yesterday afternoon returned a verdict of guilty of assault in the third degree against Eugene S. Daniell Jr. for having discharged two tear-gas bombs in the New York Stock Exchange at noon on last Aug. 4.

A growing interest of the judiciary in human relations and social welfare was traced last night by Associate Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals in an address at the annual dinner of the Brooklyn Bar Association at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 1. -- R.H. Martin's speedy old mare, Night Flash, dashed to victory in the six furlongs of the featured race at Agua Caliente today. Anapola was second and Portcodine third in a field of eight platers.

Chancellor J.O. Wolcott of Wilmington, Del., approved on Wednesday the reorganization plan of bondholders of the East Coast Utilities Company and ordered the sale at public auction at Richmond, Va., on Feb. 26, of the miscellaneous receivership assets of the company.

Tony Canzoneri and Cleto Locatelli will clash in a return bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The pair, who traveled over the ten-round route on Dec. 15, with Canzoneri winning the decision, will make their second battle a twelve-rounder.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- Artificial radioactivity has been produced for the first time by Professor F. Joliot and Mme. Irene Curie-Joliot, the famous Paris physicists who are husband and wife. Mme. Curie-Joliot is the daughter of the discoverers of radium.

A fine display of courage and aggressiveness enabled the New York Rangers to earn a tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. Faced with a 3 -- 0 deficit at the end of the first period, Lester Patrick's skaters fought their rivals savagely and before the end of the third period rolled around had succeeded in drawing abreast at 5 -- 5.

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- By rejecting the appropriation asked for the relief of United States Government employes in the diplomatic and consular services abroad, who are suffering from the depreciation of the dollar, the House Appropriations Committee has placed in a state of real privation the 150 clerks and minor employes in the splendid new United States Embassy building in the centre of Paris.
The Boston Metropolitan Transit District is expected to announce a new issue of $2,098,000 of three-year bonds.

AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Apparently participating in a suicide pact, Dr. Claude Mattingly, aged 39, a specialist in diseases of children, and Mrs. F.A.C. Perrin, about 35, wife of a psychology professor at the University of Texas, were found dead in a hotel here today.

Six more committees for the 1936 Olympic Games were announced yesterday by Secretary Frederick W. Rubien of the American Olympic Committee. This brings the total number of committees already revealed to eighteen. Five more will be ready for release today.
Housing properties in Manhattan and a business building in the Bronx proved attractive to operators again yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 2. -- A jury in Supreme Court here today returned a verdict in favor of Saks Co. in the $100,000 damage suit brought against the company by Lieut. Commander Frank M. Hawks, air speed-record holder, for alleged unauthorized use of a caricature of him in a magazine advertisement.

Stockholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., will be asked at their annual meeting on March 12 to ratify the action of the directors in approving a new form of bonus plan and a new form of executives stock-purchase and merit-bonus plan, according to a letter sent to them by Lammot du Pont, president.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- Challenging the constitutionality of the AAA licensing program for milk stabilization, Attorney General Bennett handed down an opinion today in which he warned against any further extension of Federal control in the national recovery drive.

The telegraph, telephone and radio companies, the army and navy will probably endorse the report which has been submitted by the President's interdepartmental committee and which recommends unification of communications under the control but not under the ownership of the Government. A situation has arisen which certainly calls for correction, especially in telegraphic communication by wire, cable and radio.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- All monarchist propaganda has been outlawed in Nazi Germany, at least for the time being. Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, ordered today the immediate dissolution of all monarchist organizations and he forbade the formation of similar associations.
Democratic members of the Assembly joined with local Republicans yesterday in criticizing Mayor LaGuardia's presentation of the city's financial plight over the radio last Thursday night.

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- Two consignments of gold of a total value exceeding 5,600,000 will he shipped from Europe to New York tomorrow. The Cunard liner Berengaria is expected to carry 4,000,000 of gold, mostly from Britain, while the German liner Bremen is taking 1,600,000 from Britain, as well as a considerable amount from Cherbourg.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- A warning to radio stations to observe the proprieties in broadcasting liquor advertising was issued by the Federal Radio Commission today.

Long Island University's undefeated basketball team scored its nineteenth successive victory last night. Arnold College of New Haven was the victim, 42-24, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.
Mrs. Philip Kip Rhinelander gave a luncheon yesterday at the Park Lane for her aunt, Countess Alexandro Mercati of Paris; Mrs. Hill Orvis and Mrs. Thomas Blake.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The Civil Works Administration program should end on May 1 or shortly thereafter through a tapering-off process, Harry L. Hopkins, Civil Works Administrator, said in testimony Tuesday at an executive session of the House subcommittee in charge of deficiency appropriations.

Hertha Thiele, the schoolgirl heroine of "Maedchen in Uniform," will be brought to America this Fall by John Krimsky and Gifford Cochran, to whom she is under contract. The producers are seeking a vehicle for the young German star. Their English dialogue version of the film, "Girls in Uniform," will end its engagement at the Criterion tomorrow night.

With the renewal of the great series of Gene Venzke-Glenn Cunningham foot-racing duels as the featured attraction the Millrose A. A. will stage its twenty-seventh annual indoor track and field games at Madison Square Garden tonight. A capacity crowd of more than 16,000 is indicated by the fact that the reserved seat supply is virtually exhausted and that only 5,000 unreserved balcony seats remain.

MILLBRAE, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP). -- Ogden L. Mills, whom political observers have regarded as a possible contender for the Republican nomination for President in 1936, said today he was not a candidate.
PARIS, Feb. 2. -- The winner of a 5,000,000-franc prize in the fifth French national lottery succeeded today in cashing his ticket in Paris without disclosing his identity.

The Rev. Dr. William Hubert Rogers, pastor of the Hinton Memorial Baptist Church, Portland, Ore., has accepted a call to the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, this city, it was announced yesterday by the official board of the church here.

Sam Kaplan, former president of Local 306 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union of New York, lost his appeal yesterday to upset his sentence of six months in prison for coercing unsympathetic members of the union, and to reverse a judgment ousting him from his office and from control of the union.
ISLIP, L.I., Feb. 2. -- Fire early this morning completely destroyed the large hangar of the Islip Airport, Inc., and seven planes which were stored there. The damage has been estimated at $100,000.

" Don Giovanni" will have its last performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night, with Mmes. Ponselle, Mueller. Fleischer and Messers Pinza, Schipa, Lazzari, Rothier and D'Angelo, Mr. Serafin conducting.

The taxicab strike came so suddenly as to take the community unawares. Some of the issues in the controversy are still confused. However, its origin is clear enough. The difficulty arose out of the action of the O'Brien administration in imposing a tax on taxicab rides only to have it thrown out by the lower courts.
HARRISON, N.J., Feb. 2. -- New Jersey soon may have its first woman brewer.

Heavy buying of bonds of all classifications at steadily advancing prices was again the order of the day on the Stock Exchange yesterday. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of forty domestic corporation bonds touched the highest level since 1931 as these issues were bid up fractionally to 3 points and in a few instances to as high as 7 points.

A daily radio talk on all station in which the city will inform horsewives what foods will be abundant and at low price, is planned by Mayor LaGuardia, he told the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs in convention at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:
" The Pure in Heart," by John Howard Lawson, has been acquired by the firm of Richard Aldrich and Alfred de Liagre Jr. for immediate production.

Beekman Pool of the Harvard Club, defending champion, and William E. Coyle Jr. of the Montclair Athletic Club will meet as contenders for the metropolitan Class A squash racquets singles championship at the University Club today as a result of their victories in the semi-final round yesterday.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 2. -- It will be the North vs the South in the final of the national championship of golf club champions on St. Augustine links tomorrow.

The flow of timid, liquid capital which has sloshed about the world money markets in the past few years, sweeping one country after another off the gold standard, turned full-tide toward the new safety of the American dollar yesterday.

The Mayor's suggestion of a separate "high school of art" shows a gratifying appreciation of real values. Whether or not awakening interest in music and the fine arts and their cultivation are to be best advanced by a separate school, the fact of importance is that the Mayor has given "the finer things" recognition even in these days when "practical" things are so demanding.

JOHNNY M'HUGH, the benevolent gunman, was oiling up a brace of pistols yesterday. The lean Mr. McHugh, who has fired several million shots amid great throngs without ever hitting anybody, is ready to give another peerless pistol-shooting exhibition at the Millrose games at the Garden this evening.
Leading most of the way, the New York A.C. hockey team upset Lake Placid, 5 to 3, at the Bronx Coliseum last night. A crowd of more than 1,500 saw the hard-fought battle.

When the fishing season opens this Spring the New York Conservation Department will have planted in the State's thousands of streams and lakes upward of half a billion new fish, according to an estimate just made by Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne.

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- It is suggested in financial quarters now that England herself may tentatively return to the gold standard in about two months as her next move to meet the situation created by America's resumption of that standard.
News of the sudden resignation of Howard G. Cann as head football coach at New York University was the main topic of conversation wherever groups of students, alumni or faculty gathered yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Seeking a compromise of the American and Philippine viewpoints on Philippine independence, President Roosevelt today conferred with Senator Manuel L. Quezon and later it was learned the President was considering the advisability of modifications in the Hawes-Cutting Law of last year -- extension of which has been projected.

William Grinnell, 11 years old, and his sister, Alice, 8, confessed to detectives yesterday that they had started the fire in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Rosary, 135 Chauncey Street, Brooklyn, on Wednesday, which resulted in damage estimated at $10,000.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- Vera Borea's Summer style show launches the doll silhouette with a cloche skirt stiffened by trousercuff hems or fabric side wings. Her new necklines are both high and wide with standing folded pieces open and standing high.

Emma Goldman, the anarchist, came back to New York yesterday, her first visit since her deportation in 1919. Plump, mild-mannered and speaking with a slightly "English" accent, she received a throng of reporters in a private dining room at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- In reply to questions concerning the meaning of the Executive order governing elections of spokesmen for collective bargaining, issued yesterday by President Roosevelt, General Johnson said today that the effect was to hold that two unions in the same shop or unit of a plant were not practical.

A service of thanksgiving opening the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless will be held tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 2. -- Wiffy Cox held his slim lead in the Agua Caliente open by shooting a par 71 today for a fifty-four-hole total of 210, but the golfing pack was on his heels, and the Brooklyn professional's position was none too secure.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2. -- The Maryland Kennel Club celebrated its coming of age today, opening its twenty-first annual show with 614 dogs on the benches and an entry of 924. This is a large increase over last year and closely approached the best figures of the boom year.
BOSTON, Feb. 2. -- Four bandits killed a policeman and shot down three other men this morning as they robbed the Needham Trust Company of $13,900.

Loans on securities made to members of the New York Stock Exchange and carried in New York increased $57,941,983 in January to $903,074,507, according to a compilation made by the Exchange. At the end of December loans were $845,132,524, while, at the close of January, last year, they were $359,341,058.

The Street rate for call loans hardened in the late trading to 1 per cent, after going at 3/4 earlier. Stock Exchange quotations remained at 1 per cent. Time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were all quiet and unchanged in quotation.

By the test of international reputation Mlle. LOUISE WEISS would be the leading woman editor of the day. Sixteen years ago she founded the weekly publication L'Europe Nouvelle to expound the doctrine of a new international order in place of the system that produced the World War and crashed into ruins.

Definite evidence proving that criminal acts were committed in the Welfare Island Penitentiary has been uncovered in the last few days, David Marcus, Deputy Correction Commissioner, announced yesterday. Mr. Marcus would not amplify this statement other than to say that in many incidences the cases against guilty individuals had not been completed.

Sherman Phelps Ketchum, 34 years old, son-in-law of Edward Mortimer Allen, president of the National Surety Company, was seriously injured early yesterday morning when he plunged five stories from his apartment at 28 East Tenth Street.

The undefeated Thomas Jefferson High School quintet conquered Samuel J. Tilden High, 33 to 29, in the Jefferson gymnasium in one of the six Brooklyn division P.S.A.L. basketball games played yesterday.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Judicial liquidation of what Japan calls the "May 15th incident," a terroristic attempt in 1932 to overthrow the civilian government, was completed in Tokyo District Court today.
W.R. Beck, Ellery A. Bogert and Dudley Guillaudeu have joined the investment firm of Robert Josephson Co.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- According to the best informed opinion at the Capitol, another week and possibly more will elapse before a bill to help the LaGuardia administration restore the credit of New York City is taken up again for final action in either the Senate or the Assembly.

A slightly slower pace developed in retail trade during the week in comparison with the week preceding, retail executives here reported yesterday. Volume, however, picked up yesterday and a brisk turnover is expected today, particularly in homefurnishings lines.

Giulio Gatti-Casazza, in his twenty-sixth year as director of the Metropolitan Opera, observed his sixty-fifth birthday yesterday. Sitting in the office which he has occupied since May, 1908, when he arrived to take over the general managership, he discussed the future of opera and public taste in this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- President Roosevelt decried politics in the recovery program in a speech to State directors of the National Emergency Council; set forth a plan to form an export bank with RFC funds; announced a preliminary agreement on sugar policy and reconsidered his earlier decision to wind up the CWA on May 1.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 2. -- The approaching 1934 baseball season finds the St. Louis Cardinal management watching its farm hands -- rookies to you -- with the same careful attention that through the years spells winning teams and financial gain.

Ratification of the proposed child labor amendment to the Federal Constitution would be a threat to the American form of government, and to the American home, the family, the school and the church, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said in a radio address last night.

Annulment of the twenty-five-year franchises voted by the Board of Estimate on Dec. 22 last to the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, Madison Avenue Coach Company, New York City Omnibus Corporation and Comprehensive Omnibus Corporation is demanded by the city in an answer and counterclaim about to be filed in the Supreme Court.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

In a highly interesting twelve-round battle, the finish of which saw one decision rendered, then reversed, Tony Canzoneri, former lightweight champion, defeated Cleto Locatelli of Italy last night in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The sugar problem approached a solution tonight as preliminary agreements on a policy were reached at a White House conference among President Roosevelt and administration officials.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 2. -- The arson trial of Milton J. Gordon, Croton-on-Hudson attorney, for allegedly setting fire to the Hessian Hills Country Club of which he was president in 1930, grew more complicated today when witnesses for the defense contradicted the testimony of the State's star witnesses and involved a new figure in the situation.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- Kenneth Collins, advertising executive of Gimbel Brothers store in New York City, said tonight that "the greatest potential force for the political, economic and social welfare of the nation is not in editorial columns of newspapers, but in the unused advertising space."

The executors and trustees of the Wendel estate intend to fight any attempt by the charitable institutions that are the chief legatees of the estate to establish a foundation for control of its vast real estate holdings.

By comparison with the day before, yesterday's market was tame and unexciting, but brokers insisted that the public was still keenly interested and that the market was merely resting after its exertions. That is always a comforting belief after speculative excitement has died down.
PENNS GROVE, N.J., Feb. 2. -- Four bandits held up two messengers of the Penns Grove National Bank and Trust Company here today and escaped with $130,000 in cash.

Among the passengers sailing for Plymouth and Havre on the French liner Ile de France today will be Lord Decies, Colonel Anthony J. Drexel, Sir Alfred Bishop Morine, Mme. Emma Eames, Jascha Helfetz, Harriet Cohen. Cole Porter, Laura La Plante, Lady Daphne Finch-Hatton, Mrs. William Boyce Thompson and the following:

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2. -- Maryland race track operators, with the approval of the State Racing Commission today increased the track "take" on pari-mutuel or totalisator tickets from 5 per cent, with "breakage" to the dime, to 7 per cent, with "breakage" to the nickel.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2 (AP). -- An executive order signed by Governor O.K. Allen, coupled with a 54-year-old statute, today gave Senator Huey P. Long and the State Attorney General's office the right to conduct an investigation into New Orleans City Hall, whose incumbent old regulars defeated the Long forces in a city primary ten days ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Early discussions with Great Britain which are expected to lead to a tie-up of the dollar and pound sterling, with the stabilization funds of the two nations used chiefly to promote exchange stability over a test period, were indicated authoritatively today. Official conversations have not been started, but the belief is that they will begin as soon as the first effects of devaluation of the dollar are assessed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Representative McReynolds of Tennessee, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today that foreign service employes in countries where depreciated currency had caused hardships would not be compelled to suffer much longer.

George Grantham, one of the few new cogs Manager Bill Terry has decided to add to the Giant machine that captured the world's baseball championship last season, yesterday became the twenty-third member of the 1934 east to fall in line.

The third and final Junior Assembly for this season was held last night in the Ritz-Carlton amid profusion of yellow Spring flowers. The guests, on arriving at the hotel passed through a lane of forsythia, daffodils and pussy willows in tall golden standards, placed at intervals in the foyer to the ballroom, where there also were quantities of these early Spring blossoms.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Repudiation by Commander Hayes of the authorship of an article entitled "My Proposal to Roosevelt," published in the March issue of Real America under a by-line reading "By the National Commander of the American Legion, Edward A. Hayes," today led to an exchange of telegrams between Mr. Hayes and J.M. Lansinger, publisher of the magazine.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad ordered fifteen freight locomotives yesterday from the American Locomotive Company, or more than had been built for all railroads in 1932 and 1933. Previously this company ordered five switching engines and twenty large tenders from the Lima Locomotive Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The government on Jan. 31 ended the seventh month of the fiscal year 1934 with a public debt of $25,068,052,506 and a deficit of $1,922,598,173, Treasury figures showed today.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2. -- Miss Aileen Pendergast's Running Heel led home five other 3-year-olds in the featured six-furlong Cameron Purse at the Fair Grounds today, but the Bud Lerner colt was extended to his utmost to win.

IRELAND shook hands with the devil, some of the Irish might tell you, from 1918 through the battle of Rochestown in 1922. The English could say the same, and with about as much truth, for there were cracked fingers on both sides. Along with the many funerals, the lorry-load or more of national martyrs, and the republic, some fine bits of writing came out of it all.
Several flats and business buildings were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Thirty changes in flag commands at sea and on shore will be made immediately after the fleet review off New York by President Roosevelt at the end of May. In announcing them today Colonel Henry L. Roosevelt, Acting Secretary of the Navy, explained that they are "in accordance with the policy of rotating commands in the fleet annually and are normally announced at this time of the year."

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Profit-taking appeared again today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade and, despite unfavorable crop comments from the Southwest, support was slow in developing until the May delivery had declined to around 91 cents a bushel.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The government ended its round-up today of the six Western outlaws who kidnapped the Denver broker, Charles Boettcher 2d, on Feb. 12, 1933, and hid him on a South Dakota ranch until his $60,000 ransom was in their wallets.

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- Excited dealings in gold-mining shares again absorbed attention on the Stock Exchange today and almost every other department suffered from lack of interest. A fair amount of business was done in British Government funds, but industrial issues were quiet and neglected.

The twenty-cent charge now registered on taxicab meters for the first quarter mile probably will remain after the dispute over the five-cent tax is settled, it was brought out yesterday in connection with the taxicab strike.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 2. -- The grand jury investigation into gambling conditions in this county resulted today in indictments against the four highest ranking members of the Passaic Police Department. All were accused of misfeasance in office in connection with the alleged operation of slot machines, lotteries and other forms of gambling.

The Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington, Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, is to be a daytime shelter and recreation centre for homeless and unemployed men, beginning at 8 A.M. tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

The rules committee of the American Football Coaches Association, meeting today of the New York Athletic Club under the chairmanship of Lou Little of Columbia, is expected to approve only one of the five major changes up for consideration in the intercollegiate gridiron code.

Controller W. Arthur Cunningham made public yesterday a report showing the cash receipts and cash expenditures of New York City each year for the last eight years and the debt and budget totals, tax levies and rates, and assessed valuations for each year.

Year after year the New York Crime Commission and the crime commissions of a number of other States have dwelt upon the prevalence of perjury. The willful giving of false witness is a common practice, according to the courts, the bar, the police and independent citizens. It is rarely punished.

President Roosevelt's executive order governing elections of spokesmen for collective bargaining, issued Thursday, drew exceptions yesterday from the steel industry. In a statement issued here by executives of all the leading steel companies, following a meeting at the offices of the American Iron and Steel Institute, the employers say:

It is no accident that Professor JOLIOT and his wife, the daughter of Mme. CURIE, should have selected boron for bombardment by helium nuclei or alpha particles. That element is readily disruptible, and therefore a favorite target of the atomic bombardiers. In the past, which means the last five years, experimenters saw only protons or hydrogen nuclei splash on a scintilating screen when a stream of alpha particles was turned on boron.
BERLIN, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Criticism of General Sessions Judge Joseph E. Corrigan was made yesterday by the Appellate Division in reversing the conviction of William Thomas, a truck driver of 601 West 185th Street. Thomas was sentenced to serve seven to fourteen years in prison for second-degree manslaughter as a result of the death of his wife, Jean Jones Thomas, on Jan. 1, 1932.

VIENNA, Feb. 2. -- Following is the text of the telegram the Austrian Foreign Office sent to Dr. Stefan Tauschitz, the Austrian Minister in Berlin, on Jan. 16, instructing him to present a protest against German Nazi interference in Austrian affairs to the German Foreign Office:

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The Superintendent of Banks has surrendered possession of the Huguenot Trust Company of New Rochelle, it was announced today in the department's bulletin. This is for the purpose of permitting resumption of business by the company in compliance with the banking law and on conditions of the offer of the directors contained in the certification filed in the Westchester County clerk's office.

Today is the festival of St. BLASIUS, kept by many. So popular was this saint in England in the thirteenth century that all work was forbidden on his day by order of Council. Altars still stand dedicated to him. Why he was popular is not far to seek, for "his "aid was held sovereign against throat "and lung diseases."
The speech of Ogden Mills at Topeka shows that light is breaking in the darkest of all regions (not excepting "money"), the United States tariff.

W. Palmer Dixon and Herbert N. Rawlins Jr., the national amateur racquets doubles champions, started out in defense of their title at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday and passed from the tournament in their first match.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- The gold rush toward America begins tomorrow when the Berengaria and the Bremen leave Havre. Space on the Bremen has been booked for 48,000,000 francs and on the Berengaria for 15,000,000, while more can be expected tomorrow at Havre and when the ships touch England.

Officials of the Metal Trades Council of the New York Navy Yard, in a telegram sent to Secretary of the Navy Swanson yesterday, charged discrimination in the construction allotments of the seven Coast Guard cutters made by the Navy Department last week.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2. -- Joseph Stalin Premier Molotoff, other Soviet leaders and soldiers who completely filled Red Square took part this afternoon in the simple but poignant ceremony of immuring in the Kremlin wall the ashes of the three stratosphere balloon victims.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- President Roosevelt made known today his plans for the formation of a bank, with funds to be supplied by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, for the financing in part of exports, particularly those destined for the Soviet Union.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 2. -- Abolition of city and police courts, a curtailment of the jurisdiction of justices of the peace and the creation of a circuit court to take over the duties of all was recommended tonight in a report of a special committee to the Westchester Bar Association.

WARSAW, Feb. 2. -- Relieved that Poland was chosen by the British Government to be among the seven countries which received the British disarmament memorandum, Poles are pleased also that the memorandum contains a detailed project for a future convention.
PARIS, Feb. 2. -- Paris is undergoing a taxicab strike, which today took a turn toward violence that promises to add another element of disorder to the already unsettled conditions in France.

A recent jump in the sales of "100,000,000 Guinea Pigs: Dangers in Everyday Foods, Drugs and Cosmetics," by Arthur Kallet and F.J. Schlink, is reported by Vanguard, the publishers. The spurt is supposed to be due to widespread discussion of the so-called "Tugwell Bill," and has sent this book, one of the ten best sellers of 1933, into its twentieth large printing.

Borrowers paid $103,901 interest in January on loans from the Railroad Credit Corporation and reduced their loans by $144,068, according to E.G. Buckland, president. Added to the corporation's free balance at the end of the year, the payments enabled the corporation to distribute a 1 per cent dividend amounting to $717,565 to contributing carriers.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed admission of Thomas B. Berentsen to the firm of Ingalls Snyder and the proposed retirement of John T. Collins Jr. on Feb. 15 from Samuel McCreery Co.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2. -- The Walters Art Gallery, which, with its vast collection of works of art, was bequeathed to the city of Baltimore by the late Henry Walters, opened its doors to the public today. The gallery had been closed since Mr. Walters' death in 1931.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Business has slumped again in the wool trade this past week. Demand -- such as it is -- favors the fine and fine medium territory, fair combing wools and the medium bright fleeces for the knitting trade.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday in a 10-point range under a light volume of business and closed at gains of 3 to 8 points.

A few minutes before the stroke of noon yesterday, a solemn delegation might have been observed standing ankle-deep in the snow that blanketed the ostrich corral at the Bronx Zoo. Though the dazzling sunlight had reduced most of the watchers to a state of incipient snow-blindness, not one budged.

As the police continued a vigorous drive against the policy racket throughout the city yesterday, detectives made a raid on the lower East Side in the headquarters of a policy gang at 68 Oliver Street, and arrested four men.

Mayor LAGUARDIA'S fight for his Economy Bill was half won before he began it Thursday evening. All the indications from Albany are that the Legislature will grant him substantially what he asks. Already compromise bills are being drafted. Postmaster General FARLEY has virtually thrown the influence of the Washington Administration on the side of the Mayor, and Governor LEHMAN stands firmly committed to the main features of his bill.

The Bayside Tennis Club team maintained its hold on first place in the Class B division of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League by scoring a 5-0 victory yesterday over the Princeton Club squad. The match, played on the Princeton Club courts, was featured by the powerful all-around playing of the victors.

George H. Combs Jr. resigned yesterday as general counsel to the Triborough Bridge Authority within twenty-four hours of the retirement of Joseph Johnson, Tammany strategist, from the post of general manager.
New York was virtually a taxi-less city yesterday, following an unexpected walk-out of drivers.

Elimination of what was characterized as a political clique of physicians holding a monopoly in the treatment of workmen's compensation cases under the Civil Works Administration was announced yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, depputy CWA administrator in charge of the compensation division.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- The Boerse was firm today and the turnover expanded. Gains between 2 and 3 points were frequent. Heavy industrials led the upturn, followed by motors and electricals. Machineries and metals slowed their recent upward trend.

The high level at which retail distribution has been holding since the first of the year was lifted during the current week by the strong stimulus to demand provided by the freezing temperatures in most sections of the country, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
LONDON, Feb. 2. -- A warning against "arbitrary interference" by governments in industry was expressed today by J. Beaumont Pease, chairman of the Lloyds Bank, in his annual address to shareholders.

The National Bridge Association, sponsor of the third annual World Bridge Olympic, made public yesterday the pars on the sixteen hands played simultaneously by 150,000 contract bridge enthusiasts, here and abroad, on Thursday night. The winners will not be known for about two months.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 2. -- Alvanley Johnston, former president of the Engineers National Bank, forerunner of the Standard Trust Bank, admitted on the witness stand today that he used the bank's funds for stock-market speculation. His operations resulted in a loss of $36,000 to Standard depositors, he said.

John Charles Thomas, the American baritone, became a member of the Metropolitan Opera Company yesterday afternoon in excellent standing. He is a distinguished addition. His singing left no doubt of this, and the capacity audience, which brought the Vassar College Scholarship Fund a profit of $4,500, proved by its cheers and applause that it held him in high esteem.

Opposition to the Tug-well-Copeland bill, or similar legislation, which tends to limit the manufacture and sale of food, drugs and cosmetics by "bureaucratic control'' was expressed yesterday in a report by a newly formed committee representing leading manufacturers of these and similar products.

Reorganization of the Park Department at an annual saving of more than $49,000 in salaries was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate, which asked the Board of Aldermen by resolution to ratify the new plan.
This is what Brand Whitlock said of the telephone almost twenty years ago:

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- The fifteen nations remaining in the list of challengers for the Davis Cup after last Summer's preliminary rounds were paired today for the international tennis competition from which will come the team to challenge England for the trophy.

THE TIMES published a letter from J. Pryse Goodwin calling attention to the congestion at Grand Central Station on the Lexington Avenue line of the Interborough and offering several suggestions for improving conditions.

At a hearing on a site for Brooklyn College before the Board of Estimate yesterday Mayor LaGuardia served notice on Dr. Arthur M. Howe, a member of the Board of Higher Education, that he was "not going to take any resistance" from the board while he was Mayor.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2. -- J.E. Smallman's Feudal Lord scored a driving half-length victory in the featured Coral Gables Purse at Hialeah Park today, with G.W. Ogle's Mountain Elk second. The Jersey Stable's Character was a badly outrun third finishing eight lengths behind Mountain Elk.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- A campaign for reduction of interest rates on Germany's foreign bonds has been launched in the German press. It came on the heels of the new moratorium agreement reached Wednesday between Germany and her creditors, according to which Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, increased German interest payments from 65 to 76.9 per cent of the contractual amount.

George M. Cohan's 1905 libel on the suave city-State of New Rochelle came back to its paternal Broadway for a visit yesterday afternoon. The temporal occasion was the revival, by members of the Professional Children's School, of "Forty-five Minutes From Broadway."

The Westchester County Commission on Government held its organization meeting yesterday at the Uptown Club, 60 East Forty-second Street. Carl H. Pforzheimer of Purchase was elected chairman, Colonel John Motley Morehead of Rye, former Minister to Sweden, vice chairman and Mrs. W.H. Lough, secretary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Subscriptions to the Treasury's $500,000,000 offering of 2 1/2 per cent notes, dated Jan. 29 and maturing March 15, 1935, amounted to $3,424,212,200, according to final figures received from the Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- President Roosevelt has reconsidered his decision to wind up the Civil Works Administration by May 1, and is now said to have an "open mind" on the proposal to continue this phase of relief work as long as it appears necessary and to the extent needed.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- The jury debating the fate of Roger Touhy and two companions, charged with the kidnapping for ransom of John Factor, reported at 5:30 P.M. today that its members were hopelessly deadlocked and Judge Michael Feinberg, twenty-five minutes later, dismissed the twelve men.

Speculative interests lost some of their enthusiasm yesterday, as evidenced by the less active trading in stocks and commodities and by the erratic price movements in these markets. Bonds were exceptionally strong. Efforts to force the dollar nearer to its new parity in the international market were unsuccessful and all foreign currencies declined.

A trend to lower prices prevailed yesterday in the local commodity markets and the volume of trading declined. The raw sugar futures market was an exception both as to trend and volume. Cash prices were mixed.

Following the lead of Mayor LaGuardia, the Board of Estimate refused yesterday to appropriate $76,000 to pay the city's share of salaries and administrative expenses of the Transit Commission for February. Conceding that payment by the city was mandatory under the State law, Mayor LaGuardia indicated that he wished to teach an object lesson to those who are opposing enactment of his economy bill at Albany.

VIENNA, Feb. 2. -- The press of Vienna was unanimous today in treating as entirely unsatisfactory Germany's answer to the Austrian note charging German interference in Austria's affairs. Most of the newspapers declare that Austria must now carry out her threat to take the matter before the League of Nations.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 2. -- Four armed robbers held up the Union Trust Company branch bank today and escaped with about $12,000.

Rimsky-Korsakoff's delightful, satirical opera, "Le Coq d'Or," was presented as the second production of the Russian opera season of the Art of Musical Russia, Inc., at the Casino Theatre. The company deserves credit for reviving this opera; its amusing tale and delectable, colorful music make it one of those enjoyable works that should not be neglected.

HAVANA, Feb. 2. -- The Employes' Power and Gas Union at a mass meeting tonight voted to reject President Mendieta's formula for returning to the Compania Cubana de Electricidad its properties. Although the workers' delegation up to a late hour tonight had not formally advised the Chief Executive of the resolution, the President upon receiving information of the action, stated to foreign correspondents:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Another blow was struck at price fixing in NRA codes today when the Senate adopted a resolution sponsored by Senator Borah calling upon the Federal Trade Commission to investigate, study and report on price fixing under the steel code and on the increased price of gasoline.
A letter from Bernhard Ostrolenk raises questions relative to the program of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration for emergency nursery schools that should be answered.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- Without pomp or ceremony the first regular transatlantic airline in history will come into being tomorrow when the German Lufthansa begins its all-air mail service between Germany and South America.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP). -- A "reaffirmation of marriage" tonight supplied all the romantic ceremony which the wedding of the former Verna True Neidig and Reinald Werrenrath, baritone, six years ago lacked.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- William P. MacCracken Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce in charge of Aeronautics under President Hoover, and later Washington representative of many air lines, was arrested late today by order of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Changed to suit the administration's views, the Johnson bill barring future security flotations here by nations which are in default to this government on debts was again passed in the Senate today with virtually no debate.
Tenement houses formed the bulk of properties offered at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Fourteen Manhattan and Bronx parcels were put up for bidding, and all were bought in by the plaintiffs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Part-time jobs for 100,000 needy college students who otherwise would be unable to enter or complete the second semester of the present year will be financed by the Federal Emergency Relief Administration under a plan made public today by Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator.

Edward A. Hayes, National Commander of the American Legion, telegraphed THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that an article in the magazine Real America under his signature, excerpts from which appeared in THE TIMES yesterday under a Chicago date line, was not only unauthorized but had been specifically disapproved by him.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- Without changing it in the slightest, the Republican Assembly advanced to the order of final passage today Governor Lehman's main Executive Budget Bill, calling for expenditures of $249,948,431.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- The German Government, obviously chagrined at the show of opposition offered byI the Dollfuss government, as indicated by the Austrian Cabinet's communique on the German reply to its protest, unexpectedly made public tonight a summary of the text of the reply.
